DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 1, or the 18th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with help from the West.
1916: Peking University Professor Hu Shih's proposal that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style wins quick acceptance.
1918: T.E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia, " and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government cracks down on Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up a branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: Gen. Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Beijing with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a U.S. government agency that conducts and coordinates research on flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency headquartered in Washington, D.C.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The annual three-day meeting of the Sino-U.S. Cooperation Science Program is held in Taipei.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali had recaptured the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier had beaten Ali in 1971.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung leaves for Lesotho to attend a ceremony marking the kingdom's independence.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 centimeters tall, dies. 1999: Taiwan announces the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in last-ditch efforts to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.
2000: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew says he is "less pessimistic" about cross-strait ties than he had been before his recent visit to Taiwan.
2001: A six-day conference of Asian Aborigines sponsored jointly by the Asian Indigenous People's Pact (AIPP) and Taiwan Aborigines concludes in Taitung, eastern Taiwan with a statement supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations Indigenous People's Workshop.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) approves the opening of electronic commerce insurance services for domestic insurance companies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: SETTLEMENT OF TAIWAN ISSUE MUST BE ACCEPTABLE TO BOTH SIDES: POWELL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell said Thursday that the ultimate settlement of the Taiwan issue has to be acceptable to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Powell made the comments while responding to media questions at a joint press conference held after he had a working lunch with mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing, who was recently in New York to deliver a speech at the 59th General Assembly of the United Nations.

"We strongly support our 'one China' policy, which has stood the test of time, " Powell said, adding that the policy "has benefited the people in Taiwan, the people in the mainland, the international community and certainly the United States."
He also said that the United States does not support Taiwan independence as this would be inconsistent with its obligations and commitments to its "one China" policy.
Pointing out that his meeting with Foreign Minister Li was his fourth this year, Powell said that as always, they talked about the Taiwan issue, which is of uppermost concern to Beijing.

"I once again reaffirmed our 'one China' policy and the three comuniques and also noted our obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act and reaffirmed what President Bush has said a number of times, that we do not support any movement toward independence on the part of Taiwan," he said.

For his part, Li said that Beijing is ready to do its utmost to realize a peaceful solution to the Taiwan question. However, he strongly reiterated China's opposition to Taiwan independence, saying that "we will never, ever allow anyone to use any means to separate Taiwan from China."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR CALM OVER RED FIRE ANT PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Friday called for calm among the public in the face of the spread of the imported red fire ant from Taiwan's farmlands to urban areas.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Yu said that the government has set up a red fire ant prevention center to systematically battle the serious new pest problem. The red fire ant was first detected in Taiwan in September of last year in the southern county of Chiayi and in the northern county of Taoyuan.

Yu urged the people not to panic and the media to refrain from sensationalizing related reports. He said the media should instead inform the public about the problem and how to counter it, especially how to protect children.

The red fire ant, which is native to southern Brazil, was detected in Taipei City for the first time four days ago. Environmental protection and public health officials said they have no clues about when and how the red fire ant spread to Taiwan's capital city.

Officials from the Council of Agriculture's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine said they believe that the red fire ant -- which becomes aggressive when its anthills are disturbed -- was probably brought into Taipei City via potted plants or landscaping sod.

The red fire ant was first spotted in Taipei City on a traffic island on Chunghua Road, where about 16 anthills of the dangerous pest were found Tuesday. Although environmental protection personnel from Taipei City Government quickly applied pesticide to the area, 20 new anthills up to 3 centimeters high were discovered Thursday. It is estimated that close to a hectare of lawn on the traffic island has been occupied by the ants.

Farmers consider the insect a nuisance because of its painful sting. Although the ants do not endanger crops, their bite is annoying, and for a small number of people who are allergic to the ants, a single bite could be fatal.
The council called a meeting Thursday to build an islandwide monitoring, information and prevention system to battle the pest.
Meanwhile, the Environmental Protection Administration has said that it will host seminars around the island to help local environmental officials to check the spread of the pesky insect.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA RESEARCHER TO BE NEW MAC VICE CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has decided to name Huang Wei-feng, a scholar versed in European affairs, as its third vice chairman, a senior official said Friday.
"Huang, an associate researcher at Academia Sinica's European and American Studies, is scheduled to assume the MAC post next week, " said Chiu Tai-san, the MAC's first vice chairman.
The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, hopes Huang can help make its policy formulation more comprehensive and circumspect, Chiu said.

Noting that Taiwan-mainland China relations are not just an issue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait but also an issue of international concern, Chiu said the MAC must care about the views of major countries around the world, including the 25-state European Union.
"Huang's European academic background will contribute to our policy planning work," Chiu added.

Huang, 40, has a master's degree from the prestigious Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a doctoral degree in political science from Oxford University. He is noted for his research in contemporary Western political theories, American and British politics, European Union politics, election strategies, and political sociology.

Huang, a son of former Central Election Commission Chairman Huang Shih-cheng, is expected to play an active role in mainland policy planning and communications with the international community regarding Taiwan's stance and basic policies on cross-strait relations.

Early this year, Huang joined a Taiwan delegation to brief E.U. countries that President Chen Shui-bian's plan to hold a "defensive referendum" along with the March 20 presidential election had nothing to do with changing Taiwan's status quo.
Huang lost a bid for a legislative seat in a Changhua County constituency in 1998. At that time, he was only 33 years old. Huang's father once served as Changhua County magistrate for two terms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, OHIO TO BOLSTER BIOTECH COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Ohio Governor Bob Taft is currently leading a large delegation from the U.S. state to promote bilateral exchanges in Taiwan, particularly in research, development and commercialization of bioscience.
Taft has led a multi-dimensional effort to make bioscience a pillar in the economic future of Ohio, which is one the strongholds of bioscience and biotechnology in the United States.

Members of Taft's entourage took part in a forum being sponsored by Taiwan's Development Center for Biotechnology (DCB) Friday on Ohio's international efforts to promote the research and development cooperation as well as commercialization of the state's bioscience and technology.

The members include executives from contract research organization big names such as Battelle Memorial Institute; Omeris Bioscience; Diagnostic Hybrids, Inc.; and Ohio University's Edison BioTechnology Center.

Huang Jui-lien, president of the non-profit Development Center for Biotechnology, and John Lewis, director of Omeris' International Business Development department, are scheduled to sign a letter of intent later Friday to bolster R&D as well as commercialization of bioscience and technology between Taiwan and the state of Ohio.

The two sides will vow to increase bilateral cooperation in the fields of bioenergy, pharmaceuticals, life sciences, virus tests, molecular biology, commercialization of R& D results, and fund raising techniques, DCB officials said.

It is hoped that the DCB-Ohio cooperation -- featuring R&D cooperation, product development, clinical applications and joint-venture operations -- will help promote Ohio-originating bioscience products, technologies and services to the vast Asian market using Taiwan as a gateway.

Taft and the Ohio mission arrived in Taiwan Thursday for a three-day trade-promotion trip. The mission -- made up of about 50 representatives from more than 30 companies and organizations from Ohio -- is visiting mainly to identify local companies interested in investing in the state and to promote the state's exports to Taiwan.

Taiwan is one of Ohio's top-20 export markets, and advanced technology collaboration between the two sides has been growing in recent years. In 2003, Ohio's exports to Taiwan totaled some US$201.48 million.

Taft met with Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou at Taipei City Hall Thursday evening. He is scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office later Friday afternoon. Taft and his group are set to depart Taiwan Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO DISCUSS TWO-WAY CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) won't rule out the possibility of two-way cross-strait charter flight services for the 2005 Chinese New Year holiday, but Beijing must send an envoy so that the two sides can discuss related matters as soon as possible, an MAC spokesman said Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said that charter flight services were launched two years ago on a trial basis during the holiday period for the convenience of Taiwan businesspeople operating in mainland China, but only Taiwan carriers were allowed to operate via a third location, such as Macau or Hong Kong.

Noting that mainland China has requested the mainland Chinese carriers be allowed to join the cross-strait charter flights and on a non-stop basis during the holiday period, Chiu said the MAC doesn't rule out the possibility of such flights, but added that the two sides must first sit down at the negotiating table to discuss related matters.
Two-way cross-strait charter flights were not opened during the 2004 Chinese Lunar New Year holiday season due to Beijing's refusal to engage in bilateral consultations.
Cross-strait charter flight services during the Chinese New Year holiday period are seen as important as there are some 500,000 to one million Taiwanese businesspeople operating in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN DO NOT VIOLATE "ONE CHINA" POLICY: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The United States' policy of selling weapons to Taiwan has always been based on the island's self-defense needs and have not violated Washington's "one-China" policy, U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell said Thursday.

Powell made the remarks in response to media questions at a joint press conference held after he had a working lunch with mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing, who visited New York to deliver a speech at the 59th General Assembly of the United Nations.
Li expressed at the conference the mainland's firm opposition to the sale of arms by any foreign country to Taiwan, Powell defended the U.S. policy of continuing to sell weapons to the island.

Li said that Beijing does not think such sales are in the interests of its "peaceful efforts" to resolve the so-called "Taiwan question, " nor do they serve the interests of peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and the interests of those countries who are prepared to sell weapons to the country.

Powell said he told Li that "our obligations under our domestic law with respect to the Taiwan Relations Act in our judgment are not in any way inconsistent with our one China policy and our obligations under that one China policy and the three communiques."

"We always measure what is sold to Taiwan on the basis of what they need for their self-defense, and I think our policy has served both nations, the United States and China, very, very well -- and Taiwan very, very well -- over the course of a number of years, " he said.

Taiwan and U.S. are discussing arms sale plans and Taiwan's Cabinet has proposed a special budget of NT$610.8 billion over 15 years to purchase arms, including eight diesel-electric submarines, six sets of Patriot-III anti- missile systems and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIREARM AMNESTY DRIVE FRUITFUL: NPA

TEXT.P: A nationwide campaign encouraging Taiwan people to turn in illegal firearms and ammunition concluded fruitfully Thursday with 428 citizens voluntarily surrendering weapons, police reported Friday.

National Police Administration (NPA) officials said that over the past three months, a total of 428 people voluntarily approached the police, investigators, military police or coastguard officials to surrender their illegal weapons, including 428 firearms and more than 9,000 rounds of ammunition.
The firearms included two assault rifles, 43 pistols or revolvers, 155 modified guns, 121 home-made guns and 16 air pistols, NPA officials said.
The weapons also included 77 controlled sabers, knives and swords, as well as 108 firearm components and parts.

During the same July 1 - Sept. 30 period, the law enforcement authorities also raided organized crime rings or individuals and seized 226 rifles and pistols, 812 modified guns and some 16,000 rounds of ammunition, NPA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSETS OUTPACE NATIONAL DEBTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that Taiwan's national assets still outpace its debts by more than NT$10 trillion.
Yu made the remarks to refute an independent lawmaker's claim that Taiwan's national debts are approaching NT$12 trillion, which translates into a debt of NT$520,000 for each Taiwan citizen.

Legislator Su Ying-guei claimed at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has not honored its promise to balance the central government's budget and has even widened the public debt in the past few years.

This year alone, Su said, the DPP administration has requested a total special budget of more than NT$1.1 trillion to finance its new "Ten Major Construction Projects" and arms procurement projects. "The figure surpasses the accumulated special budget earmarked in the past seven years," he claimed.

Su said the central government's debts stood at NT$2.6 trillion in 2000 when the DPP came to power. The debt surged to NT$3.3 trillion in 2003 and will break the NT$3.9 trillion mark this year, Su said, adding that if potential national debts are included, the aggregated national debts are approaching NT$12 trillion.

Touching on the NT$610.8 billion special budget over a 15-year period for procuring eight diesel-electric submarines, 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries from the United States, Su claimed that it would add up to a financial burden for posterity.
He recalled that President Chen Shui-bian opposed a NT$50 billion special budget proposal to purchase 150 F-16 jet fighters back in 1993, when Chen was a legislator.

"Chen's opposition indicated that using special budget to finance arms procurements is unreasonable and would 'hollow out' the government's finances and undermine the existing fiscal system," according to Su.
In response, Yu said the DPP administration had to propose a special budget plan for the arms procurement project mainly because of constraints set forth in the new Public Debts Law.

Moreover, Yu said, the government will pay the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement bill over a 15-year period. "The arrangement will enable us not to leave any debts to posterity, " he said, adding that the nation still has more than in NT$29 trillion in assets.

Yu further urged Su to take the changing times into consideration when commenting on the government's policy initiatives, pointing out that when Chen opposed a special budget to finance the F-16 procurement plan, the nation had not yet implemented a public debt law to restrict the government's floating of state bonds to finance major arms procurement or infrastructure construction projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA HOPES TO CONTROL SPREAD OF FIRE ANTS BY END OF YEAR

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) aims to control the spread of red fire ants, an alien species, by the end of the year, COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung said Friday.
Lee made the remarks when he observed ways of controlling the ants in a COA-sponsored seminar held by the Taoyuan County Farmers' Association in northern Taiwan.

Amid heightened alert in the wake of the discovery of the ants in Taipei over the past few days, Lee said Premier Yu Shyi-kun has instructed the formation of a supra-government agency team to coordinate with local governments to grapple the problem of the imported pests.
He noted that he and Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lung have reached an agreement to purchase up to 12,000 kg of related environmental and farmland pesticides.
Lee said that the COA is adopting a two-stage strategy. In the first stage, the COA aims to control the proliferation of the pests by the end of the year.

In the next stage, the COA will develop even more effective ways to kill the pests, taking reference from the approach of the United States and Australia, in the hope that they can be exterminated in two or three years.

Lee noted that since April this year, the ants have made inroads into Taiwan. Currently, Taoyuan, Taipei and Chiayi counties, as well as Taipei City, have reported the pests. No reports have come from other cities and counties.

Meanwhile, Legislator Lee Cheng-nan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said Friday that unidentified black bugs have recently plagued the farmlands of Kuangying township in Taoyuan, becoming a nagging problem for residents.
Lee said the bugs, which can inflict a painful bite, have come in great multitudes, not only invading farmland, but also infesting households.

The speed at which the bugs can consume crops is especially stunning, he went on, citing a local farmer who claimed that his more than 2,400 pings (one ping equals to about 3.3 square meters) of yams were eaten completely in about seven days.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SURGE ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Encouraged by positive reports such as the central bank's move to raise interest rates, share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange surged Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 99.66 points to close at 5,945.35.
The bourse opened at 5,869.42 and fluctuated between 5,945.35 and 5,5857.54 during trading. A total of 4.42 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$102.53 billion (US$3.02 billion).

All eight major stock categories posted gains, with both cement and textile stocks increasing the most by 3.7 percent, followed by plastic and chemical shares by 3.2 percent, paper and pulp shares by 2.4 percent, financial stocks by 2.1 percent, construction issues by 1.9 percent, and both machinery and electronics shares and foodstuff shares by 0.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 494 to 185, with 135 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAMPAIGN MISSION LOBBIES IN TAOYUAN FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: A legislative campaign mission of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party lobbied for public support Friday for the government's arms procurement plan in Taoyuan City, one of the stops of a three-day railway campaign trail.

Members of the "Gold-Medal Campaign Train" including former Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan Salt Corp. Chairman Cheng Pao-ching and Legislator Lin Cho-shui, gave away brochures entitled "Have Strength, Have Peace" to people in a busy market.

Tsai said the content of the brochures are simple and readable, to provide the public with a quick understanding of the government's NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement package from the United States.
She said beefing up the country's defense capabilities does not mean it is giving up on peace.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun said last week that Taiwan must equip itself with adequate counter-attack capabilities in order to protect itself against mainland China's military threats. The argument has been criticized by Beijing as an attempt to provoke a war.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKER OF OLYMPIC GOLD-MEDAL WINNING BIKE CITED

TEXT.P: Merida Industry Co., the maker of cutting-edge bicycles, was cited with a "Taiwan Brand Award" by the Bureau of Foreign Trade Thursday for promoting Taiwan's image in the international community by using a brand name that is backed up by quality.
Norwegian athlete Gunn-Rita Dahle rode on a made-in-Taiwan Merida bike with a magnesium frame to win a gold medal in the mountain bike event in the 2004 Athens Olympic Games.
Jose Antonio Hermida of Spain won a silver medal in the men's cross country at the Games, riding a Merida carbon fiber machine.

In addition to the Olympic contributions, Merida bikes -- made with state-of-the-art design, materials and technology -- have also been used in various international cycling races and championships, gaining prestige for Taiwan, BOFT officials said.

The Changhua-based Merida Industry Co. was the only Taiwan company commended by the Bureau of Foreign Trade Thursday and conferred with a "Taiwan Brand Award, " which recognizes special contributions to Taiwan.

In related news, several Taiwan brand names, including BenQ, Microlife and ZyXEL, were praised at the 2004 CEO International Brand Name Strategy Forum Friday as examples of names that have successfully cracked the European market with high-quality brand-name products made in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market rose Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 58 points to close at 5,947, with 33,218 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November gained 67 points to finish at 5,937, with 253 contract transactions, while December futures increased 80 points to close at 5,930, with 14 contracts traded.
March futures moved up 73 points to close at 5,898 with one contract transaction, while June futures increased 51 points to finish at 5,845, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,889 points for October, 5,870 points for November, 5,850 points for December, 5,825 points for March and 5,794 points for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
October TE futures moved up 0.5 points to close at 218.90, with 6,388 contracts changing hands, while November TE futures increased 0.4 points to finish at 218.50, with 98 contract transactions.

December futures gained 1.5 points to close at 216.90, with one contract changing hands and March TE futures dropped 1.30 points to close at 216.90, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.
October TF futures moved up 15.2 points to finish at 1005.0, with 7,259 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures increased 17.0 points to close at 1001.0, with 206 contracts traded.

December TF futures gained 23.4 points to finish at 997.0, with 11 contract transactions, while March TF futures moved up 1.0 points to close at 984.0, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN TO HIKE ELECTRICITY PRICES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun denied Friday a report that the government is planning to raise electricity prices as a result of soaring oil prices.
Yu said the report was untrue when asked about the issue by lawmakers in the Legislative Yuan.

Hsu Chang-yao, head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said the government is always very careful about its decisions to hike electricity or oil prices, but there is no such plan for the time being.

Tai Chein, director-general of the Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration, said the sharp rise of oil prices has had an impact on Taiwan's technology-based industries, especially those that rely on manufacturing.
However, the impact will be limited if electricity prices do not go up, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAPITAL RATED TOP BUS SERVICE IN TAIPEI FOR 10TH CONSECUTIVE TIME

TEXT.P: Capital Bus was rated the top bus company in Taipei Friday in terms of services and vehicle condition, according to a report by the Taipei city government.

Capital Bus received a score of 92.6 points to win the title for the 10th consecutive time in the rankings rated by the Taipei City Bureau of Transportation aimed at monitoring bus services in Taipei.

Bureau of Transportation Director Lin Chih-ying said that Capital Bus is considered by many Taipei residents as the best bus company in the city, not only because its buses are newer and cleaner, but more importantly because its drivers, who are required to wear ties and freshly ironed white shirts, do not treat the passengers rudely.

Capital Bus is also the only bus company in Taipei to require that its drivers wear small microphones on duty to announce the name of every stop along their routes, enabling passengers to know where they are.
In recent months, some Capital drivers on certain routes have also been announcing the name of every stop in English.
Drivers from Capital have registered the highest rate of enrollment in English conversation lessons that have been offered by the Taipei City Drivers' Training Center.

An official of Capital attributed the keen interest demonstrated by the company's bus drivers to several factors, including that Capital offers paid leave to those who enroll in the classes, as well as paying their tuition and providing a small allowance to give them the feeling that "they are not on their own" and have the company's support.

He added that many of the Capital drivers themselves feel that they need to hone their English conversation skills for their job, as the company operates buses on routes that include the up-scale Min Sheng Residential District in eastern Taipei where many foreigners live, as well as routes around the Ta An Forest Park and Yong Kang Street, leisure spots for many foreigners in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH-TECH PRODUCTS EXHIBITED IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: An exhibition displaying Taiwan-developed high-tech products touted as "Taiwan's first class" kicked off Friday in Taichung and is expected to run until Oct. 29.

Twenty different categories of industrial and agricultural products are on display at Wen Yin Hall, the Taichung venue of the traveling exhibition that is organized by the Presidential Office. They include 10 product categories that are ranked as the largest in the world in terms of both output value and output amount.
The world's "No.1" products include notebook computers, LCD monitors, motherboards, compact disk drives, recordable disk drives, rockfish and orchids.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu presided over a ceremony Friday to kick off the exhibition, which will tour major cities around the island.
Hu thanked the Presidential Office for organizing the exhibition because by attending the event, Taichung citizens can see the pride of Taiwan and its efforts to develop world-class products.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TAIWAN'S LOW-INCOME FAMILIES ON RISE: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan's low-income families had reached 78,000, involving 192,000 people, as of the end of June, according to the newest government statistics released Thursday.

The tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , show that the figures account for 1.1 percent of the total number of Taiwan's families and 0.85 precent of the country's overall population, respectively.

A total of 3,816 people, a decrease of 5.3 percent from the previous year's level, in the low-income families are individuals who rely solely on government subsidies as they are unable to work and have no family assets or income, according to the DGBAS tallies.

A total of 45,034 people, down by 0.9 percent from the year-earlier level, are individuals in low-income families who earn less than NT$7,750 (US$228) a month, while 143,372 people, up by 11.7 percent compared to the previous year's level, are citizens from low-income families who earn an income ranging between NT$ 7,751 and NT$13,797 per month.
DGBAS officials attributed the growth in the third group of low-income people to greater government care for the underprivileged.

In the first half of this year, the government spent NT$1.37 billion (about US$40 million) in subsidies for low-income families, as well as NT$430 million in subsidies for school tuition for children from poor families.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION PLANS VALUED AT OVER NT$100 B. CARRIED OUT

TEXT.P: Over 90 percent of the government's public construction plans valued at more than NT$100 million (US$2.94 million) had been completed as of the end of August, the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC) reported Friday.

Some 93.16 percent of the government's 225 public construction plans worth more than NT$100 million, involving a total value of NT$357.2 billion, were carried out in the first eight months of this year, a PCC spokesman said.

At the same time, personnel of relevant government agencies had inspected 351 public construction projects, up from the previous year's level of 275, an increase of 28 percent, the spokesman said, adding that the quality of the cases under construction has shown noticeable improvement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT CRITICAL TO CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian defended his administration's NT$610.8 billion arms procurement plan Friday, saying that maintaining Taiwan's defense capability is a prerequisite to safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with a U.S. academic delegation headed by Henry E. Catto, chairman of the Atlantic Council of the United States, which id dedicated to promoting the effectiveness of the U.S. foreign policy.

Noting that beefing up Taiwan's defense capabilities and maintaining a balance in military strength are crucial to keeping peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, Chen said Taiwan must purchase advanced defensive weapons to protect its national security and dignity.

"We believe maintaining our defense capabilities is the biggest support for our future negotiations with mainland China, " Chen said, adding that arms procurement has nothing to do with promoting Taiwan independence. "Beijing should not link our arms procurement plan to boosting independence because they are completely unrelated."

The president told his guests that the mainland often accuses Taiwan of provocation and alleges that every Taiwan move, ranging from arms procurement, bids for joining international organizations or activities, abbreviation of the national title to constitutional re-engineering, are actions designed to promote Taiwan independence.

"Beijing's accusations are all wrong and not true, " Chen said, adding he has on many occasions explained that his administration's constitutional re-engineering plan is aimed at creating a modern and efficient administrative system and will not touch on the sensitive sovereignty, territory and unification vs. independence issues. After more than 50 years of development, he said, Taiwan needs a new viable constitution that fits its present situation.
As to Taiwan's pursuit of "international space, " Chen said the quest reflects the Taiwan people's desire for respect in the international community.

"We cannot understand why mainland China would oppose our participation in international security dialogue and the global campaign against terrorism and the spread of contagious diseases, " Chen said, adding: "Taiwan's participation can contribute more to the common well-being of mankind and global peace."

Chen also cried foul about Beijing's criticism of his administration's decision to use "Taiwan" as the abbreviated form of the country's formal title -- the Republic of China -- asking why calling Taiwan Taiwan is a provocation.

Reaffirming that Taiwan looks forward to forging a stable relationship with the mainland for peaceful development, Chen stressed that such a relationship should be developed in line with the principles of democracy, parity and peace.

He further said Taiwan does not have any preset stance on resuming cross-strait dialogue. "While we hope mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao demonstrates a new leadership style and shows more flexibility in dealing with cross-strait relations, we will not harbor unrealistic illusions before the one-party dictatorship undergoes a fundamental change," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: APARTMENT COMPLEX DESTROYED IN 921 EARTHQUAKE REOPENS TO RESIDENTS

TEXT.P: An apartment complex in Taipei County's Hsinchuang area that was destroyed in the disastrous earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999 finally reopened to residents Friday after reconstruction.
A housewarming ceremony was held to celebrate the rebirth of the complex, which has discarded its old name of "Doctors' Home" and has been renamed "Peaceful Sail."

Li Kuo-min, head of a committee coordinating the complex's reconstruction, said the residents shared a common memory of sadness and suffering in this place, but they are now "standing up" again to welcome their new life ahead.

Li thanked the assistance of the Taipei county government, financing from the 921 reconstruction foundation, support from a group of volunteer lawyers and donations from the general public, which made the reconstruction possible.
The apartment complex was originally comprised of 12 stories with 137 housing units. The earthquake left 45 residents dead, 28 injured and another 136 homeless.
The reconstructed complex consists of two blocks, each with 12 stories above ground and two basement floors. It has a total of 94 housing units.
The case marks the first collective lawsuit by consumers in Taiwan and a settlement was reached between the residents and the landowner, construction company, contractor and architect.
More than 2,000 were killed and over 8,000 injured islandwide in the earthquake that measured 7.3 on the Richter scale and was centered in central Taiwan's Nantou County.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK TO HOLD CROSS-STRAIT PEACE AND DEVELOPMENT SEMINAR

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) will sponsor a cross-Taiwan Strait peace and development seminar for businessmen, the organizers said Friday.

Officials from the private think tank said that to promote cross-strait peace and development and to induce businesses to pay attention to the government's advocacy of establishing a " peace and stability framework" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, they decided to hold the seminar that will take place Monday.
It is hoped that when the businessmen consider their investment policies, they will also work in tune with the government's policy, the officials said.

Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng, National Federation of Industry and Commerce Chairman Huang Mau-hsiung and TIER President Wu Rong-i will speak on cross-strait trade and peaceful development, as well as industry planning, and will analyse possible changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INVITES HEADS OF FIVE YUANS FOR A MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has invited the heads of the five government branches to discuss major issues, probably next week, Presidential Office staff said Friday.

Amid media reports that Chen has invited the heads of the Executive, Legislative, Judicial, Examination and Control Yuans for a dinner meeting next Monday, the officials said they hope it can take place later in the week.
Chen last met the five heads in early July to inquire about their views on setting up a commission to probe the March 19 assassination attempt, as well as other political issues.

During the meeting, Chen also showed them the gunshot wounds on his abdomen, hoping to end doubts surrounding the shooting which the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party claimed to have been staged to help him win the bitterly contested election.

Last week, Chen promulgated a special statute passed by the Legislative Yuan to allow the formation of a commission to investigate the shooting, but he added a rare note that while the government supports the investigation, it should not be unconstitutional. Since the statute has generated major constitutional controversy, it should seek a ruling from the Council for Grand Justices with regard to its constitutionality, Chen said.

Chen also proposed to give a state-of-the-nation address to the Legislative Yuan to address such major issues as arms procurement, Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, and peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait development, but said he will not accept questioning by the legislators, pointing out that under the Constitution, they can only question the premier and the government heads.
But the opposition "pan-blue alliance" legislators claim it is up to the legislature to invite the president to give such a report and that he should also accept questioning.

The Presidential Office would not confirm if all the recent developments will be on the agenda of the proposed meeting, but only stressed that the president "will discuss major national issues of mutual concern with the heads of the five yuans."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Cabinet Gives Approval to Kyoto Protocol
The Cabinet endorsed the Kyoto Protocol on Thursday, making international implementation of one of the most far-reaching and controversial environmental initiatives a near certainty.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Prime Minister to have heart operation today.
Tony Blair is to have a heart operation today after a period in which he has been under his greatest pressure as prime minister.
He broke the news himself last night to three television channels and coupled it with the astonishing announcement that he intends to serve a third term as Prime Minister but will stand down shortly before what would be his fourth term.
Financial Times: Merck hit as $2.5bn painkiller is withdrawn.
Shares in Merck, the US pharmaceuticals giant, plunged by 27 per cent on Thursday after the company withdrew Vioxx, its $2.5bn-a-year painkiller, because of fears that it increases the risk of heart attacks and strokes.
Merck said it was taking the drug off the market voluntarily after a patient trial showed that those taking Vioxx were twice as likely to suffer cardiac problems than patients taking a placebo.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE POLICY AIMS AT PREVENTING WAR: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday the government's defense policy is aimed at defending Taiwan and preventing war, rather than invading another country.
Yu said the recent uproar over his argument on beefing up the island's counterattack capabilities was triggered by a misinterpretation by the media.
The premier was speaking to lawmakers during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

Trying to make a case for the government's NT$610.8 billion (US$18.07 billion) arms procurement from the United States, Yu said last Saturday that "Taiwan will be safe if it has the capabilities to counterattack Shanghai in the event of the mainland attacking Taipei and Kaohsiung."

The argument was reported by local media as a "balance of terror" theory and drew criticism from Beijing authorities that Taiwan was attempting to "provoke a war" and "promote independence with military power."

Also during the session, opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Te-fu challenged the legitimacy of the arms procurement, pointing out that a referendum held on the issue of enhancing the country's weaponry on March 20 was determined invalid because of a low voter turnout.
In reply, Yu said the procurement had been planned before the referendum and that the referendum was "declaratory" in nature.
Yu said he will take the responsibility if the government breaks the law, urging the lawmaker not to underestimate the wisdom of the Taiwanese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU FORECAST 4.5 PERCENT ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR 2005

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2005 is projected at 4.5 percent despite a slowdown in global economic development.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan plenary session, Yu said the global economy grew fast in the first half of this year thanks to robust expansion in the U.S. and major Asian economies. The growth, however, has lost some steam since the middle of the year due to continued oil price hikes and rising interest rates in major countries.

Against this backdrop, Yu said, Taiwan's exports -- a major driving force behind Taiwan's economic growth, may return to normal growth from the unusually robust growth seen this year. Consequently, he added, the government forecasts a 4.5 percent growth rate for the coming year.
According to Yu, Taiwan registered 7.2 percent growth in the first half of this year with the annual growth reaching 5.9 percent, the highest in seven years.
In the first seven months of this year, Yu said, Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped to 4.5 percent, the lowest in four years.

Touching on the government's 2005 budget plan, Yu said the projected expenditure will increase 2.4 percent from this year's level to reach NT$1.64 trillion, while the revenue will increase 3.9 percent to NT$1.4 trillion. The budget gap will be filled by floating state bonds and by surplus budgets left in previous years, Yu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EYEING OPTO-ELECTRONICS TALENT FROM JAPAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is seeking to recruit skilled individuals from Japan's hi-tech sector for its domestic opto-electronics industry, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.

Relevant government agencies have maintained contacts with about 200 professionals in Japan's opto-electronics sector after an official recruitment delegation visited Tokyo, New York, Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles and San Francisco in late September, the spokesman said.

Claiming that Japan's hi-tech workforce is highly competitive and that some 200 of them have shown interest in coming to work in Taiwan, he said that government authorities will further work out preparations and arrangements to make it possible for them to relocate.

Citing CEPD statistics, he said that the supply-demand gap in Taiwan's hi-tech spectrum is deteriorating fast. He pointed out that domestic high-tech companies will need about 248,000 professionals with an advanced education over the next three years, while supply is estimated at 198,000, resulting in a shortfall of 5,000.

The Taiwan authorities are actively promoting the opto-electronics industry, which has been targeted by the Cabinet in its flagship "two-trillion, two-star" program that also includes the biotechnology and digital-content industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT AT HOME MAKES UP 79 PERCENT OF FULL YEAR TARGET: MOEA

TEXT.P: Private sector investment in the first eight months of this year at home totaled NT$686.7 billion, accoutring for 79 percent of the full-year target of NT$866.2 billion (US$25.5 billion), the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Friday.

Of the capital funneled into the domestic market during the January-August period, NT$276.7 billion was made for seven investment projects worth over NT$10 billion, and NT$58.2 billion went to seven projects valued more than NT$5 billion, MOEA statistics show. Direct investment from overseas Chinese totaled US$2.32 billion, up by 24.6 percent over the previous year's level.
MOEA officials attributed the growth to an economic upswing this year across the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR SINGAPORE COOPERATION IN KEEPING CORDIAL FRIENDSHIP

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-lun urged Singapore Friday to cooperate with Taiwan in preserving the longstanding cordial friendship between the two countries.
Yu made the appeal in a media statement. It marked the first time that Yu publicly touched on the Taiwan-Singapore relation issue since MInister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen's verbal gaffe.

Noting that Taiwan and Singapore share a common language and similar social customs and cultural backgrounds, Yu said the two countries have long enjoyed a cordial relationship and have always helped each other.
"The Republic of China government and people have cherished the enduring friendship with Singapore, " Yu said in the news statement.
Nevertheless, Yu said the continuation of congenial relations requires concerted efforts by both sides based on the universal principle of "equal national sovereignty."
"We should respect each other's sovereignty, " Yu said, adding that both sides should refrain from interfering with internal affairs of the other.
As to Minister Chen's verbal gaffe, Yu said he has directed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to strengthen communications and coordination with Singapore.

"The MOFA should more clearly expound on our official policy goals and stances, " Yu said, adding that he looks forward to seeing Taiwan and Singapore continue reinforcing bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
Meanwhile, the MOFA issued a statement in the evening urging local people to view the country's "relations with Singapore in a rational and calm manner."

The MOFA made the call after 20-plus local demonstrators set fire to a Singaporean flag in the southern port city of Kaohsiung earlier in the day, protesting recent comments by the city-state's foreign minister who warned that Taiwan's pro-independence supporters are risking a war with mainland China.

"We must treasure our friendship with Singapore, " MOFA said in the statement issued after the flag-burning protest. The ministry further said it will ask the nation's representative office in Singapore to brief the city-state on Taiwan's basic stance.
Singaporean Foreign Minister George Yeo gave a speech at the U.N. in New York last week in which he blamed cross-Taiwan Strait tensions on Taiwan.

Yeo claimed that cross-strait relations "went from bad to worse" while pro-independence forces in Taiwan became "increasingly adventurous" during the term of former President Lee Teng-hui, who has described himself as "Moses leading his people out of Egypt."

Yeo further said the international community should not allow "the deteriorating relationship" across the Taiwan Strait to get out of control and warned that the pro-independence movement in Taiwan is likely to trigger a war with the mainland and upset stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
In response, Minister Chen took advantage of a meeting with a group of pro-independence activists on Monday to express his displeasure with Yeo's statements.
Chen described Singapore as "the size of a piece of snot" and said Yeo was pandering to mainland China by unfairly criticizing Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERANS AFFAIRS COMMISSION OPPOSED TO BEING PHASED OUT

TEXT.P: The Veterans Affairs Commission said Friday that it opposes the government's plan to dissolve it.
In a statement, the commission said that even Minister of Defense Lee Jye considers the plan to transfer the business of the commission to the Ministry of Defense as "inappropriate."

The statement also spoke out against the plan to transfer Veterans General Hospital under the commission to the Department of Health and other production units under the commission to the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The commission said its business of taking care of the country's 2.4 million veterans and their families is the government's long-standing policy and the commission has come a long way in improving efficiency.
Dismantling the commission and giving its business to different government agencies will has serious impacts on the country's economic development and social stability, the commission warned.
Under a plan worked out by the Executive Yuan to streamline iteslef, the current ministries and councils under it will be reorganized into 14 ministries and five councils.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEREST RATE HIKES MAY AFFECT STOCK MARKET IN SHORT TERM

TEXT.P: The recent decision by Taiwan's central bank to raise its key interest rate by a quarter percentage point is expected to cause a short-term impact on the domestic stock market, market watchers said Friday.

Their analysis came after the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) announced a day earlier that it will raise its key interests rate by 0.25 of a percentage point, making the discount rate 1.625 percent, the accommodation with collateral rate 2 percent and the short-term accommodation rate 3.875 percent.
The CBC said it made the move to tackle looming inflationary pressures arising from contagiously rising oil prices since late last year in the international market.

It was the CBC's first interest rate hike since 2000, when the domestic stock market began to plummet from its full swing at near 10,000 points, analysts said, adding that it is an indication that the historically low interests rates in the home market will gradually bottom out.

The experts pointed out that the move is set to have a negative impact on the domestic bourse on the grounds that the rate increases will unavoidably add pressure to companies' operating costs, because most of them are capital-intensive and export-oriented businesses.

They predicted that the domestic stock market will fall in the coming months, but claimed that its middle- and long-term performance will mainly depend on in which cycle the bourse is for the time being.
They warned that the export sector could get hurt if the interests rate raises are too fierce.
However, they also pointed out that foreign capital could not enter Taiwan should the CBC fail to have made the move to plug the interest gap.
The United States has three times adjusted its key interests rates upward since late June, with the latest being made last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICS, NOT ARMS ARE STICKING POINT FOR NEGOTIATIONS: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Political differences are keeping Taiwan and mainland China away from the negotiating table and not the current issue over Taiwan' s U.S. arms procurement plan, a Kuomintang (KMT) official said Friday.

Chang Rung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Department said as long as political differences exist, negotiations between Taiwan and China are impossible no matter how many weapons Taiwan acquires.

Disputing President Chen Shui-bian's claims earlier in the day that Taiwan's proposed arms procurement will give the country the capability to negotiate with the mainland from a strong position, Chang asked whether anybody would be convinced that China's deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan is only to facilitate negations?

Citing as an example, Chang said when former U.S. President George Bush approved the sale of 150 F-16 jet fighters to Taiwan in 1992, Taiwan and the mainland had already engaged in negotiations for more than a year, which led to the first meeting of Koo Cheng-fu and Wang Dohan, the chief negotiators for Taiwan and the mainland in 1993.

Chang suggested that President Chen Shui-bian has offered to give a state-of-the-nation report to the Legislative Yuan to make a case for the arms procurement package in an attempt to boost the campaign for a certain presidential candidate in the United States, and his claim that the weapons will give Taiwan the wherewithal to open negotiations with the mainland is unconvincing.
The truth is, Chang cautioned, the more weapons on both sides of the Taiwan Strait amid the absence of contacts between Taiwan and the mainland, the greater the possibility of military conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REFUSES TO APPOINT MEMBERS OF INVESTIGATION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian turned down a request from the Legislative Yuan Friday to appoint nine opposition party members and one independent to the "319 Truth Investigation Commission, " but they will assume their positions on the commission nevertheless.

Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general to the president, said at a news conference that the president considers the statute, which mandates the creation of the commission, to be unconstitutional and would rather not appoint anyone. The 10 seats will be filled anyway since the statute passed by the opposition-controlled legislature calls for them to automatically be assigned 15 days after they have been chosen.
Su said the president felt the statute was contradictory given that it requires the president to appoint the members but still allows them to take their posts even without his appointment.

The statute provides for 17 members for the commission, each of them being named by political parties at the legislature according to their percentage representation. As the ruling Democratic Democracy Party (DPP) and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, have boycotted the commission, only the Kuomintang and the People First Party have named members -- nine altogether -- and one has been appointed by an independent party.
Meanwhile, the Executive Yuan urged the Council of Grand Justices to freeze the statue while determining its constitutionality as requested by 93 lawmakers from the DPP.

Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said it is the understanding of the Executive Yuan that the Council of the Grand Justices will consider the case carefully, but as the statute will serious damage the public interest, the Council should immediately suspend it before handing down a ruling.

The Grand Justices asked the Legislative Yuan Friday to send representatives of the political parties involved to argue before the Council on Oct. 14 over whether the statute should be frozen immediately as requested by the DPP.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng promised to consult with various political parties on the issue Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU WARNED NOT TO LIFT BAN ON ARMS SALES TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen has warned the European Union not to lift its ban on arms sales to China because it is not only morally wrong but also against European economic interest in Asia.

In an article published in the Financial Times Friday, Chen reminded the EU that the regime behind the 1989 military crackdown on student demonstrators in Tiananmen Square is still in power and that lifting the ban would be a positive reward to the regime.

Chen said arms sales to China would impose costs on ordinary people throughout Asia. For example, people in Taiwan would prefer to spend more on social welfare, but faced with China's ever-increasing military capabilities, they would have no choice but to use their resources in national defence.
Furthermore, European weapons sales to China would slow East Asia's economic growth and reduce opportunities for European business to expand its Asian markets.

Chen pointed out that China already has more that 500 ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan. "Enhancing the quality of its weapons could only magnify China's threat to the region and embolden hardliners in Beijing. The cost of any conflict for Europe would be grave, with around one-quarter of total EU exports directly at risk, not including the knock-on effects from the global economy," he said.

Using Taiwan again as an example, Chen said that any military conflict would not only cost Europeans billions of euros of trade with Taiwan but also cause massive disruption in world markets for key items such as computers and mobile phones. "Japan, Korea and southeast Asia would suffer severely, as indeed would China's own coastal regions, where most of the country's recent boom has occurred."
Chen urged EU officials and European governments to take every opportunity to impress on Beijing the need to refrain from using force.
"Needless to say, offering China offensive weaponry is not the best way to send this message," he said.

The Taiwan foreign minister reminded the EU that it is not just the United States that is concerned about lifting the ban on arms sales to China but rather all democratic countries in the Asia-Pacific region, because these countries are directly in the front line.
Chen called on EU member countries to continue engagement with China and help it develop into a modern, peace-loving member of the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 2, or the 19th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
322 B.C.: Aristotle, Greek Philosopher, dies of a stomach illness at the age of 62. A pupil of Plato, the tutor of Alexander the Great, and the author of works on logic, metaphysics, ethics, natural science, politics and poetics, he profoundly influenced western thought.
1803: Samuel Adams, American statesman, dies at the age of 81. He was one of the signatories of the Declaration of Independence.
1835: Texan-Americans strike the first blow for an independent Texas by staging an armed uprising against the central government of Antonio de Santa Anna in the town of Gonzales, located 108 km east of San Antonio.
1869: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Indian leader, is born. He used non-violent civil disobedience in his campaign for Indian independence.
1870: Rome becomes the capital of Italy.
1871: Cordell Hull, American statesman, diplomat, and the secretary of state under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, is born. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1945.
1909: A 220-km railway from Peking to Changchiakow (Kalgan) in Inner Mongolia, the first railroad built and owned by China, is opened to traffic.
1918: The world's first public health college is established at John Hopkins University in Baltimore.
1920: U.S. marines, sent by President Woodrow Wilson to Haiti to restore order, clash with rebel forces and kill their leaders.
1924: The League of Nations in Geneva adopts a protocol for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed commander-in-chief of the Northwestern Communist-Suppression Army, and Chang Hsueh-ling is appointed the deputy commander-in-chief, with their headquarters located in Sian.
1942: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's special envoy, Wendel Willkie, arrives in Chungking to confer with Chinese leaders.
1945: George Smith Patten Jr., American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany, is demoted by U.S. Army Chief-of-Staff Dwight D. Eisenhower.
1973: Siri Siriyodhin, Thai speaker of the House of Representatives and head of an 11-member parliamentary mission, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: A total of 319 model soldiers are cited to mark the ROC's 21st Armed Forces Day.
1985: The ROC government announces the liberalization of gold imports and transactions.
1985: Rock Hudson, Hollywood star, dies of AIDS at the age of 59.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the revision of tariffs, lowering the highest tariff rate to 58 percent.
1989: The ROC and Liberia re-establish diplomatic relations. Peking severs formal ties with Liberia in protest.
1990: A hijacked Chinese jet crashes into two parked planes at the Guangzhou airport, killing 127 people.
1996: A Peruvian plane crashes into the Pacific Ocean, killing all 20 people on board.
1998: Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, a popular government minister and the leading figure in Mongolia's peaceful democratic revolution, is murdered.
1999: Overseas Chinese communities around the world donate a total of NT$540 million (US$16.9 million) for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Taiwan.
2000: Premier Tang Fei points out during a meeting on Taiwan's energy needs that he does not think nuclear power is "absolutely safe" or the "only option," but says he is choosing the "lesser evil."
2001: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is studying the feasibility of using undercover agents in its battle against organized crime.
2001: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vows in a party resolution to build a knowledge-based economy and an efficient and clean government for the people of Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "During the examination of every system of moral laws with the teaching of acknowledged great and wise men of the past, there must be no divergence. Applying the examination to the operations and porches of nature in the physical universe, there must be no contradiction."

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN FOREIGN AFFAIRS MINISTRY URGED TO HELP HANDLE FISHING BOAT CASE
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By H.K. Chang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Representative Office in Moscow sent a letter to the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs Friday to request that the ministry help resolve the matter related to a detained Taiwan fishing vessel.
In the letter, the office urged Russian authorities to treat the crew members of the detained vessel well and to handle the matter in accordance with legal, fair and reasonable principles.

The "Cheng Huei No. 1, " a deep-sea Kaohsiung-registered fishing vessel, was intercepted Sept. 20 by a Russian patrol vessel and then detained for allegedly trespassing into Russian waters near the Kuril Islands.

The office learned of the incident on the evening of Sept. 21 from reports on Russian national television and the business associate of the owner of the detained fishing vessel in Russia immediately requested that the office help in resolving the matter.
Meanwhile, under the assistance of the office, a lawyer of the owner of the fishing boat has been sent to Russia to deal with the case.

According to the office, the fishing boat has a 36-member crew, including five Taiwanese, 23 mainland Chinese, and eight others from Vietnam and the Philippines. All crew members have been reported to be safe.
The office had said a week ago that the owner of the fishing boat could face a fine for illegally entering Russian waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES US$2 MILLION TO PARAGUAY TO BOOST ITS EXPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Lee Pei-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan donated US$2 million to Paraguay Friday to help its sole diplomatic ally in South America boost its exports.
Victor Varela Allegretti, a Paraguayan Industry and Commerce Department (ICD) official in charge of export affairs, said the donation will be subject to transparent management.

According to Varela, US$1.6 million of the donation will be used to revitalize Paraguay's sagging exports and economic development while the remaining US$400,000 will finance a project to improve the ICD's overall information system.
Varela stressed that the ICD will adopt suitable strategies to manage the generous donation from Taiwan.

With Americans Leading Way, Iraqi Forces Secure Key Religious Sites
A heavily armored force of 3,000 U.S. troops, followed by 2,000 Iraqi soldiers, police officers, commandos and National Guardsmen, swept into Samarra on Friday to confront insurgents in what a senior Iraqi official said had become an "outlaw city."

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST FRENCH-LANGUAGE TAIWAN TRAVEL GUIDE PUBLISHED
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The first Taiwan travel guide for the French-speaking world has been published Friday in Paris by Petit Fute Collection.

The company, which has so far published travel guides for 167 destinations around the world, announced the publication of Petit Fute Taiwan at the booth of the Taiwan Tourism Bureau at Top Resa, the leading European fair for tourism professionals from around the world, which is being held in Deauville, France.
A senior staff member of the company said that the new publication will provide the French-speaking reader with a new angle on Taiwan.

According to a Taiwan Tourism Bureau official stationed in Germany, European tourists, particularly those from Germany and Great Britain, are expected to visit Taiwan in increasing numbers this year. He predicted that compared with 2002, Taiwan will attract 10 percent more tourists from Germany and Great Britain in 2004.
The official, who is responsible for promoting Taiwan's tourism in Europe, also expected that there will be more French tourists visiting Taiwan next year.

In order to attract more Europeans to Taiwan, the tourism bureau will push for the publication of an Italian-language travel guide, the official said, adding that the bureau is also planning to participate in various travel fairs held by Germany, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain and Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CHINESE MARATHON TO BE HELD IN PENGHU SUNDAY

TEXT.P: The first Chinese marathon will be held on the outlying island of Penghu Sunday, with more than 4,600 Chinese runners from around the world participating.

Penghu County government said that there will be three divisions: a 42.2 kilometer marathon, a 10 kilometer race and a three kilometer race. All three groups will depart from downtown Makung. The marathoners will run to the Cross-Sea Bridge, the longest inter-island bridge in the Far East, and then return.
Participants include Taiwan runners Wu Wen-chien and Tsai Wen-hua, as well as mainland Chinese Zhang Shujing, who clocked 2:34:34 and was 12th in the Olympic Games in Athens this year.

Penghu County Tourism Bureau head Lin Yao-cheng said the race will feature Chinese runners from five continents and the race route will take in much of the picturesque island. With a seafood festival in June and a fireworks festival in July, the marathon Sunday will be icing on the cake for the island's tourism, Lin said.

Chi Cheng, a former sprinter and currently president of the Chinese Marathon Association, said that although it is very windy at this time of year on Penghu, the participants will rise to the challenge.

Chi said that although the cash prizes for the winners of the races are not very big, it is the spirit of the event that matters and that in the future the purse could increase. The races are expected to be held each year from now on, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARRIAGE PARTNERS HARD TO FIND FOR MANY WHITE-COLLAR WORKERS: POLL

TEXT.P: Sixty-six percent of white-collar workers who want to get married have problems finding a partner mainly because of long work hours, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

The survey conducted by the 9999 Pan Asia Job Bank, an online job search Web site, shows that 52.31 percent of white-collar workers have a desire for marriage, compared with 26.08 percent who said they are not the marrying kind and 21.61 percent who have little interest in marriage.

On the reasons not to get married, 43.52 percent of the respondents said they do not want the bondage of wedlock, 22.77 percent believe marriage is the burial of life, 18.49 percent think marriage will subject them to too much legal responsibility, and 12.95 percent said they have not found the motivation to get married.
For those who intend to get married, 66.25 percent think it is difficult for them to find a suitable partner, while 21.12 percent said it is not so hard and 12.95 percent said it is easy.
The obstacles cited by the respondents include long work hours, the lack of chances to have personal contact with the opposite sex, and not having an attractive shape or look.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BOTULISM FOUND IN BLACK-FACED SPOONBILL'S HABITAT

TEXT.P: Tests in Taiwan's major habitat for the black-faced spoonbill have found no evidence of botulism contamination, the Tainan County Animal Disease Control Center reported Saturday.
Center officials said the first test was completed in September, with officials checking 18 sites; a second test will be conducted this month and samples will be taken until early next year.
They made the remarks as the first group of the rare birds arrived at the Chiku Wetlands Sanctuary near the estuary of the Tsengwen River in Tainan County to overwinter.
Between Dec. 2002 and Jan. 2003, cases of black-faced spoonbills infected with botulism were reported and 73 died, the first time the rare birds had died en masse in Taiwan.
Center officials conducted tests between June and December last years and determined that the overwintering area was free of contaminants.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL IN U.S. TO PROMOTE LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chang Chun-hsiung, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), arrived in Los Angeles Friday to attend celebrations for the party's 18th anniversary and drum up support for the party's candidates for the year-end legislative elections.

Speaking at a news conference at the DPP's U.S. West Coast chapter office in Rosemead on the outskirts of Los Angeles, Chang said he will take advantage of his current U.S. tour to campaign for the DPP candidates for expatriate legislative seats.
Chang said all DPP legislative candidates and party workers are making concerted efforts to win voter support ahead of the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
"Our top goal is to win more than half of the seats in the new Legislative Yuan to facilitate the DPP's political reform programs, " Chang said.

Noting that the legislature has long been controlled by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and its ally, the People First Party, Chang said the DPP administration has been unable to put many of its policy initiatives into practice since it came to power in 2000.

Chang said the DPP is determined to closely cooperate with its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- in the year-end elections with the ultimate goal of winning a majority in the new legislature. A total of 225 seats will be up for grabs, with 168 regional seats, eight seats each for aboriginal and expatriate communities, and 41 at-large seats.
Following his Los Angeles visit, Chang will travel to Houston, Texas to attend celebrations for the party's anniversary.
