DOC.HEADLINE: TERRY FOX RUN DRAWS LARGE CROWD IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A huge crowd of Kaohsiung residents took part in the 2004 Terry Fox Run in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Saturday to raise funds for cancer research.
The non-competitive, recreational run was organized by Kaohsiung Medical University (KMU) . Kaohsiung City Deputy Mayor Yao Kao-chiao and KMU President Wang Kuo-chao joined the run.
Many foreign expatriates also participated in the run through the city's major thoroughfares to show their support for the cause.
KMU President Wang said the annual Terry Fox Run is an international fundraiser aimed at encouraging cancer research.

Noting that the KMU is carrying out many innovative cancer treatment research programs, Wang said financial support from the Terry Fox Foundation has contributed much to the university's research work and has benefited many cancer patients.

Taiwan began to sponsor the annual Terry Fox Run in 1995. This year, the event will be held in four cities around the island -- Kaohsiung, Taipei, Taichung and Hualien. The Taipei run is scheduled for Oct. 31.

The annual Terry Fox Run commemorates Terry Fox, a Canadian track and field athlete who had his right leg amputated in 1977 at the age of 18 due to bone cancer. He managed to run across Canada with a prosthetic leg to raise funds for cancer research before dying of the cancer in 1981.

Despite his death, Fox's courage, perseverance and love spread around the world through his cross-Canada run. Nowadays, 8,000 cities in more than 50 countries around the world hold the Terry Fox Run annually to commemorate him and raise funds for cancer research.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP ANXIOUS FOR PRESIDENT TO ADDRESS LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) urged lawmakers Saturday to schedule a date for President Chen Shui-bian's state-of-the-nation address at the Legislative Yuan as soon as possible.
Liu Wen-hsiung, whip of the PFP caucus in the legislature, made the call ahead of a second consultation meeting between ruling and opposition parties on the matter, set for Monday.
Liu argued that President Chen's request to address the legislature in person indicates that Premier Yu Shyi-kun is losing the president's trust.

This is a "very serious matter" that lawmakers must deal with immediately, Liu said, urging the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to stop obstructing the progress of arranging the address over technical details such as whether the president can take questions from lawmakers after his address.

Chen sent a letter to the Legislative Yuan earlier this week asking that he be permitted to give a state-of-the-nation report on major national policies including arms procurement, Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and peaceful development of cross-strait relations.

The last inter-party consultation meeting held Thursday to discuss the arrangements concerning the report failed to come to any conclusion because of differences between the two sides on a number of technical issues.
The DPP insisted that the president should not be questioned by lawmakers after the address, saying that they can only question the premier and Cabinet ministers according to the Constitution.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the PFP, meanwhile, believed lawmakers should be allowed to debate the president. They also claimed that it should be up to the legislature to invite the president to give such a report, instead of the president taking the initiative.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER UNSURE IF REPRESENTATIVES CAN BE CHOSEN FOR DEBATES

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday that he is not sure if the legislature will be able to come up with representatives before next Tuesday to attend three open debates on the constitutionality of a bill to investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.
Wang made the remarks after receiving an urgent letter from the Judicial Yuan, asking the legislature to name the persons by Tuesday for the debates of the special statute.

Wang said that the legislature can only discuss the matter Monday at the earliest, and even if the people are selected, they will need the approval of the legislature. If the process is not completed by Tuesday, he hopes the Judicial Yuan will "take into consideration the reality and make some adjustment."

Meanwhile, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that before the alleged "lobbying" of grand justices on the matter is clear, the impartiality of the entire Council of Grand Justices is in question, and the Grand Justices should not ask for open debates and the Legislative Yuan shouldn't send representatives to attend them.
Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, was referring to and allegation that several grand justices had lobbied legislators for the DPP over the statute.

On their part, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that if the KMT won't send representatives, it shows that they are afraid of the interpretation because they know they will lose, and that the result will seriously affect their chances in the year-end legislative elections.
Ker Chien-ming, DPP whip in the legislative caucus, said legal proceedings cannot be put on hold, and that if the KMT won't send representatives, it is forfeiting its rights.

Fifteen grand justices said in Friday's meeting that due to the controversy of the bill, they decided that the process of interpretation should be as transparent as possible, and it is necessary to hold open debates.

The first debate, scheduled for Oct. 14, will focus on whether to put the controversial bill on hold for the time being, while the next two sittings will be on Oct. 27 and 29 to discuss whether the statute has violated the Constitution.
Those who attend the debates will include representatives, deputies and experts from both sides -- the one who requested the interpretation.

The Executive Yuan asked the opposition-control legislature for a reconsideration of the special statute passed in August, but failed to overturn it in September. The DPP lawmakers then filed a petition with the Council of Grand Justices, asking it to interpret whether the special statute is constitutional.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party wants an independent commission to be formed to probe the presidential election-eve shooting, which it claims was staged to give President Chen sympathy votes in the bitterly contested election.

The DPP believes the commission set up under the bill will encroach on the judiciary's powers and seriously infringe on human rights, and will be a violation of the division of power and legal proceeding protected by the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINAL POPULATION GROWS FASTER THAN TAIWAN'S OVERALL POPULATION

TEXT.P: The number of aborigines has increased 23.8 percent over the past decade while the nation's total population has grown only 7 percent during the same period, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Saturday.

According to MOI tallies, Taiwan had 452,000 indigenous people at the end of August, accounting for 2 percent of the nation's total population. The number marked a 2.43 percent growth from the year-earlier level.
Among them, 53.05 percent lived in mountainous regions while the remaining 46.95 percent resided in the plains.

In terms of administrative districts, Hualien, Taitung and Pingtung had the largest aboriginal communities, with 48.59 percent of aborigines living in the three counties. The offshore frontline island of Matsu, which lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan, had the smallest aboriginal population of 67 individuals.
The MOI statistics also showed that the indigenous people's "greying index" is only half that of the total population, indicating that aborigines are generally younger than other local citizens.
The indigenous people's "greying index" is 23.01 percent, far lower than the overall population's "greying index" of 48.05 percent.

The current average age of aborigines is 30.27, lower than the average age of 34.6 of the local population overall. Among aborigines, those aged 65 and over account for 5.85 percent of the total, compared to the 9.38 percent ratio in the nation's overall population. Moreover, aborigines aged below 14 accounted for 25.42 of the total, compared to the 19.52 percent ratio in the overall population.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOLK DRUMMERS TO BE ON WORLD STAGE

TEXT.P: A folk acrobatic troupe from Taichung County, central Taiwan, will perform folk drumming in the upcoming Seoul Drum Festival by invitation of the Taiwan representative group of the International Organization of Folk Arts (IOFA).
The Jyou-Tian Folk Drum and Arts Group will participate in the three-day festival that opens Oct. 8.

Since 2000, many different drum troupes from around the world, either performing in modern style or traditional, have been invited to join the annual event, sponsored by the Seoul City Government, to introduce their native music and culture to local people.
This year, a total of 12 groups will perform from Argentina, Australia, Canada, Ghana, India, Japan, Sweden, Taiwan and the United States, as well as the host country South Korea.

The Jyou-Tian troupe was founded by drum performer Shue Chen-rong in 1995, who put together energetic young people, mostly dropouts and marginal people, to play drums, do acrobatics and perform traditional dances for local temple activities.

Jyou-Tian members have been dedicated to performing Taiwan's most traditional folk drumming. Their ideas and efforts have made the team the distinguished performing group of Taichung County in 2002 and have kept the title each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUICIDE PREVENTION ASSOCIATION OPENS CLASS FOR VOLUNTEERS TO HELP

TEXT.P: The ROC Suicide Prevention Association opened a suicide prevention training class in Kaohsiung Saturday, officials from the Department of Health (DOH) said.
The class was set up to train volunteers to spot people with suicidal tendencies early before it is too late.
The volunteers will get hands-on knowledge about how to dissuade those stricken with grief from committing suicide and how to analyze their psychological state.
Suicide is especially common among people aged 15-24 and over 65, Kuo Chian-che, a psychiatrist at the Taipei City Psychiatric Center said.
To prevent youngsters from killing themselves, the Suicide Prevention Association has established an "Angel Hotline" for them to complain about their sufferings. The telephone number is 080-055-5911.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WHEELCHAIR-BOUND WRITER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Saturday visited physically-challenged writer Yu Hsiu-chih, praising the woman as having given people a good path to follow on the quest for the meaning of life.
Chen said Yu's biography, entitled "With Perseverance, There Will Be Hope, " is bringing optimism to and touching the hearts of many people who have experienced misfortune in their lives.
Taking his own wife, Wu Shu-jen, who is also bound to a wheelchair, as an example, Chen said Wu won respect at the 2004 Athens Paralympic Games last month because of her perseverance.

Chen pointed out that Yu had donated 50 copies of her book to the Chinese Taipei Paralympic Committee to raise funds for the mentally and physically challenged, and that the excellent showing of Taiwan's paralympic athletes is the best reward for Yu.
The Chinese Taipei team won two gold, two silver and two bronze medals at the Games, the best-ever performance for the country.
Chen said his wife led the team to Athens to show her support for athletes with disabilities, and the good results prove that nothing is impossible.
The president said people in good health have no right to be pessimistic and lose hope in life because they can stand up and overcome whatever problems they have.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY NATIONAL DEFENSE MINISTER LEAVES FOR U.S. TO ATTEND CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Deputy Minister of National Defense Houh Shoou-yeh departed Saturday for the United States to attend a U.S.-Taiwan defense industry conference.

Houh's departure came at a time when the Legislative Yuan will soon review a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) for an arms procurement from the U.S., mainly for six PAC III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-powered submarines, and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

Houh said his trip will mainly focus on representing National Defense Minister Lee Jye at the annual meeting. The United States-Taiwan Defense Industry Conference will be held in Scottsdale, Arizona Oct. 3-5. Scottsdale is north of Phoenix.
He will also give a speech at the invitation of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council.

Houh said during his visit to the United States, he will have no activities related to the arms purchase. But if he has the chance to meet with U.S. officials, he will stress to them that the arms purchase must meet the overall interests of the nation, combat needs as well as the monitoring of the Legislative Yuan.

Asked if he will have contacts arms manufacturers in the U.S., Houh stressed the conference aims to address national defense, the future of U.S. defense cooperation with Taiwan, and the defense procurement process, and that he will "have no chance to contact the arms manufacturers."

This year is the third in a series of conferences to address these issues. The first conference was held in St. Petersburg, Florida in March 2002, and the second was held in Feb. 2003, in San Antonio, Texas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRUTH INVESTIGATION COMMISSION TO HOLD FIRST MEETING OCT. 4

TEXT.P: The March 19 truth investigation commission to investigate the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian will convene its first meeting Monday, an official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday.
Tseng Yung-chuan, head of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said that after President Chen decided not to appoint members to join the commission, the commission was put into effect immediately.

He said the 10 members appointed by the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, will select the conveners and decide the operational procedure and meeting venues during the first meeting.

He said the commission will be a supra-partisan and impartial body, hoping that it will operate according to the special statute passed by the Legislative Yuan to shed light on the election-eve shooting.
The opposition-backed commission is supposed to be made up of 17 members recommended by various political parties according to their representation in the Legislative Yuan.

The "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, have refused to name members to the commission, believing it is unconstitutional and in violation of judicial and prosecutorial powers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 500,000TH 'NATURAL PERSON CERTIFICATE' APPLICANT TO BE AWARDED

TEXT.P: The 500,000th "Natural Person Certificate" (NPC) applicant will be awarded a full set of personal computer, including terminal, monitor, laser printer and NPC card reading machine, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Saturday.

The Natural Personal Certificate is an electronic identity IC card on the Internet. The certificate is a protocol of the electronic signature and electronic code between the smart card holder and the government.

Noting that the certificate is an infrastructure service for the promotion of e-government to upgrade administrative efficiency and strengthen services for ordinary citizens, an MOI official said more than 280 public services can now be provided through the Internet with the NPC card. The number of such services will break the 1,000 mark in three years, he said.
The MOI began to accept NPC card applications April 30, 2003, and more than 490,000 cards have been issued so far. The number is growing by 1,000 pieces a day, the official said.
With a view to encouraging local people to apply for the NPC cards, the official said, the ministry will award a personal computer plus all necessary accessories to the 500,000th applicant.
"The application procedures have been simplified. Prospective applicants can apply with the household registration offices near their homes," the official said.
Before the end of this year, the NPC card is free of charge. Starting Jan. 1, 2005, applicants will have to pay IC card fees.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA URGES MATSU RESIDENTS NOT TO SMUGGLE MAINLAND FARM PRODUCE

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) urged Matsu residents Saturday not to smuggle agricultural and poultry products from mainland China to prevent spread of epidemics.
The Matsu station of the COA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine Bureau made the call after coast guard officials busted a spate of livestock smuggling cases.

Quarantine officials said mainland China remains an area stricken by many diseases communicable among both humans and animals and infested by certain pests. Worse still, the officials said mainland China's epidemic information system is not transparent.

"Against this backdrop, Matsu residents should refrain from smuggling live animals or poultry products from the mainland. Otherwise, local public health and livestock industry could be at stake," said a quarantine official. Matsu lies closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. and Iraqi forces battle resistance in Samarra
Sporadic gunfire echoed through the Sunni Muslim stronghold Samarra Saturday as U.S. and Iraqi forces battled pockets of resistance a day after the start of what appeared to be the first major push to regain control of a string of cities before elections in January. More than 100 g uerrillas were killed and 37 captured on the first day of the operation Friday, according to an Iraqi official. The military said one American soldier was killed and four were wounded after some 5,000 swept in to seize the city hall, the main mosque and other key sites in Samarra.
Wall Street Journal: Effort to create terror watch list is falling behind, report finds
A U.S. government report concludes that efforts to protect U.S. borders and better identify terrorist suspects by compiling a single consolidated watch list -- from more than a dozen currently in use by federal agencies -- have badly foundere. The inspector general of the Homeland Security Department cites poor cooperation among many agencies and says his own agency failed "to play a lead role" in oversight. The report has been delivered to Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge and congressional leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 3, or the 20th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last Thursday of November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, the U.S. inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made about US$2 million from the patent, subsequently winning patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, the German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown in a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the Protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: Armando Yoshida Vaca, new Bolivian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign a pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of their respective countries to 200.
1973: Gen. Robert E. Cushman, commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The sixth World Chinese Pharmacists Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1975: The 10th World Chinese Traders Conference opens in Taipei with more than 900 overseas Chinese from 57 countries and areas attending.
1976: ROC Finance Minister Walter H. Fei leaves for Manila for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
1976: Jack Davis, president of Rotary International from 1977 to 1978, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and mainland China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite to become the single nation of Germany, with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it is clocked at 451 kilometers per hour on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
1999: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends its appreciation for the efforts of the 25 countries that support membership in the United Nations for the ROC.
2000: Premier Tang Fei announces his resignation after a four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.
2001: Dr. Chern Jeng-shing, an official with the Republic of China's Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC), is elected a member of the prestigious International Academy of Astronautics (IAA).
2001: The Hong Kong branch of the Taiwan-based United World Chinese Commercial Bank (UWCCB) opens, becoming the eighth Hong Kong branch of Taiwan-funded banks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe, a man must be able to maintain moral law without any doubts. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations without any misgivings for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm moral law."

The Washington Post: Debate Leads to Shifts in Strategy. Advisers Predict Tightening Race
A newly energized battle for the White House heads into a crucial two-week period with John F. Kerry planning to capitalize on the momentum from a strong debate performance by shifting the focus to President Bush's economic record, while the president revives his attack on Kerry's foreign policy credentials, according to officials with both campaigns.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taiwan-Japan Science and Technology Forum opened here Sunday.

About 260 industriests and scholars from Japan and Taiwan exchanged views on the issues of industrial research and development policy, digital techonology and nanoelectro plating technology in the conference which will last until Monday.

Speaking at the opening ceremony, Vincent Siew, chairman of the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research, lauded the forum for improving the scientific and technological excahnges between Taiwan and Japan.

The forum, the second of its kind, was jointly organized by the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research and the Association of East Asian Relations which is charged with dealing with Japan after Tokyo switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DESERVES MORE FEEDBACK IN CYBERCRIME PREVENTION: U.S. OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Having made significant contributions to cybercrime prevention efforts around the world, Taiwan deserves more feedback in this regard in return, according to a senior U.S. Justice Department official.

Richard W. Downing, a senior counsel in the Computer Crime and Intellectual Property Section of the U.S. Justice Department's Criminal Division, said in Taipei Saturday that the fact that Taiwan is "giving much more than taking" in cybercrime prevention efforts has been noticed and that this unfair situation should be addressed.

Downing, co-chair of the APEC e-Security Task Group, was in Taipei Sept. 27-Oct. 2 to meet with Taiwan law enforcement authorities to discuss the Cybercrime Legislation and Enforcement Capacity Building Project -- one of the important issues that APEC is actively dealing with this year aimed at cracking down on cybercrimes in the Asia-Pacific region, the largest economic bloc in the world.

Downing said that Taiwan and Japan are on an identical level in terms of computer and Internet crime prevention and that the two countries' capacities in this regard are better than those of most APEC member countries.

Accompanied by Alan J. Peters, an FBI specialist on Internet crimes, Downing met with 67 Taiwan prosecutors, inspectors and police officials during his stay to exchange views on the feasibility of the Cybercrime Legislation and Enforcement Capacity Building Project in Taiwan, as well as on ways of solving and addressing cross-border computer-related crimes, and security and protection of electronic evidence.
The ROC military also sent specialists to the APEC e-Security presentations hosted by Downing and Peters.

Downing said that as Internet use becomes globally prevalent, the surveillance and prevention of cross-border cybercrime is critical for governments, adding that they need to tackle the problem not only through law enforcement, but also by passing legislation to facilitate the enforcement.
In addition, he said, APEC economies should build counterpart communication units to collaborate in the identification and rounding up of cyber criminals as quickly as possible.
For his part, Peters shared with his Taiwan audience the FBI's experience in arresting those involved in computer-related crimes in the United States.

Both Downing and Peters gave the thumbs-up to Taiwan law enforcement authorities, including prosecutors from the Ministry of Justice and members of the Ninth Squad of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, for successfully helping other Asian countries crack down on cross-border hacking and intellectual property rights infringement cases in recent years.
Taiwan -- with the passage of new statutes on cybercrime prevention, as well as high-caliber law enforcement personnel -- is at the "advanced" level among APEC economies in this regard, they said.

According to Taiwan law enforcement authorities, Taiwan received 32 requests filed by other APEC governments in 2003 for assistance in cracking down on crimes that were endangering e-security or for information to help solve related criminal cases.

Taiwan successfully and efficiently responded to 25 of the 32 requests, the authorities added. By comparison, Taiwan issued 19 similar requests to other APEC countries, but received responses for only three cases.

Despite mushrooming cybercrime globally, only a few regional blocs, such as APEC, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , and the Organization of American States (OAS) , have established groups to exclusively deal with Internet-related crimes. So far, Taiwan participates in such groups established by APEC and by the G8.

The APEC e-Security Task Group is scheduled to focus its work on six APEC economies, namely Taiwan, Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Peru, this year to promote the implementation of the Cybercrime Legislation and Enforcement Capacity Building Project.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR SECURITY DIALOGUE WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged Japan Sunday to play a more active role in ensuring regional peace and to open dialogue with Taiwan on the issue of regional security.

Speaking at the opening of the 2004 Taiwan-Japan Forum, Yu said a security dialogue between Taiwan and Japan, coupled with Japan's defense cooperation with the United States and the U.S. commitment to helping Taiwan meet its self-defense needs can help form a close cooperation triangle among Taipei, Tokyo and Washington, and improve stability in the region.
Since the end of the Cold War, Yu said, mainland China and North Korea have become the biggest threat to security in Northeast Asia.

Yu said the six-nation talks aimed at dissuading North Korea from developing nuclear weapons has not yielded any progress thus far, and mainland China's military build-up has helped lead U.S. President George Bush to shift away from the doctrine of "static defense" to one of "preemptive strike."

The premier noted that Japan must have realized after 1996 when mainland China lobbed missiles into waters near Taiwan that any military conflict across the Taiwan Strait would compromise Japan's interests, adding that this is why Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's advisors recommended that he list China as a potential nearby threat.

Noting that the United States, Japan and Taiwan all believe in democracy, liberty and human rights, the premier said closer cooperation among the three countries is natural as well as vital for regional peace and security.
In order to improve the security in the region, Yu urged Japan to assume a bigger share of responsibility for regional security and to open dialogue with Taiwan in this field.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN PLANS LEAN-AND-MEAN CENTRAL GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The Central Personnel Administration (CPA) has just completed a draft bill to create a leaner and meaner central government, with the bill scheduled to be screened jointly by three Legislative Yuan committees Monday.

According to the CPA's draft bill, the total number of central government staff -- including those of organizations ranging from the Presidential Office and the five Yuans, to law enforcement agencies and national educational institutions -- will be controlled at under 200,500.

The number of central government-level staff has continued to decline over the past three years, down 3.45 percent, 5.6 percent and 1.7 percent in 2002, 2003 and 2004, respectively, CPA officials said.
The total number of central government staff has been cut by 48,000 over that period, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS FIRST IN GLOBAL E-GOVERNMENT SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks first in the world in terms of government online services and information, according to the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Citing the recently released fourth annual Global e-Government Survey conducted by researchers at Brown University in the United States, DGBAS officials said that Taiwan topped the list of 198 countries around the world surveyed with 44.3 points in overall e-government performance, followed by Singapore with 43.8 points, the United States with 41.9 points, Canada with 40.3 points and Monaco with 39 points.

The study reviewed 1,935 government Web sites in the 198 nations during June, July and August of this year. Among the sites analyzed were those of executive offices, judicial offices, Cabinet offices and major agencies serving crucial functions of government, such as health, human services, taxation, education, interior, economic development, administration, natural resources, foreign affairs, foreign investment, transportation, military, tourism and business regulations.

Using the number of services plus access to information, disability access, privacy, security, and foreign language translation as the criteria, the researchers rated each country on a point scale of 0 to 100.
Taiwan jumped to the No. 1 spot in this year's survey after ranking fifth overall last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH HEAD ARRIVES IN ROME
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Minister of the Department of Health (DOH) Chen Chien-jen arrived in Rome Saturday for a four-day visit.

While in the Italian capital, Chen will meet with ranking health officials and public opinion leaders of Italy and the Vatican to exchange views and explore the possibility of joint cooperative ventures, particularly in the prevention and control of new contagious diseases.

According to Chen, Italian Health Minister Girolamo Sirchia has proposed strengthening two-way exchanges of medical students and medical treatment personnel as a gesture to thank Taiwan for its setting up of a fund commemorating Dr. Carlo Urbani, who died after having discovered the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) virus and first identified the outbreak of the killer disease.

Sirchia also encouraged Italian pharmaceutical firms to consider opening branches in Taiwan as a means of helping step up Taiwan's cooperation with Italy and the European Union in relevant fields, Chen said.
The DOH chief is slated to proceed to Austria Oct. 5 for a visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR LIKELY TO CONTINUE APPRECIATING THIS WEEK: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar is expected to gain in value against the U. S. dollar this week if the domestic stock market continues to rise in the coming days, foreign exchange analysts said Sunday.

Boosted by a strong Japanese yen and a stock market rally last Friday as well as the Central Bank of China's announcement of a key interest rate hike of 0.25 percentage points a day earlier, the new Taiwan dollar finished at 33.94 against the U.S. dollar Friday. It appreciated by NT$0.041 against the greenback over the past week.

Market analysts predicted that the local currency will hover between 33.85 and 33.95 against the greenback during this week should the domestic bourse maintain its rising streak and the Japanese yen remain stable.

Taiwan Institute of Economic Research President Wu Rong-i forecast over the weekend that the central bank is very likely to allow the local currency to gradually appreciate in the months ahead to curb looming inflation.

Wu said that the time is ripe for the central bank to do so, as local commodity prices have been adjusted upward various times this year as a result of rising oil prices since late last year in the international market. The international price of oil has remained at the historic high of more than US$50 per barrel in recent days.

As the United States has raised its interest rates three times since late June, Taiwan's central bank should be planning to make further moves in this direction to plug the interest rate gap between the two countries, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-AUSTRALIA WORKING HOLIDAY PROGRAM TO KICK OFF NOV. 1

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Australia will begin issuing working holiday visas to each other's young citizens from this Nov. 1.
Taiwan and Australia signed an agreement July 15 on the exchange of working holiday visas to facilitate tourism development in both countries.
Australia is the second country to sign such an agreement with Taiwan after New Zealand. The Taiwan-New Zealand working holiday visa agreement was implemented in June this year.

Under the Taiwan-Australia working holiday agreement -- signed in Taipei by Yang Chin-tien, Taiwan's representative to Australia, and his Australian counterpart, Frances Adamson -- Taiwan citizens aged between 18 and 30 can apply for working holiday visas for a maximum one-year stay in Australia.

Such Taiwan citizens can take on short-term employment during their stay, but their main purpose of entry must be for vacation or pleasure trips, and not work. Therefore, they cannot work for the same employer for more than three months and cannot take full-time jobs.

Australian officials present at the opening of the Australian Education Exhibition in Taipei Sunday solicited Taiwan students and young working people to go to Australia for leisure trips or study by taking advantage of the new agreement.

The Australian officials said that Australia offers much better treatment to Taiwan students and young working people than the United States does. They noted that the United States allows only students to "work and tour" in America during summer vacations and that the applicants must be aged between 18 and 28.

There will be no limit in terms of the number of Taiwan students or young working people who can apply for Australian working holiday visas, the Australian officials said. The applicants cannot take any children with them on their trip, and they must produce proof that they have at least A$5,000 (US$3,598), the officials added.
Taiwan is the 17th country or area to sign a working holiday visa accord with Australia, which issued 90,000 such visas last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITY CHIEF URGES JAPAN TO NORMALIZE TIES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Japan should normalize relations with Taiwan by discarding its policy of only developing economic ties with the island, Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the National Security Council said Sunday.

During his speech to the Taiwan-Japan Forum which opened in Taipei Sunday, Chiou said Japan's current policy toward Taiwan has hampered the normalization of bilateral ties and is compromising both sides' capability to deal with the changing situation in the Asia-Pacific region.

Some sixty years after the end of World War II, Chiou said, Japan has emerged as the most powerful democracy in East Asia and exercises the most influence on China in the region. He called for Japan to throw off the past and join the other Asian states in embracing the future as a regional leader should do.

Chiou said Taiwan supports Japan's bid to play an active role in reforming the United Nations and encourages it to assume the role of leader in Asia which he claimed will help ensure peace and prosperity in the region.

Just as Japan underwent difficulties in stepping onto the international stage and contributing to the international community, Taiwan now also faces challenges in its bid to take part in and contribute to the international community.

Facing the emergence of mainland China, Chiou said, Taiwan and Japan share the same interest in seeing mainland China move toward democracy, but he cautioned that Japan should not to be so naive as to have any illusions about China which is still ruled by a dictatorial communist regime.

While mainland China is aggressively modernizing its military forces, Chiou said, Taiwan and Japan share the common interest of prodding it to be a responsible member of the international community. This requires that Japan discard its economic-only policy toward Taiwan and begin to normalize relations with it, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE SHOULD BE VIEWED AS INTERNATIONAL: JAPANESE ENVOY

TEXT.P: The cross-Taiwan Strait question should be viewed as an international issue which affects the interests of other countries, a Japanese representative to Taiwan said in Taipei Sunday.

Uchida Katsuhisa, director-general of the Taipei Office under the Interchange Association of Japan, told the 2004 Taiwan-Japan Forum that the international community is shifting away from the conventional notion that the "Taiwan question" is a Chinese internal affair as Beijing has consistently claimed.
Katsuhisa said that as cross-strait tensions increase, other countries must pay closer attention and see it as an issue of international concern.
He also said President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural address has convinced the international community that Taiwan is pulling its weight to maintain cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO CONTINUE TO PROMOTE SUBSTANTIVE TIES WITH SINGAPORE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will continue to promote substantive ties with Singapore based on the existing communication channels, a spokesman for the MOFA said Sunday.

Commenting on the conciliatory remarks by Singaporean Foreign Minister George Yeo on Taiwan-Singapore relations a day earlier, Michel Lu said that the MOFA hopes that the recent verbal controversy between the two countries has come to an end and that the two sides can maintain the existing good communication channels and continue to promote substantive bilateral relations.
Lu said that Taiwan is aware of the goodwill Yeo demonstrated in his remarks.

Speaking of the burning of the Singaporean national flag by a group of pro-independence demonstrators in Taiwan on Saturday, Yeo told Singaporean media that he was sad rather than angry about the incident because of the longstanding friendship between the two nations.
Taiwan can disagree with the position taken by Singapore, but it should not take extreme actions against it, Yeo noted.

The verbal controversy arouse in late September when Yeo gave a speech at the U.N. General Assembly in New York in which he blamed cross-Taiwan Strait tensions on Taiwan and warned that pro-independence forces in Taiwan risked provoking a war with mainland China.

In response, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen took advantage of ameeting with agroup of pro-independence activists Sept. 27 to express his displeasure with Yeo's statements, describing Singapore as "the size of a piece of snot" and claiming that Yeo was pandering to Beijing by unfairly criticizing Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELIGIBLE FOREIGN SPOUSES MAY RECEIVE GOVERNMENT SUBSIDIES: CLA

TEXT.P: Eligible foreign spouses of Taiwan nationals will be able to receive temporary subsidies aimed at helping them improve their lives here, according to a draft plan of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

Under the terms of the draft being worked on by the CLA, foreign husbands and wives of Taiwan citizens of low-income families who have remained jobless for more than 12 weeks will be able to receive financial aid of up to NT$16,000 (about US$470) from the council each month for a maximum period of six months, if they get work through public-run employment service agencies.
Employers who hire this type of job seekers through public-run job agencies will be given NT$5,000 per month in government subsidies for a maximum period of one year.
To help foreign spouses set up their own small businesses in Taiwan, the CLA will also offer free career development consultation and low-interest loans, a CLA official said.

CLA statistics show that more than 100,000 foreign husbands and wives in Taiwan are qualified workers, but only about half of them, with an average age of 35 and a low level of education, are currently employed.
There are about 310,000 foreign spouses in Taiwan at present, with more than 200,000 coming from mainland China (including Hong Kong and Macau) and 110,000 from countries in Southeast Asia.
The number is expected to rise to 400,000 -- a level to be on par with that of Taiwan's aboriginal citizens -- in two years at the current rate, experts said.
Last year, about 50,000 Taiwan nationals got married to foreigners, with 30,000 of them coming from mainland China.

Since Taiwan lifted a ban on cross-Taiwan Strait travel in 1987, a large number of mainland brides has entered Taiwan every year, creating an unprecedented immigration experience for Taiwan society, experts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU PRESIDES OVER PENGHU MARATHON RACE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu presided over the opening ceremony of an international marathon race held on the offshore island of Penghu on Sunday.
In addition to encouraging the participants from around the world to run their best times, Lu also called on all the runners and the general public to pray together for world peace.
The vice president expressed the hope that the marathon would be held on Penghu again next year and urged more companies to sponsor the event.
It was the first time that an international marathon race was held on the island located southwest off the coast of Kaohsiung.
Braving gusty northeast winds and sandy air, scores of runners from home and abroad took part in the race which kicked off at 6: 30 a.m.
Taiwan's Wu Wen-chien won the men's group with a time of 2: 29:09 to take the top cash prize of NT$150,000 (about US$4,410).
Wu was followed by mainland China's Bai Zengquan with a time of 2:33:41 and Taiwan's Chiu Chien-hsing with a time of 2:39:56.

Meanwhile, mainland Chinese runner Zhang Zhujing grabbed the top spot in the women's group with a time of 2: 47: 20. Runners from South Africa and Taiwan finished in second and third spots, both recording a time of more than three hours.

The Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr has begun laying the groundwork to enter Iraq's nascent democratic process, telling Iraqi leaders that he is planning to disband his militia and possibly field candidates for office. Afte weeks of watching his militia witheh before American military attacks, Sadr has sent emissaries to some of Iraq's major political parties and religious groups to discuss the possibility of involving himself in the campaign for nationwide elections, according to a senior aide to Mr. Sadr and several Iraqi leaders who have met with him.

U.S. and Iraqi commanders have declared the operation a successful first step in a major push to wrest key areas from insurgent control before January elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER RETURNS FROM PALAU

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen returned home Sunday night after concluding a three-day visit to Palau.
Unpon arriving at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Chen declined to comment on the recent development of Taiwan-Singapore relations but saying that he has nothing to say about the matter.

A verbal controversy between Taiwan and Singapore arouse in late September when Singaporean Foreign Minister George Yeo gave a speech at the U.N. General Assembly in New York in which he blamed cross-Taiwan Strait tensions on Taiwan and warned that pro-independence forces in Taiwan risked provoking a war with mainland China.

In response, Chen took advantage of a meeting with a group of pro-independence activists Sept. 27 to express his displeasure with Yeo's statements, describing Singapore as "the size of a piece of snot" and claiming that Yeo was pandering to Beijing by unfairly criticizing Taiwan.
Chen left Taipei at the head of a six-member Taiwan delegation for Palau Thursday to take part in celebrations marking the 10th anniversary of the Pacific island nation's independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONTINUE TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT PEACEFUL INTERACTION: CHEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to promote cross-Taiwan Strait peaceful interactions, President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday.

Addressing the mid Autumn conference of Taiwan businessesmen operating in mainland China held in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Chen said that his administration will continue to create friendly evironment for economic, educational and cultural exchanges between the two sides of the strait, including the direct cross-strait trade, transportation and postal services, or the so-called three links.

Taiwan has no illusion of the Beijing authorities despite of the fact that mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao has successfully assumed to the leadership, Chen noted, adding that the Chinese Communist "one-party" authoritarian rule has not changed.
However, Chen went on, Taiwan will continue to carry out its promise of creating a friendly environment for the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interactions.

Thepresident also revealed that he will issue an "important statement" on the development of the cross-strait relations on Oct. 10 -- the National Day of the Republic of China -- in which, he said, he will reply to the statement jointly issued by the Chinese Communist Party's Taiwan Affairs Office and State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office on May 17.

Beijing urged Taiwan leaders with intimidating words in its statement to forgo Taiwan independence and recognize that there is only one China so that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume talks and end animosity.

Beijing also gives two options to Taiwan leaders: stop the independence movement and recognize that there is only one China to promote the development of cross-strait relations, or try to split Taiwan from China and risk the consequences.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 4, or the 21st day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1669: Rembrandt van Rijn, Dutch painter whose works are unmatched in their portrayal of subtle human emotions, dies at the age of 63.
1777: U.S. forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but are repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th president of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877, supported the welfare of minority groups, and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" as well as "Ben Hur" for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The U.S. State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, a Reuters correspondent, is freed from house arrest after being held in Beijing by the Communist China for 20 months.
1974: The 75-member Peiping opera troupe leaves Taipei for the United States on a 72-day performance tour.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" missile.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at the appropriate time and passes legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 people.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliamentary leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1999: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines forges a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
2000: Yu Kuo-hwa, former premier of the ROC, dies of respiratory failure at the age of 87 at Taipei Veterans' General Hospital.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian appoints Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the place of Tang Fei as premier.
2001: A local basketball team financed by Chinese-language Internet portal Sina.com announces that it is officially quitting the basketball scene in Taiwan and relocating to mainland China.
2001: New Palau Ambassador to the Republic of China Johnson Toribiong presents the credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
2001: The Republic of China government spokesman expresses welcome for U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks that the United States will not make deals against Taiwan's interests, describing it as "a very friendly statement" toward Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man that every act of his life becomes an example for generations, that everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and that every word he utters becomes a law for generations."
