THE new Medishield insurance scheme being worked out holds one promise: the extra that people will fork out for the higher premiums will be less than $10 a month.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Meishield premium hike up but more compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Presidential race enters crucial stage; Focus to be on Bush's economic records, Kerry's foreign policy.
A newly energized battle for the White House heads into a crucial two-week period with Sen. John Kerry planning to capitalize on the momentum from a strong debate performance by shifting the focus to President George W. Bush's economic record, while the president receives his attack on Kerry's foreign policy credentials, according to officials with both campaigns.

DOC.HEADLINE: 300 SOLDIERS TO BE SENT TO PINGTUNG TO HELP COMBAT DENGUE FEVER

TEXT.P: A total of 300 soldiers will be sent to Taiwan's southernmost city of Pingtung beginning Monday to help combat dengue fever, Pingtung County Government reported.

A total of 64 cases of indigenous dengue fever, a mosquito-borne disease, have been reported in the Pingtung area over the past two weeks, with 61 cases in Pingtung City and three cases in Pingtung County, the county government officials said.

The military personnel will conduct intensive disinfection work in 16 boroughs in Pingtung City over the following three days to clean up mosquito-infested areas in an effort to stave off the spread of dengue fever.

Some schools in Pingtung City have been found to have stagnant water in ponds and sewers, as well as standing water that did not contain pesticides, all of which are believed to have allowed mosquitos to multiply.

According to Pingtung County Government regulations, a school principal could be fined up to NT$30,000 under the Disease Control Law and the Waste Management Statute if mosquito-infested areas are discovered on the campus of their school.

Small-scale dengue fever outbreaks occur about every three years in Taiwan, with a major outbreak happening about every decade, dating back to the early 1930s when nearly 80 percent of the population contracted the disease in a major outbreak.

Four types of the virus that causes dengue fever have been found, and patients with more than one type of virus can develop symptoms that include bleeding of the gums, the skin and the intestinal tract, in addition to the classic symptoms of sudden high fever, severe headaches, nausea and vomiting, and muscle and joint pain.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TRIED TO HAVE TAIWAN EXCLUDED FROM WTCA: CHAIRMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The head of a world leading trade-promotion organization revealed that 20 years ago, Beijing tried to make Taiwan's withdrawal from the World Trade Center Association (WTCA) a precondition for its own entry into the association.
WTCA President Guy Tozzoli made the revelation in a speech he delivered at the 35th WTCA assembly, which kicked off the same day in Geneva.
Tozzoli said that when he invited Beijing to join some two decades ago, then mainland Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping insisted that Taiwan should first exit the association.

Pointing out that the WTCA's goal is to push for world peace and stability through the promotion of trade, Tozzoli said that he resolved the problem by telling Beijing that WTCA membership is given on the basis of city status rather than nationhood status.
The WTCA is a non-political and non-profit international organization which groups some 300 world trade centers from more than 100 countries around the world and serves more than 750,000 companies.

The Taipei World Trade Center is one of the WTCA's main members, and its chairman, C.J. Hsu, who is heading a delegation to participate in the current assembly, is also one of the association's administrators.

Noting that the outstanding performance of the Taipei World Trade Center in the organization has won affirmation from other WTCA members, Hsu said that this is why Taiwan has been among the 22 WTCA administrators for many years.

The operations of the Taipei World Trade Center, which combines the operations of other establishments nearby, including the Taipei World Trade Building, the Taipei International Convention Center, Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall and the Taipei Hayatt Regency, have become a model for other world trade centers, Hsu said, adding that the 1994 WTCA assembly, which was held in Taipei, is regarded as the organization's most successful assembly ever by its members.

Hsu, also chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, expressed his admiration for Tozzoli's leadership in the association and his efforts to promote world peace, saying that the WTCA chairman's name has been forward several times as a Nobel Peace Prize candidate. Tozzoli has actively pushed for peace in the Korean Peninsula over the years.

According to Hsu, world trade centers in various important cities on the both sides of the Taiwan Strait are WTCA members, and there has never been any confrontation among them in the organization over the years.
The 36th WTCA assembly will be held in Shanghai next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2,600 ROC EXPATS TO RETURN FOR NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: About 2,600 Taiwan expatriates will return to attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations, a senior official of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) said Monday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, OCAC Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei said the number of ROC expatriates intending to return for Oct. 10 National Day celebrations this year is lower than in previous years because many expatriates already returned between March and May either to vote in the March 20 presidential election or to attend the May 20 presidential inauguration.

"I admire the expatriates' patriotism as they are returning at their own expense for the National Day celebrations, " Chang said, adding that the OCAC will only offer a NT$3,000 subsidy for each returning expatriate for local tour packages.

According to Chang, the OCAC has commissioned 17 selected local travel agencies to organize three-day tour packages for returning expatriates so that they can see for themselves Taiwan's latest progress in political, social and economic development.
Chang said the returning expatriates will include members of some pro-"pan-blue alliance" groups, but she admitted that the number is indeed limited.
The "pan-blue alliance" refers to the coalition of Taiwan's two major opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP).

Chang attributed the limited number of pro-"pan-blue alliance" expatriates willing to return for National Day celebrations mainly to the disputes over the result of the March 20 presidential election in which the "pan-blue alliance" presidential candidate KMT Chairman Lien Chan lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian by a slim margin.

Lien has since filed two lawsuits challenging Chen's re-election victory and even the validity of the election. The Taiwan High Court is scheduled to hand down its judgment on the validity of Chen's re-election victory on Nov. 4.

Since the end of the election, Chang said, the OCAC has made strenuous efforts to communicate with overseas "pan-blue alliance" supporters, asking them to refrain from making unfounded allegations against the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration over the election disputes and to patiently wait for the court's verdict.

Except for a few radical "pan-blue alliance" stalwarts in the United States, Chang said, most overseas expatriate groups have stopped anti-government demonstrations for the sake of maintaining Taiwan's national image and sustainable development.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Vice Presidential Debate Gains New Importance; Republicans are depending on Cheney to halt slide in momentum.
Tomorrow's vice presidential debate, which both campaigns once presumed would be a sideshow to the presidential race, has assumed critical importance, with Republicans depending on Vice President Cheney to halt the ticket's slide in momentum.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC, FORMOSA BEING INVESTIGATED ON COLLUSION SUSPICIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two oil suppliers, Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and Formosa Petrochemical Corp. (FPCC) , are being investigated on suspicions of adjusting oil prices in collusion in recent years, the Fair Trade Commission chairman said Monday.

Fielding questions at the Executive Yuan, Hwang Tzong-leh said the government has begun probing possible collusion between the CPC and FPCC, which he said would be in violation of fair trade laws and consumers' rights.
The Fair Trade Commission has received numerous complaints from ordinary gas station customers that the CPC and FPCC have raised or lowered prices in sync 20 times since 2002, Hwang said.

He noted that solid evidence is required to enable the Fair Trade Commission to determine that the two companies have violated fair trade laws and to mete out penalties, adding that it will be difficult to prove the two companies worked in concert to manipulate domestic oil prices.

He added that the Fair Trade Commission will publicize the results of the investigations in three weeks and that a commission will then decide if and how the CPC and FPCC will be dealt with -- including possible fines ranging from NT$50,000 to NT$25 million.
The state-run CPC currently controls about 75 percent of the island's entire oil market. The FPCC has a 25-percent market share, with 525 gas stations islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT STREAMLINING TO BE DONE GRADUALLY: PERSONNEL HEAD

TEXT.P: Streamlining the central government will be done gradually and there will be no mass layoffs in the short term, Lee Yi-yang, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration (CPA), said Monday.

Lee made the remarks when he was fielding questions at a joint meeting of three committees in the Legislative Yuan to screen a draft bill concerning the total number of workers in the Central Government.

Under the draft bill, the total staff of the Presidential Office and the five government branches -- the Executive, the Legislative, the Judicial, the Examination and Control yuans -- should have a ceiling of 200,500, Lee noted.
He explained that the draft bill will move along the line of streamlining the staff as well as reforming the government so as to make the operations more flexible.

According to CPA officials, the number of central government-level staff has continued to decline over the past three years, down 3.45 percent, 5.6 percent and 1.7 percent in 2002, 2003 and 2004, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: After 3-day fight, U.S. and Iraqi forces retake Samarra
American and Iraqi forces in Samarra finished retaking the last insurgent-controlled neighborhood early Sunday, completing a relentless three-day push through this ancient city in a first step toward wresting control of important central Iraqi areas held by Sunni guerrillas. American commanders said they are beginning the second phase of the operation, turning over the city to the Iraqi police and military forces the same way they took it - one neighborhood at a time.
Wall Street Journal: Extra supply won't come in time to tame iImpact of US$50 crude on recovery
With oil having settled above US$50 a barrel for the first time, petroleum executives say the industry won't be able to bring on enough extra supply in time to significantly tame prices in the short term, due to long lead times needed to gin up new fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S LEGISLATIVE ADDRESS ON HOLD AS LAWMAKERS DISCUSS DETAILS

TEXT.P: Legislators on Monday failed to reach a consensus on President Chen Shui-bian's request to give a state-of-the-nation address in the Legislative Yuan and the chance of him delivering such a report soon seems remote.

Legislators across the political spectrum held another round of consultations Monday to discuss President Chen's request. As no conclusions were reached, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said that the matter will be turned over to the Rules Committee of the legislature to deal with. The legislature held the first consultation meeting last Thursday.

Since the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party dominates the Rules Committee, and given they have asked to amend legislative regulations so that delivering a state-of-the- nation address can be institutionalized, the chance of the president giving such an address before the year-end legislative elections, or Dec. 11, seems slim.

The caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) proposed inviting President Chen to give the address, hoping that the proposal could be passed quickly by the Rules Committee Tuesday so that it can be put on the legislature's agenda.

The president sent a letter to the Legislative Yuan Sept. 27 expressing his intention to give a state-of-the-nation address in the legislature on major national policies, such as arms procurements, Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and peaceful development between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. The president also asked the Legislative Yuan to arrange for him to give the address during the current session, which ends in December, as soon as possible.
If his request is accepted, Chen will become the first Republic of China president to deliver a state-of-the-nation address in the legislature.

The "pan-blue alliance" believes that it is up to the legislature to decide if the president can give the address and they want the rules of the legislature changed to make it possible for presidential addresses to governed by set rules.

The DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, for their part think that the president should have the right to take the initiative to ask for a state-of-the-nation address, and not have to wait for an invitation from the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: 2nd Leak Puts Fair Price on Yugansk.
Investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein has completed its valuation of core Yukos production unit Yuganskneftegaz, pricing it at between $15.7 billion and $17.3 billion, Interfax reported Friday. If confirmed, the range would bein line with market analysts' hopes for a fair valuation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST KEEP ABREAST OF ECONOMIC CHANGES IN CHINA: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan has to be aware of the changes taking place in mainland China's economy and the country's current trends if cross-strait economic and trade exchanges are to be peacefully developed, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said Monday.

Noting that Taiwan and mainland China have maintained inextricably close economic relations, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of over US$200 billion between 2000 and 2003, Hu said keeping abreast of changes in mainland China's economic situation is a vitally important task that the ROC government must undertake.

Speaking at a seminar on "Cross-strait Peace and Development" sponsored by the think tank Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, Hu said that while celebrating its expanding economy, mainland China is also facing challenges from economic globalization as well as other internal economic variables, which are poised to have an adverse impact on the development of cross-strait economic and trade relations.
As mainland China's economy matures, Taiwan could lose its competitive edge before long, Hu asserted.

In order not to lose out, he said, Taiwan should accelerate the 10 new major construction projects by 2008; advance the development of core, high-tech industries; upgrade the structure of industries; allow the private sector access to low-interest loans and taxation incentives; and help the industrial and service sectors to secure higher value-added production.

Taiwan enterprises continuously expanding and strengthening global operations to sharpen their international competitiveness would be another way of bolstering Taiwan's bargaining power to seek a cross-strait peace framework, Hu added.
Hu quoted CEPD tallies as indicating that currently there are about 40,000 to 50,000 Taiwan companies operating throughout mainland China, with investments totaling over US$70 billion.
Between 2000 and 2003, cross-strait trade totaled US$311 billion, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$201.3 billion, the CEPD statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGULAR TAICHUNG-SEOUL CHARTER FLIGHTS BEGIN AT CCK AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Regular charter flights between Taichung and Seoul will begin Tuesday, marking the start of international air travel service for Chingchuankang (CCK) International Airport in central Taiwan.

According to a spokesman for Mandarin Airlines, which operates the charter flights, the airlines will hold a ribbon-cutting ceremony Tuesday at the CCK Airport to celebrate the Seoul-bound flight, the first in 12 years between the two countries. The plane will take off at 2:30 p.m.
Scores of Mandarin Airlines officials and more than 100 passengers will take part in the ceremony and witness the historic event, the spokesman said.
Air links between Taiwan and South Korea were cut in 1992 after Seoul switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing earlier the same year.

Mandarin Airlines will use 108-seat FK-100 airplanes to ply the route, which will be a round trip in one day, with the return flight at 7: 10 p.m., he explained. Travel time is about two hours and 40 minutes.

The first Mandarin Airlines charter plane for Seoul will go fully loaded, while 95 percent of the seats on its return trip have been sold, bringing in some 100 tourists from South Korea, he said, adding that the South Korean visitors will sightsee for five days in central Taiwan -- a region famous and most frequented by local people for its resorts and tourist spots.
The Taichung-Seoul charter service will fly once every five days in the initial stage, and starting from Nov. 14 the service will be increased to twice a week on every Wednesday and Sunday.
The Taipei-based aviation company has begun arrangements for a charter service in November from CCK International Airport to Japan.

In view of the warm public response for the Seoul-bound charter service, local travel agencies are optimistic about making the CCK airport a transshipment center of charter flights in Taiwan by offering more services to destinations in Japan and countries in Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PEACE BREEDS WEALTH' SAYS TAIWAN BUSINESS LEADER

TEXT.P: One of Taiwan's business leaders on Monday called for friendliness and reconciliation across the Taiwan Strait for sustainable development in cross-strait relations.

From a businessman's point of view, peace is the supreme principle of all conduct, said Huang Mao-hsiung, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, one of the largest and most influential organizations of businessmen in Taiwan.
Saying that "peace breeds wealth," Huang called for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to try to defuse military tensions and reduce hostility when making economic policies.

Speaking at a seminar on "Cross-strait Peace and Development" sponsored by the think tank Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, Huang offered seven tips to "breed wealth" by achieving cross-strait peace.
First, Huang called for the mainland Chinese authorities to allow Taiwan and mainland Chinese companies to maintain separate but complementary operations for producing at lower prices.
Second, Huang called for rulers from both sides not to force civilian businessmen to take sides or make known their political affiliation.
Third, he said unfair trade barriers and discriminatory economic policies should be stopped.

Other tips include having both sides cooperate under the World Trade Organization framework and help each other face dumping charges or other unfair competition from countries beyond Taiwan and mainland China and encourage both sides to enter regional free trade arrangements, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR FALLS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, losing NT$0.064 to close at the day's low of NT$33.876.
A total of US$530 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.921 and fluctuated between NT$33.876 and NT$33.965.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SURGE ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose above the 6,000-point barrier Monday on positive reports such as the central bank's move to raise interest rates and a surge in U.S. stock prices, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 132.61 points to close at 6,077.96.
The bourse opened at 6,020.68 and fluctuated between 6,012.92 and 6,084.31 during trading. A total of 6.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$147.35 billion (US$4.35 billion).

All eight major stock categories posted gains, with financial issues increasing the most by 3.3 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares by 2.4 percent, textile issues by 2.1 percent, construction issues by 1.9 percent, paper and pulp stocks by 1.7 percent, cement stocks by 1.6 percent, plastic and chemical shares by 1.1 percent and foodstuff shares by 0.9 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 586 to 117, with 123 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Poll troulbe for Tories as Blair bounces back.
Michael Howard and the Conservatives start their conference today in a worse position in the polls than a year ago, a month before Iain Duncan Smith was forced out as leader. A new Populus poll for the Times unerlines how large a mountain the Tories stall to climb to be credible challengers at the next election, even though party activists will be told today that they are already set to win enough target seats to deny Labour a majority.
Financial Times: Brown leads call for unity.
Gordon Brown and John Prescott yesterday called on Labour to unite in the run-up to the next general election as they sought to stabilize the government after Tony Blair's vow to serve a full third term if re-elected. As the prime minister prepares to return to work today following last week's treatment for a heart flutter, the chancellor urged the party not to become "distracted" by speculation over the Labour leadership.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market rose Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 158 points to close at 6,105, with 31,836 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November gained 163 points to finish at 6,100, with 341 contract transactions, while December futures increased 159 points to close at 6,088, with 28 contracts traded.
June futures surged 153 points to finish at 6,011, with 10 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,947 points for October, 5,937 points for November, 5,929 points for December, 5,885 for March and 5,858 points for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
October TE futures moved up 6.65 points to close at 225.55, with 8,663 contracts changing hands, while November TE futures increased 6.5 points to finish at 225, with 204 contract transactions.

December futures gained 5.45 points to close at 223.2, with three contracts changing hands and March TE futures surged 6.5 points to close at 223.5, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.
October TF futures moved up 35 points to finish at 1,040, with 8,331 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures increased 35 points to close at 1,036, with 319 contracts traded.

December TF futures gained 34 points to finish at 1,031, with six contract transactions, while March TF futures gained 36.2 points to close at 1,020, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO GIVE MAJOR SPEECH ON DOUBLE TEN NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: The public can expect a major speech by President Chen Shui-bian on the Republic of China National Day on Oct. 10, Vice President Annette Lu said Monday.

Lu's spoke a day after President Chen said that for Taiwan's long-term security and the normalization of cross-strait relations, he would deliver a major speech, which will include a response to the May 17 statement by mainland China, in which a "carrot-and-stick" approach was adopted.

Beijing issued the statement three days before the inauguration of President Chen for his second term May 20 in which it sternly warned against advocating Taiwan independence, saying doing so would be playing with fire. At the same time, the statement offered to resume cross-strait dialogue, build a mechanism for mutual trust and settle the issue of Taiwan's maneuvering space in the international community commensurate with its status through contacts and consultations.
President Chen reaffirmed Monday that he hoped his speech will help ease cross-strait tensions, saying, "There is no need for rivalry between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."
The vice president said that cross-strait relations are like relations between the genders and should be based on the principle of "peace, mutual benefit and equality."

Lu also said that Beijing's May 17 statement excluded its favorite rhetoric of national unification, use of force against Taiwan, and the "one country, two systems" formula for unification, which could be construed as a gesture of goodwill.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY PROJECTED TO GROW BY 4.5 PERCENT FOR 2005: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will grow by a moderate 4.5 percent in 2005 due to a slowed global economic expansion, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng predicted Monday.
The CEPD chief made the forecast while reporting at the Legislative Yuan.

Pointing out that the domestic economy will perform less brilliantly in 2005 than it has this year, Hu attributed the lower economic growth rate to weaker international demand as a result of high oil prices and interest rate hikes.
Although continued high oil prices in the global market has fueled inflationary pressures, Hu claimed that the overall impact on Taiwan has eased due to the changes in its industrial structure.
Citing estimates by Global Insight, Inc., Hu said that the world economy will grow by 3.4 percent in 2005, a slide from the 4.1 percent forecast for this year.

However, he explained that spurred by the government's investment in public construction and private-sector investments at home, the country will still be able to manage a moderate economic growth rate of 4.5 percent next year.

According to assessments made in August by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the domestic economy will expand by 5.87 percent for the whole of this year, up by 2.56 percentage points over the 2003 level and its best performance since the 1997 Asian financial crisis.

In contrast to a continued decline over the past three years, consumer product prices in the domestic market in the first eight months of this year were higher than the previous year's levels by 1.37 percent.
Hu ascribed this year's higher commodity prices to rising oil prices and the devastation caused by recent typhoons, factors that have noticeably pushed up vegetable and fruit prices.
He said that domestic farm produce prices are unlikely to continue climbing, as they have started showing signs of decline in recent weeks with the new harvest hitting markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU URGED TO PASS LAW MODELED ON TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT

TEXT.P: The European Union should pass a law similar to the U.S. Taiwan Relations Act to establish a foundation for closer ties, the head of Taiwan's top mainland China policy agency said Monday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks while meeting with a group of officials from the European Union Commission.

Wu noted that the U.S. Congress passed the Taiwan Relations Act in 1979 after the United States severed diplomatic relations with the Republic of China. The law has since become the major document governing relations between the U.S. and Taiwan in the absent of official ties.

The Taiwan Relations Act, among other things, says: "The United States will make available to Taiwan such defense articles and defense services in such quantity as may be necessary to enable Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability."
Wu expressed the hope that the EU would consider passing a similar law.
Wu also explained to the visiting officials that mainland China's military intimidation and diplomatic blockade of Taiwan will only have negative effects on cross-strait peace.
Instead, mainland China should remove its missiles targeting Taiwan and end its diplomatic boycott to facilitate peaceful and stable development between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Wu said.
He said that the EU should understand that human rights in mainland China are poorly protected, and Beijing has not given up its threat of the use of force against Taiwan.

The EU should cautiously assess the possibility of lifting an arms embargo against mainland China that was put into place after the bloody 1989 Tiananmen Massacre, so that the military balance across the Taiwan Strait is not changed in Beijing's favor, Wu said.
During the meeting, Wu also exchanged views with the guests on various situations in Asia and future cooperation between Taiwan and the EU.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PITCHES FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-JAPAN COOPERATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday there is ample room for Taiwan and Japan to cooperate in forging a comprehensive Asian security mechanism or promoting Asia-Pacific economic development.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of Taiwan and Japanese scholars attending the 2004 Taiwan-Japan Forum on Asia-Pacific Regional Security Issues, which opened in Taipei a day earlier.
During the meeting, Chen lamented that mainland China has consistently attempted to exclude Taiwan from regional security cooperative mechanisms and economic dialogue frameworks.
As a matter of fact, Chen said, Taiwan's participation in those fields would contribute greatly to regional economic prosperity and peaceful dialogue.
Touching on recent developments in Taiwan and Japan, Chen said he sees similarities in the two countries' pursuit of constitutional reforms and a greater role in the international community.

"I have noticed that there have been many discussions in Japan in recent years about constitutional amendments that would allow Japan to become a 'normal country' and play a more active role in world affairs, " Chen said, adding that Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's appeal for a permanent seat for Japan in the U.N. Security Council in a speech at the just-concluded U.N. General Assembly symbolized Japan's desire for a greater role in the international arena. The current Japanese constitution imposes strict restrictions on the country's military buildup.
In his view, Chen said, Japan is mulling new ways and new strategies to shed its historical shackles and face up to the challenges of the 21st Century.
Likewise, he went on, Taiwan is also re-thinking its national identity now that it has succeeded in its political democratization and economic take-off.

"We look forward to becoming a normal and complete country by writing a new constitution that fits our status quo and facilitates the upgrading of our administrative efficiency and overall national competitiveness, " Chen said, referring to his constitutional re-engineering plan.
Amid the wave of economic liberalization and globalization, Chen said, the people of Taiwan also yearn to take part in international organizations and activities.
"We are more than willing to share our economic and democratic development experiences and work hand-in-hand with other countries to promote the common well-being of all mankind," Chen said.
The president further said that Taiwan and Japan not only have similar development experiences but also have shared geopolitical and strategic interests.

Noting that Taiwan and Japan will be the most-affected countries by several major developments in the Asia-Pacific region in recent years, such as the rise of China as an economic powerhouse, Chen said the two countries should cooperate even more closely in security affairs and economic development for their mutual benefit.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW JIA KAOHSIUNG CHIEF MEETS WITH MAYOR

TEXT.P: Japan is more than willing to assist Kaohsiung in organizing the 2009 World Games, Yasuo Makita, director of the Kaohsiung office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), said Monday.

Makita made the remarks during a courtesy call on Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh. The JIA is a quasi-official organization authorized by the Japanese government to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

In his first meeting with Hsieh since assuming office last week, Makita said Japan would offer counseling to Kaohsiung in organizing the 2009 World Games, an international contest for events not included in the Olympic Games. The 2001 World Games took place in the northern Japanese prefecture of Akita.

Makita once worked in Kaohsiung 34 years ago. "I have fond memories of my work experience in the city. I take great pleasure in being able to work in Kaohsiung again after all these years. I have worked in 11 different countries and I think Kaohsiung people are among those who are most familiar with Japanese culture," he said.

At present, Kaohsiung has about 1,500 Japanese expatriates and Makita said they are grateful for the Kaohsiung city government's concern and assistance for them, particularly in the education of their 180-plus children.
Makita assured Hsieh that he will do his utmost to promote exchanges and cooperation between Kaohsiung and Japan during his tenure.

For his part, Hsieh said the city government has given priority to promoting the high-tech industry and tourism. "We will step up efforts to attract more tourists from Japan, South Korea and Southeast Asian countries," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH 19 SHOOTING INVESTIGATION COMMISSION BEGINS OPERATION

TEXT.P: A commission to probe the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu held its first meeting Monday amid calls for a boycott by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The 10 members of the commission -- nine people recommended by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party and one suggested by the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union -- convened the meeting at the Legislative Yuan following the passage of a special statute authorizing the commission in August.

Shih Chi-yang, a former Judicial Yuan president who was elected convener, claimed that the commission will act in "an impartial manner" and hopes to complete an investigative report within three to six months.

Shih said the election-eve shooting had a big impact on the nation's image and added that "the dignity and image of the president and the vice president is the dignity and image of the Taiwan people."
"The president should not shoulder so much misunderstanding, " Shih said, adding that the perpetrator must be found early and brought to justice.
He also said the commission will act in a supra-political party manner, and will not suffer interference by any government agencies.
"The commission will conduct its investigation in a way that conforms to the Constitution and the law," he claimed.

He noted that many people have tried to block the formation of the commission, saying it is unconstitutional and illegal, but according to Shih, the constitutionality should be left for an interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices. He also said that it is "too early" to say if its operation violates the law.
But to "assuage the misgivings of others, " he suggested that the legislature should simply revise the law.

Wang Ching-feng, spokeswoman of the commission and a former Control Yuan member, said the commission plans to interview Tainan Prosecutor's Office and Criminal Investigation Bureau officials this week and to invite National Security Bureau members for a briefing next week.
She also said that the Executive Yuan should pay for the commission and provide administrative resources.
Meanwhile, the DPP reaffirmed that the commission is both unconstitutional and illegal and that the Executive Yuan will not accede to its requests or appropriate a budget for its operation.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , a DPP ally, said it opposes the operation of the commission before the Council of Grand Justices returns a verdict on the constitutionality of the bill.

The opposition-dominated legislature passed the special statute authorizing the establishment of the commission in August, upon which the Executive Yuan requested a reconsideration. After failing to overturn the bill, the DPP caucus in the legislature then asked the Council of Grand Justices for an interpretation of its constitutionality.

According to the special statute, the commission should have 17 members, chosen by the various parties in proportion to their legislative representation. The DPP and the TSU have refused to recommend anyone to sit on the commission, saying the law encroaches on judicial and prosecutor's rights and is a serious violation of human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS CASH IN ON TAIWAN SHARES

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices were sharply higher Monday on the back of strong buying by foreign investors, who bought domestic stocks with a net value of NT$15.362 billion (US$4.52 billion) during the day's trading, according to the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).

The figure -- a gap between the NT$26.358 billion worth of shares they bought and the NT$10.996 billion worth of shares they sold -- represents the seventh-highest level for a single day in the TAIEX history, the tallies show.
The weighted index, the key barometer for the domestic stock market, jumped by 132.61 points to break the 6,000-point level by finishing at 6,077.96. Market turnover expanded to NT$147.345 billion.

Market watchers said that the domestic bourse is expected to gain momentum in the peak fourth quarter, to be fueled by the effects of a Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) announcement in late June that it will increase the inclusion weight of the MSCI Taiwan Index from 75 percent in late November to 100 percent in May 2005.
Financial and hi-tech DRAM shares are targets worthy of investment, they said.
According to TAIEX statistics, foreign institutional investors purchased Taiwan shares last week with a total value of NT$42.291 billion, outstripping the NT$31.815 billion worth of shares they sold.
The imbalance of NT$10.476 billion brings the total gap to NT$109.774 billion in Taiwan shares' favor for the year ending Oct. 1.

Foreign investors currently hold Taiwan shares worth a total of NT$2.8484 trillion, an increase of NT$45.5 billion over the Sept. 24 level of NT$2.8029 trillion and accounting for 21.72 percent of the overall scale of the domestic stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC STEPS UP MONITORING FOR YEAR-END LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will ask local election commissions to carefully select polling station staff to handle the election operations that kicked off Monday for the year-end legislative elections.
The CEC has also instructed the head of each polling station to rigorously follow the guidelines and review the voting procedures.
The CEC, taking its cue from the controversy surrounding alleged voting irregularities in the March 20 presidential election, wants to avoid possible errors in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
All legislative candidates can get registration forms at their local election commissions until Oct. 12, and can submit their registrations Oct. 8-12.
CEC officials said candidates must fill out the necessary forms, prepare certification and deposit NT$200,000 (US$5,920) when registering with the local election commissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REBUTS RICHARD GERE'S COMMENTS ON MARCH 19 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday rebutted Hollywood movie star Richard Gere's comments on the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian as "not circumspect."

KMT spokeswoman Kuo Shu-chun made the remarks after Gere told Taiwan's TVBS cable TV channel that he did not believe Chen staged the shooting that grazed his stomach on the campaign trail on the eve of the March 20 presidential election in which he won re-election by a slim margin. It was not clear why Gere's opinions were being sought on the issue.
"What I thought was kind of bizarre was that the opposition assumed that he had set it up, in some way had himself shot, " Gere said. "That doesn't sound right."
Gere was promoting his latest film, "Shall We Dance? " when he talked to TVBS in the United States. TVBS broadcast Gere's interview Monday.
In response, Kuo claimed that Gere's comments reflect an "insufficient understanding" of Taiwan.

"As Gere just read media reports about the incident, he was unable to gain a full understanding of suspicious behind-the-scenes maneuvering in Taiwan's presidential election. He shouldn't make judgment purely based on his impression of Taiwan during his previous visit, " Kuo argued, adding that she hopes foreigners can focus on whether the principles of fairness and justice prevail while commenting on Taiwan's presidential election disputes.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who narrowly lost to Chen in the bitterly fought presidential election, insinuated that Chen might have staged the shooting to win sympathy votes. Although he has offered no evidence to support his allegations, he has filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory and even the validity of the election.

Law enforcement authorities have not yet arrested any suspects in the assassination attempt and have not announced many solid leads. The Taiwan High Court is scheduled to hand down a judgment Nov. 4 on whether Chen's re-election victory should be nullified because of the shooting and other allegations of irregularities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL SEMINAR ON BLOCK GAUGE APPLICATIONS OPENS IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: An international seminar on the application of block gauges opened in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Monday with the participation of experts from more than 10 countries.

The seminar, jointly organized by the Asia Pacific Metrology Programme (APMP), the National Measurement Laboratory of the Republic of China, the Center for Measurement Standards under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and the ITRI College, is aimed at promoting international exchanges of measurement technology and establishing an international training platform for measurement technology.
Experts from Japan, Mexico, Switzerland, Egypt, Fiji, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and Taiwan are taking part in the three-day meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF CENTRAL GOVERNMENT PERSONNEL CAPPED AT 200,000

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Monday a draft act in the first reading that would cap the number of central government personnel at 200,000.
The draft act was passed during a joint screening meeting of the legislature's home and nations, organic laws and statutes and budget and final accounts committees.

Under the terms of the bill, the total number of personnel in central government agencies, including police, coast guard patrols and public senior high school teachers, must not exceed the level of 200,000 and must be trimmed by 2,000 each year to reach the level of 190,000 in five years after the act is signed into law and takes effect.

According to Central Personnel Administration Director-General Lee Yi-yang, the number of central government staff totals about 193,000 at present and the administration hopes to keep the total number below the 200,000 mark to build a neat and efficient government.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE MINISTER REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO SELF-DEFENSE AT U.S. MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Phoenix, Arizona, Oct. 4 (CNA) (BY Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's commitment to defending itself against any invasion has remained firm and unchanged, Vice Minister of National Defense Houh Shoou-yeh said Monday at the opening of an annual Taiwan-U.S. defense industry conference.

"Although different opinions may arise in the policy formulation and budget screening process following Taiwan's democratization, we'll never waver on our determination to defend our national security," Houh said.

Houh was referring to a special NT$610.8 billion budget bill that will cover the cost for purchasing six PAC III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-powered submarines, and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States. The bill is pending legislative approval and has drawn a heated debate in Taiwan society. Some private groups have spoken loudly against the package.
In the face of mainland China's growing missile threat, Houh said Taiwan needs the new arsm package to beef up its defense capabilities.

Houh is heading a Taiwan delegation of military officials and defense strategists to attend the conference, the third of its kind. Former Vice Defense Minister Lin Chong-pin will deliver a keynote speech at the meeting.

Senior U.S. officials, including Deputy Asistant Secretary of State Randall Schiver, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard Lawlless and Daniel Blumenthal, a Pentagon division chief in charge of China affairs, will attend the conference.

The meeting is organized by the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council. Rupert Hammond-Chambers, the council's president, said 20 percent of the participants are Taiwan government officials, 20 percent are U.S. government officials and the remaining 60 percent are U.S. defense contractors and scholars.

As lawmakers have played an increasingly important role in Taiwan's defense policy formulation, Hammond-Chambers said the council will invite Taiwan's legislators from across the political spectrum to attend the conference next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RESPOND ON CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: In a bid to invite a positive response from Beijing on the opening of talks on cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services for the coming Lunar New Year holiday, a government official said Monday that Taiwan is willing to send a negotiator acceptable to both sides for talks in mainland China.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks at an unofficial gathering with mainland-based Taiwan businessmen who were home to spend the recent Mid-Autumn Festival.

Claiming that Taiwan is very willing to dispatch such a person to exchange views and opinions on the issue with relevant mainland authorities, Wu, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner, reiterated the call for a quick response from Beijing to clear the way for related arrangements.
Taiwan is open to holding the talks in a flexible fashion so as to make the homebound trips of Taiwan businessmen easier by offering exclusive charter flight services, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD ASSUAGE CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Mainland China should take steps to assuage cross-Taiwan Strait tension, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday.

The premier made the remarks when he spoke to around 300 Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China who had returned for the mid-Autumn Festival holiday and met in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan for an annual autumn gathering.
Yu said cross-strait peace must be built on the basis of mutual respect and that peace will not be achieved by pressuring Taiwan.
The mainland's military buildup and its increased deployment of missiles against Taiwan are the major causes of the present cross-strait tension, according to the premier.
It is up to the mainland, not Taiwan, to assuage the tension, he added.

To promote cross-strait exchanges, the premier said the Executive Yuan will follow the guidelines set by President Chen Shui-bian in his May 20 inauguration speech and will continue to promote mutually beneficial trade exchanges, including the easing of restrictions on mainland businessmen visiting Taiwan, opening of Taiwan to mainlanders for tourism, allowing more mainland products into Taiwan and promoting consultation on direct cross-strait transport links.

The premier also instructed the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and related government agencies to help the estimated 500,000 to 1 million Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland and their dependents to return to Taiwan for Chinese New Year, which will include the expansion of the transport links between Fujian Province and the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, as well as charter flight services during the holiday.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said that Taiwan is willing to send delegates to the mainland to exchange views with Beijing on the charter flight services, which were launched two years ago on a trial basis, but only Taiwan carriers were allowed to operate the service, and they had to travel via a third location such as Macau or Hong Kong.

The mainland has demanded that mainland carriers be allowed to offer the cross-strait charter flights on a non-stop basis during the holiday period. The MAC has said that it does not rule out the possibility of such flights, although both sides have to discuss related matters.
Two-way cross-strait charter flights were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday season due to Beijing's refusal to engage in bilateral consultations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPE RECEIVES ROC HEALTH MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Huang Kwang-chun)

Chen arrived in Rome last Saturday for a four-day visit.
The pope received the Chens after officiating at a ceremony at St. Peter's Square and blessed the 23 million people of Taiwan.
During his stay in Rome, Chen will meet Vatican officials and visit cultural establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 5, or the 22nd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1830: Chester A. Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, is born. Arthur became president after the assassination of James A. Garfield.
1908: Bulgaria declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire with Ferdinand I assuming the title of czar of Bulgaria.
1922: Tsao Kun is elected president of the Peking government.
1930: The first Balkan Conference is held in Athens, with representatives from countries from the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey taking part.
1941: Chinese forces heavily defeat Japanese invaders near the Milo River in northern Hunan Province, killing or wounding nearly 80,000 Japanese troops.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek accepts General George C. Marshall's proposal for a 10-day cease-fire to pave the way for a resumption of peace talks. Marshall arrived in Chungking on Dec. 22, 1945 as U.S. President Harry Truman's special envoy.
1951: The Republic of China's Legislative Yuan passes regulations providing farmland to soldiers.
1958: The United States delivers a batch of "Hercules" ground-to-air missiles, known in Taiwan as the "Goddess of Victory" missiles, to help improve the ROC's national defense.
1970 Anwar Sadat becomes the president of Egypt following the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Togo.
1973: Taiwan's first case of coronary artery surgery is performed at National Taiwan University Hospital.
1974: The third World Chinese Christian Conference opens in Taipei.
1976: The fifth World Chinese Tourism Amity Conference opens in Taipei with E. T. Chu, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors' Association, presiding.
1978: More than 20,000 boy scouts and brownies from Taiwan and 10 foreign countries launch an eight-day series of camping activities in the 5th National Jamboree held in Kaohsiung.
1980: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi arrives in Taipei to take part in the 16th Conference of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1983: Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: Premier Lee Huan instructs the Executive Yuan to set up special task forces to study problems concerning law and order, communications, environmental pollution, public housing, and economic crimes.
1991: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev pledges to match the United States in scraping tactical nuclear weapons.
1991: Cheng Kung, the first guided missile frigate built in Taiwan, is launched.
1993: Communist China breaks its moratorium on nuclear testing.
1996: Some 50 countries adopt a declaration calling for the earliest possible agreement on a global ban on anti-personnel land mines.
1998: The Judiciary Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives votes to recommend an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton's action during the Monica Lewinsky case.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill in favor of Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the World Health Organization.
2000: Hung Chien-hsiung, a 27-year-old man, donates 60 percent of his liver to his father in a transplant operation that is the only way to save the older man's life.
2001: Gao Xingjian, who won the Nobel Prize in literature in 2000 -- the first Chinese writer to win the prestigious award, shows his other talent by opening an exhibition of his paintings in Taipei.
2001: Republic of China Presdient Chen Shui-bian receives visiting U.S. economist Lester Thurow, exchanging views with him on the economic problems faced by Taiwan and the rest of the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The fact that a man is able to confront the spiritual powers of the universe without any doubt, shows that he understands the will of God. The fact that he is prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the man of perfect divine nature without any misgiving, shows that he understands the nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BOASTS 713 CENTENARIANS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has 713 centenarians, with an average age of 101.7, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Tuesday in connection with the approach of the Double Ninth Festival.
The festival, also known as the Chong Yang Festival, which falls on Oct. 22 this year, has been set aside to honor senior citizens in Taiwan since 1966.
According to the MOI report, the oldest citizen in Taiwan is a 120-year-old woman, and the oldest man is now 109 years old. Both currently reside in Taipei.
The number of centenarians increased by 57 from the 2003-level, the report said, adding that 91.4 percent of the centenarians are aged between 100 and 104.
Women account for 496, or 69.6 percent, of the total number of centenarians in Taiwan, representing 2.3 times the number of male centenarians.
By area, Taipei City boasts the largest number of centenarians at 150, followed by Taipei County at 100 and Taoyuan County at 59.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAX INCREASE BEFORE YEAR'S END: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that the government has no plans to increase taxes before the end of this year.
The premier made the remarks while fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan by Legislator Lo Shih-hsiung of the opposition Kuomintang.

Lo asked if the administration has any plans to increase taxes at a time when the life of the average citizen is already getting tougher due to soaring oil prices and reported increases in transportation and commodity prices.

The premier said the tax reform committee under the Executive Yuan did suggest a tax adjustment, but the Executive Yuan currently has no plans to increase taxes ahead of the year-end legislative elections, which are scheduled for Dec. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CALLS FOR NO RASH OPENING OF DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT LINKS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian must not act rashly and open direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait at the expense of a majority of average local citizens, an opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) caucus legislator said Tuesday.

Chen Chien-ming, deputy convener of the TSU legislative caucus, made the appeal amid reports that the Cabinet plans to open direct two-way cross-strait passenger and cargo flight services and that President Chen will announce this an other major cross-strait policy initiatives in his upcoming Double Ten National Day address.

To the best of his understanding, Chen Chien-ming said, the Presidential Office received information in September from the other side of the Taiwan Strait that the two sides can negotiate direct cross-strait shipping and air links.

Chen Chien-ming claimed that Kuo Tai-chiang, president of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development, a private trade association, has been acting as messenger for the proposed cross-strait negotiations.

"We are afraid that such negotiations would mainly be based on the interests of business people rather than on the overall interests of the nation, " Chen Chien-ming alleged, adding that a rash opening of direct cross-strait transportation links could exacerbate capital and personnel flows from Taiwan to mainland China.

Should that be the case, Chen Chien-ming warned that Taiwan's industries will hollow out and its unemployment rate will get worse. Chen Chien-ming reminded President Chen that he should honor his campaign promise to give top priority to safeguarding Taiwan's separate national identity in dealing with cross-strait issues.

"The president should insist on negotiating with Beijing through official channels on an equal footing, " Chen Chien-ming said, adding that Taiwan should stand firm on defining cross-strait shipping and air links as "special state-to-state" routes in such talks.

Chen Chien-ming also urged the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration not to commission any "secret envoys" to negotiate direct cross-strait transportation links because such moves violate the government's basic policy of "official authorization" and the principle of transparency in all cross-strait dealings.

"We have the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation to handle cross-strait affairs. The DPP administration should refrain from authorizing any private organization or individual to handle direct air and shipping links negotiations with Beijing that would avoid legislative and public supervision," Chen Chien-ming added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

The Times: You can trust me, Tory leader vows.
Michael Howard will today pitch for the trust of the British people with a promise to sack any minister who fails to meet pledges made by an incoming Tory government.
In his first conference speech as leader, Mr Howard will call for a new era of accountability in politics. Conservative ministers would have a timetable for action and no "wiggle room."
Financial Times: Rapid rise in corporate returns.
Corporate profits grew at their fastest rate in almost five years in the second quarter, official figures showed yesterday, amid growing signs that earnings among listed UK companies may have peaked.
The net rate of return for non-financial companies rose 13.8 percent in the second quarter, the Office for National Statistics reported yesterday, up from 13.2 percent in the previous three months - the highest figure since the final quarter of 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEYSER'S CASE WILL NOT IMPEDE INVITATIONS TO U.S. FOR DOUBLE TEN DAY

TEXT.P: The recent case involving a former U.S. State Department official and two Taiwan National Security Bureau (NSB) staff is irrelevant in relation to inviting U.S. dignitaries to attend the Oct. 10 ROC National Day celebrations, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Victor Chin, director-general of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, was referring to the case involving Donald Keyser, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific Affairs, and two NSB intelligence operatives posted in Washington, D.C.

Keyser was recently arrested by the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of concealing a trip he made to Taiwan last September and was later released on US$500,000 bond. Media reports said Keyser was also found to have passed files to the two Taiwan operatives.
Chin said that the case has nothing to do with inviting former U.S. government officials and congressmen to Taiwan to attend the Double Ten celebrations.
Meanwhile, Chin also said that MOFA will continue to assist the Ministry of National Defense in communicating with the U.S. on the proposed arms procurement.

Chin said members of the think tank Atlantic Council of the United States said during a recent visit to Taiwan that if the Legislative Yuan does not approve a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) special budget for arms procurement from the United States mainly for six PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-powered submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, it will certainly have an impact on Taiwan-U.S. relations.

He said MOFA has no way of knowing if the arms procurement proposal will be approved by the legislature, but he is sure that the U.S. will understand the government's efforts and sincerity in promoting the arms deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET
