DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HAVE AT LEAST SEVEN FREE TRADE HARBOR ZONES BY 2008

TEXT.P: Taiwan has to actively promote free trade harbor zones to improve the island's edge in global logistics, and it is estimated that by 2008, there will be at least seven such zones, an official from the nation's top economic planning agency said Tuesday.
The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) official said that faced with the globalization, global logistics management will be the cornerstone of many enterprises.

To keep Taiwan's edge in global logistics, the government will have to actively promote free trade harbor zones, creating the zones in international harbors or areas around the airports, waiving custom tariffs and commodity and business taxes, streamlining the flow of goods within the zones to create benefits from transshipments and increasing industries' high value-added products, the CEPD official said.

The official said that harbor authorities in Kaohsiung, Keelung, Taichung and Taipei, as well as some export processing zones, have already applied to set up free trade harbor zones. Among them, Keelung and Kaohsiung harbors have already been approved by the Executive Yuan to operate this month and in January 2005, respectively.
There are 10 export processing zones in Taiwan, the official said, and it is estimated that at least two will be transformed into free trade harbors.

Even by the most conservative estimates, there will be seven free trade zones by 2008 in Taiwan, with 1,000 manufacturers stationed in them, employing 31,000 people and creating a value of NT$162.5 billion (US$4.779 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN PLANS TO SUE KMT OVER ILL-GOTTEN PROPERTIES

TEXT.P: The government will file a lawsuit against the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) unless it returns all the properties it obtained through unlawful means, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Tuesday.

In an effort to prevent the KMT from selling the properties to a third party, Chen said Premier Yu Shyi-kun has ordered that a "retroactive clause" be added to a bill aimed at restoring the properties, which will subject whoever owns the properties to the legal responsibility of returning them to the government.

Chen accused the KMT of attempting to "cheat the world" by claiming that it has returned 80 percent of these properties, pointing out that there is a big difference of opinion between the KMT and the Control Yuan on the number of properties that are supposed to belong to the government.

According to the Control Yuan's report, the KMT appropriated from the government or took over from the Japanese colonial government a total of 114 pieces of land, but the KMT claims only 24 pieces of land and five buildings were obtained in this manner, Chen said.
Of the properties in this category, the KMT has only returned 10 pieces of land and two houses, he said.

Regarding the cinemas taken over by the KMT from the Japanese colonial government, the Control Yuan determined there are 19 of them, but the KMT only promised before the March 20 presidential election to return seven, Chen said.
While the KMT has never honored its promise, Chen said, it sold the Lotung Cinema in Ilan County in May.
In another category, properties presented by local governments to the KMT total 123 as shown in the Control Yuan report, compared with 134 counted by the KMT, Chen said.
He said the KMT has returned 80 percent of the properties in this category but has refused to return another 191 pieces of land and 32 buildings purchased by KMT-controlled media.

If the KMT still shows no intention of returning the remaining properties during a fresh round of negotiations with the Ministry of Finance on Thursday, the Executive Yuan will take legal action against the party, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S NATIONAL DAY SPEECH WILL FOCUS ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES: YU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian's National Day speech will focus on the promotion of exchanges and peace between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Yu made the remarks in response to questions by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lo Shih-hsiung, who asked whether Yu, who plays a role in Chen's planning on policies toward mainland China, knows the exact content of the president's Oct. 10 National Day speech.
The premier said that he only knew the outline of the speech, not the details.
Noting that Taiwan's military strategy is "effective deterrence and resolute defense, " Yu stressed that the island has no intention of engaging in an arms race with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Total Officials in Bribes Probe.
Executives at French oil major Total have been detained for questioning as part of an investigation into transfers of millions of dollars in suspected bribes to win oil development rights in Russia and Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: At least 26 die as three car bombs explode in Iraq.
Three powerful car bombs exploded across Iraq on Monday morning, killing at least 26 people and wounding more than 100 others in a day of carnage that demonstrated the relative ease with which insurgents are striking in the hearts of major citie. The first blasts hit Baghdad, where two suicide car bombs exploded within an hour of each other, one on either side of the Tigris River. The bomb in the west detonated after a car loaded with explosives rammed into a recruiting center for Iraqi plainclothes police officers. The attack took place near a checkpoint to the fortified headquarters of the interim Iraqi government and the American Embassy.
Wall Street Journal: As election nears, counting the vote faces new pitfalls.
Four years after electoral chaos in Florida sent the Bush-Gore presidential battle to the Supreme Court, sparring is erupting around the country over the very procedures intended to prevent a repeat, even as some familiar problems loom just weeks before Election Day. A new federal election law that was meant to bring more uniformity to locally run elections is itself spawning a patchwork of inconsistent policies in different states. Language in the law allowing voters to cast "provisional votes" when their registration is in doubt has already set off legal battles over which provisional ballots will ultimately be counted. New voting technology has sparked debates over the possibility of computer hacking, even as the infamous punch-card machines, outlawed in Florida and elsewhere, are still in use in parts of 22 states.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER SUPPORTS JAPAN'S BID FOR UNSC PERMANENT SEAT

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday he supports Japan's bid to become a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council (UNSC).
The minister made the remarks after meeting with Chen Hung-chi, Taiwan's new deputy representative to Japan, who left for Tokyo to assume his new post the same day.
Chen said that during his recent visit to the United States, he was asked about his view on Japan's quest for a UNSC permanent seat.
"I told my U.S. hosts that I support Japan's bid and will be pleased to see Japan enter the Security Council as a permanent member," Chen said.
Chen pointed out that Japan donates 20 percent of the annual U.N. budget and has had outstanding economic achievements over the past decades.

"The world should not continue to restrict Japan's role in international affairs due to its aggressive military action 60 years ago. I think the United Nations should work out a more reasonable UNSC organic framework with Japan, Germany, India and Brazil being given permanent seats," Chen said.

Regardless of the fact that the Republic of China lost its U.N. seat in 1971, Chen said that since the ROC was a founding member of the world body, Taiwan could possibly help Japan's efforts to obtain a permanent seat, but the issue would need further study.

Meanwhile, Chang Fu-mei, chairwoman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, also gave moral support to Japan's quest for a UNSC permanent seat on the grounds that Japan has on many international occasions spoken for Taiwan's cause and that the two countries have traditionally maintained close relations.
Chang said Japan cast a "yes" vote in the World Health Assembly -- the World Health Organization's governing body -- held in Geneva in May on Taiwan's bid to join the organization as an observer.

Quoting the result of a recent public opinion poll conducted by the Japanese daily newspaper Mainichi Shimbun, Chang said 81 percent of Japanese citizens responding to the survey gave a thumbs-up to Taiwan's goal of U.N. representation. The poll results indicate that a majority of Japanese people support Taiwan's pursuit of greater "international space," Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN RESEARCH UNIVERSITIES TO MEET IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Members of the Association of East Asian Research Universities (AEARU) are scheduled to meet Oct. 6-9 in Taiwan, organizers said Tuesday.

More than 40 representatives from 17 member universities in Taiwan, mainland China, Japan and South Korea are expected to attend the 10th annual general meeting and 15th board of directors meeting of the association, which will take place at the Grand Hotel in Taipei and National Tsing Hua University (NTHU) in Hsinchu City, respectively, the organizers said.
The theme of this year's meeting is "advancing to the rank of world-class universities."

Jan Graafmans, a representative of the Conference of European Schools for Advanced Engineering Education and Research, has been invited to share the experiences of European universities with the participants.
In addition to NTHU -- the host of this year's event, National Taiwan University is another university that is a member of AEARU.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOOTING COMMISSION MUST BE SUSPENDED PENDING RULING: CABINET

TEXT.P: The operations of a commission authorized under a controversial bill to investigate the March 19 shooting of the president must be suspended until the Council of Grand Justices can rule on the statute's constitutionality, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Tuesday.

Chen Chi-mai made the remarks after Shih Chi-yang, the convener of the commission to investigate the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, suggested the previous day that the statute be revised during the first meeting of the commission to assuage public misgivings. The "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) accepted Shih's suggestion.

On Tuesday, the KMT and PFP caucuses in the Legislative Yuan proposed a revised draft of the special statute to probe the March 19 shooting. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , while mocking the opposition for "returning to the correct path after going astray, " said the action vindicates what they have been saying all along -- the statute as passed is unconstitutional. As such, the DPP did not oppose the move and the issue of revising the bill will now be put on the agenda of the legislature.

Chen Chi-mai noted that the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan have repeatedly warned that the special statute was unconstitutional and illegal, but the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan went ahead anyway and passed the bill in August and rejected the Executive Yuan's request for reconsideration the following month.

However, Chen Chi-mai said that even though the "pan-blue alliance" has agreed to take another look at the bill, the fact is that the statute violates the ROC Constitution and various laws and even if the bill is revised down from being "85 percent in violation of the Constitution and laws to 75 percent, " the effort would be an exercise in futility as the statute would still be unconstitutional.

Chen Chi-mai cited as an example that under the bill, the 17 members of the commission are to be recommended by the legislature in accordance with the proportion of each political party; however, this would create a political force that would interfere with judicial investigations. The DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, were designated to have seven people sit on the commission, but they decided to boycott the proceedings by not recommending any members.

For this reason, Chen Chi-mai said that if the opposition is unable to handle this situation, the operations of the commission should be frozen until the Grand Justices hand down a ruling "so as not to cause irreversible damage to human rights."

DOC.HEADLINE: DISTINCTIVE ART MEETS FINE CHINESE CUISINE IN NANTOU

TEXT.P: Eating in style has a new meaning in Nantou County with the creation of sets of ceramic "butterfly-style" cups, bowls and saucers especially for use with Chinese cuisine.
A pottery studio founded in 1955 has released the butterfly-motif dishes as part of the government's efforts to promote a combination of ceramic arts and local delicacies.

The "Ten Shing Yao" ceramic art company in Chi Chi township, the epicenter of the 7.6 magnitude earthquake in 1999, is among 10 pottery manufacturers selected by the Council for Cultural Affairs to carry out the project aimed at encouraging local ceramic artists to create distinctive tableware.

The pottery studio's butterfly-style series comprise 103 pieces of various utensils from the smallest chopsticks holder to the heaviest ceramic pot. The creations were inspired by Taiwan's image as a kingdom of butterflies, according to Ten Shing Yao's master of ceramic arts, Lin Ching-ho.
Lin said that the creations add aesthetic and historic value to local foods.

To introduce the new products and its effort of combining pottery and food, Ten Shing Yao will host a food festival on Nov. 11, the day of the annual Ceramic Arts Festival's opening, at its studio, which is situated near the popular tourist spot "Chi Chi Green Tunnel."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ADVISOR'S AD DOES NOT REPRESENT THE ROC GOVERNMENT: MOFA

TEXT.P: The advertisement paid for by senior presidential advisor Koo Kwang-ming in the Washington Post does not represent the government's position, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Tuesday.

Koo put a 2,000-word, full-page advertisement in the paper urging the United States government to reassess its "one China" policy, which he says has only benefited the communist totalitarian regime on the mainland.
Koo says the "one China" policy is already outdated and that many practises of Washington today are making people doubt if the United States has deviated from its founding philosophy.
Lu called the article Koo's personal opinion, adding that the government had no knowledge beforehand that the article would be run.
Locally, the article also appeared in the Taipei Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN MAY OFFER VISA-FREE TREATMENT FOR TAIWAN TOURISTS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Japan is considering granting visa-free treatment for tourists from Taiwan, given their strong purchasing power, Taiwan's top envoy to Japan said Tuesday.

Koh Se-kai, Taiwan's de-facto ambassador stationed in Tokyo, made the announcement at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport prior to his return to Japan after having taken part in a Taiwan-Japan forum at home.

Koh said that the Japanese government is very likely to make the move in March next year at the earliest or in October at the latest, adding that the earlier date is more likely as Japan is set to sponsor the 2005 World Exposition the same month.
In an effort to entice foreign visitors to the EXPO 2005 AICHI, the Japanese government has targeted Taiwan tourists, he said.
Bilateral exchanges are close and frequent on a wide number of fronts, with seven regular air travel routes already in place between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MORE MAINLAND CHINESE TOURISTS ABSCOND

TEXT.P: Three more mainland Chinese tourists absconded from Taiwan hotels between late August and September, a Tourism Bureau official said Tuesday.
"As the tour guides and travel agents involved immediately reported the cases in accordance with relevant regulations, they will not be disciplined," the official said.

Nevertheless, the official said, the Tourism Bureau will tighten supervision of travel services, including demanding local travel agencies to "prudently select" their mainland cooperative partners in organizing local tour packages for mainland tourists.

Since Taiwan opened its doors to select mainland citizens for pleasure trips two years ago, the official said, more than 40 mainland tourists have absconded, either upon arrival or from the hotels where they were staying.
"The absconding rate is relatively low in comparison with the ratios in other countries," the official said.
The absconding rate was 0.23 percent in Taiwan, compared to 0.37 percent in Japan, 3 percent in Australia and 10-13 percent in South Korea, the official said.

The official further said the Travel Agent Association (TAA) of the Republic of China, which has been commissioned by the Tourism Bureau to screen the backgrounds of prospective mainland visitors in advance, has adopted a new disciplinary system to tighten the management of local travel agencies.
Under the new supervisory system, any travel agency that reports two absconding cases within one month will be banned from receiving mainland tour groups for a month.

TAA officials said the system was implemented Sept. 1 after two en-masse absconding cases were reported between July and August. Only one of the three latest absconding cases took place after the new disciplinary system was put into practice, the officials said. The other two cases occurred in late August.

Since the disciplinary system's implementation, the TAA has screened more than 2,000 mainland tourists. During the period, the TAA rejected applications by two mainland tour groups, the officials said.

The case reported Sept. 13 involved a woman surnamed Qin. Police have located a local man who had contact with Qin following her arrival, but the man claimed not to know the woman's current whereabouts.
Police said they have stepped up the search in places where illegal mainland immigrants traditionally take jobs, such as restaurants and hospitals.

Immigration and aviation police authorities have also adopted stricter measures, including demanding that local tour guides receive mainland tour groups at special waiting rooms at airports instead of in the usual arrival lounges, to prevent absconding en masse.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC TO STUDY TICKET PRICE RISES FOR TRANSPORT SECTOR

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) will study the feasibility of price hikes for air carriers, trains and buses in view of high oil prices that show no signs of cooling, a ministry spokesman said Tuesday.
The ministry will discuss adjustment ranges in the coming days, as the domestic transport sector has been dogged by the soaring oil prices since the beginning of this year, the spokesman said.
Transport Minister Lin Ling-san told a legislative committee a day earlier that the ministry will revise the current air, rail and bus ticket rates in the face of the situation.
Lin said that the amount of the increases for the various forms of transport has not been decided, as oil prices have fluctuated noticeably in recent days.
Chang Kuo-cheng, director-general of the MOTC's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), said that the present air fares were worked out when the international oil price was about US$34 a barrel.

Now, with the price having surged to nearly US$50 per barrel, operating costs of the aviation companies has jumped, Chang pointed out, adding however that the CAA feels it is better to impose further fuel surcharges on tickets rather than directly increasing fares.

Four Taiwan-based carriers -- Far East Air Transport Corp., Mandarin Airlines, UNI Airways Corp. and Trans Asia Airways -- each filed an application with the CAA last month requesting a ticket price hike.
Pushed by the rising oil price, the four airlines, through a transport industry association, again raised a fuel surcharge request recently for their domestic routes.
CAA officials said the carriers will be allowed to make the increase either way on their domestic routes to avoid a double hike.
Business sources forecast that the fuel surcharge on domestic routes will be around NT$80 (US$2.4) per ticket.
The CAA first permitted six airlines to impose a fuel surcharge on their international routes from July 1 until the end of September. The practice was extended to last until mid-March next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT REJECTS RETRIAL APPEAL INVOLVING WEEKLY AND VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Court rejected Tuesday an appeal for a retrial of a case involving Vice President Annette Lu and local weekly the Journalist.
The Journalist asked for a retrial after the Supreme Court threw out an earlier appeal by the magazine for a reversal of a lower court ruling in Lu's favor in April.

The Supreme Court upheld the High Court judgment and instructed the magazine to publish the court ruling against it in newspaper advertisements, as well as to apologize to Lu for failing to check its facts when it published a story in 2000 claiming that Lu circulated a rumor that President Chen Shui-bian was having an affair with one of his aides.
The High Court ruling said that evidence the Journalist claimed the Supreme Court failed to examine did not constitute conditions to ask for a retrial under the Code of Civil Procedure.

Chen Yen-jen, a lawyer commissioned by the Journalist, said he regretted the decision and said that the magazine has already asked the Council of Grand Justices for an interpretation of the constitutionality of the court's decision.
After receiving the verdict, the magazine will decide whether to ask again for a retrial, Chen said.
Lu, who brought the lawsuit against the weekly as well as its president, editor-in-chief, and writers of the story, asked for a "restoration of her reputation" damaged by the story.

The Supreme Court said in April that the judges hearing the case fully agreed with a Council of Grand Justices' opinion that it would unnecessarily limit the freedom of the press and jeopardize the mass media's role as a monitor of society if they were required to report only "accurate " stories.
But the court found that the appellants in the case failed to reasonably verify the truth of the story and should be held responsible for damaging Lu's reputation.

The Journalist attributed its sources to its editor-in-chief Lee Ming-chun, who goes by the pen name of Yang Chao, claiming that Yang was told by Lu on the phone about the alleged affair at the Presidential Office. However, neither the Journalist nor Yang were able to prove their claim and the telephone company's records did not show any such calls being made by Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SITS ON WORLD'S THIRD-LARGEST FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) said Tuesday that as of the end of September, the country's foreign exchange reserves had snowballed to a record high of US$233.006 billion.
CBC officials said that the figure represents a growth of US$1.397 billion from August, or an increase of US$26.374 billion from the end of last year.
They added that the increased reserves are mainly because of interest and the appreciation of the euro.
Taiwan is the world's third largest foreign exchange holder, behind only Japan and China.
Japan held US$808.372 billion in foreign exchange reserves as of the end of August, while mainland China held US$483 billion as of the end of July.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL SEMINAR ON SLOPELAND DISASTER PREVENTION BEGINS

TEXT.P: The two-day 2004 International Conference on Slopeland Disaster Mitigation began Tuesday in Taipei with the hope of elevating Taiwan's capability in disaster prevention.
The issue of landslides prevention drew special attention after Taiwan suffered significantly from a series of typhoons that struck the island this summer.

Experts from the United States, Japan, Switzerland, Austria, Italy, Hong Kong and Vietnam were invited to the conference, organized by the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau under the Council of Agriculture (COA) , to share their experiences in slopeland disaster mitigation.

Kuo Yao-chi, chairperson of the Cabinet-level 921 Earthquake Post-Disaster Recovery Commission, also attended the conference. Reconstruction is still going on in some areas five years after the island was hard hit by the devastating earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999.

COA Vice Chairman Tai Chen-yao noted that the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau is working actively in determining which rivers and creeks around the island that may cause landslides during natural disasters, and is raising its ability to prevent landslides.
Tai expressed hope that discussing the issues and sharing experiences with foreign experts, Taiwan's disaster prevention can reach that of advanced countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT DEFICIT TOPS NT$297.2 BILLION IN 2003

TEXT.P: The deficit of the central government hit a record high of NT$297.2 billion (US$8.74 billion) in 2003, while the payable debts of the government topped NT$3.29 trillion, Auditor-General Su Chen-ping said Tuesday.

The amount of payable debts increased NT$264.1 billion over the previous year, with the interest payable to the government reaching NT$144.3 billion, according to a report delivered by Su to the Legislative Yuan.

On the financial condition for this year, Su said the government's tax revenue accounts for only 49.77 percent of its expenditure, which is a record low. He noted that the increase of tax revenue is lagging far behind the rise of government expenditure.

Su said rising spending on sectors such as social welfare, education, science, culture, retirement benefits for civil servants and debts is severely squeezing the spending on economic development and public infrastructure.
Because of this, he went on, a number of the government's policies have been financed by additional or special budget plans relying on the issuance of government bonds.

According to Su, tax revenue has failed to meet the government's target for five consecutive years because of the large amount of unpaid taxes and the large amount of tax deductions and waiving measures.

On the deficiencies of the government in implementing its annual budget, Su said the funding for major public infrastructure projects has decreased over the years and has limited its investment capacity, while the government's measures to boost employment are lacking a comprehensive control mechanism.

Other deficiencies include the lack of proper planning for the government's social security and welfare programs, as well as inefficiency in implementing forestation projects and restoring government property illegally occupied by the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REGRETS LEGISLATURE'S SNUB OF PRESIDENT'S REPORT

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office expressed regret Tuesday over the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan's snubbing of President Chen Shui-bian's proposal to deliver a state-of-the-nation report on the legislative floor.

Chen Wen-chung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, made the remarks after the legislature's Procedure Committee killed a bill jointly initiated by the legislative caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) inviting Chen to deliver an unprecedented state-of-the-nation report in the legislature by a vote of 11:18.
Chen Wen-chung said the legislature has missed a good opportunity to "write a new page in Taiwan's constitutional democratic history" by rejecting the proposal.

"The report could have provided opportunities for the executive and legislative branches to communicate and forge trust so as to break the domestic political stalemate. We feel deep regret over the legislature's decision," Chen Wen-chung said.

The president expressed interest in addressing the legislators on major policy issues in a letter sent to the legislature Sept. 27. In his letter, the president said he would focus his report on three major issues -- the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement plan, Taiwan's bid to joint the United Nations and the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

As the Constitution does not contain clear provisions regarding state-of-the-nation reports, the legislature declined a day earlier to put the president's request on its meeting agenda after two rounds of cross-party consultations.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) claimed that it is up to the legislature to decide whether to invite the president to deliver a state-of-the-nation report and that the president himself is not eligible to propose such a report.

On Tuesday, the DPP and the TSU legislative caucuses jointly initiated the bill inviting the president to deliver the report. As the "pan-blue alliance" dominated the Procedure Committee, however, the bill was killed and failed to make the legislative meeting agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH MINISTER MEETS VATICAN OFFICIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen met Vatican officials Tuesday to exchange opinions on matters of mutual concern.

Chen, who was in Rome on a four-day visit, called separately on Vatican Foreign Minister Giovanni Lajolo, Cardinal Fiorenzo Angelini, a former president of the Pontifical Council for the Pastoral Assistance to Health Care Workers and the council's secretary, Bishop Jose Luis Redrado.
During the meetings, they exchanged views on a wide range of issues and Chen thanked them for the Holy See's support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization.

The Vatican officials praised Taiwan for its efforts in improving public health, particularly its national insurance system, and expressed the hope that Taiwan will continue to send medical personnel to participate in international conferences at the Vatican.
They also wished great success to the 13th Congress of the Asian Catholic Health Care Workers Federation to be held in Taipei in November.
Chen left Rome for home Tuesday night after meeting several Italian parliamentarians.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON URGES TAIWAN TO ACCEPT MILITARY DEFENSE PLAN
DOC.DATELINE: Phoenix, Arizona, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's legislators should put aside their partisan strife and pass a major military procurement program for the sake of the interests of the country, the United States and the rest of the world, a ranking Pentagon official said Monday.

In a keynote speech at an annual defense industry conference sponsored by the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council here, Richard Lawless, deputy assistant secretary of defense, said Taiwan should seek to display a keen desire to beef up its defense capabilities by approving the controversial military procurement plan.

Such a move would make Taiwan's resolve to safeguard its national security clear to the whole world, and the United States would honor its commitment by rallying behind Taiwan to deter attack from mainland China from generation through generation, Lawless said.
He warned of serious consequences in the long term should Taiwan fail to do this.

Pointing out that the people of Taiwan will have the final say in the arms procurement program, he claimed, however, that failure to give the green light would invite repeated military threats from mainland China and relay a message to the world that Taiwan is not yet a fully fledged democracy in which national security is above political interests.

Should Taiwan's parliament fail to approve the budget for the purchase plan, friends and foes alike might well begin to regard Taiwan as a liability rather than a partner, at a time when many countries in the world, including the United States, are highly skeptical of Taiwan's determination to safeguard itself, he said.
National Defense Vice Minister Houh Shoou-yeh also took part in the conference, the third of its kind, at the head of an official delegation from Taiwan.

The expensive military procurement plan, estimated to cost Taiwan NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) over a 15-year period, has stirred heated debate between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition parties.
The opposition camp claims that the military buildup plan is no more than pork barrel politics that will leave Taiwan's younger generations strapped with huge debt.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SIGNS OF INFLATION: DGBAS OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Government officials said Tuesday that Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in the first nine months of this year registered a growth of 1.54 percent over the same period of last year and that there is no sign of inflation for the moment.

According to statistics released that day by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), the CPI for September stood at 102.24, which represents 0.54 percent growth over August, and a 2.78 percent increase over the same month of last year.

However, the wholesale price index (WPI) stood at 113.4 in September, an increase of 0.23 percent over August, but a notable 11.43 percent growth over the same month of last year, the highest increase since May 1981.

DGBAS officials said the CPI growth in September was due largely to price hikes for vegetables and fruit resulting from flooding caused by typhoons that occurred in late August and heavy rain in September, and stressed that the price hikes are temporary.

According to the DGBAS statistics, the core CPI (excluding prices of vegetables, fish products and energy) only grew 0.99 precent in September, and 0.65 percent during the first nine months of the year.
Judging from the CPI growth of 1.54 percent and core CPI increase of only 0.65 percent, the officials added, the price rise is moderate.

In addition, the officials noted, although international oil prices have topped US$50 per barrel recently, local public transport fares have remained unchanged, leaving them unworried about possible inflation.

However, the officials said they will study whether to adjust upward the CPI and WPI increases for this year, which were originally estimated at 1.49 percent and 16.99 percent, respectively, at a conference on national income to be held in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SEES NO CAUSE TO RETHINK 'ONE CHINA' POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: There is no cause for the United States to rethink its "one China" policy, U.S. State Department Deputy Spokesman Adam Ereli said Monday.

Ereli made the remarks after Koo Kwang-min, a senior adviser to Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, took out a 2,000-word, full-page advertisement in the Washington Post that day urging the U.S. government to reassess its "one China" policy, which Koo claims has only benefited the communist totalitarian regime in mainland China.
"Our China policy remains the same. There's no cause to rethink it," Ereli said at regular news briefing.

Koo said in the advertisement, paid for by himself, that the "one China" policy is already outdated and that many practices of Washington today are making people wonder if the United States has deviated from its founding philosophy.
The veteran pro-Taiwan independence activist said that more than 60 percent of the people of Taiwan now perceive themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese and that the ratio continues to rise.

In his advertisement, titled "US Adherence to One China Policy Only Benefits Communist Dictators: Let Taiwan Speak Out for Lasting Peace, " Koo said the U.S. "one China" policy based on the 1972 Shanghai Communique no longer fits political reality in Taiwan.
Koo said he hopes the U.S. government can reassess its "one China" policy in light of Taiwan's new mainstream public opinion and its new political reality.
In Taipei, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Koo's advertisement does not represent the ROC government's position.

Noting that the article reflects only Koo's personal opinion, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the government had no knowledge beforehand that the advertisement would be run. The advertisement also appeared in the English-language Taipei Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S MISSILE DEPLOYMENT IS MAIN FACTOR OF INSTABILITY: MOFA

TEXT.P: Mainland China's missile deployment is the main reason for the instability of Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations, according to a report presented to the Legislative Yuan Tuesday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Citing a U.S. Congress report, the MOFA noted that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) has continued to build up its military forces to intimidate Taiwan and deter the United States from intervening in a Taiwan Strait crisis.
The PLA has so far deployed 500 to 550 missiles and the number continues to increase by about 75 per year, according to the report.
The missiles pose a threat not only to Taiwan but also to U.S. and Japanese military deployments in east Asia, the MOFA claims in its report.
The MOFA also extended a welcome to a suggestion by U.S. think tanks that both the U.S. Congress and administration should review Washington's "one China" policy.

Noting that Taiwan and the United States share the same ideals and values of democracy, freedom and human rights and that the two countries have common interests and benefits in cooperation on security, trade, agriculture, fishery, education and cultural affairs, the MOFA predicted that bilateral ties will continue to steadily improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAIDEN TAICHUNG-SEOUL CHARTER FLIGHT FULLY BOOKED

TEXT.P: International passenger flight services at Chingchuankang (CCK) International Airport in central Taiwan kicked off Tuesday with the inauguration of regular charter flights between Taichung and Seoul.

A Mandarin Airlines FK-100 plane with 108 passengers aboard took off from the commercial-cum-military airport on the outskirts of Taichung City at 2: 30 p.m. amid cheers from government officials, elected representatives and airline executives.

Among the well-wishers were Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng and Liao Yung-lai, director of the Cabinet's Central Taiwan Liaison Office.

It marked the first international flight from the airport since its inauguration March 5 when three outbound international charter flights used the facility. At that time, the return flights had to land at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan as CCK Airport had not yet been fully completed.
This time around, the return flight from Seoul, with 70-plus South Korean travel agents and journalists aboard, landed smoothly at CCK Airport at 9 p.m.

From now on, Taichung-Seoul charter services will fly once every five days. The first seven Seoul-bound charter flights are all fully booked. Starting Nov. 14, the service will increase to twice a week, every Wednesday and Sunday.

In light of the warm public response for the flights, Mandarin Airlines has begun preparations for charter flights to several southern Japanese destinations in November. In the future, the company said, it will also operate charter flights to Southeast Asian nations from CCK Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LOAN RATIO OF TAIWAN'S BANKS DROPS TO 3.45%

TEXT.P: The overdue loan ratio registered by domestic banks had dropped to 3.45 percent as of the end of August, down 0.88 percentage points from the end of last year, officials of Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Tuesday.
According to FSC statistics, the amount of overdue loans had fallen to NT$525.4 billion (US$15.49 billion) as of the end of August.
Among the 50 domestic banks, 37 registered an overdue loan ratio of under 5 percent, seven posted a ratio of between 5 percent and 10 percent, while six registered a ratio of more than 10 percent.

A total of NT$1.3 trillion in non-performing loans was written off during the period between January 1999 and August 2004 with the banks' own earnings, which indicates that their operations are improving, FSC officials added.
An FSC executive stressed that the commission will continue to push domestic banks to resolve problems related to non-performing loans in order to elevate their competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REBUTS SECRET ENVOY RUMOR

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office rebutted Tuesday a rumor regarding a secret envoy in connection with mainland China, calling it a "fabricated and groundless" story.

The Presidential Office issued the rebuttal in a press release in response to a comment aired earlier the same day by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Chen Chien-ming, who accused the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan of sending Kuo Tai-chiang, chairman of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development (CICD), as a secret envoy to engage with the mainland.
According to Chen, the matter is a clear reflection of the government's softening stance toward the mainland and it goes against Taiwan's national interests.
The Presidential Office expressed deep regret over the rumor and stressed that such rhetoric will seriously mislead the public judgment and viewpoint.

President Chen Shui-bian has not met Kuo since Aug. 17 at the Presidential Office, it said, adding that it is out of the question that the president would send Kuo as a secret agent to deal with the mainland. The president fully respects the government system in terms of cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, it added.

However, in the latest development, CICD Secretary-General Wang Tiao-chun, admitted that Kuo, in his capacity as CICD chairman, did meet ranking mainland officials during a recent trip to Beijing from Sept. 21-28.

Wang said he was also present at the meeting and explained that the purpose of Kuo's visit was only to transmit President Chen's hope of designating the direct transport, trade and postal services between the two sides as "cross-strait" routes instead of international links as Beijing insists upon.
Claiming that the proposal has gained a positive response from Beijing, Wang refused to reveal where the meeting took place or which Beijing officials were present, citing a mutual agreement.
But Wang added that neither Kuo nor he himself were "secret envoys" of the Presidential Office.
People on both sides of the strait are hoping fervently for the opening of direct three links, and the CICD will do its best to push toward that end, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S GDP 17TH-LARGEST IN WORLD IN 2002: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) reached US$281.9 billion in 2002, the 17th-largest in the world, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Citing statistics compiled by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the International Financial Statistics (IFS), Taiwan's GDP was the 21st-largest in 1992.
The United States enjoyed the world's largest GDP -- US$10.48 trillion -- in 2002, followed by Japan with US$3.97 trillion and Germany with US$1.98 trillion.
Mainland China's GDP totaled US$1.26 trillion in 2002, representing the sixth-largest in the world due to its rapid economic growth in recent years.
Singapore's GDP remained the 40th-largest in the world, while South Korea's GDP of US$546.9 billion advanced it to the 11th place in 2002 from the 14th place in 1992.
Meanwhile, Norway's per capita GDP led the world in 2002 with US$42,275, followed by Switzerland's US$37,342 and America's US$36,366.
However, Taiwan's per capita GDP totaled US$12,588 in 2002, remaining at the 25th place, GDBAS officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAMBASTS SO-CALLED `TRUTH' COMMISSION AS OUTRAGEOUS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lambasted a commission created under a controversial statute to investigate the the March 19 assassination attempt against him as "outrageous and disgraceful."
Chen expressed his views on the March 19 Shooting Truth Investigation Commission during a meeting with Jerome A. Cohen, a Harvard University professor.

Chen told his guest that Shih Chi-yang, the convener of the commission, which his administration believes is illegal and unconstitutional, had called for revisions to the controversial statute even before the commission began formal operations.
"This indicates that the statute is indeed problematic, " Chen said, adding that the statute violates the ROC Constitution and a number of critical laws.

Chen's administration has asked the Council of Grand Justices to interpret the constitutionality of the statute and the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has also asked for a temporary injunction of the statute before the council hands down its judgment.
Chen said he hopes the commission can suspend its operations until the Council of Grand Justices has determined whether the statute is constitutional or not.
Chen said he is not afraid of investigations of the shooting since he did not stage it. "I was a victim of the election-eve incident," he asserted.

Chen narrowly won re-election a day after the shooting on the campaign trail grazed his stomach. His challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan insinuated that Chen might have staged the shooting to win sympathy votes. Although he has offered no evidence to support his allegations, he has filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory and even the validity of the election.
The KMT and its ally -- the People first Party -- jointly authored and railroaded the controversial statute through the legislature to create the all-powerful commission to investigate the shooting.
Chen said the commission is a joke and can lead nowhere because its existence is unconstitutional.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 6, or the 23rd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary in China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: English chemist Sir Humphrey Davy discovers a new metallic element and calls it potassium.
1860: A Franco-British force captures Beijing. China's Ching court is thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Beijing.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forces the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander in chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The U.S. State Department condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down Gen. George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1958: Seawolf, a U.S. nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The ROC and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: As Israelis begin to observe Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force begins an attack on Israel on two fronts, triggering the fourth Arab-Israeli war.
1975: The 11th General Assembly of the Asian Parliamentarians Union opens in Taipei with more than 80 delegates and observers from nine countries taking part.
1976: Shiroshichi Kimura, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for a 16-day visit.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, comprising the National Theater and National Concert Hall, is inaugurated after six years of construction costing NT$7.5 billion.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
1999: Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal who raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of television celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997, is executed after being sentenced to death for his crimes.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian explains that the "stone" in his earlier comment that "the stone has been removed from the path" of his four-month-old government actually referred to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party itself and not to any specific person.
2001: A local banker urges Taiwan consumers to use "plastic currency" more often amid outrage against increasingly rampant currency counterfeiting.
2001: Some 40 representatives from the overseas chapters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) participates in a three-day joint meeting in Bangkok.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER CONFIRMS PRESIDENT'S TOP AIDE VISITED MANILA IN JULY

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen confirmed Wednesday that Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, visited the Philippines in July.
Chen made the remarks when giving a report on the operations of his ministry to the Foreign Affairs Committee at the Legislative Yuan.
He noted that Taiwan has continued to develop relations with Southeast Asian nations over the past six months despite the relentless pressure from mainland China.

He citied as an example that Su, before assuming the post of the secretary-general to President Chen Shui-bian, visited Thailand and Singapore in early May, and after becoming the president's top aide, visited the Philippines in July.

The Siang Po, a Chinese-language newspaper in the Philippines, reported July 10 that a seven-member delegation headed by Su arrived in Manila July 9 to arrange for President Chen to visit the Philippines. The mainland Chinese embassy in Manila had negotiated with the Philippine Foreign Ministry over the matter, the reports also said.
At that time, the Presidential Office said it couldn't confirm the reports, and Su himself did not "deny or confirm" the matter.
