DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT URGED TO ASK BEIJING TO ABANDON OPTION OF FORCE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct.5 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's new representative to the European Union and Belgium urged the members of the European Parliament Tuesday to request that mainland China abandon the option of the use of force against Taiwan.

Chen Cien-jen, who arrived in Brussels Oct. 4 to officially assume his new post, made the appeal in a speech delivered at a gatherIng held by Gerog Jarzembowski, chairman of the European Parliament Taiwan Friendship Group, at the parliament's Brussels-based headquarters the same day.

Apart from briefly introducing the history of Taiwan's political, economic and social development, the envoy also told the 24 European Parliament members attending the gathering that the island has made great democratic achievements, such as the establishment of direct presidential elections and the complete lifting of a ban on the organization of political parties.
"Compared with other Chinese societies of neighboring countries, including mainland China, Singapore and Hong Kong, Taiwan is the most democratic and free country," he further said.

Calling for the European parliamentarians to request that Beijing give up the option of force against Taiwan and to help push for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in dialogue as soon as possible, Chen also expressed the island's opposition to idea of the European Union lifting its arms embargo against mainland China.

The European Union put in place a ban on arms exports to mainland China in the wake of the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre, but some E.U. members, including France and Germany, have been pushing for the removal of the ban since last year following a request by Beijing.
Chen said the lifting of the ban would help mainland China in the development of its military forces and affect Taiwan's security as well as peace and stability in the Far East.
"A lifting of the ban would be an undesirable encouragement to mainland China which has yet to improve its human rights record, " he continued.

In response, several of the European parliamentarians voiced their concerns over cross-Taiwan Strait developments, saying that they will urge the mainland to develop its democracy and the rule of law and to pay more attention to human rights, as well as to promote a positive development in cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS LEADER DENIES MEETING WITH HU JINTAO

TEXT.P: Taiwan business tycoon Kuo Tai-chiang categorically denied late Tuesday that he had acted as an "emissary" between Taiwan and mainland China and that he had met with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao during his trip to the mainland in September.

In a written statement, Kuo, chairman of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development (CICD) , denied that he had represented President Chen Shui-bian in Beijing as an emissary in meetings with ranking mainland Chinese officials in September.

Kuo, a high-technology industry tycoon, said he did not meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao as claimed by a rumor Tuesday. Kuo said he met with Hu Deping, first vice chairman of the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce, and Li Bingcai, executive deputy director of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, during his visit in Beijing Sept. 21-23.
Kuo said that he attended the two meetings accompanied by other CICD officials and that the meetings were purely business.

At the head of a Taiwan delegation, Kuo and several CICD officials, as well as other Taiwan business and political figures, including Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Chen Chien-ming, visited mainland China Sept. 21-28 to drum up cross-strait business and industrial cooperation. The itinerary of the visit included trips to Beijing and Hangzhou, Kuo said in the statement.

The highlights of the visit included the signing of a memorandum on bilateral cooperation between the CICD and the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce, Kuo said, adding that the memorandum was inked by CICD Secretary-General Wang Tiao-chun and All-China Vice Chairman Xie Boyang in Beijing Sept. 27.

Kuo issued the denial statement in the wake of comments made Tuesday by Legislator Chen, who accused the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan of sending Kuo as a secret envoy to engage with the mainland. Chen claimed that the trip is a clear reflection of the government's softening stance toward the mainland and that it runs counter to Taiwan's national interests.

Kuo said that the CICD, one of the largest and most influential trade associations in Taiwan, has continuously urged the leaderships of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to put aside their political differences and work to open the "direct three links" across the strait at the earliest possible date.
People on both sides of the strait are fervently hoping for the opening of the direct trade, postal and transportation links, and the CICD will do its best to push toward that end, he added.

Kuo said that in his capacity as the head of the CICD, he had also urged the Chinese leadership during his visit in Beijing to be more concerned about the interests of Taiwan businesspeople operating in mainland China and heedful of the impact of China's measures aimed at cooling its overheated economy on the Taiwan businesses.
He said he thinks the CICD's recent visit to Beijing was fruitful as the group received favorable responses from the Chinese leadership to many of their appeals.
Refuting Chen's accusation, Kuo said that Chen himself was among the group and should certainly know well the mission and purposes of the CICD.

Kuo said that the CICD has vowed to play a bridge role between Taiwan's private business and industrial sectors and the government, but the organization will never represent any political party or government agency in dealing with mainland China.
He added that he has not met with President Chen Shui-bian or any other government officials since the trip to mainland China.
Meanwhile, the Presidential Office rebutted Tuesday the rumor regarding Kuo's being an emissary between Taiwan and mainland China, calling it a fabricated story.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLU SHOTS ORDERED FROM BRITAIN YET TO ARRIVE IN TAIWAN: DOH

TEXT.P: The influenza vaccines ordered from a British company have yet to arrive in Taiwan, an official of the Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of DOH's Center for Disease Control, made the remarks amid reports that British health authorities have suspended the license of Chiron Corp. for three months because of fears of contamination of the vaccines it produced.
Taiwan has ordered 170,000 doses from the British flu shot manufacturer, but they have yet to arrive in Taiwan, Shih said, adding that this will not affect the current free flu shot drive.

He said the government has ordered 2.5 million doses of influenza vaccine this year for senior citizens and infants aged between six months and two years old, as well as medical staff and those employed in the poultry industry.
The doses from Britain account for only a small fraction of the total ordered, Shih stressed.
He said the CDC has asked Chiron to pay compensation according to the terms of the contract or supply shots from other manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO'S AD DOESN'T REPRESENT GOVERNMENT'S STANCE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: The advertisements placed in the Washington Post and the New York Times Monday by senior presidential advisor Koo Kwang-ming do not represent the government's stance, the Presidential Office said Wednesday.

The Presidential Office also did not know in advance about Koo's plans to take out the ads urging the U.S. government to reassess its "one China" policy, said James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.

Koo took out 2,000-word, full-page advertisements in both the Washington Post and the New York Times Monday urging the U.S. government to face the reality concerning Taiwan and rethink its "one China" policy, which Koo claims has only benefited the communist totalitarian regime in mainland China.

In the ad, titled "U.S. Adherence to One China Policy Only Benefits Communist Dictators: Let Taiwan Speak Out for Lasting Peace, " Koo said America's "one China" policy based on the 1972 Shanghai Communique no longer fits the political reality in Taiwan.
Koo said he hopes the U.S. government can reassess its "one China" policy in light of Taiwan's new mainstream public opinion and its new political reality.

Commenting on the ads, Randall G. Shriver, U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian affairs, reportedly has suggested that President Chen Shui-bian or the Presidential Office clarify Koo's advertisements and Taiwan's position.

Huang said that the running of these ads was Koo's personal move which had nothing to do with the government. He added that the Presidential Office has also become aware of Shriver's message via media reports.

Meanwhile, Koo, a veteran pro-Taiwan independence activist, said in an exclusive interview with the CNA in Washington, D.C., Tuesday that he guarantees with his personal reputation that the ads have nothing to do with the government of Taiwan.
Koo said that his son who resides in Japan helped with the composition of the advertisement and that he himself handled all the affairs regarding having the ad placed in the two major U.S. dailies.
"I myself paid for the ads, and the Taiwan government knew nothing about it in advance, " he added.

On U.S. State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli's response to the ads that there is no cause for the United States to rethink its "one China" policy, Koo said that bureaucracy and reform are usually slow and reserved.
Koo said that the "one China" policy is already outdated and that many practices in Washington today are making people question whether the United States has deviated from its founding principles.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS URGE GOVERNMENT TO ADDRESS PROBLEMS CAUSED BY MONKEYS

TEXT.P: More than 200 farmers from central Taiwan appealed Wednesday to the Legislative Yuan and the Council of Agriculture (COA) to address the problem caused by the Formosan macaque.

The farmers, accompanied by Legislator Tseng Tsai Mei-tsou of the opposition Kuomintang, first protested outside the legislature building in downtown Taipei, urging the government to protect their rights.
The farmers complained that the monkeys take their fruit, ravage farmland, and even sometimes harass women and children.
They asked the government to consider taking the monkeys off the conserved animal list and that the COA also compensate them for their crop losses.

They said that although the macaques repeatedly wreak havoc to farmland, they cannot be rounded up or killed because they are conserved animals, so that the only way of dealing with them is to chase them away.
They suggested that the COA conduct a comprehensive census of the animals to investigate their numbers and seriously consider removing them from the conserved animal list.

The farmers later went to the COA with their requests. In addition to compensation for crop losses and removal of the monkeys from the conserved list, they also suggested that an exclusive tourism zone be set up to shelter the macaque.

They brought with them two rock macaques in cages, along with pineapple plants that have been damaged by the macaques and pointed out how the animals gnaw the roots of the plants, seriously affecting the crop.
COA Vice Chairman Tai Chen-yao said the council will set up a task force soon to investigation the damage done by the animals and study ways to subsidize the farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH MINISTER FLIES TO VIENNA FOR EUROPEAN HEALTH FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen headed for Vienna Tuesday to attend the 2004 European Health Forum after ending a three-day visit in Rome.
The annual forum is scheduled for Oct. 6-9 in Bad Hofgastein, Austria and Chen will preside over a session on issues related to health insurance.

Chen said that in addition to giving the participants a better understanding of Taiwan's National Health Insurance system, he will also lobby for the support of European countries for the island's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO).
He is expected to hold bilateral talks with health officials of various European countries during the meeting, sources said.

Earlier in the day, Chen visited Italy's Chamber of Deputies and Senate in the company of ROC Representative to Italy Lin Ki-tseng to exchange views with Italian parliamentarian on Taiwan's WHO bid and health cooperation between the two countries.

During the visit, he met Giuseppe Palumbo, president of the Chamber's Social Affairs Committee, Gustavo Selva, president of the Foreign Affairs Committee, and Giuseppe Mascioni, vice chairman of the Senate's Hygiene and Health Committee.

Selva told Chen that the Chamber of Deputies firmly supports Taiwan's efforts to take part in the WHO, pointing out that it adopted a resolution May 4 urging the Italian government to endorse Taiwan's WHO participation.
Mascioni, meanwhile, said it is humanitarian and just to support Taiwan's observer status in the WHO as a health entity.
During his stay in Rome, Chen also met with Pope John Paul II and other Vatican officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, EVA AIR STRONG ENOUGH TO COMPETE IN INT'L AIR CARGO MARKET: IATA
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The International Air Transportation Association (IATA) affirmed the performance of Eva Air and China Airlines Tuesday, saying that facing tough competition, the two Taiwan carriers have established successful and competitive business operations.
The organization also said that even in the highly competitive international air cargo market, Eva Air and CAL hold a strong position.

According to an assessment by Taiwan's Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the new aviation agreement signed recently by mainland China and the United States could impact on the Taiwan carriers' air cargo business.

However, an IATA spokesman said the same day that he is confident about the future development of Eva Air and CAL, pointing out that despite the fact that the agreement will create more opportunities for the American and mainland Chinese airlines, the sustainable economic development in mainland China will also provide new business opportunities for other airlines.

Admitting that the rapid liberalization of the global air cargo market has increased competition among airlines, Anthony Council, who is responsible for the IATA Communication Department, said however that both Eva Air and CAL are successful airlines with strong positions in the air cargo market.
Touching on the problem of establishing direct air links between Taiwan and mainland China, the spokesman said that its a political issue and beyond the scope of the IATA to resolve.
IATA represents more than 270 airlines comprising 95 percent of international scheduled air traffic.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ENVOY PUSHES FOR CLOSER EXCHANGES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The de-facto Australian ambassador to Taiwan paid a visit to Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsiung Wednesday as part of efforts to further boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation.

Frances Adamson, representative of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office, which represents Australian interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, told Yang that Taiwan is Australia's ninth-largest trading partner and that there is still ample room for the two countries to expand their cooperation.
Adamson briefed Yang on the highlights of a Taiwan-Australian working holiday visa agreement to be implemented from Nov. 1.
Under the terms of the agreement, the two countries will issue working holiday visas to each other's young citizens to boost tourist exchanges and mutual understanding.

Many Taiwan citizens make sightseeing trips to Australia each year and the number of Taiwan students study in Australia has also increased steadily, Adamson said, adding that in 2003 alone, Taiwan people made 190,000 visits to Australia and the number of Taiwan students studying in Australia has already reached 10,000.
"We hope the working holiday visa agreement will further facilitate student exchanges between our two countries, " Adamson said.
For his part, Yang said Australian citizens are welcome to visit Kaohsiung County, either for sightseeing or investment.
Yang noted that he has traveled to the United States, Europe, Russia and Scandinavian countries in the past few years to woo investment in the southern Taiwan county.

Introducing the county's general investment climate, Yang said Kaohsiung is been one of Taiwan's most important agricultural and manufacturing bases. In recent years, he went on, the county government has also given priority to promoting tourism.
Yang said the county government has also adopted many measures to attract foreign investors to its new environmental protection industry park and telecommunication industry park.
"We welcome Australian business groups to invest in these two new industrial parks," Yang added.

Taiwan and Australia signed an agreement July 15 on the exchange of working holiday visas. Australia is the second country to sign such an agreement with Taiwan after New Zealand. The Taiwan-New Zealand working holiday visa agreement took effect in June.
Under the Taiwan-Australia working holiday agreement, Taiwan citizens aged between 18 and 30 can apply for a working holiday visa for a maximum one-year stay in Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Cheney and Edwards Go Toe to Toe.
Iraq and terrorism dominated a hard-hitting and sometimes personal debate Tuesday night between the vice presidential nominees, with Vice President Cheney accusing the Democratic ticket of lacking the judgment to lead, and Sen. John Edwards (N.C.) responding that Cheney and President Bush lack credibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Alkhanov Sworn In as President No. 2.
Major General Alu Alkhanov was sworn in Tuesday as Chechnya's new president behind the thick walls of a government compound swarming with security forces and armored vehicles, as the Kremlin sought to bolster its claims to be bringing stability to the restive republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October dropped 35 points to close at 6,088, with 39,947 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 32 points to finish at 6,078, with 656 contracts traded, while December futures lost 15 points to finish at 6,070, with 31 contracts traded.
March futures gained 38 points to finish at 6,099, with one contract traded, while June futures lost 14 points to close at 6,015, with 16 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,123 for October, 6,110 for November, 6,085 for December, 6,061 for March and 6,029 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures moved down 0.55 points to close at 225.15, with 10,700 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 0.55 points to finish at 224.65, with 198 contract transactions.
December TE futures rose 0.35 points to close at 225, with six contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures lost 14.8 points to end at 1,032, with 9.075 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 11.6 points to end at 1,028.2, with 338 contracts traded.
December TF futures lost 8.8 points to close at 1,025, with eight contract transactions, while March TF futures rose 0.8 points to finish at 1,025, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARES PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 20.4 points to close at 6,060.61.
The bourse opened at 6,093.22 and fluctuated between 6,135.55 and 6,060.61 during the day's trading.
Trading increased, with 6.45 billion shares changing hands on a market turnover of NT$140 billion (US$4.13 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up at 1 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1 percent, textile stocks at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.6 percent and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 383 to 279, with 162 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TOUTS SUNGSHAN AIRPORT FOR DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou was keenly touting Sungshan Airport as a hub for direct transport links with mainland China, saying that the opening will reduce travel time for Taiwan businessmen traveling between the two sides by more than 25 percent.
Ma made the remarks at a seminar Tuesday with local business community leaders and representatives.

Claiming that direct air links between Taipei, Shanghai and Dongguan will save passengers a great deal of time, Ma contended that Taipei's Sungshan Airport should be made into an exclusive gateway for cross-strait travel, while Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in neighboring Taoyuan should continue to handle international passenger and cargo travel.

Ma said that Taiwan should make the move to sharpen its competitive edge and create business opportunities in view of the grouping of economies in Southeast Asia and Northeast Asia by 2010, when mainland China is slated to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Japan and South Korea.
By that time, the economic development in Northeast Asian and Southeast Asian countries will be integrated, he said.

Apart from this, he pointed out, the closer economic partnership arrangements inked by the mainland with Hong Kong and Macau will put Taiwan at a disadvantage, as a large number of products from the two territories are set to enjoy "zero-tariff" treatment.
Should Taiwan fail to make breakthroughs in FTAs with other countries, it will lose the vast mainland market to Japan, South Korea and other Southeast Asian countries, he warned.
Compared with the mainland, which absorbs US$50 billion in foreign investment per year, Taiwan took in only US$3.6 billion last year, he noted.

The Taipei mayor said that Taiwan cannot afford to overlook the mainland market, citing a forecast by the Far Eastern Economic Review that the mainland will have replaced the United States as the world's largest economy by 2020.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WANTS RED FIRE ANTS ERADICATED IN THREE YEARS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed relevant government agencies Wednesday to control the proliferation of red fire ants by the end of the year and have the alien pests completely exterminated from Taiwan in three years.

Speaking at a supra-division meeting at the Executive Yuan, Yu said that the invasion of red fire ants into Taiwan not only threatens human safety and health, but is also endangering the island's ecology, necessitating the government at all levels to make concerted efforts to stamp out the pests.

Amid heightened alert in the wake of the discovery of the ants in Taipei at the end of September, Yu has instructed the formation of a supra-government agency team to coordinate with local governments to grapple the problem.

At Wednesday's meeting, he instructed the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) to build a standard operating procedure (SOP) to allow agencies, local governments and schools to follow when dealing with red fire ant infestations.

For their part, the COA officials said that relevant government agencies, including the COA, the Environmental Protection Administration, the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of National Defense, will all pitch into the concerted efforts to battle the insects.
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who was also present at the meeting, said the city has formed a contingency task force, since red fire ants were first detected in the capital city Sept. 28.

The city task force, led by Deputy Mayor Yeh Chin-chuan, will see to it that all potted plants, construction earth and landscaping sod that enter Taipei is examined and certified ant-free before being distributed, Ma said.

The red fire ants, which are native to southern Brazil, were first spotted in Taipei City on a traffic island on Chunghua Road, where about 16 anthills were found Sept. 28. Although environmental protection personnel quickly applied pesticide to the area, 20 new anthills up to 3 centimeters high were discovered Sept. 30. It is estimated that close to a hectare of lawn on the traffic island has been occupied by the ants.

Officials from the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine said they have no clue as to when or how the ants spread to Taipei, but believe that the ants -- which become very aggressive when their anthills are disturbed and bite and sting repeatedly -- were probably brought into the city via potted plants or landscaping sod.

While racing to control the proliferation of the red fire ants, COA officials said that they will try to develop more effective ways to kill the pests, taking reference from the approaches of the United States and Australia, which have been battling the ants for many years with little success.

Farmers consider the insect a nuisance because although they do not endanger crops, their bites and stings are annoying and very painful, and for a small number of people who are allergic to the venom, a single sting could be fatal.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.001 to close at NT$33.919.
A total of US$730 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.900 and fluctuated between NT$33.883 and NT$33.927.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Flu risk for millions as safety fears hit vaccines.
Millions of people face long delays in getting flue vaccinations after regulators halted production at one of the world's largest vaccine manufacturers.
Financial Times: Euro court set to rule on 3bn VAT case.
An attempt by British mobile phone operators to claim tax rebates worth 3.35bn ($5.97bn) for 3G licences that were bought at the height of the telecommunications boom has been referred to the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: For Cheney and Edwards, efforts to improve on the other debate.
Dick Cheney sought Tuesday night to come to the rescue President Bush, while in the most of the 90-minute encounter with his rival, Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, Cheney tried to reassure Republicans unsettled by President Bush's debate performance against Senator John Kerry last week, while hammering home the case against Mr. Kerry that polls now suggest Mr. Bush failed to make.
Wall Street Journal: U.K. agency makes gains in terror war; can it work here?
In the wake of the 9/11 terror attacks and scathing reviews of U.S. intelligence- gathering, some security experts have held out MI5 as a model for the U.S. Not bound by strict rules of evidence required for law-enforcement agencies to make cases that would stand up in court, MI5 can focus on infiltration and intelligence gathering. It can thus concentrate on preventing potential mayhem rather than gathering evidence after the fact. MI5 has proved strong in the areas where U.S. intelligence has struggled: developing human sources able to infiltrate terrorist organizations, winning cooperation from moderate elements in Muslim communities and sharing information more effectively with other agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC TO ELEVATE FINANCIAL COMPETITIVENESS OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) will do everything it can to maintain Taiwan's financial stability and competitiveness, FSC Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng said Wednesday.

At a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee, Kong gave an outline of the Cabinet-level FSC's work in the future, which includes the establishment of a regional financial service center, encouraging mergers among financial institutions, reinforcing financial supervision and promoting international cooperation in financial supervision.

On the establishment of a regional financial service center, the FSC will begin with the improvement of the finance environment and will develop diverse financial services in order to create a dynamic and competitive financial market.
With regards to mergers among banks, Kong said the FSC will limit the establishment of financial institutions and give high marks to those mergers that operate well.
The FSC will also promote the transparency of financial information about listed-companies by referring to the experiences of advanced countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEMS, PRICES OF ARMS PROCUREMENT FROM U.S. SHOULD BE `REASONABLE'

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that the items in the proposed arms procurement plan should be "reasonable" and that the prices should conform with international market prices.

Wang made the remarks amid reports that a Pentagon official said Monday that Taiwan should display a keen desire to beef up its defense capability by approving the controversial military purchase plan.

Richard Lawless, the U.S. deputy under-secretary of defense, also warned in an annual defense industry conference in Phoenix, Arizona, of serious consequences in the long term should Taiwan fail to do so, saying that if the legislature fails to approve of the procurement plan, friends and foes alike might well begin to regard Taiwan "as a liability rather than a partner."
Taiwan need not pay too much attention to the warning, Wang claimed, adding that "our stance is clear -- we need to consider the overall defense needs of Taiwan and to adopt the right policy."

He said he expressed clearly to Minister of National Defense Lee Jye that a statute governing the arms procurement from the United States could be sent to the legislative caucuses of the various political parties, so that it can be reviewed quickly.
He expressed the hope that the defense ministry will take stock of the views of the Legislative Yuan and consult with the United States to obtain a new quotation for the arms.

At stake is the Executive Yuan's proposed NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) special budget in June over a 15-year period starting 2005 mainly for the purchase of six batteries of the Patriot-III anti-missile system, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft.

Wang said that the delivery of the arms will be between three and 15 years, and that "a few months shouldn't make too much difference" when reviewing the statutes for the arms purchase and special budget.

He reaffirmed the three principles of the legislature: the major purchase statute should be sent to the committee for screening before the Dec. 11 legislative elections; the statute for the purchase should be reviewed first and then the budget should be reviewed; and the legislature must not squander money and should judge what is in Taiwan's best interests.

He said that the current legislative session will be put on hold Nov. 12 for the year-end elections. Returning to the legislature after the elections, the lawmakers can start to review the special budget if the arms procurement statute has already passed the legislature.
In the meantime, the Defense Ministry will still have two months to haggle over the price with the United States, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIALS ATTEND ROC NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS IN PHILADELPHIA
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan officials stationed in New York attended a party Tuesday held by the overseas Chinese community in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to celebrate the Oct. 10 National Day of the Republic of China.

The officials included Andrew L.Y. Hsia, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York and his deputy Chi Yun-sheng, as well as Wu Hsue-cheng, director of the office's Chinese Cultural Center in New York.
While addressing the "Double-Ten Day" celebration, Hsia expressed his gratitude to members of the Chinese Cultural and Community Center in Philadelphia for their long-term support for the ROC.
Leaders of the Chinese community reiterated their support for the ROC. They also underlined the hope that China will be unified under the consensus of freedom, democracy and equal prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CALIFONIA-TAIWAN BUSINESS FORUM TO BEGIN OPERATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: California Lieutenant-Governor Cruz Bustamante confirmed Tuesday that a California-Taiwan Business Forum organized by private businesses will soon begin operations in Taipei.

Bustamante, who concurrently serves as chairman of the California Commission for Economic Development, noted that there was formerly a California trade office in the Taipei World Trade Center, but it closed due to insufficient budget during the tenure of former Governor Gray Davis.

But with the close trade relations between Taiwan and California, and the large amount of bilateral trade involved, Paul Giubergia, president of a California group -- friends of California in Taipei -- began to plan the business forum six months ago.

He pointed out that the business forum will be to help California businessmen solicit business opportunities in Taiwan, attend major exhibitions and provide services to Taiwan businessmen interested in business opportunities in California.

Bustamante also said he will lead a 20-member trade delegation to visit various Asian countries Saturday to solicit business opportunities. As he already visited Taiwan in May to attend the presidential inauguration, he will not be visiting Taiwan this time.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL CAUTIONS TAIWAN OVER POSSIBLE ATTACK BY CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Phoenix, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is facing a serious threat from mainland China, which is exploring every possible coercive means against Taiwan that might include a "non-traditional military action" similar to the 911 terrorist attacks on the United States, U.S. Deputy Under-secretary of Defense for Asian and Pacific Affairs Richard Lawless said Monday.

Speaking at the 2004 U.S.-Taiwan Defense Industry Conference held in Phoenix, Arizona, Lawless expressed Washington's concern that Taipei has so far failed to recognize the consequences of such a threat.
The disastrous earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, which resulted in massive blackouts around the island, exposed the weakness of Taiwan's infrastructure, Lawless pointed out.
At that time, many people were worried that the mainland might take advantage of the chaos to launch a surprise attack on Taiwan, Lawless said.
A similar situation of chaos occurred after the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian on March 19, he added.
He said Taiwan must beef up the security of its public infrastructure and central command against a possible swift invasion and decapitation campaign by Beijing.

In a keynote speech to the conference, Lawless urged Taiwan's lawmakers to pass a special budget plan aimed at financing arms procurement from the United States to show the island's resolve in defending its security.
The procurement plan will cost NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) over a 15-year period.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT TO ADDRESS TAIWAN-U.S. TELECONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will address a Taiwan-U.S. videoconference Friday to explain the gist and necessity of Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering movement, local organizers of the teleconference said Wednesday.

The seminar on Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering and the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations will be jointly organized by the Taipei-based Alliance to Promote a New Constitution for Taiwan and the Washington-based Center for Taiwan International Relations.

Wang Kang-hou, the alliance's spokesman, said this will be the first time the alliance has sponsored an international teleconference to help other countries understand the importance of writing a new constitution for Taiwan.

"By holding the videoconference, we hope the international community will come to know that our new constitution movement will not change Taiwan's status quo nor will it cause regional instability, " Wang said, adding that similar teleconferences will be held in Japan and major European countries in the future.
The U.S. venue for the videoconference will be the conference hall of the Senate Hart Building on Capitol Hill, while the Taipei venue will be the Ambassador Hotel.

In his 30-minute speech, Wang said, Lee will stress what he describes as the "absurdity" of the current Constitution and the importance of formulating a new constitution that fits Taiwan's status quo.

Following Taiwan's democratization and its decades of economic and social development, Wang said, the country needs a new constitution to facilitate efficient governance and allow it to become a "normal" country.

Taiwanese delegates to the videoconference will include Koo Kwang-min, a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, Evergreen University Professor Lee Hsien-jung and Chen Lung-chih, chairman of the Taiwan New Century Cultural and Educational Foundation. Examination Yuan President Yao Jia-wen will travel to Washington, D.C. to attend the seminar.
American participants will include former American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Nat Belocchi and several noted scholars, including John Tkacik, Arthur Waldron, Larry Niksch and James E. Auer.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON DOES NOT TAKE TAIWANESE AD SERIOUSLY: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Phoenix, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Washington is not taking seriously an advertisement by Taiwan Senior Presidential Advisor Koo Kwang-ming urging the United States to reassess its "one China" policy, U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for China Randall Schiver said Tuesday.
Schiver said the advertisement, which he said contains a number of factual errors, looks more than a statement of Koo's personal political stance than the policy of the Taiwan government.
However, he said he expects clarification from Taiwan's Presidential Office, since Koo published the advertisement using his official title.
Both President George W. Bush and Secretary of State Colin Powell have said the United States has no plans to change its "one-China" policy, Schiver pointed out.
Schiver was referring to a 2,000-word full-page advertisement that ran in the Washington Post Monday, in which Koo says the "one-China" policy has benefited the communist dictators in mainland China.
Koo also says the "one China" policy is already outdated and claims that many practises of Washington today make people wonder if the United States has deviated from its founding philosophy.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE DELEGATIONS TO VISIT TAIWAN FOR ROC NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Several Japanese parliamentary delegations will leave for Taiwan in the coming few days to participate in activities to celebrate Republic of China National Day, which falls on Oct. 10.

Takeo Hiranuma, chairman of the cross-party ROC-Japan Parliamentarians Council, will lead a parliamentarian delegation of 19 members to Taiwan from Oct. 9-11, while the Democratic Party of Japan will also send five dietmen.

Meanwhile, Taiwanese expatriates living in Tokyo will also return in groups to Taipei to celebrate the National Day and there will be a series of activities to be held around Japan Oct. 10 to mark the occasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCH UNIT UNVEILS AMOLED TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) unveiled its AMOLED technology Wednesday, saying that the development places it in the world's second spot behind only South Korea's Samsung.

The ITRI will display the country's first 3.8-inch double-emitting mold based on its AMOLED (active-matrix organic light emission display) at an international exhibition of key electronics components that will kick off Friday in Taipei, a researcher at the ITRI's Opto-Electronics and System Laboratories said.

According to the researcher, Taiwan is only the world's second developer capable of producing cellphones of two caps with just one double-emitting device display, largely slashing the coating, breadth and weight of cellphones with conventional flat panel displays.
He attributed the success to the application to LTPS TFT -- low temperature poly silicon thin film transistors -- by the ITRI team.
Chen Liang-chi, director-general at the ITRI laboratories, said that Taiwan companies have been exploring advanced TFT LCD expertise amid fervent interest in the booming sector around the world.

OLEDs -- organic light emitting device displays -- are widely viewed as the technology for the next generation of flat panel displays due to their bright, vibrant colors, full viewing angles and low power consumption for a wide range of products from cellphones to laptops and video monitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS COULD HAVE 100 PERCENT STAKE IN TAIWAN BANKS

TEXT.P: The government will not rule out the possibility of allowing foreign investors to own a 100 percent stake in a privatized government-run bank as Taiwan works to become a financial hub in the Asia-Pacific region, Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng said Wednesday.
Kong made the remark after a financial and economic meeting of the Executive Yuan.

Kong said the government is actively promoting mergers between banks and the privatization of government-owned banks and is encouraging local financial firms to expand to become international or regional corporations.

Stressing that foreign capital is essential to helping Taiwan achieve the goal of becoming an Asia-Pacific financial hub, Kong said the government is considering allowing foreign investors or those in the local private sector to have a 100 percent share in privatized government-owned banks.

Kong said what Taiwan needs are large-scale banks with an international competitive edge and that he expects one of the existing banks in Taiwan will emerge to become a giant enjoying a 20-percent market share in three years.

Currently, the five biggest banks in Taiwan enjoy a total market share of 26 percent, which is far behind most developed countries where the combined market share of the three biggest banks reaches 70 percent to 80 percent, Kong noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TEAM TO MEET WITH 'TRUTH COMMISSION' HEAD

TEXT.P: A team of senior government officials will meet with the convener of a special commission investigating the March 19 assassination attempt against President Chen Shui-bian Thursday to discuss how to amend the controversial statute under which the commission was created.

Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday Premier Yu Shyi-kun ordered the meeting with Shih Chi-yang, convener of the "truth investigation commission, " after listening to a Ministry of Justice (MOJ) report on the difficulties that would be faced in implementing the statute, commonly known as the "319 statute," at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

In addition to Chen Chi-mai, members of the Cabinet team to meet with Shih will also include Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan, Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung and Hsu Chang-yao, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

Chen Chi-mai said the Cabinet team will discuss with Shih the 60-plus provisions in the statute that are deemed hard to implement as well as budget appropriations to finance the operations of the "truth commission."

Noting that even Shih, a former Judicial Yuan president himself, had at the commission's inaugural meeting earlier this week said that the statute should be revised to comply with the Constitution, Chen Chi-mai said the Cabinet team hopes to forge a consensus on amending the statute.
"We hope the two sides will have good interactions to pave the way for amending the statute to facilitate operations of the "truth commission,'" Chen Chi-mai said.

The "319 statute" was authored and railroaded through the legislative floor by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to create the all-powerful "truth commission." The statute was promulgated only after the "pan-blue alliance"-dominated Legislative Yuan overrode the Cabinet's veto in a narrow showdown vote last month.

The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has asked the Council of Grand Justices to impose a temporary injunction on the statute before the council decides whether the statute is unconstitutional. The council will hold a hearing on Oct. 14 to decide whether to impose a temporary injunction and will hold two additional hearings on Oct. 27 and Oct. 29 before issuing its "constitutionality" interpretation.
President Chen took advantage of a meeting with Harvard University law professor Jerome A. Cohen Tuesday to express his views on the "319 statute," lambasting it as "lawless and outrageous."
Chen narrowly won re-election a day after the shooting which happened on the campaign trail. He was only lightly injured.

His challenger, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, insinuated that Chen staged the shooting to win sympathy votes. Although he has offered no evidence to support his allegations, he has filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory and even the validity of the entire election.

Chen said he is not afraid of investigations into the shooting since he did not stage it. "I was a victim of an election-eve incident, " he asserted, adding that he hopes the commission can suspend its operations until the Council of Grand Justices determines whether it is constitutional or not.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CONFLICT ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT DURING CHEN'S TERM: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he believes that there will be no conflict across the Taiwan Strait during his final term as president, since Taiwan will not do anything provocative during that time.

At a meeting with Terry Meguid, head of Investment Banking at Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) , Chen stressed that if Taiwan does nothing to provoke Beijing, he can almost assure that there will be no war between the two sides before 2008, when he will step down as president.
Chen also said that his administration has used economic and non-economic enticements to lure more foreign investments to Taiwan.

As for non-economic incentives, Chen said he puts a great deal of importance on cross-strait ties and wishes to maintain the status quo between the two sides, since peaceful cross-strait relations are key to attracting foreign investments.
The president added that he will give an important speech on cross-strait issues on the Oct. 10 National Day.
In addition to welcoming Meguid to Taiwan at a time when the island is promoting financial reforms, Chen said he admired the MSCI for its increase of market weighting of the MSCI Taiwan Index.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION TO VISIT CZECH REP, HUNGARY AND LATVIA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan legislative delegation left for the Czech Republic, Hungary and Latvia Wednesday to strengthen ties with these European countries that have no diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.

The delegation, headed by Sun Guo-hua, convener of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee, is composed of five legislators from both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and opposition Kuomintang.
Sun noted that they will meet some of their European counterparts during their stay and the visit is aimed at breaking Taiwan's diplomatic isolation by Beijing in the international community.
The delegation is scheduled to return on Oct. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRANSACTIONS FOR TAINAN SCIENCE PARK HIT RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Business transactions for the Tainan Science Park hit a record high of NT$47.21 billion (US$1.39 billion) in July and August, the Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration Bureau said Wednesday.

Transactions in July and August grew 1.49 percent over the May to June period, an increase of 68.13 percent over the same period last year. The accumulated transactions from January to August amounted to NT$170.86 billion, up 68.13 percent over the same period last year, and have already reached 68.35 percent of the annual target.
Transactions for optoelectronics and semiconductor industries made up 97 percent of the park's total.

Transactions in the optoelectronics industry from July to August reached NT$30.94 billion, or 65.53 percent of the park's total, an increase of 109.81 percent over the same period last year. The accumulated transactions from January to August hit NT$113.02 billion, up 124.69 percent over the same period last year.

As for semiconductor industries, business transactions from July to August reached NT$14.91 billion, making up 31.58 percent of the park's total, up 19.56 percent over the same period last year. The accumulated transactions from January to August hit NT$53.38 billion, up 48.23 percent over the same period last year.

The transactions for biotechnology from July to August reached NT$213 million, up 110.64 percent over the same period last year. The accumulated transactions from January to August added up to NT$700 million, up 142.61 over the same period last year.

The transactions for precision machinery from July to August reached NT$838 million. The accumulated transactions from January to August hit NT$2.62 billion, up 36.98 percent over the same period last year.

As for telecommunications, transactions from July to August amounted to NT$139 million. The accumulated transactions from January to August reached NT$552 million, up 37.97 percent over the same period last year.
Transactions for computers and peripherals from July to August added up to NT$151 million. The accumulated transactions from January to August amounted to NT$504 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. NOT TO IMPROVE TIES WITH CHINA AT TAIWAN'S EXPENSE: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Phoenix, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The United States will not improve relations with China at the expense of Taiwan, U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for China Randall Schiver said Tuesday.

Delivering a speech at Arizona State University, Schiver said that the U.S. has maintained good relations with Taiwan even though Washington-Beijing ties are now in the best shape they have been in for the last 30 years.
The U.S. and Taiwan are also cooperating closely in anti-terrorism and security issues, he added.
Schiver praised Taiwan for its active participation in international affairs in spite of not being a member of the United Nations.

In addition to participating in the reconstruction of Iraq, Schiver explained, Taiwan has played an important role in blocking the smuggling of firearms and drugs from North Korea and is the world's third-largest donor for the reconstruction of Afghanistan, behind only the U.S. and Great Britain.

He reiterated that the U.S. policies on China and Taiwan are based on the Three Communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act and that Washington will deliver on its promises to supply necessary defensive arms to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BROADCAST OF MAINLAND RADIO, TV PROGRAMS SUBJECT TO APPROVAL: GIO

TEXT.P: Broadcast of mainland Chinese radio and television programs is subject to prior approval of the Government Information Office (GIO), a senior official said Wednesday.

GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting in response to a question by Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lo Chih-ming as to whether Taiwan business people can use mainland Chinese capital to set up radio stations in Taiwan or purchase mainland radio programs for broadcast at local stations.

Lin said local radio stations are prohibited from selling their stakes to mainland Chinese investors or collaborating with their mainland counterparts in program production or broadcast on a regular basis.

Moreover, Lin said broadcasting any mainland radio or TV programs is subject to advance GIO approval. Mainland programs that propagate communism, contain "united front" propaganda, violate general social customs or may obstruct public order have consistently been blocked from entering Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING INTENSIFIES DIPLOMATIC OFFENSIVE AGAINST TAIWAN: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Wednesday that mainland China has intensified its diplomatic offensive against Taiwan, including sending senior officials to visit Taiwan's diplomatic allies.
Chen made the remarks while delivering a report on the nation's diplomatic situation at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting.
Chen said the intensity and scope of Beijing's diplomatic offensive against Taiwan have continued to expand.
For instance, the minister said, mainland China has often taken advantage of Taiwan diplomatic allies' presidential elections to try to drive a wedge between Taiwan and their new governments.

In addition to sending high-ranking officials to visit countries that diplomatically recognize Taiwan, Chen said, mainland China's mission at the United Nations has also often approached Taiwan's allies to forge friendships and lobbied them to exchange trade offices.
In his report, Chen also expressed regret over a few countries' issuing unbalanced or unjustified statements against Taiwan on international occasions to appease Beijing leaders.

Chen didn't identified those countries. But it was believed that he was referring to Singapore and Australia. Foreign affairs ministers of the two countries recently publicly alleged that Taiwan was pursuing independence, which they said could disrupt regional security and stability.

Meanwhile, Chen said Taiwan's relations with the United States could suffer if the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan fails to approve the NT$610.8 billion special budget bill for procurement of advanced U.S. weapons.
"If the arms deal fails to clear the legislative floor, it will affect the foundation of mutual trust between Taiwan and the United States," Chen said.
The special budget is expected to be reviewed by lawmakers during the current legislative session.

Chen's warning came after U.S. Deputy Undersecretary of Defense Richard Lawless said at an annual U.S.-Taiwan defense industry conference in Arizona a day earlier that Taiwan could face grave repercussions if the deal for eight diesel submarines, 12 anti-submarine aircraft and six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries was delayed.
"Taiwan would be viewed as 'a liability rather than a partner, '" Lawless was quoted as having said at the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POULTRY PRODUCTS PASS JAPANESE INSPECTIONS: COA

TEXT.P: A shipment of about 14 tons of Taiwan's poultry products passed Japanese health inspections Wednesday and were allowed to enter the Japanese market, officials of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said.
The shipment becomes the first of its kind since Aug. 30 when the Japanese government announced it would lift its ban on poultry imports from Taiwan.

Japan imposed the ban Jan. 16, shortly after officials of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the COA discovered the H5N2 bird flu virus for the first time on a poultry farm in central Changhua County earlier the same month.
The COA applied to have the Japanese ban lifted June 11 after a 90-day period had passed without any fresh bird flu cases.
Japan is the largest overseas market for Taiwan's poultry products with an annual consumption of 400 tons of chicken and 3,000 tons of ducks, according to the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMERGING MAINLAND CHINA THREATENS WORLD IF DEMOCRACY DOESN'T BLOSSOM

TEXT.P: Mainland China is rapidly emerging as a strong economy, but being an undemocratic and large country means that it poses a great threat to the world, a prominent mainland dissident based in the United States said Wednesday in Taipei.

Giving a keynote at the Central News Agency on mainland China's crises and the prospects of cross-Taiwan Strait ties, Wang Dan said that a continued influx of foreign capital has made mainland China superficially prosper.

However, mainland China may face serious crises arising from the so-called "relative deprivation" in the years ahead, a sentiment which Wang ascribed to the result of a fervent chase for wealth and prosperity among its people in the process of a social revolution.

Mainland people are increasingly feeling a "relative deprivation" due to both short-term and long-term divulgence in a wide range of fronts about economics, education, politics and urban-rural gaps, Wang said.
Citing a forecast by some observers, he said that a crisis would occur in 2012 within mainland society.
He voiced his strong belief that the Beijing regime is doomed to collapse sooner or later, because "all the authoritarian governments have the same destination -- dismantled overnight."

Should mainland China fail to turn into a democracy, a surging military power, irrational like it is, will become a big threat to the whole world, he contended, suggesting that a democratized Chinese mainland provides the best guarantee for Taiwan's permanent security.

Although many analysts opined that Beijing will not attack Taiwan for the time being, he claimed that such a possibility cannot fully be ruled out as the actions of a dictatorship like that in Beijing are hard to be assessed in advance, evidence being the June 4, 1989 massacre of the student-led pro-democracy movement in Beijing's Tiananmen Square.
Hundreds or even thousands of students were killed by troops sent into Beijing in the Tiananmen Massacre, but the Beijing leaders denied such an incident.

A separation of more than five decades between Taiwan and mainland China due to historical factors is the root cause for the many existing differences between the two sides, he said, pointing out the course of cross-strait relations will in principle depend on the internal changes of both sides.

According to the former student leader in the Tiananmen pro-democracy movement, Chinese Communists are very likely to resolve the Tibet issue under the current leadership formed by President Hu Jintao and Prime Minister Wen Jiabao.
Settling Tibet's pro-independence movement will be in Beijing's interest to later deal with the Taiwan issue, he said.

He called on Taiwan leaders and its people to pay greater attention to changes on the mainland and encouraged President Chen Shui-bian to forge a better and positive relationship with Beijing to pave the way for cooperation.
Wang, currently exiled in the United States after being released from a Beijing prison in 1993, is now studying at Harvard University. He is on an academic research tour in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO GOVERNOR TO BE ON NEW LUXURY TRAIN'S INAUGURAL TRIP IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara will be the honored dignitary Oct. 25 when the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) unveils its newest luxury train, officials of Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Wednesday.
Ishihara was invited on a four-day trip on the new train because the last time he was in Taiwan he said he hoped to have the chance to see Taiwan's beautiful scenery by train.

TRA Director-General Hsu Ta-wen noted that the seats in the new luxury train will be similar to that in an airplane's business class, and the train will have only five coaches to accommodate 120 passengers with free beverages and snacks.
The trip around Taiwan will include stops at high-class hotels, such as the Lalu Sun Moon Lake Hotel, which was once the favorite summer house for late President Chiang Kai-shek.
The four-day trip around Taiwan by the new train will cost NT$25,000 (US$737) per person.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 7, or the 24th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1900: Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of U.S. automobiles in early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build the model T cars.
1919: KLM, the national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled to begin in 1920.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed, with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Communist Chinese troops enter Tibet.
1958: Communist Chinese begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people would eventually participate. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in the loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Mario Lanza, U.S. tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two Communist Chinese pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1974: A 90-member Japanese calligraphic mission led by Akira Koyama arrive in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: U.S. President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "there is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1982: Jimmy Wei, the national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of a heart attack at the age of 77.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the Republic of China government will soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but adds that new political parties should abide by the ROC Constitution and anti-Communist policy. He also emphasizes the ROC will never negotiate with the Communist Chinese.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of the society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan confirms that the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau will formally phase out its controversial "political surveillance" work soon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity, and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAJOR CHANGES IN BEIJING'S TAIWAN POLICY FORESEEN: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Beijing's Taiwan policy is seen as not altering dramatically in the near future despite the fact that the make-up of the mainland Chinese leadership has changed recently, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner said Thursday.

Judging from the remarks that mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao has made publicly since his succession to the chairmanship of the Central Military Commission of the Chinese Communist Party Sept. 20, the overall tone of China's policies toward Taiwan has remained unchanged, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said.

Following the recent Fourth Plenum of the 16th Communist Party of China Central Committee, the basis of Beijing's stance toward Taiwan remains "peaceful unification, " "one country, two systems, " and "the eight-point peace overture of Jiang Zemin," Wu said.

Wu made these remarks at a Legislative Yuan Interior Affairs Committee meeting, recapping the latest political situation across the Taiwan Strait and analyzing the new era of mainland China under the leadership of Hu Jintao.
Although mainland China's fourth-generation leadership under Hu is now firmly established, this does not necessarily mean the internal power struggles and competition have ceased, Wu pointed out.
It is foreseeable that the new mainland Chinese leadership under Hu will make internal reorganization and internal affairs the top administrative priority for a certain period of time, Wu said.
Reviewing measures to cool down mainland China's overheated economy -- measures that have drawn mixed reactions -- will be one of the new leadership's top priorities, Wu continued.

Despite Taiwan's continual peace overtures, including calls for concerted efforts to open the cross-strait "three direct links" and extended charter flight services during the Chinese New Year season, the new mainland leadership has refused to renounce the option of the use of force against Taiwan, Wu noted.
This demonstrates that the new leadership under Hu is not ready to make any new readjustments in the short term to address the cross-strait political deadlock, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 600 FOREIGN DIGNITARIES TO ATTEND ROC NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: Some 600 foreign dignitaries, including Swazi Prime Minister Absalom T. Dlamini, will travel to Taipei to attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Fielding questions at a regular news conference, Lai Chien-chung, director of the MOFA's Protocol Department, said the ministry has continued to invite foreign celebrities and politicians to visit Taiwan to boost friendship, mutual understanding and international cooperation.
"We have a well-organized plan for inviting foreign dignitaries to visit Taiwan, " Lai said, adding that the work has been proceeding smoothly in accordance with the plan.
According to Lai, 64 percent of the MOFA's annual budget for hosting foreign dignitaries' Taiwan visits had been used as of the end of August.

A total of 573 foreign guests will attend this year's National Day celebrations, compared to last year's number of 529, Lai said. The head of state of one of the ROC's diplomatic allies was originally scheduled to attend the National Day celebrations, but he informed the MOFA a few days ago that the travel plan had to be delayed for certain reasons, Lai said.
Lai further said the prime minister of a member state of the British Commonwealth will visit Taiwan shortly after the Double Ten National Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR MALAYSIANS ARRESTED AT CKS AIRPORT FOR SMUGGLING KETAMINE

TEXT.P: Four Malaysian citizens were arrested at CKS International Airport for attempting to smuggle 12.8 kilograms of ketamine into Taiwan, aviation police and customs officials reported Thursday.

It marked the largest ketamine seizure in years. The seized ketamine has an estimated street value of about NT$50 million (US$1.48 million), police said. It also marked the biggest bust in terms of the number of people arrested at one time, they added.
The four passengers -- Koh Ting Moh, Chai Yee Boon, Wong Ah Kheong and his brother Wong Ah Kooi -- arrived at CKS International Airport on a Malaysia Airlines flight Wednesday night.
Customs officials detected unidentified powder in their luggage with an X-ray machine. After a thorough search, the officials discovered the ketamine wrapped up in xerox copy paper and aluminum foil.
Police turned over the four men to the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office. They are currently trying to track down the intended recipient of the ketamine.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAMPIONING CROSS-STRAIT PEACE BILL

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is actively championing cross-strait peace safeguarding legislation aimed at securing peace across the Taiwan Strait for the next 30 to 50 years, PFP sources said Thursday.

The cross-strait peace safeguarding law envisaged by Soong and PFP lawmakers will be conducive to facilitating cross-strait peace talks and helping secure a breakthrough in the current cross-strait political stalemate, PFP legislators said.
A draft of the law has already been penned, and it is expected to be submitted to the Legislative Yuan before Oct. 10 for discussion, PFP Legislator Lee Yung-ping noted.

Other highlights of the cross-strait peace acceleration draft bill include an insistence that the Republic of China is a sovereign state and that its sovereignty be safeguarded at any cost; principles for peaceful interactions across the Taiwan Strait; and a requirement that a peace executive committee be formed and manned by legislators from across Taiwan's political spectrum, PFP legislators said.

It is hoped that through the cross-strait peace safeguarding law, the leaderships of the two sides will commit themselves to pursuing peace based on the principle that as long as Taiwan doesn't declare independence, Beijing will not resort to force against Taiwan, Liu Wen-hsiung, a PFP party whip at the Legislative Yuan said.
Liu added that the peace acceleration law should not only be passed by the Legislative Yuan, but also endorsed by the Taiwan people in a nationwide referendum.
The peace acceleration bill is seen as being the primary "selling point" in the PFP's campaign for the year-end legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: 665 ORGANIZED CRIMINAL RINGS SUBJECT TO SPECIAL POLICE MONITORING

TEXT.P: A total of 665 organized criminal rings, with 6,461 members, have been placed under intense police monitoring, according to a National Police Administration (NPA) report released Thursday.

As underworld gang activities have traditionally been shrouded in secrecy and having underworld gangs closely monitored requires certain prerequisites and procedures, the report said, the actual number of organized gang members should be higher than the officially listed figure.
Of the listed underworld gang members, the report said, 1,171 belong to the Bamboo Gang, accounting for 18 percent of the total and making the Bamboo Gang Taiwan's largest organized criminal ring.
The Four Seas Gang come in second, with 726 members; followed by the Heavenly Gang, with 632 members. These three gangs account for 40 percent of all the gangsters subject to close police monitoring.
Two other gangs -- the Sunglien Gang and the Peilien Gang -- also have members exceeding 100 each, while all the remaining gangs have memberships smaller than 100.

In terms of area, Taipei City boasts the largest number with 2,119, followed by Taipei County with 736, Taoyuan County with 639, Keelung City with 418, Taichung City with 338, Changhua County with 288, Hsinchu City with 210, Kaohsiung City with 208, and Kaohsiung County with 204.
The number of listed gangsters falls below 200 in all other cities or counties. The figures indicates that gangsters tend to converge in northern Taiwan and urban areas, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT VISITS FORMER FIRST LADY FAINA CHIANG IN HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu paid a short visit Thursday to former ROC First Lady Faina Chiang who checked into Taipei Veterans General Hospital the day before suffering from inflammation of the windpipe and acute asthma.

After Lu greeted Chiang in her hospital room, the vice president said that Chiang is greatly respected, and although a native of Russia, she spent most of her prime in Taiwan with her husband, the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, and their children.
Although Faina Chiang, who is 88, has led a secluded life over the past decade, she deserves the concern of all the people of Taiwan, particularly during now that she is ill, Lu said.

Doctors at Veterans General said that Faina Chiang developed breathing problems Wednesday stemming from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, but she is now in stable condition after receiving medication.
Dr. Feng Chang-feng said that there is no timetable at present for Faina Chiang to be released from hospital since she is still undergoing testing.
According to Chiang Fang Chih-yi, Faina Chiang's daughter-in-law, her mother-in-law has had a poor appetite recently and became lethargic Wednesday, prompting the family to rush her to the hospital.
Chiang suffered a stroke in October 1994 and still suffers from atherosclerosis -- or hardening of the arteries, emphysema and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Chiang was dealt a series of blows in her later life. Her health began to decline after President Chiang died in 1988 following a heart attack. Her eldest son, Chiang Hsiao-wen, died the next year, and her second son, Chiang Hsiao-wu, at the time just retired from the post as the ROC representative to Japan, died in 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUPS SENDING RICE TO MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan public interest groups have applied to send rice, totaling 10,120 metric tons, to Mongolia to help relieve food shortages there, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Sacks of the Taiwan rice are on their way to Mongolia and are expected to reach Ulan Bator in batches starting this week, said Lin Chin-chung, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs.
Of the total, 10,000 tons were donated by World Vision Taiwan and 120 tons were bought by the Fulin Rotary Club in northern Taipei City, Lin said.

He added that after discussions with Mongolian authorities, it was decided that the rice will be distributed to the Mongolian people based on a "work relief" program, namely giving the rice to the people who suffer from food shortages but engage in certain community services.
