DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP LASHES OUT AT PENTAGON OFFICIAL'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: A ranking Pentagon official is trying to blackmail Taiwan into buying expensive arms by saying that if Taiwan does not go through with the purchase, others might begin "to regard Taiwan as a liability rather than a partner," a civic group said Thursday.

The Democracy Action Alliance, which is comprised mainly of scholars, was referring to the remarks of U.S. Deputy Undersecretary of Defense Richard Lawless at an annual Taiwan-U.S. defense industry conference in Phoenix, Arizona earlier this week.
Lawless advised Taiwan to display a keen desire to beef up its defense capabilities by approving the controversial military procurement.

Chang Ya-chung, convener of the alliance, claimed that with the upcoming U.S. presidential election on Nov. 2, collaboration between politicians and arms dealers is closer than ever. However, he pointed out that the interests of the U.S. arms dealers do not represent the general sentiments of the American people.

Not all Americans agree that Taiwan should purchase U.S. weapons to show its goodwill toward the U.S., Chang said, adding that many Americans have also been reflecting on whether mixing arms purchases and politics will create problems for international security.

Chang said that arms procurements do not guarantee Taiwan's security. According to Lawless' logic, Chang claimed, Taiwan will need to acquire high-altitude missile defense systems, and more advanced destroyers and fighter planes after the special NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) package of six PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-powered submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft is purchased.

In his view, Chang said, if Taiwan over-purchases, it will find itself financially in the red, which will sap its economic strength. At that point, it would be pointless to acquire more weapons, he added.

He said that the people of Taiwan shouldn't believe the rhetoric of U.S. arms dealers and politicians that "arms will buy security, " adding that the way the ROC government has fawned over the U.S. for affirming the need to purchase the arms is disappointing and denigrating to the people of Taiwan.

He said that cross-strait problems are political, not military issues and the government should use the money to pay its debts first. The government should also communicate with the public about which weapons are needed, he said, adding that the alliance wants to debate with the arms procurement with the Ministry of National Defense.
The alliance initiated a rally last month to protest the arms purchase, saying it is against financing the package through selling national lands and stakes in state-controlled enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET REGRETS UNFRIENDLY TREATMENT BY 'TRUTH COMMISSION'

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan officials expressed their regret Thursday over the unfriendly treatment they received during a meeting with members of the "truth investigation commission."

Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said the Executive Yuan will continue to coordinate with the commission to schedule another meeting for both sides to discuss the possibility of amending a special statute governing the commission's formation.
The opposition-backed commission is aimed at probing the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian on March 19.
The Executive Yuan considers the statute unconstitutional and has had the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) request a constitutional interpretation from the Council of Grand Justices.

It sent five officials, including the spokesman, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan, Minister-without-portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung, and Hsu Chang-yao, head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics to visit the commission on Thursday.
However, the atmosphere of the meeting was unpleasant right from the beginning, with both sides trading accusations.

Commission convener Shih Chi-yang was especially unhappy with President Chen's recent comment that the commission is a "lawless" organization, and he questioned the purpose of the meeting since this is considered a "lawless" agency.
Shih called off the meeting halfway and showed the visitors the door after it became clear that no common ground would be found between the two sides, according to spokesman Chen.
He said the way the commission members treated their guests was regrettable but the Executive Yuan will not give up on its effort to communicate.

Justice Minister Chen said he hopes the commission will suspend its operations until the Council of Grand Justices releases its interpretation on the case, citing problems in implementing the statute.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, however, said, "Even a bad law is a law and the Executive Yuan has no power to resist its implementation."
Wang said the commission should operate according to the statute unless it is determined unconstitutional by the Council of Grand Justices.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERMENT OF TWO LATE PRESIDENTS SCHEDULED FOR JULY OR AUG. IN 2005

TEXT.P: The late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and his son and successor Chiang Ching-kuo will be permanently interred in July or August 2005, an official of the Ministry of National Defense said Thursday.

Lu Lin-tsu, director of the defense ministry's Bureau of Armament and Acquisition, said that the bidding for the construction of the tombs for the two late presidents will open later this month or early next month. The work is scheduled to be completed next June.
The ministry will fully respect the views of the Chiang family concerning the design and construction of the tomb, he said.
After the construction is complete, the Ministry of the Interior will also discuss with the Chiang family about interment arrangements.
"The Chiang family understands the situation and they have not pressured the defense ministry to speed up the process," Lu stressed.

Lu made the remarks after a local newspaper reported Thursday that the wishes of the Chiang family to have the two men buried in a military cemetery in Hsichih, Taipei County next spring may fall through.

The report in the China Times said that the ministry has appropriated NT$27 million (US$801,180) for the burial and construction after receiving a request from the Chiang family earlier this year. But the bidding for the first stage of the project, including a geological survey and the repair of connecting roads failed to attract suitable contractors and the work was delayed numerous times.
Late president Yen Chia-kan and many generals are also buried in the Wutzushan military cemetery known for its serene and beautiful surroundings.
Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing the Chinese mainland to the Mao Zedong-led communist party in a bloody civil war. Chiang died in 1975.
His remains lie embalmed in a temporary mausoleum at Tzuhu in the northern county of Taoyuan, awaiting a proper burial on the mainland.

Chiang ruled Taiwan with an iron fist, using martial law to suppress democracy. However, some view him as a hero for keeping the island out of reach of the Chinese Communists and claim that it was he who fostered a freewheeling market economy.

Chiang Ching-kuo is respected for ending martial law in 1987, shortly before his death, thus unleashing the democratic forces that broke his family's dynastic grip on power and eventually ended the Kuomintang's half-century rule of Taiwan.
Chiang died in 1988 and his remains also lie embalmed in an interim mausoleum at Touliao in Taoyuan County, awaiting a final burial.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF SAYS INCIDENT WITH CHINA POSSIBLE, BUT NOT WAR

TEXT.P: The possibility of an incident in the future with mainland China cannot be ruled out, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday, but he stressed that this would not equate to the outbreak of war.

Against this backdrop, Wu said, Taiwan looks forward to negotiating with mainland China on military confidence-building measures to avert any possible sporadic conflicts and ensure permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait.

The nation's top mainland policy planner made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Home Affairs Committee in response to questions from Legislator Chung Jung-chi of the opposition People First Party about the probability of a cross-strait war.

Noting that although the possibility of an occasional incident similar to the situation after the U.S.-mainland Chinese military aircraft collision in 2001 indeed exists, Wu said this differs from a war.
Therefore, Wu said his statement didn't contradict President Chen Shui-bian's declaration a day earlier that there would be no war across the Taiwan Strait before his term expires in May 2008.
Wu stressed the importance of maintaining cross-strait peace, saying he believes that the international community would not keep silent if Beijing attacked Taiwan without being provoked.

With a view to avoiding any possible sporadic cross-strait conflicts, Wu said mainland China should negotiate with Taiwan for the establishment of a military confidence-building mechanism as soon as possible.

During the meeting, Wu also reaffirmed the government's sincerity to send a delegate acceptable to both sides to Beijing to negotiate special cross-strait charter flight services during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday to facilitate the return of Taiwanese business people operating on the mainland for family reunions.
"It's now up to Beijing to decide whether and when negotiations for such charter flight services can get underway," Wu said.

In terms of the principle of division of power, Wu said, the administration cannot commission any lawmaker or lawmakers to represent it in negotiation with Beijing over the holiday charter flight services.

Asked why the MAC has not followed its previous practice of organizing a legislative delegation to attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations to be hosted by the ROC representative office in Hong Kong this year, Wu said this is mainly because the Hong Kong government declined to issue visas for some Taiwan lawmakers last year.
As to when Pao Cheng-kang, the new ROC representative to Hong Kong, can obtain a working visa to travel to Hong Kong to assume his post, Wu said that day will come soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN NEW YORK CELEBRATES NATIONAL DAY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York held a cocktail reception Wednesday to celebrate the ROC's Oct. 10 National Day, with the participation of more than 1,000 foreign diplomats and Taiwanese expatriates living in the greater New York area.

Andrew L.Y. Hsia, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, expressed gratitude for the participation of the guests, stressing that the ROC government and its people are willing to share its experiences in development with the world community through participation in international organizations.

Hsia expressed hope that Beijing can respect the right of the 23 million people on Taiwan to participate in the world community, and urged China to put aside political squabbles and give priority to the welfare of the people to turn a new page in relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Guests at the occasion included U.S. Congressman Ed Towns, New York state Congressmen Richard Gottfried and Tom Duane, as well as representatives on behalf of New York, Connecticut, New Jersey and Pennsylvania state governments and New York city government.
Several ambassadors of ROC's diplomatic allies stationed at the United Nations also attended.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL DELEGATION TO ENTICE INVESTMENT ABROAD FOR PUBLIC BANKS

TEXT.P: A delegation to be formed of chiefs of government finance and economics agencies is planning to go abroad by the end of this year to woo foreign investment for public banks, an official of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday.

According to the CEPD official, the delegation is expected to embark on a mission to the United States and Europe by year-end at the earliest. Destinations may include New York, London, Zurich and Paris, he revealed.

The announcement came after an Executive Yuan meeting held a day earlier, in which Premier Yu Shyi-kun, CEPD Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng took part.

Citing Yu's remarks in the meeting, CEPD Vice Chairman Yeh Ming-feng said that the government is encouraging Taiwan-based banks to develop themselves into groups with regional and global influence through mergers, consolidation or business alliances with their foreign counterparts to sharpen their competitive edge and grab a larger slice of the world market.

According to Yeh, Yu said that the government expects to see the emergence of one to three regional banking groups headquartered in Taiwan by 2008, and he instructed the delegation to prepare for the mission as quickly as possible.

To increase the possibility of cooperative ventures between local banks and large-scale foreign-based banking institutions, the government will first set its sights on state-run banks, Yeh said, adding that the Central Trust of China, the Bank of Taiwan and the Land Bank of Taiwan are the main targets in the initial stage.
If necessary, the government will allow foreign banks to hold a 100 percent ownership in local banks to serve that end, Yeh said.
In response to the new development, foreign bankers in Taipei hailed the idea but were very reserved about the feasibility, pointing to the large payrolls of Taiwan's public banks.
A foreign bank executive acknowledged their low interest in acquiring or merging with Taiwan's public banks but voiced a greater interest in local private banks.
Merging with Taiwan's state-run banks will not be profitable due to their large assets and workforce, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. report finds Iraqis eliminated illicit arms in 90's.
Iraq had destroyed its illicit weapons stockpiles within months after the Persian Gulf war of 1991, and its ability to produce such weapons had significantly eroded by the time of the American invasion in 2003, the top American inspector for Iraq said in a report made public Wednesday. The report by the inspector, Charles A. Duelfer, intended to offer a near-final judgment about Iraq and its weapons, said Iraq, while under pressure from the United Nations, had "essentially destroyed'' its illicit weapons ability by the end of 1991, with its last secret factory, a biological weapons plant, eliminated in 1996.
Wall Street Journal: Report disputes U.S. assertions on Iraqi weapons.
The chief U.S. arms inspector in Iraq says in a new report that Baghdad abandoned its chemical, biological and nuclear weapons programs a decade ago and they remained largely dormant even as the Bush administration was asserting that the U.S. had intelligence indicating the programs were active. The 1,400-page report, described by U.S. officials as the government's most definitive assessment of Iraq's weapons activities, undercuts one of the administration's main rationales for the war.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLAYS HOST TO HEADS OF FIVE YUANS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his wife, Wu Shu-jen, played host to the heads of the five branches of the government and their wives at a luncheon Thursday.
Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that the luncheon was just a cordial gathering for the exchanges of views on various questions.

The participants did not discuss a commission formed to probe the March 19 shooting of Chen and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the presidential election, a commission the president lambasted as "unlawful and outrageous" earlier this week.
Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen said they did not touch much on politics and it was simply a gathering before the Double-Ten National Day.
All those invited, except for the wife of Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who was unwell, attended the gathering.

Vice President Lu, who was also present, said that the "wives talked more than the men" and that the atmosphere was warm and casual. Lu also presented a doll to the first lady for her grandson's second birthday.
The wife of Premier Yu Shyi-kun presented a bouquet of wild ginger blossom to the first lady.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT TO STRESS NEED FOR NEW CONSTITUTION IN TELECONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will underline the necessity of Taiwan's drafting of a new constitution in a teleconference scheduled with a group of American scholars Friday, organizers said Thursday.

The seminar on Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering and the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations is being jointly organized by the Taipei-based Action for Constitution Taiwan, led by Lee, and the Washington-based Center for Taiwan International Relations.
Lee is expected to deliver a speech at the seminar at 8:30 p.m. (Taipei time).
The U.S. venue for the teleconference will be the Senate, while the Taipei venue will be the Ambassador Hotel.
The organizers said the seminar is aimed at highlighting the absurdity of the existing Constitution and the urgent need for a new one.
While Taiwan is now a model of rising countries in Asia, it cannot become a "normal" country because of mainland China's obstruction and the shackles of the Constitution, they said.

They said the Constitution has become an obstacle for Taiwan to participate in the international community, and that drafting a new constitution will be the only option to help the country out of the dilemma.
They emphasized that the movement promoting a new constitution is not intended to provoke any other country and said that changing the constitution is a right enjoyed by normal countries.

Taiwanese delegates to the seminar will include Senior Presidential Adviser Koo Kwang-ming, Evergreen University Professor Lee Hsien-jung and Chen Lung-chu, chairman of the Taiwan New Century Cultural and Educational Foundation.
The American participants will include former American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Nat Belocchi and several noted scholars, including John Tkacik, Arthur Waldron, Larry Niksch and James E. Auer.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA OFFICIALS DECORATED BY EL SALVADOR

TEXT.P: El Salvador Ambassador to the Republic of China Francisco Ricardo Santana decorated two high-ranking Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials Thursday in recognition of their contributions to bilateral ties between El Salvador and the Republic of China.

Santana, acting on behalf of Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca, bestowed the Order of the Liberator of Slaves Jose Simeon Canas-Grand Cross Degree and the National Order of Jose Matias Delgado-Grand Official Degree on Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Hwang and South and Central America Department Director-General Javier Hou, respectively, MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR CLEAN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called Thursday for clean elections, starting with the legislative elections planned for the end of this year.

Lu made the call during a tea party with female political figures, including Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei, Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu and lawmakers Chou Ching-yu, Lan Mei-chin and Hsu Jung-shu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Lu praised the outstanding ability of Taiwan's female political participants and encouraged them to play a locomotive role in purifying Taiwan's elections with the approach of the Dec. 11 legislative polls. The performance of Taiwan's female political figures is ranked No. 1 in Asia and 20th in the world, she added.
According to the vice president, Taiwan's women should exercise greater influence to cleanse the country's elections, which are traditionally mired in money, corruption and violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE EXPATS PROTEST SINGAPOREAN MINISTER'S REMARKS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Representatives of seven Taiwanese associations in Southern California staged a demonstration in front of Singapore's U.S. West Coast Tourist Promotion Office Wednesday to protest what they called Singaporean Foreign Affairs Minister George Yeo's "inappropriate remarks" about Taiwan.
The 60-plus demonstrators carried posters reading "Support Taiwan Independence" and "One Taiwan, One China" and chanted slogans to express their protest.

Wu Ming-yung, organizer of the demonstration, said Yeo's speech at the 59th session of the U.N. General Assembly in New York last month hurt the feelings of the people of Taiwan and claimed that it will impair Taiwan-Singapore relations.

An official of the Singapore travel office met with Wu shortly after the demonstration began and said as the office is only a quasi-official body, it cannot issue any statement on behalf of the Singapore government. However, the official promised to convey their protest to Singapore's representative office in San Francisco. The demonstration ended peacefully one hour later.

Yeo's said at the U.N. General Assembly that the international community has a strong vested interest in supporting a peaceful resolution of cross-Taiwan Strait conflict, based on the "one China" policy adopted by the United Nations in 1971.

Yeo also blamed cross-strait tension on Taiwan, claiming that cross-strait relations "went from bad to worse" as pro-independence forces in Taiwan became "increasingly adventurous" during the office of former President Lee Teng-hui, who has described himself as "Moses leading his people out of Egypt."

Yeo further said the international community should not allow "the deteriorating relationship" across the Taiwan Strait to get out of control and warned that the pro-independence movement in Taiwan is likely to trigger a war with the mainland and upset stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TV ANCHORWOMAN ELECTED TO HEAD WORLD BODY OF WOMEN JOURNALISTS
DOC.DATELINE: Madrid, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By T.L. Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan news anchorwoman Shen Chun-hua was elected as the president of the World Association of Women Journalists and Writers (or Asociacion Mundial de Mujeres Periedistas y Escritoras, AMMPE) at the 16th congress of the organization in Spain Wednesday.
Shen, head of Taiwan's nine-member delegation and an anchorwoman for China Television Company, was elected unanimously on the last day of the three-day meeting in Salamanca.

Fu Yi-ping, secretary-general of the delegation, said the activities during the meeting were tightly scheduled, with speeches, seminars and group discussions in the mornings and visits to cultural and artistic sites of the historic city in the afternoons.
The reports by the Taiwan delegates were "meaty, " she said, adding that the delegation was welcomed by the other participants because of their versatility and dynamism.

The AMMPE, one of the United Nations' non-government organizations, was founded by Mexican woman journalist and writer Gloria Salas de Calderon. The Republic of China joined the organization in 1986, and hosted a world congress in 1996.
The organization holds a congress every two years. Women journalists and writers from more than 30 countries around the world attended this year's meeting.
It was also decided that an AMMPE director and supervisors meeting will be held in Taiwan next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE CONTINUES TO GROW IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade continued its strong momentum in September, with both exports and imports registering double-digit growth for the 11th consecutive month since last October, the Ministry of Finance reported Thursday.

The ministry's statistics show that outbound shipments amounted to US$14.96 billion in September, while imports stood at US$14.21 billion, up 19.2 percent and 29.4 percent, respectively, from the previous year's levels.
The figures represent the second- and third-highest single-month export and import values, with the monthly trade surplus totaling US$750 million, according to the ministry.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the ministry's Department of Statistics, attributed the growth to robust demand from Hong Kong, mainland China, Japan, Southeast Asia and South Korea, which rose more than 17 percent year-on-year.
At the same time, inbound shipments from Hong Kong, the mainland, Japan, South Korea and the United States also increased by over 26 percent, Hsu said.
He predicted that trade will continue to expand in the fourth quarter as a result of seasonal demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: MADAME CHIANG'S PERSONAL EFFECTS TO GO ON DISPLAY SATURDAY

TEXT.P: A large collection of personal effects that once belonged to Madame Chiang Kai-shek will go on display at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei Saturday to mark the anniversary of the most famous ROC first lady's death, organizers said Thursday.

Shao Ming-huang, director of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) party history department, which organized the rare show, said many of the exhibits were loaned by Madame Chiang's relatives in the United States.
"The Oct. 9-Nov. 5 exhibition will be the largest of its kind ever held in Taiwan," Shao said.

Among the exhibits will be 28 Chinese brush paintings created by Madame Chiang, who died at her New York home Oct. 24, 2003 at the age of 106, Shao said, adding that many of the paintings carry the late President Chiang Kai-shek's handwriting. Major painting utensils used by Madame Chiang will be also on display.
Other exhibits will include a number of her personal effects, including costumes, handbags, shoes, hats, jewels and other accessories.
"Moreover, photos featuring Madame Chiang wearing those fashionable articles will be shown to allow the audience to remember her grace and fashion taste," Shao said.
On display will also be Madame Chiang's manuscripts and personal letters, as well as historical documents and photos featuring her and her husband.
Madame Chiang, whose life traversed three centuries, helped the late president rule mainland China and later Taiwan during years of war, upheaval and Cold War tension.

The Chiangs were once one of the most famous couples in the world -- a dashing general married to a beautiful, urbane woman. Time magazine publisher Henry Luce named them "Man and Woman of the Year" in 1938. Chiang Kai-shek headed the KMT and the Republic of China for decades until he died April 5, 1975.

Madame Chiang led a reclusive life at her Manhattan home for much of her later life after her husband's death. Born Soong Mei-ling, she became widely known in the West as a spokeswoman for Chinese efforts to resist the Japanese forces that began invading China in the 1930s.

After the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland, the Republic of China government, under her husband's leadership, moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949. Chiang and his wife became Asia's foremost anti-communist symbols.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT PEACE TALKS

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh clamored Thursday for peace across the Taiwan Strait, urging Taiwan and mainland China to hold talks to avoid military conflict that could affect the whole world.
Lee issued the call while reporting at a legislative committee.
Commenting on the government's plan to purchase NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) worth of defensive weapons from the United States, Lee suggested that the two sides hold talks to build peace.
To achieve this aim, he said, the mainland should forswear its military intimidation of Taiwan and Taiwan should drop the expensive military procurement plan.
"Peace will be built upon joint efforts from the two sides, " he said, adding that "my stance and keen desire is to seek peace."

Pointing out that promoting Taiwan independence is highly risky that could undermine the whole world's interests, the Academia Sinica chief said it is good that the mainland is increasingly involved in the world's economic system today -- more than 30 years after the end of the Cultural Revolution.
A more democratic mainland China will provide greater security for Taiwan, he said.

To prevent the breakout of "a third world war across the strait," the leaders on both sides should exercise extra caution in their words and deeds to stave off misunderstanding and miscalculation that could bring about massive destruction, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EMBASSIES, REPRESENTATIVE OFFICES CELEBRATE NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Republic of China embassies and representative offices abroad have presented a series of activities in recent days to celebrate the country's Oct. 10 National Day, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Thursday.

According to the officials, the ROC Embassy in the Vatican held a cocktail reception Thursday to mark the day, attended by some 300 Vatican officials, foreign diplomats stationed in the Holy See, and Taiwanese expatriates living in Italy.
In Paraguay, a photo exhibition featuring cooperation projects between the South American country and Taiwan was held the same day to mark the event.

In Canada, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office organized a cocktail party Wednesday, with the participation of more than 800 Canadian congressmen, foreign diplomats stationed in Canada, as well as overseas Taiwanese residing there.

Thomas Chen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada, expressed gratitude to both the Senate and House of Commons of Canada for their support of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization as an observer.

In Russia, the representative office in Moscow for the Taipei-Moscow Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission also held a cocktail reception Wednesday, during which ROC Representative to Russia Chen Jung-chie noted that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Russia had reached US$1.93 billion as of the end of August, already exceeding the volume registered the previous year. He added that it is expected to total US$2.5 billion at the end of this year, a record high.

Noting that both countries have had frequent exchanges in economic, scientific, and cultural spheres during the last few years, Chen expressed hope that the two countries can continue their substantial ties and cooperation.

Meanwhile, the Taipei Representative Office in the Netherlands held a cocktail reception in which Taiwanese officials introduced the island's political and economic achievements, as well as its beautiful scenery through a series of DVDs.

Katharine Chang, ROC Representative in the Netherlands, told the more-than 300 guests that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Holland had increased 43 percent as of the end of August, a record growth that makes the country a new close trading partner of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE WANT REFERENDUM ON ARMS PROCUREMENT: KMT POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of the people who responded to a recent survey said they want the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration put its NT$610.8 billion arms procurement package to a referendum, the Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus said Thursday.

The KMT caucus conducted the telephone poll of 1,069 randomly chosen adult residents Sept. 29-Oct. 1 to explore their views on the Cabinet's plan to purchase six PAC-III Patriot anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States with a price tag of NT$610.8 billion.
According to the poll results, 50 percent of the respondents said the price is too high and 33 percent said the price should be cut by NT$300 billion.
The poll also found that 56 percent want the procurement package put to a referendum, while 30 percent oppose such a proposal.

Meanwhile, 55 percent said they are worried that the arms procurement package could accelerate the cross-Taiwan Strait arms race, while 28 percent said they hope to see the package clear the legislature for the sake of safeguarding national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: IEA GENERAL ASSEMBLY TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 45th general assembly of the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA) will be held in Taipei from Oct. 11-14, National Science Council (NSC) officials said Thursday.
More than 100 representatives from 61 IEA member countries are expected to participate in the assembly, which will be jointly organized by the Cabinet-level NSC and the Ministry of Education.

The IEA, an international organization composed of privately and government-run investigation centers from around the world, is dedicated to the study and evaluation of educational achievement in member countries.

Taiwan, an IEA permanent executive member, is participating in IEA research projects including Trends in Mathematics and Science Study, Progress in International Reading Literacy Study and Teacher Education and Development Study.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU SEEKS SPEEDY CONSTITUTIONAL INTERPRETATION ON TRUTH COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called Thursday for a speedy constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices of an opposition-backed "truth investigation commission, " which he said will seriously damage the country's constitutional order.

Yu made the call during an inspection visit to a free trade zone being planned at Kaohsiung Port, on which he was accompanied by Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai and lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

In addition to encouraging the port authorities to achieve a target of handling 10 million containers next year based on an estimated performance of 9.7 million for this year, the premier also harshly criticized the establishment of the commission.

Yu said that he hopes for an early constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices on the controversial commission to minimize the damage it could cause to the country's constitutional order.

The premier was referring to a special 10-member body set up by the opposition, supposedly to "dig out the facts" behind the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian. A statute paving the way for the formation of the commission cleared the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan in August and was promulgated by President Chen late last month.

He also called for greater public support for the DPP in the Dec. 11 legislative elections. Giving the ruling party a majority in the 225-member legislature will provide the administration with a boost and allow it to carry out sweeping reforms on a wide range of fronts, he said.
The opposition-led "truth investigation commission" began its operations Monday but the Executive Yuan called it an unlawful body and refused to allocate a budget for its operations.
Shih Chi-yang, a former Judicial Yuan president, serves as convener of the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCT. 8 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are major events scheduled to take place Friday, Oct. 8:
09: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive Chad Foreign Minister Nagoum Yamassoum at the Presidential Office.
09:00, The Taiwan-Sweden economic cooperation conference will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center.
09:30, Vice President Annette Lu will attend the world convention of five clans from Leishan at the Taipei International Convention Center.
09:30, The Taiwan-Germany economic cooperation conference will be held at the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel in Taipei.
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat President Ron Klemencic at the Presidential Office.
10:00, Vice President Annette Lu will participate in an activity to promote health at the Presidential Office.
10: 00, The 2004 Taitronics Show will open at the Taipei World Trade Center.
10: 30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
11: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will decorate Taiwan's 2004 Athens Paralympic Games medalists at the Presidential Office.
12:20, The Inauguration of the Taiwan-Korea Business Council will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center Club.
13: 00, Ex-President Lee Teng-hui will attend a Rotary Club meeting at the Holiday Inn in Taipei.
14: 00, The National Awards Ceremony for Small- and Medium-Sized Businesses will be held at the Grand Hyatt Taipei.
14: 00, A rehearsal for the Double-Ten National Day celebrations will be held at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.

16: 20, The Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.
20: 30, A Taipei-Washington teleconference on a new constitution for Taiwan will open at the Ambassador Hotel in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 8, or the 25th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: John Hay, U.S. statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "Open Door Policy" toward China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers and 12 of the vessel's sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at the instigation of the Japanese.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrial average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1973: Thai Air Force Marshal Boon Choo Chandrubekas arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Economic Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for the United States to attend the China Week Celebration at Expo 74 in Spokane, Washington.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1981: A team of 10 divers recovers 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of the "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in the Barents Sea in 1942.
1981: Costa Rican President Rodrigo Carazo Odio, Madame Carazo, and their 12-member entourage arrive in Taipei for a five-day official visit.
1984: Beijing announces a plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe, and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's Legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to Communist China.
1998: The U.S. House of Representatives approves the launching of a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation against a U.S. president in the country's history.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei says the ROC is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.
2000: Direct air links between Taipei and Manila resume after a protracted dispute over air rights.
2000: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen throws his weight behind the island's controversial fourth nuclear power plant despite the fact that the Cabinet seems determined to stop its construction.
2001: Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao reaffirms that the Republic of China government is opposed to any form of terrorism and that it will "actively participate" in the anti-terrorism campaign launched by the United States.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian receives Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, the head of a Japanese delegation for the ROC National Day celebrations.
2001: The National Police Administration (NPA) instructs police to strengthen protection of foreign personnel stationed in Taiwan following the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of originality, energy, strength of character and determination: qualities necessary for the exercise of endurance."

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL TV CELEBRITY TO RUN FOR LEGISLATIVE SEAT

TEXT.P: Local TV variety show host Wu Tsung-hsien will run in the year-end legislative elections under the banner of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) , according to reports Friday.

It has not been decided yet whether the newly-formed party will arrange for Wu to run for a regional legislative seat representing the NPSU or instead have him listed as an NPSU candidate for a legislator-at-large seat, NPSU Secretary-General Chen Jung-chieh said.
Legislator Tsai Hao, who is the incumbent vice chairman of the NPSU, said that Wu will formally announce his election bid at a press conference next Monday.

Wu, a TV celebrity who has been one of the hottest targets of local paparazzi because of his colorful private life, has reportedly amassed a fortune over the years in his career as an entertainer and a businessman.
Wu has said that if he were a lawmaker, one of the areas he would like to straighten up is the local media.
Kao Chin Su-mei, one of the 11 current NPSU legislators, is a movie-star-turned-lawmaker who has focused her attention on the welfare of Taiwan's aboriginal people.
The 2004 legislative elections are scheduled to be held Dec. 11, according to the Central Election Commission (CEC).
All 225 seats will be up for grabs, including 168 regional legislative seats, eight Aboriginal seats, eight overseas Chinese seats and 41 at-large seats.

The 168 regional legislators will be elected from the special municipalities, counties and cities around the country, including the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, while the 41 at-large legislators will be chosen based on the total number of ballots each political party garners in the elections.

The parties fielding candidates are the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, its ally the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, the Kuomintang, and the People First Party, as well as the newly established Non-Partisan Solidarity Union. Another newly formed group, the Taiwan Democracy School, is also poised to recommend a number of candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH CHADIAN MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with Chadian Foreign Affairs Minister Nagoum Yamassoum at the Presidential Office Friday for wide-ranging talks.
Chen thanked Yamassoum for his traveling halfway around the world to Taipei to attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations.
Chen also expressed hopes that cooperation between the two countries will further expand in the years ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUWAITI OIL FIRM PLANS TO INVEST IN CHINA: HONG KONG STANDARD

TEXT.P: Kuwait Petroleum Company (KPC) , one of the Middle East's top oil producers, has offered to invest as much as US$3 billion in mainland China's oil refining and distribution system, the English-language Hong Kong Standard reported Friday.
According to the report, the oil firm aims to secure a significant presence in the world's fastest-growing energy market.

Quoting mainland Chinese and Kuwaiti oil industry sources, the report said that the offer has met with a cool response from China's oil giants, who are not keen to see a well-heeled competitor enter their backyard.

KPC's offer, the report said, follows an official visit to Beijing by Kuwait's prime minister during which the two governments signed a framework agreement pledging closer co-operation in a variety of areas including energy. That deal paved the way for talks between government-owned KPC and several of China's partly-privatized oil majors, including PetroChina, Sinopec and CNOOC as well as their trading subsidiaries, including Chinaoil and Unipec.

However, KPC is not interested in investing in refining without at the same time securing a foothold in China's oil retailing market, which is currently controlled by Sinopec and PetroChina, according to the report.
The sticking point is that the mainland Chinese oil firms are reluctant to share their huge domestic market with foreign companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-GERMANY ECONOMIC COOPERATION CONFAB OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 6th Taiwan-Germany Economic Cooperation Conference opened in Taipei Friday with more than 100 officials and business leaders from the two countries taking part.

Rezzo Schlauch, a vice minister of economic affairs in Germany, led the German delegation to the conference, signifying the importance that Germany attaches to the annual gathering, said officials from the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA), sponsor of the conference.

The CIECA and the Taiwan Committee of the German Economy have been largely instrumental in arranging the holding of the Taiwan-Germany Economic Cooperation Conference, which is aimed at building regular communication channels between business and trade communities from Taiwan and Germany and in turn advancing bilateral private sector cooperation, the CIECA officials said.

Hsieh Fa-ta, a vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, delivered a keynote speech at the conference on Taiwan's current economic situation and the development of its service industry.

Hsieh briefed the participants on the Taiwan government's current policies in helping accelerate industrial upgrading and restructuring in the private sector aimed at sharpening Taiwan's international competitiveness and enabling the island to carve a niche in the world's economic and industrial chain.

Other speakers at the conference included officials from Taiwan's Industrial Development and Investment Center, the Tourism Bureau, and the Industrial and Technology Research Institute, as well as Germany's National Tourism Bureau and Siemens AG.
Areas that the speakers dealt with included public infrastructure, investment, energy, environmental protection, tourism and information technology, the CIECA officials said.
Germany is Taiwan's largest trade partner in Europe. Two-way trade between the two countries totaled some US$9.17 billion in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO PROTECT SAFETY OF `TAISHANG'

TEXT.P: The Beijing authorities should strengthen the protection of the safety of Taiwanese businessmen operating in mainland China, commonly known as "taishang, " a senior Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san made the call after reports that a taishang, identified as Hsu Shih-chieh, was murdered in Kunshan near Shanghai late last month.

Quoting official tallies, Chiu said the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) had handled 1,202 cases involving cross-Taiwan Strait disputes as of the end of August. Of these cases, 672 were related to the safety of taishang.

A spate of high-profile murders involving taishang between June and July last year caused panic among taishang and their families, Chiu said, adding that the latest murder has caused grave concern again.

"We hope the mainland Chinese authorities will pay more heed to protect the safety and interests of taishang," Chiu said, adding that the mainland should substantiate its promise to protect taishang by signing an investment guarantee agreement with Taiwan.

Taiwan businessmen have poured billions of dollars into the mainland for various investment projects since the late 1980s. For years, Taiwan has pushed Beijing to sign a bilateral investment guarantee agreement to offer better protection for taishang's interests and rights. However, Beijing has so far been reluctant to start relevant negotiations with Taiwan.

For the sake of mutual benefits, Chiu said, Beijing should not continue to drag its feet on the issue. Even before such an accord is signed, Chiu said the mainland authorities should take immediate steps to protect the safety, rights and interests of taishang.

Chiu further said that the MAC, the SEF, major local trade associations and Taiwanese chambers of commerce on the mainland will also step up efforts to offer better services and assistance to taishang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO COMMUNICATE WITH 'TRUTH' COMMISSION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that the government will communicate with a commission set up under a special statute to investigate the March 19 election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

Yu made the remarks after five officials sent by the Cabinet to call on the March 19 truth investigation commission ended in a row the previous day in which both sides traded accusations, with one side questioning the constitutionality of the body and the other side asking the point of the visit if they regard it as "unlawful" as President Chen has described it.

The premier said that he felt sorry for the five officials, but stressed that the Executive Yuan is sincere and that communication must continue before a revision of the "truth" bill and a ruling on the constitutionality of the bill by the Council of Grand Justices has been issued.
"As long as there is consensus, the Executive Yuan will work with the commission," Yu said.

The premier said that Shih Chi-yang, convener of the 10-member so-called "truth" commission, advocates an amendment of the controversial bill, which the Executive Yuan considers a vindication of its earlier request for a legislative reconsideration of the bill.
He called for continued communication so as to avoid damage to society and a dilemma for civil servants.
The premier's words came as the commission suffered another blow Friday when a second official failed to respond to its request to give a briefing to the commission.

Wang Ching-feng, spokeswoman of the commission and a former member of the Control Yuan, said the failure of Hou You-yi, commissioner of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) , to show up was "regrettable, although expected."
Wang said that since the inauguration of the commission, it has continued to request various personnel to present themselves for interviews over the shooting.

The commission asked the Tainan Prosecutor's Office to send officials Thursday, but waited in vain. Shih Chi-yang, convener of the 10-member commission, went to Tainan, southern Taiwan, to call on them Friday.

She claimed that the commission was set up under the law and must work with the administrative and prosecutorial agencies to probe the shooting in Tainan, southern Taiwan, which the defeated opposition claims helped Chen edge out his rival in the election the following day.

Noting that the commission has yet to receive funds from the government and that an independent legislator had suggested that it should solicit donations to facilitate its operation, Wang said that as a government body established under the law the commission cannot accept donations.
The commission estimates that it will need NT$10 million (US$295,850) for basic expenses and is hopeful that the comptroller-general will allocate an appropriate budget, Wang said.
The commission has so far spent around NT$250,000, all provided by the members themselves, she said.

Meanwhile, Kao Cheng-sheng, deputy CIB commissioner, said that as the Executive Yuan believes the legality of the commission is "questionable" and as the implementation of the bill is difficult, the CIB hopes that the legislature will revise the bill soon so that it can work with the commission.

Kao also said that CIB, at the request of the Tainan Prosecutor's Office, has turned over forensic and investigation reports to the office and will await instructions from the Prosecutor's Office to work with the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20TH TAIWAN-SWEDEN ECONOMIC COOPERATION CONFERENCE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Sweden welcomes Taiwan investors to make the Scandinavian country their new investment hub, from where they can make inroads into the global market, a Swedish official said here Friday.

Lotta Fogde, a vice minister from Sweden's Ministry of Industry, Employment and Communication, said that Sweden, boasting advanced research and development in telecom infrastructure, biotechnology and other hi-tech industries, is worthy of Taiwan investment to help sharpen the country's competitiveness in the global market.

Fogde made the remarks at the 20th Taiwan-Sweden Economic Cooperation Conference which opened in Taipei Friday. She is the highest-ranking Swedish official ever to have been invited to take part in the Taiwan-Sweden Economic Cooperation Conference in the recent decade.

More than 100 government officials and business leaders from Taiwan and Sweden took part in the one-day conference sponsored by the Taipei-based Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA).
Participants in the conference focused their discussions on telecom and information technologies, biotechnology and environmental protection, CIECA officials said.

Also addressing the conference, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said that Taiwan and Sweden have maintained close economic and trade relations over the years. Bilateral trade totaled US$755 million in the first eight months of this year, up a whopping 16.6 percent over the corresponding period of the previous year, Yiin said.
The holding of this meeting will give a big boost to both sides and will enable bilateral business and trade ties to grow even faster in the future, according to Yiin.

Yiin said that while Sweden is an important trade partner for Taiwan in Scandinavia, Taiwan could serve as a gateway for Swedish businesses eager to expand their investments and sales throughout Asia.
Other prominent figures from Sweden that took part in the conference included Kurt Hellstrom, former president of the Swedish telecom giant Ericsson.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved up one point to finish at 6,128, with 650 contracts traded, while December futures gained seven points to finish at 6,120, with 13 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,134 for October, 6,127 for November, 6,113 for December, 6,085 for March and 6,048 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
October TE futures moved down 1.3 points to close at 224.2, with 5,372 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 1.4 points to finish at 224, with 164 contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 0.84 points to close at 6,102.16.

The bourse opened at 6,083.01 and fluctuated between 6,115.93 and 6,073.41 during the day's trading. A total of 4.33 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$94.75 billion (US$2.79 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, and construction issues, plastics and chemicals shares and cement stocks all at 0.4 percent.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down at 0.8 percent and textile stocks at 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 335 to 303, with 174 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGISTRATION STARTED FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Registration for the 6th legislative elections scheduled for Dec. 11 are being accepted at local-level election committees from Friday until next Tuesday, according to an announcement by the Central Election Commission (CEC).
However, the list of nominees for at-large legislative seats and seats representing overseas Chinese must be submitted directly to the CEC by political parties, CEC officials said.
The order of the candidates will be decided by a draw Nov. 17 after their qualifications have been reviewed by the CEC, they added.
Politicians seized the opportunity Friday to attract media attention as they competed to finish their registration on the first day.
In Taipei City, a team of five candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) jumped on the bandwagon of the recent Olympic frenzy by wearing fake gold medals on their chests.

Calling themselves "gold-medal warriors, " the team, including incumbent legislators Shen Fu-hsiung, Kuo Cheng-liang, Tuan Yi-kang and Lan Mei-chin, as well as Taipei City Councilor Wang Shih-chien, expressed confidence in their chances of victory.

Not to be outdone, opposition People First Party (PFP) candidates Lee Ching-an, Pang Chien-kuo, Lin Yu-fang, Lee Yung-ping, Hsu Yuan-kuo and Chin Huei-chu tore apart plastic bags symbolizing "unemployment and recession" to highlight their platform of boosting the economy.
Chin went a step further, arriving to register in a white naval uniform, standing on a rubber raft borne by six men.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Justine Chou arrived barefoot, wearing a baseball suit of the Chinese Taipei Olympic team, while aboriginal DPP candidate Chen Ying appeared dressed in traditional aboriginal costume and singing a traditional aboriginal song.
In Taipei County, KMT candidate Lin Hung-chih brought along a hunting dog dressed in a campaign vest to act as his campaign assistant.

DPP candidate Wu Ping-jui, meanwhile, cooked two dishes at the scene, which he said represented the "constitutional freak" of the opposition-backed "truth investigation commission" and the ill-gotten assets of the KMT.
In Taichung County, Yen Ching-piao of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union was accompanied by a cheering team of 3,000 people who waved banners and chanted slogans to drum up support for him.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MULLING PIG EXPO IN 2007

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday that it is planning to sponsor a pig exposition in 2007.

The nation's top economic policy planer said that the event could be linked to a Taiwan expo scheduled for 2008 and it has initially estimated that the pig expo will cost about NT$360 million (US$10.68 million) , which would be the largest-scale expo of this type in years.

The Animal Technology Institute, which proposed the idea to the CEPD, said that before the outbreak of foot and mouth disease in Taiwan in 1997, Taiwan had 15 million pigs. Even after the decimation of the hogs in the wake of the disease, the number remains at around 8 million on average per year.

Institute officials said pork is the main source of animal protein for local people, citing statistics to show that Taiwan people consume 40 kg of pork -- about half a pig -- per person per year, compared with only 3.5 kg of beef.
Because of the love of pork, the technology for raising pigs is also world-class, the officials said.
According to the preliminary plan, the 2007 pig expo will include such activities as a photo exhibition of pigs of the world, as well as delicious local and world pork dishes.

There will also be a pig Olympics, gathering different species of pigs in an arena for competitions, as well as 10,000 people producing sausages to gain a niche in the Guineas Book of World Records, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN NEW PARTY POLITICIANS JOIN KMT

TEXT.P: A group of seven opposition New Party politicians were Friday sworn in as members of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in what was seen as the first step in the integration of the "pan-blue alliance.".
The politicians will run under the KMT banner in the year-end legislative elections.

Fei Hung-tai, Lai Shyh-bao, Lee Sheng-feng, Lei Chien, Chen Li-ling, Chen Shu-wan and Lu Li-kang took the oath at the KMT headquarters, in the company of New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming and the party's only legislator, Wu Cheng-tien.
Presenting letters of recommendation to the candidates, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said he was very happy to see the like-minded friends from the New Party return to the KMT at this crucial moment.
Lien said the New Party, which split from the KMT 12 years ago, is now responding to a call from "pan-blue" supporters who expect solidarity in the camp.
He praised the New Party for its unselfishness and wished the candidates great success in the elections.

Yok claimed that this is the first step in "pan-blue" solidarity and promised to continue to push for the integration of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party for the ultimate goal of a merger of the three.

Lee Sheng-feng, another founding member of the New Party, said that only a merger of the three parties will be strong enough to resist what he called the "pro-independence fascist dictatorship" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and find out "the truth" behind the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTERS DEGREE HOLDERS EDGE OUT BACHELOR GRADUATES IN WORKPLACE: POLL

TEXT.P: Masters degree holders have markedly edged out bachelor graduates in Taiwan's workplace, a recent survey has found.

According to the results of the poll carried out by the Career employment Website, more than 45 percent of Taiwan companies prefer hiring masters degree holders rather than university graduates, even though the jobs require only bachelor degree holders.

Some 52 percent of the companies surveyed said that their hiring of masters degree holders was not to meet actual work needs, but rather a reflection of the situation of the current employment market, in which the number of masters and doctoral degree holders is growing fast.

Statistics showed that the number of Taiwan students pursuing a masters degree has jumped to more than 160,000 from 50,000 five years ago. The number of graduate schools has also increased to top 2,000 from about 800 during the same period.

In terms of professions, jobs related to research, marketing, overseas sales representatives, head hunting and legal consultation have the highest ratios of personnel with a masters degree, the survey discovered.
Around 88 percent of the hi-tech companies hope to recruit researchers with a masters degree background, while 46 percent of them harbor the same idea for overseas sales positions.
Some 84 percent of the financial services companies and about 47 percent of the law offices said that they will do the same while advertising for new employees.

The employment information Website conducted the survey in September and recovered 201 valid questionnaires from human resources executives working for Taiwan's top 1,000 companies in the manufacturing sectors and top 500 in the service sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZILAND PRIMER MINISTER VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Swaziland Prime Minister Absalom Dlamini, leading an eight-member delegation, arrived in Taipei Friday for a five-day visit.
Accompanying Dlamini were Swaziland Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade Mabili Dlamini, Congressman Nokukhanya Gamedze, and other high-ranking government officials.

During his stay, Dlamini will meet President Chen Shui-bian, who will confer upon him the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of bilateral ties.
In addition to attending the activities to celebrate Republic of China National Day on Oct. 10, Dlamini will also meet Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen.

Dlamini's delegation will also visit the International Cooperation and Development Fund, which is under the supervision of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and several cultural and economic establishments in Taiwan, including the National Palace Museum and the Taipei World Trade Center.
