The Moscow Times: CIA: Russia Got Rich Violating Sanctions.
Russian government officials, political leaders and companies helped Saddam Hussein secretly amass $11 billion between 1996 and 2003 and pocketed an estimated $130 million, violating intricate UN sanctions on Iraq in the run-up to the U.S. invasion, a CIA report says.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Death toll is uncertain after three explosions strike resort towns.
Three explosions shook three Egyptian Sinai resorts popular with vacationing Israelis on Thursday night. There were conflicting reports on the number of casualties. Egypt said at least 30 people were killed, including 12 Egyptians. But an Israeli official later said he could confirm only 14 or 15 dead, including five or six Israelis. Earlier, Israel Radio had reported that at least 35 people were killed and more than 100 wounded.
Wall Street Journal: Blasts in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula kill at least 21, injure scores.
Blasts from a car bomb and a suicide bomber tore through a resort hotel in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula where Israelis were vacationing at the end of a Jewish holiday Thursday night, officials said. There were at least 19 dead and the toll was likely to rise.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN TO GO INTO ONE-MONTH RECESS NOV. 10

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will go into recess Nov. 10 for a month to prepare for the Dec. 11 elections for members of the next legislature.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng made the announcement Friday after a consultative meeting of representatives from the legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties.

Wang said the legislature is scheduled to resume work Dec. 13. During the consultations, Wang said the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) did not propose holding an extra session before the recess to screen the NT$610.8 billion special budget bill for the procurement of eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries from the United States.

The DPP caucus instead expressed hope that the draft package of amendments to the statute governing the Financial Reconstruction Fund can clear the legislative floor before the one-month recess, Wang said, adding that the legislature may hold an extra session to screen the package before Nov. 10.

It was also decided during the consultations that the legislative caucuses of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , the People First Party (PFP) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) will jointly designate from one to three of their legislators to defend the controversial "319 truth commission" statute in two hearings to be called by the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) later this month to decide whether the statute violates the Constitution or not.
Wang said the three caucuses will unveil a short-list of their debate representatives next week.

Meanwhile, the caucuses of the DPP and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- both of which jointly applied for a CGJ interpretation of the statute's constitutionality -- said they will send three lawmakers to take part in the two debates.

The statute was authored and railroaded through the legislature by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP to create an all-powerful special commission to investigate an assassination attempt against President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of the bitterly contested March 20 Presidential election.
The statute was promulgated only after the "pan-blue alliance"-dominated Legislative Yuan overrode the Cabinet's veto in a narrow showdown vote last month.

The DPP legislative caucus has asked the CGJ to impose a temporary injunction on the statute until the council decides whether the statute is unconstitutional. The council will hold a hearing Oct. 14 to decide whether to impose a temporary injunction and will hold two additional hearings Oct. 27 and Oct. 29 before issuing its "constitutionality" interpretation.

Chen narrowly won re-election a day after the March 19 shooting on the campaign trail. He was only lightly injured. His challenger, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, has insinuated that Chen staged the shooting to win sympathy votes. Although he has offered no evidence to support his allegations, he has filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory and even the validity of the entire election. The Taiwan High Court has yet to hand down verdicts on the two lawsuits.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHEREABOUTS OF HONG KONG REPORTER REMAINS A MYSTERY

TEXT.P: A Singapore journalist working for Hong Kong's Oriental Daily newspaper has been reported missing in Taiwan, government sources said Friday.

Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said the whereabouts of Wong Yuk Tung, a Singapore national, remained unknown as of noon Friday and that relevant government agencies have begun a search for him.
According to authorities from the National Police Administration (NPA) , Wong arrived in Taiwan Sept. 9 as a solo backpacker for a four-day trip.
The police found that he checked into the Holiday Inn Asia World Taipei Sept. 9 and checked out Sept. 12 as scheduled. Hotel staff said the young man did not behave unusually during his stay.
The Oriental Daily contacted the Government Information Office a couple of days ago in the hope that the NPA would mount a search.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHEAP OPTIONS FOR NATIONAL DEFENSE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday the Executive Yuan hopes to purchase arms as cheaply as possible, but he stressed that "there are no cheap options for national defense."

The premier made the remarks while fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan one day after Lee Yuan-tseh, a Nobel laureate and president of Academia Sindica, claimed that a Cabinet-proposed NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) special budget for arms procurements from the United States is too expensive and that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should hold talks to avoid military conflict and work toward cross-strait peace.
"Taiwan's strategy focuses on war prevention and we will not take the initiative to attack or provoke China," the premier said.
Taiwan will not launch an offensive strike, nor will it change the status quo, Yu said, adding that "the preservation of the status quo is in the best interests of the 23 million people of Taiwan."

He said that arms procurement will depend on the country's needs and on the threats from enemies. From the stance of the Executive Yuan and the Ministry of National Defense, the cheaper the price tag the better, although there are no cheap options for national defense.

Also, he went on, the budget for the major arms procurement package will be cheaper if Taiwan does not insist on building some of the eight submarines it wants. He was referring to the Cabinet's plan for the purchase of six batteries of the anti-missile PAC-III system, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States.

Legislators also asked if Taiwan will announce "no independence" or if it will ask the respected Nobel laureate to send messages to mainland China, to which the premier replied that although he admires Lee for his concern about cross-strait peace and national security, it is President Chen Shui-bian who is ultimately in charge of cross-strait policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER URGES CALM AND RATIONALITY AMID CLASHES

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan urged all sides Friday to be rational and avoid confrontation after clashes were reported between police and supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

Chen's call came as Shih Chi-yang, convener of a 10-member investigation commission set up under a special statute to probe the March 19 election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, led a four-member team that called at the Tainan Prosecutor's Office earlier that day to try to learn more about the case after the office refused to respond to the commission's request to send officials to present a briefing to the commission a day earlier.

Supporters of the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the TSU, led by legislators Wang Sing-nan, Chien Lin Whei-jun and Tang Pi-a, tried to force their way into the offices to protest against the commission. They clashed with police who were called in to maintain order. No-one was injured in the melee.

Apparently implying that the legislators were merely indulging in a bit of self-publicity, Chen said that in the run-up to the Dec. 11 legislative elections, all legislative aspirants will want to use every possible chance to stump for themselves.
"The Tainan Prosecutor's Office will investigate the incident this afternoon to see if any laws have been violated," Chen said.
He pleaded for calm and rationality to prevail and for further confrontations to be avoided.

Chen said that all government agencies have received instructions from the Executive Yuan that they are not to cooperate with the commission until the Council of Grand Justices has ruled on the constitutionality of the recently passed statute that provided legal grounds for the formation of the commission.
Only when the commission is ruled to be working under the premise of constitutionality and legality will the administrative agencies cooperate with it, he reiterated.

Chen, who was one of the five government officials that called on the commission Thursday, also said Shih, a former Judicial Yuan president, talked about an amendment to the controversial statute, but when the officials questioned the commission on the issue, they were "treated rudely" and the meeting ended in a row with one side questioning the constitutionality of the body and the other side asking the point of the visit if they regard it as "unlawful" as President Chen has described it.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR ENHANCEMENT OF MENTAL HEALTH AWARENESS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged local people Friday to pay more heed to their mental health and turn their negative feelings into positive and healthy energy.
Lu made the appeal during a seminar on health held as part of celebrations for the Oct. 10 World Mental Health Day.

Noting that Oct. 10 is also the Republic of China's National Day, Lu said she hopes all local residents can chant the slogans "Oct. 10 -- a happy day" and "You're fine, I'm fine, everyone is fine" on that day to mark the festive occasion.

Lu said health is a present from God. "It seems to me that many people have forgotten this fact and tend to overlook their own health until after they lose it, " Lu said, adding that she hopes every citizen will pay more heed to his or her own mental and physical health.

In her view, Lu said, life is full of both joys and sorrows. "We should face up to challenges and frustrations with a positive attitude and turn negative feelings and stress into positive and healthy energy," she added.
Participants to the seminar included Yang En-tien, a mouth-and-foot painter; Chu Mu-yen, an Olympic gold medallist; and Hsu Ming, a psychiatrist.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAYS, LESBIANS TO HOLD PARADE IN TAIPEI NOV. 6

TEXT.P: An alternate lifestyle parade will be held in Taipei Nov. 6, but will not be financially supported by the city government as was the case last year, an organizer of the event said Friday.

The 2004 Taiwan Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender Pride Parade will be an ad hoc arrangement since the city is not funding the event this year, according to a spokesman for the organizing committee, Wu Hsu-niang.

Wu said the parade will feature colorful and dazzling costumes to show the community's rich diversity, and will highlight the need for society to respect all individuals, regardless of their sexual orientation.

Wu said in a statement that as citizens of Taipei, gays and lesbians need to come out and be a part of the city. They also must understand that they have the responsibility to teach the next generation that there is no "wrong" identity and that differences must be acknowledged and even respected.
The upcoming parade will set off from the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall and wind through the 228 Park to the Red Theater in Hsimenting where a series of activities will be held.
Wu said they expect about 2,000 people to participate. Around 1,000 people took part last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT CALLS FOR NEW CONSTITUTION TO SAVE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Friday that drafting a new constitution for Taiwan is the only way to save the country and that it is time for the people to make a concerted effort to achieve that end.
Addressing a meeting of the Rotary International Taiwan's Taipei Peimen district, Lee said the current Constitution must be redrafted to leave mainland China no more excuses to invade Taiwan.
Lee, who founded the Action for Constitution Taiwan in July, said the Republic of China has long been replaced by the People's Republic of China and thus is a non-existent country.
The ROC Constitution has been amended six times but is still "too big to fit Taiwan," Lee said.

While there are more than 180 sovereign states around the world, Taiwan is recognized by fewer than 30 of them and is excluded from most international organizations including the United Nations, Lee pointed out.
Lee claimed that Taiwan is rejected by the international community because major countries including the United States, Britain and Japan believe the legal status of Taiwan is undetermined.
As shown in the 1951 Treaty of San Francisco, the document officially renounces Japan's right to Taiwan and Penghu but does not state which nation is sovereign over them, Lee noted.
Because of this, it is impossible for Taiwan to rejoin the United Nations under the name of the Republic of China, so it needs to use the name of a new country, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DAY SPEECH WILL HIT RIGHT NOTE WITH EVERYONE: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Friday that the speech he will give on the Oct. 10 National Day will please all parties concerned.

Chen made the assurance while speaking at the 13th National Awards Ceremony for Small- and Medium-sized Enterprises and the sixth National Awards of Overseas Taiwan Businesses at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Taipei. Representatives from 16 companies, 12 based at home and four based abroad, received the honor from the president.

According to Chen, his speech will focus on national unity, and cross-Taiwan Strait stability and economic development. He expressed his belief that the speech will help build confidence among the people of Taiwan toward the country's future amid grave concerns from other countries -- namely mainland China and the United States.

Chen has pronounced various times in recent days that he will make major policy announcements in his national day speech, prompting widespread speculation that his remarks may have something to do with mainland China. The president also gave a pledge Wednesday that there will be no war during his present tenure ending in 2008.

Current cross-strait ties are somewhat sensitive after Chen was re-elected in March. Tension is increasing in the region recently after Taiwan announced a plan to purchase NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) in defensive weapons from the United States.

The high-profile military procurement plan has been the focal point of a heated debate between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition camp, with the two sides arguing over the controversial package.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI 101 IS DREAM COME TRUE FOR TAIWAN: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday the completion of the Taipei 101 skyscraper, the tallest in the world, proves that dreams do come true.

In a meeting with Ron Kelmencic, head of the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat, Chen noted that some people thought it was no more than wishful thinking and a "mission impossible" when the idea was first floated in 1994.

Now the building has been certified as the tallest in the world, which represents the highest recognition for Taiwan's architectural designers and is the pride of the 23 million people on the island, Chen said.

Chen pointed out that he set up a panel to plan the construction of Taipei 101 in January 1995 soon after he was elected mayor of Taipei, and the construction project officially started in January 1998.
Witnessing every crucial stage of the project, the president said he is proud to see that the building is now standing tall in the capital city's Hsinyi district.

Chen said the significance of Taipei 101 is that it has helped vitalize the commercial activities in the Hsinyi district, which has been transformed from a place with very few buildings to become a showcase of Taiwan today.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN DIGNITARIES ARRIVE FOR DOUBLE TEN DAY

TEXT.P: Various foreign dignitaries will be in attendance for the Republic of China National Day on Oct. 10, according to Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials.
Chad Minister of Foreign Affairs Nagoum Yamassoum arrived in Taipei Friday for a three-day visit.

In addition to attending the activities in celebration of the ROC National Day, Yamassoum will also sign an agreement on Taiwan-Chad petroleum cooperation with the Taipei-based Chinese Petroleum Corp.
Malawi National Assembly Speaker Rodwell Munyenyembe also arrived in Taipei the same day for a five-day visit.

Munyenyembe will meet Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen. He will visit the International Cooperation and Development Fund, which is under the supervision of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and hear a state-of-the-nation report from the Government Information Office.

Meanwhile, Hedayat Abdel, president of the Geneva Association of United Nations Correspondents (ACANU) , will arrive at the head of a five-member delegation in Taipei Saturday. The visit is aimed at learning more about Taiwan's political and economic development, as well as its democratization.
Abdel will also exchange views with ROC officials and experts about Taiwan's bid to participate in world organizations, such as the United Nations and World Health Organization.
A three-member parliamentarian delegation from Iceland will arrive in Taipei Saturday for a five-day visit.

Another parliamentarian delegation from Switzerland, to be led by Legislator Christiane Langenberger, will arrive in Taipei on Oct. 10 for a six-day visit aimed at learning about Taiwan's political and economic situation. It will be their first visit to Taiwan.
According to MOFA officials, some 600 foreign dignitaries will arrive in Taipei to celebrate ROC National Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PACKAGE WOULD PREVENT MAINLAND CHINA INVASION: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The new arms procurement package will help deter any possible mainland Chinese invasion, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Friday.

Lee Jye made the remarks during a meeting with members of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislative caucus as part of his efforts to lobby the party's support for the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement budget bill.

During the meeting, TSU lawmakers asked Lee about his views on Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh's remarks a day earlier that the arms package is too expensive and that it's a pity that the government has to spend such a large amount to purchase weapons from the United States.
In response, Lee Jye said he above others does not want to see the two sides of the Taiwan Strait go to war and earnestly looks forward to maintaining permanent peace in the region.
Lee Jye, an admiral-turned-minister, said he is convinced that so long as Taiwan can acquire the new arms, mainland China will refrain from invading Taiwan because doing so would be very costly.

According to a computer war game simulation, Lee Jye said mainland China would have to sacrifice two-thirds to four-fifths of its troops if it were to attack Taiwan after the island obtains the new arms.
The package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFERS MEDALS ON PARALYMPICS GOLD MEDALISTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian conferred medals on two physically challenged gold medalists Friday in recognition of their excellent performance in the 2004 Athens Paralympic Games.

Chen bestowed the Order of Brilliant Star with Cravat on Chiang Chih-chung, a 24-year-old blind athlete who won a gold medal in the javelin event in the Paralympics, and on Lin Chih-hui, a 23-year-old polio-affected athlete who took gold in the 75-kilogram women's weightlifting event.
The president also presented money and citations to other medalists in the Paralympics, which ended in late September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VISITS AILING FORMER FIRST LADY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian paid a visit to ailing former first lady Faina Chiang at Veterans General Hospital in suburban Taipei Friday.
Chen was accompanied by the hospital's vice president, Lai Yung-yao, and a team of doctors responsible for treating the former first lady.
Chen stayed in the ward for about 10 minutes and didn't issue any statement before leaving the hospital.
The 88-year-old Russian-born widow of late President Chiang Ching-kuo has been hospitalized since Wednesday and is suffering from inflammation of the windpipe and acute asthma.

Feng Chang-feng, director of the hospital's infectious disease department, who is leading the medical team caring for Chiang, said the former first lady is now in stable condition and is being medicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO LOWER NUMBER OF FOREIGN LABOR FOR MAJOR PROJECTS AT HOME

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Friday that it is considering lowering the number of foreign labors allowed into the country to work on major private sector construction projects.

The CLA is planning to cut the ratio from the current 30 percent to 20 percent of the total number of workers on a project that is worth more than NT$10 billion (about US$2.95 million) in the short term in view of the warm response from local contractors to the introduction of foreign laborers for their major construction projects, a CLA spokesman said.

The CLA had expected that only two or three contractors would apply for the foreign laborers since the council made public regulations in late December, the spokesman said. But the response from the private sector has been high, with eight applications being approved, which are expected to bring in more than 6,900 foreign workers.
Currently, around 3,400 of them have already entered Taiwan, he noted.

Although the government is encouraging the private sector to launch large investment projects at home as a means of creating job opportunities for local people, he pointed out, however, that the larger-than-expected influx of foreign laborers will take away jobs from local workers.

Under these circumstances, the CLA is planning to cap the number of foreign workers at 20 percent for major construction projects -- a move based on its quota control mechanisms designed to protect local workers, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO RESIGN EN MASSE IN FEB. IN ACCORDANCE WITH RULES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday he and all other Cabinet members will resign en masse before the new Legislative Yuan is inaugurated Feb. 1 next year in accordance with existing rules and practices.

Yu made the remarks during a legislative interpellation session. During the meeting, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lu Hsiu-yen asked Yu whether he will remain premier after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
Yu replied, "It's up to President Chen Shui-bian to decide whether I should retain the post. It's not my style to try to hang on to a certain post just for appearances," Yu told lawmakers.
Yu further said he will devote his full energy to his work until the last minute before his departure.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REPORTEDLY TO SELL HIGH-SPEED ANTI-RADIATION MISSILES TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The United States has reportedly agreed to sell high-speed anti-radiation missiles (HARM) to Taiwan, according to a report published Friday in the Washington Times.
The report noted that the Pentagon recently notified the government of the Republic of China on Taiwan that it is prepared to sell the island the advanced missiles.

The approval came in response to inquiries made recently by Taiwan that also included an appeal for the U.S. to sell guidance kits that would turn Taiwan's gravity bombs into satellite-guided joint direct attack munitions (JDAM), the report went on, adding that the JDAM decision is pending.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SOUTH KOREA BUSINESS COUNCIL ESTABLISHED TO BOOST TRADE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-South Korea Business Council, organized by Taiwan's six major trade organizations, was established Friday to boost economic and trade exchanges between the two countries.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said at the inauguration ceremony that Taiwan's exports to South Korea have increased more than 30 percent during the period from April to August since Bureau of Foreign Trade Director-General Huang Chih-peng led a delegation to South Korea in March to explore trade.

Ho stressed that the notable growth indicated that there is still a lot of space for the development of trade between Taiwan and South Korea, and urged South Korean enterprises to buy more high-quality products from Taiwan and to jointly develop global markets with their Taiwanese counterparts.
Taiwan is expected to suffer a trade deficit of US$5 billion with South Korea this year, making the latter the second-largest source of trade deficit for Taiwan, only after Japan.
Kwon Jun Han, president of the Importers and Exporters Association of South Korea, led a delegation composed of representative of 21 South Korean enterprises to attend the event.
After the ceremony, the South Korean delegation held a trade consultation meeting with their Taiwanese counterparts as a move to promote bilateral trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCT. 9 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are major events scheduled to take place Saturday, Oct. 9:
09:30, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will sign a joint statement with his Chad counterpart at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
10: 30, Former President Lee Teng-hui will attend the opening ceremony of a charity sale of artistic articles organized by Taiwan Advocates at the gallery of the National Cultural Association.
12: 00, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will host a luncheon party to entertain his Chad counterpart at the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei.
14: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a concert in celebration of the Oct. 10 National Day at the National Concert Hall in Taipei.
14: 00, The exhibition of arts and cultural articles of Madame Chiang Kai-shek will open at the gallery of Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
14:30, The Mainland Affairs Council will host a reception at the Howard Hotel in Taipei to mark the Oct. 10 National Day.
15: 00, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will attend the Asia-Pacific Arts Festival being held at the National Center for Traditional Arts in Ilan County.
18: 00, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will host a dinner party to entertain Malawi National Assembly Speaker Rodwell Munyenyembe at the Sherwood Taipei.
19: 00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a concert in celebration of the Oct. 10 National Day at the National Concert Hall in Taipei.
22: 50, The Minister of Transportation and Communications will leave for Chile via CKS International Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TO HAVE MILITARY EDGE OVER TAIWAN IN 2006: MND

TEXT.P: Mainland China will eventually gain a military advantage over Taiwan in 2006 based on the current trend of Beijing's military buildup, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) warned Friday.
The defense ministry made the announcement in a cross-strait military analysis submitted to the Legislative Yuan.

Pointing out that mainland China is actively engaging in a military buildup program that grows at a double-digit rate each year, the defense ministry said that the mainland will have a military edge in 2006.

By that time, Taiwan will be in a disadvantageous position in terms of the number of its airplanes, missiles and submarines compared with mainland China, the defense ministry said, stressing that its plans to buy Patriot-III missiles, anti-submarine airplanes and diesel-powered submarines are urgently needed and the decisions to buy them must be made swiftly.

According to the defense ministry, mainland China has this year allocated US$25.4 billion in its military buildup and modernization program, with an additional hidden spending possibly amounting to US$60 billion.

In view of the mainland's rapid military expansion, the defense ministry pointed out that Taiwan's ground troops, air and naval forces will confront a sharp deterioration in terms of new generation weapons in two years.

For the time being, mainland China has about 200 cruise missiles under development, which are capable of launching precision attacks on Taiwan from some 1,800 nautical miles away, the defense ministry said, adding that the mainland's navy will have as many as 50 advanced subs by 2006, capable of imposing an undersea blockade against Taiwan over the long term.
During the same time, the number of its armored troops will increase by 300,000, an exclusively designed move in case of an attack on Taiwan, it said.

Although the mainland's military force is not expected to be able to conduct a massive invasion of Taiwan by 2006, it warned, however, that it will be strong enough to launch a blitz against the island through airborne or seaborne strategies.
In an effort to effectively deter any mainland attacks, Taiwan should build a strong defense capability through an adequate military procurement, it concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS A NEW CONSTITUTION: EX-PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs a new constitution for facilitating its pursuit to join international organizations and to avoid China's intimidation and threats, former President Lee Teng-hui said Friday.

Speaking via teleconference with a group of American scholars gathered at the U.S. Senate, Lee said that drafting a new constitution for Taiwan is the only way to save the country and that it is time for the people to make a concerted effort to achieve that end.

Lee said the current Constitution implemented in Taiwan is quite outdated and not suitable because it was established in 1946 by the Republic of China which was founded in 1912 when Taiwan was not a part of it.

Furthermore, Lee pointed out, the ROC Constitution violates international laws because its stipulates the country's territories cover the People's Republic of China and Mongolia, which are now members of the United Nations.
A new constitution for Taiwan should be established by the 23 million people of Taiwan and should not infringe on the sovereignty of other countries, he stressed.
The ROC Constitution was amended six times during his term from 1988 to 2000 but is still "too big to fit Taiwan," Lee said.

The conference on Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering and the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations was jointly organized by the Taipei-based Action for Constitution Taiwan, led by Lee, and the Washington-based Center for Taiwan International Relations.

Taiwanese delegates to the seminar included senior presidential adviser Koo Kwang-ming, Evergreen University Professor Lee Hsien-jung and Chen Lung-chu, chairman of the Taiwan New Century Cultural and Educational Foundation.
The American participants included former American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Nat Belocchi and several noted scholars, including John Tkacik, Arthur Waldron, Larry Niksch and James E. Auer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 9, or the 26th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: The United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China promulgate a draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.
1965: ROC Ambassador to the United States and Representative to the United Nations Tsiang Ting-fu dies of liver cancer in New York at the age of 71.
1967: Ernesto "Che" Guevara, the Argentine-born revolutionary who helped Fidel Castro gain power in Cuba, is shot dead after being captured by Bolivian army troops. He was 39.
1967: Indonesia severs diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1970: Dissident Soviet writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize for literature, turns down an invitation to Stockholm to attend the award ceremony in December.
1970: Cambodia declares itself the Khmer Republic.
1972: Prime Minister Tupua Tamasese Lealofi IV of Western Samoa arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Mayor Chang Feng-shu of Taipei leaves for Honolulu to attend a council meeting of the Asian and Pacific Area Conference of Mayors.
1974: A two-day post-congress symposium of the first conference of the World Nuclear Medicine Federation opens in Taipei.
1975: Soviet dissident and human rights activist Andrei Sakharov is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Alberto Nogues Perez, foreign minister of Paraguay.
1983: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan escapes unharmed when 17 members of his entourage, including Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk, are killed in a bomb blast in Rangoon.
1984: A famous Cantonese opera performer from mainland China, Hung Hung, 40, announces her defection in a press conference held at the Free China Relief Association in Taipei.
1986: The Executive Yuan passes the Program for Taroko National Park, in which NT$4 billion is to be invested in developing the park over six years.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Task Force approves the first draft of the Temporary Provisions Governing Relations between the People of the Mainland Region and Taiwan Region.
1998: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government resigns after losing its 31st vote of confidence.
1999: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urges mainland China to promote relations with Taiwan based on a "special state-to-state relationship."
2000: Haitian President Rene Preval and his wife, leading an official delegation, arrive in Taipei to attend celebration activities marking the ROC's Double-Ten National Day.
2001: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taiwan holds a party to mark the 50th anniversary of its founding.
2001: The five-day 2001 Taipei International Electronics Show kicks off with the number of international buyers in the first day down significantly compared with the previous year's figures.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of dignity, noble seriousness, order and regularity: qualities necessary for the exercise of self-respect."

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:

A six-month-old baby dies after inhaling air contaminated with amphetamines.

The Liberty Times:

The Taiwan Daily:

The Central Daily News:
The controversial '319 truth commission' statute to be revised.
The China Post:
Arms buy will prevent China attack: minister.
The Taiwan News:
319 committee welcomed by angry citizens.
The Taipei Times:

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: ASEM meet starts in Hanoi HANOI (via PLDT) -- Thirtynine leaders from Asia and Europe yesterday began informal talks on issues on trade, security threats and terrorism, proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, disease control and cultural diversity, despite a spat on how to handle Myanmar.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Military graft eyed in murder CORRUPTION in the military has become so vicious it may have provoked the murder of an Army officer. Investigators said they were pursuing the angle that former Army logistics chief Col. Raul Heredia was killed after he allegedly failed to give other officers their share of a commission from a "big contract."
The Philippine Star: Lifestyle checks on at PNP Philippine National Police (PNP) chief Director General Edgar Aglipay ordered Camp Crame's Internal Affairs Service yesterday to revive the lifestyle checks on police generals, following reports that two of his classmates from Philippine Military Academy (PMA) Class '71 are being investigated for alleged irregularities.
The Manila Times: Case vs Garcia 'strong' The evidence against Maj. Gen. Carlos Garcia, who is accused of massive corruption, is strong, the Office of the Ombudsman said on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Blast Destroys Israeli-Filled Hotel in Egypt. An enormous explosion ripped through a resort hotel in an Egyptian border enclave that caters to Israeli tourists, killing at least 19 people and injuring more than 100 in what Israeli security sources said appeared to be a terrorist attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Bangkok Post:Muslim leaders urge more trust. Islamic leaders in the Muslim-dominated border provinces yesterday called on the Southern Border Provinces Peacekeeping Command (SBPC) to swiftly establish mutual trust and understanding between local people and government authorities. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR HOSTS LUNCHEON FOR TAIWAN EXPATS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou hosted a luncheon Saturday for Taiwan expatriates returning for the Double Ten National Day celebrations.
Ma welcomed the Taiwan compatriots from the United States, Canada, Indonesia, Malaysia and other places, and then together with them toasted the prosperity of the nation.

He also took the opportunity to promote Taipei as a tourist city, urging them to visit the Taipei 101 skyscraper, which is the world's tallest building, and the surrounding posh business district, as well as other sites, such as the world-famous National Palace Museum and the MOCA Taipei fine arts museum.
Above all, the mayor urged them to go shopping to help contribute to the city's economy. (By Lilian Wu) endtiem/Li

DOC.HEADLINE: 'REPUBLIC OF CHINA (TAIWAN)' TO BE NORM IN OFFICIAL DOCUMENTS: CHEN

TEXT.P: The use of the "Republic of China (Taiwan)" as the nation's title in official diplomatic documents will become the norm in the future to avoid inconveniences and confusion, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Saturday.
Chen made the remarks after signing a joint statement with visiting Chadian Foreign Affairs Minister Nagoum Yamassoum reaffirming their commitment to further promoting bilateral cooperation.
"In the joint statement, our country is referred to as the 'Republic of China (Taiwan) ' for the first time in a diplomatic document," Chen said.
The joint statement has Chinese and French editions. The ROC is referred to as the "Republique de Chine (Taiwan) " in the French version of the document.

Chen said the administration has reached a consensus on the issue. With a view to avoiding unnecessary troubles and confusion, Chen said, referring to the country as the "Republic of China (Taiwan)" will be the norm from now on.

In the joint statement, the foreign ministers of the two countries expressed satisfaction with the current state of bilateral relations. The two ministers pledged to further expand bilateral cooperation in various fields, including joint exploration of oil resources in the central African country.

Meanwhile, Yamassoum extended his gratitude for Taiwan's long-term assistance in his country's agricultural and economic development. He also reaffirmed Chad's firm support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other major international organizations.

For his part, Chen said Africa deserves more support and assistance amid the trend of globalization. He said the international community should assist all African countries in getting rid of poverty and political instability so as to establish a more equitable world economic system.
Yamassoum arrived in Taipei Thursday to attend the ROC's Double Ten National Day celebrations Oct. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DOUBLE TEN NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATED IN U.K.
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Outgoing ROC Representative to the U.K. Tien Hung-mao on Friday expressed his appreciation for the friendship and support offered to Taiwan by various sectors in Britain in bolstering bilateral ties.
Hosting a cocktail reception in celebration of the upcoming ROC Double Ten National Day, Tien said relations between Taiwan and Britain have become closer over the past two years.
Most significantly, the number of Taiwanese students in Britain has increased quickly over the last few years to more than 13,000 today, Tien pointed out.
This year alone, the British government has issued nearly 10,000 visas for Taiwanese students, Tien said.
Tien also noted that bilateral trade now stands at more than US$4.3 billion, and that Britain-based mutual funds account for one-third of all foreign mutual funds in Taiwan's stock market.
In addition, he continued, Britain has now become the most important base of Taiwanese corporations and banks operating in European Union countries.

Taiwan has been trying to show the world its concern for freedom, democracy and human rights, Tien said, pointing out that the presidential election in March of this year proved that Taiwan is already a full-fledged democracy.

He said Taiwan will share its resources with other countries and assist the international community in promoting human rights, as well as economic and technological cooperation and cultural exchanges, adding that the island will be able to contribute more if it enjoys more international recognition.

The event was participated in by over 300 British government officials, members of Parliament, experts from a number of British think tanks, academics, leaders of British financial circles, senior executives of news media and leaders of Taiwanese expatriate groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-LANGUAGE WEB SITE ON PHILIPPINE TOURISM DEBUTS

TEXT.P: The Philippine representative office in Taiwan announced Saturday the launching of a Chinese-language tourism Web site to serve Chinese around the world wanting to get tourism information on the Philippines.

The Manila Economic and Cultural Office noted that the Philippines has set the target of attracting 5 million tourists per year by 2010. Currently, foreign tourists to the Philippines come mostly from Taiwan, the United States, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong and mainland China. Taiwan tourists account for the fastest growing source of foreign tourists to the Philippines.

Statistics compiled by the office show that since February of this year, the number of tourist arrivals from Taiwan has increased by 58 percent. The office said it hopes the launch of the new Chinese-language Web site will help maintain this growth.
The Web site address is www.wowphilippines.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE CAPABILITIES KEY TO PRESERVING NEW CONSTITUTION: U.S. EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu, Lin Wen-chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan must acquire credible defense capabilities before enacting a new constitution, otherwise it will be vulnerable to being overturned, an American expert on China policy said Friday.
John Tkacik, a research fellow at the Heritage Foundation, made the remarks at a seminar on issues related to a new constitution for Taiwan held at the U.S. Senate Hart Building.

Tkacik said constitutional reforms are necessary in Taiwan for several reasons, including the fact that the existing ROC Constitution in Taiwan was enacted by the Kuomintang in 1947 without any input from the people of Taiwan.

Nevertheless, Tkacik said, before putting a new constitution in place, the island must first acquire credible military capabilities to defend itself against possible mainland Chinese military attack. Otherwise, even if Taiwan succeeds in enacting a new constitution, it will be difficult to preserve, he said.
The seminar was jointly organized by the Taipei-based Action for Constitution Taiwan, headed by former President Lee Teng-hui, and the Washington-based Center for Taiwan International Relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA CALLS FOR NORMALIZING ECONOMIC RELATIONS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Saturday urged the central government to work to normalize economic relations with mainland China, claiming this will help deter Beijing from taking any military actions against the island.
To this end, Ma proposed that the government lift its restrictions on mainland tourists and on mainland capital in certain sectors of the economy.
The mayor made the remarks while addressing the opening of Kuomintang Legislator John Chang's campaign headquarters.
Ma argued that cross-strait peace does not depend solely on arms procurement but requires the support of a comprehensive cross-strait policy.
As Taiwan is much smaller than mainland China, it must deal with Beijing with wisdom, not force, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CHUNG-HUNG TO BE NEW ROC REP TO MACAU

TEXT.P: Chen Chung-hung, director of the Department of Information and Liaison of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , will serve as the new representative to Macau, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said Saturday.
Wu made the announcement during a banquet to welcome Taiwan expatriates from Hong Kong and Macau returning to attend the ROC Double Ten National Day celebrations Oct. 10.
Chen is expected to assume his new post in a month, Wu said.

Meanwhile, Pao Cheng-kang, the new ROC representative to Hong Kong, said that depending on the operations of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, he should be able to assume his new post in one month at the latest.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP TO SINGAPORE CALLS FOR FAIR TREATMENT FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to Singapore Roy Wu on Friday called for fair treatment for the ROC, saying that as a democratic and freedom-loving country, Taiwan shouldn't have to face "political apartheid" in the international community.
Wu made the remarks during a dinner party held to celebrate the upcoming ROC Double Ten National Day, with political, military and economic officials from various countries attending.

He stressed that the 23 million people of Taiwan have become international "nomads" who are discriminated against in the international community and who have been shut out of international organizations such as the United Nations and the World Health Organization without any rights or dignity.
Wu also took the opportunity to review Taiwan-Singapore bilateral relations, saying the two sides enjoy close exchanges in the areas of trade, culture, technology, education and tourism.

He said that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Singapore totaled NT$464 billion (US$13.72 billion) in 2003, representing a 12.9-percent increase over the previous year, with Singapore enjoying a trade surplus of NT$15 billion.
Taiwan is Singapore's sixth largest trade partner, while Singapore is Taiwan's seventh largest trade partner, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REP OFFICE IN INDIA HOSTS ROC DOUBLE TEN NATIONAL DAY PARTY
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Lin Huei-chun & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in India hosted a major Double Ten National Day cocktail party Friday in New Delhi, with over 200 representatives of the Indian political, business and academic sectors, as well as foreign diplomats to the South Asian country attending the event.
It marked the first time the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center in New Delhi publicized its party to celebrate the ROC Double Ten National Day since the center's founding in 1995.
In the past, the Double Ten Day celebrations at the center were always low-key events. The ROC does not maintain formal diplomatic relations with India.

ROC Representative to India Kao Chen-chun told CNA reporters at the evening party that there has been much close contact between India and Taiwan over the last few years, with frequent exchanges in the trade, economic and technology fields.
Given India's huge population and its growing middle-class and consumer demand, Taiwan businesses should take the South Asian country into consideration when planning to invest abroad.

Following the opening of the Taiwan representative office in New Delhi in 1995, the two sides kicked off direct Taipei-New Delhi flight services and signed an investment protection agreement in 2000. Meanwhile, bilateral trade and investment has also grown at a steady pace, with two-way trade expected to hit US$2 billion this year.
In an effort to expand Taiwan's relations with India, Kao said, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming is planning a visit to India in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S SMALLEST MP3 PLAYER DEBUTS AT TAIPEI ELECTRONICS SHOW

TEXT.P: A domestic technology firm on Saturday unveiled the world's smallest MP3 player at the 2004 Taipei International Electronics Show.

The MP3 player, manufactured by the Hsuan Mao Enterprise Co., is only four centimeters in diameter and 16 grams in weight. It has a memory capacity of up to 256 megabytes and is powered by a rechargeable battery that lasts four to six hours. It will be sold at the competitive price of around NT$1,600 (US$47).
MP3 players are replacing CD walkmans as the mainstream product in the portable stereo market thanks to their handy size, large storage capacity, and excellent acoustic quality.
According to a survey by the International Data Corp. (IDC), some 25 million MP3 players are expected to be sold this year, up by over 10 million from the previous year's level.
Market analysts expect MP3 player sales to continue to increase by 10 million units annually over the next several years.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN WEAKENING: SCHOLARS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu, Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. support for Taiwan has shown signs of weakening, several Taiwan and American scholars said at the opening of a seminar on U.S.-Taiwan-China relations on Capitol Hill Friday.

Addressing the Symposium on Taiwan's Constitutional Reform and U.S.-Taiwan-China Relations, Larry Niksch, a U.S. congressional Asian affairs expert, said he has noticed that U.S. support for Taiwan is gradually weakening.

If the United States wants to maintain the Taiwan Strait status quo, Niksch said, it should prevent Beijing from continuously eroding Taiwan's international presence or "space", including luring away Taiwan's diplomatic allies.
Chen Wen-yen, chief executive of the U.S.-based Formosan Association for Public Affairs, echoed Niksch's views, saying he has detected such a trend.

"Taiwan should keep vigilant against this trend and make every possible effort to keep the United States informed of Taiwan's latest situation in order to win more U.S. support for its cause, " Chen said.

As to what the Taiwan Strait status quo means, John Tkacik, a Heritage Foundation research fellow, said he once asked the U.S. State Department about this question, but none of the State Department officials could give a clear definition.
To the best of his understanding, Tkacik said, the Taiwan Strait status quo can be described as "no unification, no independence and no war."
Chen Lung-chih, chairman of the New Century Culture and Education Foundation, said the "status quo" is dynamic and cannot remain unchanged forever.

James Kelly, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said during a congressional hearing in April this year that the United States is opposed to either side of the Taiwan Strait unilaterally changing the status quo, adding that it's up to the United States to define what the status quo means.

Speaking on the same occasion, Nat Belocchi, a former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, suggested that the U.S. government set up a special cross-strait task force to review Taiwan-U.S.-China relations regularly and to submit reports to the U.S. president periodically. These reports should also be made available to Taiwan, he suggested.
The seminar was jointly organized by the Taipei-based Action for Constitution Taiwan, headed by former President Lee Teng-hui, and the Washington-based Center for Taiwan International Relations.

Former President Lee delivered a speech in English via video link to the participants in the seminar held at the U.S. Senate Hart Building. In the speech, Lee said he believes it is high time to "save Taiwan" by writing a new constitution that fits the island's present situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DAY SPEECH WILL HELP IMPROVE CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he will deliver a significant speech on the Oct. 10 National Day and that the speech will have a positive impact on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Taiwan-U.S. ties, and the maintenance of peace.

Chen made the remarks in his address to a National Day concert at the National Concert Hall. He indicated that in his speech, he will elaborate on his five main points in terms of dealing with cross-strait issues -- namely self-confidence, responsibility, sincerity, innovation and foresight.
The president said he believes the National Day speech will make a positive contribution toward efforts to improve cross-strait relations, boost Taiwan-U.S. ties, and strengthen peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. URGED TO MAINTAIN BAN ON ARMS SALES TO CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng, Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A campaign against considerations by the European Union to lift its ban on arms sales to mainland China dominated celebrations in Los Angeles Friday for the upcoming ROC Double Ten National Day.

Many guests at a cocktail reception held to celebrate the Oct. 10 National Day signed a petition in support of the campaign by Taiwan's government, with the statement and signatures to be sent to the L.A. missions of all European Union member states.

Wei Wu-lien, director of the Tapei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles, said the peace-loving ROC has for years been actively involved in international anti-terrorism and humanitarian efforts. He said Taiwan looks forward to expanding its international participation so as to contribute more to the global community.

By contrast, Wei noted, Beijing has deployed more than 500 missiles targeting Taiwan, which he claimed demonstrates China's strong military ambitions. He warned that proposals being discussed in the European Union to lift its arms sales ban in disregard of this fact are bound to lead to an escalation in cross-strait confrontation and endanger security and stability in the Asia-Pacific region and the world.
Over 1,000 guests, including a number of California politicians, attended the reception held at the Bonaventure Hotel.

Also on Friday, a group of pro-Taiwan members of the U.S. Congress sent their congratulations to the ROC government for the nation's 93rd birthday. In their messages, the congressmen said Taiwan is a great friend of the United States despite the absence of diplomatic relations.
Taiwan has become a model of democracy over the last 20 years, with its people now enjoying a high standard of living and the right to directly elect their president, they said.
The members of Congress also noted that Taiwan has fully cooperated with the United States since the 911 terrorists attacks and has supported the post-war reconstruction in Iraq and Afghanistan.
They praised President Chen Shui-bian as a resolute national leader for his commitment to maintaining peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXHIBITION OF MADAME CHIANG'S PERSONAL EFFECTS DRAWS HUGE CROWD

TEXT.P: A large crowd swarmed into the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei Saturday to view a collection of personal effects that once belonged to the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek, the most famous ROC first lady.

The rare show was organized by the ROC Women's League to mark the anniversary of Madame Chiang's death. The exhibition, which will run through Nov. 5, is believed to be the largest of its kind ever held in Taiwan.

Among the exhibits are 28 Chinese brush paintings by Madame Chiang, who died at her New York home Oct. 24, 2003, at the age of 106. Many of the paintings carry the late President Chiang Kai-shek's handwriting. Major painting utensils used by Madame Chiang are also on display.
According to the organizers, many of the exhibits were loaned by Madame Chiang's relatives in the United States.

Also on display are a number of Madame Chiang's personal effects, including costumes, handbags, shoes, hats, jewels and other accessories. Photos featuring Madame Chiang wearing those fashionable articles are also being shown to allow visitors to remember her grace and fashion taste.
Other exhibits include Madame Chiang's manuscripts and personal letters, as well as historical documents and photos featuring her and her husband.
Madame Chiang, whose life traversed three centuries, helped the late president rule mainland China and later Taiwan during years of war, upheaval and Cold War tension.

The Chiangs were once one of the most famous couples in the world -- a dashing general married to a beautiful, urbane woman. Time magazine publisher Henry Luce named them "Man and Woman of the Year" in 1938. Chiang Kai-shek headed the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Republic of China for decades until he died April 5, 1975.

Madame Chiang led a reclusive life at her Manhattan home for much of her later life after her husband's death. Born Soong Mei-ling, she became widely known in the West as a spokeswoman for Chinese efforts to resist the Japanese forces that began invading China in the 1930s.

After the Chinese Communist Party took control of the mainland, the Republic of China government, under her husband's leadership, moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949. Chiang and his wife became Asia's foremost anti-communist symbols.

Many KMT party elders, including former Premiers Sun Yun-hsuan and Lee Huan as well as former Control Yuan President Wang Tso-jung, attended the opening ceremony. KMT Vice Chairwoman Lin Cheng-chih read a congratulatory message from KMT Chairman Lien Chan on the occasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA REFUSES TO ATTEND IEA GENERAL ASSEMBLY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Mainland China will be the only one of the 61 institutional members of the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA) to be absent from the organization's general assembly set for Oct. 11-14 in Taipei, it was learned Saturday.

In line with past IEA practice, the host country must display the national flags of all participating countries at the meeting, but mainland China decided not to send delegates because it cannot accept having the ROC national flag displayed.

Sources from the National Science Council (NSC), sponsor of this year's 45th IEA General Assembly, said this has again shown mainland China's relentless stifling of Taiwan, even on academic occasions.

They cited last year's meeting in Cyprus as an example, saying that mainland Chinese delegates protested to the host country after seeing the ROC national flag flying side by side with the flags of other member states. The host country later decided to remove all the flags to demonstrate its impartiality.

The move angered many other countries, according to Lin Fu-lai, director of the NSC's Science Education Department who represented Taiwan at the meeting. He was later elected as an IEA board member IEA in Asia after obtaining the support from many countries.
The Philippines would have hosted this year's meeting, but it later gave up, and the IEA then inquired about the intention of Taiwan hosting the meeting.

Mainland China, after learning that Taiwan was awarded the right to host this year's general assembly, invited the IEA president and other officials to visit the mainland, protesting to them in person and asking that the site of the meeting be shifted to the mainland. However, the IEA only agreed to let mainland China host the 2006 meeting and insisted that Taipei host this year's event.
The IEA, founded in 1958, is an independent, international cooperative of national research institutions and governmental research agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COUNTY OFFICIALS CAN'T CONFIRM HANDOVER DATE FOR ISLETS

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Government officials said Saturday that they could not confirm reports that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will turn over six islets off Kinmen to the county government next January, stating only that the "handover plan is proceeding smoothly."

The officials made the remarks amid media reports that the MND will withdraw stationed troops from the six islets -- namely Tatan, Ertan, Tungting, Peiting, Shihyu and Menghuyu -- and hand the islets over to the Kinmen County Government for opening to tourism in Jan. 1, 2005.
The officials would not confirm the "timing" for handover, saying it is "top secret."

However, they did disclose that since Premier Yu Shyi-kun inspected the outlying island of Kinmen in September 2002 and announced the principle of having the Kinmen County government take over the six islets, the plan has been moving forward smoothly.

The officials said that the Executive Yuan replied in a letter in late July that it agrees in principle to the Kinmen County government's plan for the takeover, and that they would work out related details.

In expectation of the handover, Kinmen County Government has commissioned National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences to conduct a tourism resource and development survey of Tatan and Ertan, the two islets off Kinmen that are closest to mainland China.
In September, the county government also worked with the Kinmen Defense Command to survey the islets and recently convened a closed-door meeting to discuss matters related to the hand over.

Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng has repeatedly said that the county government will take over the six islets by the year's end. On Oct. 7, when Lee led a delegation to visit Taiwan expatriates in Southeast Asian nations, he mentioned the handover plan in distributed pamphlets and welcomed the expatriates to return for investment.
Kinmen is located off the southeastern coast of the mainland Chinese province of Fujian. The shortest distance from the main island of Kinmen to the mainland is only 2,310 meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-DPP CHAIRMAN URGES PEOPLE TO CHERISH DEMOCRATIC ACHIEVEMENT

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung Saturday urged the people to cherish Taiwan's hard-fought achievement in its democratic development.
In a speech on the role of the people in a democracy, Lin pointed out that Taiwan is one of 86 countries where people enjoy full freedom, citing a report by U.S.-based Freedom House.

Although the first power transition in the history of Taiwan's democracy was completed in 2000, there are still a lot of "viruses" impeding the progress of democracy which will require the united effort of the people to get rid of, Lin said.
Lin said many people are wondering what benefits Taiwan has gained since the power transition besides now being able to curse the president more freely than ever before.
The people have had enough of the disorderly Legislative Yuan and think it is no better than in the past when it was controlled by the "old guards," Lin noted.
Lin said the people are the masters of the country in a democracy, and all the heads of governments and the people's representatives are elected by the people.
The chaotic situation in Taiwan is the result of abuse of freedom, the lack of democratic concepts, and the people's disinterest in politics, according to Lin.
He called on the people to foster the concept of democracy in the younger generations to improve the situation.

For example, he said, parents should avoid treating their children in an authoritative manner in order to develop a democratic personality in their kids; schools should enhance education on democracy and train students in democratic ways of thinking; and the attitude of complying with the majority view and respecting the minority view should be adopted in group activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR INTER-PARTY COOPERATION IN AMENDING '319' STATUTE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" Saturday to cooperate with it in resolving all the disputes surrounding the "319 truth commission" statute.

DPP legislative whip Tsai Huang-liang made the call after several "truth commission" members encountered a violent protest in front of the Tainan Prosecutor's Office in the southern city of Tainan the previous day.

Claiming that the "truth commission" statute under which the all-powerful commission was established is unconstitutional and unlawful, Tsai said the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) should cooperate with the DPP in amending the statute in compliance with constitutional provisions and other existing laws.
"Only after the statute is properly revised can the 'truth commission' operate smoothly. Otherwise, the commission will lead nowhere," Tsai said.
Even though the "pan-blue alliance" has come up with a draft revision package, Tsai said, it is not enough to ensure the smooth operations of the commission.

"The 'pan-blue alliance' should take into account the DPP's amendment proposals so that the statute can become practical and feasible, " Tsai said, adding that the administration and judicial authorities will cooperate with the "truth commission" only when the statue no longer contains any unconstitutional or unlawful provisions.

The statute was authored and railroaded through the legislature by the "pan-blue alliance" to create an all-powerful special commission to investigate an assassination attempt against President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of the bitterly contested March 20 presidential election.
The statute was promulgated only after the "pan-blue alliance"-dominated Legislative Yuan overrode the Cabinet's veto in a narrow showdown vote last month.

The DPP legislative caucus has asked the Council of Grand Justices to impose a temporary injunction on the statute until the council decides whether the statute is unconstitutional. The council will hold a hearing Oct. 14 to decide whether to impose a temporary injunction and will hold two additional hearings Oct. 27 and Oct. 29 before issuing its "constitutionality" interpretation.

Chen narrowly won re-election a day after the March 19 shooting on the campaign trail. He was only lightly injured. His challenger, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, has insinuated that Chen staged the shooting to win sympathy votes. Although Lien has offered no evidence to support his allegations, he has filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory and even the validity of the entire election. The Taiwan High Court has yet to hand down verdicts on the two lawsuits.

Meanwhile, Legislator Huang Chung-yuan of the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- the DPP's ally -- said if the statute is finally revised, KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong should make a public apology to the public for their parties' insistence on passing such an unconstitutional statute in the first place.

DOC.HEADLINE: DATE FOR ISLETS TRANSFER STILL UNDER DISCUSSIONS: MILITARY

TEXT.P: The date for the military to hand over control of six offshore islets to the Kinmen County Government is still under discussions, the Kinmen Defense Command (KDC) said Saturday.

The KDC was responding to media reports that the military will withdraw troops from six small islets off Kinmen -- namely Tatan, Ertan, Tungting, Peiting, Shihyu and Menghuyu -- and transfer control of the islets to the civilian Kinmen County Government Jan. 1, 2005.

A KDC official said the proposed handover is being planned in line with the principles of national defense, civilian livelihood and tourism development in Kinmen, which lies closer to mainland China's Fujian province than to Taiwan.

"While the transfer plan has been proceeding smoothly, the exact date for the handover has yet to be decided. We are still discuss relevant issues with the Kinmen County Government, " the official added.

In preparation for the takeover, the Kinmen County Government has commissioned National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences to conduct a tourism resources survey of Tatan and Ertan, which lies very close to mainland China. The county government also would not reveal when it will formally take over control of the six islets.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC, CHAD SIGN PRELIMINARY COOPERATION PACT

TEXT.P: Chadian Foreign Affairs Minister Nago Yamassoum signed a preliminary cooperation agreement with Taipei-based Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) Chairman Kuo Chin-tsai Saturday expressing their interest in cooperating in oil exploration.
Chad is believed to have rich crude oil reserves suitable for commercial exploration. Major international oil companies have expressed interest in prospecting for oil in the central African country.

CPC Chairman Kuo said the preliminary agreement just represents an expression of intent to cooperate between the two sides. The two sides will have to further discuss cooperative formula, terms and goals before a formal pact can be signed.
Yamassoum arrived in Taipei Thursday to attend the Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MALAYSIAN TIES GROWING EVER CLOSER: ENVOY

TEXT.P: Substantive relations between Taiwan and Malaysia have been growing ever closer, with commercial and civilian exchanges increasing rapidly, the Republic of China's de facto ambassador to Malaysia said Friday.
Wu Wen-ya, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia, made the remarks at an evening party celebrating the ROC's Oct. 10 National Day.
Wu said Malaysia has been one of the key destination for Taiwan's "go south" investment policy which encourages Taiwan businesspeople to invest in Southeast Asian countries.

Under the "go south" policy, Wu said, Taiwan's investment and trade with ASEAN countries have grown substantially since 1994. Over the past decade, he went on, Taiwan has invested more than US$43 billion in ASEAN nations, including Malaysia. In 2003, Taiwan's trade with ASEAN reached US$34.1 billion.

According to Wu, Taiwan is now Malaysia's sixth largest trading partner and Malaysia is Taiwan's eighth largest trading partner. In the first eight months of this year, Taiwan-Malaysia trade amounted to US$6.2 billion, up 26 percent from the year-earlier level, and Malaysia enjoying a trade surplus of US$1 billion.
Taiwan is also third largest foreign investor in Malaysia, with total investment reaching US$9.5 billion.

Meanwhile, Taiwan people made 130,000 visits to Malaysia in the first eight months of this year, up 73 percent from the same period of last year, while Malaysian citizens made 54,000 visits to Taiwan during the same period for a 72 percent year-on-year growth.
Wu said he will do his utmost to further boost Taiwan-Malaysian ties during his tenure.
More than 1,000 Malaysian officials, parliamentarians, social celebrities as well as Taiwanese expatriates and business executives attended the celebration party.
Taiwanese trade associations in Malaysia also jointly donated US$38,000 to help Taiwan people affected by typhoon-caused flooding this summer.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 4,500 EXPATS RETURN FOR NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: A total of 4,526 Taiwan expatriates have registered with the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) for return to attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations, OCAC officials said Saturday.
As of Saturday afternoon, 3,351 of them had returned and reported to the OCAC for attending various National Day celebration activities, the officials said.

Although many expatriates already returned between March and May either to vote in the March 20 presidential election or to attend the May 20 presidential inauguration, the officials said, the number of expatriates returning for National Day celebrations remains almost same as previous years, indicating that ROC expatriates love and support Taiwan.
The OCAC organized two concerts at the National Concert Hall Saturday to entertain returning expatriates, one in the afternoon and the other in the evening.
The OCAC has also commissioned 17 selected travel agencies to organize local tour packages for expatriates.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIC PACIFIC ALLIANCE TO BE INAUGURATED NEXT AUGUST: VP

TEXT.P: The Democratic Pacific Alliance (DPA) will be formally inaugurated in Taipei next August, Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday.

Lu made the announcement in a speech delivered ahead of a concert at the National Concert Hall in Taipei to entertain Taiwan expatriates who have returned to attend the Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day celebrations.
Lu said representatives from some 20 democratic countries in the Pacific Rim will take part in the DPA inaugural meeting to be held Aug. 14, 2005 in Taipei.
"The alliance will offer a forum for Taiwan to share its democratic and economic development experiences with other countries," Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush and Kerry trade attacks in their second presidential debate
U.S. Senator John Kerry assailed President Bush for a record of soaring deficits and anemic job growth and a foreign policy that stirred resentment around the globe in a tense and testy second debate Friday night. President Bush derided Kerry as a liberal who would usher in higher taxes and bigger government and would make the United States less safe. For 90 heated minutes as they paced across a platform in a "town hall" forum at Washington University in St. Louis, Bush and Kerry offered sharply different responses in heated language to virtually every question that came before them: from health care to taxes, from Iran to Iraq, to who should be on the Supreme Court and what kind of limits should be placed on stem cell research.
Wall Street Journal: Bush and Kerry battle in fierce second debate
In a crackling second debate, President Bush and Sen. John Kerry battled over the war in Iraq, jobs, education, health care, the environment, cheaper drugs and other issues at a town-hall session 25 days before the election. Bush defended his invasion of Iraq. He insisted that the Iraqi leader posed a unique threat and the world was safer without him in power. But the Massachusetts senator accused Bush of misplaced priorities.

In the second campaign debate, President Bush sharpened his performance considerably over his first encounter with Democrat John F. Kerry, the result being rough parity between the candidates on stylistic grounds.That put their differences on substance -- dramatically different governing priorities, and starkly different responses to whether the country is on the right course at home and abroad -- on even more vivid display, the paper said.
