DOC.HEADLINE: BANGLADESH PREPARING TO SEND LABORERS TO TAIWAN: CLA

TEXT.P: The South Asian country of Bangladesh is preparing to export laborers to Taiwan to work, sources from the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday.

The Department of Health has given its consent to a list of hospitals recommended by Bangladesh's public health and labor affairs agencies to allow potential Bangladeshi workers to have health check-ups prior to their journey to Taiwan, CLA officials said.
As soon as Bangladesh opens its liaison office in Taiwan, the CLA will give the green-light to open Taiwan's doors to Bangladeshi laborers, the CLA officials said.
Taiwan maintains a representative office in Bangladesh, while the Bangladeshi government is planning to open one in Taiwan, although no definite timetable has been set.

CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu paid a five-day visit to Bangladesh in August this year. During her stay, Chen and her entourage met with senior Bangladeshi officials to discuss the procedures for importing Bangladeshi workers and feasible labor cooperation formula, particularly in designing of vocational training programs and cultivation of labor training instructors.
With a population of more than 131 million, Bangladesh has rich manpower resources.

Bangladesh will become the newest source of foreign laborers in Taiwan. At present, Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia and Mongolia export laborers to Taiwan. Mongolia sent its first batch of workers to the island in May of this year.

Indonesia, because it failed to work in tune with the CLA's request to cut the exorbitant brokerage fees charged by employment agencies in the Southeast Asian country, has not been allowed to export laborers to Taiwan since Aug. 1, 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZI PRIME MINISTER REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO SUPPORT ROC'S U.N. BID

TEXT.P: Swazi Prime Minister Absalom Dlamini said Monday his country will do whatever it can to help Taiwan join the United Nations and other major international organizations.
In terms of its population, democratic development and economic prosperity, Dlamini said, Taiwan deserves a U.N. seat.

Dlamini, who arrived in Taipei Friday to attend the Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day celebrations, made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian decorated him with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of Taiwan-Swaziland ties.

Noting that Taiwan and Swaziland have shared values, Dlamini said the two countries have for long cooperated closely in various fields, including public health, education, handicrafts, tourism, agriculture, investment promotion, information sharing and technological development. Dlamini expressed gratitude for Taiwan's long-term assistance in Swaziland's national development.

Dlamini further said his country is now undergoing social and political transformation. As a developing country, the southern African kingdom is facing many challenges. Dlamini said he hopes Taiwan can continue to be Swaziland's working partner in addressing all these challenges.
Meanwhile, according to Dlamini, the work to write a new Swazi constitution is entering the final stage.

"I hope our new constitution can be put into force next year. To the best of my understanding, the ROC is also reviewing its existing constitution. We can learn from each other in this regard, " Dlamini said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST CONTINUE TO BEEF UP DEFENSES UNTIL TRUST IS BUILT: WANG

TEXT.P: Taiwan must continue to beef up its defensive capabilities through the purchase of arms until cross-strait mutual trust on arms control efforts is established, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday.
Before the two sides engage in talks on arms control and reach an understanding in this matter, it is imperative for Taiwan to continue to strengthen its military defenses, Wang noted.

Wang made the remarks in response to President Chen Shui-bian's peace overture toward mainland China spelled out in his Oct. 10 National Day address Sunday calling for the two sides to seriously consider the issue of "arms control" and seek to establish a "code of conduct across the Taiwan Strait" as a tangible guarantee of permanent peace.

Chen also suggested that Taiwan and mainland China use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible schemes that are "not necessarily perfect but acceptable" as steps toward a resumption of dialogue and consultations.
Wang hailed President Chen's proposals as "constructive and useful" in terms of reducing tensions and increasing prospects for resuming the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.
However, he stressed that Chen must demonstrate his sincerity in pushing for the implementation of these proposals so as to help build trust across the strait.
Only when mutual trust is built can Taiwan expect to see a resumption in cross-strait dialogue, Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VIETNAMESE OFFICIALS TO DISCUSS LABOR EXPORT POLICIES

TEXT.P: Labor affairs officials from Vietnam are scheduled to meet with their Taiwan counterparts in Taipei Wednesday to discuss labor export issues, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) officials said Monday.

The main topic of the meeting is expected to be the issue of Vietnamese laborers absconding while in Taiwan. Although Vietnam is not the largest source of foreign laborers in Taiwan, Vietnamese workers top the list in terms of number of absconders who had not yet been found as of the end of September, the CLA officials said.

The officials said a possible freeze on the import of Vietnamese laborers might be adopted, probably in mid-October, if a report on this group of people for the July-September period shows that the situation has not improved.

According to CLA talles, 7,900 out of the some 72,000 Vietnamese workers currently in Taiwan have absconded, for a rate of 9.39 percent. The rate for Vietnamese workers was also the highest among all foreign laborers as of the end of August in terms of nationality, followed by that for Philippine workers at 2.5 percent and Thai laborers at 1.6 percent.
The CLA in May of this year suspended the introduction of Vietnamese fishermen and fishing boat crew members into Taiwan, also in response to the group's high absconding rate.

Taiwan had about 302,000 legal foreign laborers at the end of June, with 102,000 from Thailand, 86,000 from the Philippines, 72,000 from Vietnam, 40,000 from Indonesia, 36 from Mongolia and 22 from Malaysia.

Indonesia, because it failed to work in tune with the CLA's request to cut the exorbitant brokerage fees charged by employment agencies in its country, has not been allowed to export any laborers to Taiwan since Aug. 1, 2002.

The manufacturing sector has absorbed the largest number of foreign laborers, followed by the caregiving sector and the construction industry. A few thousands of these foreign laborers serve as maids.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI AIRWAYS INAUGURATES MATSU-TAICHUNG, MATSU-KAOHSIUNG FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Air traffic between Taiwan proper and the frontline island of Matsu has become more convenient with UNI Airways inaugurating flight services between Matsu and two major Taiwan cities -- Taichung and Kaohsiung, officials said Monday.

UNI Airways, an affiliate of Evergreen Group, made its maiden flight from Taichung in central Taiwan to Matsu's Nankan Airport Monday and will inaugurate its flight between Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan and Nankan Tuesday.

The carrier held a ceremony celebrating the inauguration of the two new air routes Monday at Nankan Airport in Matsu, with the participation of Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng, Lienchiang County Magistrate Chen Hsueh-sheng and other local government officials and elected representatives.

UNI is the only carrier that operates regular flight services to the island group of Matsu, which lies closer to the southeastern mainland Chinese province of Fujian than to Taiwan. As it originally only plied the Taipei-Nankan and Taipei-Peikan routes, residents in the central and southern parts of the island had to travel to Taipei to take flights to Matsu.
From now on, UNI will operate one round-trip Taichung-Nankan flight on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday as well as one round-trip Kaohsiung-Nankan flight on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday.

Addressing the inaugural ceremony, Legislator Tsao Yuan-chang, who represents the Matsu constituency, said he hopes direct flight services between the two Taiwan-held offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu can be opened in the future.

Tsao further said he will also push for the opening of direct flights between Matsu and Fujian Province's Mawei port. Tsao said that although direct Matsu-Mawei shipping services have opened as part of the "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait, a voyage between the two places takes one hour and 45 minutes. It will take less than 20 minutes if flight services are permitted, he noted.
In response, CAA Director Chang said direct Kinmen-Matsu flights are not likely to be opened for now because both islands are located within mainland China's 15-mile territorial airspace.
As to Matsu-Mawei direct flights, Chang said cross-strait negotiations are required.

The bourse opened at 6,079.25, with the weighted index hitting a high of 6,096.28 and a low of 6,041.31 during the day's trading.

Five of eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 3.8 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.4 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.3 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.2 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by financial stocks at 0.4 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISFIGURED CHINESE-MALAYSIAN WOMAN RECEIVING TREATMENT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Chinese-Malaysian citizen Chang Si-mei, who suffers from congenital lamellar ichthyosis, an autosomal recessive disorder which can cause severe disfigurement, has come to Taiwan for treatment of skin cancer, medical sources said Monday.
Chang, 47, has checked into Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linko, Taipei County, where doctors are treating the cancer in her left foot, Chang Gung officials said.

Chang has planned to stay for two months on her third trip to Taiwan since 1992 when she first came to receive treatment and plastic surgery for the disfigurement caused by lamellar ichthyosis. Her second visit Taiwan came in 1996.

Chang had confined herself to her tiny cottage room in Malaysia before the age of 35. She was discovered unexpectedly by Taiwan writer Po Yang in 1992 during a journey to Malaysia. After extensive media coverage, Chang was invited to Taiwan the same year to receive medical treatment at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital which enabled her to return to society.

During her current stay in Taiwan, Chang said she plans to meet several "old friends, " including Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan's largest charity organization. She also plans to visit the Taipei 101, the world's tallest building.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO DEVELOP CAPACITY TO LAUNCH SATELLITES

TEXT.P: The government is currently assessing whether Taiwan will be able to launch satellites itself, Wu Mao-kun, chairman of the National Science Council (NSC), said Monday.
Wu made the remarks when he was fielding questions at the Science-Technology and Information Committee in the Legislative Yuan.

Legislators asked if the development of vehicles to launch satellites such as ROCSAT-II, which was developed by the National Space Program Office and launched in California in April this year, have other than scientific purposes.

Wu said the development of a launch vehicle for satellites aims to develop the country's aeronautics program. The NSC has in the past cooperated with the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) for spacecraft research.
This time, it has asked the CIST and other specialists to assess the feasibility of sending satellites to an orbit of 700 kilometers, he said.

Wu said that ROCSAT-II is mainly for scientific research. Whether it can be used for national security or information gathering is up to other government agencies, he said. However, if the NSC were to be tasked with such missions, the council would work to that end, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT PLANS TO DRAFT NEW CONSTITUTION FOR TAIWAN BY 2007

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui Monday unveiled his plan to draft a "new Taiwan constitution" by 2007, saying the Republic of China Constitution now used by the country is trapping Taiwan in a "one China" pitfall.

Lee was delivering a speech entitled "Only if Taiwan enacts a new constitution will Asia-Pacific stability be ensured" during a Taipei seminar jointly organized by the Taiwan Advocates, a think tank chaired by Lee, and two Japanese civic groups.

Lee pointed out that Taiwan does not have a constitution belonging to itself and is still using the "Constitution of the Republic of China" which exhibits a wide gap with the political realities of today.
At the time of its enactment, the Constitution covered a territory that is now the People's Republic of China and Outer Mongolia but not Taiwan, Lee said.

Besides its incongruity with the status quo of Taiwan, the Constitution is ensnaring Taiwan into a "one China" pitfall and offering Beijing an excuse to declare to the international community that the Taiwan question is one of its "internal affairs, " Lee argued.

Lee said having been president for 12 years, he has a deep feeling that the so-called "Republic of China" is nothing internationally and is simply a non-existent entity like the "emperor's new clothes" which Taiwan uses to fool itself.

Lee said he does not approve of President Chen Shui-bian's remarks that "the Republic of China is Taiwan" and "Taiwan is the Republic of China, " because Taiwan is deceiving itself and others by using this description.

If the Taiwanese people continue to be governed under the "Republic of China" system, they will never be able to participate in the international community and the instability across the Taiwan Strait will carry on, according to Lee.

Lee said the Taiwanese people will be irresponsible to themselves and their offspring as well as to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region if they do not adopt a new constitution to terminate this abnormal situation.

Accusing mainland China of being the origin of the crisis in Asia, Lee said Beijing is threatening other countries against supporting Taiwan and recognizing Taiwan as a sovereign state, while it is upgrading its coercive language toward the island from "independence means war" to "refusing unification means war, " Lee said.

Unless the Taiwanese people free themselves from the "one China" framework formed by the Republic of China system, it will be tantamount to the Taiwanese people acquiescing to Beijing's territorial claim over Taiwan, Lee said.

Lee emphasized that the "one China" framework maintained by the Republic of China system is encouraging the mainland to invade Taiwan, which he said would be the severest crisis across the Taiwan Strait.
In addition, he said, the five-branch government under the ROC Constitution does not fit a presidential or parliamentary system and is hampering Taiwan's politics from operating normally.
Hsu Ching-hsiung, a professor of Japanese studies at Tamkang University, said a new country needs to be built on Taiwan because the Republic of China is not recognized by the world.
Enacting a new constitution and adopting a new name for the country are the two essential parts of building a new country, Hsu added.
Hsu criticized President Chen as being self-contradictory for calling Taiwan and the mainland "one country on each side" but not trying to join the United Nations in the name of a "new country."

DOC.HEADLINE: ISRAELI POLITICIANS ATTEND ROC DOUBLE TEN CELEBRATION
DOC.DATELINE: Tel Aviv, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Yang Yi-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Some 200 Israeli friends of the Republic of China from the political, commercial, academic and media sectors attended a cocktail party Sunday evening hosted by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Tel Aviv to celebrate the Republic of China's 93th National Day.
The dignitaries included Israel Knesset member Shaul Yahalom, four parliamentarians, and a media advisor to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.
In recent years, contact between Taiwan and Israel has gradually increased, with official statistics showing a growing trend in terms of trade and tourism.

ROC Representative to Israel Teng Shen-shen cited statistics released by Israel's Central Bureau of Statistics and said that during the period from January to July this year, two-way trade between Taiwan and the Middle East country grew 62.3 percent.
Israel's exports to Taiwan expanded 180 percent to US$294 million during the period, while Taiwan's export to Israel increasing 31 percent to US$270 million, according to the statistics.
Teng also noted that his office issued a total of 1,786 visas to Israelis last year, and from the beginning of this year to September they have granted 2,467 Israelis permission to visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO IMMEDIATE PRICE HIKES FOR WATER, ELECTRICITY

TEXT.P: Water and electricity prices will not go up in the short term to help stabilize domestic commodity prices, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Monday.
Chen made the remarks while fielding questions at a committee in the Legislative Yuan.

Chen noted that domestic water and electricity prices have been low for a long time, and there is room for reasonable adjustments, but in the future. Electricity prices are also affected by rising coal prices and the cost of generating electricity is rising.
If there is no adjustment, Taiwan Power Company could be in the red to the tune of NT$9 billion (US$267.06 million) for the first time next year, he said.

Chen also said the recent surge in crude oil prices, as high as US$52.68 a barrel, is a concern, but he said that after short-term factors for the price spike recede, prices should better reflect supply and demand, although the possibility of a dramatic decrease in price is unlikely.
Chen said the ministry will keep a close eye on the international situation and oil price fluctuations to mitigate any adverse impacts on the domestic economy.

He said that considering the fact that price hikes for water and electricity will trigger price hikes in other industries and stoke public worries about inflation, any price hikes will not be done right away.

The ministry will consider the impact on the industry, the tolerance level of the public as well as the sustainable development of the water and electricity industries in its assessment of the timing and level of price hikes, he said.

He also said that the consumer price index in the first nine months rose 1.54 percent, modest compared with other countries, and attributed the hike to the surge in international crude oil prices, as well as the short term factor of a series of typhoons that hit Taiwan in the summer, causing prices hikes for fruits and vegetables.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSPECT OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS RESUMING UNCERTAIN: U.S. EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The prospect for the resumption of cross-strait dialogue remains uncertain despite President Chen Shui-bian's latest offer since it failed to address the "one China" precondition set by mainland China, an American expert on East Asian affairs said Monday.
Alan Romberg, a senior associate at the Henry L. Stimson Center, said it would be "wishful thinking" to believe that this precondition will vanish, no matter how unreasonable it is.

"President Chen's proposal, however, does not address the mainland's sole criterion for getting back to the table, and that is acceptance of the current existence of 'one China,' even if each side has a different way of defining that 'one China,'" Romberg said.
In his National Day address on Sunday, Chen proposed that Taipei and Beijing resume their long-stalled dialogue based on the talks that officials from both sides held in Hong Kong in 1992.

Romberg said some people may hope that Beijing, especially after Taiwan's year-end legislative elections, will rethink its position at least to the extent of engaging in an authoritative dialogue with Taipei at some level, but that is "far from a certainty."

Beijing will be paying close attention to developments in Taiwan, especially to the handling of sensitive issues, including the possible change of the national title and the proposals to amend the Constitution, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIR CARRIERS POISED FOR CROSS-STRAIT DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based air carriers are keenly hoping for direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait after President Chen Shui-bian called for an early resumption of negotiations on the issue in his Oct. 10 National Day address.

Chen said that the government's executive branch is currently devising a plan to provide a convenient and swift way to facilitate charter flights for passengers and cargo, and he voiced his hope that cross-strait consultations can begin as soon as possible to seek further progress in the "three-links" policy.

China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways Corporation -- Taiwan's two largest aviation companies -- said that they Beijing should respond quickly to Chen's call considering that the move would benefit both sides.

Taking factors such as travel time, fuel costs and market share into consideration, they contended that technical issues centering on cargo travel are easier to handle and urged the Taiwan authorities to put forward concrete measures, such as allowing mainland China's carriers to offer the same services.
According to the civil aviation sector, Taiwan people make about four million trips every year to mainland China via a third country or area, incurring an extra cost of about NT$30 billion.
If extra flying time and fuel costs are added, they pointed out that the total cost through a third area -- usually Hong Kong or Macau -- is about NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion) per year.

According to estimates by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , the volume of present indirect cargo travel between Taiwan and mainland China amounts to around 73,000 tons each year. MAC officials said that the level will further increase after travel links are set up.

In an effort to tap the cross-strait market, CAL has signed an accord for joint operations with the mainland's Air China, China Southern Airlines Co., Ltd. and China Eastern Air, Ltd. It also inked cooperative ventures with shipping and bus companies based in Hong Kong to provide better land and sea travel.
CAL, Taiwan's No. 1 carrier, opened an office in Guangzhou earlier this year and has increased flights between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

A CAL executive said that there will be no technical problems for cross-strait air travel and that they welcome other aviation companies to join the service. He said that CAL will do its best to cooperate with the government when concrete measures are worked out and put in place.
The MAC has announced that future cross-strait routes will be open to six carriers based in Taiwan.

An assessment by the Taipei Aviation Industry Association shows that direct cross-strait air links will help passengers flying between the two sides save some 50 percent in travel time on single trips and that carriers can save from US$50,000 to US$80,000 in operating costs on a round trip.
Meanwhile, stock market watchers predicted that President Chen's proposal on this front will inject momentum to shipping and aviation company shares in the coming days.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMBASSADOR HOPES ROC-PARAGUAY TIES CAN BE FURTHER STRENGTHENED
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Lee Pei-jen and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to Paraguay Yen Ping-fan on Sunday expressed the hope that bilateral ties between Taiwan and Paraguay can be further strengthened in the future.
Yen made the appeal during an occasion to celebrate the ROC's Oct. 10 National Day held in Paraguay, the island's only diplomatic ally in South America.

Yen noted that ROC and Paraguay have maintained close relations for many years, and the ROC government has sent agricultural and technical missions to help Paraguayan farmers increase their production in rice, corn, vegetables, flowers and processed pork products since the two countries established diplomatic ties in 1957.
The ROC government has also offered advanced economic and commercial courses to Paraguay's small enterprises to assist in raising its technical level.

To help elevate the quality of life in Paraguay, the ROC government has helped construct some 1,000 housing units for low-income families, elementary schools, kindergartens, health care centers and donated funds and improved equipment for Paraguayan police authorities, according to the ambassador.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO SEND NEGOTIATORS TO TAIWAN TO DISCUSS AIR LINK ISSUE

TEXT.P: Mainland China is welcome to send negotiators to Taiwan to discuss issues regarding opening direct charter flight services across the Taiwan Strait, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday.

Wu said Taiwan is not opposed to the Beijing-proposed three principles for forging direct cross-strait air links, namely two-way, participation of carriers from both sides on a reciprocal basis and non-stop.

"As these kinds of air links involve the exercise of public authority, the two sides must negotiate viable and mutually acceptable terms to begin with, " Wu said. "We hope Beijing can send negotiators to Taipei for face-to-face consultations."
Wu made the remarks at a news conference held after a meeting chaired by Premier Yu Shyi-kun of senior government officials, scholars and executives of major industry associations.

Yu called the meeting a day after President Chen Shui-bian said in his National Day address a day earlier that cross-strait charter flights should be opened to facilitate passenger and cargo transport.

In addition to Joseph Wu, several other senior officials, including Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san and Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, also attended the meeting.

Other participants included Wu Rong-I, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, Huang Mao-hsiung, president of the Chinese National Association of Commerce and Industry, and Hsu Sheng-hsiung, president of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association.

With a view to accelerating the start of cross-strait negotiations, Joseph Wu said the government will invite senior executives of the nation's six largest trade associations and representatives of air carriers to discuss how to kick-start cross-strait talks on direct air links issues.

Noting that the newly revised statute governing cross-strait relations has authorized the government to commission private groups to negotiate with parallel mainland organizations, Wu said the government will exercise flexibility in handling cross-strait talks. Before the statute was revised, only the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation could handle cross-strait talks in the absence of official ties.

Speaking on the same occasion, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said the government will uphold the principles of pragmatism, flexibility and respect in handling cross-strait negotiations, including the status of negotiators, timing, venue and the meeting format.

If mainland authorities prefer to hold charter flight negotiations in any mainland city or at a third place, Chen said, Taiwan will not oppose this. "Anyway, we hope Beijing can make a goodwill response to our offer," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIPPING AND AVIATION LEADERS KEY IN CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's decision to consider the possibility of direct cross-strait charter flights for passengers and cargo is a breakthrough, but shipping and aviation figures should take part in the ensuing talks, an entrepreneur suggested Monday.

Hsu Sheng-hsiung, president of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, made the remarks after a Cabinet decision Monday that confirmed President Chen Shui-bian's proposal announced in his Double Ten National Day address to formulate a plan that provides convenient and efficient means to facilitate such charter flights.
After the Executive Yuan's decision, the next step will be the selection of representatives for talks.
Hsu suggested that during such technical consultations, individuals from the aviation and shipping sectors should take part while government officials can serve as advisers to the negotiation team.

Charter flight services across the Taiwan Strait were operated on a trial basis two years ago for Taiwan businessmen based in mainland China to return to Taiwan for the Chinese New Year holiday, but they were only one-way and had to make stops in Hong Kong or Macau.
There were no cross-strait charter flights this year because Beijing did not wish to engage in bilateral consultations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING FRIENDLINESS NEEDED TO START DIRECT LINKS: MOTC

TEXT.P: Amid a government drive to promote direct charter flights for both passengers and cargo between Taiwan and mainland China, an official said Monday that Beijing's friendliness is needed to start such services.
Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Tsai Tui made the remarks after Premier Yu Shyi-kun convened a meeting earlier the same day with key trade and economics officials.

It was decided in the meeting that cross-strait direct air links will be offered based on the principle of "allowing aviation companies from both sides to offer round trips without a technical stop in a third country or area."

Claiming that there will be no technical problems for cross-strait air travel, Tsai, however, pointed out that Beijing still needs to display goodwill of its own, since Taiwan has again offered to talk on the issue.

President Chen Shui-bian said a day earlier in his Oct. 10 National Day address that Taiwan is eagerly hoping to begin consultations with the mainland to facilitate charter flights for passengers and cargo between the two sides to pave the way for further progress in the "three-links" policy.
Meanwhile, local business and industrial communities gave a thumbs-up to the government's newest stance regarding direct air links between Taiwan and mainland China.

It is an irreversible path for the two sides given the present prevailing trends of division of labor and such a move will help Taiwan companies more effectively keep their talent, capital and core operations at home, they said.

Pointing out that both sides should do their best to remove political barriers to push for the talks, they also expressed their hope for a full opening of links to cover all sectors, including the hi-tech industry and tourism-related businesses.

Taiwan and mainland China have been at odds since the end of a civil war in 1949. Direct transport, trade and postal links -- the so-called "three links" -- remain absent despite frequent and close trade and economic exchanges between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE TAIWAN CITIZEN KILLED IN MAINLAND TRAFFIC ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday it has asked the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to assist the family of a Taiwan citizen killed in a traffic accident in mainland China Sunday.

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said the SEF will offer all necessary assistance to the family of Han Tien-yi, who was confirmed to have died in a traffic accident in mainland China's famous Jiuzaigou scenic area a day earlier.

A large tour bus overturned into the Peijiang River in Sichuan province on its way to Jiuzaigou, according to a report from Beijing. Twenty people were killed and four others are missing in the accident, while 21 passengers were rescued, the report said.
According to the report, the tour group was mainly composed of mainland Chinese citizens. Han reportedly had lived in Chongqing, Sichuan province in central China for a long time.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S INTERCHANGE ASSOCIATION CHAIRMAN VISITS KINMEN

TEXT.P: Japan's Interchange Association Chairman Masaji Takahashi visited Kinmen Monday to look at the direct shipping links between the frontline island and the mainland Chinese city of Xiamen.

During the trip, Takahashi, who was in Taiwan for the ROC National Day celebrations, went to Shuitou Pier to survey the ferry services between the two sides and called on Kinmen County Deputy Magistrate Yang Chung-chuan.
Yang told Takahashi the Kinmen-Xiamen "mini three-links" started in 2001, and there are two ferries operated by each side every day, with total trips hitting 30,000 people per month.
In addition to local residents, Taiwanese businessmen in mainland China can also use the services to travel across the Taiwan Strait, Yang said.
Takahashi, meanwhile, said Japan is very concerned about the development of cross-strait relations because peace and stability across the Strait are related to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL IN U.S. FOR 'SPECIAL 301' REVIEW

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs' Intellectual Property Office (TIPO) has sent a high-ranking official to the United States to communicate with authorities and groups ahead of a review of Taiwan's progress in intellectual property protection, officials said Monday.
TIPO Deputy Director-General Lu Wen-hsiang left for Washington, D.C. last week, the officials said.

During trip, Lu is set to visit the Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR), Business Software Alliance (BSA), Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA), Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) , Entertainment Software Association (ESA) and Association of American Publishers (AAP) to let the American side better understand the Taiwan government's efforts in attacking piracy.
The U.S. has again put Taiwan on a priority watch list in a report released in May on its annual "Special 301" review on intellectual property protection of its trading partners.
It has promised to survey the opinions of relevant groups during an out-of-cycle review of Taiwan's progress in this respect in the fall, according to the officials.

The officials said the USTR and the intellectual property rights groups have been impressed by the recent actions taken by Taiwan, which include institutionalizing a police squad to crack down on piracy, revising the Copyright Law and setting a goal of lowering the percentage of software piracy to below 40 percent by the end of 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL DANCE SPORT COMPETITION TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2004 International DanceSport Federation's (IDSF) Taipei International Open will be held Oct. 23-24, with dancers from 24 countries participating, a record number in recent years.

Officials of the Chinese Taipei DanceSport Federation, the organizer of the event, said Monday that countries with normally high-level dancing skills, including Hungary, Russia and the Slovak Republic, will send dancers to participate in the competition, while some new faces from Italy, Great Britain, Poland and Slovenia will also join the event to be held at the gymnasium of the Taipei Physical Education College.
For its part, Taiwan will send "Latin Dance Princes" Wang Yu-hung, Tsai Chung-lun and Chao Chun-lun to vie for the championship.

Yeh Jung-yu, secretary-general of the Asian DanceSport Federation, expressed hope that the participation of world-class dancers can help elevate Taiwan dancers' skills and attract more people to take part.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC FOOD FESTIVAL TO OPEN THIS WEEKEND

TEXT.P: An ethnic food festival will be held this weekend at a square in front of the Presidential Office, the head of the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) announced Monday.

CCA Chairman Chen Chi-nan said at a news conference to promote the food festival that the Oct. 16-17 food festival will feature famous dishes from Hakka, Hoklo, mainland China and Southeast Asian countries.

The food festival will be part of an ethnic and cultural development conference Oct. 16-18. Other related activities will include a "cultural citizen carnival, " a Taiwan culture night, an ethnic images exhibition and artistic and literary performances.
Six chefs invited to attend Monday's conference spoke on the origins of some famous dishes.

Chiu Ping-hsin, who serves as the chef of state banquets given by President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui, said that the dish "lamb meat in red rice wine sediment" best illustrates the diversity of ethnic groups because it requires red rice wine sediment from Fuzhou, lamb meat from Tibet and rice wine from Taiwan to create its distinctive flavor.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE WELCOMES PRESIDENT CHEN'S NATIONAL DAY ADDRESS
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By S. J. Kan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Singapore's foreign ministry said Monday that it welcomed President Chen Shui-bian's address a day earlier, calling it a development that would reduce tensions between Taiwan and mainland China.
The foreign ministry made the remarks in a statement, which said that Singapore was aware of the contents of the speech, which was part of the Republic of China's National Day celebrations.

Media outlets in Singapore also reported extensively on Chen's address, two weeks after relations between Taiwan and Singapore became strained due to ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan San Chen's "piece of snot" comment that suggested a belittlement of Singapore.

The president said in the address that "based on the existing foundation, both sides should promote the resumption of cross-strait dialogue and communication to reduce the gap between the two sides and to construct a foundation of mutual trust.

"Today, I would like to take the initiative to propose that both sides use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways that are 'not necessarily perfect but acceptable' in preparation of a step forward in the resumption of dialogue and consultations, " the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG TO SIGN INITIAL COOPERATION PACT WITH GUGGENHEIM TUESDAY

TEXT.P: The Taichung City Government will sign an initial agreement with the New York-based Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation Tuesday on cooperation in building a Guggenheim branch museum in the central Taiwan city.
Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu said the city government will sign the preliminary cooperation accord with the Guggenheim foundation by fax.

According to a consensus reached during Hu's visit to the Guggenheim foundation Sept. 21, the two parties should sign an initial agreement before Oct. 12 and the Taichung City Government must pay a total of US$8 million in initial royalties, project management and architectural design fees before Oct. 29 as a guarantee that it will indeed carry out the cooperative project; otherwise, the foundation will forfeit its cooperative plan with Taiwan.

In response to a request by the Taichung City Council, Hu said, the Guggenheim foundation has agreed to cut its royalty fee by US$3 million and extend the contract period to 25 years to meet the council's demand of a 20 percent discount in royalty payments.
As the city council will begin a session Oct. 18, Hu said he believes they will have enough time to screen and approve the initial payment of US$8 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN LOOKS FORWARD TO NEW ROUND OF KOO-WANG MEETINGS: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian looks forward to a new round of Koo-Wang meetings to kick-start the long-stalled dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker said Monday.

Legislator Hung Chi-chang, an influential member of the DPP's New Tide faction, made the remarks a day after Chen suggested in his National Day address that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways that are "not necessarily perfect but acceptable" as preparations for a step forward in the resumption of dialogue and consultations.

Hung said the 1992 conference between Taiwan and mainland officials in Hong Kong paved the way for a high-level meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) in Singapore in April 1993.

The historic Koo-Wang meeting laid the foundation for cross-strait dialogue and exchanges. However, Beijing has unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue since mid-1999 after then-President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as special state-to-state in nature, a statement which Beijing viewed as a veiled move to promote Taiwan independence.

Hung said he believes that President Chen, by proposing using the 1992 Hong Kong meeting as a basis, hopes to break the lingering cross-strait political stalemate and jump-start a new round of Koo-Wang meetings to discuss the much-anticipated opening of direct cross-strait air and shipping links and jointly work for permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'BOMB' IN TAIPEI MRT STATION RESTROOM A HOAX

TEXT.P: A cookie box found Monday in a men's restroom at the MRT Taipei Main Station with a note attached in Chinese saying, "bomb" was a hoax, according to police.
A commuter noticed the box at around 4: 45 p.m. and informed police immediately.
Since the box was located in a busy area between the MRT line and the main train station, the incident drew much attention from passersby.
Police sealed off the restroom and called in the bomb squad, who later confirmed that the box did not contain explosives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER THANKS SWAZILAND FOR ITS SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun expressed his appreciation Monday for the support Swaziland has extended to Taiwan in the international arena and said that he wishes to visit the African ally some day.

Speaking at a dinner party he hosted to entertain his Swazi counterpart, Absalom Dlamini, Yu said that he specially appreciated the remarks made by Dlamini's deputy in this year's United Nations General Assembly in support of Taiwan's U.N. bid.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei and other government officials also attended the party.
Dlamini arrived at the head of an eight-member delegation Friday to attend the Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day celebrations.
During his stay, he met President Chen Shui-bian, who conferred upon him the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of bilateral ties.

Dlamini and his delegation also visited the International Cooperation and Development Fund, which is under the supervision of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and several cultural and economic establishments in Taiwan, including the National Palace Museum and the Taipei World Trade Center.
They are scheduled to leave for home Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DEAD, 11 INJURED IN FIRECRACKER FACTORY EXPLOSION

TEXT.P: An explosion at a fireworks factory in Hsinchu County left two dead and 11 injured Monday.

The explosion, which broke windows as far as a kilometer away, happened at about 10: 25 in the morning at the Yunkuang Firecracker Factory, located at the intersection of Hsinfeng and Fukou townships, a witness said.
Three buildings were demolished and neighboring crops were also burned. Seven men and six women were taken to hospitals, but two workers -- a man and a woman -- died despite emergency treatment.
Firefighters said that Yunkuang is one of only three legally registered firecracker factories in the county, adding that it passed regular safety inspections, the latest one being on Oct. 2.
Nearby residents said that although the factory was legally run, it had been renting out parts of its facilities to other manufacturers who were not licensed.

Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin said he was saddened by the news and asked firefighters to step up inspections of firecracker factories. He also encouraged residents to report any illegal operators within their communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER NT$600 BILLION OF INVESTMENT ENTERS THREE MAJOR SCIENCE PARKS

TEXT.P: Thanks to an economic recovery, three major science parks in Taiwan have continued to attract more than 100 manufacturers who have invested more than NT$600 billion (US$17.75 billion) in the parks as of September this year, the Cabinet-level National Science Council Chairman Wu Mao-kun said Monday.

Wu, while reporting to a committee at the Legislative Yuan, said that among them, investments in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park amounted to NT$39.14 billion, up two fold from the same period last year. Investments in the Southern Taiwan Science Park totaled NT$26.5 billion, and hit NT$541.4 billion in the Central Taiwan Science Park.

He said that as of June this year, the revenue of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park reached NT$533.4 billion, up 46 percent from the same period last year. The Central Taiwan Science Park had revenues of NT$170.8 billion as of August, or a 92 percent growth from the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHIPBUILDING PROFITS EXCEED TARGET FOR THE YEAR

TEXT.P: The state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) registered profits worth NT$470 million (US$13.9 million) in the first nine months of this year, far exceeding the annual profit target of NT$320 million, according to CSBC statistics released Monday.
CSBC officials attributed the gain to the recovering marine transport market and to the success of the company's revival plan, which began at the end of 2001.
Under the plan, the CSBC laid off more than 2,000 employees, cut salaries of the remaining workers by an average of 35 percent, and streamlined its structure in a bid to strengthen efficiency.
The officials revealed that construction orders are now booked until April 2008, with the orders of more than 40 ships being worth NT$50 billion.
CSBC's target is to deliver 14 commercial ships this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DEFENSE MINISTRY TO OUTSOURCE TO PRIVATE SECTOR

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) reported Monday that it has projected to release NT$58.2 billion (US$1.71 billion) worth of business opportunities this year to the private sector.

The MND made the report at an Executive Yuan meeting presided over by Premier Yu Shyi-kun. MND officials reported that major items to be released in this year's package include military airplanes and light armored vehicles as well as wireless telecommunications facilities and non-sensitive strategic equipment.

According to Yu, it is a set government policy to gradually release the military's maintenance and repairs as well as research and development and manufacturing business opportunities to domestic contractors as a means of incubating a capable national defense industry in the private sector.

Yu said that the business value commissioned to the private sector will gradually grow each year and that the target designated for 2011 will hit NT$90.6 billion. The MND met its target for 2003, he noted, adding that the ministry has been purchasing general military supplies and equipment made at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCT. 12 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Oct. 12:
09:00: The Legislative Yuan will open the day's session.
10:00, The Ministry of National Defense will hold a routine news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
10:00, The March 19 shooting truth investigation commission will visit the National Security Bureau.
10:30, Department chiefs of the MInistry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
11: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive Malawi National Assembly Speaker Rodwell Munyenyembe at the Presidential Office.
11:30, Senior Advisor to the President Koo Kwang-ming will hold a news conference at the Ambassador Hotel in Taipei.
13:00, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's central campaign group for the December legislative elections will hold a news conference at the party's headquarters.
14:00, The National Invention Awards ceremony will be held at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei.
14: 10, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will see off Swaziland Prime Minister Dlamini at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
16: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
16: 00, The Institute of Transportation will hold a news conference at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16: 30, The Foreign Exchange Department of the Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.
17: 30, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will meet with visiting Dallas deputy mayor at Taipei City Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIUM FOR VOCATIONAL INJURY INSURANCE TO BE REDUCED

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved a proposal Monday to reduce the premium for vocational injury insurance that will go into effect at the beginning of next year, CEPD officials said.

Under the proposal presented by the Council of Labor Affairs, the officials said, the average percentage of the premium that should be paid by employers will decrease to 0.27 percent from the current 0.33 percent.
The CEPD gave the green light to the proposal given that the ratio of vocational injuries has gradually fallen over the past years, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 12, or the 29th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: After a month of experiencing mirages of land, explorer Christopher Columbus and his three ships sight "terra firma" at dawn today.
1822: Brazil becomes independent from Portugal.
1866: Ramsey McDonald, Scottish statesman and first Labour prime minister of Britain, is born.
1870: Robert E. Lee, Confederate general in the US Civil War, dies in Lexington at the age of 63. He won victories at Bull Run (1862), Fredericksburg (1863), and Chancellorsville (1863), before surrendering to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox in 1865.
1899: The Boer states respond to Britain's despatch of troops to South Africa by issuing a declaration of war, and the British military garrison at Mafeking, under Colonel Robert Baden-Powell, is under siege by Boer forces.
1901: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, renames the Executive Mansion "The White House." He won the 1908 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1920: Bertrand A. W. Russell, British philosopher, mathematician, social critic, and writer who won the 1950 Nobel Price for Literature, arrives in Shanghai as a visiting professor. He had profound influence on the development of symbolic ligic, logical positivism, and the set theory of mathematics.
1935: Adolf Hitler bans American jazz from German radio, calling it decadent.
1949: The ROC government moves its seat from Canton to Chungking.
1949: Euginie Anderson is appointed US ambassador to Denmark, becoming the first female US envoy.
1951: Florence Chadwick, US swimmer, breaks the cross-English Channel record with a time of just 13 hours 33 minutes.
1959: The United Nations General Assembly votes for a full-scale debate on Chinese communist bloodshed in Tibet.
1960: Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, angered during a debate on colonialism at the United Nations General Assembly, takes off his shoe and ponds his desk with it several times.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a frienship treaty in Taipei.
1968: The 19th Olympic Games opens in Mexico City, capital of Mexico.
1968: Equatorial Guinea becomes independent after 190 years of Spanish rule.
1968: Omar Torrijos Herrera, a military officer, takes control of Panama and bigins to rule as a dictator.
1971: Dean Acheson, US politician and secretary of state from 1949 to 1953, dies at the age of 78. He promoted the Marshall Plan and helped established NATO.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE REPS ABROAD CALL FOR NEW CONSTITUTION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P. C. Tang)

TEXT.P: More than 60 Taiwanese representatives in Europe, America and Asia who attended a two-day World Taiwanese Leaders Conference in Washington, D.C., Oct. 9-10 urged Taiwan to accelerate its steps to write a new constitution and to rectify the nation's official designation.
The representatives made the appeal in a declaration adopted at the conference, the first of its kind ever held abroad by Taiwanese representatives residing in locations around the world.
They claimed that Taiwan's fundamental goals are to gain recognition from the international community and to write a new constitution

Noting that the use of an inappropriate national designation, impractical government organization operations, and uncertain territorial claims are all causes behind Taiwan's encountering a lot of difficulties, the representatives said that all of these urgently require reform and that all Taiwanese around the world should do their utmost to help achieve this goal.

Emphasizing that Taiwan can only make a breakthrough by writing a new constitution and clearly identifying its national status, they also said in the declaration that only by doing this can the island's security and position be ensured.

The representatives also decided during the meeting to urge Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties to accelerate their steps to launch a campaign for the writing of a new constitution and the rectification of the nation's official designation.

Calling for Beijing to give up the option of force against Taiwan and to stop its efforts to obstruct Taiwan in the international arena, they also expressed the hope that leaders of other nations will pay more attention to the global development of human rights, economy and trade as well as Taiwan's contributions to the world.
They also requested that the leaders of the world accept the willingness and capacity of Taiwan to become a member of the global village and recognize Taiwan as a nation as soon as possible.

The representatives also adopted several action plans at the meeting, including asking members of the U.S. Congress to write a letter to President Chen Shui-bian to request that the island's Representative Office to the United States rectify its designation; lobbying the European Union to maintain its ban on arms sales to mainland China; continuing to push Taiwan's bid to join international organizations; promoting Taiwan's image abroad; and holding various seminars to discuss the writing of a new constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURSES ON SOUTHEAST ASIAN CULTURE TO BE TAUGHT IN SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: Courses on Southeast Asia culture will be taught in elementary and junior high schools starting next year, an education official said Tuesday.

Vice Education Minister Fan Sun-lu said this will be part of a project under the name of a new immigration culture to create a pluralistic and new Taiwan which was worked out by National Chi Nan University at the commission of the ministry.

Fan noted that the number of foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens is growing every year. The latest statistics show that the number of foreign spouses has passed the mark of 310,000, with their children, numbering more than 30,000 in Taiwan's elementary and junior high schools, having become a new immigration group.
This is the reason the government wants to promote a pluralistic and equal ethnic society and the learning of the culture of new immigrants, Fan added.

Under the project, the ministry will work along the lines of teaching about Southeast Asian culture, mobilizing students from Southeast Asia who are currently studying in Taiwan, and increasing international cultural exchanges.
Courses to enhance understanding of Southeast Asian culture will start to be taught in elementary and junior high schools in February when the new semester begins.
In addition, a two-part "Understanding Southeast Asia" documentary featuring the region from the angle of Taiwan will also be aired by the Public Television Service.
The ministry will also ask the education departments in universities to devise comprehensive teaching materials for the teachers in the immigration learning centers in Taoyuan, Nantou and Tainan.

The overseas Chinese and foreign students who are currently studying in more than 60 colleges and universities in Taiwan will be mobilized so that they will become the bridge between new immigrants and Taiwan society.

The team comprised of these overseas students will work in Nantou County, where there is a large number of new immigrants, in the first year on a trial basis, and then the service will be expanded to the whole island.

Fan noted that Taiwan people used to travel to Southeast Asian nations for work or marriage in earlier years, and that now many Taiwan people travel to the region for investment. She added that it is hoped the "Understand Southeast Asia" project will help the people of Taiwan see the new immigrants as their equals through more understanding.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CALLS FOR WORLD ATTENTION TO CHINA'S GROWING MILITARY STRENGTH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged the international community Tuesday to pay more attention to mainland China's ever-growing military strength which the ministry said poses a serious threat to Taiwan Strait and Asia-Pacific security.

The ministry made the appeal amid reports that European Union foreign ministers had failed to agree Monday on lifting the bloc's 15-year-old arms embargo against mainland China despite strong French lobbying.

Speaking at a regular news conference, MOFA deputy spokeswoman Anna Kao said the proposal to lift the arms sales ban against mainland China was not put on the agenda of the current E.U. foreign ministers meeting in Luxembourg because a majority of member nations oppose lifting the ban. The E.U. foreign ministers only held informal discussions during a lunch meeting Monday, Kao said.

Yang-Huang Mei-hsing, director of the MOFA's Research and Planning Board, said that thanks to prominent media coverage in recent months, the world community has taken greater notice of Taiwan's concern about the proposed lifting of the E.U. arms embargo against mainland China.
For instance, Yang-Huang said, foreign wire services had reported a series of demonstrations staged by local activists outside major E.U. countries' representative offices in Taipei.

Moreover, she added, Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen's letter to the editor published in the London-based Financial Times urging the European Union not to view a lifting of its ban on arms sales to mainland China lightly had been widely quoted by major international news media.

Yang-Huang said she hopes local news media can continue to report on Taiwan's concerns about the issue so that the world can understand that Taiwan has been the guardian of peace in the Taiwan Strait and that keeping the arms embargo against China is very important to preserving regional stability, security and prosperity.

The European Union imposed the arms sales ban against mainland China after the 1989 Tiananmen massacre in which Beijing mobilized troops to crush a pro-democracy demonstration. Some E.U. member states oppose lifting the ban on the grounds that Beijing has not imporved its human rights records.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR RIGHTS ACTIVISTS PUSH FOR HOUSEMAID SERVICE LAW

TEXT.P: A group of labor rights activists demonstrated in front of the Legislative Yuan Tuesday advocating passage of a housemaid service law to protect basic human rights and the interests of local and foreign family helpers.

The activists displayed a barrel bearing signatures of more than 10,000 foreign housemaids working in Taiwan to show support they have received for the legislation. Also on display was a collection of photos of foreign housemaids who had been allegedly abused or maltreated by their local employers.
Chen Su-hsiang, president of the Taiwan International Workers Association, said Taiwan has not enacted a special law to protect foreign workers.

Noting that the absence of such a law has violated the international norm for human rights protection, Chen said the nation should enact a housemaid service law as soon as possible to protect both local and foreign family helpers from being abused by their employers.
"The proposed housemaid service law can clearly prescribe work terms to offer better protection for some 300,000 local and foreign housemaids in Taiwan," Chen said.
Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Shyu Jong-shyong has joined some of his colleagues in drafting a housemaid service bill, which is pending legislative screening.

The draft bill contains 51 articles in eight chapters. Highlights of the bill include protection of housemaids' privacy, regulations on employers' family members in dealing with housemaids, the code of conduct of housemaids, housemaid's rights to leaves and holidays, minimum wages, direct payment of wages and the rights of housemaids and employers to terminate working contracts.
Chen said she hopes this draft bill can clear the legislative floor during the current session.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY CLARIFIES REPORTS ABOUT PULLOUT FROM SIX ISLETS OFF KINMEN

TEXT.P: The military will turn over six islets it administers to the Kinmen County Government to help the outlying county's tourism efforts, but the Ministry of National Defense said Tuesday the move is an "adjustment of military personnel, " not a troop withdrawal.

Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng, spokesman for the defense ministry, made the remarks amid media reports that the six islets -- namely Tatan, Ertan, Tungting, Peiting, Shihyu and Menghuyi -- would be turned over to the Kinmen County Government and be opened to tourism on Jan. 1, 2005.

Huang noted that Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng proposed the takeover of the six islets, which lie closer to mainland China than to Taiwan, for tourism in 2000, and Premier Yu Shyi-kun, while inspecting the area in 2002, agreed to release the six islets in line with the plans of the Kinmen County Government.
He said that the Kinmen Defense Command is currently working with the Kinmen County Government on the details of the handover, but the date will be decided by the Executive Yuan.

Huang stressed that after the adjustment of military personnel, land and sea security will be turned over to police, but the six islets will still be within the effective range of the military's sphere of influence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CLAIM RIGHTS OVER CONTINENTAL SHELF

TEXT.P: Taiwan will submit information to the United Nations on the outer limits of its continental shelf if they extend beyond 200 nautical miles to protect its sovereign rights over the shelf, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

As Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, the government is planning to have the submission made through its diplomatic allies, according to Maysing Yang, head of MOFA's Research and Planning Board.

Yang noted that the U.N. Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf (CLCS) has requested its member nations to file the information by May 2009 in accordance with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

As stated in the convention, the continental shelf of a coastal state comprises the sea-bed and subsoil of the submerged areas that extend beyond its territorial sea throughout the natural prolongation of its land territory to the outer edge of the continental margin, or to a distance of 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured where the outer edge of the continental margin does not extend up to that distance.

The coastal state should establish the outer edge of the continental margin wherever the margin extends beyond 200 nautical miles and register the information with the U.N. commission, the convention stipulates.
It says the coastal state exercises over the continental shelf sovereign rights for the purpose of exploring and exploiting its natural resources.
Yang said the Ministry of the Interior is currently surveying the outer limits of Taiwan's continental shelf and that it is still unsure if they extend beyond 200 nautical miles.

However, Yang said Taiwan's continental shelf could extend northward to the East China Sea and Yellow Sea and overlap partially with that of mainland China's, Japan's and South Korea's; eastward to overlap partially with that of Japan's and the Philippines'; and westward to overlap almost completely with that of the mainland's.

Yang said MOFA believes that the government should lodge a serious protest over any foreign invasion of its continental shelf to safeguard its rights and to prevent Taiwan from being demarcated to become part of the mainland's territory.
MOFA will also inform neighboring countries of its claim over the continental shelf limits and seek bilateral negotiations for a settlement, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUMBER IMPORTS TO BE SUBJECT TO INSPECTION AND QUARANTINE FROM DEC. 1

TEXT.P: Sixty-one lumber products will be subject to inspection and quarantine before entering Taiwan from Dec. 1 as part of the government's efforts to avert invasion by dangerous exotic pests and insects, agriculture officials said Tuesday.

It will mark the first time in Taiwan's history that lumber imports are subject to inspection and quarantine. The announcement came amid concerns about the infestation of red fire ants in some parts of the island.
Officials from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said the items to be subject to inspection will mainly be large pieces of uncut wood and lumber products.

The COA's Bureau of Plant and Animal Health Inspection and Quarantine has worked out regulations governing inspection and quarantine of the 61 listed items, the officials said, adding that the bureau will hold a series of seminars in October and November to help local lumber importers understand the new regulations.
In terms of the new regulation, about 836,000 tons of uncut wood and 682,000 tons of lumber products imported in 2003 had to be inspected.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGEST DESALINATION PLANT PLANNED FOR HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest desalination plant is to be built at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan to help meet the growing demand for water there, a government official said Tuesday.
According to the official with the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), the proposal was adopted at a CEPD meeting held a day earlier.

It was decided that the Ministry of Economic Affairs will offer a parcel of land for the build-transfer-operate (BTO) project in cooperation with the private sector, which will be in charge of operations of the facility upon completion of its construction, the CEPD official said.

The planned desalination plant will be Taiwan's largest, with a projected capacity of more than 30,000 tons of fresh water per day for the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, which relies heavily on a sufficient water supply to sustain normal operations.
CEPD Vice Chairman Chang Ching-sun said at the meeting that a 20 percent water shortage could halt at least 50 percent of the park's operations.

Chang pointed out that it is increasingly difficult to maintain stable water supplies for the hi-tech park -- Taiwan's most representative and oldest facilities of its kind -- in the face of a growing threat of dry spells due to the worsening disparity in rainfall across Taiwan in recent years.

Citing an initial assessment by the CEPD, he said that each water meter unit of the desalination plant will cost an additional NT$1.5 and that many companies based in the park have shown a keen interest in its construction.

Estimates by water resource authorities show that it is necessary to explore alternative sources to satisfy the long-term need for fresh water in the Hsinchu area. Underground water, which has in the past been the major source for emergency use, is gradually running out, they noted.

Government authorities will open bidding to the public by Nov. 15 to invite a qualified private investor to participate in the construction project and an investment accord will be signed between the two sides by June 2005. Overall completion of the project and trial operations are scheduled for Dec. 2006.
Ownership of the plant will be returned to the government 20 years later after it has paid the private investor the total construction spending in installments.

The construction plan will carry a price tag of NT$1.788 billion (US$52.5 million) and the government will, starting from 2007, return NT$176 million per year to the investor through to the end of the 20-year installment plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BOTTOM LINE FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: PREMIER YU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can talk about any issues in consultations and dialogue, even the "one China" rhetoric cherished by mainland China, and there will be no bottom line.

The premier was responding to questions by Legislator Cheng Kuo-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the Legislative Yuan who asked how the Executive Yuan is going to follow through on President Chen Shui-bian's call for the resumption of cross-strait dialogues in his Double Ten National Day message.

President Chen said he would propose that both sides use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways that are "not necessarily perfect, but acceptable" in preparation for a step forward in the resumption of dialogue and consultations.

The premier said that there was a meeting in Hong Kong in 1992 which paved the way for the first high-ranking negotiations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait the following year, but there is no such thing as the "1992 consensus."

The president's words that the Hong Kong meeting could be used as a basis aims to put aside cross-strait disputes on sovereignty and engage in pragmatic exchanges, and his words should not be twisted as if there were a consensus reached in 1992.

The premier reaffirmed that those who took part in the Hong Kong meeting in 1992 know that there was no consensus reached between the two sides -- a tacit understanding that there is only one China, but mainland China and Taiwan have different interpretations on what this constitutes.

On cross-strait issues that the president touched on in his address, including arms control to avoid conflicts, confidence-building measures through consultations and dialogues, and the establishment of a "code of conduct across the Taiwan Strait, " the premier said that the government has "made preparations for cross-strait matters."
"There will be no bottom line for cross-strait consultations, " the premier added, saying that anything can be discussed, including venues and timing.
"The government is extending an olive branch in sincerity, and is hoping to have a positive response from mainland China," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS NO PLAN TO RAISE HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUMS BEFORE FEB. 1

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday the government has no plan to raise the premiums of the National Health Insurance within his term, which expires Feb. 1 next year.
Yu made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan in response to reports that the government will raise the premiums next year.
Yu said he is only responsible for the policy as long as he is in office.
Yu's Cabinet is set to resign en masse before the new Legislative Yuan is sworn in on Feb. 1, and it is uncertain if Yu will be reappointed premier by President Chen Shui-bian.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen, meanwhile, said it is necessary for the government to comprehensively plan the future financial program to ensure that the health insurance system remains viable.
However, any plans for adjustments will be raised for discussions at a civic meeting before they are finalized, Chen said.

Wang Yi-jen, deputy chief of the National Health Insurance panel under the DOH, said in a news conference that raising the premiums is not the only option for improving the program's financial condition.
There are other options such as increasing tobacco and alcohol taxes to finance the program, Wang said.

Also on Tuesday, staff members of nearly 500 regional hospitals around the island took to the streets demanding that the DOH raise the quota on National Health Insurance coverage for the medical services provided by regional hospitals.
The protesters claimed the current quota is driving them into bankruptcy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT DEVELOPING MISSILES THAT CAN REACH SHANGHAI: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun denied Tuesday that the nation is developing cruise missiles that can reach Shanghai.
"We have no such capability, nor are we developing such weapons," the premier said as he was fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Ku Chung-lien of the opposition People First Party asked if Taiwan was developing such offensive missiles. He also asked if the nation will develop them in the future after the premier's denial.

The premier said that he could only give his word that there will be no such development during his term. The premier will step down in February according to practice after the new legislature is established.
The premier also said that his recent mention about missiles to be used against the mainland was only a "presumption."

In a call for Taiwan to purchase arms to maintain a sufficient military deterrent, the premier said late last month that if mainland China fired 100 missiles at Taiwan, the island should be able to fire at least 10 back at the mainland.

Ku, a former ROC Navy commander-in-chief, also asked if the nation's "nuclear free" policy will be confined to opposition to the construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant, and not opposition to nuclear weapons, and whether there is a "five-man team" in the government to plan for the development of cruise missiles and nuclear weapons.
"There are no such things," the premier said categorically.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE RANK NEARLY LAST IN LOVE-MAKING FREQUENCY: DUREX POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan may be gaining strength in the global electronics industry, but in one area Taiwanese are definitely sagging -- sex.
The latest annual survey on sex by condom-maker Durex found that Taiwanese had sex only 80 times per year, ranking them fourth from the bottom of a list of 41 countries.
According to the 2004 Durex Global Sex Survey, released Tuesday, French top the global list with an average 137 times per year.
Taiwan had close company, as the three countries below them were Asian neighbors Hong Kong, Singapore and Japan.
Hong Kongers and Singaporeans had sex 79 times on average a year with Japanese bringing up the rear at 46.

As if that weren't bad enough, Taiwanese also cut to the chase faster than many other nationalities. Taiwan people spent an average of 16.3 minutes on foreplay, 3.4 minutes less than the global average from a sample size of 350,000 people worldwide, ranking them fifth from the bottom.
Topping the list of foreplay were those from Great Britain at an average of 22.5 minutes.

Coming to the final question, the survey found that 35 percent of all people responding said that they always achieve orgasm; however, only 17 percent of women said this compared to the 45 percent of men who did.
Among Chinese, 11 percent say they have never had an orgasm.
