Wall Street Journal: Corporate tax bill passes Senate, goes to President.
After four years of fits and starts, the Senate approved and sent to President Bush a huge tax bill that repeals a controversial export subsidy and replaces it with an even bigger break for U.S. manufacturers. The bill, dubbed the "American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, " is a treasure trove of tax breaks for scores of industries, multinationals with profts parked overseas, tabacco farmers subject to Depression-era quotas and residents of states that rely heavily on sales taxes. The billl was approved by a Senate vote of 69-17 after passing the House last week by 280-141. Though the Bush administration has reservations about some provisions of the bill, Mr. Bush is expected to sign it -- and will likely herald it as part of his plan to boost the U.S. economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TRUTH COMMISSION' MEMBERS VISIT NSB TO PROBE PRESIDENT'S SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Members of the "truth investigation commission" visited the National Security Bureau (NSB) Tuesday to examine details of President Chen Shui-bian's campaign tour on March 19 right before he was shot.
The members were received by NSB Director-General Hsueh Shih-min and his deputy, Wang Chin-wang, and both sides met for just under two hours.

Hsueh said he welcomes the chance to meet with the commission members, but stressed that no written material will be provided to them until a constitutional dispute surrounding the body's formation is settled.
A briefing on Chen's itinerary on that day was given to the visitors by Hsu Li-meng, head of the NSB's special services center.

Wang Ching-feng, spokeswoman for the commission, said the meeting was intended to let its members have a rough idea of what happened on that day and that the commission will continue to examine other details.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party is arguing that the opposition-backed commission is unconstitutional and has requested a constitutional interpretation from the Council of Grand Justices.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$610.8 BILLION ARMS PROCUREMENT IS NOT BOUND BY REFERENDUM: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement from the United States is not bound by the results of the March 20 national referendum because it had been decided upon before the vote was held, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday.
Speaking during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Yu said the referendum is only binding to policies that came after it.
Yu pointed out that Taiwan asked the U.S. repeatedly to sell the weapons to Taiwan between 1995 and 1999, and Washington finally agreed to the sale in 2001.
Taiwan held its first referendum along with the presidential election on March 20; whether the country should upgrade its anti-missile defense capability was one of two questions posed to voters.
However, although the question was approved by over 90 percent of those who participated, the referendum was declared invalid as a result of a low turnout rate of less than 50 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG ILLITERATE FOREIGN BRIDES TO BE REQUIRED TO RECEIVE EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Illiterate foreign and mainland Chinese brides under the age of 34 will be required to receive supplementary education, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Tuesday.
The new requirement is aimed at lowering the illiteracy rate among foreign and mainland brides younger than 34 years old to 1.8 percent by 2007 from 2.26 percent in 2003, MOE officials said.
To this end, the officials said, the ministry will revise current supplementary education laws to have certain foreign and mainland brides receive compulsory elementary education.
According to official tallies, the illiteracy rate among foreign and mainland brides reached 2.6 percent in 2003, with the rate among those younger than 34 standing at 2.26 percent.

In light of the fact that one-quarter to one-third of local newborns were born to mothers of mainland Chinese and Southeast Asian origins in recent years, the officials said the MOE has to take effective measures to lower the illiteracy rate among young mainland and foreign brides to maintain good manpower quality.
The number of Taiwan citizens marrying foreign and mainland Chinese citizens has been growing steadily, with the number of foreign and mainland brides exceeding 310,000.

More than 30,000 children born to foreign and mainland mothers are now studying at local elementary and junior high schools. Those new "sons of Taiwan" spread in all cities and counties around Taiwan, with Taipei and Taoyuan counties boasting the largest numbers. One-third of their mothers come from mainland China; 7,853 come from Indonesia and 3,578 come from Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRE ANTS SHOULD BE ELIMINATED WITHIN THREE YEARS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian instructed government agencies Tuesday to contain the spread of fire ants by the end of the year and have them completely eliminated from Taiwan within three years.

Speaking at a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Central Standing Committee meeting, President Chen, who doubles as DPP Chairman, pointed out that the invasion of fire ants into Taiwan not only threatens the island's ecology, but is also a nuisance for people.

Since the fire ants are new to Taiwan, most people are not familiar with their habits, the president said, adding that the Council of Agriculture and other government agencies must do more efforts to educate the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIGNING OF COOPERATION PACT WITH GUGGENHEIM POSTPONED TO LATE OCT.

TEXT.P: The signing of an initial agreement between the Taichung City Government and the New York-based Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation on cooperation in building a Guggenheim branch museum in the central Taiwan city will be postponed to late October, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Tuesday.
"The postponement was mainly meant to express our respect for the city council, " Hu said, adding that the postponement received the consent of the Guggenheim foundation.

According to a consensus reached during Hu's visit to the Guggenheim foundation Sept. 21, the two parties should sign an initial agreement before Oct. 12 and the Taichung City Government must pay a total of US$8 million in initial royalties, project management and architectural design fees before Oct. 29 as a guarantee that it will indeed carry out the cooperative project; otherwise, the foundation will forfeit its cooperative plan with Taiwan.
The city government was originally scheduled to sign the initial cooperation pact with the Guggenheim foundation Tuesday by fax.

"As the Taichung City Council is now in recess and will not open its new session until Oct. 18, we decided to postpone the signing to late this month so that the city council can screen and approve the project before the agreement is sealed," Hu explained.

The city council has been scheduled to screen the project Oct. 25-26. Once the city council formally approves the project, Hu said, the city govenrment will sign the initial cooperation accord with the Guggenheim foundation and pay UN$8 million in initial royalties, management and design fees immediately afterwards.
Hu further said preparations for the ambitious project will get underway after the initial cooperation pact is signed.
"We believe that the new museum will be able to open to the public in 2008 as originally scheduled," Hu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER, MOFA DENY REPORT LINKING MONEY TO CHAD FOR TIES

TEXT.P: Responding to a media report that the government has paid NT$350 million (US$10.3 million) to Chad in exchange for its continued diplomatic recognition, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that he has no knowledge of the matter and that he doubted the accuracy of the report.
Stressing that he does not have the slightest idea about any money for recognition, Yu said that media reports are not always accurate.

Yu made the remarks while answering questions from Legislator Li Yung-pin of the opposition People First Party, who cited a story in the China Times Express evening newspaper that Chad obtained NT$350 million (US$10.3 million) from the Republic of China government in exchange for its continued diplomatic recognition.
Chad is one of the 26 nations, predominantly in Africa and Latin America, that maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

According to the report, the African nation threatened to cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan in the middle of this year should it refuse to give the money to help it renew a set of power generating facilities. The report said that Taiwan eventually granted the money to Chad in the form of a "cooperation project."

Speaking on the same occasion, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao categorically denied the report and gave his assurance that relations between the two countries remain very good on the grounds that Chad Foreign Affairs Minister Nagoum Yamassourm led a delegation to Taiwan to take part in the Oct. 10 National Day celebrations.
Kau blasted the report's details, although he admitted that it is true that Taiwan has to extend economic aid to Chad quite often.

"If what the report said were true, I would step down from my post to assume political responsibility, " he said, and harshly criticized the newspaper of running the false report without first verifying the facts.

Foreign ministry spokesman Michel C. L. Lu told a news conference later the same day that renewing power generating facilities is surely one of the issues contained in bilateral joint cooperative ventures. But he called the report saying that Chad threatened to suspend diplomatic links with Taiwan to trade for the money is a far cry from the truth.
According to Lu, Taiwan-Chad ties are sound and stable and all sorts of cooperative plans are faring well, ranging from medical and agricultural to technical cooperation.

An oil exploration project between the Chad government and the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corporation, under negotiation since last year, has reaped initial progress after Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan San Chen and his Chad counterpart reached agreement days ago in Taipei.

As to a reporter's question that Beijing would meddle in the project, Lu said that the ROC Embassy in Chad is keeping a close watch on developments and he described the current situation as "so far, so good."

DOC.HEADLINE: CREATION AND INVENTION KEY TO TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC TRANSFORMATION: MOEA

TEXT.P: Creation and invention are keys to the success of Taiwan's economic transformation, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday.

Addressing the 2004 National Creation and Invention Awards ceremony, Ho said that the government has been actively promoting the country's economic transformation, from a manufacturing-based economy to a knowledge-based one.

The success of the transformation relies on whether the country has sufficient acumen for the job, the minister said, adding that the government has announced an increase in the country's expenditures in research and development to 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) by 2006 and has adopted incentives to encourage domestic and foreign enterprises to set up their R&D centers in Taiwan.
In addition, she went on, the government has also enhanced intellectual property protection by amending relevant laws and regulations and improving law enforcement techniques.
The government has pledged to reduce the ratio of commercial software piracy to less than 40 percent in the next year from this year's 43 percent, she noted.
What the government is doing is to create an environment friendly to creation and invention, which will lead the country to a new era amid the knowledge-based economy, the minister said.

Taiwan's ability for creation and invention is one of the world's best, Ho said, explaining that the number of patents obtained by its nationals in the United States during the period between 2000 and 2003 was forth-highest in the world, only behind the U.S., Japan and Germany.

A total of 61 companies and individuals were awarded by the government with a combined prize money of NT$13.75 million (US$405,000) at the ceremony for their excellent creative works and inventions, according to the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: 387 CANDIDATES REGISTER FOR DECEMBER LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS: CEC

TEXT.P: A total of 387 candidates officially registered to run in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, a spokesman for the Central Election Commission (CEC) reported Tuesday after the five-day legal requirement process ended earlier the same day.

The candidates will vie for 168 regional and eight aboriginal seats. The registered candidates will be screened by the CEC to be qualified to run and will then draw designation numbers Nov. 17 at local CEC committees across the country.

According to CEC statistics, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has recommended 92 candidates, followed by the prime opposition Kuomintang (KMT) with 74, and the People First Party (PFP) with 41. The tiny pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) fielded 30 and 26 hopefuls, respectively.

Citing survey results carried out by the DPP, a key party official forecast that the "pan-green camp" -- formed by the DPP and its political ally the TSU -- will be able to grab from 110 to 115 seats -- a turnaround from the last legislative elections in 2001.

Chung Jia-ping, DPP deputy secretary general, expressed his belief that the "pan-green camp" will beat the opposition "pan-blue alliance" and hold more than half of the seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan as a majority.

On the other hand, the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP also claimed that they will keep their majority in the legislature, as the two parties have agreed to cooperate based on a conservative quota system to ensure their maximum seats.
The NPSU is also very optimistic about its performance, predicting that the party will be able to pass the 5 percent threshold to win as many as 17 regional seats and up to three at-large seats.
The 225 seats will include 168 regional seats and eight aboriginal seats, as well as eight overseas Chinese seats and 41 at-large seats.
The overseas Chinese and at-large legislators will be produced based on a proportional representation of the ballots that each party grabs in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE PAYMENTS FOR IMPORTS HIT NEW RECORD

TEXT.P: Taiwan paid a total of US$16.98 billion in foreign exchange for imports in September, a new monthly record, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Central Bank of China (CBC).

Meanwhile, the tallies show, Taiwan earned US$17.63 billion in foreign exchange, the second-largest monthly record, from its exports in the same period, leaving the country a surplus of US$642 million.

During the first nine months of this year, Taiwan earned a total of US$147.11 billion in foreign exchange from its exports and spent US$136.52 billion for imports, up 26.5 percent and 31.5 percent year-on-year, respectively.
CBC officials attributed the country's swelling foreign trade to the rapid economic recovery both domestically and internationally.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 13, or the 30th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
A.D. 54: Claudius I, 64, Roman emperor and historian, dies after supposedly consuming poisoned mushrooms dished up by his fourth wife, his niece Agrippina. Shortly before his death, Claudius had agreed to acknowledge Nero, Agrippina's son from a former marriage, as his heir instead of his natural son, Britannicus.
1792: U.S. President George Washington lays the foundation stone of the White House.
1812: British forces under Sir Isaac Brock defeat the Americans at the battle of Queenston Heights, helping to put an end to the U.S. attempt to invade Canada.
1884: Greenwich, England, is adopted as the universal meridian from which standard times throughout the world are calculated.
1913: Representatives from China, Britain and Tibet attend a meeting held in Simla, India, to discuss various problems concerning Tibet.
1923: Ankara becomes the capital of Turkey.
1925: Margaret Thatcher, British Conservative politician and prime minister from 1979 to 1990, is born. Her administration was marked by anti-inflationary measures, a brief war in the Falkland Islands (1982), and the passage of a poll tax.
1939: Adolf Hitler tries without success to persuade U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt to mediate peace between Germany, France and Britain.
1943: Italy declares war on Germany, its former Axis partner.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Canton.
1960: The Institute of History and Philology of the Academia Sinica begins excavations at dwellings of the Yin people in Anyang County, Hunan Province, once the capital of the dynasty before 1200 B.C.
1964: Three Soviet cosmonauts operating Voshkod, the world's first multi-seat spacecraft, land safely after a 24-hour journey.
1968: Liu Shao-chi, state chairman of Communist China, is purged at the 12th Plenum of the 8th Chinese Communist Party Central Committee held in Beijing.
1970: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severance of diplomatic relations with Canada.
1974: U.S. Senator Hiram Leong Fong of Hawaii arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1980: President Pieter W. Botha of South Africa is presented with the Key to the City of Taipei by Mayor Lee Teng-hui upon arrival for a state visit.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui presents a Key to Taipei to Mayor Leon Amon of the Ivory Coast's Dimbokro City.
1988: The Shroud of Turin, for centuries regarded as the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, is shown by carbon-dating tests to date from between 1260 and 1390 in the Middle Ages, a period rife with forgeries.
1993: The United Nations Security Council decides to resume an oil-and-arms embargo against Haiti after Haitian military leaders fail to follow an agreement to allow President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to office and restore a democratic government.
1995: Joseph Rotblat, the nuclear physicist who devoted his life to trying to ban the bomb he helped create, wins the 1995 Nobel Peace Prize.
1995: France rejects appeals to abandon nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
1998: Daniel Chee Tsui, professor at Princeton University and a member of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, becomes one of the three co-winners of the 1998 Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Jordanian Royal Air Force transport plane airlifts 14,600 kilograms of relief goods to Taipei to help surviving victims of the devastating earthquake that rocked Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian hails the decision to grant the 2000 Nobel Prize in literature to self-exiled mainland Chinese writer Gao Xingjian, saying that the honor marks Gao's greatest achievement.
2001: The rampancy of counterfeit bank notes in circulation in Taiwan prompts the Central Bank of China (CBC) to add two items on its Web site's home page to teach the public the different ways to distinguish fake bills from real ones.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is plain, and yet not unattractive; it is simple, and yet full of grace; it is easy, and yet methodical."

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG WELCOMES NEW TAIWAN REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong government welcomes Pao Cheng-kang, new Taiwan representative to Hong Kong, to assume his post, a spokesman for the Constitutional Affairs Bureau (CAB) said Wednesday.
The spokesman said the Hong Kong government has consistently adopted a positive attitude toward Pao's application for a working visa.
"We welcome Pao to assume his post as managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong," the spokesman said.
Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong is designated as Chung Hwa Travel Service because Hong Kong doesn't have official ties with Taiwan due to Beijing's "one China" principle.

Asked whether CAB Director Stephen Lam would meet Pao after Pao took office, the spokesman said the CAB has traditionally maintained effective communication channels with the Chung Hwa Travel Service.

"Lam will meet with Pao so long as it is necessary in handling bilateral affairs," the spokesman said, adding that in the past, Lam had met with Pao's predecessor, Chang Liang-jen, from time to time to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.
Taiwan authorities confirmed Tuesday that Pao has received a working visa from Hong Kong and will soon travel to Hong Kong to assume the post left vacant by Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-GERMAN PRESIDENT CALLS FOR PEACE ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Walter Scheel, who served as president of the former West Germany, called Tuesday for both sides of the Taiwan Strait not to resort to force under any circumstances in dealing with cross-strait differences.

Scheel, in a speech at the Republic of China National Day cocktail party held in Berlin, quoted ROC President Chen Shui-bian as saying in his National Day speech that cross-strait differences can only be solved through peace.

The 85-year-old Scheel was the highest-ranking former or incumbent German official to attend the ROC National Day celebrations in Berlin. He was the president of West Germany between 1974-1979. A Free Democratic Party stalwart, Scheel served as West German foreign minister prior to becoming president.
In his speech, Scheel said that Taiwan's democratization and the freedom that its people enjoy are facts that deserve the respect of the international community.
Annual two-way trade between Taiwan and Germany has reached some 1 billion euros, making Taiwan one of Germany's major trade partners in Asia, Scheel noted.

He also expressed his appreciation to Taiwan's National Palace Museum for having arranged for its flagship collections, known as "the treasures of the Chinese emperors, " to be exhibited in Germany, allowing the German people to savor the magnificent Chinese culture without having to travel to China.
Scheel said he hopes that Taiwan and Germany will enhance their bilateral cultural exchanges in the future.
Meanwhile, Wolfgang Lueder, chairman of the German China Association, praised Taiwan and its people in his speech to the cocktail party.

Citing the story of a Taiwanese farmer who planted Chinese mushrooms in a Berlin suburb and went on to market his produce throughout Europe, Lueder said that Taiwan's people have been important investors in Germany beyond the high-tech field.

Lueder said that Taiwan -- with its economic strength and high level of human rights -- would be worthy of being invited by German politicians to join the European Union if the island were located in the Mediterranean Sea. His remarks received loud applause from those attending the cocktail party.

The German China Association, established in Germany 47 years ago, has been an influential private organization devoted to relations between the German and Chinese people. It has maintained very close interactions with Taiwan since its inception.
Currently, the association has about 200 members, most of whom are influential people from Germany's political, economic and cultural circles.

More than 20 German government officials, Bundestag members and scholars, as well as some 600 Taiwanese and Chinese people attended the cocktail party, which was sponsored by the Taipei Representative Office in Berlin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL PATIENTLY WAIT FOR GOODWILL RESPONSE FROM BEIJING: MAC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government will patiently wait for a goodwill response from mainland China to its peace overture, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Wednesday.
Chiu made the remarks after Beijing sternly responded to President Chen Shui-bian's latest olive branch extended in his ROC Double Ten National Day speech.
"Our goodwill and stance toward Beijing will not change. We are willing to wait patiently for Beijing to weigh and understand our appeals," Chiu said.

President Chen proposed in his Oct. 10 address that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways that are "not necessarily perfect, but acceptable" in preparation for a step forward in the resumption of long-stalled cross-strait dialogue and consultations.

Referring to himself by his nickname 'A-bian, ' Chen further said that as any conflict could cause irreparable damage to both sides, Taiwan and mainland China should seriously consider practical steps toward "arms control."
"Therefore A-bian proposes that both sides should seriously consider the issue of arms control and take concrete actions to reduce tension and military threats across the Taiwan Strait."

For the sake of maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, Chiu said, Beijing should resume talks with Taiwan on issues that conform with the common desires and interests of the people on both sides in order to jointly create win-win prospects.

In mainland China's first official response to President Chen's olive branch, Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, told a news conference in Beijing Wednesday that Beijing's stance remains unchanged and warned that Chen risked "great catastrophe" by pushing for independence.

"Chen Shui-bian claimed that he intends to ease tensions and confrontation across the Taiwan Strait, but he has obstinately stuck to his separatist stance of 'one country on each side' of the strait," Zhang said.

"If Chen Shui-bian remains bent on sticking to his splittist and Taiwan independence activities, he will never bring peace and prosperity to the Taiwan compatriots, but will only bring great catastrophe," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S 'BACKPEDALING' ON CROSS-STRAIT LINKS REGRETTABLE: DPP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Legislative Yuan said Wednesday it regrets that mainland China has linked direct cross-strait transportation links to the "one China" issue, calling it "backpedaling" on Beijing's part.

The DPP caucus was responding to a rejection by Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for the mainland's Taiwan Affairs Office, of President Chen Shui-bian's call in his Double Ten National Day speech for early peace talks so as to seek progress in direct cross-strait links.

Zhang said earlier in the day that cross-strait transportation links must be conducted based on the premise of "internal affairs" and the principles of mutual benefits and reciprocity, adding that the opening of cross-strait links will not depend on proposing "two-way chartered flight service."

DPP Legislator Chang Hsueh-shun said Zhang's remarks represented a backpedaling on mainland China's part, noting that Beijing had earlier defined cross-strait transportation links as a "special route" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, which Chang noted is similar to President Chen's proposal in his National Day speech.

Chang expressed the hope that cross-strait economic and political issues could be separated and that the two sides could begin direct cross-strait transportation links consultations by focusing on the economic aspect of the issue.

Lee Chun-yi, DPP whip in the Legislative Yuan, said Zhang was harping the same old tune by linking cross-strait links to the "one China" issue, which Lee called "inappropriate" and a hampering of the common wish of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait for the opening of such transportation links.

Lee said that President Chen hopes to establish direct cross-strait links through the implementation of direct charter flights and through shelving disputes on sovereignty, adding that it is regrettable that Beijing has defined the links as an "internal affair."

DOC.HEADLINE: NHRI FORMS ALLIANCE WITH U.S. PHARMACEUTICALS TO DEVELOP CANCER DRUGS

TEXT.P: The National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) Wednesday established a strategic alliance with U.S.-based Bridge Pharmaceuticals on the research and development of cancer medicines.
The first cooperation project between the two sides will be the clinical development in Taiwan of two new cancer medicines, SR-13668 and SR-16158, NHRI officials said.
The two medicines have been tested on animals in the United States and have been shown to be effective in inhibiting the growth of cancer cells, the officials said.
The first phase of clinical trials on humans is expected to start next year in Taiwan, they said.

The SR-13668 is for oral consumption and can curb the AKT retroviral oncogene protein, which is extremely active in patients with malignant tumors, including breast cancer, lung cancer, prostate cancer, liver cancer, ovary cancer and colon cancer, according to the NHRI.
The SR-16158, meanwhile, is intended for the treatment of breast cancer.

Jacqueline Whang-Peng, director of the NHRI's Division of Cancer Research, said that compared with existing cancer medicines, the two drugs have produced better therapeutic results and less side effects.
Compared with hormonal drugs, SR-16158 is less likely to trigger cardiovascular disease in patients, Whang-Peng said.
She said the two new medicines will be available on the market three years from now at the earliest if the clinical trials proceed smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL TV STAR DECIDES AGAINST BEING LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Local TV variety show host Jacky Wu (Wu Tsung-hsien) announced Tuesday that he has decided against being a legislator-at-large candidate in the upcoming legislative elections, citing "personal reasons" for his decision.
Wu -- whom the newly-formed Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) announced last Friday would run under the NPSU banner -- declared in Beijing that he will not get involved in politics.

Wu said that due to his mother's strong opposition, he has decided against being a candidate. He denied that he is an opportunist who has eaten his own words as some in the media have said, claiming that they had interpreted his words out of context.

Responding to Wu's change of heart, NPSU Secretary-General Chen Jung-chieh said Wednesday that his party fully understands the awkward position Wu has been placed in following the earlier disclosure of his intentions to be a candidate.
Chen said that he regrets the fact that Wu, who enjoys a high level of popularity in Taiwan, cannot join the NPSU as a legislative candidate, but added that his party respects Wu's decision.

According to Chen, the NPSU decided Tuesday to have Wu listed as an NPSU candidate for a legislator-at-large seat after Wu and the NPSU leadership reached a certain understanding last week that Wu would represent the NPSU in the legislative elections slated for Dec. 11.
Legislator Tsai Hao, who is the vice chairman of the NPSU, also said last Friday that Wu would formally announce his election bid at a press conference in Taipei Oct. 11.

Wu changed his mind due to considerations of his entertainment career, Chen said, adding that Wu turned his back to the NPSU after some "upstairs" individuals at a television station warned that Wu's "stage would be dismantled" if he decided to take part in politics.
Wu, who has been one of the hottest targets of local paparazzi because of his colorful private life, has reportedly amassed a fortune over the years in his career as an entertainer and a businessman.
Wu had said that if he were a lawmaker, one of the areas he would like to straighten up is the local media.
In the legislative elections, all 225 seats will be up for grabs, including 168 regional legislative seats, eight Aboriginal seats, eight overseas Chinese seats and 41 at-large seats.

The parties fielding candidates are the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, its ally the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, the Kuomintang, and the People First Party, as well as the newly established Non-Partisan Solidarity Union. Another newly formed group, the Taiwan Democracy School, is also poised to recommend a number of candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Oct. 13 C(NA) The Moscow Times: Fears of Revenge at End of 40 Days.
As 40 days of mourning end Wednesday, relatives of the hundreds of people killed in the Beslan school massacre are debating whether to seek revenge -- and reopen a festering dispute between the Ossetians and the Ingush.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE DELEGATION ARRIVES IN SHANGHAI
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By M. L. Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A large trade delegation comprised of Taiwan business leaders arrived in Shanghai in low profile Wednesday.

The 60-odd delegation is the first business group to visit mainland China following President Chen Shui-bian's Double Ten National Day speech in which he called for peace talks to ease cross-strait tensions.
Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. Chairman Jeffrey Koo, who is heading the delegation, came directly from Tokyo to Shanghai via a special plane to join the other members from Taipei.
The delegation will attend a banquet given in its honor by the Shanghai municipal government, with Shanghai Deputy Mayor Feng Guoqin and Deputy Secretary Luo Siqian attending, Wednesday night.
Shanghai Mayor Chen Liangyu will meet Thursday with the delegation, whose main purpose will be to visit Shanghai automobile and electronics groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER TO DEBATE OPPOSITION REPS IN CONSTITUTIONAL COURT

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said Wednesday he will debate opposition representatives on behalf of the government in the upcoming constitutional court hearings on the dispute surrounding the formation of the opposition-backed "truth investigation commission."
Chen said the other government debater at the hearings set for Oct. 27 and 29 will be Lin Huei-huang, director of the Judges and Prosecutors Training Institute.
Chen said he will make the government's case on the dispute from the perspective of the Constitution and public law.

The Executive Yuan considers the commission, set up to probe the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, unconstitutional and has had the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) request a constitutional interpretation from the Council of Grand Justices.
The DPP has also asked the Grand Justices to order a temporary injunction to freeze the operations of the commission before the interpretation is released.
A hearing will be held Thursday to let both sides present their respective arguments on the petition.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Pensions crisis is looming for 12 million workers.
More than 12 million people are not saving enough for old age and will see their pension income slashed by 30 percent three decades from now unless they pay more tax, save more or accept a later retirement age.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 16.49 points to close at 5,963.07.

The bourse opened at 5,993.94 and fluctuated between 6,005.99 and 5,957.47 during the day's trading. A total of 3.47 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.64 billion (US$ 2.17 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up at 1.6 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues and foodstuff issues both moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.9 percent, textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.5 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 324 to 312, with 171 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIJACKED SUAO FISHING BOAT TO RETURN TO TAIWAN THURSDAY

TEXT.P: A Suao-based fishing boat which was hijacked and taken to mainland China Oct. 9 has managed to escape and will return to Taiwan Thursday, the Suao Fishermen's Radio reported Wednesday.

Skipper Hung Chi-chen and an engineer -- the only two Taiwanese crew members of the 42.38-ton "Chin Lung Yu" -- are scheduled to arrive in Suao, eastern Taiwan, around 3 a.m. Thursday, from Shacheng port, Fujian Province, after a four-day ordeal on the seas.

The "Chin Lung Yu" was hijacked by six mainland Chinese deckhands working aboard the vessel on the night of Oct. 9 after it sought temporary shelter on the coast of Yaeyama Island of Japan's Okinawa Prefecture due to Typhoon Ma-on.

The six mainlanders subdued Hung and the engineer before robbing them of NT$3,000 in cash and making away with more than 7,000 kilograms of shark catch and 12,000 liters of gasoline, according to the fishermen's radio.
Neither Hung nor the engineer were hurt by the mainland crew members, the radio broadcasters said.
The "Chin Lung Yu, " which sailed from Shacheng port at around 1: 20 a.m. Wednesday, is scheduled to arrive in Suao Thursday morning, according to the radio report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CPI GREW MILDLY BY 1.1 PERCENT OVER PAST DECADE: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) increased by 1.1 percent per year on average during the 1994-2003 period, lower than the 2.4 percent seen in the United States and the 3.8 percent in South Korea, according to government statistics.

The newest tallies released Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that Taiwan's CPI increased by between 3 percent and 4 percent each year in the first half of the 1990s. A DGBAS official said this was the result of a severe labor shortage and increases in workers' wages.

The rate of increase in Taiwan's CPI began to slow in the second half of the 1990s due to economic globalization, output expansion and the influx of cheap products made in mainland China into the world market, the official pointed out. He added that CPI increases fell further starting in 2001 because of drops in product prices in the home market amid fierce competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.012 to close at NT$33.890.
A total of US$495 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.855 and hit a high of NT$33.900.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING FOCUSES MORE ON ECONOMY THAN ON TAIWAN: EX-U.S. AMBASSADOR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former U.S. ambassador to China James Lilley has noticed that Beijing is now paying more attention to economic issues than on cross-strait affairs, according to Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen Tuesday.
Yao has met Lilley during his just-concluded trip to Washington, D.C.
Before his departure, Yao told reporters that Lilley had mentioned in the meeting his recent visit to mainland China, at the invitation of the Communist Party School.
Lilley said he felt an obvious difference in the attitudes of Beijing officials and academics on the mainland, namely that they are focusing their attention on the economy, according to Yao.
The officials and academics were reluctant to make any response even if Lilley raised an issue concerning Taiwan deliberately, Yao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACCESS TO VENTURE CAPITAL 4TH EASIEST IN THE WORLD: IMD

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked fourth in the world in terms of availability of venture capital for business development, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) quoted the International Institute of Management Development (IMD) Wednesday as reporting.

With a score of 6.76 in terms of venture capital easily available for business development in a criterion of the Swiss IMD for its World Competitiveness Yearbook 2004, Taiwan was behind the United States (7.95) , Hong Kong (7.06) and Finland (6.8), CEPD officials said.
Taiwan was the second-best in this ranking in all Asian countries behind only Hong Kong, the officials added.

According to CEPD tallies, there were a total of 241 venture capital companies in Taiwan as of 2003, operating 8,719 venture capital service projects which involved some NT$161.9 billion (US$4.77 billion).

Newly contracted venture capital in 2003 alone totaled NT$16.54 billion, constituting 0.17 percent of the island's gross domestic product (GDP) that year, marking a record high in the most recent three years, CEPD officials said.

Most of the venture capital was channeled into high technology industries, with semiconductor manufacturing taking the lion's share, followed by optoelectronics, electronics, information technology and telecommunications industries, in that order, the official said.

Nevertheless, biotechnology and software development industry took only an alarming low percentage of 7.3 percent and 1.9 percent, respectively, of the total venture capital granted in 2003, they noted.

They added that biotechnology and software development industry are currently two up-and-coming star industries in industrially-advanced countries and may serve as leading indices for countries' competitiveness in the world in the near future.
The IMD surveyed a total of 60 countries and regional economies for its World Competitiveness Yearbook 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW POSSIBILITY FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: LEGISLATURE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that the possibility of resuming cross-Taiwan Strait talks has been reduced considerably given China's reaction toward President Chen Shui-bian's National Day address.

In his Oct. 10 speech, President Chen Shui-bian proposed that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways in preparation for a step forward for the resumption of long-stalled cross-strait dialogues, and called for talks on direct "three-links" between Taiwan and mainland China as soon as possible.

The Chinese government made its official and harsh response to Chen's Oct. 10 speech Wednesday, with Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, saying that "Chen Shui-bian claimed that he intends to ease tension and confrontation across the Taiwan Strait, but he has obstinately stuck to his separatist stance of 'one country on each side' of the Strait."
Chen's words completely promote Taiwan independence, and they are again a challenge to peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, Zhang added.
Wang opined that Beijing's reaction reflected its dissatisfaction with Chen's address, which means that the possibility of resuming cross-strait talks is slim.

Meanwhile, Chen Min-tong, a former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, noted that Chen's proposal on convenient and efficient ways to facilitate cross-strait charter flights for passengers and cargo has gained approval from the international community, including the United States, Japan and Singapore.
However, in Beijing's reaction, it only reaffirmed the "one China" policy, but avoided the substantial issue of the charter flights proposal.

He stressed that Chen has presented many creative proposals on cross-strait exchanges, expressing hope that the Chinese government consider the international situation and the welfare of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait so that cross-strait ties can be developed benignly.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA WELCOMES U.S. GROUP'S RECOGNITION OF TAIWAN'S IPR EFFORTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday it welcomes the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council's public suggestion that Taiwan be removed from the U.S. government's Special 301 "priority watch" list for intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.

The U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, a Washington-based private organization that groups American companies with interests in Taiwan, publicly urged the U.S. government to take Taiwan off its Special 301 "priority watch" list in recognition of Taiwan's progress in IPR protection and crackdowns on commercial piracy.

"We welcome the U.S. organization's recognition of our achievements in IPR protection," an official with the MOEA's Intellectual Property Office said, adding that the organization's suggestion will definitely have a positive effect on having Taiwan removed from the U.S. "priority watch" list or downgraded to the less serious "watch" list.

The official stressed that Taiwan's strenuous efforts to improve IPR protection is primarily aimed at enhancing its international competitiveness, not at having its name taken off the U.S. IPR watch list.

Thanks to concerted efforts of ruling and opposition parties, the official said, Taiwan has completed IPR-related legal reforms, including the institutionalization of a police agency responsible for IPR protection and commercial piracy crackdown, as well as amendments to the Copyrights Law to better protect copyrights.
Since the revised Copyright Law was implemented in 2003, the official said, Taiwan has scored remarkable achievements in IPR protection.

Noting that Taiwan has twice been left off the top-10 list of sources of pirated products seized by U.S. customs authorities, the official said the absence indicates that Taiwan's IPR enforcement has improved in the past two years and its crackdown on commercial piracy has paid off.

Quoting tallies compiled by the National Police Administration, the official said the IPR police uncovered 2,017 commercial piracy cases in 2003, in which NT$6.6 billion worth of counterfeit goods were seized. In the first nine months of this year, 953 cases involving IPR infringements and trademark law violations were uncovered, with NT$7.73 billion worth of goods seized. The official attributed the rise in the amount mainly to increased inflow of counterfeit goods.

Moreover, the police conducted 1,088 spot checks on the island's 84 optical disc manufacturing firms in 2003 and 544 inspections in the first half of this year, with 200 inspections made at night. The frequent spot checks have deterred optical disc firms from producing pirated products, the official said.

According to the results of a recent survey released by the Business Software Association, Taiwan's software piracy rate was 43 percent, far lower than the average rate of 53 percent in Asia-Pacific countries. Taiwan's piracy rate was only higher than Japan's, the official said, adding that the government has set the goal of lowering the software piracy rate to 40 percent in 2005.

Stressing that strengthening IPR protection is the government's policy goal, the official said, the concerted efforts of the public and private sectors in the past two years have paid off and this achievement will contribute to the upgrading of Taiwan's international competitiveness and image.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S REACTION TO CHEN SPEECH PREDICTABLE BUT OF NO HELP: CABINET

TEXT.P: Mainland China's negative response to President Chen Shui-bian's Double Ten National Day address was expected, but Beijing's stern words won't help cross-strait differences, a Cabinet spokesman said Wednesday.

Chen Chi-mai was responding to remarks by Zhang Mingqing, a spokesman of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, earlier in the day in which he again reiterated the "one China" principle for cross-strait talks, and warned of "great catastrophe" if President Chen continues to push for Taiwan independence.

Noting that Beijing has consistently adopted a negative attitude toward Taiwan's overtures, Chen Chi-mai said Beijing's response was expected, although "a hard mind can't see things in the right perspective, and stern faces and harsh words also won't help overcome differences."

He urged Beijing to respond to the olive branch extended by President Chen, saying that there is goodwill as well as positive policies in his National Day speech, such as the promises in his 2004 inaugural speech will remain unchanged, the establishment of "code of conduct" between the two sides of the Strait, as well as cross-strait charter flights for passengers and cargo.

On Taiwan's proposal of cross-strait charter flight services for passengers and cargo as a way to establish direct links, Zhang said the three principles governing such links are that they are internal affairs, utilize direct two-way charter flights, and create mutual benefits and reciprocity. Zhang emphasized the "internal affairs" part the most.
Zhang also said that charter flight services for Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland during the 2003 Chinese New Year holidays were not covered by these principles and were a "special case."

On this, Chen Chi-mai said these charter flight services, though only one-way and rerouted via third places such as Hong Kong and Macau when it was inaugurated on a trial basis in 2003 was a "valuable experience."

Zhang's premise for direct cross-strait links shouldn't become a hindrance to cross-strait charter flight services between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait during Chinese New Year in the future, Chen said.

Chen said that Beijing has long promoted its three principles before 2003, but it and Taiwan managed to put aside their differences, and addressed pragmatically the needs of Taiwan businessmen in the mainland at that time.
China knew clearly the procedure of charter flights during Chinese New Year, and as long as Taiwan carriers make related applications, the flights should be feasible, Chen said.
Chen noted that the president urged in his address that both sides should come back to the long-stalled negotiation table based on the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong.

The significance of the 1992 meeting is to shelve disputes on sovereignty and engage in pragmatic exchanges, Chen Chi-mai said, expressing the hope that both sides can resume talks as early as possible on issues that have been discussed or have yet to be discussed.

Chen urged Beijing to see the goodwill in President Chen's speech and seize the opportunity so that both sides can conduct talks on matters such as two-way charter flights for passengers and cargo early.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES CHINA TO RESPOND POSITIVELY TO PRESIDENT'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities should properly interpret President Chen Shui-bian's constructive remarks on cross-strait relations and respond to them positively, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Wednesday.

Chiu was reacting to criticism made earlier in the day by Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman Zhang Mingqing, who said it was pointless for President Chen to make the remarks when "they are based on the premise of separatism."
In his National Day address on Sunday, Chen called for the resumption of cross-strait dialogue based on the 1992 talks held by representatives of both sides in Hong Kong.

Chen also proposed that both sides establish a "code of conduct" to maintain peace and start negotiating on the launch of direct passenger and cargo charter flight services to pave the way for direct cross-strait air and shipping links.

However, Zhang accused Chen of "faking temperance but actually meaning independence for Taiwan, " saying Chen is responsible for cross-strait tensions for insisting there is "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" and making vicious attack at the mainland constantly.
In a statement, the MAC said President Chen's proposals have fully exhibited Taiwan's proaction, goodwill and integrity.

Taipei and Beijing share a responsibility to seek a peaceful resolution to cross-strait disputes and should look for consensus through dialogue on ways to maintain long-lasting peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, according to the statement.
The MAC hopes that Beijing authorities will see the olive branch extended by Taiwan from an innovative perspective and work together with Taiwan for cross-strait peace, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR PATIENCE TOWARD DEVELOPMENT OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he was not surprised by mainland China's tirade against his Oct. 10 National Day speech on reducing tension and safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait.

"Beijing's tirade was expected, but we should not be daunted by the arduousness of the task of forging cross-strait rapprochement. We should be patient toward the development of cross-strait relations, " Chen said after undergoing an annual routine physical at National Taiwan University Hospital.
As the nation's leader, Chen told the media that he is obligated to defend national sovereignty, dignity and security as well as seek the greatest possible benefits for the people.

"While working to boost popular wellbeing, I must also endeavor to ease cross-strait tension and avert unnecessary confrontation. It's an onerous mission. I must have wisdom and good health to accomplish this duty, " Chen said, adding that the just-concluded physical showed him to be in good health.
Chen also revealed that U.S. authorities have expressed warm welcome and fervent support in private for his National Day speech regarding cross-strait relations.

"U.S. authorities had also told me that Beijing would definitely issue a sternly worded statement against my peace appeals. They advised me to remain patient in handling cross-strait affairs. They also urged our government and people to be patient toward the development of cross-strait ties, " Chen said. "You can take it easy. Nothing will happen. Cross-strait ties will remain peaceful."

President Chen proposed in his National Day address that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways that are "not necessarily perfect, but acceptable" in preparation for a step forward in the resumption of long-stalled cross-strait dialogue and consultations.

Referring to himself by his nickname 'A-bian, ' Chen further said that as any conflict would cause irreparable damage to both sides, Taiwan and mainland China should seriously consider practical steps toward "arms control."
"Therefore A-bian proposes that both sides should seriously consider the issue of arms control and take concrete actions to reduce tension and military threats across the Taiwan Strait."

For the sake of maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, Chiu said, Beijing should resume talks with Taiwan on issues that conform with the common desires and interests of the people on both sides in order to jointly create win-win prospects.

In mainland China's first official response to President Chen's Oct. 19 address, Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, told a news conference in Beijing Wednesday that Beijing's stance remains unchanged and warned that Chen risked "great catastrophe" by pushing for independence.

"Chen Shui-bian claimed that he intends to ease tensions and confrontation across the Taiwan Strait, but he has obstinately stuck to his separatist stance of 'one country on each side' of the Strait," Zhang said.

"If Chen Shui-bian remains bent on sticking to his splittist and Taiwan independence activities, he will never bring peace and prosperity to the Taiwan compatriots, but will only bring great catastrophe," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Tightening race increases stakes of final debate.
U.S. President Bush and Senator John Kerry meet in their final presidential debate on Wednesday night after two encounters that polls suggest weakened Bush and fortified Kerry, leaving some Republicans concerned that 20 days of the contest would be more competitive than they had expected. Republicans who had been confident of victory before the debates said they were uneasy as Bush returns to a format - 90 minutes of questions from one moderator - that has seemed to play to the strength of Kerry, a 20-year senator and former prosecutor.
Wall Street Journal: Tax windfall may not boost hiring despite claims.
Big companies in the U.S. long lobbied for a tax cut on their overseas profit as a way to spur job growth. But now that it has been granted, much of the windfall won't go toward hiring but for such uses as strengthening balance sheets, buying back shares and making acquisitions. The one-year break, included in a sweepin g tax bill that cleared the Senate and went to the president this week, will allow hundreds of billions of dollars in overseas profit to be brought home by dozens of U.S. companies at a steeply reduced tax rate. By some estimates, U.S. companies have parked as much as US$500 billion in profit abroad to avoid taxes back home.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO PUT ASIDE CROSS-STRAIT DIFFERENCES FOR EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun urged mainland Chinese leaders Wednesday to put aside cross-strait difference for pragmatic consultations between the two sides.
The premier was responding to the negative response of Beijing toward President Chen Shui-bian's Double Ten National Day address in which Chen called for cross-strait negotiations.

The premier said President Chen has extended an olive branch in the utmost sincerity in his speech, but it is a misfortune that Beijing has stuck to its "one China" ideology, and couldn't see the goodwill.
Yu expressed the hope that the fourth generation of Beijing leaders can have sufficient wisdom to shake off its iron-clad "one China "ideology.
He urged Beijing to seize the opportunity and base engagement on the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to put aside differences and begin pragmatic consultations.

Zhang Mingqing, a spokesman for China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said earlier Wednesday that Beijing's stance remains unchanged and warned that Chen risked "great catastrophe" by pushing for independence.

"Chen Shui-bian claimed that he intends to ease tension and confrontation across the Taiwan Strait, but he has obstinately stuck to his separatist stance of 'one country on each side' of the Strait," Zhang said.

"If Chen Shui-bian remains bent on sticking to his splittist and Taiwan independence activities, he will never bring peace and prosperity to the Taiwan compatriots, but will only bring about catastrophe," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINLOCH ANDERSON LICENSES BRAND TO FOUR TAIWAN FIRMS

TEXT.P: British clothing manufacturers and suppliers Kinloch Anderson Wednesday licensed its brand to four Taiwanese corporations specializing in umbrellas, stationery, leather shoes and whiskey products.
The licensing agreements were signed by Douglas Kinloch Anderson, executive chairman of the Scottish firm, with leaders of the four companies in Taipei.

The agreements were brokered by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) under a project for the establishment of strategic alliances between Taiwanese companies and noted international brands.

TAITRA Deputy Secretary-General Lee Tsai-jen called the partnership a "win-win" situation, saying it will help the Taiwanese companies enter the international market and help Kinloch Anderson expand its business landscape.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN REPRESENTATIVE TO HONG KONG TO ASSUME TO POST OCT. 18

TEXT.P: New Taiwan representative to Hong Kong Pao Cheng-kang will leave for the former British colony Oct. 18 to assume his post, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said Wednesday.
The officials made the announcement after a spokesman for the Hong Kong government said that the special administrative region's authorities welcome Pao to assume his post.

"We welcome Pao to assume his post as managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong, " the spokesman said, adding that the Hong Kong government has consistently adopted a positive attitude toward Pao's application for a working visa.
Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong is designated as Chung Hwa Travel Service because Hong Kong doesn't have official ties with Taiwan due to Beijing's "one China" principle.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOMINATIONS FOR DOCUMENTARY FILM TAIWAN AWARD RELEASED

TEXT.P: Organizers of the 2004 Taiwan International Documentary Festival (2004 TIDF) announced Wednesday that 20 films out of 142 were nominated for a Taiwan Award.
Officials of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CFCA) , which is sponsoring the festival, said the Taiwan Award is open to local directors with work focusing on Taiwan.
Winners will be announced Oct. 17, with first prize of NT$200,000.
The 20 films nominated will be displayed in the festival to be held Dec. 11-17 in Taipei. The festival will be organized by the Chinese Taipei Film Archive. ( Nick Huang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROUTINE PHYSICAL SHOWS PRESIDENT CHEN IN GOOD HEALTH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he is in good health and will be able to safeguard Taiwan over the next four years.
Chen made the remarks after a routine physical at National Taiwan University Hospital.

Thanks to his regular exercise, Chen said his fatty "toro-shape" belly already disappeared and that he has recovered from the gunshot wound he sustained in the March 19 election-eve shooting on the campaign trail in the southern city of Tainan. A bullet grazed his abdomen in the incident. A videotape taken by the Presidential Office on the whole process of Chen's health examination showed a scar on Chen's abdomen.

Chen won re-election by a slim margin a day after the shooting. His challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, insinuated that the shooting might have been staged to help Chen win sympathy votes. Without offering any evidence to back his allegations, Lien has filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory. The Taiwan High Court has yet to mete out its judgments on the two lawsuits aimed at invalidating Chen's re-election victory and even the entire presidential election so that a new one can be held.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU SUGGESTS PUTTING ALL ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS ON ONE ISLET

TEXT.P: An ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party suggested Wednesday that the government choose one islet off the outlying island of Kinmen to set up a detention center for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants.

The caucus of the Taiwan Solitary Union (TSU) made the suggestion amid reports that the military will soon turn over the administration of six islets -- namely Tatan, Ertan, Tungting, Peiting, Shihyu and Menghuyu -- to the Kinmen County Government to be opened for tourism.

The TSU, in a press conference to highlight the situation that Taiwan has become a haven for illegal mainland immigrants, said that one of the six islets, which lies very close to mainland China, should be chosen to set up the detention center.

Chen Chien-ming, TSU convener, said that illegal mainland Chinese immigrants get easy money working in Taiwan, and even if they are arrested, the period for repatriation could be six months during which they get treatment for venereal disease and cancer, and have babies delivered, all without paying medical insurance fees.
Their treatment is better than those behind bars in prison, he claimed.

Chen suggested that all the illegal Chinese immigrants could be put in the detention center on the islet off Kinmen, and they could return to the mainland based on the "mini three-links" model by paying themselves, or mainland Chinese fishing boats could be allowed to come to the islet to pick them up.
Direct postal, trade and transportation links, or commonly known as "mini three-links," were established between Kinmen and Matsu and Fujian province in coastal mainland in January 2001.

Chen also suggested that the government confiscate all the money the illegal mainlanders earned in Taiwan, impose steep fines for the smuggling rings, and raise the cash award for police nabbing the illegal Chinese immigrants so as to stem the flow of the immigrants.
The TSU also unveiled statistics compiled by the National Police Administration to show that between 1987 and 2003, they had nabbed more than 43,600 illegal Chinese immigrants.

There were more than 3,400 illegal Chinese immigrants in a detention center in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan last year, and the government has to appropriate NT$4.02 million (US$118,500), averaging NT$21,000 per illegal mainlander, which the TSU said is a "serious drain on Taiwan taxpayers."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE URGED TO CURB RECORD ENERGY PRICES

TEXT.P: Government officials are worried about soaring oil and fuel coal prices and economists urged the government to swiftly tackle the issue to minimize the impact on the country's economic activities and the people's livelihood.

Although the impact is expected to be less significant than the one in the 1970s, experts said that high energy prices will unavoidably add production costs to manufacturers and drag down the country's economic growth.

They suggested that the government work out countermeasures as soon as possible and give the public and industries an orientation to deal with the situation in the face of a looming wave of hikes in water rates, electricity fees, ticket fares, construction materials and petrochemical products.

The price of oil pierced through the US$54 per barrel level a day earlier in electronic trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a 21-year high, boosted by strikes in Nigeria and Norway and the approach of the northern hemisphere winter.
The price later fell below US$53 per barrel, but market watchers called it a natural retreat on profit taking and not a change in the trend.

Meanwhile, the international fuel coal price also surged to a historical high of around US$62 per metric ton in the first half of this year, an astounding jump over the US$26 level registered in the second half of last year. The price increase has levied a heavy operating burden on the state-run Taiwan Power Company.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun said early this month at the Legislative Yuan that the government has no plan for the time being to raise its water and power rates, while an executive at the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corporation also ruled out the possibility as part of the government's efforts to help stabilize product prices.

According to statistics released recently by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , Taiwan's wholesale price index (WPI) for September rose by 11.43 percent on an annual basis -- the largest rise in 23 years.
The September consumer price index (CPI) increased by 2.78 percent compared to the previous year's level, the second-largest growth in nearly six years.
The same tallies show that Taiwan's CPI grew mildly by 1.1 percent per year on average during the 1994-2004 period, lower than 2.4 percent in the United States and 3.8 percent in South Korea.
DGBAS officials attributed the WPI and CPI growth mainly to implications arising from high oil prices that show no signs of cooling.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS WORLD'S FOURTH MOST COMPETITIVE ECONOMY: WEF REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the world's fourth most competitive economy, ranking behind Finland, the United States and Sweden, according to the Global Competitiveness Report 2004-2005 published Wednesday by the World Economic Forum (WEF).

Taiwan moves up a notch this year in terms of the WEF's Growth Competitiveness Index -- the highest ranking of the Asian countries -- and is followed by Singapore at seventh spot, according to the report. The leading three economies maintain their same ranking as last year.

Of the Asian economies surveyed, Japan advances to ninth spot this year in terms of the Growth Competitiveness Index, a jump from 11th place a year ago. Hong Kong ranks at 21st this year, followed by South Korea at 29th and mainland China at 46th.

The report hails Taiwan and Singapore as Asia's best performing economies and attributes the two countries' top-10 rankings to their "excellent performance in technology" and "sound macro-economic environment."

Taiwan scores second in technology competitiveness this year, an advance of a notch from last year, and it grabs ninth spot in terms of macro-economic situations, an improvement from 18th place last year.

But Taiwan losses ground in terms of the quality of public institutions, falling to 27th from 21st, and it ranks only at 16th in terms of the Business Competitiveness Index, a drop of one place from last year.
Taiwan is relatively weak in terms of Business Competitiveness Index, lagging behind Japan at eighth spot, Singapore at 10th and Hong Kong at 11th.
The WEF surveyed 104 economies for its Global Competitiveness Report 2004-2005, with more than 8,700 responses from business leaders across the world.
In cooperation with 109 prominent academics worldwide, it issues the annual study to serve as a valuable tool for shaping economic policy and guiding investment decisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO CALL MEETING ON HEALTH INSURANCE FINANCIAL REFORM

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday he will call a meeting in the next few days to discuss feasible measures for National Health Insurance-related financial reforms.
Yu said he plans to invite former Department of Health (DOH) Minister Lee Ming-liang, government officials and legislators versed in health insurance affairs to contribute their views on the reforms.

Yu disclosed his plan a day after about 1,000 healthcare professionals from 300 clinics and hospitals around the island demonstrated in Taipei to protest what they called an unfair payment fixed by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI).

Yu said he will solicit opinions of conference-goers about the appeals made by the demonstrators as well as feasible complementary measures for the current "Hospital Excellence Plan" and other reform projects aimed at improving the financial status of the nation's universal health insurance program.
According to DOH officials, the universal health insurance program faces serious financial difficulties and the program could collapse if no effective measures are taken to improve its finances.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S REACTION NOT BEYOND EXPECTATION: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Former Vice Minister of National Defense Lin Chong-pin said Wednesday that Beijing's reaction toward President Chen Shui-bian's Oct. 10 National Day speech was expected.

On Chen's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways in preparation for a step forward for the resumption of long-stalled cross-strait dialogues, the Chinese government said that Chen's words completely promote Taiwan independence, and they are again a challenge to peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

However, Lin noted that in his judgment and according to the information he received in the United States, Beijing has reoriented its strategies on Taiwan by adopting a more flexible attitude toward the people of Taiwan, but still has not changed its harsh attitude with respect to the Taiwan government's position and the island's space to development in the international community.

In addition, Lin, who is CEO of the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies, revealed that Beijing is now drawing a strategic bead on Taiwan "by causing the fewest human casualties and the minimum economic losses" and to control the whole of East Asia.

Lin told the participants at a seminar on national defense that the Chinese government knows well that there is no need to cause a large and bloody conflict or to ruin Taiwan and reconstruct it later with tremendous sums of money.

He went on that the military power of mainland China will surpass that of Taiwan in 2005, and the U.S. Pentagon believes that the time between 2006 and 2008 will be the most dangerous period for a crisis across the Taiwan Strait.
However, he opined that Beijing will not make a large-scale invasion, but will launch an "acupuncture war" to paralyze Taiwan's political and military nerve centers.
According to Lin, the number of China's military satellites will rise to 30 in 2010 from the current three, which means its military attack will be of high precision.

With apparently superior numbers of fighters, submarines and cruise missiles, China's military forces can attack Taiwan's Chiasan Air Base and blockade the east coast, and edge out "third country's" aircraft carriers from reaching the island's coastal areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD MEDICAL ASSOCIATION APPROVES USE OF 'TAIWAN' IN NAME

TEXT.P: The World Medical Association (WMA) recently approved the name change of Taiwan's membership from the "Chinese Medical Association Taipei" to "Taiwan Medical Association, "Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Wednesday.

The officials noted that a Taiwan delegation, composed of Veterans General Hospital President Lee Liang-hsiung, Taiwan Medical Association's former chairman Wu Yun-tung and medical professors, successfully persuaded the association to make the change in discussions at the WMA's general assembly in Tokyo from Oct. 5-9.

MOFA officials said the successful name change will allow Taiwan to begin medical diplomacy in the future and end the use of the confusing name of Chinese Medical Association Taipei, which is often mistaken as a local organization of China.

Wu indicated that the WMA has been very supportive of Taiwan's bid to participate in the World Health Organization, and many of its chairmen have visited Taiwan, where they were profoundly impressed by the island's progress in many aspects.
According to Wu, the WMA supported Taiwan's bid to enter the WHO as an observer in 2001 and 2002.
Taiwan should work hard to gain the continued support from the WMA and participate more in its activities, which will help the island's WHO bid, Wu stressed.
