DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GIRDING FOR SOUND INVESTMENT CLIMATE AT HOME: MOEA

TEXT.P: The government will continue building an unfettered investment climate in Taiwan, despite the fact that the country performs brilliantly in ratings by the world's major research institutions in recent years, a spokesman for the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

The spokesman made the comments after the World Economic Forum ranked Taiwan as the fourth most competitive economy in the world, after Finland, the United States and Sweden in its Global Competitiveness Report 2004-2005 issued earlier the same day.
Taiwan is the best performing Asian economy in the survey, ahead of Singapore at seventh and Japan at ninth.

The WEF's newest ranking of Taiwan is an indication that the government has done the right thing in improving the investment climate at home, and it will keep on doing so to maintain the country's competitive edge globally, he said.

Commenting on a recent proposal by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan suggesting the U. S. government resume its Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) talks with Taiwan, he said that the ministry welcomes such a development but added that it has not yet received any information from the U.S. side in this regard.

Bilateral TIFA talks have been suspended for more than one year due to Taiwan's lackluster performance in resolving key matters related to foreign rice and telecommunications services, as well as pharmaceutical pricing and intellectual property rights protection.
According to U.S. Assistant Trade Representative Charles Freeman, who briefly visited Taiwan in mid-July, Taiwan has made noticeable progress on these issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER DECORATES OUTGOING DOMINICAN REPUBLIC ENVOY

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen decorated outgoing Dominican Ambassador Carlos Guzman Wednesday in recognition of his contributions to the relations between the Republic of China and the Dominican Republic.
Chen bestowed on behalf of the ROC government the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Guzman at a ceremony held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Chen praised the Dominican envoy for his efforts to promote relations between the two countries since assuming his post in Taipei in April, 2003. Guzman has made great contributions to bilateral ties, he noted.
The minister expressed the hope that Guzman will continue to help promote ROC-Dominican Republic relations after returning home.
In response, Guzman thanked Chen as well as the government and people of Taiwan for the assistance the ROC has extended to his country, particularly in the economic, agricultural and medical fields.
Guzman said that the ROC's assistance has benefited the Dominican people a lot and that he will continue to contribute to further enhancing the friendship between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 14, or the first day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: Dwight D. Eisenhower, U.S. military commander in Europe during World War II and two-term president of the United States after the war, is born.
1912: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, is shot in an attempted assassination prior to his assuming the presidency. He won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese war.
1915: The Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of China government orders a halt to the practice of binding the feet of women.
1920: Oxford University, the oldest university in Britain and one of the world's most famous institutions of higher learning, grants degrees to women for the first time.
1933: Nazi Germany walks out of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and withdraws from the League of Nations.
1939: The British Royal Navy battleship HMS Royal Osk is torpedoed and sunk at Scapa Flow, killing 810 people on board.
1944: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, summons 100,000 young intellectuals to join the army and organizes them into an expeditionary force of 10 divisions.
1944: Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, one of Nazi Germany's finest military leaders known as "Desert Fox," dies at the age of 53.
1947: The Bell X-1 becomes the first aircraft to fly faster than sound when the rocket-powered plane, piloted by U.S. Air Force Maj. Charles Yeager, is taken to a height of 9,700 meters under a B-29 Superfortress mother-plane. The test begins at 22,700 meters and the maximum speed achieved is Mach 1.05, which is held for several seconds.
1964: Martin Luther King Jr., American cleric who formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1973: Thanom Kittikachorn is forced to resign as prime minister of Thailand after violent clashes between troops and student protesters.
1977: The much-loved entertainer Bing Crosby collapses and dies after completing a round of golf near Madrid. He was 73. One of his most successful films was "High Society, " with Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.
1991: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader held under house arrest for more than two years by Burmese military rulers, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: The United Nations General Assembly ends a two-week general debate during which a total of 23 nations express their support for the Republic of China membership in the world body.
1999: A delegation from the Republic of China takes part in the 26th International Small Business Congress held in Toronto, Canada.
2000: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji says in Tokyo that Beijing will take a cautious attitude to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully, but he adds that this issue should not be prolonged indefinitely.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man knows that the accomplishment of great things consists in doing little things well. He knows that great effects are produced by small causes. He knows the evidence and reality of what cannot be perceived by the senses. Thus he is enabled to enter into the world of ideas and morals."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, BELGIUM SIGN AGREEMENT ON AVOIDING DOUBLE TAXATION
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Belgium signed an agreement to avoid double taxation in Brussels Wednesday.
Chen Chien-jen, Taipei representative to Belgium, and Hugues Mignot, director of the Belgian Trade Association in Taipei, signed the agreement on behalf of their respective governments.

Wei Ke-ming, deputy director of the Taipei Representative Office in Belgium, said that the agreement will reduce the tax burden on Taiwanese and Belgian manufacturers and enhance their willingness to invest in each other's country.

According to a statement released by the Taipei Representative Office in Belgium Wednesday, Taiwan has invested around US$30 million in Belgium, mostly in setting up footholds in the computer, financial, information, aviation, trade, restaurant, and manufacturing sectors.
Meanwhile, Belgium has invested in 18 projects in Taiwan, mostly in the financial, trade, telecommunications and precision machinery sectors.
The office said there is ample room for growth in investment between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC CONVERGENCE WILL LEAD TO POLITICAL CONVERGENCE: DIPLOMAT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The economic convergence of Taiwan and mainland China will eventually result in political convergence of the two sides, the French ambassador to the United States said in a speech Tuesday.
Ambassador Jean-David Levitte said that France considers Taiwan and mainland China as one country and hopes that the two sides will address their differences in a peaceful manner.

Levitte delivered a speech entitled "Changes in Europe and America: A French View, " at the School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS) of Johns Hopkins University, giving his audience a French perspective of the major blocs around the world today and in the future.

In a question and answer session after the speech, Levitte was asked whether the French government supports the need to promote democracy in mainland China by supporting democracy in Taiwan or believes that commercial interests are paramount and that arms sales to mainland China should be permitted.

Levitte ducked the part about arms sales to China, but gave a response on the prospects of China's democratization and on the development of cross-strait relations. "We are in favor of democracy in China, as we are in favor of democracy all over the world, " he said.

"My personal conviction is that you cannot have a strong market economy competing so well in this globalized world without democracy developing at the same time, even without knowing democratic values, because a market economy brings democracy," he added.
"With Taiwan investing so heavily in mainland China, I believe that this convergence of the two economies will gradually result in the convergence of the two different regimes," Levitte said.
On the changes taking place in mainland China, Levitte said China today is "a very different China" from 20 years ago.

Noting that he lived in China 30 years ago for several years during the Cultural Revolution, Levitte said that "if you compare the level of freedom, liberties and market economy in China in the days of the Cultural Revolution with that of today's China, you'll see it's a totally different world."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOCTORS TO JOIN ORBIS 'FLYING EYE HOSPITAL' MISSION IN MYANMAR

TEXT.P: Two senior Taiwan ophthalmologists are scheduled to visit Myanmar in December, in a trip organized by ORBIS Taiwan, to join an Orbis Flying Eye Hospital program aimed at helping treat some 250,000 Burmese suffering from blindness or other vision problems.

The two Taiwan eye doctors -- Dr. Liu Jung-hung, president of the Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Medical Center, and Lu Ta-wen, chief of the Ophthalmology Department of Tri-Service General Hospital -- will join other counterparts from around the world to take part in World Sight Day activities in Myanmar to be sponsored by ORBIS International, according to Cliff Chien, executive director of ORBIS Taiwan.

World Sight Day, which falls on the second Thursday of October, is an annual activity regularly sponsored by ORBIS International, the World Health Organization (WHO) , the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF), the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness, the Lion's Club International, and 10 other public interest organizations from around the world.

Liu and Lu will be in Myanmar between Dec. 6-10, during ICDF Taiwan Week, mainly to train Myanmar healthcare workers in the treatment and prevention of blindness to enable them to better care for their compatriots.

Of the 42 million people of Myanmar, about 252,000 suffer from blindness or severe vision problems. Nationwide, there are only 183 eye doctors, 32 optometrists and 150 ophthalmology nurses, Chien said.
ORBIS Taiwan, established in 2001, is an affiliate of ORBIS International, a non-profit organization dedicated to the prevention of blindness and saving the sight of the visually impaired.
According to Chien, there are 45 million blind people around the world and 135 million others with severe visual problems, 90 precent of whom live in countries with inferior medical resources.

In light of the quality medical services and the existence of a large number of professionally trained ophthalmologists in Taiwan, ORBIS International invited in August a number of eye doctors from the island to join its "flying eye hospital" on a mission to Myanmar.

Mohan Jacob Thazhathu, chief operating officer of ORBIS International, who came to Taiwan in August for a promotional event, cited an estimate by the World Health Organization that blindness costs society some US$25 billion every year, with Southeast Asian countries bearing approximately US$5.6 billion of that burden.
The number of people suffering from blindness in the world can be stopped from increasing further by merely investing US$200 million per year in blindness prevention and treatment programs, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC, FPCC EACH FINED NT$6.5 MILLION FOR COLLUSION

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission meted out a NT$6.5 million fine to each of Taiwan's two oil suppliers, Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and Formosa Petrochemical Corp. (FPCC) , Thursday for their tacit business collusion.

After long investigations into the marketing practices of the CPC and FPCC, the commission determined that the two companies have adjusted oil prices in collusion in recent years, violating fair trade laws and consumers' rights, Fair Trade Commission Vice Chairman Chen Chi-yuan said.

The Fair Trade Commission had received numerous complaints from ordinary gas station customers about possible collusion between the two companies, prompting the commission to begin probing the matter early this year, Chen said.
It was found that the CPC and FPCC had raised or lowered prices in sync 20 times since 2002, he said.

Chen added that although the two companies had not held meetings or signed any agreements regarding the collusion practices, solid evidence was found that the two have worked in concert to manipulate domestic oil prices under a tacit understanding.
The commission said earlier this month that if it were confirmed that the two companies were guilty of collusion, they could each be fined between NT$50,000 and NT$25 million.
The state-run CPC currently controls about 75 percent of the island's entire oil market. The FPCC has a 25-percent market share, with 525 gas stations islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRIAL VOLUNTARY MILITARY SERVICE PROGRAM NOT AS POPULAR AS EXPECTED

TEXT.P: The trial voluntary military service program which began to be implemented in 2003 on a trial basis has not been as popular as was expected, sources from the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Thursday.
The MND began implementing the program last year with the goal of recruiting 647 non-commissioned officers and enlisted soldiers in the first three stages to be assigned to three military units.

However, the three military units -- a missile battalion, a marine battalion and an air force maintenance and supply group -- have only recruited 328 volunteers as of this week, marking a recruitment rate of a barely passable 51 percent, said Wu Ta-peng, director of the MND's Department of Manpower.
Of the 328 new recruits, 81 percent have come from within the military, Wu added.
Wu made the revelation at a Legislative Yuan National Defense Committee meeting, where he reported on the progress of the voluntary military service program and other conscription programs.

Wu analyzed the reasons behind the lukewarm reception by society to the voluntary program -- namely that the salary is not high enough to attract recruits; that the publicity campaign has been not powerful enough; and that the average physical agility of the potential volunteer recruits is low.

He said that the NT$27,000 monthly salary is about the same as that for someone beginning their first job, and therefore offers no incentive to young men to join the military; that nearly 80 percent of young male civilians were not made aware of the program; and that only 68.12 percent of the applicants passed the physical agility tests.

Under a "lean and mean" strategy, the MND has envisaged focusing on voluntary military service starting next year, with the goal of recruiting 45,000 enlisted soldiers and non-commissioned officers over a period of four years.

In the MND's five-year national defense buildup report which was sent to the Legislative Yuan last month, the ministry said that according to the voluntary military service plan, it will increase recruitment of non-commissioned officers by 4,000 and enlisted soldiers by 2,000 in 2005, with an additional 21,000 non-commissioned officers and 18,000 enlisted soldiers over the next three years, to reach its target of 45,000 non-commissioned officers and enlisted soldiers by 2009.
In line with the nation's military streamlining policy, the number of military personnel will be cut to under 300,000 by 2009 from the present figure of 360,500, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF PEOPLE APPROVE OF CHEN'S NATIONAL DAY REMARKS: POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of Taiwan residents are satisfied with President Chen Shui-bian's remarks made in his Oct. 10 National Day speech, according to the results of a government-conducted public opinion poll released Thursday.

A total of 64 percent of Taiwan residents approved of the idea expressed by Chen in his speech that leaders from all of Taiwan's political parties be invited to collaborate in the establishment of a Committee for Cross-Strait Peace and Development, according to the survey by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

The telephone poll, conducted between Oct. 11-12, found that 60 percent of the respondents think that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should build a military mutual trust mechanism to help reduce cross-strait tensions.

A total of 68 percent of the respondents said that Taiwan should seek to join the United Nations, while 59.5 percent said that the government should engage in negotiations with Beijing without delay on direct cross-strait passenger and cargo charter flight services.

Meanwhile, 47.8 percent said that they support Chen's notion that the two sides resume dialogue based on the "1992 Hong Kong talks, " while 14.7 percent said they are against it, and 37.5 percent said they have no clear ideas on the issue.

Slightly over 48 percent of the respondents said they think President Chen showed goodwill toward Beijing in his speech, 15.7 percent said they think he didn't, and 35.7 percent gave no clear answers.

A total of 1,074 valid responses were collected in the poll of randomly-selected Taiwan adults islandwide. The survey is said by its authors to have a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.020 to close at NT$33.870.
A total of US$572 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.890 and fluctuated between NT$33.863 and NT$33.924.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slumped Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 132 points to close at 5,831.07.

The bourse opened at the day's high of 5,924.44 and hit a low of 5,823.58 during the day's trading. A total of 3.8 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$81.72 billion (US$2.41 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks, pulp and paper issues and construction issues all moving down the most at 4.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 5.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 4.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 2.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 2.6 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 567 to 126, with 110 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEF REPORT IS RECOGNITION FOR TAIWAN'S EFFORTS IN ECONOMY: CABINET

TEXT.P: The fact that Taiwan has been listed as the world's fourth most competitive economy indicates that the government's efforts in boosting the economy have gained international recognition, Executive Yuan officials said Thursday.
The officials were referring to the Global Competitiveness Report 2004-2005 released Wednesday by the World Economic Forum (WEF).

Taiwan moves up a notch this year in terms of the WEF's Growth Competitiveness Index because of its "excellent performance in technology" and "sound macro-economic environment, " according to the report.
The officials noted that this is the fifth consecutive year Taiwan has advanced, while the country's showing has topped other Asian countries for the third consecutive year.

The results show that the government's measures on upgrading industrial technology, improving domestic investment environment, and strengthening the country's economic growth potential have won worldwide recognition, the officials said.

They said the government will not be complacent about this achievement but will continue to work harder to maintain Taiwan's edge in innovation, information and communications technology and its steady economic environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN READY TO TALK WITH CHINA ON SENSIBLE ISSUES AT ANY TIME: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to open negotiations with mainland China on pragmatic issues of mutual concern at any time, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.
Wu made the remarks while giving a speech at the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Claiming that the MAC has started training negotiation personnel to serve that purpose, Wu said that the government is poised to hold negotiations with the mainland at any time on a wide range of practical matters that are not politically charged, but are mutually beneficial, such as fishing and trade disputes, illegal immigrants, crime prevention and tourism exchanges.
Resolving these issues through two-way talks will help both sides boost mutual understanding and build trust to create greater cooperation and progress in cross-Taiwan Strait dealings, Wu said.
The MAC chief proposed doing this by beginning with talks on Chinese New Year charter flight services for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen wishing to return home for the holiday.
Wu said that the proposal has gained full support from Premier Yu Shyi-kun and that Taiwan is waiting patiently for a positive response from Beijing.

He urged both Taiwan and mainland China to take the first step boldly to forge a favorable atmosphere for a second meeting between the top negotiators from the two sides, reiterating that it will be a win-win situation for the two sides.

SEF Chairman C. F. Koo and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , met for the first time in 1993 in Singapore, based on a framework reached by Taiwan and mainland officials in a meeting held a year earlier in Hong Kong.
It was decided in the meeting that the two sides would put aside their political differences to discuss practical matters of mutual concern.

President Chen Shui-bian again extended an olive branch to Beijing in his Oct. 10 National Day address, calling for joint efforts to reduce the risk of military conflict, and clear the way for direct links based on the existing framework.

"I would like to take the initiative to propose that both sides use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways that are "not necessarily perfect, but acceptable" as preparation of a step forward in the resumption of dialogue and consultation, " Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND HOPES DEFENSE BUDGET CAN INCREASE BY 1 PERCENT NEXT FISCAL YEAR

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense (MND) Tsai Ming-shian on Thursday expressed hope that Taiwan's defense budget will account for 3.5 percent of gross domestic product in future over the current 2.5 percent.

At a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee, Tsai said the proposed defense budget increase is to support arms purchase plans and the implementation of a voluntary military service program in the future.
Tsai noted that the defense budget for fiscal 2005 will total US$260 billion, accounting for only 2.5 percent of the country's GDP.

According to opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang, a defense expert, the MND will need an additional NT$380 billion (US$11.2 billion) from 2005 to 2009 to support the implementation of the voluntary military program in conformity with a five-year military structural readjustment plan.

If this is the case, Lin argued, additional money used for the plan will mean that NT$76 billion will be unavailable for general annual defense spending, making it difficult to support the voluntary military service program.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lee Wen-chong suggested that the MND increase salaries for enlisted soldiers and non-commissioned officers who are under a trial voluntary military service program as an incentive to lure more young people to join the military forces, while accelerating the reduction in the number of current military personnel.

Tsai stressed that the implementation of the voluntary military service program is a redistribution of the country's resources, and the MND believes that without the obligatory military service program, young people can add more production to the nation by one or two years.

Noting that the cost for the obligatory military service program is three times that of a voluntary military service plan, Tsai expressed the hope that the defense budget for fiscal 2006 can be increased by 1 percent, which would result in an additional NT$100 billion, to account for 3.5 percent of the country's GDP.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC INVITES MAINLAND'S TOP NEGOTIATOR TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Thursday again invited a top mainland Chinese negotiator to visit Taiwan, saying this is the common wish of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu extended the invitation to Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) when he delivered a speech on seizing the opportunity to restart sensible cross-strait dialogues at the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a semi-official body set up to handle cross-strait matters in civilian exchanges and the Taiwan counterpart of ARATS.

Wu noted that both sides of the Taiwan Strait met in Hong Kong in 1992, during which time both sides displayed the attitude of "shelving disputes on sovereignty and pragmatically engaging in consultations."

Though no substantial agreement was reached in 1992, it paved the way for historic talks between Wang and his Taiwan counterpart, Koo Chen-fu, SEF chairman the following year. It was the first high-ranking contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after a hiatus of nearly five decades.
A flurry of cross-strait contacts afterward also made possible another Koo-Wang meeting in Shanghai in 1998, Wu said.

Stressing that history will continue to move forward and that people on both sides of the Strait are hoping for a third meeting between the two octogenarians to complete the unfinished consultations in 1998, he openly extended the invitation, saying a third Koo-Wang meeting is the aspiration of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

He also took the opportunities to elaborate on the establishment of a "code of conduct" across the Taiwan Strait, which President Chen Shui-bian espoused in his National Day address, saying its purpose is to avoid accidental conflicts.

Wu noted that mainland Chinese leaders in a recent conference stressed the theme of strengthening the ability to govern, and the documents approved during the conference showed that mainland China has encountered problems within itself which will require a peaceful and stabile environment to settle.

But he said that with military confrontation between the two sides, many people are worrying that accidental conflict could worsen and become uncontrollable. This is why Taiwan is willing to face the situation and formulate a "code of conduct across the Taiwan Strait."

He said that the content of such a code could include exchanges of military personnel and information, the establishment of an emergency hotline and notification mechanism, joint presence in international security seminars, cooperation to combat crime, no use or threats of the use of force, not taking the initiative to attack, mutual notification of military exercises, military aircraft not flying over the "midpoint" of the Taiwan Strait, and no use of radar to lock onto aircraft or ships.

Among these, not taking the initiative to launch an attack, mutual notification of military drills, as well as military aircraft not flying over the "midpoint" of the Strait can be a "tacit understanding and agreement" between the two sides, while cross-strait consultations are required for other issues, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES OPEN HEARING ON PETITION TO FREEZE 'TRUTH COMMISSION'

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices opened a hearing Thursday on a petition for the issuance of a temporary injunction to freeze a special statute governing the formation of the controversial "truth investigation commission."

The petition has been jointly filed by the "pan-green alliance" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, which has also requested a constitutional interpretation on the opposition-backed statute, which they consider to be unconstitutional.
Building a case for the DPP, lawyer Wellington Koo asked the council to suspend the statute immediately and not to wait until an interpretation is released.
Koo argued that the statute has done irreparable damage to the Constitution, seriously violating human rights and the constitutional principle of the division of powers.
The mistake will be beyond remedy even if the Council of Grand Justices declare the statute unconstitutional in the future, Koo said.
Representatives of the commission, however, argued that a constitutional interpretation will become superfluous if the Grand Justices have the power to order a temporary injunction.
Wang Ching-feng, spokeswoman for the commission, said the Grand Justices can interpret the Constitution but are not allowed to create a new measure that does not exist in the Constitution.
According to Taiwan law, any attempt to abolish a law must be made in the Legislative Yuan by a majority vote, Wang said.
As the hearing was being held, different groups representing both sides of the issue demonstrated outside the Judicial Yuan offices.

The commission is aimed at probing the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, which the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party claims was set up by the DPP to give Chen an advantage in the presidential election.

The "pan-blue alliance, " which enjoys a marginal majority in the legislature, pushed through the statute on Aug. 24. The legislature upheld the statute in a second vote held on Sept. 14, following the Executive Yuan's request that the bill be reconsidered.
The commission was officially formed and started operations on Oct. 4.
The "pan-green camp" has refused to join the commission and sought legal means to try to end its operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CHECKING ALLEGATION THAT FORMER COSTA RICAN HEAD POCKETED MONEY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is investigating reports that former Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez pocketing money from Taiwan that was given as donations, a MOFA spokesman said Thursday.

Michel Lu made the remarks as reports said that Costa Rican prosecutors had confirmed that they are investigating alleged payments by the government of Taiwan to accounts controlled by Rodriguez, who resigned Oct. 8 as head of the Organization of American States.
The reports also cited Costa Rican media as saying that Rodriguez received the money of about US$400,000 from Taiwan in 2000 and 2002. Rodriguez served as president from 1998 to 2002.
Lu said that the ROC maintains diplomatic relations with allies based on long-term mutual trust and sincerity.

Taiwan's assistance to its allies takes into consideration its own capacity to provide foreign aid, adding that both sides work on projects that will benefit the national development of these allies, he said.
All projects are carried out according to established schedules, he said.

Lu said that in view of the fact that Costa Rica is currently investigating Rodriguez for alleged acceptance of commissions from French company Alcatel during his term, the ministry will refrain from making comments so as not to obstruct judicial procedures of the Central American nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC SERVANTS WILL HAVE 112 DAYS OFF INCLUDING WEEKENDS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Central Personnel Administration Director-General Lee Yi-yang announced Thursday that public servants will have 112 days off next year, including weekends.
Among the 112 days off, Lee added, employees at government offices will have eight consecutive days off as Chinese Lunar New Year vacation from Feb 6-13, but will have to work the previous Saturday.
Lee made the announcement following discussions with representatives from local governments, the Chinese National Federation of Industries and the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE DEMOCRATIC ACTIVIST PREDICTS DRASTIC CHANGES ON MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Chinese democratic activist Wang Dan predicted Thursday that a tremendous change will take place in mainland China in 10 to 15 years.
Wang urged Taiwan to promote its experience in democratic development to the mainland to lower the possible impact of the change on the island.
Wang was delivering a speech at the Mainland Affairs Council to share his views on the future development of the mainland.
Wang said China is now open to the outside world but that does not mean reform is on the way.
A great deal of crises underlie the fast economic development of China, which include an unhealthy financial system and the widening gap of rural-urban development, according to Wang.
This will lead to drastic changes -- which could be for the better or the worse -- on the mainland in 10 to 15 years, Wang said.

In order to lessen the possible repercussions on the island, the authorities in Taiwan should continue to maintain the status quo with China and strengthen cross-strait economic and cultural exchanges, Wang proposed.

He said Taiwan should also promote its democratic experience to China to let the Chinese people better understand the true meaning of its Taiwanization movement and bring on a transformation of Chinese society.
He stressed that the values of democracy and human rights will be the only ones common to both sides of the Strait in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAX HIKE THIS YEAR: VICE MINISTER OF FINANCE

TEXT.P: There will be no tax hike this year, but the feasibility of such a move is yet to be assessed, Vice Minister of Finance Lin Tseng-chi said Thursday.

Lin made the remarks while fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan at a time when tax reform has again become a focal point in the face of a wave of domestic product price hikes that seem imminent.
Lin said that tax increases are out of the question this year and he fell short of confirming such a possibility for 2005, saying only that "the issue has yet to be further evaluated."

Thanks to an economic upturn this year, national coffers took in NT$769 billion (US$22.6 billion) in net tax revenues during the first nine months of this year, accounting for 85.2 percent of the full-year target, he reported.

Speaking on the same occasion, Economic Affairs Vice Minister Yiin Chii-ming said that the ministry will consider water and electricity rate hikes no earlier than before late February next year, depending on the overall business climate at home by that time. "It is not just an issue about making money," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CZECH PRESIDENT EXPECTED TO VISIT TAIWAN IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Former Czech President Vaclav Havel is expected to arrive in Taiwan for a visit in November, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Hsieh Chun-teh, deputy director-general of the MOFA European Affairs Department, said that Havel originally planned to visit Taiwan in January this year during his Asian journey, but Havel fell ill in India and had to cancel the trip, although he is still hoping to visit Taiwan.
Hsieh said Taiwan is inviting Havel to come in November, adding that he is a good loyal friend of the island and has spoken up for Taiwan on various international occasions.

The ministry welcomes the democracy-fighter who stepped down in early 2003 as Czech president after 12 years on the post, and hopes he is in good health so he can come to Taiwan as scheduled, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPPOSES EU LIFTING ARMS BAN AGAINST MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is opposed to the European Union lifting its arms ban against mainland China and will closely monitor the EU-China summit on Dec. 8 in The Hague, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

Hsieh Chun-teh, deputy director-general of the ministry's European Affairs Department, said the foreign ministry feels the situation is serious and has been watching developments since late last year when the EU was reported to be reconsidering the ban that has been in place against Beijing since 1989 following the Tiananmen Massacre.
Hsieh said the EU must take into account the impact on regional security and stability in the Pacific Rim should it lift the arms embargo.

Mainland China's recent military buildup and modernization poses a great threat to the Asia-Pacific region's security and stability as well as to the strategic interests of the United States and Japan, Hsieh noted, adding that both Washington and Tokyo have clearly expressed their opposition to the lifting of the arms ban against mainland China.

The foreign ministry will continue to actively seek every possible way to make known internationally its stance, including by speaking via established channels to the administrative and legislative branches of EU member nations, the European Parliament, scholars, the media and non-governmental organizations, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIFEX NAMED AS TOP FUTURES EXCHANGE OF 2004 BY ASIARISK MAGAZINE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Futures Exchange (TAIFEX) is named as the top futures exchange of 2004 by AsiaRisk magazine in recognition of its brilliant performance in recent years.

The TAIFEX was awarded the honor thanks to its outstanding risk management, successful promotion of a variety of financially derived products and profitable business operations -- the most profitable and innovative in the Asia-Pacific region over the past year, a magazine spokesman said.
The futures markets of South Korea and Australia were given the title in 2002 and 2003, respectively.

The TAIFEX dealt with a total of 31.87 million lots last year, marking an annual growth rate of 300 percent and obtaining a world ranking of 26th from 35th in 2002. Its world status surged to 19th in the first quarter of this year based on an increased business volume.
For the first nine months of this year, the TAIFEX handled more than 43.5 million contracts, with its single-day contract number hitting a new high of 546,968 deals on Feb. 12.
At the same time, institutional investors are playing a bigger role in the domestic futures market, with their participation rate growing from 31.44 percent in 2003 to 36.51 percent in September.
AsiaRisk, first launched in 1995, is a professional magazine dedicated to financial risk management and consultancy.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 TAIWAN BUSINESS ALLIANCE CONFERENCE TO BEGIN ON NOV. 7

TEXT.P: The four-day 2004 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference will begin on Nov. 7 in Taipei, with the participation of more than 400 corporate representatives from around the world, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Officials said Thursday.

Officials of MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC) noted that the conference, the second of its kind in Taiwan, will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center, and will focus on biotechnology, IC design and information service industries, the three key sectors in Taiwan that have great potential.

According to statistics compiled by IDIC, as of June, the number of confirmed and promised foreign investment projects made following the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference in October totaled 241 worth NT$147.8 billion (US$4.36 billion).
Among the figure, 32 projects are being promoted with an investment value worth NT$11.5 billion.

The 2004 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference is aimed at continuing the economic momentum created last year, which was the largest investment promotion conference the country had ever held, but on a smaller scale, the officials said.
The conference will begin with a news conference on Nov. 7, in which foreign investors with operations in Taiwan will talk about their investments in Taiwan.

On Nov. 8, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, MiTAC-Synnex Group Chairman Matthew Miau, and IBM Director-General in charge of Asian and Pacific operations Frank Kern will deliver keynote addresses at the conference.
The organizer will arrange a trip around Taiwan's enterprises for those participants on Nov. 9-10 to allow them to have a better understanding of the island's investment climate.
According to IDIC, those applying to participate in the 2004 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference include executives from IBM, Bayer, Microsoft, Oracle, Infineon, Renesas and Novartis.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC ADVISORY PANEL WORRIED ABOUT HIGH-TECH TALENT SHORTFALL

TEXT.P: The Economic Advisory Panel to the President will report to President Chen Shui-bian on Oct. 20 on the shortage of individuals skilled in the high-tech sector.

Panel member Wu Rong-i, who is president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, noted Thursday that there is a large shortfall in Taiwan in terms of the supply of high-tech experts, which will seriously affect the island's development in the semiconductor and TFT-LCD panel industries, in which Taiwan now leads in the world market.

According to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, Taiwan needs 1,585 experts with doctorate degrees and 23,193 with masters degrees in the next three years.
However, it is estimated that schools can only supply 1,140 with doctorate degree and 18,579 with masters degree in this period, falling short by 5,000 high-level experts in the next three years.
Wu urged the government to pay high heed to the problem and find ways to resolve it, suggesting that it seek people from abroad in addition to strengthening the training of experts at home.

The panel members also suggested that the government review its alternative military service program, in which conscripts can serve in selected fields such as scientific, as the handsome benefits the conscripts gain in these corporations will reduce their ambition to pursue advanced studies abroad, which will affect the cultivation of highly talented people for the country in the long-run.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES US$100,000 TO HOLY SEE FOR CHARITY
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government donated US$100,000 Thursday to the Holy See in response to a call by Pope John Paul II to assist poor people in Asia on the occasion of his 26th anniversary since being elected.

ROC Ambassador Tou Chou-seng made the donation on behalf of the ROC government to the Vatican, with Foreign Minister Giovanni Lajolo receiving the money on behalf of the Pope. The ROC Embassy here issued a press release in Chinese, English and Italian.

According to the statement, the ROC government and its people have always been loyal followers of the Pope and they are very willing to take part in charitable activities in Asia and the rest of the world by the Vatican.
Taiwan feels that it is important to give to the international community to try to end poverty and hunger, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES DEMAND WRITTEN SUPPLEMENT ON 'TRUTH COMMISSION'

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices urged the concerned parties Thursday to present within four days a written supplement about the issuance of a temporary injunction to freeze a special statute governing the formation of the controversial "truth investigation commission."
The council issued the demand after concluding the hearing on a petition jointly filed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
The case is pending, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 15, or the second day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
70 B.C.: Virgil, Roman epic, didactic and pastoral poet, is born. His greatest work was the epic poem "Aeneid," which tells of the wanderings of Aeneas after the sack of Troy.
1821: The Central American Federation wins independence from Spain.
1925: During the warlord era in China, Sun Chuan-fang, superintendent of Chekiang Province, appoints himself as the commander in chief of a military alliance force of five provinces in central China to launch an expedition against Chang Tso-lin's army in Manchuria.
1928: The airship "Graf Zeppelin" lands in New Jersey after making its first transatlantic crossing from Germany.
1945: Pierre Laval, the French politician who led the Vichy government which collaborated with Nazi Germany during World War II, is executed.
1946: Nazi war criminal Hermann Goering commits suicide by poisoning himself one day before his scheduled execution.
1950: The first popular elections of magistrates in Taiwan Province are held in Hualien and Taitung. There is a poor voter turnout and new elections are scheduled for Oct. 22.
1955: A single Republic of China air force Saber jet, piloted by Capt. Sun Szu-wen, shoots down one MiG-17 in a dogfight with 12 Chinese Communist MiG-17s north of Matsu.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the late president of Academia Sinica, is buried in a cemetery in Nankang.
1964: Nikita Khrushchev is replaced by Leonid Brezhnev as First Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, with Alexei Kosygin becoming prime minister.
1969: The biggest antiwar demonstration in U.S. history is staged as millions of Americans take part in organized rallies and marches to voice their disapproval over their country's continuing involvement in the Vietnam War.
1973: The Sino-Paraguayan Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and Vietnamese political leader Le Duc Tho share the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the U.S.-North Vietnam cease-fire. But Le refuses it on the grounds that peace is not yet established in South Vietnam.
1973: Y.T. Wong, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, leaves for Los Angeles to attend a seminar on Sino-American trade.
1974: A 15-member national team leaves Taipei for Seoul to take part in the First Asian Taekwondo Championships.
1975: A martial arts contest is held in Tainan with 400 people from 11 countries attending.
1980: Lt. Gen. Armando Reyes Villa, defense minister of Bolivia, visits the ROC army headquarters and also the ROC navy headquarters.
1986: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang, presided over by KMT Chairman Chiang Ching-kuo, unanimously passes a resolution of political reform to institute the National Security Law during the period of Communist Rebellion and allow the formation of new political parties and organizations.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh, an Academia Sinica member, wins the 1986 Nobel Prize for chemistry. President Chiang Ching-kuo would send a letter of congratulations to Lee on Oct. 17.
1987: The ROC Executive Yuan passes regulations governing the applications of local residents wishing to visit relatives in mainland China.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: South African President F. W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela share the Nobel Peace Prize for their work toward ending apartheid and laying the foundations for democracy in South Africa.
1997: Steven Chu, a member of Academia Sinica and a professor at Stanford University, becomes one of the two co-winners of the Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet of the Republic of China crashes while on a routine training mission off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan.
2000: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, urges the government to pay more attention to the nation's economic problems.
2001: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi and Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih arrive in Shanghai to attend a series of ministerial meetings under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated for Oct. 15-18.
2001: Gen. Chang Hsueh-liang, who briefly kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1936 at the peak of the Chinese civil war, dies in Hawaii at the age of 101.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man must examine his own heart and see that he has no cause for self-reproach, that he has no evil thought in his mind. Wherein the moral man is superior to other men consists even in that which is not seen by men."
