Amid the continuing violence gripping Palestine, Iraq, and other parts of the 1.3 billion-strong Islamic world, Muslim Filipinos will join their brothers in 23 other countries today, Friday, on the first day of Ramadan fasting.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: General's assets frozen
ACTING on the request of the Anti-Money Laundering Council, the Court of Appeals yesterday ordered the freezing of the 40 accounts of Maj. Gen. Carlos Garcia and his family in six banks and in the Armed Forces of the Philippines Savings and Loan Association, Inc.
The Philippine Star: CA freezes Garcia's assets
The Court of Appeals (CA) directed yesterday several financial institutions to freeze the bank accounts and the disposition of vehicles of Maj. Gen. Carlos Garcia, his wife and three sons amid "probable cause" that these were acquired through illegal and corrupt means.
The Manila Times: Garcia still no-show
THE controversial former military comptroller, Maj. Gen. Carlos F. Garcia, on Thursday failed to appear again before a congressional inquiry into his unexplained wealth owing to what doctors agreed upon as his "life-threatening condition."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. AGAIN CALLS FOR RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Washington has once again expressed welcome to President Chen Shui-bian's peace overture to Beijing spelled out in his Oct. 10 National Day speech calling for a resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

Responding to reporters' questions at a regular press conference Thursday, U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said that the department views Chen's speech as "a welcome and constructive message that offered some creative ideas to reduce tension and resume cross-state dialogue."
Boucher said that "we have urged both sides -- we will continue to urge both sides -- to take the opportunity to engage in dialogue in order to resolve the differences peacefully."

The spokesman did not comment when asked by a reporter about the notion that mainland China sees President Chen's speech quite differently from the United States and regards it as a provocation rather than an opportunity for dialogue.
A deputy spokesman of the State Department expressed a similar welcome Oct. 10 immediately after learning about President Chen's message to China.

The State Department official said that the U.S. policies have remained unchanged -- namely firmly supporting the "one China" policy, not supporting Taiwan independence, and opposing any moves by either side that would change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.
He said that the United States has been consistent in its stance that the cross-strait differences should be solved in a peaceful way that is acceptable to the people of both sides.

President Chen took the initiative to display goodwill toward Beijing by proposing in his National Day speech that Taiwan and mainland China use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible schemes that are "not necessarily perfect but acceptable" as steps toward a resumption of dialogue and consultations.

Chen also called for the two sides to seriously consider the issue of "arms control" and seek to establish a "code of conduct across the Taiwan Strait" as a tangible guarantee of permanent peace since "any conflict in the Taiwan Strait would result in irreparable damage to the people on both sides."

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB CLOSELY MONITORING TYPHOON TOKAGE

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) is closely monitoring Typhoon Tokage, a "large" typhoon with a radius of 400 kilometers, which has been looming in the Pacific Ocean since Monday.

The weather bureau is not expected to issue any warnings for Tokage on Friday unless the typhoon hastens its pace and continues moving in a northwestward direction directly toward Taiwan, CWB meteorologists said.

Typhoon Tokage, packing maximum sustained winds of up to 136 kilometers per hour, was centered about 1,900 kilometers southeast of Taiwan at 8 a.m. Friday, moving northwesterly toward Taiwan at a speed of 12 kilometers per hour.

The forecasters said they'll be monitoring how the northeastern trade winds coming from the north influence the typhoon's course over the following day, adding that Saturday and Sunday will be the crucial period in terms of determining whether the typhoon will hit Taiwan.
The typhoon is expected to bring tremendous amounts of rainfall to Taiwan regardless of whether or not it hits the island directly, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFSHORE QUAKE ROCKS ENTIRE ISLAND

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 7 on the open-ended Richter scale rattled eastern Taiwan at 12: 08 p.m. Friday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.
The epicenter of the quake was located about 110 kilometers from the northeastern city of Ilan at a depth of 59 kilometers beneath the surface of the sea, CWB seismologists said.
The temblor shook the entire island of Taiwan, with Ilan and the neighboring county of Hualien registering the greatest intensity, at 5.

The quake had an intensity of 4 in Taipei and Taoyuan in the north, Taichung and Yunlin in central Taiwan, and Taitung in eastern Taiwan. It had an intensity of 3 in Hsinchu, Miaoli, Changhua, Nantou, Chiayi and Tainan, and an intensity of 2 on Penghu Island in the Taiwan Strait and in Taiwan proper's southernmost city of Pingtung.
CWB seismologists called for the public to be on alert against possible aftershocks, adding that aftershocks of a major earthquake may occur one hour, one day, one week, or even one month afterward.
Officials from Ilan's Fire Department said that as of 12:45 p.m., no damage or casualties had been reported in the city.
The National Fire Administration, which has begun checking into the situation around Taiwan, also said no damage or casualties had been reported anywhere on the island as of 1 p.m.

Taiwan experienced its deadliest earthquake in five decades on Sept. 21, 1999, when a magnitude 7.6 temblor struck central Taiwan, killing 2,415 people and injuring more than 10,000 others. Some 100,000 residents were displaced in the quake, and damage to property was immeasurable.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DOESN'T WANT HEIGHTENED CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS: U.S. SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An American China hand said Thursday that Beijing's response to President Chen Shui-bian's peace overture was not too harsh, and that the mainland Chinese leadership continues to want to avoid a heightening of cross-strait tensions.

Bonnie Glaser, a researcher at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), said that Beijing has long demanded that Taiwan accept the "one China" principle, which she said President Chen has not done so.

Beijing's negative response to President Chen's Double Ten National Day message was predictable, with mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman reiterating Beijing's distrust of Chen and its demand that he accept its "one China" principle, Glaser said.

She said that Beijing's response was not "excessively harsh, " and that it is trying to moderate its rhetoric toward Taiwan and lower the temperature between the two sides, adding that the new leadership in Beijing does not want heightened tensions with Taiwan and "hopes for greater stability."

Glaser pointed out that Beijing is especially displeased with the fact that Chen has successfully kicked the ball into China's court, and that the United States has termed some of the content of Chen's speech as "constructive " and expressed the hope that China will respond with its own positive gestures.

She said that the United States is willing to "cherry pick" the positive points from the speech -- namely his suggestions that the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong be used as a basis for moving toward a resumption of cross-strait dialogue, and that a "code of conduct across the Taiwan Strait, a confidence-building mechanism and direct cross-strait air links be established.

But China "is analyzing the speech in its entirety and finds the overall tone and many specific elements provocative, " she said, adding that Beijing "is strongly opposed to Chen's statement that the Republic of China is equal to Taiwan, and his emphasis on Taiwan national identity."

Glaser also predicted that when U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao meet at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting in Chile in November, Hu will underscore China's displeasure with U.S. policy toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARTIFICIAL REEFS CONSTRUCTED OFF TAIWAN TO ENHANCE FISHERY RESOURCES

TEXT.P: Discarded utility poles were submerged in waters off Nanliao Port in the northern Taiwan county of Hsinchu Friday to create artificial reefs as part of the government's fishery resources conservation efforts.
The reefs were constructed under a long-term cooperative program between the Council of Agriculture's (COA's) Fishery Administration and state-owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower).

Over the past three decades, Taiwan has created a large number of artificial reefs made from discarded utility poles, decommissioned naval vessels and discarded tires at 100-plus designated areas along the coastline to enhance fishery resources.
COA officials said the artificial reefs not only function to prevent the deterioration of fishing grounds but also help increase fish stocks.

"The structures provide a foundation that is colonized by coral polyps and in time becomes thickly encrusted with living coral, providing an ecosystem in which marine life can thrive, " a COA official said.

With underground electrical wiring becoming a general trend in recent years, Taipower has donated many waste cement utility poles for the creation of more than 10,000 artificial reefs in 79 coastal regions, including Taoyuan County's Yungan, Hsinchun County's Nanliao, Taichung County's Wuchi, Changhua County's Wangkung and Hualien County's Yenliao, for conservation of fishery resources and other marine life.

In addition to enhancing fishery resources, the artificial reef areas have also become points of interest and create new businesses in such areas as deep-sea diving, leisure fishing and recreational scuba diving.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Candidates Debut Closing Themes; Bush and Kerry Gear Up for Final Push.
John F. Kerry rolled out a new campaign speech packed with populist rhetoric and sharp indictments of the Bush administration Thursday, while President Bush sounded the theme he will take to voters in the next 2 1/2 weeks: that Kerry is a big-government Massachusetts liberal, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIR PUSHES FOR 'PAN-BLUE' INTEGRATION

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DDP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said Friday that he will call on the leadership of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) shortly to push for the signing of a pact to merge the two main opposition "pan-blue alliance" parties once and for all.

Hsu, who served as DPP chairman before the party came to power more than four years ago, said that all the "pan-blue alliance" groups, including the New Party, should merge to enable the opposition forces to secure a majority in the Legislative Yuan after the year-end legislative elections.

A co-founder of the new political group -- the Taiwan Democratic School -- Hsu noted that only by calling all the "pan-blue" supporters back to vote in the Dec. 11 legislative elections can the opposition camp win a majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan to "rebuild a new center of power" for the country.

Hsu, who had a falling out with the DPP after the party failed to nominate him to run in the 2000 presidential election, claimed in July of this year at the inaugural ceremony of the Taiwan Democratic School that the new group is aimed at "promoting a new democratic movement to sustain Taiwan's young democracy."

Claiming that Taiwan has been divided into "two countries and two peoples" since the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election, Hsu said the island now needs a new and powerful popular movement to address this crisis.
Hsu and three other Taiwan Democratic School members have registered to run in the Dec. 11 legislative elections as independents.

Hsu said that he will probably call on KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong prior to the elections to push for a "big consolidation" of the opposition forces and to make known the Taiwan Democratic School's determination to throw its support behind the "pan-blue alliance" as well.

Hsu and Taiwan Democratic School President Hou Hsiao-hsien as well as Vice President Cheng Li-wen held a press conference Friday to call for the Taiwan public, particularly TV talk show hosts, to refrain from using inflammatory rhetoric and abusing the term "love Taiwan" during the campagin season.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTY CHIEF WANTS TROOPS TO REMAIN ON ISLETS OFF MATSU

TEXT.P: Amid reports that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will withdraw troops from six Kinmen islets, the head of another outlying island has said he opposes the pullout of troops.
Chen Hsueh-sheng, magistrate of Lienchiang County, said Friday that he is strongly against a similar withdrawal of troops from the islets off Matsu.

The MND has confirmed that it will adjust its deployment on the six islets -- Tatan, Ertan, Tungting, Peitung, Shihyu and Menghuyu -- and turn over administration of the islets to the Kinmen county government, with the police to maintain order on the islets.

Residents of Matsu have speculated that the MND will also withdraw its small number of troops currently stationed on the islets off Matsu, which are located only 11 nautical miles from the mainland Chinese port of Mawei, Fujian province.

Chen said that Kinmen and Matsu will be unable to take over the islets after the military pullout, and that even the National Park Administration will be unable to handle them. Even if Matsu wants to adopt the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model, it won't be able to attract private sector interest because of a lack of incentives.
Chen said he believes that at the present stage, the troops should remain on the islets, and that the government should make good use of the unique landscape of the islets by opening them to tourism.

The MND's plan to turn over the six islets off Kinmen is at the request of Kinmen County, but the people of Matsu have expressed concerns that if the MND withdraws troops from the islets near Kinmen and Matsu, this will trigger a complete troop withdrawal from Matsu, which he said would be a major blow to the Matsu economy as spending by the soldiers stationed there is a major source of income for the residents.

In recent years, Kinmen's economic development and that of Matsu have diverged, with the two relying on the military to different degrees, which may be the reason why the two counties have different views on the troop withdrawal issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN SLIGHTLY ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market dropped slightly Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October fell 34 points to close at 5,816, with 29,951 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 32 points to finish at 5,816, with 4,131 contracts traded, while December futures lost 43 points to finish at 5,800, with 13 contracts traded, and June futures moved down 73 points to close at 5,712, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,850 for October, 5,848 for November, 5,843 for December, 5,812 for March and 5,785 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, saw mixed results.
October TE futures moved down 2.6 points to close at 212.9, with 5,770 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 2.65 points to finish at 212.55, with 1,352 contract transactions.
December TE futures dropped 3.65 points to close at 212, with one contract traded, while June TE futures moved down 0.05 points to close at 210.0, also with one contract traded.
October TF futures rose 4.8 points to end at 1,006.4, with 5,496 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 3.6 points to end at 1,000.6, with 2,059 contracts traded.
December TF futures increased 5 points to close at 998, with seven contract transactions, while March TF futures moved down 1.0 points to finish at 970.2, with one contract traded.
June TF futures surged 12.0 points to close at 999.4, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAJOR DAMAGE CAUSED BY FRIDAY'S QUAKE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: No major damage was caused in Taiwan by Friday's magnitude 7.0 earthquake because the quake's epicenter was well below sea level and far out to sea, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday afternoon.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Yu said that only one man in Ilan City, eastern Taiwan, and another man in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, were reported injured after the temblor struck at 12:08 p.m. Both men suffered only minor injuries, according to local government reports.
The man in Ilan City was hurt when he was hit by falling ceiling debris. He received four stitches on his forehead at a nearby hospital and then returned home.

The Taoyuan County man was injured when his left leg was hit by an iron bar falling from the ceiling which was smashed when a roof-top water tank overturned at the road-side restaurant where he was eating. He returned home after receiving treatment at a nearby hospital.

Also in Toayuan County, a fire broke out at a TECO Electric and Machinery Co. plant only five minutes after the earthquake struck. It remains to be determined whether the fire was caused by the temblor, police said.

The quake's epicenter was located about 110 kilometers off the coast from Ilan City, at a depth of 59 kilometers beneath the surface of the sea, according to the Central Weather Bureau's Seismology Center.

The quake was the strongest to shake Taiwan since the deadly magnitude 7.6 earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, the CWB seismologists said. The 921 earthquake, the deadliest in five decades in Taiwan, killed 2,415 people and injured more than 10,000 others. Some 100,000 residents were displaced in the quake, and damage to property was immeasurable.

Friday's earthquake was also the third strongest "undersea" earthquake since Taiwan began to keeping firefighting records in the early 20th century. A magnitude 8.3 temblor occurred off Keelung, northern Taiwan, on April 12, 1910, and another magnitude 8.3 quake occurred on June 5, 1920, off Hualien, eastern Taiwan, the National Fire Administration reported.
Friday's temblor was felt throughout Taiwan, with Ilan and the neighboring county of Hualien registering the greatest intensity, at 5.

The quake had an intensity of 4 in Taipei and Taoyuan in the north, Taichung and Yunlin in central Taiwan, and Taitung in eastern Taiwan. It had an intensity of 3 in Hsinchu, Miaoli, Changhua, Nantou, Chiayi and Tainan, and an intensity of 2 on Penghu Island in the Taiwan Strait and in Taiwan proper's southernmost city of Pingtung.
CWB seismologists called for the public to be on alert against possible aftershocks, adding that aftershocks of a major earthquake may occur one hour, one day, one week, or even one month afterward.

In Taipei City, the MRT system was shut down immediately after the earthquake struck in accordance with standard operating procedures. Service was resumed about one hour later after the operators made sure that the system had not been affected by the quake.
Meanwhile, the chairwoman of the Taipei 101 Tower, recently certified as the world's tallest building, expressed satisfaction with the sturdy construction of the skyscraper.

Diane Chen said that Friday's earthquake, which had an intensity of 4 in Taipei, has helped prove that the Taipei 101 is safe and strong -- not only in terms of structure, but also the software it is equipped with and the management's emergency response mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES ON TAIEX DOWN

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 10.25 points to close at 5,820.82.

The bourse opened at 5,817.81 and fluctuated between 5,863.91 and 5,782.02 during the day's trading. A total of 3.45 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.48 billion (US$2.17 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 1.1 percent, banking and financial shares at 1 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, and cement stocks and textile stocks, both at 0.3 percent.
Meanwhile, machinery and electronics shares moved down 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 374 to 275, with 149 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.004 to close at NT$33.866.
A total of US$470 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.892 and hit a low of NT$33.856.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECORATES OUTSTANDING VETERAN WRITERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated five noted veteran writers with the Order of Propitious Clouds with Grand Cordon Friday in recognition of their literary achievements.
The honored writers were Bo Yang, Chung Chao-cheng, Yeh Shih-tao, Chi Chun and Chi Pang-yuan.
Chen said the decoration symbolizes recognition of the five veteran writers' career achievements and remarkable contributions to the promotion of Taiwan's cultural and literary development.

On behalf of all honored recipients, Bo Yang, who was imprisoned for some 10 years during Taiwan's martial law era due to his criticism of then-top government leaders, said the decoration signifies Taiwan's evolution to a liberal democracy.

"Now is a brand new era in Taiwan. The government recognizes our literary creations. The decoration ensures that we will never suffer literary persecution again, " said Bo Yang whose real name is Kuo Yi-tung.
In addition to creative writing, Bo Yang is also a noted columnist specializing in analyzing major social and political events.

Chung Chao-cheng has dedicated himself to Taiwan-centered literary writing and the promotion of Hakka culture. Yeh Shi-tao has also contributed much to the development of Taiwanese literature. Chi Chun is known for her novels and prose rooted in traditional Chinese culture and Chi Pang-yuan has been a respected literary commentator and has translated many English literary works into Mandarin.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIGITIZATION IS TRANSFORMING LIFE IN 21ST CENTURY: HP CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: The 21st century is a totally different era from the past, with digitization being one of the transformational trends that is changing people's lifestyle, according to visiting Hewlett-Packard Company Chairwoman Carly Fiorina Friday.

Delivering a speech in Taipei, Fiorina said a massive transformation is taking place, in which every process and all content is being transformed from physical, static and analog, to digital, mobile, virtual and personal.
For instance, Fiorina said, while only 20 percent of cameras were digital five years ago, they are the mainstream product in the camera market today.

Individuals will enjoy easier access to knowledge and services in the future, and all technological, recreational and government services will have to be redesigned to meet individual needs, Fiorina said.
She said technology firms and technology-oriented countries like Taiwan must realize the importance of safety, reliability and adaptability of technology.
For society, corporations and individuals alike, those having a higher degree of pliability will enjoy the more advantages, she said.
Another trend is that value is delivered horizontally, not vertically, according to Fiorina.
Taking Taiwan as an example, she said both corporations and the government adopted a vertical organization in the past and created value by setting up different divisions.
However, value is now derived from the connection between different divisions and different products, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP SUGGESTS MANDARIN SHOULD BE TAIWAN'S OFFICIAL LANGUAGE

TEXT.P: All languages used in Taiwan should be treated as national languages, but Mandarin should be the only official language, a group suggested Friday.

The group, composed of scholars, experts and government officials, made the suggestion while discussing how to preserve and develop ethnic languages. The conclusions of the group will be submitted to an ethnic and cultural development conference scheduled for Oct. 16-18 in Taipei.

The participants said that the languages of all ethnic groups should be treated as equal, and that they should be considered national languages. Mandarin will not be the only language with the honor of national language, they said.

Establishing the official language must take into consideration the language most people use and the one that is most convenient for communication; therefore, Mandarin is most acceptable, they maintained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES US$1 MILLION TO GRENADA TO HELP WITH HURRICANE RELIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Following dispatching relief goods and foodstuffs to Grenada since early September, the Republic of China donated US$1 million in cash Friday to Grenada to help with post-disaster rehabilitation in the Caribbean island country that was ravaged by Hurricane Ivan Sept. 7.

Grenada Premier Keith Mitchell received a check for the money on behalf of the Grenada people presented by Jiang Lii-shang, ROC ambassador to the Caribbean country, at a ceremony held at Mitchell's office Friday.
Addressing the presentation ceremony, Mitchell offered his sincerest appreciation to Taiwan for its magnanimity and compassion.
Mitchell assured Jiang that his administration will use the money efficiently to help the people get back on their feet again and expressed his hopes that Taiwan will continue to help to his country.
Mitchell also stressed the importance of the realization of a promise that Taiwan has made to Grenada on helping build a sports stadium in his country.
Once the stadium is built, he said, it would be the largest and best-equipped sports stadium throughout the entire Caribbean.
He added that the stadium will also showcase Taiwan's strength and magnanimity if it were used as the venue of the 2007 World Cricket Games, which will be held in Grenada that year.

After learning that Hurricane Ivan had struck Grenada on Sept. 7, President Chen Shui-bian and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen telephoned the Grenada government to express their concern about the disaster.
Minister Chen also instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs staff to dispatch US$200,000 in relief materials bought in Venezuela to Grenada in the following days.

Meanwhile, the ROC embassy in Grenada's capital of St. George's saved the US$5,000 that was originally allocated for the Oct. 10 ROC National Day celebrations and donated the sum to the Grenada government for relief.
On Sept. 18, Minister Chen traveled to Grenada to express concern over the natural disaster and facilitating the donations.

Immediately after that, the Taiwan agro-tech mission gave more than 10,000 seedlings of vegetables and crops to the people of Grenada, followed by the arrival of a full container of foods and clothes donated by ROC citizens residing in the greater New York area.

Grenada has maintained a close and friendly relationship with Taiwan since both sides established official diplomatic relations 15 years ago. The Caribbean country also spoke up for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations at this year's U.N. Steering Committee meeting held Sept. 16 in New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH INSURANCE BUREAU SEEKS TO IMPROVE QUOTA SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) President Liu Chien-hsiang Friday pledged to continue to consult with the medical sector for measures to improve the quota system on medical expenditure coverage.

During a public hearing on the issue at the Legislative Yuan, Liu said the purpose of the quota system is to control unnecessary increases in medical spending and to let the medical sector share the responsibility in managing medical resources.
The bureau will negotiate with representatives of the medical sector to set proper quotas while protecting people's right to quality medical services, Liu said.

To prevent the waste of medical resources and to save the cash-strapped insurance program from going bankrupt, the government has set quotas on health insurance coverage of medical spending depending on the level of the hospital.
The hearing was held after a group of medical staff from nearly 500 regional hospitals islandwide staged a demonstration earlier this week to demand the quota for regional hospitals be raised.
The protesters claimed the low quota was insufficient to cover their costs and was forcing them to go out of business.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: New malaria vaccine will save millions of children.
Malaria could be eliminated from the world in a generation, with a groundbreaking new vaccine set to fight a disease which kills over a million children every year.
Financial Times: Yukos knock-down sale plan.
The Russian government on Thursday night appeared to be preparing to sell the main asset of Yukos, the country's embattled oil company, for as little as $4bn - a fraction of its fair value - in a move analysts branded as "daylight robbery" and a "worst-case scenario".

DOC.HEADLINE: SMALL BUSINESSES IT BUDGETS TO FOCUS ON SOFTWARE IN 2005: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's small businesses will maintain a similar spending in the field of information technology (IT) for 2005 as this year, focusing on the improvement of their software, a recent survey has found.

According to poll results released Thursday by IBM (Taiwan) , about 70 percent of Taiwan's small- and medium-sized businesses will match their 2004 budget next year for their IT facilities, mainly to upgrade their software to improve their knowledge management system, set up company portal Web sites, improve their electronic working processes and step up security.
The trends mark a departure from last year's mainstream on building e-mail or Web systems, an indication which an IBM executive said shows that e-solutions are in greater demand in Taiwan.

Some 20 percent of the companies polled said that they will increase their IT expenditures to modernize their e-solution equipment. Professional technology, service efficiency and flexibility are their top considerations while selecting a service provider, according to the survey. Price factors came after these elements -- contrary to a popular assumption, it discovered.
According to the IBM executive, a lack of correct information and backward corporate cultures are the leading barriers for domestic small businesses to launch their e-solution programs.
To sharpen small businesses' willingness and capabilities for advanced knowledge, business owners must have a clear concept and create an adequate business environment to collaborate, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTS OF TAIWAN'S PLUTONIUM EXPERIMENTS 20 YEARS OUT OF DATE: U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Recent reports that Taiwan conducted plutonium separation experiments refer to events 20 or 30 years ago, a spokesman for the U.S. State Department said Thursday.

Richard Boucher made the remarks in response to reports that preliminary samples taken in Taiwan by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) indicated that plutonium separation experiments probably continued until the 1980s. Plutonium is the raw material to produce nuclear weapons.
Boucher said the reports referred to what happened in Taiwan in the 1970s and 1980s, and that the IAEA is studying the history of the matter.
It was common knowledge that Taiwan worked with the IAEA on monitoring measures on the security of plutonium in the 1970s, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINARS IN TAIPEI SHOULD HELP 'NEW IMMIGRANTS' IN TAIWAN ADJUST

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government will host two seminars on Oct. 16 and 23 for foreign and mainland Chinese spouses of local citizens to help them adjust to life in Taiwan and introduce them to the nation's social welfare resources.

Many of the "new immigrants" who live in low-income families in Neihu and Nankang lack the basic understanding of jobs, social resources and laws that govern them, city social services worker Chen Pei-ping said Friday.
Children's education and day-care are other problems, Chen added.

In order to resolve the problems, Chen said officials from the city's Department of Labor, Bureau of Social Affairs and other relevant agencies, as well as representatives of private social welfare organizations such as the Eden Social Welfare Foundation will be invited to the seminars.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CROSS-STRAIT LITERATURE CONTEST REGISTRATION OPENS

TEXT.P: Registrations are being accepted until Nov. 30 for the first cross-strait cyber-literature competition, organizers said Friday.
The Cyber-Literature Award for romantic fiction is jointly organized by Taiwan's Business Weekly Publications and mainland China's Shantou University Press.

The prizes to be handed out total nearly NT$1 million (US$29,500) , with NT$400,000 cash to be awarded to the first-prize winner. The stories of the winners will also be published, according to organizers.
The word limit for submissions is between 60,000 and 120,000, and the deadline is Dec. 31.
The winners will be announced in March next year.
For more information, see the official Web site at www.novelnet.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTILE INTERNATIONAL FORUM AND EXHIBITION TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The International Textile Forum and Exhibition 2004 will be held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei Oct. 21-22, organizers said Friday.

The exhibition is organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and several other organizations including the Industrial Technology Research Institute, the Taiwan Textile Research Institute, the Taiwan Textile Federation, the Taiwan Footwear Research Institute and the Institute for Information Industry. The event will bring together textile experts from the United States, Australia, Japan, Singapore and China.
The displayed items will include textile products using nanotechnology and articles with specific functions such as for the medical field and safety equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY DOWNSIZING TO BE FINISHED IN 2009

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has advanced the date for achieving the goal of downsizing the military to below 300,000 personnel from 2012 to 2009, according to a defense ministry report released Friday.

The report on the defense ministry's policy and budget plan for 2005, which was submitted to the Legislative Yuan Friday, says that the unreasonable structure of the military is hampering its modernization.
The military hopes the downsizing will enable it to better use defense resources, diversify the use of manpower and rationalize the structure of the defense budget, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANIZING COMMITTEE FOR KAOHSIUNG 2009 WORLD GAMES INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The organizing committee for the 2009 Kaohsiung World Games was formally launched Friday, with Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh serving as chairman of the committee.

According to an agreement signed between Kaohsiung City and the International World Games Association (IWGA) , Kaohsiung City Government representatives will travel to Duisburg, Germany next July to participate in the closing ceremony of the 2005 World Games and will receive the World Games flag.
Kaohsiung will also put on an eight- or 10-minute performance at the ceremony to promote Taiwan and the Kaohsiung Games.
In February 2005, Kaohsiung will also send a delegation to Duisburg to attend the coordination meeting of the IWGA to observe how Duisburg prepares for its Games.
Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Lin Yung-chien led a delegation to the Athens Olympic Games this August to gain experience in hosting international competitions.
Hsieh welcomed all those who are experts in the private, academic and sports sectors or anyone who is versed in international affairs to join his advisory group.
Kaohsiung was awarded the right to host the Games on July 1 this year.
Noting that there are myriads of things to do after signing the contract with the IWGA, the organizing committee will be a good start for all other preparations, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ENCOURAGES VOLUNTEERISM IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: In a gesture to show the world Taiwan's keen interest in humanitarian activities, President Chen Shui-bian will give a speech and present a flag to an overseas volunteer service group Saturday at an international seminar held in Taipei.
The president will elaborate on the meaning and significance of Taiwan's volunteer services abroad and encourage the departing group to do its best to serve people in need, organizers said.

The seminar, co-sponsored by the non-profit International Cooperation and Development Fund and Taiwan ThinkTank, on international cooperation, will invite Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore to deliver an address through video conferencing.

Many other foreign dignitaries will also take part in the event, including various ambassadors stationed in Taipei and Kunihiko Saito, a former Japanese ambassador to the United States, as well as representatives from the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) and the Mercy Corps based in the United States and their Taiwan counterparts.
The JICA-affiliated Japan Overseas Cooperation Volunteers -- one of the world's largest volunteer groups -- sends about 1,300 youth to 64 countries every year.

An official at Taiwan ThinkTank said that President Chen attaches a great deal of importance to Taiwan's overseas volunteer services and is proud of the marked achievements obtained by the country's alternative military servicemen doing volunteer work in foreign countries.

In the face of Taiwan's diplomatic isolation in the international community, the country can pride itself in playing a role in offering humanitarian and economic assistance to other countries, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WELCOMES TOP MAINLAND NEGOTIATOR TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday he supported the Mainland Affairs Council's (MAC's) invitation to the top mainland Chinese negotiator to visit Taiwan, saying Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) is welcome to visit the island.
Yu echoed the MAC's invitation to Wang during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session.
During the session, opposition People First Party Legislator Huang Yi-chiao asked Yu about his attitude toward MAC Chairman Joseph Wu's open invitation to Wang a day earlier.
"I definitely support Wu's move. The government's stance is consistent," Yu said.

Wu extended his invitation to Wang while addressing a seminar Thursday, saying Wang is welcome to visit Taipei to meet with his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
During Friday's legislative session, the Cabinet's top mainland policy planner was asked about the possibility of Wang traveling to Taipei for a new round of Koo-Wang meetings.
In response, Wu said the MAC is sincere in inviting Wang to Taipei. Nevertheless, he would not elaborate.
Earlier in the day, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san told a news conference that Wang agreed to visit Taiwan during his meeting with Koo in Shanghai in 1998.

"We sincerely invite Wang to visit Taipei at an appropriate time for a third Koo-Wang meeting, " Chiu said, adding that the MAC hopes the two elder statesmen can jointly turn a new page in the development of cross-strait relations.

Chiu said negotiators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait met in Hong Kong in 1992 where both sides displayed the attitude of "shelving disputes on sovereignty and pragmatically engaging in consultations."

Although no substantial agreement was reached at the 1992 Hong Kong meeting, Chiu said it paved the way for the historic Koo-Wang meeting in Singapore the following year. It was the first-ever high-level meeting between the two sides after a hiatus of nearly five decades.

The ice-breaking meeting laid the foundation for regular SEF-ARATS dialogues. A flurry of cross-strait contacts afterward also made possible a second Koo-Wang meeting in Shanghai in 1998. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogues in mid-1999 to vent its anger at then-President Lee Teng-hui's defining cross-strait relations as "state-to-state" in nature.

Noting that people on both sides of the Strait look forward to a third Koo-Wang meeting to complete the unfinished consultations in 1998, Chiu said the MAC welcomes Wang to visit Taipei to realize this common wish.

"Earlier this week, Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, also expressed the hope in a news conference in Beijing that the two sides can enhance mutual understanding through increased civilian exchanges and cooperation, " Chiu said, adding that since Beijing desires enhanced mutual understanding, it should jointly work with Taiwan to pave the way for a third Koo-Wang meeting.
"We have extended our invitation. We'll show maximum goodwill and flexibility in making concerted efforts with Beijing to craft a setting for a third Koo-Wang meeting," Chiu added.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRAISES TAIWAN'S OLDEST MOTORCYCLE MANUFACTURER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian heaped praise on Taiwan's oldest motorcycle manufacturer Friday at the company's 50-year anniversary.

The president hailed Sanyang Industrial Co. for setting five "Taiwan first" records: the producer of the first motorcycle on the island; the first Taiwanese motorcycle company with its own trade mark promoted worldwide; the first motorcycle enterprise with whole-plant export experience to other countries; the largest R&D facilities in Taiwan for motorcycles; and the first company able to produce cars and motorcycles at the same time.
The five "Taiwan first" records have contributed significantly to Taiwan's economy, and reflect the process of Taiwan's economic development during the last half century, Chen added.

Chen noted that according to a report released by the World Economic Forum Wednesday, Taiwan was ranked fourth in the world in terms of the Growth Competitiveness Index, and holds the top spot in Asia for a third consecutive year.

Although Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said modestly that Taiwan must work harder to vie for third place in the world in terms of growth competitiveness, Chen encouraged everyone to strive to be number one.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER MAKES LOW-PROFILE VISIT TO SPAIN

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Ou-Yang Jui-hsiung has traveled to Spain to preside over the opening of an exhibition of contemporary Taiwan works of art, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Friday.

Ou-Yang and Wang Yu-yuan, director of the MOFA's European Affairs Department, left for Spain Wednesday, Lu said, adding that their visit is part of the government's efforts to promote substantive Taiwan-Spanish relations and cultural exchanges.
A MOFA official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Ou-Yang has kept a low profile at the request of the Spanish government.

"While Spain looks forward to enhancing cultural exchanges and substantive relations with Taiwan, it would not like to draw the protest and displeasure from Beijing, " the official said. "Therefore, Ou-Yang did not disclosed his travel plans to the media before his departure."
"The main purpose of his visit is to preside over the opening of the Contemporary Formosan Artworks Exhibition at the Museum of Barcelona," the official said, adding that the show opened Friday.

According to the official, the exhibition is part of the Barcelona museum's Asian arts festival activities. The show features contemporary Taiwan paintings and artifacts, the official said, adding that the exhibits will offer the audience a glimpse into Taiwan's modern culture and the differences between contemporary Taiwan artworks and ancient Chinese ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG CITY CARES ABOUT ITS FOREIGNERS: CITY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The central Taiwan city of Taichung is transforming itself into a more progressive place due to its emphasis on the needs of its foreign residents, a city government official said Friday.
He pointed to the fact that the city has commissioned consulting companies to find out the needs of foreigners.

In addition to publishing pamphlets for foreigners to better understand the city, the city government will hold a seminar on Oct. 23, inviting foreign expatriates to make suggestions to the government on how to make Taichung a friendlier city for foreigners.
All of these are part of the city government's efforts to make the city more internationalized, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. launches airstrikes on Falluja.
U.S. warplanes pounded the insurgent stronghold of Fallujah on Friday, a day after the city's leaders suspended peace talks and rejected the Iraqi government's demands to turn over terror mastermind Abu Musab al-Zarqawi. l-Zarqawi's Tawhid and Jihad group has clai med responsibility for Thursday's twin bombings inside Baghdad's heavily guarded Green Zone -- home to U.S. officials and the Iraqi leadership -- which killed six people, including three American civilians. A fourth American was missing and presumed dead.
Wall Street Journal: Spitzer charges bid rigging in insurance.
Marsh & McLennan Cos., the world's biggest insurance broker, cheated corporate clients by rigging bids and collecting huge fees from major insurance companies for throwing business their way, according to allegations made by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer. Spitzer's charges came in a civil suit as well as in plea- bargain deals on criminal charges against two insurance executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL TO FOCUS ON IMPROVING TAIWAN'S INT'L STATUS

TEXT.P: The National Security Council (NSC) will focus on improving Taiwan's international status in its operations for next year, according to an NSC report presented Friday to the Legislative Yuan.

The report said that the NSC will organize international conferences on global and regional security cooperation on a larger scale and more often to promote bilateral and multilateral cooperation as well as Taiwan's international status.

The NSC will also collect and analyze information on issues related to national defense, foreign relations and cross-Taiwan Strait ties and will come up with countermeasures that should be taken by the government for reference of the president, it added.
Besides, it went on, the NSC will enhance communication channels with friendly nations and allies of Taiwan and will exchange with them information and opinions on matters of mutual concern.
The report was attached to a draft budget from the Presidential Office and its subordinate agencies for 2005 and was presented to the Legislative Yuan for screening.

DOC.HEADLINE: LINGERING US$60/BARREL OIL COULD TRIGGER 'STAGGERING INFLATION': CEPD

TEXT.P: Should oil prices rise above US$60 per barrel and stay there for over a year, Taiwan would be hit with "staggering inflation," a key government official said Friday.

Yeh Ming-feng, vice chairman of the Cabinet's Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that such a situation would push up product prices and drag down the country's economic growth rate.
The CEPD vice chairman made the remarks after the international price of oil skyrocketed to a 21-year high of US$54 per barrel Tuesday in electronic trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Although the price retreated below US$53 per barrel, market analysts pointed out that there was no change in the trend.

As world oil prices have been maintained at a level of over US$50 for more than two weeks, Yeh said that the CEPD may call an inter-ministerial meeting next week to gauge the situation to minimize its impact.
He forecast that the price of oil will not drop below US$50 by the end of this year with the approach of winter in the northern hemisphere.

CEPD officials tried to calm inflation fears by saying that inflationary pressures are under the control of the government, despite the fact that a wave of product price hikes is just around the corner.
Experts have called on the government to work out countermeasures soon to help lead the public and industries through the foreseeable difficulties arising from higher spending and costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO SET UP SPECIAL OFFICE TO BOOST SERVICE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will set up a special office to promote the development of service industry, an official said Friday.
CEPD Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng will personally head the office while CEPD Vice Chairman Hsieh Fa-ta will serve as chief executive to handle day-to-day affairs, the official said.
The special office is scheduled to open at the end of this month, the official said, adding that the office will hire researchers to help draw up comprehensive service industry promotion plans.
Over the next three years, the official said, the government will invest NT$100 million for various service industry promotion programs.

According to the CEPD's plan, the service sector will account for more than 70 percent of Taiwan's annual gross domestic product (GDP) by 2008 and create some 600,000 new jobs. By then, the service sector will hire up to 60 percent of Taiwan's total employed population.
President Chen Shui-bian declared recently his administration's determination to make the service sector Taiwan's new economic growth engine, with "Served by Taiwan" becoming Taiwan's new logo.
"We hope 'Served by Taiwan' will enjoy same popularity as 'Made in Taiwan' in the world market by 2008," Chen said in a public speech delivered late last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEA ANCHOR SPRUCES UP NAVY HEADQUARTERS ENTRANCE

TEXT.P: The entrance to the ROC Navy General Headquarters is now graced with an old Japanese anchor on display, a symbol of the navy's commitment to defending the island's peace and stability.
Sea anchors and anchor chains have traditionally epitomized a navy's combat capability and spirit of solidarity. They can be seen at entrances to nearly all major naval bases around the world.

The sea anchor installed at the ROC Navy General Headquarters in suburban Taipei was built by the Japanese Navy in 1942. It was originally at the Tsoying Naval Base in southern Taiwan. The ROC Navy took over the base when the Japanese surrendered at the end of World War II in 1945.
The sea anchor stands more than 10 meters high. The installation of the sea anchor is part of the ROC Navy General Headquarters' ongoing face-lift to improve the landscape in the nearby area.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NEW TAIWAN CITIZEN MOVEMENT' ON THE WAY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The "new Taiwan citizen movement" is aimed at making people have more cultural confidence in an era of globalization, a professor at National Chengchi University said Friday.
Chen Fang-min noted that Taiwan culture has not been highly valued until recently after being seriously repressed for almost four decades during martial law.
Taiwan, which has been through aboriginal, migration and colonial cultures, has abundant ethnic cultural assets, he noted.

With these characteristics, Taiwan culture is worth discovering by foreign students who are here to learn more about the island, and the people here should have the confidence that their culture can contribute more to human civilization, Chen added.
Chen said he will promote the idea of "new Taiwan citizen movement" in a three-day seminar to be held in Taipei Oct. 16-18.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SEEKS BACKING FOR CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER SERVICE FROM HP HEAD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met Hewlett-Packard Company Chairwoman Carly S. Fiorina Friday and sought her backing for Taiwan's proposal of charter flight services across the Taiwan Strait.
In addition to thanking Fiorina for HP's large purchases every year in Taiwan, Chen also praised her support for cross-strait charter flight services for passengers and cargo.
The HP chairwoman publicly called for cargo charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China last year.

Chen said that Taiwan is keenly hoping for normal trade and economic relations with mainland China and reiterated his call for early two-way negotiations on cross-strait charter services he advocated in his Oct. 10 National Day address.

Stressing that the issue is mutually beneficial for both Taiwan and mainland China and is in the best interests of the United States and the whole world, Chen expressed his hope that Fiorina would help Taiwan seek U.S. support and reflect her backing for the matter to Beijing.
The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should put aside their political disputes and engage in talks "the sooner the better, " the president said.
HP purchased a total of NT$550 billion (US$16.2 billion) in products from Taiwan last year, accounting for two-thirds of the total value registered by all foreign buyers.

The U.S. company is planning to buy NT$580 billion worth of Taiwan products this year and set up a hi-tech research and development center here in three years, which is expected to draw NT$980 million into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PERSUADES HEALTH OFFICIAL TO STAY ON AT POST

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Friday persuaded Chang Hung-jen, deputy minister of the Cabinet-level Department of Health, to stay at his post amid squabbling surrounding the island's health insurance system.

Chang, who is a former president of the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI), offered to resign Thursday for the quota system on medical expenditure coverage he designed as head of the BNHI after a group of medical staff from nearly 500 regional hospitals around the island protested against the system earlier this week.
Yu stressed that politicians should not abandon their goals due to pressure, urging Chang to assume his responsibility and to work hard for the reform of the health insurance system.
Chang agreed to take some days off to consider what to do next.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 16, or the third day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1758: Noah Webster, American lexicographer responsible for the first American dictionary, is born.
1793: The execution of Marie-Antoinette, 38, queen-consort of the late King Louis XVI, and the prospects of further executions by guillotine of both counter-revolutionaries and revolutionaries suggest that France is slipping even deeper into anarchy.
1846: American dentist William T. G. Morton successfully uses an anesthetic (diethyl ether) for the first time and removes a tumor from a young man's jaw at Massachusetts General Hospital.
1886: David Ben-Gurion, first prime minister of Israel, is born in Poland. He was a leading force in the creation of the Israeli state.
1906: British New Guinea becomes part of Australia.
1933: Republic of China government troops launch a fifth all-out offensive against communist rebels by adopting a fort-blockade policy of moving carefully and steadily in a step-by-step fashion.
1946: Ten leading Nazis found guilty some two weeks earlier of crimes against humanity by the International War Crimes Tribunal are hanged in the gymnasium of Nuremberg Prison.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek presents the Chinese communists with eight conditions for a nationwide cease-fire.
1949: The Kuomintang establishes the Revolutionary Practice Institute with party leader Chiang Kai-shek as its president.
1951: Liaquat Ali Khan, prime minister of Pakistan, is shot dead while addressing a public meeting in Rawalpindi.
1959: George C. Marshall, American soldier, diplomat and politician, dies at the age of 78. As U.S. secretary of state, he organized the European Recovery Program, often called the Marshall Plan, for which he received the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize.
1963: Ludwig Erhard succeeds Konrad Adenauer as chancellor of West Germany.
1964: Communist China explodes its first atom bomb at the Lop Nor test site in Sinkiang.
1972: President Dawda Kairbr Jawara of Gambia arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives a 30-member delegation of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. The group is headed by Eastern Washington State College President Emerson C. Shuck.
1978: Polish Cardinal Karol Wojtyla is elected pope, the first non-Italian pope since 1542 and the youngest this century.
1979: Wei Jingsheng, noted human rights activist in mainland China, is sentenced to 15 years imprisonment by a "people's court" in Beijing for "anti-revolutionary" activities.
1981: Moshe Dayan, Israeli politician and minister of defense, dies of a heart attack at the age of 66. He directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old mainland Chinese air force pilot, flies his MiG-19 to a U.S. military base outside Seoul in South Korea.
1982: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, 1970 Nobel Prize winner for literature, arrives in Taiwan from Tokyo at the invitation of the Wu San-lien Literary Foundation of the Republic of China.
1984: Chiang Nan, pen name of Chinese writer Liu Yi-liang, is shot and killed by an assassin at his home in San Francisco.
1987: The worst storm to hit Britain in 300 years lashes southern Britain, demolishing buildings, blacking out London and killing 18 people.
1989: A committee of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, meeting in Lausane, Switzerland, votes 76-11 in favor of a ban on international trade in ivory.
1999: The ROC navy's destroyer "Kunyang" is formally decommissioned after 31 years of service.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh says that he feels no remorse for having thrown his weight behind President Chen Shui-bian in the later stages of the presidential campaign in March of the same year.
2001: Taiwan atmospheric scientists successfully obtains vital typhoon data by flying two remote-control aircraft close to the depression's eyewall, a world first for any flying object collecting meteorological information.
2001: A Taipei delegation leaves for Indonesia to attend the 46th Asia Pacific Film Festival in Jakarta.
2001: Taiwan's Picvue Electronics, Ltd. invests US$12 million to engage in research and development of crystal display plates with two Scottish manufacturers.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, even when he is not doing anything, is serious; and, even when he does not speak, is truthful."

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC MEETING ON HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM TO BE HELD IN DECEMBER: DOH

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen pledged Saturday to hold a civic meeting before the end of this year to discuss measures to reform the National Health Insurance program.
Chen, who is a professor at National Taiwan University's College of Public Health, is on special leave from the university until Dec. 31 to join government service.
Chen said he hopes that holding the civic meeting will help to achieve a consensus on reforming the insurance program, which has been operating at a loss, before he leaves the DOH.
He said the DOH is currently planning to hold the civic meeting in December, after representatives to the meeting are selected in November.
Meanwhile, on DOH Deputy Minister Chang Hung-jen's offer to resign, Chen said he hopes Chang will change his mind and stay.

Chang tendered his resignation earlier this week after the allocation system on health insurance coverage triggered a strong backlash from regional hospitals which complained that the allocation of medical resources under the system is unfair.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS TO PLAY MORE ACTIVE ROLE IN INTERNATIONAL AID: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen urged the international community Saturday to give Taiwan fair opportunities to take part in international aid projects with dignity.

Chen made the appeal while delivering a keynote speech at the opening of a seminar on the general world trends in foreign aid, co-sponsored by the International Cooperation and Development Fund under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Taiwan Thinktank, a private group.
Because of Beijing's ubiquitous diplomatic embargo, Chen said, Taiwan faces serious difficulties joining international cooperative programs.

"International isolation has denied us fair opportunities to participate in international aid projects with dignity, " Chen said, adding that unreasonable restrictions have hindered enforcement of Taiwan's international aid work.

For instance, Chen said, Taiwan has donated funds to help finance post-war reconstruction projects in Afghanistan and Iraq. Much to its regret, Chen added, Taiwan was barred from sending representatives to attend international donors meetings held in Japan simply because of Beijing's opposition. "This was extremely unfair to us," he lamented.

In the early years of Taiwan's economic development, Chen said, Taiwan received aid from other countries. Through such assistance and the concerted efforts of the Taiwan people, Taiwan has now emerged as the world's 15th largest trading nation.
"We are now able and willing to share our knowledge and experience with other developing countries through international cooperative programs, " Chen said.
"So long as Taiwan is granted fair opportunities and dignified treatment, it will definitely be able to play an active and constructive role in the world arena," he added.

Despite facing "political apartheid" in the world community, Chen said the Republic of China government will continue to join international humanitarian aid projects and assist needy countries in economic development in order to fulfill its duty as a member of the Global Village.
Moreover, Chen said, the ROC government will help Taiwan's non-government organizations and private groups to take part in more international humanitarian aid projects in the future.

Experts from the Japan International Cooperation Agency have been invited to attend the seminar to offer counseling on the promotion of international aid work. Other conference goers include local scholars, social workers and business executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:Youths invited to put ideas to work.
Young Singaporeans who spoke up during a six-week consultation exercise that has just ended want a better and more inclusive Singapore. Now, they are being given a chance to put their ideas into action.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Government is giving out the final Economic Restructuring Shares (ERS) next year early.
The Government is giving out the third and final lot of ERS next year,but 650,000 self- employed and unemployed Singapoereans who do not top up their Central Provident Fund (CPF) accounts by the end of this year may miss out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST 2007 WORLD ASSOCIATION OF WOMEN ENTREPRENEURS CONGRESS
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan delegation attending the world congress of the World Association of Women Entrepreneurs (FCEM) in Scotland has won the right for Taiwan to host the event in 2007.
The 52nd world congress of the organization was held in Glasgow, the largest city in Scotland, Oct. 10-14, with more than 200 delegates from more than 40 countries taking part.

The FCEM, originally a businesswomen's group in France set up following the Second World War, has grown to become a global organization with the aim of promoting solidarity and friendship among women entrepreneurs around the world.
The Taiwan delegation arrived at the venue of the congress on the ROC's Double Ten National Day, and its members took the opportunity to explain the significance of the day.
The delegation also made a generous donation during a banquet that night for a charity auction initiated by Princess Anne of Britain.
The Taiwan delegates also used the meeting to promote understanding of Taiwan, winning friendship as well as support for Taiwan to host the FCEM world congress in 2007.
