The Washington Post: Crucial Florida Vote May Hinge On Burgeoning Latino Population
The state that decided the 2000 election remains as deeply divided over the choice for president today as it was four years ago, with President Bush and Sen. John F. Kerry deadlocked in Florida amid signs of extraordinary intensity and partisanship among voters, according to a new survey by The Washington Post, Univision and the Tomas Rivera Policy Institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Importing less expensive drugs not seen as cure for U.S. woes.
U.S. Senator John Kerry, the Democratic presidential candidate, has made a campaign pledge to help cut Americans' prescription drug costs by allowing them to import drugs from Canada. President Bush has conceded that the idea is worth a try "if there's a safe way to do it. "Bipartisan legislation in Congress would allow the reimportation of prescription drugs from Canada and other industrialized countries. It may make political sense to point to Canadaas a solution to high prescription drug prices in the United States. But many economists and health care experts say that importing drugs from countries that control their prices would do little to solve the problem of expensive drugs in the United States, where companies are free to set their own prices. Even the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimated that allowing Canadian drug imports would have a " negligible" impact on drug spending.
Wall Street Journal: Greenspan warns further jump in oil prices would intensify risk
High oil prices have damped economic growth and a further increase would risk "more serious negative consequences," U.S. Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan said Friday. High oil prices have a lready trimmed about three-quarters of a percentage point off economic growth this year, Greenspan said in a speech to the National Italian American Foundation in Washington. That is a far smaller effect than when oil shot up in the 1970s, he said. But the "risk of more serious negative consequences would intensify if oil prices were to move materially higher."

DOC.HEADLINE: 35% OF WHITE-COLLAR WORKERS REGULARLY STAY LATE AT OFFICE: POLL

TEXT.P: Some 35 percent of white-collar workers in Taiwan regularly remain at the office after their normal work hours are up, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

Topping the list of reasons for staying late was unfinished work, mentioned by 61.47 percent of the respondents, followed by a desire to work harder in the hopes of earlier career advancement, mentioned by 26.61 percent. The No. 3 reason was wanting to use the office facilities for things not related to work, mentioned by 24.77 percent of the respondents.
The survey was conducted by the 1111 Job Bank between Oct. 7-15 on 2,172 white-collar workers. The poll is said by its authors to have a margin of error of plus or minus 2.1 percentage points.

The results seem to correspond with the 2003 Year Competitiveness Yearbook released by the International Institute for Management Development, which showed that the Taiwan people top the global list in terms of average number of work hours per person in a year at 2,282.

According to human resources statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics in September of this year, Taiwan workers in the 20-29 age group work an average of 2,159 hours per year; while those in the 30-39 age group work 2,166 hours per year; and those in the 40-49 age group work 2,170 hours.

The 111 Job Bank survey found that 52 percent of the respondents feel lonely and empty after work, while 60 percent said they could not identify their goals in life. These two problems were found by the survey to be most common among workers in the 20-29 age group.

1111 Job Bank spokesman Wu Rui-ying attributed this to the fact that most people under 30 years old are single and therefore tend to feel lonely if they have no one to talk to after work. He also said that most workers in this age group are not married and don't have a family, adding that after they get married, their "family" will automatically give their life a a purpose.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL FOREIGN AID OFFERED IN LINE WITH LEGAL PROCEDURES: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's aid to its diplomatic allies has consistently followed stringent legal procedures, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Saturday.
Chen was responding to reports that Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos may be impeached due to his alleged acceptance of huge foreign political contributions.

Noting that the government has long formulated comprehensive regulations governing the offering of aid to other countries, Chen said, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is unlikely to distribute foreign aid in violation of those rules.

For instance, Chen explained, the government usually signs a five-year cooperative agreement with the aid recipient country in the first phase, with the agreement outlining concrete cooperative items, such as the building of bridges or hospitals, followed by the MOFA providing funds in accordance with progress in each specific construction project.

While Taiwan follows its legal procedures to the letter in offering aid to foreign countries, Chen said that the manner in which the recipient countries handle the cooperation projects is a different matter.

Noting that the reported possible impeachment of Bolanos is a Nicaraguan internal affair, Chen said the MOFA is not in a position to comment on or get involved in the issue. He added that the MOFA will ask the nation's embassy in Nicaragua to look into what has happened for its reference.

Asked whether Taiwan has ever offered political contributions to any individual foreign political figures, Chen categorically ruled out the possibility, stressing that foreign aid is primarily aimed at assisting in diplomatic allies' national development and the improvement of their people's livelihood and well-being.

Commenting on media reports that former Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez has been detained for allegedly accepting bribes, including illegal political donations from Taiwan, Chen said the reports were not correct.

"All the allegations about Taiwan offering political contributions to individual foreign political figures were unfounded, " Chen said, adding that Taiwan has consistently followed proper legal procedures in offering aid to its diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARSENIC IN GROUNDWATER INCREASES CANCER RISKS: DOH HEAD

TEXT.P: The nation's top health official said Saturday that regular users of groundwater that contains high levels of arsenic are at greater risk of developing cancer.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen made the remarks while giving a report on the health hazards of arsenic-containing groundwater in a seminar sponsored by the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI).

Chen pointed to a study of residents in southwestern Taiwan and in Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, who regularly use groundwater. The study found a direct relation between arsenic levels in the groundwater and the risk of developing cancer.

In the study, a group of people who regularly drink groundwater with an arsenic level of 300 ppb (parts per billion) was compared with a group who regularly use groundwater with an arsenic level of 0.1 ppb. The results showed that those in the first group were four times more likely to develop lung cancer, eight times more likely to develop bladder cancer, and 20 times more likely to develop skin cancer.

Chen, who is an epidemiologist, said that a person who regularly uses groundwater and who also smokes is 15 times more likely to develop lung cancer than someone who does not. He therefore urged those who drink groundwater to check the arsenic level and filter out the heavy metal, and advised smokers to quit.
Chen said that drinking groundwater that contains arsenic can also lead to pancreatic problems, dementia, diabetes, and cardiovascular problems.

He noted that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the World Health Organization have revised the safety standard for arsenic levels in water to 10 ppb from the original 50 ppb, and that Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration followed suit last year.

Wang Shu-li, an NHRI associate researcher, speaking on the same occasion, said that many residents in Peimeng, Hsuehchia in Tainan County used to suffer from an endemic disease called "black foot disease" in the 1950s because of long-term use of artesian well water that contained high levels of arsenic.
Now, the ratio of Peimeng and Hsuehchia residents who suffer from pancreatic problems, diabetes, retinal problems, or cardiovascular problems is much higher than for residents in the rest of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO SENDS PETITION AGAINST ARMS BAN LIFTING TO E.U. MISSIONS IN L.A.
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's de facto consulate in Los Angeles sent a petition Friday to the L.A. missions of 23 E.U. member nations urging that the European Union's ban on arms sales to mainland China not be lifted.
The petition was written under the name of Wei Wu-lien, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Los Angeles, with the signatures of hundreds of Taiwanese and foreign supporters.

The petition urges the European Union not to lift its arms embargo against mainland China for the sake of global security and peace, and calls the European Union's attention to Beijing's continuous military buildup.
It also warns that a lifting of the ban would sharpen the crisis across the Taiwan Strait, spur an arms race, and give rise to regional conflict.
In early October, the TECO in L.A. also launched a "Global E-petition Campaign" on the GoPetition Web site, a leading non-partisan petition hosting portal.

Officials from the TECO's L.A. office said that the campaign has won the support of nearly 600 people from around the world and that they hope the number of signatures collected in the campaign will top those of all the other petitions posted on the Web site by the end of the month. The petition will then be submitted to the European Parliament, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO HELP DEVELOPMENT OF ELECTRONICS SECTOR

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday that the government will continue to provide an investment environment that is conducive to the stable growth of the electronics industry and to work to build Taiwan into a "technology island."

Addressing the opening of the 2004 Taipei International Electronics Show on finished products, Yu said the electronics sector can claim much credit for Taiwan's excellent competitiveness showing -- which ranks fourth in the world according to the 2004-2005 Global Competitiveness Report released by the World Economic Forum.

In the World Competitiveness Yearbook 2004 published by the International Institute for Management Development, Taiwan's competitiveness ranked 12th in the world, up from 17th place for the previous year, Yu pointed out.

With Taiwan's economy recovering since the second half of last year, export orders and the volume of outbound shipments are hitting new highs, and investment by the private sector has increased by 20 percent in the first half of this year, Yu said.

The premier said major economic research institutions in Taiwan have revised their economic growth forecasts for Taiwan for 2004 upward to 5.5 percent -- which, if achieved, would be the highest in four years.

While the semiconductor sector's overall production is expected to top NT$1 trillion (US$29.53 billion) for this year, that of the optoelectronics sector is likely to reach the same level next year, Yu said.

He noted that although the high-tech industries have unlimited development potential, they also face the challenges of a high technology replacement rate and short product lifespan. Therefore, they need to carry on with their research and development efforts to meet these challenges, he added.

The premier said the government will continue to guide the development of the high-tech industries and provide them with a stable and desirable environment in which to operate in order to attract more enterprises to firmly establish their roots in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SATISFIED WITH WETLAND CONSERVATION RESULTS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his satisfaction Saturday after listening to a briefing at the Tzuoying wetland park on the results of wetland conservation efforts in the Tzuoying district of Kaohsiung City.

Accompanied by Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, President Chen listened to the briefing by the city's Public Works Bureau director, Lin Chin-jung, who said the bureau had adopted ecological engineering methods to maintain the equilibrium between man-made environments and natural environments in the wetland park. The cost of the ecological engineering efforts amounted to over NT$8 million (US$242,400) , he added.
The wetland park is home to a wide variety of birds, including egrets and pheasant-tailed jacanas.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER ARRIVES IN ZURICH FOR EVIAN MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long has arrived in Zurich to attend an annual meeting of the EVIAN Group -- an association of elite members in political and business communities in major countries around the world.
It marked the first time that Chen has been invited to attend an EVIAN annual meeting which usually focuses on international trade issues.
The 2004 EVIAN meeting opened Saturday for a two-day run. Chen is expected to speak on Taiwan-related subjects at the meeting which would not open for media coverage.
Chen inspected operations of Taiwan's representative office in Zurich after his arrival Thursday afternoon.

Following the EVIAN meeting, Chen will travel to Geneva for a two-day visit. During his stay in Geneva, Chen will meet with senior officials at the World Trade Organization (WTO) headquarters as well as Australia's ambassador to the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE-STAR JAPANESE LINER ARRIVES AT TAICHUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: The five-star Japanese cruise liner "Asuka" arrived at Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan Saturday carrying 558 Japanese passengers.
The visitors were warmly welcomed on their arrival by Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng and officials of the Taichung Harbor Bureau.

While the liner was being escorted into the harbor by a tow boat and a fountain display, folk dancing and music shows were performed at the lobby for the visitors, who were greeted by attendants dressed in kimonos.

The "Asuka," operated by Japan's NYK Cruises Co., ranks 6th among 15 five-star cruise liners mentioned in the Berlitz Complete Guide to Cruising and Cruise Ships. It is also the only five-star cruise liner in Asia.
The 28,856-ton Asuka is about 192 meters long, 24 meters wide and 29 meters high. It has 296 guest rooms -- all with a sea view, with a passenger capacity of 600 people and 270 crew members.
The visitors, who are retired workers of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, have toured around North Europe in the summer before beginning their fall-winter trip in Taiwan and Southeast Asia.
During the trip, the tourists will visit major attractions in Taiwan, including Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County, Lukang in Changhua County, Taichung City, and the National Palace Museum in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR HIKE IN WATER, ELECTRICITY RATES: ECONOMIC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Saturday that the government has no timetable for raising water or electricity rates.

Ho made the remarks in response to reports that the Ministry of Economic Affairs is planning to adjust the country's water and electricity rates separately, with electricity rates expected to be raised first.
Ho said the government will communicate with the public to seek a consensus before making a decision on hiking water or electricity rates.

She said the ministry will present a reasonable pricing calculation plan for the public's reference to make sure the decision-making is transparent, because the adjustment of public utility prices concerns every family and company.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO STEP UP MONITORING OF EELS AFTER ANTIBIOTIC RESIDUES FOUND

TEXT.P: The government will step up monitoring of eels for export following reports that some eels exported to Japan had been found to contain bactericidal residue, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday.

Officials from the COA's Fisheries Administration said that they will issue directives next week calling for antibiotic enrofroxacin tests to be conducted and for the requirement that antibiotic-free certificates be issued before any eels are allowed to be exported.
The officials also asked eel growers to exercise self-discipline, to observe norms in using antibiotics for the eels, and to not use unauthorized bactericide.

The officials said that some Taiwan-originating live eels and processed eel were found last October to contain sulfamethazine (SMZ) , and that Japan kicked off testing of eel imports from Taiwan the following month. SMZ is a drug used to treat a variety of infections.

Since then, the government and the eel growers have taken several steps to strengthen safety controls on eel exports, including implementing the requirement that eels for export be tested for the presence of residue of five types of antibiotics, including SMZ and oxolinic acid.
Every batch of eels exported also has to pass tests to ascertain that they contain no pesticide residues, and must receive export approval from the Fisheries Administration.
The Fisheries Administration also provides aquaculture and management classes to the eel growers.

The officials said that as of the end of this September, no eels exported had been found to contain SMZ residue. Japan lifted its inspection order for Taiwan eels Aug. 9, but recent individual cases have led to a reimposition of the order.

Fishery officials said that they have confidence in upgrading the hygiene quality of Taiwan's eel ponds, adding that they will consistently promote a good aquaculture environment for the eel ponds, establish a good monitoring system, step up the campaign against illegal bactericide, and increase testing for the presence of illegal bactericidal drugs.
Statistics by the Fisheries Administration showed that Taiwan produces about 22,000 tons of eels a year, with 90 percent of that total being exported to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC, CULTURAL DIVERSITY AN IMPORTANT SOCIAL ASSET FOR TAIWAN: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that ethnic and cultural diversity has not only been an important social asset for Taiwan but also a driving force behind the island's social progress.

Addressing the opening of an ethnic and cultural development conference held at the National Central Library, Chen said Taiwan has experienced successive waves of immigration over the past four centuries.

In addition to the aboriginal citizens, native Taiwanese, Hakka and mainlanders that now populate Taiwan, many new immigrants have also come to Taiwan through marriage or naturalization in recent years amid globalization and liberalization, the president said.
"Against this backdrop, our population has become ever more diverse, " Chen said, adding that this ethnic diversity has injected new blood and vitality into local society.

Chen further said the various ethnic groups should respect and recognize one another's differences and unique features in order to create a harmonious living environment and forge a common national identity.

Noting that Taiwan has come a long way in its national development, the president said some historical ethnic rifts might have left wounds and scars. Chen said that he hopes that from now on, all the people of Taiwan can forget and forgive past "mistakes" and treat each other with understanding, respect and goodwill.
"Let's forget any bitter memories. Let's see no more ethnic disharmony, and let's work hand-in-hand for national progress and prosperity from now on," he urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POETRY HEARD AT PARIS READING FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Low Yuan-shao & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The lyric voice of Tu Ying-hui from Taiwan floated through the air of the East Railway Station in Paris Saturday as she read a poem in Chinese in front of a crowd of book-lovers sitting on a corner at the station, one of 18 major railway stations in cities around France that have joined in the annual Reading Festival.

Tu works for Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, and her job is to encourage residents nationwide to read. In order to study France's efforts in promoting reading, Tu came to Paris to participate in the 16th Reading Festival that kicked off Friday around the country and will last for three days.
She read a poem by Taiwanese poet Chen Yi-chi to the onlookers, while Tang Shu-chuan, a staff member of Taitung City Government's Department of Cultural Affairs, read a verse of Tang poetry.

Tu told the Central News Agency that various activities related to the reading festival have not only been held at schools, libraries and bookstores around France, but also in public spaces, such as railway stations and street corners, and even at some hospitals and prisons.

She said that it is difficult for efforts at promoting reading to bear fruit in a short period of time, but added that through the organizing of colorful and interesting activities, like the annual Reading Festival in France, people can be drawn to experience the joy of reading.
France has held the annual Reading Festival for the past 16 years, while the festival activity at the railway stations has been held for the last seven years.

The 2004 festival has a "bookstore" theme, with organizers arranging an activity called "sleepless in bookstores, " inviting the public to remain late in bookstores that stay open until midnight or around the clock during the festival.
According to the French Ministry of Cultural Affairs, the reading festival has so far been introduced into 91 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN TRANSMISSION OF BIRD FLU ACCIDENTAL: EXPERT

TEXT.P: The recent report of avian flu transmission in a Thai family does not mean there will be an outbreak, an epidemiologist said Saturday.

Michael M. C. Lai, vice president of the Academia Sinica, made the remarks when he delivered a speech on the mystery of the virus and its impact on human beings. The speech was one of the activities to mark the 50th anniversary of the top research institute in Taiwan.

He said the accidental transmission of bird flu to humans should be considered as accidental cases as it is not a human flu after all. The health of each individual varies and so there is this isolated case.

However, he added that if a person contracts the bird flu and the human flu simultaneously, then the genes of the two viruses could interact and mutate into a new virus, which would then be a source of serious concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU BREAKS LONGEST RICE NOODLE RECORD

TEXT.P: The 2004 Hsinchu rice noodle and pork meatball festival kicked off in the northern Taiwan city Saturday.
Rice noodles and pork meatballs are Hsinchu's most famous delicacies, and the city wants to use the festival to promote them and the city.

Hsinchu Mayor Lin Cheng-tze invited the mayors of Hsinchu's sister cities in the United States and Japan -- namely Mayor Pat Evans from the city of Plano in Texas and Mayor Seiji Hagiwara from Okayama City -- to join him and Hsinchu residents in making the longest rice noodle in the world.
Together, they were able to make a rice noodle 12,000 centimeters in length, shattering the old world record of 10,000 centimeters and bringing the day's activities to a climax.
The three mayors then displayed their culinary skills by frying the rice noodles. Their "rice noodle dishes" were then put up for charity auction, fetching a total of NT$16,000 (US$473).
Evans and Hagiwara also brought with them several members of council of their respective cities, and they all enjoyed rice noodles and pork meatballs cooked in various styles.

Lin Kuang-hua, governor of the Taiwan provincial government, welcomed the foreign guests to the festival and invited them to Hsinpu Township in Hsinchu County later to savor another local delicacy -- preserved persimmon -- and to experience the Hakka culture there.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC COUNTRIES URGED TO FORGE JOINT MISSILE DEFENSE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Asia-Pacific countries should work together to develop a joint missile defense system in the face of mainland China's fast growing military strength, Vice Defense Minister Tsai Ming-hsien said Saturday.

Addressing a seminar on the present state and prospects for Asian security, Tsai said mainland China's continued military buildup has become the biggest "variable" to Asia-Pacific regional stability and peace.
Tsai said mainland China has deployed 610 ballistic missiles along its southeastern coastline and that the number of its missiles deployed in the region is growing by 50 to 70 annually.

Against this backdrop, Tsai said the Taiwan-U.S.-Japan security dialogue mechanism should be upgraded to an official- or quasi-official level and Asia-Pacific countries should cooperate in developing a joint missile defense system.

According to Tsai, Taiwan has expressed its willingness to the United States through various channels to join the U.S.-proposed theater missile defense (TMD), but U.S. authorities have not yet given a clear response.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RULES OUT POLITICAL CONTRIBUTIONS TO FOREIGN POLITICIANS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday Taiwan is unlikely to offer political contributions to any individual foreign political figure.

Chen made the remarks while attending an evening party co-sponsored by the International Cooperation and Development Fund under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Taiwan Thinktank, a private group.

Chen's statements came amid reports that Nicaragua President Enrique Bolanos may be impeached due to his alleged acceptance of political contributions from Taiwan and that former Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez has been detained for allegedly accepting bribes, including political donations from Taiwan.

"Taiwan's aid to foreign countries has not been done out of charity nor is it an act of 'dollar diplomacy.' We have offered aid primarily for helping resolving issues of human survival," Chen explained.
Based on this idea, Chen said, Taiwan is absolutely not likely to offer political donations to any individual foreign politician.

The evening party was organized to entertain foreign and local participants to a seminar on the general new world trends in international aid projects. Twenty-six young Taiwan volunteers who will soon head for 12 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies for volunteer services also attended the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT TO DEVELOP NUCLEAR ARMS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Vice Defense Minister Tsai Ming-hsien reaffirmed the government's commitment Saturday on no development of nuclear arms.
Tsai said Taiwan's stance on nuclear arms is crystal clear. "We have not conducted any nuclear arms research or development in the past 20-plus years," he added.
In the face of mainland China's military threat, Tsai said, Taiwan needs counterattack weapons in order to deter Beijing from launching an attack on the island in the first place.

"We'll never launch the first strike. But in line with our 'effective deterrent and firm defense' strategy, we need counterattack arms so that Beijing would have to pay 'big price' in case it attacks Taiwan, " Tsai said. However, he didn't elaborate on Taiwan's response strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HAS NOT ASKED HP CEO TO SERVE AS MESSENGER: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has not asked Hewlett-Packard Co. Chairwoman and CEO Carly S. Fiorina to serve as his messenger to mainland China, a Presidential Office spokesman said Saturday.

"President Chen has not asked and does not need any businesses or individual persons to pass messages on his behalf or be his messenger, " said Chen Wen-chung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department.

Chen Wen-chung made the remarks after Hewlett-Packard (HP) Taipei office issued a statement late on Friday saying that Fiorina's visit to Taiwan was strictly for business and that the purpose of her visit in Taiwan is to meet with the company's customers. "She believes that businesses should stick to business and leave politics to politicians," the HP statement said. Fiorina left Taipei for home Friday evening.
Commenting on the HP statement, Chen Wen-chung said President Chen didn't ask Fiorina to be his messenger to Beijing during their meeting on Friday.

"What President Chen said during the meeting was that the opening of direct charter passenger and cargo flights across the Taiwan Strait was an issue of mutual concern of both sides of the strait and was in the interest of the international community, " Chen Wen-chung said, adding that the president's remarks were mainly aimed at expressing Taiwan's goodwill to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: British troops ready to go into Baghdad.
Hundreds of British troops are to be moved into the Iraqi capital to fill in for American troops involved in an expected all-out assault on the rebel stronghold of Fallujah after the American presidential election on November 2.
Financial Times: Spitzer action spills over to UK.
UK insurers were facing unprecedented scrutiny on Friday night after Eliot Spitzer's assault on the industry in the US.
As shock waves continued to reverberate from the New York attorney-general's decision to file a lawsuit against Marsh & McLennan , accusing it of corruption and anti-competitive practices, the UK industry was braced to mount a defence of its own business model.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCT. 17 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Oct. 17:
09: 00, An international seminar on submarines and Taiwan's security will open at Armed Forces Officer's Club in Taipei.
09: 30, A seminar on Taiwan and government-to-government international organization will open at the conference room at National Taiwan University's College of Law.
10:15, Premier YU Shyi-kun will attend the opening ceremony of DPP legislative candidate Tsai Chi-chang's campaign office in Chingshui in Taichung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 17, or the fourth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Charles II, King of England, sells Dunkirk to the French.
1849: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and virtuoso pianist of the romantic era, dies of tuberculosis in Paris at the age of 39. His music, written chiefly for the piano, is noted for its expressiveness.
1855: Englishman Henry Bessemer patents his process for making steel.
1912: The first Balkan War breaks out when Bulgaria, Serbia and Greece declare war on Turkey.
1919: Zhao Ziyang, former Chinese Communist Party chief, is born. As prime minister in the 1980s, he pioneered bold economic reforms. He was swept from power in the political crisis sparked by the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations centered in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1920: Hsieh Wen-ta, Taiwan's first aviator, flies his aircraft over Taichung in central Taiwan.
1945: The first batch of ROC government troops aboard some 40 U.S. Navy ships arrives at Keelung in Taiwan, which reverts back to Chinese rule after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1956: Calder Hall, Britain's first nuclear power station, is opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
1963: The Hong Kong government sets up the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
1964: Construction of a cross-harbor bridge on Penghu (the Pescadores) is started.
1966: Lesotho and Botswana are admitted into the United Nations.
1967: Henry Puyi, formerly Hsuan Tung, the last Ching ruler, dies in Beijing at the age of 61.
1972: President Park Chung Hee declares martial law in South Korea.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center is inaugurated in Shanhua in southern Taiwan.
1973: The ten Arab members of OPEC announce an enormous 70 percent hike in oil prices and a cutback in production in response to America's support for Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
1974: The Asian Christian Federation opens its first conference on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei with 200 delegates from 15 Asian countries attending.
1977: Akira Nishiyama, former Japanese ambassador to South Korea, arrives in Taiwan to assume his duties as director of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei office.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for caring for the world's "unwanted and unloved."
1981: A group of more than 100 former officers of the U.S. Air Force's 14th squadron, better known as the Flying Tigers, arrives in Taipei to visit Chinese friends.
1989: An earthquake rocks northern California, killing more than 60 people.
1994: Israel and Jordan initial a historic peace treaty, ending their 46-year state of war.
1995: The Republic of China and Macau establish a five-year renewable air pact allowing Eva Airways, TransAsia Airways and Air Macau to fly routes between Taiwan and Macau.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks security chief Alexander Lebed one day after Lebed is accused of building his own army in an attempt to seize power.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan calls on Cardinal Paul Shan to express gratitude for the 921 earthquake relief assistance provided by the Catholic community in Taiwan.
2000: The Republic of China's Central News Agency enters into an agreement with France's Agency France-Press at a ceremony that ROC Vice President Annette Lu says signifies Taiwan's future leadership role in global Chinese news networks.
2001: The two-day ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum begins in Shanghai with foreign ministers, trade ministers and representatives from the 21 member economies participating.
2001: The 2001 Taipei International Electronics Products Exhibition opens with 806 domestic and foreign manufacturers participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, without the inducement of rewards, is able to make the people good; and without a show of anger, to awe them into fear more than if he had used the most dreadful instruments of punishment."

DOC.HEADLINE: FM RULES OUT POLITICAL CONTRIBUTIONS TO COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen reiterated Sunday that all foreign aid that Taiwan offers is implemented in accordance with plans and there never have been any aids given out as political contributions.
Chen was referring to allegations that Taiwan had conducted dollar diplomacy under the guise of foreign aid to Costa Rica.

Chen noted that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will formally give an explanation to the Costa Rican government shortly, as it has required, on Taiwan's aid plans to Costa Rica, including those conducted during the stint of former President Miguel Angel Rodriguez.
"There were absolutely no political contributions to Costa Rica," Chen stressed.
Chen made the remarks when he was at a stump for Democratic Progressive Party legislative elections candidate Lin Chung-mo.

Former Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez has been detained for allegedly taking huge sums of kickbacks from Alcatel, a French telecom company. The Costa Rican government is also reportedly investigating into allegations that Rodriguez received political donations from Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Vice Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said Sunday that the MOFA-initiated foreign aid has been conducted in accordance with a set standard operating procedure (SOP) under the supervision of the Legislative Yuan.
However, he added, the exact amounts of cash aid to countries varied and have been kept secret to avoid diplomatic faux pas, as well as jealousy by other countries.
Kau said that the MOFA will present explanations on Taiwan's cash aid to Costa Rica after further understanding.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON TOKAGE MAY MISS TAIWAN, BUT RAIN EXPECTED: WEATHER BUREAU

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau is closely monitoring Typhoon Tokage and tropical storm Nock-Ten, although Tokage has decreasing chances of directly hitting Taiwan and Nock-Ten is still very far away.

According to bureau forecasters, Typhoon Tokage, which has been looming in the Pacific Ocean since Oct. 12, was centered about 880 kilometers south-southeast of Okinawa at 10: 30 a.m. Sunday, moving northwesterly toward Taiwan at a speed of 18 kilometers per hour. It was packing maximum sustained winds of up to 154 kilometers per hour.
The weather bureau is not expected to issue any warnings for Tokage on Sunday or Monday unless the typhoon hastens its pace and moves more westerly toward Taiwan, bureau meteorologists said.

The forecasters said they'll be monitoring how the northeastern trade winds coming from the north influence the typhoon's course over the following days, adding that the typhoon is expected to bring tremendous amounts of rainfall to Taiwan in the following couple of days regardless of whether or not it hits the island directly.
Meanwhile, tropical storm Nock-Ten was centered some 4,000 kilometers away from Taiwan as of 10:30 a.m. Sunday.
It is still too early to determine whether Nock-Ten -- moving in a west-southwesterly direction at a speed of seven kilometers per hour -- will directly affect Taiwan or not, the forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Violence, Crash in Iraq Kill 6 Troops; 5 Baghdad Churches Targeted by Bombers.
Two U.S. military transport helicopters crashed Saturday night in southwestern Baghdad, the military said, killing two soldiers and bringing to six the number of American servicemen reported killed in violence across Iraq over the past two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 43,000 PARTICIPATE IN 2004 CHINA MOTOR MARATHON IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2004 China Motor Marathon got underway Sunday morning in Taipei, with more than 43,000 runners participating, a record number, an organizer said.

The competition, organized jointly by the Taipei City Government, the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports and the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association, was divided in groups of full marathon (42.195 kilometers) , half-marathon (21 kilometers) , 10-kilometer and five-kilometer runs.
Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who ran in the 10-kilometer race, urged the public to run however far they can and set new records.
The organizer invited nine experienced runners from around the world to vie for prices worth a total of US$100,000.

The two taekwondo gold medalists at the 2004 Athens Olympic Games -- Chen Shih-hsin and Chu Mu-yen -- as well as the winner of the silver medal in taekwondo, Huang Chih-hsiung, participated in the five-kilometer run.
Noteworthy were the dozen blind runners, Hsieh Kuan-ching -- who ran backwards -- and 87-year-old Peng Hung-nien who ran the half-marathon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION PARTICIPATES IN INTERNATIONAL FOOD SHOW IN PARIS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Luo Yuan-shao and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation, composed of 26 food companies and agricultural associations, is participating in the Salon International de I'Alimentation (SIAL 2004) in Paris, officials of Taiwan's Trade Center in Paris said Sunday.
The SIAL 2004, one of the largest international food shows in the world, began Sunday and will run until Oct. 21, attracting more than 5,200 food-related companies from 98 countries.
In addition to presenting their best food products at the exhibition, the Taiwanese enterprises will also hold sampling activities to introduce Taiwan's fruits and tea products.
The officials noted that Taiwan agricultural products can tap the European market through the food show in France, a major trade center in the European Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN RESIDENTS DON'T THINK CHARTER FLIGHTS 'INTERNAL AFFAIR'

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan residents do not think opening direct charter flight services across the Taiwan Strait is an "internal affair" as mainland Chinese officials put it, according to results of a government-conducted public opinion poll released Sunday.

A total of 67.2 percent of Taiwan adults said that it is unacceptable to them that officials from mainland China's State Council's Office of Taiwan Affairs set a premise for the start of cross-strait talks over charter flight services that such talks would be China's "internal affair, " according to the poll sponsored by the Government Information Office.
The telephone poll, conducted Oct. 13-14, found that 63 percent of the respondents think the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume official dialogue, while 19 percent disagreed.

Just over 71 percent think that Taiwan and mainland China should build a military mutual trust mechanism to help reduce cross-strait tensions. Only 17 percent said nay to the notion, according to the poll.
On who is to blame for the cross-strait political deadlock, 42.7 percent said that China should bear the responsibility, compared with 20 percent who said President Chen Shui-bian is to blame.

A total of 44.8 percent of the respondents said that President Chen demonstrated true sincerity in the remarks he made in his Oct. 10 National Day speech about efforts to improve cross-strait relations. Some 30 percent said Chen did not.
The poll also found that respondents aged between 20-29 are most supportive among all age groups for President Chen in this regard, followed by those in the 40-59 age group.

A total of 53.2 percent approved of the idea expressed by Chen in his National Day speech that "the Republic of China is Taiwan and Taiwan is the ROC, " also with the greatest support by those from the youngest age group.

In this regard, the poll also found that 41 percent of the supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" approved of President Chen's advocacy, while another 41 percent of this group thought otherwise.

On the future of Taiwan, 30 percent of the respondents support Taiwan independence or the notion of "one side, one country, " compared with 54.9 percent who said they support the status quo for Taiwan and mainland China, and only seven precent supported reunification or the "one country, two systems" formula, the poll found.
A total of 1,115 valid responses were collected in the poll of randomly selected Taiwan adults islandwide. The survey had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.99 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER STUMPS FOR RULING PARTY'S LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called on the public Sunday to support the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) candidates in the year-end legislative elections to allow the DPP to control the legislature and thus help improve the government's efficiency.

Speaking at the inauguration of the campaign office of Wang Shih-shung, a DPP legislative candidate for Taichung City, central Taiwan, Yu said that many draft bills initiated by the administrative branch for carrying out the nation's development programs and public construction projects are being stockpiled in the Legislative Yuan due to the boycott by the opposition camp which, enjoys a slim majority in the legislature.

The government has always performed with a high degree of efficiency when dealing with matters that are not involved with the legislature and the government's efficiency is reduced with the engagement of the opposition-controlled legislature, Yu said.
More than 200 draft bills initiated by his Cabinet are pending be screening by the Legislative Yuan, Yu noted, adding that the inefficiency has affected the government's administration.
The legislative elections will be held Dec. 11 with 225 legislators to be elected.
A total of 387 candidates have registered to vie for 168 regional and eight aboriginal seats, of which 92 have been recommended by the DPP.

The prime opposition Kuomintang (KMT) nominated 74 candidates, followed by the People First Party (PFP) with 41, the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) with 30 and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) with 26.
The parties will add additional seats for 41 legislators-at-large and eight overseas Chinese legislators based on a proportional representation of the ballots that each party secures in the election.

Citing survey results carried out by the DPP, Chung Jia-ping, the party's deputy secretary-general, forecast that the "pan-green camp" -- formed by the DPP and its political ally, the TSU -- will be able to win from 110 to 115 seats -- a turnaround from the last legislative elections in 2001.

On the other hand, the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP also claimed that they will keep their majority in the legislature, as the two parties have agreed to cooperate based on a conservative quota system to maximize their seats.

The NPSU, a new party created by 10 incumbent independent legislators, is also very optimistic about its performance, predicting that the party will be able to pass the 5 percent threshold to win as many as 17 regional seats and up to three at-large seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUFFICIENT SUBMARINES CAN ASSURE ECONOMIC LIFELINE IN EAST ASIA: MND

TEXT.P: A sufficient number of submarines in Taiwan's military could reduce the mainland Chinese threat along the Western Pacific and maintain an economic lifeline for Asian and Pacific countries, Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-shian said Sunday.
Tsai made the remarks at a seminar organized by the Institute for Taiwan Defense and Strategic Studies in Taipei on Taiwan's national defense capability.

Noting that Taiwan's northern and southern waters control the route where Chinese submarines enter and leave the Pacific, Tsai said that if China's submarines can go through these areas freely, the security of all marine transport in the Western Pacific will be threatened.
In his judgment, a strong Taiwan submarine fleet would not only help stabilize the Taiwan Strait, but would also contribute to the regional security.
Tsai made the remarks against the backdrop of the defense ministry's efforts to gain support from the legislature for its special arms purchase budget plan worth NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion).
Under the plan, the defense ministry hopes to buy six advanced Patriot anti-missile defense batteries, 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and eight conventional submarines from the United States.
However, Tsai stressed that good hardware should be accompanied by good strategies and tactics.

Tsai said China is depending more and more on its navy, and if Taiwan can boast of a strong submarine fleet, it can become a powerful counterforce and make China's blockade of Taiwan unprofitable, said.

No other weapons can have such a strong effect like submarines, Tsai stressed, quoting Hyman Rickover, father of the world's first nuclear-powered submarine, as saying that all the weapons used in wars are expensive, and cheap weapons seldom win wars.
If weapons cannot win wars, there is no need to buy them, and this is why Taiwan should buy submarines, which are of great significance to Taiwan's national defense, Tsai concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN READY FOR ISLET TRANSFER: DEPUTY MAGISTRATE
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Kinmen County Government is ready to take control of six small islets near Kinmen after the military transfer the administration of these areas, Deputy Magistrate Yang Chung-chuan said Sunday.

The civilian Kinmen County Government will make the most of this chance to develop tourism and trade in the areas to turn Kinmen, formerly an anti-communism stronghold, into a "bridge of peace" across the Taiwan Strait, Yang claimed. Kinmen lies closer to mainland China's Fujian province than to Taiwan.

Basically, Yang asserted, the Kinmen County Government will only take over the jurisdiction of the six islets -- namely Tatan, Ertan, Tungting, Peiting, Shihyu and Menghuyu -- but will not be responsible for defending them.

After the transfer of the six islets, probably on Jan. 1, 2005, the Coast Guard Administration will be responsible for their defense and the National Police Administration will help keep social order, Yang said.
"There will be no interruption in social order before, during or after the transfer period," Yang added.
According to Yang, the six islets have been purely military for more than five decades. "These islets were completely off-limits to civilians, even to Kinmen residents," Yang said.

Many people, including multinational companies, have been keen to learn of the demilitarization -- some suggesting that the islets be developed into eco-sanctuaries, and some are looking into the feasibility of developing them into resorts with casinos, while others say the islets should be kept as museums of military history, according to Yang.

In preparation for the takeover, the Kinmen County Government has commissioned National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences to conduct a tourism resources survey of Tatan and Ertan -- known as "the islets of heroes" -- which lie closest to mainland China.

Tungting and Peiting are known as "the islets of lights," because they are the only two islets to have lighthouses. The Tungting lighthouse was built in 1871 during the Tongchih Period of the Ching dynasty and the Peiting lighthouse was built in 1882 during the Kuanghsu Period.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD OFFERS FOUR WAYS TO DEFUSE CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top mainland China policy planner has been seeking a meaningful dialogue across the Taiwan Strait and has offered four ways to defuse cross-strait tensions.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, in his article contributed to the Sept.-Oct. issue of the magazine New Zealand International Review discussed many dimensions of current Taiwan-mainland China relations.
He called for a new approach by China's leaders to help break the political impasse across the Strait, while offering four methods to be taken in four stages to solve the problem.
First, he said, both sides should work to strengthen exchanges, including those of culture, business and trade, which have already been established.

Second, the two sides should begin constructive dialogue to build mutual trust. The dialogue can begin with talks on business issues and efforts to jointly crack down on crime, followed by talks on the direct "three-links," Wu noted.

In the third stage, the two sides should seek to enter into a certain kind of political engagement and build a military mutual trust mechanism, promising that neither side will take unilateral, radical means to change the status quo.
In the fourth stage, he said, Taiwan and mainland China are expected to smooth out their political differences. As long as the people of Taiwan agree, all means will be considered, he said.
Meanwhile, Wu called for the international community to help push China to pay more heed to Taiwan's peace overture. He once again urged Beijing officials to return to the negotiating table.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGLISH KEY TO SPREADING TAIWAN CULTURE ABROAD: EDUCATION MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said Sunday that Taiwan's development in diverse aspects will be limited if people in the country do not strengthen their English ability.
Tu made the remarks at a seminar held in Taipei on ethnic groups and cultural development.

As the "new Taiwan citizen movement" is one of the issues being discussed at the seminar, some participants maintained that mother languages of each ethnic group should be given priority over English. They suggested that the government should not promote English education too early for kids.
Concerning such suggestions, Tu stressed that English is the channel to the world community, and the essence of Taiwan culture cannot be accepted and understood by the world without it.

Chiang Shu-cheng, an associate professor at National Chiao Tung University, echoed Tu's opinion by saying that for comparison, Taiwan people have less intention of pursuing advanced studies abroad, which poses a problem for the island's scientific development.
Meanwhile, some participants hailed the island's efforts in "Taiwanization, " pointing as an example to some domestic orchestras that have shifted their focus on Taiwanese music and musicians.
"Taiwan can be easily connected with the world community through its own music," they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROTARY CLUBS IN TAIWAN MARK 100 ANNIVERSARY OF ROTARY INTERNATIONAL

TEXT.P: Rotary International District 3480 bestowed citations to individuals around Taiwan Sunday to celebrate in advance the 100th anniversary of Rotary International, which will fall on Feb. 1, 2005.

At the ceremony, held jointly by Rotary International District 3480 and 48 other Rotary Clubs in the greater Taipei area, 175 people coming from many different walks of life, including volunteers, teachers, environmentalists, firemen, public servants and journalists received citations.
It was the first time that journalists were given the honor by the Rotary Clubs in Taiwan, and among them were Central News Agency President Hu Yuan-hui and Apple Daily in Taiwan President James Tu.

Vice Minister of the Interior Lee Chin-yung, Vice Minister of Education Fan Sun-lu and Taipei City Deputy Mayor King Pu-tsung attended the ceremony, hailing the citation recipients for contributing significantly to society.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP IS MOST POPULAR IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS SURVEY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is the most popular in the year-end legislative elections with a 24 percent approval rating, according to results of a poll released Sunday.

The survey, conducted by the Chuan Kuo Credibility Polling Company, showed that the prime opposition Kuomintang (KMT) won support from 14 percent of the respondents concerning the Dec. 11 legislative elections, followed by the People First Party (PFP) with 5.12 percent, the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) with 2.74 percent and the newly established Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) with 2.33 percent, while 44.03 percent said they were undecided.

Meanwhile, 35 percent of the respondents believed that the DPP will continue to be the largest political party in the Legislative Yuan after the elections, far ahead of the 16 percent that were optimistic about the chances of the KMT, and less than 10 percent of the respondents demonstrated their confidence in the other parties. More than 40 percent did not reply to the question.
On which party loves Taiwan most, the DPP ranked first with 20.74 percent, followed by the KMT with 10.17 percent, the TSU with 4.63 percent, the PFP with 2.15 percent and the NPSU with 0.49 percent.

With regard to national identity, 62.2 percent of the respondents said that they are Taiwanese, while 18.6 percent described themselves as Taiwanese and Chinese as well and 14 percent identified themselves as Chinese.
Referring to cross-Taiwan Strait relations, 62.6 percent favor maintaining the status quo, while 17.2 percent support independence and 5.4 percent are pro-unification.
The poll, conducted Oct. 11-12 with 1,088 samples, had a margin of error of 2.97 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCELLENT CHINESE BUSINESS WOMEN CHOSEN

TEXT.P: The Global Federation of Chinese Business Women (GFCBW) bestowed awards Sunday to 10 excellent Chinese business women they chose from around the world.
Vice President Annette Lu was among the guests to offer the awards to the winners, who were chosen from 27 countries.
An executive of GFCBW noted that more and more women should share the economic pressure in the families with their husbands, and thus pushing them to excel in the workplace.
More and more Chinese women have performed well in various sectors, such as trade, media, education, law, medicine, government and charity, she said.
The GFCBW now has 32 branches around the world and has been dedicated during the years to charitable activities and economic and trade information exchanges throughout the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S MISSILE THREAT AGAINST TAIWAN INCREASING: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: China's threat against Taiwan is growing with around 800 ballistic missiles estimated to be targeting the island by next year, Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday.
Addressing a rally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's women members in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Lu said that China already has 610 missiles ready to strike Taiwan.
Elsewhere, according to national security agencies, more than 3,000 mainland Chinese visitors have absconded after arriving in Taiwan, posing another threat to the country's security, she noted.
Lu called on the public to stay alert for any possible trouble in Taiwan by mysterious visitors from China.
Moreover, she urged the public to support the ruling party in the year-end legislative elections to allow it to hold a majority in the legislature and thus increase the government's efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Broad use of harsh tactics is described at Cuba base.
Many detainees at Guantanamo Bay were regularly subjected to harsh and coercive treatment, several people who worked in the prison said in recent interviews, despite longstanding assertions by military officials that such treatment had not occurred except in some isolated cases. The people, military guards, intelligence agents and others, described in interviews with The New York Times a range of procedures that included treatment they said was highly abusive occurring over a long period of time, as well as rewards for prisoners who cooperated with interrogators.
Wall Street Journal: U.S. Forces continue air, ground assault in Fallujah.
U.S. forces battled insurgents around the rebel stronghold of Fallujah on Sunday after two American soldiers died when their helicopters crashed south of Baghdad. Many Iraqi Christians skipped Mass following bombings at churches in the capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S STOCK MARKET VALUE DECREASES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market value decreased to NT$13.933 trillion (US$411 billion) at the end of last week, down NT$626.03 billion or 4.56 percent over the week-earlier level, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).
The weighted index -- the benchmark indicator of the domestic bourse -- fell by 281.34 points, or 4.61 percent for the whole week to finish at 5,820.82 on Oct. 15.
Share prices of all 20 categories lost grounds with the cement industry suffering the greatest setback at 7.83 percent, followed by textiles at 7.33 percent and transportation at 7.24 percent.
The total trading value of listed stocks amounted to NT$418.2 billion during the period between Oct. 11 and Oct. 15.
In the 196 trading days since the beginning of this year, the average daily stock trading value stood at NT$104.121 billion, accumulating to a total of NT$20.661 trillion, the tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 18, or the fifth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1405: Pope Pius II, originally named Enea Silivio Piccolomini, is born. He was noted for his unsuccessful attempt to lead a crusade against the Turks.
1860: Invading British troops burn the Yuanmingyuan, the imperial summer palace in Beijing, to the ground.
1867: The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1873: Delegates from Columbia, Princeton, Rutgers, and Yale universities meet and formulate the rules for American football.
1898: The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
1907: The first plans are announced for an International Court of Justice to be set up in The Hague.
1922: Tsai Yuan-pei, a scholar and the president of Peking University, resigns in the wake of student protests against an extra levy on professor's handouts.
1926: The will of Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian founder of the Bolshevik party, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, is made public to the world in the New York Times.
1931: Thomas Alva Edison, America's most prolific inventor, dies at the age of 84. His inventions include the phonograph, the microphone and the kinescope.
1941: General Hideki Tojo becomes prime minister of Japan and begins planning for war against the United States.
1944: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt cables Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government and supreme commander of the China theater of war, regarding his decision to appoint Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China theater of war to succeed Gen. Joseph Stilwell.
1946: The Chinese communists reject the government's latest peace offer presented by Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 16.
1967: Venera 4, a Soviet spacecraft, enters the atmosphere of Venus and transmits data back to earth.
1970: Vice President Yen Chia-kan, who concurrently holds the post of premier, leaves Taipei for New York to attend the 25th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.
1974: Acting for President Chiang Kai-shek, Vice President Yen Chia-kan accepts the credentials of Maj. Gen. Ismael D. Lapus as the Philippines ambassador to the Republic of China.
1974: The ROC national taekwondo team returns from Seoul after taking second place in the First Asian Taekwondo championships.
1976: Chinese-American scientist Samuel Chao Chung Ting and his colleague Burton Richter share the 1976 Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of an elementary nuclear particle called the "psi," or "J particle."
1987: The United States attacks an Iranian oil rig in revenge for strikes against its shipping operations by gunboats.
1989: Erich Honecker, 77, East Germany's hardline ruler who failed to respond to the desire among East Germans for change, is ousted from the post he held for the previous 18 years.
1989: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer match in Guatemala. Eighty-three people are killed and nearly 200 others are injured.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Council is established under the Executive Yuan to formulate and implement mainland policy, with Vice Premier Shih Chi-yang serving as its chairman.
1998: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation, crowns a six-day visit to mainland China by meeting with President Jiang Zemin, marking the highest-level contact between the two sides since 1949.
1999: Two more Knox-class frigates leased from the United States are commissioned in order to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capabilities.
2000: A seminar on trade and economic cooperation among the three Chinese communities -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- opens in Beijing.
2001: "President A-bian's Electronic Paper, " an online newspaper published by the Presidential Office is formally launched.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reiterats the long-standing relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay when he receives visiting National Asuncion University President Paul Battilana.
2001: Several hundred Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan, Europe and the United States gathers in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgium to protest Beijing's suppression of the movement.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, by living a life of simple truth and earnestness, alone can help to bring peace and order in the world."
