DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE TO REACH 6%: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan's economic growth rate is expected to reach 6 percent this year, the highest level since 1998.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with leading members of the Global Federation of Chinese Business Women and winners of the 2004 Excellent Chinese Business Women Awards.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS PUSH FOR ESTABLISHMENT 0F CULTURE & TOURISM MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Experts attending a confab on ethnic and cultural development suggested Monday that the Executive Yuan accelerate steps toward the establishment of a Ministry of Culture and Tourism to facilitate the materialization of various policies on cultural and tourism development in Taiwan.

Upon the conclusion of the three-day Conference on Ethnic and Cultural Development, experts from the academic, political and social circles agreed that the Executive Yuan should hasten its pace in establishing the much-talked-about Culture and Tourism Ministry as many important relevant policies have lagged far behind in terms of meeting the needs of Taiwan's current situation.

The experts called for relevant Cabinet-level agencies to collaborate in working to promote four major "cultural transformations" in Taiwan -- namely transforming the "culture of colonialism" to a "culture of autonomy, " the "culture of Taiwan as a base of operations" to a "culture of Taiwan as the homeland, " the "culture of imitation" to a "culture of creativity," and the "culture of elitism" to a "national culture."

They also suggested that a new constitution for Taiwan be written, with a new section devoted exclusively to aboriginal affairs to show the government's determination in carrying out the policy of "partnership between Taiwan's indigenous people and the central government."
They added that the Executive Yuan should also work to facilitate policies on autonomy for the aboriginal people.

On the well-being of the increasing number of foreign spouses married to Taiwan citizens, the experts suggested that an anti-discrimination law be enacted and an immigration administration be established under the Ministry of the Interior.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH COULD HIT 6% FOR THE YEAR: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan's economic growth rate is expected to reach 6 percent for this year, the highest level since 1998.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with leading members of the Global Federation of Chinese Business Women and winners of the 2004 Excellent Chinese Business Women Awards.

Under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's strenuous efforts to revitalize the economy and accelerate sweeping reform, Chen said Taiwan's global competitiveness and economic vitality have greatly improved in the past few years.
Quoting the latest forecast by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Chen said Taiwan's 2004 economic growth rate could reach 5.87 percent.
"Barring any unexpected developments, the annual growth rate may even hit a seven-year high of 6 percent," Chen told his guests.

Chen further said that Taiwan ranks 29th among major countries around the world in terms of women's political participation based on the results of a recent survey of 129 countries released by the United Nations.
In the U.N. survey, Chen said, Taiwan outpaced other Asian countries in terms of women's political participation.
The president also said that although Taiwan didn't experience a transition of power between different political parties until 2000, it outran the United States in spawning a female vice president.
"I'm convinced that Taiwan women will have even greater room in the political arena in the years to come," Chen said.
Touching on his administration's work agenda, Chen said the government will continue to carry out various political and economic reforms as well as promote the constitutional re-engineering plan.

In the meantime, Chen said, his administration will actively work for the establishment of a viable mechanism for peaceful interaction between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait for the sake of maintaining regional peace and stability.

"We'll push for resumption of cross-strait dialogue on the existing foundation and craft an environment favorable for sustainable peaceful development and for the pursuit of maximum well-being for the people," Chen added. (Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PRESIDENTIAL AIDE DEFENDS DISCLOSURE OF NUMBER OF PRC MISSILES

TEXT.P: The president's chief of staff on Monday defended the appropriateness of disclosures by Taiwan's president or vice president on public occasions of the number of mainland Chinese ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Su Tzeng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that the "belligerent" People's Republic of China has never relented in intimidating Taiwan with the threat of missiles and has continued to increase the deployment of such weapon systems.

Against this backdrop, Su said, it is only appropriate for the president or vice president to talk to the nation about the number of the missiles -- which he said is as normal as a guard at a sentry post signalling a warning.
Su said that the president or vice president's disclosures of the facts about the mainland Chinese missiles is not a "disclosure of military intelligence," as some have criticized.

Su made the remarks in response to a question raised by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chiu Chuei-chen, who asked about the possible implications of Vice President Annette Lu's recent mention of the PRC's missile deployment.
Lu said that Beijing has so far deployed 610 short-range and medium-range missiles targeting Taiwan and that the number could increase to 800 by next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: General Reported Shortages In Iraq; Situation Is Improved, Top Army Officials Say.
The top U.S. commander,Army Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, in Iraq complained to the Pentagon last winter that his supply situation was so poor that it threatened Army troops' ability to fight, according to an official document that has surfaced only now, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Nation:Bid for second term/ PM's biggest hard sell. Besieged but defiant, Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra played what could be his last political card yesterday by promising generous handouts to virtually everyone, from new born children to the ignored elderly as well as to investors in the stock market. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:Brighter prospects in jobs market.
Prospects in the jobs market are improving and the jobless rate looks set to fall. Unemployment was likely to drop in the third quarter on the back of good growth in the first half of the year, said Manpower Minister Ng Eng Hen.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Gas cylinders explode at underground KPE worksite.
Two explosions and a fire occured about 17m underground at a Kallang/Paya Lebar Expressway worksite yesterday moring when a long piece of metal hit some gas cylinders.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SOFTWARE' ASPECT OF FOREIGN AID PROGRAMS HARD TO CONTROL: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said Monday that all of Taiwan's foreign aid projects are carried out in accordance with the law and established procedures and under legislative supervision, although he admitted that "the software" aspect of the aid projects is hard to control.

Chen said that the "hardware" part of the cash aid is relatively easy to monitor, such as through written reports from the government of a recipient country on the progress in an infrastructure development project.
However, the "software" aspect of the foreign aid, such as how and where the aid has been used in the training of personnel or the sponsoring of activities, is more difficult to trace, Chen added.

Meanwhile, Foreign Affairs Ministry spokesman Michel Lu reiterated that all of Taiwan's foreign aid projects are carried out in accordance with the law under legislative supervision and standard operating procedures.
Lu said that no aid has been given in the form of political contributions, and he denied the involvement of any "personal bank accounts" in the recipient countries.

The minister and the spokesman made the remarks in the aftermath of allegations out of Latin America that Taiwan had conducted "dollar diplomacy" under the guise of foreign aid to Costa Rica and Nicaragua.

Lu said that the Costa Rican government issued a note to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) last week requesting that Taiwan provide a written statement about all cash aid offered to Costa Rica during former Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez's time in office.
Lu noted that the MOFA will formally give an explanation, also in the form of a "note, " to the Costa Rican government Tuesday, as requested.

Rodriguez has been detained for allegedly accepting huge kickbacks from Alcatel, a French telecom company. The Costa Rican government is also reportedly investigating allegations that Rodriguez received political donations from Taiwan.

As to foreign wire reports saying that Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos faces possible removal from office on corruption charges, including allegations of his receiving US$4.9 million from Taiwan for his 2001 election campaign, Lu stressed that the reports are not related to Taiwan's aid to Nicaragua.

Lu said that Taiwan had indeed channeled over US$4 million to Nicaragua, under the request of President Bolanos, to establish a "Taiwan aid fund" to help carry out a series of cooperative programs, including financial aid for human rights efforts, public health and promotion projects, natural disaster prevention programs, and social emergency funds.
Lu added that the MOFA will not get involved in the Rodriguez or Bolanos cases, saying that they are the internal affairs of other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 TAIWAN FISHING SHIPS DETAINED IN MALAYSIA
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Y.P. Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan fishing vessels were detained last Friday by the Malaysian navy for illegally fishing in waters off Labuan in Sabah State in northern Borneo.
According to a Malaysian navy news release, all three Taiwan vessels -- the "Hsinhaifa, " the "Lienyuchun, " and the "Lienyuchun No. 18" -- are equipped with sophisticated fishing equipment.
During the chase by the navy, one Taiwan fishing ship was damaged when it collided with a navy vessel. The "Lienyuchun No. 18" sank after catching fire when it was being escorted back to harbor.
The three vessels have a total of 20 crew members. The captains are Tsai Fa-tsai (the "Hsinhaifa") , Cheng Chung-he (the "Lienyuchun"), and Cheng Jen-hung (the "Lienyuchun No. 18").

The Malaysian navy said that the three ships were fishing illegally in the waters off Labuan on Oct. 15, and that they were detained because they didn't have legal operating licenses, adding that the vessels have been turned over to the Labuan fishing authorities.
The navy also said that Labuan is a famous fishing ground in Malaysia, and that all fishing ships must follow legal procedures and obtain permits to enter the waters for fishing operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 48.70 points to close at 5,772.12.
The bourse opened at 5,848.15, with the weighted index fluctuating between 5,857.54 and 5,772.12 during the day's trading.
A total of 2.3 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$48.07 billion (US$1.42 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical stocks and paper issues both moving up the most at 0.3 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.1 percent.

Five stock categories lost ground, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.0 percent, financial stocks at 0.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 540 to 137, with 119 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: After Abkhaz Failure, Spin Goes to Ukraine.
Both are candidates from the party of power and have presidential aspirations. Both served as prime ministers and campaigned on a platform of strengthening ties with Russia. Both recruited Russian spin doctors and relied on images of meetings with President Vladimir Putin to bolster voter support.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October lost 37 points to close at 5,779, with 18,174 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 36 points to finish at 5,780, with 5,756 contracts traded, while December futures lost 15 points to finish at 5,785, with 14 contracts traded.
June futures dropped 42 points to finish at 5,725, with five contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,816 for October, 5,816 for November, 5,800 for December, 5,778 for March and 5,767 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures moved down 2.9 points to close at 210, with 3,577 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 2.55 points to finish at 210, with 2,069 contract transactions.
December TE futures lost 2.3 points to close at 210.8, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures lost 5.4 points to end at 1,001, with 4,564 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 7.4 points to finish at 993.2, with 3,174 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved down 7.8 points to close at 990.2, with 10 contract transactions, while June TF futures lost 15.4 points to finish at 984, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.004 to close at NT$33.862.
A total of US$580 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.835 and fluctuated between NT$33.802 and NT$33.868.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG ONE OF MOST MATURE TELECOM MARKETS IN ASIA: S&P

TEXT.P: Increased competition induced by regulatory change has made Hong Kong one of the most sophisticated and mature telecommunications markets in Asia, Standard & Poor's Ratings Services said Monday.

The international rating agent said in a report that the territory's mobile phone market is saturated, and churn rates are among the highest in Asia, while regulatory changes have made the fixed-line business increasingly competitive.
John Bailey, director at Standard & Poor's, said: "The penetration rate of mobile phones in Hong Kong is more than 105 percent, and fixed-line subscriber growth is flat."
He also said that although market conditions have improved over the past year, with mobile operators returning a profit, the environment remains difficult.
"Operators need to continue to modify their business models in response to new technologies and changing regulations, " he added.
The report pointed to several main issues that could shape Hong Kong's telecom industry, including whether the government remains committed to further deregulation in the sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS ARRIVE IN TAIWAN TO OVERWINTER

TEXT.P: With the weather getting colder, a large number of black-faced spoonbills have arrived at the Chiku Wetlands Sanctuary in southern Taiwan to overwinter, a local association dedicated to protecting rare birds said Monday.

As of Monday, 223 black-faced spoonbills had arrived at the Chiku sanctuary near the estuary of the Tsengwen River in Tainan County, marking a roughly three-fold increase from the 78 arrivals recorded at the same time last year, a spokesman for the association said.

The sharp increase might be related to the formation of typhoons in the East Pacific in recent weeks, prompting black-faced spoonbills on the Korean Peninsula to fly southward to Taiwan, the spokesman said.

The black-faced spoonbills are expected to stay at the Chiku Wetlands until early next year. The rare birds will then move to the Suchao Sanctuary in Tainan City before migrating north between March and April for mating.

Between December 2002 and January 2003, black-faced spoonbills infected with botulism were reported in the Chiku Sanctuary and 73 died, the first time the endangered species had died en masse in Taiwan.

Tainan County Government officials in charge of animal disease control said they have completed a series of tests at 18 sites in the Chiku habitat and have found no evidence of botulism contamination.
"We'll continue monitoring the habitat closely to ensure all the birds stay healthy while they overwinter here," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: CBI threatens to boycott 'flawed' exam reform plan.
Business leaders are threatening to boycott the Tomlinson report because they fear that its proposals will do nothing to improve basic standards of literacy and numeracy.
Financial Times: Russian-backed Harmony set to bid for Gold Fields today.
South African gold producer Harmony, with the backing of Russian metals giant Norilsk Nickel, has made a surprise takeover bid for Gold Fields, the world's fourth biggest producer. The bid by Harmony, South Africa's largest domestic gold producer could foil management's plans to merge with Canada's Iamgold.

DOC.HEADLINE: III INTRODUCES 10 MORE INDIAN SOFTWARE R&D ENGINEERS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Ten engineers from India versed in software research and development arrived in Taipei Monday at the invitation of the Institute for Information Industry (III) to help Taiwan's software R&D.
They will be working in Taiwan mainly in the areas of IC design and embedded software, III CEO Ke Chih-sheng said.
With the addition of these 10 engineers, there are now about 40 Indian software R&D personnel in Taiwan, an unprecedented Indian presence in Taiwan's technology sector.
The Indians will try to help Taiwan's software development, which has been lagging its hardware development, Ke noted.
Ke recommended the Indian software R&D engineers highly, saying that not only is their English native, they are disciplined and have a good work ethic.

Ke quoted estimates by India's National Association of Software and Service Companies (NASSCOM) as reporting recently that the Indian information technology (IT) industry is now a US$15.5 billion market with some 800,000 workers. It is estimated that the market will balloon to US$80 billion with an army of workers of two million by 2008, Ke added.

According to NASSCOM President Kiran Karnik, the huge number of highly skilled persons and the low costs for their employment will give India's high-technology industrial development a competitive edge the future.
India is now already the leader of the world's software industry.

It is estimated that by 2020, the United States will be in need of 1.7 million workers in its industrial sector, Japan will be short nine million while mainland China will need 19 million. By that time, Karnik said, India will be able to export some 47 million people to meet these countries' needs.
Ke said that the III will also introduce high-technology technicians and engineers from Russia, Ireland and Vietnam in the years to come to help with Taiwan's IT and telecom industrial development.
The III signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with NASSCOM in February this year to bolster two-way industrial and economic exchanges and cooperation.
Under the MOU, the two sides will set up a group to handle and promote bilateral cooperative issues such as forging joint ventures to pave the way for technology and manpower transfers.

The 2003 Taiwan-India IT Technology Cooperation Seminar was held in Taipei in September last year with the participation of leading IT companies from India, including internationally renowned TCS (TATA Consultancy Services) , Sasken Communication Technologies and Satyam Computer, as well as well-established companies that are members of NASSCOM, India's top software industry organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 HONG KONG TOURISTS KILLED, 36 INJURED IN BUS ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Five Hong Kong tourists were killed, while 36 were injured when their tour bus overturned in the mountainous area of Chioufen, Taipei County, Monday afternoon, police said.
The bus passengers were from two tour groups from Hong Kong.
The driver of the coach was also injured, police said, adding that they are still investigating the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEES BEGIN REVIEWING OF CENTRAL GOVERNMENT BUDGETS

TEXT.P: Legislative committees began reviewing the central government's 2005 budgets Monday.
The review is expected to be completed Nov. 3.

The Legislative Yuan will recess for one month from Nov. 10 to Dec. 10 prior to the legislative elections on Dec. 11. The legislature will then reconvene on Dec. 21 and will hold a floor meeting to discuss the review reports of the committees until Dec. 23. Legislators will begin the second and third readings of the budgets that passed starting Dec. 28.

The Executive Yuan set the central government's revenue at NT$1.4027 trillion (US$41.623 billion) for 2005, up 3.9 percent from the previous year, while expenditures for next year will be NT$1.6356 trillion, up 2.4 percent from the previous year.

Therefore, the shortfall will come to NT$232.9 billion -- NT$292. 9 billion if debt repayments of NT$60 billion are included. The Cabinet plans to finance this by issuing NT$255 billion in bonds and the use of the leftover surplus of NT$37.9 billion from the previous year.

With the current standoff between the ruling and opposition parties, the budgets for such key government agencies as the Presidential Office, the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Justice are expected to be bitterly contested.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party feels that altering the budget figures would be better addressed after the legislative elections so that they can be discussed without the shadow of campaigning obscuring the issues.

Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung, party whip of the opposition People First Party, suggested that discussions take place first and a full review be held after the elections to avoid making decisions in limited time.
Legislator Chen Chien-ming, party whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, said that the party will not overlook the review procedure regardless of the ferocity of the campaigning.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DISEASE CONTROL CHIEF VOWS TO BOOST INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) will step up international cooperation to avert outbreaks of any contagious diseases, the center's new chief said Monday.
New CDC Director Kuo Hsu-sung made the remarks after taking over the center's official seal from DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen at a changeover ceremony.
Kuo said the CDC will greatly increase international exchanges, particularly with the United States and Japan in the prevention of communicable diseases.
Moreover, Kuo said the CDC plans to transform one of its divisions into a special task force responsible for promoting cooperation with other countries in blocking the import of exotic diseases.
Noting that Taiwan has long faced a severe shortage of professional disease control personnel, Kuo said the CDC will give priority to recruiting and cultivating competent infectious disease experts.

Chang recalled that when severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) hit Taiwan between March and June of last year, the saying that "battling outbreaks of an infectious disease is like waging a war" was often mentioned.

"This indicates that a disease control system requires strategic thinking, teamwork, discipline, mobility, obedience and a spirit of self-sacrifice, " Kuo said, adding that the CDC will reinforce training of its staff in line with these principles in the future.

Kuo graduated from National Yangming University's medical department and has a doctorate in public health policy from Yale University. He once served as director of the DOH's planning department and played an important role in the SARS-fighting campaign last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL COMMERCE INDUSTRIAL SERVICE PORTAL OPENS

TEXT.P: The Global Commerce Industrial Services Portal Web site opened Monday, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said.
The portal, gcis.nat.gov.tw, will offer commercial information to domestic manufacturers or foreign enterprises interested in establishing companies in Taiwan.
Domestic and foreign enterprises can also apply for business permits and certificates via the Web site, economic ministry officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPARTMENT DEPUTY RESIGNS, REPLACEMENT UNDECIDED

TEXT.P: The nation's top health official said Monday that he has accepted his deputy's resignation with "reluctance," but has yet to think about his replacement.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen, in a hastily convened news conference, said that Chang Hung-jen, DOH deputy minister and a former president of the Bureau of National Health Insurance, has made a final decision and will leave his post.
Chen said that Chang has been his "right-hand man" and that he has made great contributions to the public, but because of family reasons and different career plans, he decided to resign.
As for Chang's replacement, Chen said that he "has yet to think about the matter."

Chang tendered his resignation last week in the wake of protests by the staff of some 500 regional hospitals around Taiwan who took to the streets in Taipei to call attention to what they said was an unfair allocation of medical resources under the current National Health Insurance (NHI) program, which results in a big gap of medical resources between national medical centers and regional hospitals.

The protesters said that regional hospitals are not financially viable under such unfair allocations and that many regional hospitals have been forced to shut down. They asked Chang to step down to take responsibility because he designed the current NHI program.
Chang said last Thursday that he was willing to step down if his departure meant that an obstacle would be removed.
However, Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Minister Chen strongly urged him to stay on and not to quit under pressure. Chang was moved and promised that he would take some time to deliberate on his decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS STRINGENT SCREENING MECHANISM FOR FOREIGN AID: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen stressed Monday that the country has a stringent screening mechanism regarding its foreign aid, and it is unlikely to have offered political donations to certain individuals.
Chen made the remarks amid reports that ROC's aid to its diplomatic allies have gone to the accounts of certain politicians.

In response to the reports, Chen noted that in conformity with Taiwan's foreign aid procedures, diplomatic allies should present a complete plan first, which will later be screened by the foreign ministry.

After confirming that the assistance programs are really for the construction of infrastructure and that they are within the ROC government's financial capability, such assistance will be made and it is unlikely that the ROC government could offer any contributions to individual politicians, Chen said.

The minister noted that he felt sorry that some of Taiwan's foreign aid may have gone into the accounts of certain people, and to prevent this in the future, the foreign ministry will reduce the ratio of its confidential budget to under 15 percent in the future to increase the transparency of its foreign aid.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT HOLDS FIRST-EVER BURIAL AT SEA

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government held the nation's first-ever burial at sea Monday, scattering the cremated ashes of six people into waters more than six kilometers off the northern Taiwan coast amid drizzle and wind.

Hsueh Cheng-tai, director of the Municipal Bureau of Social Affairs (BSA), presided over a joint funeral for the six deceased at the Kuantu Wharf in Taipei County before their family members carried their ashes aboard two boats.
During the voyage, Hsiao Hsien-ming, a division chief at the city government's funeral management department, played lyric songs and saxophone music.

Family members first threw rose petals and bouquets into the sea and then spread the ashes of the deceased, four Taipei City and two Taipei County residents. The oldest was a 96-year-old retiree from the ROC Air Force and the youngest was a baby boy.
The first-ever burial at sea in Taiwan took about two hours.

Chen Yi-wei, a Central News Agency reporter whose father was among the six deceased remembered in the sea burial, said all family members were grateful for the city government's assistance in handling the unprecedented burial for their loved ones.
"Sea burial was my father's preferred choice. Open sea is the source of life. My father wanted to take his final rest in the depths of the sea," Chen said.
The Taipei City Government paid the bill, including cremation, reprocessing of the ashes, the eco-friendly urns and the transportation charges.

BSA Director Hsueh said the city government will hold a burial-at-sea for deceased people once a year from now on as part of its efforts to encourage sea burials as alternatives to being buried on land. Besides Taipei City dwellers, residents in other parts of the island are also welcome to apply for sea burial, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP OFFICE IN MALAYSIA TO HELP DETAINED FISHING SHIPS: COA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in Malaysia will offer all necessary assistance to crew members of three detained Taiwan fishing vessels, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Monday.
According to media reports, the three Taiwan fishing vessels have been detained in Malaysia since last Friday on charges of illegal fishing in waters off Labuan in Sabah State in northern Borneo.

Malaysian naval authorities claimed that the three Taiwan fishing boats -- the "Hsinhaifa, " the "Lienyuchun, " and the "Lienyuchun No. 18" -- were caught fishing in waters off Labuan Oct. 15 without legal operating licenses. One Taiwan ship was reportedly damaged in the chase by Malaysian naval vessels.

The official with the COA's Fishery Administration said the council has asked the ROC representative office in Malaysia through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to assist crew members of the detained ships in resolving the issue.
"We'll also closely watch the developments in the case, " the official said.

He also urged local fishermen to refrain from traversing into the exclusive economic zones of other countries to avoid trouble. The Fishery Administration will step up a publicity campaign to remind local fishermen to abide by international rules when deep-sea fishing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraqi officials plan to extend buying of arms.
An Iraqui government plan to entice the country's biggest Shiite militia to turn in its weapons in return for cash here has brought in enough arms in its first week that Iraqi officials extended the program on Sunday and said it might be spread to other cities. The cooperation with the buyout has raised hopes that the militia's leader, Moktada al-Sadr, would continue his turn toward entering the country's democratic process.
Wall Street Journal: Pfizer to test Celebrex as heart aid.
In a surprising turn in the debate over the safety of popular arthritis drugs, pharmaceuticals company Pfizer Inc. will announce plans to fund a large-scale clinical trial of Celebrex's ability to prevent heart attacks and strokes in patients with serious cardiovascular disease. The study, expected to enroll its first patients in the next few months, will test Celebrex against a sugar pill in thousands of people with osteoarthritis and a history of serious heart disease, such as a previous heart attack or severe angina.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS NEW CONSTITUTION: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: One of President Chen Shui-bian's mentors Monday advocated the creation of a new constitution for the nation, saying the current one is out of date.

Lee Hung-hsi, president of the Ketagalan Institute, a school founded by President Chen that aims to nurture the nation's future leaders, made the remarks when he was invited to deliver a speech on constitutional reform in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Lee noted that a constitution exists for the country, if it can not keep up with the progress of the times, it should be revised, adding that the current Republic of China Constitution has been revised 11 times, but the holes are getting bigger despite the repeated efforts.
The current Constitution should be abrogated and a new one should be formulated, he said.

He said that the ROC Constitution was formulated in Nanjing in the mainland in 1946 when Taiwan delegates didn't participate. The Kuomintang regime imposed it on Taiwan, so why should Taiwan people enshrine the Constitution? he asked, claiming that over half of local people do not recognize the ROC, and that the ROC Constitution has nothing to do with Taiwan people.
He added that the ROC Constitution was formulated for 450 million Chinese people back in 1946, but Taiwan had only six million people then. The "big" Constitution simply does not fit Taiwan, he said.

He pointed out that the French Fifth Republic imposed a dual-leadership system, but the president and the premier are often at loggerheads. The ROC Constitution sets out a five-branch government, which is neither a presidential nor a Cabinet system, a practice that has baffled many foreign scholars, who ask how the system can operate, Lee said. It works because it has never been put into practice, he added.

He noted that only 28 or 29 out of the more than 190 countries in the world have a presidential system, but he said that election quality in Taiwan is one of the poorest in the world with gangsters being able to be elected as legislators, which he said wouldn't be possible in Japan or Italy, for instance.

If a Cabinet system were practiced in Taiwan, then gangster legislators could unite to control or manipulate the government, he said, adding that it is better to institute a presidential system during the transitional period.

Lee noted that mainland China has announced that it would not turn a blind eye if Taiwan creates a new constitution, believing it would be the last step toward Taiwan's independence, but he added that Taiwan is already an independent country with its own peoples, land and government, but China does not recognize this fact and instead pressures Taiwan through the United States.

Lee, who had taught many years at National Taiwan University, said that many of his students have graduated from prestigious schools from around the world. The students have thoroughly researched the Constitution, and will formulate a new one and put it on a referendum in Taiwan in due time, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN REPRESENTATIVE TO HONG KONG ARRIVES TO ASSUME POST

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to Hong Kong, Pao Cheng-kang, arrived to assume his new post Monday, pledging to do his utmost to promote ties between the two sides.

Pao, whose official title is managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong because of the lack of diplomatic ties between Hong Kong and Taiwan, was mobbed at the airport by journalists who showered him with questions about how he would try to improve the strained bilateral ties.
Pao said the mutual trust and genuine desire for better ties fostered by Hong Kong and Taiwan would lay the groundwork for closer exchanges between the two.

Actually, Pao said, Hong Kong and Taiwan benefited through medical exchanges during the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome in early 2003, and the fact that he took a shorter time to get a working visa from the Hong Kong authorities than his predecessor is an indication that bilateral ties are improving.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE STUDYING OVERSEAS FELL BY 22.1 PERCENT IN 2003

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwanese studying overseas dropped by 22.1 percent in 2003 compared with the previous year, the Directorate Generate of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Monday.

The DGBAS made the calculation based on the 26,318 visas issued by foreign missions in Taiwan for students wishing to study abroad in 2003. The United States was the most popular destination with 10,324 visa, followed by 6,662 to Great Britain and 2,823 to Australia. The three countries attracted about 75 percent of Taiwanese students in 2003.
Statistics also showed that Taiwan students going to France and Germany rose by 18.5 percent and 10.5 percent, respectively, in 2003.

According to the tallies of foreign students unveiled by the Institute of International Education of the United States, U.S. colleges and universities registered 586,323 foreign students between Sept. 2002 and June 2003. Among them, Taiwan students numbered 28,017, ranking them fifth in terms of foreign students behind India, China, South Korea and Japan.

DGBAS statistics also showed that there were 7,844 foreign students in Taiwan in 2003, among them 1,568 were studying for degrees and 6,276 were studying Mandarin, up 22.2 percent and 3.8 percent, respectively.

Among the foreign students, the humanities was the most popular discipline, followed by business, management, economics and psychology, but more and more students are coming to Taiwan to study engineering. Eighty-seven such students were recorded in 2003, an annual increase of 107 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO ESTABLISH 'CULTURALLY CIVIL SOCIETY'

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday the Cabinet will come up with concrete measures based on the action guidelines and policy initiatives proposed by scholars attending a national conference on ethnic and cultural development to establish a "culturally civil society."
Yu made the pledge at the closing ceremony of the two-and-half day ethnic and cultural development conference.
Noting that Taiwan is an immigrant society, Yu said the majority of Taiwan people have traditionally possessed an "immigrant spirit" of mutual learning, mutual assistance and mutual cooperation.

"Taiwan has experienced successive waves of immigration over the past four centuries. In addition to the aboriginal citizens, native Taiwanese, hakka and mainlanders that now populate Taiwan, many new immigrants have also come to Taiwan through marriage or naturalization in recent years amid globalization and liberalization, " the premier said, adding that with Taiwan's population becoming ever more ethnically diverse, the various ethnic groups should respect and recognize one another's differences and unique features to create a harmonious living environment and forge a common national identity.

Yu further said patience, consideration and sensibility are required elements to realize the goal of "ethnic diversity and national unity" outlined in President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural address.

With a view to realizing this ultimate goal, Yu said the Cabinet will work out concrete measures in line with the action guidelines proposed by at the conference, including establishing a viable mechanism for multicultural exchanges, offering better care for minority ethnic groups, and formulating new language and education policies to boost Taiwan's cultural diversity and transform Taiwan into a "culturally civil society."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS SEEKING INT'L COOPERATION IN TRADE: ECONOMICS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Regardless of the difficulties, Taiwan will never cease trying to create strategic international alliances, Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said Monday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Hu said the Executive Yuan has approached Paraguay, Nicaragua and Japan for possible conclusion in a free trade agreement, and is negotiating with the United States on a trade and investment framework agreement.

As a matter of fact, Hu said, a panel under the Executive Yuan overseeing the free trade agreement negotiations gathered for the first time Monday to review progress in talks with Japan, Paraguay and Nicaragua.
Consensus has emerged in talks with Japan that a free trade agreement is one of the possible ways of bilateral cooperation, Hu went on.
Talks with the United States on the trade and investment framework agreement have focused on telecommunications, medicine, rice and intellectual property rights, Hu said.

Hu made the comments in response to a question from opposition Legislator Thomas Tung-hao Lee regarding how Hu's council will cushion the impact prompted by the closer economic partnership arrangement between mainland China and Hong Kong which, Lee said, could boost the economies of Hong Kong and the mainland to the detriment of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC DELIVERS GERMAN-COMMISSIONED CONTAINER SHIP

TEXT.P: China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) on Monday delivered a container ship to the German shipping company Peter Dohle.
The delivery ceremony was held at CSBC's second wharf in Kaohsiung, with CSBC acting-President Fan Kuang-nan and Peter Dohle Executive Chairman Jochen Dohle presiding.
Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh was invited to christen the ship.
The ship, called " Copiapo, " is the first of 12 container ships that Peter Dohle and its trading partner -- Chilean shipping firm CSAV -- jointly ordered.

Fan noted that the "Copiapo," with the capacity of carrying 5,500 Twenty-Equivalent-Units (TEUs), has the newest and safest structural design offered by CSBC. Fan expressed his gratitude to Peter Dohle for giving his company the order.
The "Copiapo, " which is equipped with the newest satellite and automatic navigation systems, is 264 meters long, 40 meters wide and 24 meters high, with a top speed of 25.6 knots.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL SEMINAR ON AQUACULTURE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An international seminar on aquaculture began Monday in Taipei, with representatives from 10 Asia-Pacific countries discussing ways to seek sustainable aquaculture development.
The five-day seminar was organized jointly by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) and the Asian Productivity Organization (FAO).

Quoting statistics compiled by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United States, COA officials noted that Asia's aquaculture industry has enjoyed brilliant growth in the past, with its production in 2001 accounting for 90.8 percent of the world figure.
However, the industry was seriously affected by some problems during recent years, such as environmental pollution, the officials added.
The seminar will help Asia-Pacific countries exchange experiences for the sustainable development of aquaculture, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WILL HELP HONG KONG TOURISTS IN BUS ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Monday promised to do all it can to help the survivors of a tragic bus accident in Taipei County that killed five women tourists from Hong Kong and injured 32 others.

The MAC has informed the Hong Kong government and the families of those involved in the accident and sent representatives to visit them to express sympathy through the Chung Hwa Travel Services, its Hong Kong office.

There were 38 people on the tour bus when the accident took place in the afternoon, including 35 Hong Kong tourists, a Hong Kong tour guide, and Taiwan tour guide Ou Kuo-ming, who was not injured, and bus driver Hsu Chung-hsin. Police are still investigating why the bus overturned on a mountain road.

Chang Yung-shan, director of the MAC's Department of Hong Kong & Macau Affairs, as well as his deputy, Huang Chien-liang, visited the injured tourists, who were in Chang Kung Memorial Hospital and Patu Hospital in Keelung City as well as Rueifang Hospital in Taipei County.
Chung Hwa Travel Services in Hong Kong has taken the initiative to help the family members of the Hong Kong tourists to come to Taiwan. Twelve of them arrived in Taipei Monday night.
Chung Hwa Travel Services also set up hotlines - 9314-0130 and 8200-2665 in Hong Kong as well as 8862-0939-082-274 and 0920-538-577 in Taipei to help the families.

Shantou Company, the owner of the tour bus, said that every deceased passenger will receive an insurance payment of NT$1.4 million (US$41,660) , while all injured tourists will have their medical bills paid for by the insurance company.

Hsu Kao-ching, secretary-general of the Travel Agent Association of the ROC, said that the China Spring (chung-chun) Travel Agency that hosted the two Hong Kong tour groups Monday mainly caters to tourists from Southeast Asian countries, Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China.

Hsu said that Chioufen in Rueifeng township is one of the favorite tourist destinations for Japanese and Hong Kong tourists. The roads in Chioufen have continued to expand to accommodate the rising number of tourists. Bad weather may have caused the bus accident in the afternoon.
It is known that the China Spring Travel Agency didn't insure the Hong Kong tourists, and their operations to cater to Hong Kong tourists could be suspended because of it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTS IN ISRAEL'S GIZA FUND

TEXT.P: The Development Fund under the Executive Yuan entered into a strategic alliance with the Giza Fund owned by the GE Capital Group in Tel Aviv, Israel Monday by investing NT$450 million (US$13.32 million).

Lin Yi-fu, chairman of the Development Fund said the alliance will enhance Taiwan's presence in the international venture capital market and set the stage for industrial cooperation between Taiwan and Israel.

Citing as proof of this, Lin said several Israeli integrated circuit design companies are exploring the possibility of having the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company in Hsinchu help them produce their products.

Noting that 20 percent of the Development Fund's investments in Giza will be used for Taiwan's start-ups, especially undertakings in the fields of telecommunications, information software and life sciences, Lin said he hopes the alliance will encourage other government-controlled funds to follow suit by investing in Giza.
The Development Fund under the Executive Yuan was founded in 1973 with the purpose of helping upgrade local industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: SELF-DEFENSE ENSURES PEACE ACROSS THE STRAIT: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The proposed arms purchase from the United States is meant to show Taiwan's determination to defend itself rather than compete against mainland China in an arms race, Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Min-hsien said Monday.

In a news conference called to rally support for the government's request for a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) to buy arms from the United States, Tsai said the purchase is not meant to strike a "balance of terror" with mainland China, but to ensure that Taiwan has the capability to survive a first strike and launch a counter-strike, which would deter the mainland from even beginning hostilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC MINISTER OPTIMISTIC ON TAIWAN'S PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will continue to steadily grow at least until the first half of next year, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.

Speaking at a luncheon hosted by the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Ho said that Taiwan enjoyed 7.2 percent growth in the first half of this year and that its whole year growth rate is likely to top the targeted 5.87 percent.
Besides, she noted, it has been estimated that Taiwan's exports will set a new record of US$170 billion this year, up 24 percent from the previous year's level.
Private investment accumulated to NT$820 billion (US$24.55 billion) in the first nine months of this year and is estimated to reach NT$860 billion for the whole year, she added.
Taiwan's economic prospects will continue to be rosy in the first half of next year if the impact of high oil prices is not taken into consideration, the minister predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 19, or the sixth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1216: King John of England, known as John Lackland, dies at the age of 49. During his reign, the English lost most of their possessions in France. The nobility rose up against John and forced him to sign the Magna Carta, a cornerstone of English political and civil liberties.
1781: General Charles Cornwallis, British commander, unwittingly delivers his 8,000 troops into the hands of the besieging American forces at Yorktown in Virginia, allowing Gen. George Washington to win the War of Independence for the American colonists.
1812: Tsar Alexander's refusal to negotiate, along with renewed Russian military activity to the south of Moscow, leaves Napoleon Bonaparte with no alternative but to begin retreating from Moscow, which was captured by the French.
1872: The Holtermann Nugget, a slate weighing 235.14 kilograms, is found in New South Wales, Australia. It contains 82.11 kilograms of gold, the largest single mass of gold ever found.
1901: Alberto Santos Dumont, a Brazilian aviator, circumnavigates the Eiffel Tower in his airship to win the Deutsche Prize, the first aviation prize.
1925: Chiang Ching-kuo leaves Shanghai for Moscow to study at Sun Yat-sen University.
1935: The League of Nations imposes sanctions against Italy following its invasion of Ethiopia.
1936: Chou Shu-jen, a modern Chinese writer who used the pen name Lu Hsun and was admired most by the Chinese communists, dies of illness in Shanghai at the age of 56.
1937: Ernest Rutherford, New Zealand-born British physicist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize in chemistry, dies at the age of 66. He is regarded as the founder of modern atomic theory.
1940: The Burma road is reopened after the British had closed it for three months.
1947: The Taiwan Provincial Government opens Keelung and Kaohsiung as international seaports.
1950: The North Korean capital of Pyongyang falls during the Korean War.
1960: The U.S. State Department establishes an embargo on Cuban-bound shipments of all goods except medicine and foodstuffs.
1960: Mauritania proclaims independence from France.
1963: Sir Alec Douglas-Home succeeds Harold Macmillan as British prime minister.
1968: Republic of China athlete Chi Cheng wins a bronze medal in the women's 80-meter low hurdle event with a time of 10.4 seconds at the 19th Olympic Games held in Mexico City.
1973: Dr. Li Yuan-zu is appointed president of National Chengchi University.
1975: A total of 5,462 athletes begin seven days of competition at the Second Taiwan Area Games in Taipei.
1979: Lord Killanin, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1981: San Antonio Mayor Henry Cisneros declares that the historic city in Texas will establish sisterhood ties with the city of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan.
1987: Wall Street experiences the worst day in its history, known as "Black Monday," with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting a record 508.32 points, knocking US$500 billion off share values. The decline is 22.6 percent, almost 10 percent greater than the stock market crash of 1929, which heralded the Great Depression.
1990: Mikhail Gorbachev, leader of the USSR, wins parliamentary approval for a plan to switch the centrally planned Soviet economy to a market economy.
1999: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese for their enthusiasm in providing assistance to Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: The ROC's opposition Kuomintang expels Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi from the party, chiding him for "severely opposing KMT policies and impeding the interests of the people."
2001: Vice President Annette Lu receives 1998 Nobel laureate in medicine, Dr. Ferid Murad, at the Presidential Office.
2001: U.S. President George W. Bush tells reporters that in a meeting with his mainland Chinese counterpart, he reiterated Washington's stance on the Taiwan issue, namely "one China" and "a resolution of differences through peaceful means."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the Book of Songs it is said: `I keep in mind the fine moral qualities which make no great noise or show.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: POWELL TO ENCOURAGE BEIJING TO ENGAGE IN CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell will during his forthcoming visit to Beijing encourage mainland China to engage in dialogue with Taiwan and will respond to Beijing's concerns over U.S. arms sales to the island, a State Department senior press officer said Monday.

Spokesman Richard Boucher said at a daily press briefing that the secretary will also discuss with mainland Chinese leaders the speech recently made by President Chen Shui-bian about the prospects of dialogue with Beijing, and tell them that the United States does see that as an opportunity for cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue.
Powell will visit three Asian countries, namely Japan, mainland China and South Korea, between Oct. 23-26. He is scheduled to arrive in Beijing Oct. 25 for a one-day visit.

Pointing out that Powell will want to take up some of the Taiwan issues again during his visit in Beijing, the spokesman said that the secretary also looks forward to having a chance to respond on a lot of talk about arms sales to Taiwan.

Touching on Chen's Oct. 10 National Day speech, Boucher said that Washington knows Beijing didn't take the speech the same way as the United States did, "but it's a chance to look at what we can all do to promote the idea of dialogue across the strait."
Asked whether the United States is "entirely happy" with President Chen's speech, the spokesman said that obviously, the United States "is not endorsing anybody's speech completely."

However, he added that "we think there were elements in it that were creative, we think there were elements in it that were constructive, and we felt that there's an opportunity here to get back to a cross-strait dialogue that should be looked at by all the parties."

Tougher laws, including imposing a jail term, are to be introduced against home users who illegally download music, movies and computer programs from the Internet onto their computers.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAINT VINCENT CALLS FOR TAIWAN HELP IN NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT PLANNING

TEXT.P: Visiting Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves said Tuesday that he hopes Taiwan can assist his country in drawing up economic development and financial reform plans.
Gonsalves made the remarks while meeting with Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of Taiwan's Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Gonsalves told Hu that his country intends to launch national development and financial reform projects. Due to a lack of experience, Gonsalves said, his country needs Taiwan's assistance in outlining the work plans.

"We hope Taiwan can send economic and financial reform planning experts or strategists to our country for a two or three month stay to help with drafting detailed measures and work schedules. If necessary, we would also send personnel to Taiwan to learn from your experiences in relevant fields," Gonsalves said.

In response, Hu said the CEPD -- the Cabinet's top economic planning agency -- is more than willing to offer counseling services for the East Caribbean ally's financial reform and economic development projects.

As a mater of fact, Hu said, the two sides already reached a consensus on boosting information and personnel exchanges when Saint Vincent and the Grenadines' vice finance minister paid a visit to the CEPD about a month ago.
Gonsalves, accompanied by his wife and several senior officials, arrived in Taipei Monday for a visit to boost bilateral cooperation.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraq Vote Faces Growing Troubles; Security in Crisis; U.N. Role Limited.
The United Nations has failed to fully staff its operation in Iraq, imperiling the timing and quality of the elections there and forcing inexperienced Iraqis to take the lead in preparing for the country's first democratic balloting, due in January, the paper quoted U.S. officials and election experts as saying.

New York Times: Poll shows tie; concerns cited on both rivals
Two weeks before Election Day, voters hold a sharply critical view of President Bush's record in office, but they have strong reservations about Senator John Kerry, leaving the race in a tie, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News polls. Bush's job approval rating is at 44 perrcent, a dangerously low n umber for an incumbent president, and one of the lowest of his tenure. A majority of voters said that they disapproved of the way Bush had managed the economy and the war in Iraq. But a majority of Americans continue to see Kerry as an untrustworthy politician who will say what he thinks people want to hear. The poll found the two candidates each drawing 46 percent of all registered voters in a head-to-head race. Among likely voters in a two-way race, Bush has 47 percent, with 46 percent for Kerry.
Wall Street Journal: IBM earnings beat expectations
International Business Machines Corp. reported what its chief executive called "one of our strongest third quarters in recent years" -- benefiting from growth in new services lines and emerging markets such as China and Russia - - and urged analysts to boost their outlooks for the year. Samuel J. Palmisano, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that "IBM has been gaining momentum throughout the year, and the strength of our integrated business model gives us confidence as we look toward 2005."

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN, AUSTRALIA, SINGAPORE RESPOND POSITIVELY TO CHEN SPEECH: MOFA

TEXT.P: Japan, Australia and Singapore have all responded positively to President Chen Shui-bian's Oct. 10 National Day address, saying Chen's peace overtures are conducive to easing tension in the Taiwan Strait, a diplomatic official said Tuesday.
Chen Shan-lin, deputy director of the Asia-Pacific Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , made the remarks at a regular news conference.

"The three Asian-Pacific countries have given a thumbs-up to President Chen's peace appeals to mainland China, saying that the initiatives could help ease cross-strait tension and facilitate resumption of bilateral dialogue," Chen Shan-lin said.

The Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement immediately after President Chen delivered his National Day speech, reaffirming Japan's commitment to maintaining friendly non-governmental substantive relations with Taiwan and urging the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resolve their disputes through peaceful negotiations.

The Singaporean Ministry of Foreign Affairs also issued a public statement recognizing President Chen's peace overtures. The statement also said that Singapore was pleased to see President Chen deliver an address that would contribute to the easing of cross-strait tension.

Meanwhile, major Australian newspapers ran editorials recognizing President Chen's call for the establishment of a cross-strait military trust mechanism as helpful toward the lowering of cross-strait tensions. The Australian news media also pushed the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to end their hostility as early as possible.

President Chen proposed in his National Day address that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways that are "not necessarily perfect, but acceptable" in preparation for a step forward in the resumption of long-stalled cross-strait dialogue and consultations.

Referring to himself by his nickname 'A-bian, ' Chen further said that as any conflict would cause irreparable damage to both sides, Taiwan and mainland China should seriously consider practical steps toward "arms control."
"Therefore A-bian proposes that both sides should seriously consider the issue of arms control and take concrete actions to reduce tension and military threats across the Taiwan Strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TOURISTS CUT TRIP SHORT AFTER TOUR BUS ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Several Hong Kong tourists who suffered light injuries in a tour bus accident in Taipei Monday decided on Tuesday to cut their trip short and return home a day early.

The tour bus carrying 36 Hong Kong tourists overturned in scenic Chioufen, Ruifang, killing five female tourists and injuring 32 other passengers. It is suspected that faulty brakes combined with the driver's fast speed in the rain caused the accident, but police are still investigating. As of Tuesday, more than 10 of the tourists remained in hospital for further observation.
Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that some of the tourists will head back to Hong Kong a day earlier than the scheduled departure Wednesday.
The Travel Agent Association of the Republic of China and the China Spring Travel Agency in Taipei, which arranged the tour, are making preparations for the tourists' early return home.
Chiu said the MAC will respect the wishes of the family members in handling the bodies of those killed in the accident. The bodies are currently being held at a Keelung City morgue.

Meanwhile, two Hong Kong immigration officials and two medical staff, who arrived in Taiwan in the early morning hours of Tuesday, headed to Rueifang Hospital in Taipei County and Chang Kung Memorial Hospital in Keelung County to visit the injured and their family members to learn how the accident happened and to help with matters in the aftermath of the accident. The Hong kong team was accompanied by MAC officials.
MAC Chairman Joseph Wu also visited the two hospitals in the afternoon to express his sympathy to the family members of the deceased and to wish a speedy recovery to those who were injured.
Tourism Bureau also sent officials to the hotels where the family members of the tourists were staying to offer them any assistance they might require.

The MAC informed the Hong Kong government and the family members of the tourists right after the accident through its representative office in Hong Kong Monday, setting up hot lines for any family members of the victims to check the latest developments regarding the accident.

Meanwhile, Hsu Chung-hsin, the driver of the tour bus, faces up to seven and a half years in prison, stiff fines and the loss of his driver's license for life if he is found guilty of driving under the influence of alcohol or of using a hand-held mobile phone while operating the bus.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices surged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 35.67 points to close at 5,807.79.
The bourse opened at 5,815.91, with the weighted index fluctuating between 5,824.14 and 5,765.32 during the day's trading.
A total of 2.88 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.92 billion (US$1.85 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up the most by 1.8 percent and foodstuff shares rose by 0.6 percent.

Of the six stock categories that lost ground, the construction issues suffered the greatest setback at 2 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.4 percent, both paper issues and textiles stocks at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.2 percent and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 351 to 309, with 139 stocks remaining unchanged.
