DOC.HEADLINE: FLAP OVER TAIWAN'S FOREIGN AID COULD BE CHINA'S MANIPULATION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that the recent allegations of improper use of ROC aid to two diplomatic allies has all the trappings of backdoor maneuvering by mainland China.

The premier made the remarks while fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan amid media reports that China may be behind allegations out of Latin America that Taiwan had conducted "dollar diplomacy" under the guise of foreign aid to Costa Rica and Nicaragua.

Legislator Chou Hsi-wei of the opposition People First Party asked why Taiwan's foreign aid to diplomatic allies for national construction had allegedly been turned into a campaign fund and why the former head of Costa Rica has stepped down from an important post over the matter.

Chou was referring to the Costa Rica government's request to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs last week that Taiwan provide a written statement about all cash aid offered to Costa Rica during former Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez's time in office.

Rodriguez, who stepped down as the secretary general of the Organization of American States early this month, has been detained for allegedly accepting huge kickbacks from Alcatel, a French telcom company. The Costa Rica government is also reportedly investigating allegations that Rodriguez received political donations from Taiwan.

Foreign wire reports also said Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos faces possible removal from office on corruption charges, including allegations that he pocketed US$4.9 million from Taiwan for his 2001 election campaign.

The premier said that no one has stepped down from their post over the allegations of illegal foreign aid from Taiwan and a person is presumed innocent before a ruling and outsiders should not interfere with the internal affairs of other countries.
"We are obliged to provide assistance to the international community, " he said, adding that Taiwan provides assistance in a "cautious" manner.

Since the reports involving the two countries surfaced at about the same time and both countries are major allies of Taiwan, the premier said the situation looks suspiciously like the "invisible hand" of China at work.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen also said that "it is a reasonable supposition" that China was behind the scenes pulling the strings.

Chen again said that foreign aid, given in accordance with the law and established procedures and under legislative supervision to ROC allies is used at the discretion of the ally governments, and shouldn't be interfered with.

Chen added that mainland Chinese leaders and officials have always done everything possible to lure away allies from Taiwan, and judging by the current situation, they are up to their old tricks again.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ADVANCED E2T AIRCRAFT TO JOIN AIR FORCE FLEET NEXT SPRING

TEXT.P: Two advanced E2T Hawkeye early warning aircraft will join the ROC Air Force fleet next March to further beef up Taiwan's defense capabilities, military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regular news conference at the Ministry of National Defense (MND), Huang said the ROC Air Force placed the order for the two E2T early warning aircraft with the United States back in 1999 after it purchased four of this type of aircraft in 1992.

The two E2Ts to be delivered next spring belong to an upgraded version, Huang said, adding that the commissioning of the two additional early warning aircraft will effectively help the air force maintain its air supremacy over the Taiwan Strait.
According to Huang, the upgraded E2Ts can stay airborne longer and fly farther.
With the delivery of the two new warplanes, Huang said, the air force will have six E2Ts to assist with Taiwan's defense needs.

At present, Huang said each of Taiwan's E2Ts can stay in the air for four hours for surveillance missions. In the future, the E2T fleet will be able to conduct round-the-clock reconnaissance missions.
The E2T fleet will also support disaster rescue and relief work as well as combat strategy testing and training missions, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE UNIONS FROM STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES BEGIN HUNGER STRIKES

TEXT.P: Officials from trade unions of state-run or public-controlled enterprises began hunger strikes in Taipei Tuesday after failing to get a response from the ruling party for their call to review the nation's privatization policy.

The officials of the trade unions threatened to continue the hunger strike until Friday when the Legislative Yuan is scheduled to have a floor meeting unless the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), respond.
The Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) mobilized more than 2,000 workers from state-run and public-controlled enterprises to a rally in front of the Legislative Yuan Tuesday morning.

Rally participants asked the government to consult with the TCTU when formulating its privatization policy, and that before a consensus is reached in the consultations, the government should suspend the release of shares of the enterprises involved.

Also, before the privatization of state-owned enterprises, the enterprises should sign contacts with the trade unions, and that the government should also respect the business operations of the enterprises and cut administrative interference.

Yen Ching-piao, convener of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union's legislative caucus, and Liu Wen-hsiung, the opposition People First Party's whip in the legislature, as well as Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the Policy Committee of the opposition Kuomintang, agreed that their parties would review the privatization policy of the nation.
But the officials from the trade unions, after failing to obtain a response from the DPP and the TSU, began a hunger strike at about 3 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS NO HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUM HIKE DURING HIS TENURE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reiterated Tuesday that there will be no hike in national health insurance premiums during his tenure.

Yu made the reaffirmation during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where opposition People First Party Legislator Shen Chih-hui asked the premier whether the health insurance premiums would be raised to "salvage" the financially troubled national health insurance program.
In response, Yu said the Cabinet has no plan to raise health insurance premiums before his term in office expires Feb. 1, 2005 when the new legislature to be elected Dec. 11 is inaugurated.
Speaking on the same occasion, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Chen Chien-jen said health insurance is a kind of social insurance and requires the support of all citizens.

"Therefore, the DOH will hold a public meeting to help forge a national consensus on reforming the existing health insurance program, " Chen said, adding that the civic meeting is scheduled to take place in December.
Noting that the health insurance program has been operating at a loss, Chen said Taiwan needs to design a second-generation insurance program for local people's common well-being.

Chen also defended the "Excellent Hospital Program, " saying that since the program was put into practice, patients of acute and serious diseases have received better care at national medical centers.

The epidemiologist-turned-official further said if each local citizen can cut one outpatient visit to a medical facility per year, the national health insurance program will be more viable. According to Chen, each local citizen makes an average of 14 outpatient visits annually.
"The number is too high. We should save our medical resources. If we can cut the per capita outpatient visits by one, our health insurance program will be more sustainable," he stressed.
During the same legislative session, Premier Yu also said that the implementation of an all-volunteer military service system is still in the planning stage.

"The time is not yet been ripe for implementing an all-volunteer military service system. The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is still working on the plan and has not yet reached the policy formulation stage. It will take a long time to transform the current conscription-dominated service system into an all-volunteer one, " Yu said.

Yu was responding to PFP Legislator Lin Yu-fang's question about the feasibility of the MND's five-year troop restructuring plan under which the MND will need an additional budget of NT$380.9 billion to finance its volunteer soldiers recruitment plan.
Yu said the MND estimate was just a preliminary calculation. "The estimate may not be accurate because the volunteer recruitment plan has not yet fully matured," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ASSESS STANCE BEFORE NEW ROUND OF WTO TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Tuesday that Taiwan will make an overall assessment of its negotiation stance before the Doha round of talks under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , which is expected to begin next February.

Chen said that the ministry will make use of the time before the opening of the talks to coordinate with government agencies and make an overall assessment to establish the government's stance for the talks to obtain the best outcome for the nation.
Taiwan will still focus on four issues that are most closely related to Taiwan -- agriculture, non-agricultural market access (NAMA), the service industry, and trade facilitation, according to Chen.

Chen is currently visiting Geneva after attending an annual meeting in Zurich of the EVIAN Group -- an association of elite members in political and business communities in major countries around the world.

During his stay in Geneva, he exchanged views with Taiwan's mission to the WTO on the July package, called on WTO General Council Chairperson Shotaro Oshima as well as permanent representatives from Australia and South Korea.

Chen noted that the passage of the July package by the WTO is a major breakthrough, but the next stage of substantial talks will come early next year at the soonest. During the interval, the ministry and Taiwan's mission to the WTO will work closely to establish their stance for future talks, he added.

Of the four issues that Taiwan is most concerned about, Chen wouldn't deny that agriculture will be impacted, and that the nation will have to make adjustments to brace for future developments. As for the other three issues, they will help Taiwan's trade development.

NAMA is of course beneficial to Taiwan, Chen said, noting that export-oriented Taiwan hopes that the trade in industrial products will be further liberalized and that more markets will open to create more trade opportunities.

He also said that the service sector presently accounts for 67 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product. But as the service sector is currently confined to the island, he is hoping that in the future it will make inroads into international markets.
Chen also said that Taiwan has great potential for development in the areas of transportation, telecommunications, finance, information and technology, as well as tourism.
Chen is scheduled to leave Geneva for home Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PURCHASE PRICE MIGHT BE REDUCED BY NT$100 BILLION: DEFENSE CHIEF

TEXT.P: If Taiwan doesn't insist on taking part in the building of the eight submarines it plans to purchase from the United States, the price for them could be reduced by NT$71.9 billion (US$2.12 billion), Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Tuesday.

In an attempt to seek lawmakers' support for his ministry's request for a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) to buy the submarines and other arms from the United States, Lee told the Legislative Yuan that the price for the purchase may be further reduced by some NT$30 billion (US$886.13 million) if part of the price is financed through the ministry's regular budget.
However, Lee said there is no point in haggling with the United States over the price before Taiwan has chosen what subs are up for offer.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN-MACAU CHARTER FLIGHT INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: TransAsia Airways made its maiden charter flight from the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien to Macau Tuesday as part of its efforts to help boost the local tourist industry.
Among the passengers were Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan and several other county officials.

Hsieh said he was heading a team of officials and business executives to attract Macau investors and holidaymakers to Hualien, which has long been noted for its beautiful scenery and tourist resources.

"We hope the visit can not only help us realize the goal of doubling tourist arrivals but also attract Macau businesses to invest in Hualien County to accelerate our economic development and create more jobs, " Hsieh said, adding that the county government is determined to develop Hualien become one of the most popular recreational resorts in the West Pacific.

TransAsia has cooperated with travel agencies in Hualien in opening the Hualien-Macau charter flight services. The carrier will operate three round-trip charter flights. The other two round-trip charter flights will take off Oct. 23 and Oct. 27 from Hualien Airport. An airline spokesman said the Hualien-Macau flight time is shorter than that needed for the Taipei-Macau flight. The inauguration of charter flights to Macau will benefit residents in eastern Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Putin Calls a Bush Loss a Victory for Terrorists.
President Vladimir Putin on Monday made his strongest endorsement yet for his friend U.S. President George W. Bush, saying "international terrorism" will claim victory over the international antiterrorism coalition if Bush loses.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX COMPANIES TO OPEN IN PINGTUNG AGRO-BIOTECH PARK THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Six companies are expected to begin operations in the Pingtung Agro-biotechnology Park by the end of this year, officials of the organizing committee for the establishment of the complex said Tuesday.

The committee has so far received 27 applications since its establishment last December by companies wishing to set up shop in the park, which is located in the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung. Nineteen of them have been approved, the officials noted.

The government has earmarked NT$12.8 billion (US$3.77 billion) for the construction of the compound, which is still undergoing, they said, adding that the first stage of construction is scheduled to be completed in 2006.
The park will be capable of housing 120 companies and will provide 8,000 job opportunities after construction is completed.
The annual output of the park is estimated to top NT$24 billion within 10 years, the officials said.
The committee has organized two conferences in Kaohsiung and Taichung for soliciting investments in the park and a third one will be held in Taipei Dec. 9.
It has also organized four similar conferences in Philadelphia and Chicago of the United States, and in Winnipeg and Saskatoon of Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS SPENT NT$1.8 BILLION AIDING ANTI-TERRORISM DRIVE: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Taiwan has spent NT$1.8 billion assisting in the U.S.-led anti-terrorist campaign over the past three years, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker said Tuesday.

Legislator Sun Guo-hua claimed at a news conference held at the KMT legislative caucus office that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) appropriated a total of NT$1.8 billion in secret budgets between 2003 and 2005 to help finance U.S.-led anti-terrorist activities.
Sun said he believes that Taiwan is the third-largest supporter of the global anti-terrorist campaign after the United States and Great Britain.
Hsieh Wu-chiao, director of the North American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), would not respond to Sun's remarks at the news conference.
Instead, Hsieh said the fight against terrorism is a universal value. As a member of the international community, he went on, Taiwan should support the campaign.
Hsieh stressed that Taiwan's aid for reconstruction projects in Afghanistan and other anti-terrorist activities has not been related to any military actions.
"We only offer humanitarian aid and medical resources, " Hsieh said, adding that he couldn't reveal any details because of a tacit understanding with the United States.
Hsieh further said U.S. officials and congressmen have on several occasions recognizing Taiwan's contributions to the global anti-terrorist campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OPTO-ELECTRONICS INDUSTRY GROWS RAPIDLY

TEXT.P: The output of Taiwan's opto-electronics industry is estimated to reach NT$987.4 billion (US$29.1 billion) this year, up 34 percent from the previous year's level, an expert with the Industrial Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday.

Speaking at a conference on the development and market trends of the technology industry, Cheng Chia-lung, an analyst with the ITIS, said that Taiwan's opto-electronics industry already enjoyed a rapid growth of 29 percent last year with an annual production of NT$737.4 billion.
The industry's growth rate is higher than that of the whole world, which is estimated to stand at 13 percent this year with an annual production of US$226.88 billion, he noted.
The annual output of Taiwan's opto-electronics industry is expected to surpass NT$1 trillion in the next year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAM DELEGATION TO SEEK INVESTMENT FROM TAIWAN: ECONOMICS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A delegation from Vietnam will visit the Export Processing Zone Administration in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan Friday to seek trade partners and investments from Taiwan, an official from the administration said Tuesday.

The official said the Vietnam delegation consists of industrialists in the fields of leather, garments, machinery, electronics, household wares, construction materials, wood, agricultural and fishery products, food processing, paper manufacturing, textiles, plastics, chemicals, cosmetics and metal processing.

Vietnam, with a population of 80 million and rich natural resources, has been wooing foreign investment aggressively in recent years, and is an ideal market for Taiwanese investors, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL OFFERS HELP TO H.K. TOURISTS INVOLVED IN BUS ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, went to visit Hong Kong tourists on Tuesday who were injured when their tour bus overturned on a mountain road Monday, offering to help them return to Hong Kong.
Wu told journalists that his council will line up a special flight to ferry the injured and other survivors to Hong Kong Tuesday night.
The bodies of the five killed in the accident will be returned to Hong Kong as soon as the legal process is completed, Wu said.

In addition to giving each of the injured tourists 1,200 Hong Kong dollars (US$154), the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will help the tourists claim damages from the local travel agency that organized the tour, Wu said.

Meanwhile, Wang Chun-pao, an official posted to Hong Kong by the Taiwan Visitors Association, expressed his condolences to the families of the dead, saying that his association will help them fly to Taiwan to collect the bodies if they wish, and will do everything to ensure the safety of Hong Kong tourists in Taiwan.
The traffic accident took place on Monday when a bus carrying 36 tourists from Hong Kong overturned on a stretch of steep road in Chioufen, Taipei County, northern Taiwan killed five and injured 32.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN OCT. 25

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed a report from Seoul, South Korea Tuesday that former South Korean President Kim Young Sam will visit Taiwan later this month.

Although spokesman Michel Lu wouldn't reveal the purpose of Kim's visit, an anonymous official from the ministry said Kim, who visited Taipei in July, 2001 to lay the groundwork for the resumption of direct flights between the two countries, will meet with President Chen Shui-bian as the envoy of South Korean President Roh Moo Hyun.
The Korea Central Daily News in Seoul said Kim, who served as president between 1992 and 1997, will head for Taipei on Oct. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP HAILS TAIWAN AS MIRACLE

TEXT.P: The emergence of civil society in Taiwan contrasts sharply with China and is really a miracle in Pacific area, Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday.

Speaking to the Forum 2000 of the Czech Republic in Prague via teleconference, Lu said Taiwan has displayed a marvelous flexibility in getting along with China, in spite of China's claim that Taiwan is apart of its territory.
Lu said Taiwan has created miracles in economics, democracy and peace in the last five decades.
The forum was initiated by former president of Czech Vaclav Havel in 1997 and Lu is one of two guests invited to deliver a speech to it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 20, or the seventh day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border along the 49th parallel west of the Great Lakes.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as British, French and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat and scholar, dies of a heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize in physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his communist forces end their so-called "Long March" in Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10, 1934, the main forces of the Chinese communists fled their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contributions as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs a new Sino-Belgium Treaty and a new Sino-Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill his promise of returning that he made at the time when his forces were forced to retreat in the face of advancing Japanese forces.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the ROC Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts at improving relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: Yang Liang-kung, new president of the Examination Yuan, assumes office, while Liu Chi-hung takes office as vice president.
1975: The Fourth Pan-Pacific Conference on Regional Science opens in Taipei with more than 100 experts from Japan, the United States, Singapore and the ROC attending.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow. A total of 340 people are killed.
1999: The ROC government extends its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory.
2000: Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of finance at National Chengchi University, urges the Democratic Progressive Party government to stop presenting any new policy initiatives in order to revive public confidence and maintain domestic stability.
2000: The U.S. Senate passes by a unanimous vote a House concurrent resolution in support of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) says that the "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China is outdated and vows to replace it with a more aggressive approach.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ACCUSES TAIWAN OF NOT TREATING THERMISTOR AS IT PRODUCT
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: The United States on Tuesday accused Taiwan of not treating thermistors, or thermally sensitive resistors, as an information technology (IT) product and of therefore imposing import duties on them, a source in Geneva said the same day.

A U.S. delegate made the accusation at a meeting held by the World Trade Organization's Information Technology Product Committee, noting that the World Customs Organization (WCO) has decided that the thermistor is an IT product that is not subject to import duties, according to the source.

Taiwan's customs authorities have been imposing a 7.5-percent import duty on thermistor products imported from the United States by U.S. Tyco Co.'s Taiwan branch since they consider that the thermistor is a resettable fuse product rather than an IT product as Tyco's Taiwan branch claims.
Thermistors are solid state, electronic devices which detect thermal environmental changes for use in temperature measurement, control and compensation of circuitry.
The U.S. delegate expressed the hope that Taiwan would respect the WCO's decision and not continue to impose import duties on thermistor products from the United States.

In response to the accusation, Taiwan representatives attending the meeting said that Taiwan is reviewing the issue and promised that the island will not only deal with the issue with the United States on the basis of mutual interests, but will also give the United States an explanation regarding the matter at an appropriate time, according to the source.

This is the second time that the United States has made the accusation, showing the country's serious concern about the issue. However, the U.S. side did not mention during the meeting whether it will take further action, the source added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:PM:Chinese community has key role. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong told the Chinese community last night that it has every reason to feel confident about the future of its culture, language and traditions.
The rise of China and other Asian countries as economic powerhouses was sparking a revival of cultures and traditions across the continent, he noted.
The Chinese community should therefore take a proactive lead in helping Singapore seize the opportunities presented by Asia's renaissance,he added.
One key role it can play is to help promote the learning of the Chinese language and make it a living language in Singapore,PM said.
The Lianhe Zaobao:PM ask Chinese commuity to help promote the learning of the Chinese language.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS WITH SAINT VINCENT PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with visiting Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves Wednesday to discuss how to further strengthen cooperation between the two countries.

Noting that Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has been one of Taiwan's staunchest diplomatic allies in the East Caribbean, Chen said relations between the two countries have been cordial since they forged formal ties in 1981.
In the future, Chen said, he hopes the two countries can cooperate even closer in trade, investment, cultural development and civilian exchanges.
Chen also expressed his gratitude for Saint Vincent and the Grenadines' firm support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization.
For his part, Gonsalves said his country is grateful for Taiwan's long-term assistance in its agricultural development and infrastructure construction.

Gonsalves said one of the main purposes of his current visit is to push for the establishment of a Taiwan-Saint Vincent trade and economic cooperation promotion association with a view to attracting more Taiwan business groups to invest in his country.

This is Gonsalves' third visit to Taiwan since he assumed his current post. Gonsalves said he looks forward to seeing commercial exchanges and investment from Taiwan increase significantly in the years to come.

During a Tuesday meeting with Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Gonsalves said he hopes Taiwan can assist his country in drawing up economic development and financial reform plans.

"We hope Taiwan can send economic and financial reform planning experts or strategists to our country for a two or three month stay to help with drafting detailed measures and work schedules. If necessary, we would also send personnel to Taiwan to learn from your experiences in relevant fields," Gonsalves said.

In response, Hu said the CEPD -- the Cabinet's top economic planning agency -- is more than willing to offer counseling services for the East Caribbean ally's financial reform and economic development projects.

DOC.TEXT: The Nation:Khin Nyunt oustered. A power play within Burma's military government has ended in the sudden axing of Prime Minister Khin Nyunt- also the regime' s top intelligece chief - after a week of friction among the top brass over the political direction of the troubled country, intelligence sources said yesterday. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AMBASSADOR TO COSTA RICA RESPONDS OVER DONATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to Costa Rica Wu Tzu-dan has issued a note to Costa Rica explaining the situation surrounding the donation of US$400,000 to a foundation in the Central American country, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks amid Costa Rican media reports that former Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez received US$200,000 from the MOFA in 2001 and another US$200,000 from the ROC embassy in Costa Rica in 2002. The reports also said that a Panamanian company controlled by Rodriguez allegedly accepted two separate donations amounting to US$500,000 each and that Taiwan had provided a total of US$1.4 million in political donations to Rodriguez over three years.
The Costa Rican government last week made a request to the MOFA that Taiwan provide a written statement about all cash aid offered to Costa Rica during the former president's time in office.

Lu said that Wu presented a note to the Costa Rican vice foreign minister Tuesday asking him to turn the note over to the foreign minister. The note explained that Taiwan provided money to a foundation in Costa Rica under a cooperation project, according to Costa Rica's request, for a talent training program and the convening of an international conference.

The note also said that Taiwan had not sent two separate donations of US$500,000 each to the Panamanian firm as news reports had said, and that the MOFA has no idea why there were such reports, according to Lu.
The Costa Rican government is expected to respond by issuing a statement later after receiving the note from the ROC embassy in Costa Rica, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE GANGSTER NABBED FOR CROSS-BORDER PORNO BROADCASTS

TEXT.P: A Japanese yakuza gangster was arrested Tuesday in Taipei on charges of beaming pirated pornographic movies around Asia, using Taiwan as his operating base, according to the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB).

Shuichi Mogi, a member of the Japanese yakuza gang Yamaguchi-Gumi, who is the president of two Taiwan companies, has been operating pornographic movie broadcasts by first transporting porno DVDs from Japan to Taiwan and then beaming them from Taiwan via the satellite channel Jwave to places around Asia, CIB officials said Wednesday.

Mogi's Jwave porno broadcasts -- operated through his Taiwan companies Yixinhui and Oriental Digital -- have reached "clients" in Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Guam and many Southeast Asian countries, CIB investigators said.

In raids on Yixinhui and Oriental Digital Tuesday, the police busted Mogi and his Taiwanese vice president, Huang Wei-chin, and confiscated a large number of porno DVDs, as well as a satellite antennae, receivers, IC cards, account books, and website materials.
The investigators are also trying to track down Mogi's Taiwanese partner, surnamed Yen, and other accomplices who remain at large.

The police have learned that the Yamaguchi-Gumi gang has been broadcasting porno via satellite for quite a long time. In Taiwan, "clients" spend NT$20,000 for equipment, including an antenna, a receiver and cable, to get access to the 24-hour porno broadcasts, with extra fees for a decoding IC card and monthly payments of NT$2,000.
The Yamaguchi-Gumi beam the porno movies to clients throughout Asia by up-linking to the Palapa C2 channel in Indonesia and another channel in the Philippines, the police said.
This new kind of cross-border pornography operation has become a "grey area" for law enforcement authorities to deal with, CIB investigators said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: No Flu Vaccine Shortage At Capitol; Hill's Doctor Urges Members to Get Shots.
While many Americans search in vain for flu shots, members and employees of Congress are able to obtain them quickly and at no charge from the Capitol's attending physician, who has urged all 535 lawmakers to get the vaccines even if they are young and healthy, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Interest groups mounting costly push to get out vote
As the outcome of the U.S. presidential race is expected to hang on turnout at the polls, an army of interest groups is pumping at least $350 million into gett-out-the-vote campaigns. The efforts are part of the most expensive voter-drive ground war in history. It includes the major parties and their allies, the independent but partisan groups known as 527's, whose attack advertisements have played a big role in both President Bush's and Senator John Kerry's campaigns. For the first time in a national campaign, it includes hundreds of civic organizations and deep-pocketed business interests.
Wall Street Journal: Bush and Kerry deadlock among likely voters
Both John Kerry and George W. Bush have taken important steps toward winning the U.S. presidency during the past month, but neither has broken ahead in a race that remains deadlocked with two weeks to go. A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll, which has the two men tied at 48% apiece among likely voters, indicates Mr. Kerry's solid debate performances have helped him inch toward key objectives: building voter confidence in his ability to be commander in chief; narrowing the gap with President Bush on handling terrorism; and riding a powerful edge on the twin domestic concerns of jobs and health care. In the 12 swing states where electoral votes will likely prove decisive, he leads Mr. Bush by six percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: JCI TAIWAN SELECTS 10 OUTSTANDING YOUNG PERSONS FOR 2004

TEXT.P: The ten most outstanding young persons in Taiwan for 2004 have been selected, and their names were announced Wednesday by Junior Chamber International, Taiwan.
The 10 outstanding young men and women are scheduled to be honored with Taiwan Outstanding Young Person (TOYP) awards at a presentation ceremony in Hsinchu on Nov. 9, the JCI Taiwan reported.
Prior to that, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with them some time in October.

The Taiwan Junior Chamber has also decided that it will recommend that Chen Shi-hsin, taekwando gold medalist at the Athens Olympics and the recipient of a TOYP award in 2001, be nominated for the JCI Outstanding Young Person of the World award for 2005, said Francis Lee, Taiwan Junior Chamber national president of 2004.
The 2004 TOYP award winners are scheduled to travel to mainland China in December to meet with their mainland counterparts for a series of exchange activities, Lee added.

The 10 Taiwan outstanding young persons for 2004 are: professors Chou Hsi-tseng and Kuo Ta-wei in the science-and-technology category; Fang Chi-tai, a physician at National Taiwan University Hospital, in the social services category; Liao Yan-hsian, a high school teacher from Yuanlin, in the labor category; Pan Sheng-tsai, for outstanding diplomatic performance; Chan Ming-tsai, for outstanding contributions to agriculture; Chen Rui-ping, for commendable performances in art and culture; Drs. Wang Peng-hui and Kuo Po-chao, for outstanding performances in medical research; and Liao Hsiao-yun, an attorney, in the public administration category.

Offering his congratulations to the 10 winners, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who was one of the panel judges in the selection of this year's outstanding young persons, said all the recipients were selected after strict screening and careful examination to make sure that they are appropriate role models for Taiwan society.

To ensure that all the TOYP award winners, aged between 18 and 40, are individuals who exemplify the best attributes of the country's young people, the panel of judges decided to heighten their selection standards this year, resulting in an absence of winners in two categories -- namely the education and athletics category and the business and enterprise development category, Wang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KOREAN PRESIDENT REFUSES BEIJING'S ADVICE NOT TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Former South Korean President Kim Young Sam has decidedly refused to take mainland China's advice of not making a trip to Taiwan, saying that he would do anything that would benefit South Korea and its people.
A secretary of the former president announced Tuesday that at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian, Kim and his wife will visit Taiwan Oct. 25-Nov.1.

A daily newspaper in Seoul reported the same day that the mainland Chinese embassy in the South Korean capital had strongly suggested that Kim cancel his planned visit to the island, noting that it is not the right time for the former president to visit Taiwan and the visit might harm the spirit of the 1.3 billion people of mainland China and pass on a wrong message to Taiwan.
Responding to Beijing's suggestion, Kim said that he would do anything that would benefit South Korea and its people and that he is ready to go anywhere at any time.

In a statement released to the local media, Kim said that he had promised President Chen during his visit to Taipei in 2001 that he would visit the island again when the two countries resumed their two-way aviation links. Taipei and Seoul recently re-established direct air links after a twelve-year suspension of the links.

It is expected that during Kim's forthcoming visit to Taiwan, he will hold talks with President Chen and exchange views on issues of mutual concern with other political figures, including Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, and representatives from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Kim is also expected to meet with Taiwan business and industrial leaders and deliver a speech at National Chengchi University during the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAN STILL ACHIEVE 6% ECONOMIC GROWTH THIS YEAR: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chan Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan can still achieve a 6 percent economic growth for this year despite soaring crude oil prices and global terrorist activities.

The president made the remarks when he presided over a meeting of his economic advisory group, during which the economic experts discussed issues related to oil prices, national health insurance, financial reforms and the land value increment tax.
Chen said that according to the International Monetary Fund's latest forecast, global economic growth could reach 5 percent for this year, or the highest figure in more than two decades.

Buoyed by the world economic recovery and the efforts of the Taiwan people, Taiwan's economy has performed well this year, the president said, adding that Taiwan's imports and exports have maintained a growth at over 20 percent and that private investment and consumption have also steadily increased.

He noted that surging oil prices and terrorist activities in the world will affect the continued growth of the world economy, but "as long as we put in more effort, it is still possible for us to achieve growth of 6 percent for this year."
The economic advisory group to the president also endorsed the goals of the nation's second-stage financial reforms proposed by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
According to CEPD proposed goals, by the end of 2005, there should be at least one "representative" company in each financial field, such as asset management, banking, insurance and securities.

Moreover, the number of financial institutions in which the government have stakes will be cut by half to six institutions. By the end of 2006, financial holding companies will be cut by half from the present 14 companies, and at least one financial institution will be run by foreign-owned companies or be listed in other countries.
The president instructed related government agencies to implement the conclusions so as to upgrade the efficiency and liberalization of Taiwan's financial market.
Chen also said that the measure of halving of the land value increment tax, which was put into effect in February 2002, has had good results as seen by brisk real estate transactions.

He expressed the hope that the Executive Yuan will actively promote the revised land tax law proposed by the Ministry of Finance so as to further cut the land value increment tax. He added that if the revised law can't clear the legislature by the end of this year, the Executive Yuan should still extend the measure of halving the land value increment tax for another year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT APPOINTS NEW SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) Central Standing Committee approved Wednesday the appointment of Chang Jung-kung as chairman of the party's Culture and Communications Committee, a position which includes the role of KMT spokesman.
Chang had headed the Mainland Affairs Division under the party's Policy Committee before he was named to the new position, replacing Alex Tsai.
Tsai will be transferred to the post of deputy executive director of the Policy Committee.

It was reported by local media that Tsai's replacement was related to his recent argument with Chiang Fang Chih-yi, a daughter-in-law of late President Chiang Ching-kuo and member of the KMT's Central Standing Committee. Reportedly unsatisfied with Tsai's performance in campaigning for the party's candidates in the year-end legislative elections, Chiang Fang openly criticized him at last week's Central Standing Committee meeting.
Regarding the media reports, Chiang Fang said Wednesday that her remarks last week were meant to improve the party's campaigning efforts and were "nothing personal."

Also on Wednesday, the Central Standing Committee confirmed the expulsion of four politicians from the party who had campaigned for ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidates Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu during run-up to the March 20 presidential election.

The KMT members expelled were Huang Chao-cheng, chief of Kaohsiung County's Linyuan township; Pan Chien-fang, chief of the county's Yenchao township; Chen Sheng, an official at the KMT's branch office in Kaohsiung County's Maolin township; and Hung Tien-sheng, head of an aboriginal group.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY GETS NEW NAME

TEXT.P: Taiwan's second north-south expressway will from now on be formally called the Formosa Expressway, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday.

The second north-south expressway was originally designated as "National Highway No.3." As many drivers had complained that the designation was confusing, the Cabinet decided to find a new name for the expressway.
Chen said three final entries selected through a public contest -- Formosa, Yushan and Hope -- were put up for discussion at a weekly Cabinet meeting held earlier in the day.
"The Cabinet members unanimously selected 'Formosa' as the expressway's new name," Chen said.

"Formosa is Taiwan's original name known to the whole world. It is easy to remember and symbolizes beauty, good fortune and safety. Therefore, it has won the support of all the Cabinet members, " he explained.
Taiwan's first north-south expressway is named after Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the Republic of China's founding father.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October lost 62 points to close at 5,775, with 15,274 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 51 points to finish at 5,785, with 27,691 contracts traded, while December futures lost 29 points to finish at 5,796, with 80 contracts traded.
March futures dropped 49 points to finish at 5,750, with one contract traded, while June futures moved down 70 points to close at 5,688, also with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,837 for October, 5,836 for November, 5,825 for December, 5,799 for March and 5,758 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
October TE futures moved down 4.4 points to close at 210.2, with 3,410 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 2.65 points to finish at 211.65, with 5,666 contract transactions.
December TE futures lost 2.1 points to close at 212.65, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures gained 4.8 points to close at 1,008, with 3,627 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 7.2 points to end at 1,006.6, with 7,988 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved up 8.8 points to close at 1,003.6, with 25 contract transactions, while March TF futures gained 19.4 points to finish at 986.4, with 16 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Elections Chief Criticizes Putin Plan.
Central Elections Commission chairman Alexander Veshnyakov touted his raft of amendments to end individual parliamentary races Tuesday but criticized a bill backed by President Vladimir Putin to scrap the popular vote for governors and a proposal requiring political parties to increase their membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIC PACIFIC UNION TO BE ESTABLISHED NEXT AUGUST: VP

TEXT.P: The Democratic Pacific Union will be officially established on Aug. 14, 2005, during the next Democratic Pacific Assembly, Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday.
Lu said the union will be a permanent organization aimed at "radiating" Taiwan's democracy, peace and prosperity out to the rest of the world.
The vice president said she has been named to chair the organizing committee for the organization and will soon start recruiting talent to join the committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TO SUE PFP LAWMAKER FOR SLANDER

TEXT.P: The top presidential aide refuted an allegation made by opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung against President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday and said that the Presidential Office will sue Liu.

Su Tseng-chang, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that President Chen was "furious" when heard about the allegation made by Liu at a press conference earlier the same day that Chen had given former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso US$1 million as a "birthday gift."

Su categorically denied Liu's allegation, saying that the "red envelop" claim was totally fabricated and that the allegation has undermined the president's standing and damaged the friendship between Taiwan and Panama.
The president's chief of staff urged the few "unworthy politicians" not to sling mud at President Chen simply for political gain for their own parties or for personal pleasure.

Liu, at the press conference, quoted recent reports from Costa Rica that President Chen had given Moscoso US$1 million and that the latter had shown the check she received from Chen at many international occasions.

Liu said that President Chen's true aim in visiting Central and South America recently was to visit the United States, providing "others" in the world the opportunity to "blackmail" Taiwan after discerning Chen's true ambitions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 19.45 points to close at 5,788.34.

The bourse opened at 5,790.24 and fluctuated between 5,808.91 and 5,760.41 during the day's trading. A total of 2.54 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$53.88 billion (US$1.59 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground with construction issues moving up the most at 3.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent, textile stocks at 0.9 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.1 percent.

Three other major stock categories lost ground with plastics and chemicals shares moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.8 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 350 to 282, with 161 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUPS CALL FOR RETURN OF TAIWAN FROM HANDS OF ARMS DEALERS

TEXT.P: Civic groups against the government's proposed special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) for an arms procurement package from the United States issued a proclamation prior to the Taiwan's Retrocession Day, urging a "recovery of Taiwan from the hands of arms dealers."
The two civic groups -- the Alliance Against the NT$610.8 billion Arms Procurement and the Democracy Action Alliance -- issued its "New Retrocession Day Proclamation" in the Legislative Yuan.
They urged the public to strongly express their views to the legislators of their constituencies and vote against candidates that advocate the arms procurement in the year-end legislative elections.

The groups noted that a referendum held earlier rejected a proposal for arms procurement. Increased arms procurement was one of the two questions on the referendum. Although more than 90 percent voted positively in the referendum, the proposal failed because those who participated did not surpass 50 percent.

Officials of the alliances noted that the arms procurement is like a "drug addiction, " which could ruin the nation, and the aspirations for peace and independence of the Taiwan people shouldn't be trampled on.

The officials also said that they plan to hold a large Retrocession Day rally in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, this Sunday. Retrocession Day, which falls on Oct. 25, marks the return of Taiwan from the hands of Japanese colonial rule to the fold of the Republic of China.

They said that if the public allows the arms deal to go through, it will be tantamount to paying protection money to the United States to maintain Taiwan's security, and would be a form of capitulation. Moreover, the arms procurements in the future will get bigger and bigger, resulting in the collapse of Taiwan's economy.

They strongly urged the public to adamantly "say no to the arms procurement package, " and that they bring their concerns to the attention of the media and their friends in the United States, as well as legislators in their constituencies.

Independent Legislator Su Yin-kuei also said that the national defense budget for next year passed without any cut in the legislative committee. If NT$610.8 billion is reasonable, the budget should be put to the annual review.
Su also said that the nation's debt will hit NT$12 trillion and questioning how the government is going to finance the arms purchase.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.042 to close at NT$33.814.
A total of US$554 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.810 and fluctuated between NT$33.804 and NT$33.838.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY OPENS 'SINGLE DESK' TO SERVICE FOREIGN, M'LAND SPOUSES

TEXT.P: Taipei City Government has opened "single desk" services exclusively for foreign and mainland Chinese spouses wishing to find jobs in Taiwan's largest city.

Based on the employment service law, the city government began to implement the "single desk" services last year to help foreign and mainland Chinese nationals who are married to Taipei citizens and wish to find employment.
According to the employment service law, foreign nationals who are married to ROC citizens and have obtained permanent residence can work in Taiwan without filing for permission in advance.

Officials from the Taipei City Employment Service Center said that a total of 519 foreign and mainland Chinese spouses have applied with the center for job opportunities since the office became operational in March last year.
Of the total, 246 people have successfully landed jobs under the "matchmaking" efforts of the center, marking a 47 percent success rate.
This figure was relatively higher than the matching rate of 33 percent in terms of matching job opportunities between local people and job providing organizations, center officials said.

In addition, the officials said, the center has sponsored 15 career or vocational workshops for foreign and mainland Chinese spouses over the past 20 months, allowing 485 people to attend classes that are helpful to facilitating their joining in Taiwan's job market.
Interested parties can call the center at (02) 2594-2277 ext. 122 or ext. 712, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA TO HOLD BI-YEARLY FLIGHT SAFETY CONFERENCE IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration will hold its fourth biennial conference on flight safety improvement strategies in November, officials said Wednesday.
Jim Ballogh, head of the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration's Flight Standards Service, will present a report on "FAA Flight Plan 2004-2008," the officials said.
The conference has taken place every two years since 1999. International aviation safety will be the focus of this year's conference.
The issue of aviation safety has again raised concerns after the occurrence of two similar accidents in three months in which two domestic flights skidded off the runway at Taipei's Sungshan Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WILLING TO WORK WITH ELECTION-EVE SHOOTING INVESTIGATION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday that the Executive Yuan is willing to work with the Control Yuan's investigation on the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on March 19.
Yu made the remarks on the sideline of a ceremony to bestow medals on the winning athletes at the Athens Olympic Games.

The premier said that the Executive Yuan is unreservedly willing to work with the investigation, but the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog, has not found any violations of law or dereliction of duty on the part of anyone at the Executive Yuan.
Yu said that he is only a "witness" and that he accepts being "visited" by Control Yuan representatives over the matter, but not being "interviewed" by them.
If it is a "visit," then the venue could be at the Executive Yuan or at his residence, although the Control Yuan has not agreed to this.
The opposition believes that the March 19 shooting, which injured the president and the vice president slightly, swayed the bitterly contested election to the president's favor.

A March 19 shooting "truth investigation commission, " which was established under a special statute passed by the Legislative Yuan in August, formally began operations early this month, and has started to look into the shooting, but the Cabinet, believing that the special statute is unconstitutional, has refused to cooperate with the commission prior to a ruling on its constitutionality by the Council of Grand Justices. The request for an interpretation was made by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally Taiwan Solitary Union (TSU).

The "truth commission" originally was to have had 17 members, but because the commission is being boycotted by the DPP and the TSU, there are only nine members from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, and one from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union.

President Chen, contesting the validity of the "truth commission, " refused to confirm the commission members, but the commission began operations automatically because it had the required 50 percent of its seats filled.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOURTH LEAST-CORRUPT COUNTRY IN ASIA: TI REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the fourth least-corrupt country in Asia, after Singapore, Japan and Hong Kong, according to an annual global corruption report released by Transparency International (TI) Wednesday.
Taiwan ranks 35th in the TI's 2004 Global Corruption Report on the transparency of political finances in 146 countries and areas around the world.
Taiwan received a score of 5.6 points on the TI-designed zero-to-10 transparency index, down 0.1 points from its year-earlier level.

Yu Chih-li, director of Shih Hsin University's administrative management department, who concurrently serves as chief executive of the TI's Taiwan branch, said Taiwan dropped five notches in the global ranking as compared with the 2003 rating.

Only two of the 13 countries or areas that were gauged this year for the first time outpace Taiwan. "Theoretically, Taiwan should have only dropped two slots. But it dropped five notches. This trend is worthy of the government's attention," Yu said.

Chai Sung-lin, a national policy adviser to the president, said political democratization and economic liberalization may not necessarily reduce corruption. For instance, mainland China received only 3.4 points in the TI transparency index, ranking 71st in the global rating.

Hsieh Li-kung, a Central Police University professor, said the government has cracked down on corruption for many years. "But our score and ranking have remained almost the same over the past few years, indicating that there is still ample room for improvement," he added.

Su You-chen, a lawyer, cautioned the government that the recent reports of alleged political contributions controversies in several Central American countries with diplomatic ties with Taiwan might affect Taiwan's transparency rating in the coming year.

All of the least-corrupt countries that received a score of more than 9 points in the TI's 2004 Global Corruption Report are advanced countries. They are Finland (9.7) , New Zealand (9.6) , Denmark and Iceland (9.5), Singapore (9.3), Sweden (9.2) and Switzerland (9.1).

Singapore is the only Asian country that received a score of more than 9 points. Japan ranks 21st, with a score of 6.9 points. South Korea ranks 47th, with a score of 4.5 points. The United States ranks 17th, with a score of 7.5 points.
The most corrupt countries include Azerbaijan, Paraguay, Chad, Myanmar, Nigeria, Bangladesh and Haiti.

The TI is a non-governmental international coalition created to fight corruption. Founded in 1993, the TI has set up branches in 120 countries or areas around the world. The Taiwan branch was founded in 2002.

The TI's Corruption Perceptions Index is based on the results of surveys of multinational business group managers and national affairs analysts on 18 indicators provided by 12 independent research institutes, including the World Economic Forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU HONORS OLYMPIC MEDALISTS WITH CASH AND MEDALLIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Wednesday bestowed cash and medals on Taiwanese athletes who won medals at the 2004 Athens Olympic Games.

Yu decorated nine athletes with the Order of National Glory, the highest honor for sporting achievement. Among them were taekwondo gold medalists Chen Shih-hsin and Chu Mu-yen, taekwondo silver medalist Huang Chih-hsiung, and six archers who won silver and bronze in the Olympic archery team event.
Taiwan athletes won two golds, two silvers and one bronze, the best results in 20 years.

According to the island's sporting regulations, a gold medalist can be awarded NT$12 million (US$355,029), with the option of taking it all at one time or receiving part each month, while silver and bronze medalists can receive NT$6 million and NT$4 million, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL RELIGIOUS MUSIC ACADEMIC SYMPOSIUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The International Religious Music Academic Symposium opened at Howard International House in Taipei Wednesday, National Center for Traditional Arts officials said.

The five-day event will bring together religious music experts from the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany, Uzbekistan, Iraq, Japan, the Philippines, mainland China and Hong Kong to discuss religious music issues.
Activities of the symposium, including religious music shows and workshops, will be held at National Taiwan University of Arts Oct. 21-24.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIPINA RECOVERS AFTER HEART SURGERY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A 15-year-old girl from the Philippines suffering from congenital heart disease has fully recovered and was discharged from the hospital Wednesday after successfully undergoing open heart surgery in Taiwan.

Ann Margaret Derder was sent to the National Taiwan University Hospital for the surgery earlier this month under the "Gift of Life" program sponsored by Rotary International. The surgery was performed on Oct. 6.
At a news conference held by the hospital on her recovery, the girl expressed her gratitude for the help offered to her by the "Gift of Life" program and medical staff at the hospital.

According to Chen Yi-hsiang, a cardiovascular surgeon at the hospital, the girl was suspected of having congenital heart disease since she was little after a murmur was discovered in her heart, but her family could not afford medical treatment.
She was diagnosed with tetralogy of fallot (TOF) -- a kind of heart problem -- when she was three years old, Chen said.
Chen said Taiwan has mature technology for the treatment of TOF and the success rate of heart surgery is very high.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANK SIGNS CONTRACTS WITH POLAND, HUNGARIAN COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: Export-import Bank of the Republic of China signed contracts on export credit insurance with export credit insurance institutions from Poland and Hungary in a recently concluded meeting of the Berne Union, an international union of credit and investment insurers, in Taipei.
The officials of Export-import Bank of the Republic of China said the bank will work closely with the two institutions regarding businesses in Eastern Europe.
The agenda of the meeting Oct. 11-15 included the Bassel II and cooperation with the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, and experts from S&P and Citibank gave speeches.
The meeting also introduced three new members from the United States, South Africa and Slovakia to increase its membership to 55.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRD-PARTY CROSS-STRAIT MESSENGER ACCEPTABLE IDEA: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that she welcomes a third party to convey messages between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The vice president made the remarks on the sidelines of a meeting of a human rights advisory committee to the Presidential Office she heads when she was asked about her views on the upcoming visit to mainland China by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell, with the U.S. arms sale to Taiwan expected to be on the agenda.
Lu said that if there was a good friend such as Powell to serve as the mediator across the Taiwan Strait, "it would be a good thing."
She also said, "No one wants war, and if there is any situation in the Taiwan Strait, we welcome a third party to convey correct messages across the Strait."
Lu lamented that the peace overture put forward by President Chen Shui-bian in his Double Ten National Day address was sternly rejected by mainland China.

Lu said that at present, one major issue will be for Taiwan to nurture negotiators who can engage in cross-strait talks, saying that everyone should work toward creating an environment conducive to the resumption of cross-strait talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ST. VINCENT AND GRENADINES PRIME MINISTER HOSTS INVESTMENT CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: St. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves hosted an investment conference Wednesday in Taipei to attract Taiwanese investors.
Gonsalves said St. Vincent and the Grenadines is located in the East Caribbean region and has very beautiful scenery and a thriving tourism industry.
It has healthy tourism industry, hotel businesses and an offshore financial center, Gonsalves said.

Other investment options include fledging light industries as well as various infrastructure projects like airports and highways, which are in strong demand as the government is aggressively developing the country's economy, Gonsalves said.
Gonsalves encouraged Taiwanese enterprises to invest in his country to assist with its economic development.
According to statistics of the Board of Foreign Trade, Taiwan's exports to St. Vincent and the Grenadines amounted to US$249,563 in 2003, but there were no imports from the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS ASIAN VEGETABLE CENTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center (AVRDC) in Tainan on Wednesday.
Chen looked at different laboratories in the center and a farm where more than 200 indigenous plants are grown.
The AVRDC is the only international organization headquartered in Taiwan. It has regional centers in Thailand and Tanzania and maintains five cooperation networks in Asia, Africa and Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLEGATION THAT PRESIDENT GAVE PANAMANIAN LEADER CASH ABSURD: MOFA

TEXT.P: A spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Wednesday refuted as ludicrous an opposition People First Party legislator's allegation that President Chen Shui-bian gave former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso a US$1 million gift.

Michel Lu made the remarks in response to the claim made by PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung earlier the day that Chen gave the outgoing Mireya Moscoso a check worth US$1 million as a "birthday gift" when he visited Panama in early September for the inauguration of the new Panamanian President Martin Torrijos.

At a news conference held on Wednesday afternoon, Lu stressed that the gifts that the government presents to the leaders of other countries are generally symbolic articles, such as traditional artifacts or high-tech products produced domestically, and it is absolutely impossible that money was given.
Noting that although Taiwan and Panama have maintained cordial ties and the leaders of the two have made frequent visits, Lu said that Chen does his job of maintaining international courtesy.
It is impossible that Chen violated any international courtesy protocol; otherwise, Taiwan would have become an "international joke," Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTS CONSISTENCY IN U.S. ARMS DEALINGS: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes the United States can maintain "consistency and continuity" in its arms sales policy toward Taiwan, Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien said Wednesday..

Tsai was commenting on U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher's statement that U.S. Secretary of State Powell desires to have a chance to speak on U.S. arms sales to Taiwan during his one-day visit to Beijing on Oct. 25.
Tsai said the U.S. stance on arms sales to Taiwan is crystal clear, namely to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons in line with the Taiwan Relations Act to safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait.
"We expect the U.S. government to maintain consistency and continuity in its policy on arms sales to Taiwan," Tsai said.

He also said the Ministry of National Defense hopes the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan can approve the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement budget as early as possible so that the United States can begin selecting contractors and deciding on the type of diesel-powered submarines to be sold to Taiwan.
The NT$610.8 billion arms package includes eight diesel-powered submarines, six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.
Meanwhile, Vice President Annette Lu said she is not opposed to a third party correctly conveying information or messages between the two sides of the Taiwan strait.
Lu was responding to Boucher's remarks that Powell will take advantage of his Beijing visit to encourage mainland China to resume dialogue with Taiwan.

"Nobody wants war. We welcome respectable foreign friends, such as Powell, to serve as cross-strait mediators," Lu said, adding that she looks forward to seeing people on both sides and foreign friends work together to kick-start the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.
Lu further said Taiwan needs to cultivate a new generation of competent negotiators in preparation for future cros-strait talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RICE TO BE EXPORTED TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: A batch of 18 tons of rice produced in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan will be exported through Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan to Japan after a hiatus of 33 years, an agriculture official said in Taipei Wednesday.
The anonymous official from the Council of Agriculture said it took his council and other related agencies much effort to put Taiwan rice through Japan's testing and get permission to export.
If the Japanese market responds well to Taiwan rice, two more batches of rice will be sold in Japan before the end of this year, the official said.
As a rice producer, Japan keeps its domestic market under close control and does not import foreign rice unless it is that of the highest quality, the official went on.
Taiwan used to be a rice supplier to Japan, but the rice trade stopped since 1971.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LUXURY TRAIN TO BEGIN MAIDEN JOURNEY ON OCT. 25

TEXT.P: Want some champagne, red wine or Starbucks coffee? No, its not the beverage call in the first class of a 747, it's but a part of the service that will be available on a new luxury train that the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) will unveil on Oct. 25.

TRA officials said Wednesday that Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara will be among the honored dignitaries on Oct. 25 to witness the launch of the luxury train, in addition to Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san.

Noting that the train is designed to attract well-heeled domestic and foreign passengers to travel in Taiwan, the officials said that Ishihara can introduce Taiwan's beautiful scenery to the Japanese public.
The Japanese politician has told Taiwan government officials that he hoped to have the chance to see Taiwan's scenery by train.

With the body of the train painted with Taiwan's flowers, aboriginal young people, and scenes from Sun Moon Lake, the luxury train boasts of a karaoke-equipped living room and a dining car that offers free beverages and Taiwanese traditional foods.
The trip around Taiwan will include stops at high-class hotels, such as the Lalu Sun Moon Lake Hotel, which was once a favorite summer house for late President Chiang Kai-shek.
The four-day trip around Taiwan by the new train will cost NT$25,000 (US$737) per person.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG URGED TO SET UP REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong government should set up a representative office in Taiwan to boost bilateral relations and offer better services to its expatriates on the island, a senior official said Wednesday.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san made the call after a recent tourist bus accident in the Chiufen mountainous resort in northern Taiwan that killed five Hong Kong citizens.

"When the accident occurred Monday, we need the assistance of Hong Kong authorities in contacting the victims' families," Chiu said, adding that the accident highlights the necessity for the Hong Kong government to open a liaison or representative office in Taiwan.
In view of ever-growing tourist exchanges between the two sides, Chiu said, the Hong Kong government should seriously consider the proposal of setting up a representative office in Taipei.

According to MAC tallies, Hong Kong citizens made about 240,000 visits to Taiwan in 2003 and the number of of Hong Kong visitors to Taiwan in the first nine months of this year already exceeded 230,000.

"The figure indicates the upward swing in civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong," Chiu said. "For the sake of boosting bilateral contacts and exchanges and offering timely and better services for Hong Kong expatriates and tourists, we look forward to the opening of a Hong Kong representative office in Taipei."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND BELGIUM SIGN AGREEMENT TO AVOID DOUBLE TAXATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Belgium signed an agreement Oct. 13 to avoid double taxation in a move to further promote bilateral trade and investment, Bureau of Foreign Trade officials said Wednesday.

The officials noted that the agreement will encourage Belgian enterprises to invest more in Taiwan, introduce high technology and administration techniques to the island, as well as help Taiwan upgrade its industrial structure.

Noting that Taiwan and Belgian enterprises are generally small- and medium-sized, and that the bilateral investments have focused on the establishment of branches and operations points in each others' country, the officials stressed that there is still much space for the development of bilateral investments between the two.

The officials suggested that domestic entrepreneurs consider establishing their European distribution centers in Belgium, considering its geographical advantage of being located in the center of Western Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION OF TAIWAN'S SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY TO TOP NT$1 TRILLION

TEXT.P: Production of Taiwan's semiconductor industry is expected to top NT$1 trillion (US$29.58 billion) this year, an analyst with the Industrial Technology Intelligence Services under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Wednesday.

At a seminar on Taiwan's scientific standing and the challenges of the market, Chien Chih-sheng noted that the island's semiconductor industry looks promising considering that there are many trade opportunities hidden in 3C products -- computer, communications and consumer electronics.

As the semiconductor's sub-industries, such as IC design and original equipment manufacturing for wafers, have also performed excellently, Chien estimated that the island's semiconductor industry is full of potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERS OF TRADE UNIONS CONTINUE HUNGER STRIKE AT LEGISLATIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: A hunger strike by about a dozen leaders of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) went into its second day after lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) refused to endorse their requests Wednesday.

Legislator Ker Chien-ming, the whip of DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan said that his party would like to discuss the issues concerning workers with union leaders in a sensible way, but the party will not bow to pressure.

The three other major political parties have already pledged to support the trade union leaders' requests. TCTU Vice President Chung Kung-chao said his confederation might stage another protest if the DPP still refuses their demands before the hunger strike ends Friday.

The TCTU, which called in more than 2,000 members to stage a demonstration in front of the Legislative Yuan Tuesday, appealed to lawmakers from different political parties to stop the government from selling state enterprises before consulting the confederation and getting its approval.
They also urged the lawmakers to support their request that the government sign group contracts with workers of state-owned enterprises before selling these companies.
They also urged the government to refrain from meddling in the operation of the state-run enterprises.
