DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL URGES HONG KONG TO SET UP OFFICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A government official suggested Wednesday that the Hong Kong government set up offices in Taiwan to promote bilateral ties.

Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said that the special administrative region's government should seriously consider the matter to provide better services to the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that more than 230,000 Hong Kong visitors arrived in Taiwan in the first nine months of this year for sightseeing and business purposes, Chiu said that the number is nearly equal to that of last year and shows that the exchange between the two sides is increasing rapidly.

DOC.HEADLINE: WITHOUT ARMS PURCHASE, DEFENSE MINISTRY PREDICTS WAR ACROSS STRAIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense warned Wednesday that a war across the Taiwan Strait is likely to happen between 2010 and 2020 if Taiwan misses the chance to accept the offer from the United States of US$18.23 billion in arms.

In a last-ditch effort to win the legislature's support for its request for a special budget to finance the purchase, the defense ministry said in a position paper that the acquisition of the arms, including submarines, anti-submarine aircraft and missiles, will ensure at least 30 years of peace across the Strait.
The paper also listed the destroyer equipped with the Aegis system as being what the ministry would seek in the next 15 years.

The budget has been bogged down in the opposition-controlled legislature, not only because of its huge price tag but also because the special budget will worsen the already strained government's finance, according to opponents of the purchase.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF STATE-CONTROLLED BANKS TO BE HALVED: ECONOMICS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The number of state-controlled banks will be cut from 12 to six by the end of next year under the government's plan to reform the domestic banking system, Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said Wednesday.

In a briefing on the government's financial reform plan to President Chen Shui-bian, a written copy of which was released to the media later, Hu said the financial reform will be done in two parts. The first is to privatize the state-owned banks and sell the government's stocks in formerly state-owned banks that have already been privatized.
The second part, Hu said, is to merge these state-controlled banks to halve the number of state-controlled banks by the end of next year.
The current 14 financial holding companies will also be merged into seven by the end of 2005.
The number of commercial banks, which are choking the market, will be cut first, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 21, or the eighth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, and his expedition team are blown by storms into a strait that separates South America from Tierra del Fuego and other islands south of the continent and that also connects the southern Atlantic and Pacific oceans. The strait now bears his name.
1727: The Ching court and Russia sign a new border treaty at the trading town of Kiakhta in Outer Mongolia.
1833: Alfred Nobel, Swedish industrialist and chemist who invented dynamite, is born. He founded the Nobel Prize to award to the world's leading scientists, artists and peacemakers.
1879: Thomas Alva Edison, U.S. inventor, successfully tests an electric incandescent lamp with a carbonized filament at his New Jersey laboratory.
1934: Government troops capture Juichin, the Chinese communist's capital in Kiangsi. The main force of rebels is wiped out and the remaining ones flee to the northwest.
1938: Japanese troops finally capture the Chinese city of Canton after months of bombing.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, and Madame Chiang arrive in Taiwan for the first time for an inspection tour.
1950: Communist Chinese forces begin their occupation of Tibet.
1952: The first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference opens in Taipei.
1953: The first Overseas Chinese Day is celebrated in Taipei.
1954: The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France agree to end the Allied occupation of Germany.
1958: John Foster Dulles, U.S. secretary of state, arrives in Taipei for a visit. He pursued a policy of opposing the USSR largely through economic and military aid to U.S. allies.
1960: Queen Elizabeth II launches the HMS Dreadnought, Britain's first nuclear submarine.
1960: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Mali.
1964: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC decathlon champion who won the ROC's first Olympic silver medal in 1960, announces his retirement after winning fifth place at the Tokyo Olympics.
1973: The fifth general meeting of the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations opens in Taipei with more than 400 delegates from 50 countries and areas participating.
1975: The second naphtha cracking plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corporation begins production.
1976: Ding Mou-shih, director general of the Government Information Office, returns from a week's visit to the Republic of Korea.
1979: Israeli Prime Minister Moshe Dayan resigns over the government's refusal to negotiate with Palestinians.
1979: Willy Brandt is elected chancellor of West Germany.
1987: Ho Ying-chin, a Chinese general who received the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from Gen. Okamura in Nanking on Sept. 9, 1945, dies at the age of 97.
1994: The United States and North Korea sign a landmark deal under which Pyongyang is to freeze and then dismantle its nuclear program.
1999: Far East Transport Corp. begins flight services between Taipei and Kota Kinabala in Malaysia.
2000: Chinese Taipei's Chiang Chih-chung breaks the world record in men's Class 12 javelin with a throw of 57.228 meters to capture Taiwan's first gold medal at the Sydney Paralympics.
2001: Asia-Pacific leaders pledge to prevent "all forms of terrorist acts" and to strengthen cooperation to catch those who carry out such crimes in a joint statement after ending a two-day informal leadership summit in Shanghai.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In another place in the Book of Song it is said, `His virtue is light as hair.' Still a hair is something material. `The workings of Almighty God have neither sound nor smell.' There is nothing higher than that."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-KOREA POLITICAL EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said recently that the time has come to upgrade bilateral Taiwan-South Korea exchanges to the political level now that the people of the two countries have established close ties in the economic, trade and cultural fields, South Korea's Yonhap News Agency reported Thursday.
President Chen made the remarks in a speech to the Seventh Pacific-Rim Academic Conference on Korean Studies opened at Chinese Culture University on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei Oct. 19.
Chen said in the speech that South Korea has greatly impressed the people of Taiwan with its success in economic and high-technology development in recent years.

Korean pop culture, particularly Korean soap operas, have become extremely popular in Taiwan over the last two years, allowing the Taiwan public to learn about Korea's history, culture, customs, and even its art and foods, Chen was quoted by Yonhap News as saying.

Chen said that South Korea is one of the closest countries to Taiwan geographically, and that the two countries have maintained close economic and trade ties, with two-way trade reaching US$13 billion last year. South Korea enjoyed a trade surplus of US$4 billion for the year.

South Korea is Taiwan's fifth largest trade partner, Chen said, adding that such close and cordial bilateral ties should also be reflected in political exchanges between the two countries, according to the Yonhap report.
Chen said that Taiwan and South Korea have both persevered in the pursuit of democratization despite external and internal pressures.

Taiwan and South Korea are both role model nations among Asia-Pacific countries, and their respective development experiences are a common asset on which the two countries should continue to build their friendship, Chen said.
Over the past 10 years, Chen continued, interactions between Taiwan and Korea have been restricted due to the lack of formal diplomatic relations.

Chen said he hopes that the academic conference -- with so many influential politicians and academics from South Korea participating -- as well as the resumption of direct air links between Taiwan and South Korea will lead to the opening of a new page in bilateral relations between the two countries.

Nearly 200 scholars and politicians from more than 10 countries, including the United States, Canada, mainland China, Japan and India, took part in the two-day Korean studies. Former South Korean prime minister Hyun Seung Zong was one of the participants in the conference, the Yonhap report said.
In related news, former South Korean President Kim Young Sam has decided to visit Taiwan Oct. 25-Nov. 1 at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.
Defying Beijing's advice not to make a trip to Taiwan, Kim said recently that he would do anything that would benefit South Korea and its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT FILES CIVIL SUIT TO RESTORE REPUTATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian filed a civil suit against a political talk show host and two opposition lawmakers Thursday over "improper dealing" allegations.

Chen's lawyer Ku Li-hsiung filed the lawsuit against People First Party Legislators Liu Wen-hsiung and Tsai Chung-han as well as television and radio talk show host Jaw Shau-kong, a former lawmaker, with the Taipei District Court on behalf of President Chen.

The three have in recent days made allegations, based on unverified reports, that President Chen had presented a US$1 million check to former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso as a birthday gift and as a"compensation for Chen's improper dealings."
Ku said Chen is seeking to "restore his reputation" through a civil suit instead of a criminal suit mainly because he does not want to give the impression of intimidating a media personalty.
According to Ku, Chen filed the lawsuit in line with Article 18 and Article 195 of the Civil Code as well as the Council of Grand Justices' Constitutional Interpretation No. 453.

Ku said Chen is not seeking any financial compensation because the "president's reputation is priceless." Instead, Ku said, Chen has demanded that the three defendants publish the court verdict and an apology to him on the front pages of five local newspapers -- the China Times, the United Daily News, the Liberty Times, the Taiwan Daily and the Apple Daily -- for three days.
Su Tseng-chang, Chen's chief of staff, said the president filed the lawsuit mainly to protect Taiwan's diplomatic ties with Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT FILES LAWSUIT AGAINST UNFOUNDED ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian filed a civil suit against a political talk show host and two opposition lawmakers Thursday over unfounded political contribution and improper dealing allegations.

Chen's lawyer Ku Li-hsiung filed the lawsuit against People First Party Legislators Liu Wen-hsiung and Tsai Chung-han as well as television and radio talk show host Jaw Shau-kong, a former lawmaker, with the Taipei District Court on behalf of the president Chen.

The three have in recent days made allegations, based on unverified reports, that President Chen had presented a US$1 million check to former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso as a "birthday gift" and as a "compensation for Chen's improper dealings."
Ku said Chen is seeking to "restore his reputation" through a civil suit instead of a criminal suit mainly because he does not want to give the impression of intimidating a media personalty.
According to Ku, Chen filed the lawsuit in line with Article 18 and Article 195 of the Civil Code as well as the Council of Grand Justices' Constitutional Interpretation No. 453.

Ku said Chen is not seeking any financial compensation because the "president's reputation is priceless." Instead, Ku said, Chen has demanded that the three defendants publish the court verdict and an apology to him on the front pages of five local newspapers -- the China Times, the United Daily News, the Liberty Times, the Taiwan Daily and the Apple Daily -- for three days.
Su Tseng-chang, Chen's chief of staff, said the president filed the lawsuit mainly to protect Taiwan's diplomatic ties with Panama.

"The trio's allegations were unfounded and outrageous," Su said, adding that the Republic of China government has never offered political contributions to any individual foreign politician and that President Chen has never had any improper dealing as alleged by the two opposition lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIVE-FIRE DRILL CONDUCTED ON PENGHU ISLAND

TEXT.P: The Penghu Defense Command conducted a live-fire drill involving artillery Thursday on the island group located in the Taiwan Strait to test and hone the military's defense capabilities.

Penghu Defense Commander Wang Han-chi presided over the drill, which kicked off on a highland on the islet of Hsiyu at 5: 50 a.m. The Penghu island group is located about 40 kilometers off the southwest coast of Taiwan proper.

More than 200 officers and soldiers took part in the drill, firing hundreds of rounds with 105-millimeter and 155-millimeter self-propelled howitzers, 20-millimeter canons, and other artillery equipment.

The drill, dubbed "Lianhsin No. 247, " was staged to practice countering a simultaneous landing invasion, air attack and naval blockade by the enemy, according to officials from the Penghu Defense Command.

Wang said that the drill, one of the two annual operations to test artillery pieces and coordination among the armed forces in a combat zone, has nothing to do with the current state of cross-strait relations.

Wang said that the drill was a success, and he expressed his appreciation to the military for their efforts. He also expressed his appreciation to the local residents, whom, he said, have been understanding and cooperative.

"Only by constantly honing its combat skills can the military be capable of protecting the security of the Penghu island group and its residents and ensuring stability in the Taiwan Strait, " Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S LAWSUIT AIMED AT PROTECTING DIPLOMATIC TIES: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's lawsuit against a radio host and two opposition lawmakers is aimed at protecting his reputation and the country's relations with its diplomatic allies, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang said Thursday.
Su said the president will cooperate with the court in handling the case.

Chen had his lawyer file a civil suit calling for the restoration of his reputation against UFO Radio Chairman Jaw Shau-kong and People First Party Legislators Liu Wen-hsiung and Tsai Chung-han Thursday.

While Jaw, citing mainland Chinese news reports, claimed in his radio show that Chen had offered US$1 million to former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso as a birthday present, Liu and Tsai later used the reports to back up their accusations that the government was wasting the taxpayers' money. The two lawmakers also speculated that the "gift" could be some kind of "hush money, " implying an affair between Chen and Moscoso.

Su told a news conference that he felt angry and "chilled to the heart" that a few "unscrupulous politicians" had sided with Beijing in defaming the president at a time when the country is already facing a very difficult diplomatic situation.

Su noted that mainland China, which has always been hostile to Taiwan, has used various means to isolate Taiwan and has used vicious language to try to humiliate and smear the island in international arenas.
As the head of state, the president deserves the highest level of respect from the people, Su said.
He said the unfounded accusations have hurt the feelings of the people of Taiwan and Panama and could undermine relations between the two countries.
Also, Su said, the indecent insinuation made by the two legislators on the friendship between Chen and Moscoso is the "greatest humiliation to women."

By taking legal action, President Chen is not only trying to protect his own reputation but also the country's relations with Panama, Su said, urging all 23 million people on the island to unite to condemn what he called the "corrupt people."

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA HEAD INSPECTS DENGUE FEVER COMBAT EFFORTS IN PINGTUNG

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administrator Chang Juu-en traveled to Taiwan's southernmost city of Pingtung Thursday to inspect efforts in combating dengue fever.

After inspecting areas that have been hit the hardest by dengue fever, Chang suggested that Pingtung residents, with the assistance of city and county officials, battle dengue fever by first cleaning up their environments.

"I suggested that Pingtung City and Pingtung County accelerate community development programs, starting with each borough in the region cleaning up and beautifying their living environments, " Chang said. In the process, the mosquito-infested areas will be cleared and the scourge of dengue fever will be staved off, he noted.
Pingtung has been the hardest hit among all the regions around Taiwan this year by dengue fever, a mosquito-borne disease.

According to the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), a total of 132 cases of indigenous dengue fever were reported islandwide as of Oct. 20 this year, with 123 cases reported in Pingtung County alone. Of the 123 cases, 116 cases were reported in Pingtung City, with new cases being reported almost every day, EPA officials said.

Chang stressed the importance of residents voluntarily cleaning up their own environments to combat dengue fever, saying that efforts to eradicate mosquitoes will be doomed to failure if the residents rely simply on the government.
"Fines will have to be issued in the event that the residents do not take the initiative to clean up the areas," he added.

According to Chang, the EPA has allocated NT$4 million this year exclusively for clean-up efforts nationwide. As of last week, he said, 97.8 percent of 1,085 unattended open tracts in Pingtung City had been cleaned up.

Under a carrot-and-stick scheme, the Pingtung County Government will begin a clean-up competition in 79 boroughs in Pingtung City Oct. 23 for 20 days to select winners who perform the best in clearing up mosquito-infested environments.

The competition will feature cleaning up of stagnant water in ponds and sewers, as well as standing water that does not contain pesticides, all of which are believed to have allowed mosquitos to multiply.
The winners will be awarded with cash prizes ranging from NT$40,000 to NT$100,000, county government officials said.
A total of 300 soldiers were sent to Pingtung County Oct. 4 to help combat the spread of dengue fever in Pingtung.

Small-scale dengue fever outbreaks occur about every three years in Taiwan, with a major outbreak happening about every decade, dating back to the early 1930s when nearly 80 percent of the population contracted the disease in a major outbreak.

Four types of the virus that causes dengue fever have been found, and patients with more than one type of virus can develop symptoms that include bleeding of the gums, the skin and the intestinal tract, in addition to the classic symptoms of sudden high fever, severe headaches, nausea and vomiting, and muscle and joint pain.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Oil Fund Lures as Budget Passes.
The State Duma approved a record $105 billion in spending for 2005, as Finance Minister Alexei Kudrin defended the billions of dollars set aside from windfall oil revenues. The budget, which sees a surplus for the sixth year, was supported by 349 deputies and opposed by 86 with one abstention. Two more readings remain, though Wednesday's second reading is considered the most important.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 8.9 points to close at 5,797.24.
The bourse opened at 5,765.25 and fluctuated between 5,849.18 and 5,756.26 during trading. A total of 3.75 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$77.48 billion (US$2.29 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues both at 0.1 percent.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down at 1.7 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent.
Meanwhile, cement stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 312 to 282, with 198 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.018 to close at NT$33.796.
A total of US$811 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.814 and fluctuated between NT$33.730 and NT$33.876.

DOC.HEADLINE: COORDINATION COUNCIL TO BE GRADUALLY PHASED OUT: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Coordination Council for North American Affairs will be gradually phased out by the Executive Yuan, but when and how are matters left for further discussion, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, where lawmakers were talking about cutting regular appropriations for the council and another intermediary body, the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, Chen asked that the budgets for the two not be reduced since the council and foundation are both currently operating for the benefit of the country.
Chen said he would feel particularly "powerless" if lawmakers
move to slash the budget for the democracy foundation, which he said is an extension of Taiwan that helps foster democratization in other countries.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is chairman of the foundation, which was established in June 2003 with funds from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The coordination council, the organization that represents Taiwan in dealing with the United States in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, was established in 1979 as a counterpart to the United States' American Institute in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Another 1,300 British troops to be called up for Iraq duty.
Coalition commanders are planning to send a "surge" of extra British troops to Iraq before the elections in January, Britain's senior general in the country said yesterday. One or two extra battalions -- or up to 1,300 men -- could be sent under contingency plans being drawn up by military chiefs.
Financial Times: Chancellor poised to break golden rule.
Chancellor Gordon Brown is on course to break his "golden rule" of public finances that the Government should borrow only to invest over this economic cycle. A shift in government expenditure from investment to benefits, goods and services in the first six months of this financial year has prevented the current budget from improving as the Treasury had predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER ATTACKS PFP OVER ALLEGED FINANCIAL GIFT TO EX-PANAMA LEADER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen accused opposition People First Party lawmakers Thursday of sensationalism over their allegations that President Chen Shui-bian had given US$1 million to former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso as a birthday present.
Speaking in the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee, Minister Chen said the allegations are "100 percent false."

President Chen on Thursday filed a civil suit against UFO Radio Chairman Jaw Shau-kong and PFP legislators Liu Wen-hsiung and Tsai Chung-han, who openly spread the story based on unfounded reports from mainland China.
Minister Chen said the foreign aid offered by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to the country's diplomatic allies is always designated for specific purposes and appropriated over a five-year period.
He said there is a standard legal procedure for the Taiwan government to follow in giving foreign aid and that the Legislative Yuan must approve before any funds are appropriated.
He stressed that Taiwan that will never do anything against the law despite the difficulties in promoting the country's foreign relations.
At a separate news conference, Liu said he will reflect on his previous remark that the US$1 million could be some kind of "hush money" paid to Moscoso after unwelcome sexual advances.
However, Liu said the purpose of his commenting on the case was to raise public concern on the problems surrounding the financial aid offered by the government to the country's diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST 'GRIEF HEALING GARDEN' TO OPEN IN PEITOU

TEXT.P: National Taipei College of Nursing (NTCU) in the city's Peitou district will inaugurate a "grief healing garden" Friday as part of its efforts to help prevent suicide in Taiwan, a school spokesman said Thursday.

It will be Taiwan's first such area, the spokesman said, adding that the garden was designed in line with Western horticulture therapy concepts as well as traditional Chinese gardening principles and ideals of harmony between nature and man.
"The specially designed garden provides an environment for our minds to get over grief," the spokesman said.

Noting that suicide has continued to make Taiwan's top-10 list of killers for seven years in a row and has become the third leading cause of death for local teenagers, the spokesman said he hopes the new garden can serve as a model for other local schools at various levels to emulate.

"School education is very important to instill young students with positive concepts toward life and help them develop skills and the inner strengthen to cope with feelings of loss and grief, " the spokesman said, adding that the "grief healing garden" will become a community resource to help people work through their feelings.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VISITS SENIOR CITIZENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun visited an activity center for senior citizens in Kaohsiung Thursday to celebrate the Double Nine Chung Yang Festival with the elderly.
The festival, aimed at honoring the elderly, is observed on the ninth day of the ninth month of the lunar calendar, which falls on Oct. 22 this year.
Yu pledged that the government will strengthen its welfare policies for the elderly as Taiwan becomes an "aging country."
Welfare programs such as old-age pensions and allowances for elderly farmers as well as free physical check-ups and flu shots for seniors will continue, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES OF BUS ACCIDENT VICTIMS DISCUSS COMPENSATION WITH AGENCY

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong family members of those killed and injured in a tour bus accident in a scenic area in northern Taiwan, went to the travel agency in Hong Kong to discuss compensation.
Five Hong Kong tourists were killed and 32 were injured when their tour bus overturned in the mountainous area of Chioufen, Taipei County, on Oct. 18.
An executive of Kwan Kin Travel Services Ltd., which arranged the tour to Chioufen, said that compensation will not be determined until Taiwan police announce the results of their investigation.

A member of the Travel Industry Council of Hong Kong, who accompanied the relatives of the victims to the travel agency, asked the Hong Kong travel agency and Taiwan authorities to present the reports of the investigation as soon as possible.
Meanwhile, among the more than 30 tourists who returned to Hong Kong in the last few days, nine are still in hospitals for further treatment but are in stable condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-PRIVATIZATION HUNGER STRIKE CONTINUES INTO THIRD DAY

TEXT.P: A hunger strike by leaders of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) against the government's privatization policy went into its third day Thursday.

TCTU Vice President Chung Kung-chao said the group might begin more protests before the year-end legislative elections unless the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) agrees to their requests before the hunger strike ends Friday.
The TCTU called in more than 2,000 members to demonstrate in front of the Legislative Yuan earlier this week.
They demanded that lawmakers across party lines help stop the government from selling state-run enterprises before consulting the confederation and getting its approval.
They urged the lawmakers to support their request that the government sign group contracts with workers of state-owned enterprises before privatizing these companies.
They also wanted the government to refrain from meddling in the operation of the state-run enterprises.

With the exception of the DPP, the three other major political parties including the opposition Kuomintang, People First Party and Taiwan Solidarity Union have signed to endorse the group's petitions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS DETERMINATION TO WIPE OUT VOTE-BUYING

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reaffirmed the government's determination Thursday to crack down on vote-buying in the upcoming legislative elections.

Yu made the reaffirmation while addressing a meeting of chief prosecutors and investigators chaired by State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao to discuss measures to increase effectiveness and efficiency in vote-buying investigations.
As 387 hopefuls have registered to vie for 176 regional seats to be up for grabs in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Yu said the competition will definitely be very fierce.
"I hope all law enforcement officers, including prosecutors, investigators and police officers can maintain administrative neutrality and adopt effective steps to wipe out vote-buying, " Yu said.

To signify its determination to eliminate vote-buying and establish clean politics, Yu said the Cabinet has approved a proposal to set up vote-buying investigations that can be conducted immediately upon notification of irregularities.

According to the Cabinet's program, prosecutors' offices in various counties and cities should form a special vote-buying task force to handle vote-buying charges swiftly and effectively. The special task force will be comprised of investigators, police officers and prosecutors to enhance operational efficiency.
Yu said the Cabinet will earmark NT$48 million from its second reserve fund to finance operations of the rapid investigative task forces.

Moreover, Yu said the government will offer additional cash rewards to encourage ordinary citizens to provide leads for law enforcement officers to investigate vote-buying charges. In addition to general commendations, those who have contribute to the conviction of a single vote-buying case will be offered additional pecuniary rewards ranging between NT$150,000 and NT$5 million, Yu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Red Sox's anguish and Yankee's mystique dissolve in game 7.
With a barrage of four home runs, the Boston baseball team Red Sox eliminated the New York Yankees with a 10-3 victory in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series at Yankee Stadium. The Red Sox became the first team in baseball story to win a best-of-seven series after losing the first three games, and they will play host to the Houston Astros or the St. Louis Cardinals in Game 1 of the World Series at Fenway Park on Saturday. The National League Championship Series is tied, three games apiece, with Game 7 tonight.
Wall Street Journal: As shrimp industry thrives in Vietnam, trade fight looms.
American shrimp fishermen are struggling, as millions of shrimp farmers in Asia and Latin America are exploiting their natural advantages in climate, cheap labor and large coastal tracts. They farm their catch in ponds -- a process virtually off-limits to Americans due to environmental concerns and the high cost of coastal property. Their methods have led to a surge in world shrimp supply, and they now account for nearly 90 percent of the U.S. market. The growing supply has led to a dramatic decline in shrimp prices -- in the U.S., for instance, wholesale prices fell roughly 40 percent between between 1997 and 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSACTIONS IN EPZS TOP NT$238.2 BILLION IN 8 MONTHS

TEXT.P: The accumulated transactions from January to August in Taiwan's Economic Processing Zones (EPZs) reached NT$238.2 billion (US$7.04 billion) , up 30 percent over the same period last year, officials of the EPZ Administration said Thursday.

During the July-August period, business transactions amounted to NT$60.6 billion, up 23.13 percent over the same period last year. The high-tech electronic industry absorbed the lion's share of the transactions, with NT$46.5 billion or 76.71 percent of the total, up 21.01 percent over the same period last year. Precision machinery accounted for NT$7 billion, or 11.52 percent of the total, up 60.54 percent over the same period last year.

In the other development, the officials said, the administration approved a total of 34 investment projects worth NT$5.62 billion and 58 capital-added projects with a combined value of NT$26.6 billion during the January-September period in the five EPZs around the nation. The capital-added projects deal mostly with the high-tech electronic industry and are worth NT$19.6 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ENCOURAGES PRIVATE PARTICIPATION IN PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: The government has provided significant business opportunities to encourage private participation in public construction projects, the chief of the Public Construction Commission under the Executive Yuan said Thursday.

Speaking at a ceremony to start individual meetings on private participation in building harbor facilities organized by her commission, Kuo Yao-chi said that the government enacted the Law for Promotion of Private Participation in Infrastructure in 2000 to encourage the private sector to participate in public projects.
However, she pointed out, many private enterprises are still neither aware of related regulations nor the business opportunities that have been offered by the government.

The government has set a target of attracting investment of NT$100 billion (US$2.95 billion) a year from the private sector to participate in public constructions, Kuo said, adding that the figure is at NT$41.7 billion so far this year.
Kuo expressed the hope that the private sector will have a better understanding of the government's efforts in this regard after attending the meetings.
The regulations stipulated by the law are very pragmatic and flexible and allow the parties interested to present their own development projects in public construction, Kuo noted.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications has released nearly 600 hectares of lots in the ports of Kaohsiung, Keelung, Taipei and Taichung for private participation in the construction of harbor facilities, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER EXPORT ORDER VALUE HITS SINGLE-MONTH HIGH: MOEA

TEXT.P: Export orders received by Taiwan companies in September amounted to US$19.5 billion in value, marking a 26.61 percent annual growth and posting the highest single-month level on record, according to statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The amount brings the combined value of export orders on Taiwan manufacturers for the January-September period to US$155.29 billion, up 26.26 percent over the previous year's level.

The statistics show that the September value registered a surge of US$1.09 billion in comparison with the same month last year. The figures also indicate most orders have been in the electronics sector.

MOEA officials attributed the growth to a globally rebounding semiconductor industry that has pushed top multinationals to place a bigger number of orders from Taiwan-based contractors, and to a booming demand for consuming electronic products.

In September, orders from the United States reached US$5.64 billion in value, a new single-month high. The amount grew by US$1.26 billion from a year ago, or 28.78 percent, according to the MOEA statistics.

The figures also pointed out that orders from Hong Kong during the one-month period hit US$4.32 billion, up by US$840 million, or 24.24 percent from a year ago; Japanese orders reached US$1.99 billion, up by US$300 million, or 17.5 percent; and European orders amounted to US$3.1 billion, up by US$710 million, or 28.8 percent.

In terms of product items, September orders for information technology and communication goods generated US$3.82 billion, up by 15.05 percent from the same month of a year ago, while orders for electronic products were valued at US$4.42 billion, posting an increase of 32.73 percent compared to the previous year's level.
Orders for textile products hit US$1.09 billion in value, slightly decreasing 1.72 percent from a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA CHIEF VOWS TO HELP DISABLED PEOPLE LAND JOBS

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu said Thursday the Cabinet-level council will make every possible effort to help disabled people find jobs.
Chen made the pledge at the opening of a job fair for mentally and physically challenged people in southern Taiwan.
Noting that the unemployment rate among people with disabilities is 14.6 percent, Chen said the CLA has consistently worked hard to help the mentally or physically challenged find jobs.
"The current job fair is part of these efforts and the CLA will organize similar activities in other parts of the island to mediate job opportunities for the disabled," Chen said.

In the past few years, Chen said, the CLA has asked other government agencies to hire more disabled staff members. For instance, the Labor Insurance Bureau has recruited a batch of blind people to join its work force responsible for handling a backlog of insurance premiums collections. Since then, Chen said, the bureau's premium revenues have increased by NT$1 billion annually.
"The achievement proves the devotion and capability of disabled workers, " Chen said, adding that she hopes more disabled people can bravely stand out to seek jobs.
For its part, Chen said, the CLA will continue working to improve job opportunities and working conditions for the mentally and physically challenged.

The job fair, held at the plaza in front of the Chung Cheng Cultural Center in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, attracted a large number of disabled job seekers and prospective employers. Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan also attended the opening ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YEAR HOLIDAY CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS MAY BE POSSIBLE: MAC

TEXT.P: Direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday may still be possible, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Thursday.

Chiu said even though Beijing may be unwilling to discuss with Taiwan the opening of regular direct cross-strait charter passenger and cargo flights before the island's Dec. 11 legislative elections, it may still be willing to consider special cross-strait charter flights during the lunar new year holiday to facilitate the return of Taiwan business people operating in mainland China, commonly known as "taishang," for family reunions.

Mainland China allowed major Taiwan carriers to operate special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year holiday for the convenience of home-bound "taishang." Such services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year season because Beijing declined to negotiate technical details for mainland Chinese carriers to operate similar charter flights.

If the two sides can reach an agreement allowing Taiwan and mainland Chinese carriers to operate special non-stop, cross-strait charter flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday, which runs from Feb. 6-13, 2005, Chiu said, it will mark a new breakthrough in the development of cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT DENIES RECEIPT OF US$1 MILLION CHECK

TEXT.P: Former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso said in a statement Wednesday that she did not receive US$1 million from Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian as alleged by Taiwan's opposition lawmakers.

The Arnulfista Party, to which Moscoso belongs, issued the statement amid allegations made by some Taiwan opposition People First Party politicians and a radio program host that President Chen gave the outgoing Moscoso a check for US$1 million as a "birthday gift" when he visited Panama in early September for the inauguration of new Panamanian President Martin Torrijos.

Former Panamanian Minister of Foreign Affairs Harmodio Arias, who telephoned Moscoso about the issue, said that Moscoso was furious about the allegations, describing them as absurd and the persons who made them as harboring evil intentions.
Arias noted that no one from Taiwan had presented Moscoso birthday gifts, and the persons who said she had received a US$1 million check have no respect for her.

In Taiwan, the spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Wednesday refuted as ludicrous the allegations, and President Chen Shui-bian decided to file a lawsuit against the two lawmakers and the radio talk show host Thursday over the rumors, which the suit says have seriously damaged the president's reputation.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 300 BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS ARRIVE IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: The number of black-faced spoonbills that have arrived in the wetlands near the mouth of the Tsengwen River in Tainan, southern Taiwan, has exceeded 300, almost twice the number seen last year at this time.

According to the Tainan Black-Faced Spoonbills Conservation Association, as of Thursday, 320 black-faced spoonbills have arrived in the area, a favorite habitat for the rare birds, in comparison with 155 that arrived in the area at this time last year.

The black-faced spoonbills usually migrate from North Asia to the warmer wetlands in Taiwan and other Asian countries between late September and early December every year to overwinter, with almost half of the number of black-faced spoonbills around the world staying at the wetlands near the mouth of the Tsengwen River, and the others arriving in Hong Kong, Vietnam, China, Japan and South Korea.

Meanwhile, according to a report conducted by the Tainan County Animal Disease Control Center, one test site in the area has shown positive for clostridium botulinum, a major factor in the death of waterfowl, and the center has issued warnings to relevant agencies to strengthen protection measures for the black-faced spoonbills and other waterfowl.
The clostridium botulinum caused the death of 73 black-faced spoonbills from late 2002 to early 2003, according to a bird conservationist.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY TO SET UP EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT TASK FORCE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will set up a task force to deal with any contingent matters that could jeopardize the country's interests, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee, Chen said that the task force would establish a supervisory mechanism and procedures to monitor the implementation of Taiwan's foreign aid programs and keep abreast of developments in international situations, particularly those involving Taiwan's diplomatic allies.
The main mission of the task force will be crisis management and to prevent China from hampering relations between Taiwan and its allies, Chen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCT. 22 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, Oct. 22:
09:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive Milenko E. Skoknic, executive director of the organizing committee of APEC Chile 2004 at the Presidential Office.
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
09: 00, A seminar on the prospects of Taiwan's manufacturing sector will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center.
10: 00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a routine news conference at the council's headquarters.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the opening ceremony of the 2004 East Asian Equestrian Games at the Hannover Equestrian Club in Taipei.
11: 15, The Taiwan delegation to the CEO Summit under the APEC Chile 2004 will hold a news conference at the China Trust Commercial Bank's headquarters in Taipei.
15:30, The Department of Health (DOH) will hold a news conference at the DOH headquarters.

16: 00, The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics will issue reports on employment for September at its headquarters.
16:00, The Budapest Orchestra will hold a news conference at the Grand Hyatt Taipei.
16:00, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will meet with visiting Japanese Dietman Kamei at the Taipei City Hall.

18: 30, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the 2004 Taiwan Standard Bearer Enterprise Awards ceremony to be held at the Grand Formosa Regent, Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TRUTH COMMISSION' CALLS ON CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION BUREAU

TEXT.P: Members of the "truth investigation commission" formed at the insistence of opposition parties to look into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, called on the Criminal Investigation Bureau Thursday.

Ho Yu-yi, the director of the bureau in charge of the investigation into the assassination attempt, told commission members that the case is very difficult due to the lack of evidence and given its political overtones.
Ho said many people are reluctant to come forward with information about the politically charged case.

Citing as an example, Ho said the bureau appealed to the public about three months ago to come forward with information about a man who was caught on TV footage at the scene before the shooting, but so far not single person has spoken up.
Police have offered NT$53 million (US$1.56 million) for information leading to the arrest of the gunman who shot and lightly wounded the president and Vice President Annette Lu.
Despite these difficulties, Ho said everything that can be done is being done to crack the case.

Wang Ching-feng, a lawyer who serves as spokeswoman for the commission, told journalists afterward that she was impressed with the efforts the police have put into the case and the committee did not ask police to hand over investigation documents to the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERT RECOMMENDS DUAL RESTRAINTS APPROACH TOWARD TAIWAN ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The long-standing strategic ambiguity in U.S. policy on the Taiwan issue should better be depicted as dual restraints, Frank S. Jannuzi, a U.S. expert on East Asian affairs for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said in Washington Wednesday.

Jannuzi said in a speech at the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies, Johns Hopkins University in Washington, D.C., that dual restraints means the United States should urge Taiwan to refrain from provoking China by toying with the idea of independence while urging China to refrain from using force against Taiwan.

Jannuzi, who was portrayed as the right-hand man of Senator Joe Biden, the senior Democrat in the Foreign Relations Committee and a favorite candidate for Secretary of State if John Kerry wins the presidential election in November, said the dual restraints are not a substitute for strategic ambiguity, which is favored by Kerry, but rather the other side of the same coin.

Noting that there have been several contradictory developments between Taiwan and the mainland, Jannuzi said Taiwan is increasingly being woven together with the mainland in economics through its huge investment there while seeking an identity separate from China in politics, and China has been building up its military force and vows to take over Taiwan at whatever cost.
Under this situation, Jannuzi said the United States should stick to its policy based on its three comuniques with China and its Taiwan Relations Act, and call for self-restraint from both sides.
Washington should also assure Taiwan that it won't improve ties with China at the expense of Taiwan, and try to build trust with one another, Jannuzi went on.
It takes times and patience to solve the disputes between Taiwan and the mainland and Washington should give clear messages rather then complicate things with confusing indications.
Jannuzi said he didn't think Kerry, if he wins the November election, will drop any promises made by the proceeding government to Taiwan, including the offer of arms to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN BURTON ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. Representative Dan Burton, a Republican from Indiana, arrived in Taipei Thursday for a visit, according to a news release from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Burton, who has been in the House of Representatives since 1983, was accompanied by his chief aide, Mark Walker, on the visit. They will meet with President Chen Shui-bian and other government and business leaders, the release said.
As a member of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus, a pro-Taiwan group, Burton is friendly to Taiwan and has already visited the country six times.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESIDES OVER OPENING OF CALLIGRAPHY EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over the opening of an exhibition of works by centenarian calligrapher Chen Yun-cheng at the National History Museum in Taipei Thursday.

Citing the calligrapher's line that "We are Taiwanese, and Taiwan belongs to the Taiwanese, not the Japanese or Chinese," the president said he was impressed with Chen Yun-cheng's artistic achievements as well as his passion for Taiwan.

The president hailed Chen Yun-cheng as the first generation of Taiwan's calligrapher who has combined the best hand-writing art of Japan and Taiwan, adding that that is the reason why he sports one of the calligrapher's works in the reception room at the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION INDEX STANDS AT 127.71

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index stood at 127.71 for September, an increase of 8.12 percent over the same month last year, according to the statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Thursday.

Cumulatively, the industrial production index stood at 125.91 for the first nine months, a growth of 12.54 percent over the same period last year, with the manufacturing production index increasing the most at 13.71 percent, the largest growth since 1985.

Among the manufacturing sector, the production for the metal and machinery industry grew the most at 15.89 percent in September, followed by chemical, and the information and electronics industries at 11.47 percent and 6.77 percent, respectively.

However, in the period from January to September, the production made by the information and electronics industries increased the most at 19.56 percent, followed by metal, chemical and consumer industries by 13.20 percent, 12.16 percent and 1.11 percent, respectively.

Among different categories, the electronics components sector saw an annual growth of 14.98 percent in September, mainly because of the beginning of the school terms, the forthcoming Christmas holiday, as well as buying due to long vacations for workers in China.
In the same month, the production for the electrical and machinery industry grew by 6.29 percent, due mainly to several public construction projects.
Meanwhile, export orders for September reached US$19.5 billion, a monthly record high, MOEA officials announced, estimating that export orders will maintain high growth for the rest of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 22, or the ninth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1721: Peter I, known as "Peter the Great," is proclaimed Emperor of all of Russia. He extended his territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores and reformed the administration of the state.
1835: Sam Houston, U.S. politician and general who fought in the Texan struggle for independence from Mexico, is sworn in as president of the Republic of Texas.
1873: The emperors of Russia, Germany and Austro-Hungary form an alliance.
1906: Paul Cezanne, French painter and leading post-impressionist figure, dies at the age of 67. His most famous paintings include "Mont Sainte-Victoire" and "The Card Players."
1909: Elise de Laroche, French aviator better known as Baronne de Laroche, becomes the first woman to fly solo.
1944: The Military Committee of the National government begins drafting young intellectuals for military service after Chairman Chiang Kai-shek on Sept. 14 urged 100,000 young men to enter the army.
1947: Pakistan and India begin a war over Kashmir.
1947: Japanese spy Yoshiko Kawajima is sentenced to death by a Chinese military court.
1950: Popular elections of magistrates are held in Taiwan Province, with Yang Chung-ching being elected chief of Hualien County and Chen Chen-chung being elected chief of Taitung County.
1951: A strong earthquake rocks Hualien, killing 43 people and destroying many houses.
1953: Laos gains independence from France.
1962: U.S. President John F. Kennedy makes his first major move in the showdown with the USSR over the building of ballistic missile sites in Cuba by announcing that Cuba will be placed under a naval "quarantine" -- a blockade -- until the Soviets remove the missiles.
1964: Jean-Paul Sartre, French writer, rejects the Nobel Prize for literature by saying it would reduce the impact of his writing.
1966: KGB master spy George Blake, who had spied for the Russians for 12 years and in 1962 had been sentenced to 42 years in prison, escapes from the maximum security wing of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London.
1975: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and philosopher, dies at the age of 86. His "Study of History" explores patterns of growth and the decay of civilization.
1976: The 34,000-ton tanker Tsaineng (Talent) calls at Taichung port, becoming the first vessel to enter Taiwan's fourth international seaport.
1977: The first generator of the first nuclear power plant in Taiwan becomes operational.
1978: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea agree to exchange information on the development and preservation of energy resources at their 13th annual ministerial economic conference.
1986: Yeh Chien-ying, one of the senior leaders of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 89. With the support of Yeh, who commanded a wide following in the army and among senior cadres in 1976, Hua Kuo-feng was able to purge the "Gang of Four" and become Mao Zedong successor.
1992: Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Robert Urbain visits Taipei to relay a message of welcome to Taiwan business leaders intending to invest in Belgium. He also pledges support for the ROC's bid to join GATT.
1993: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of Russia, signs a decree governing private farms, paving the way for the breaking up of state-controlled farms and the move toward a free market economy.
1995: Independent presidential candidate Chen Li-an names Wang Ching-feng, a Control Yuan member, as his running mate.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew rushes to Chiayi immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern city at 10:19 a.m. and injured more than 320 people.
2000: Industrial sources say that Taiwan's exports in personal and notebook computers have increased by more than 40 percent over last year, with local notebooks accounting for 60 percent of the global market.
2001: After years of preparations, a group of scholars, social workers and medical specialists form the "Taiwan Health Reform Foundation" to monitor the operations of the nation's medical system.
2001: Lien Chan, chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), urges the public during a video shot for an ad to put their love of Taiwan into action by joining volunteer services.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON NOCK-TEN EXPECTED TO BRING TORRENTIAL RAINS TO TAIWAN: CWB

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) is closely monitoring Typhoon Nock-Ten, the 24th typhoon reported in the Pacific Ocean region this year, CWB sources reported Friday.

Typhoon Nock-Ten was centered some 1,900 kilometers southeast of Taiwan at 10 a.m. Friday, moving northwesterly toward the island at a speed of 21 kilometers per hour. With a radius of 200 kilometers, the typhoon was packing maximum sustained winds of up to 180 kilometers per hour, CWB meteorologists said.

The forecasters said that they won't be able to determine whether Nock-Ten will directly hit Taiwan until Saturday at the earliest given that the typhoon is still far away and that there are many variables that could influence the typhoon's direction, including the northeast trade winds.

Typhoon Nok-Ten comes on the heels of Typhoon Tokage, another "autumn typhoon, " which pounded Japan Wednesday and caused heavy damage and the highest death toll of any typhoon to hit the country in the last two decades.
The CWB forecasters said they expect Typhoon Nock-Ten to bring tremendous amounts of rainfall to Taiwan in the following couple of days regardless of whether or not it hits the island directly.

The weather bureau warned people in Taiwan not to take any autumn typhoon lightly because the arrival of such typhoons coincides with the northeast monsoon season, a combination which can cause torrential rains, that in turn can trigger torrents and landslides.

TEXT.P: Several leading Panamanian newspapers on Thursday widely reported that former Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso Rodriguez has denied ever having received a US$1 million check from Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian.
The newspapers include El Siglo, Critica, El Panama America and La Prensa.

Some members of the ROC opposition People First Party (PFP) caucus at the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday accused Chen of giving a US$1 million check to the former Panamanian president as a birthday gift, and criticized the government's behavior in dealing with foreign affairs regarding its Central American diplomatic allies.
According to La Prenda, the new Panamanian government has decided to investigate and clarify the matter regarding whether any donations were ever made by Taipei to the Moscoso administration.
Meanwhile, Jose Antonio Sossa, Panama's chief prosecutor, paid a courtesy visit to ROC Ambassador to Panama David Hu on Oct. 19 to discuss relevant matters.
During the meeting, Hu told the prosecutor that all donations made by Taiwan to Panama have been made via appropriate government-to-government channels.

These estimates contrast sharply with earlier intelligence reports, in which the number of insurgents has varied from as few as 2,000 to a maximum of 7,000. The revised estimate is influencing the military campaign in Iraq, but has not prompted a wholesale review of the strategy, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN MAN FOUND ADRIFT AT SEA BY TAIWAN COAST GUARD RETURNS HOME

TEXT.P: A Russian man who drifted on the seas aboard his knockabout for over 5,000 nautical miles and ended up off the coast of Tamshui, northern Taiwan several days ago, returned safely to Russia Thursday, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) sources reported Friday.

Alexander Rudnev, a real estate manager from Siberia, had never imagined that his originally-scheduled 16-day sailing journey would end up being a one-month ordeal of drifting on the high seas along a course that took him from Vladivostok to South Korea, Japan and down to Taiwan.

Rudnev was found drifting aboard his unpowered single-mast sailing boat "Falco" off Tamshui on the night of Oct. 16. When he was found, Rudnev was in bad shape and had no idea of his location. Arrangements were made for him to stay at the CGA's Tamshui operations center.

The CGA Tamshui officials notified the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission about Rudnev's situation. They also hired a Taiwanese Russian-language student from Tamkang University in Tamshui to act as an interpreter as Rudnev speaks no English or Chinese.

After five days of rest, Rudnev departed Taipei for home Thursday, this time aboard a Northwest Airlines flight. He expressed his sincere gratitude to Taiwan and said that next time, he will take his wife and children to Taiwan, "by airplane of course, " to say thank you again and for tourism.

According to Rudnev, he departed from his home in New Siberia City Sept. 12. After a six day train journey on the "Red Train, " he reached the far eastern Russian city of Vladivostok, from where he sailed off alone aboard the "Falco" for South Korea.
After sailing for about 1,000 nautical miles, Rudnev reached Pusan, South Korea, Sept. 26 as planned and went ashore for a four-day backpacking trip.

He set off from Pusan for home Sept. 30 but was met with a storm before long. Having no other option, Rudnev lowered his mast and drifted. Four days later, he found himself beached ashore at a fishing village in northwest Japan. With the assistance of the Russian embassy in Japan, he obtained his visa and took a sightseeing trip in Japan for seven days.
On Oct. 10, he departed Japan for home and was immediately met with strong northeast trade winds. Like a small leaf, his boat drifted for about one week in high waves before it was pushed southward.

Rudnev's situation turned for the worse when Typhoon Tokage, the deadliest typhoon to hit Japan in two decades, swept the region with gusty winds, downpours and a record-large radius of 500 kilometers.

During the typhoon's onslaught, Rudnev on at least two occasions felt certain he would not survive. However, he did, and after drifting further southward, he was met by Taiwanese patrol officers who brought him to safety in Tamshui.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL CHINESE-LANGUAGE DOMAIN NAME AND ADDRESS SYSTEM POSSIBLE: ITU
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: Experts from the International Communication Union (ITU) are not optimistic about the development of a global Chinese-language Internet domain name and address system, noting that many technical problems still need to be solved before such a system can be used by all the netizens in the world.
The Geneva-based ITU is an international organization within the United Nations System where governments and the private sector coordinate global telecom networks and services.

As the management of Internet domain names and addresses has become an important issue in the future development of the Internet, the ITU experts have expressed that developing a Chinese-language Internet domain name and address system is absolutely possible for those who use computers with Chinese-language software.

Pointing out that using Chinese-language Internet domain names and addresses is very easy for Chinese computer users, the experts said, however, that for those who not do know Chinese, even a Chinese key-in operation might become a tough matter. Besides, they said, Chinese has not yet become an international language.

It is absolutely possible to develop Chinese, Korean and Japanese Internet domain names and addresses, the experts said, adding however that in order to develop these domain name and address systems, many technical problems still need to be solved.

Despite the fact that English letters and Arabic numerals are most commonly used in Internet domain names and addresses, many people have been researching how to develop Chinese, Korean, Japanese, Arabic and Russian Internet domain name and address systems, the experts said, adding that the ITU will also set up working groups to do research on relevant matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER PLAYS DOWN REPORTED MAINLAND WARPLANE PROVOCATION

TEXT.P: National Defense Minister Lee Jye said Friday that mainland Chinese warplanes did not traverse the center line of the Taiwan Strait, which separates Taiwan from mainland China, during a training exercise late last month.
Lee was responding to a media report that a large fleet of mainland Chinese warplanes flew very close to the sensitive Taiwan Strait center line in late September in an act of provocation.

The media report quoted U.S. sources as saying that more than 10 squadrons of various types of mainland warplanes, including Su-27, Su-30, J-8 and J-10 (mainland versions of the MiG-21) jet fighters and various kinds of bombers, flew 30-plus sorties close to the Taiwan Strait center line in the second half of September. The number of sorties broke the single-day record set in 1998, the report said.
Taiwan's military aircraft had scrambled into the air to monitor the mainland warplane operations, the report said, adding that the situation in the Taiwan Strait became extremely tense at one point.

Minister Lee played down the report when asked by lawmakers about the event during a legislative session, saying that no mainland Chinese warplanes joining the reported training exercise had traversed the center line.
Lee further said the Ministry of National Defense had dispatched military aircraft to scramble to monitor the mainland warplane exercises in accordance with the armed forces' combat regulations.
In the face of mainland China's growing military threat, Lee said, the military will continue to beef up its defense capabilities and intensify its combat preparedness.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DEMANDS AUTHORITIES RETRIEVE FORMER PRESIDENT'S GIFT ITEMS

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislator on Friday demanded that the Academia Historica retrieve the gifts received by former President Lee Teng-hui during his presidency, which the lawmaker said are part of national property.

Huang Te-hu, whip of the KMT's legislative caucus, was referring to the collection, including a number of souvenirs presented to Lee by foreign officials as diplomatic protocol, which is stored by Lee at the Hupaokeng military base in Tahsi, Taoyuan County.
Huang argued that Lee became a regular citizen when he retired from public office and that the military base cannot be used as a "private treasure vault."

According to law, the Academia Historica is in charge of managing the relics of presidents and vice presidents and therefore must check on Lee's collection and have the items transferred to the organization as soon as possible, Huang said.
He said the items are national property and must be returned to the people.
The lawmaker threatened to lodge a complaint with the Control Yuan and ask for the impeachment of Academia Historica officials for failing in their duties unless actions are taken on the matter.

On the request, Academia Historica President Chang Yen-hsien promised to work out a set of guidelines in one month on ways to handle the collection and to send a formal notice to the offices of the president and vice president.

Meanwhile, in retaliation for the KMT's move, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Chen Chien-ming said he will lead a group of Academia Historica officials to the residence of KMT Chairman and former Vice President Lien Chan to check on the gifts received by Lien during his time as vice president.
Chen said Lee has agreed to hand over the collection at Hupaokeng to the Academia Historica, but Lien has not followed suit.

In addition to the gifts collected by Lien, the Academia Historica must also examine and retrieve those received by the late Presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo as well as the late first lady Soong Mayling, Chen said.
Reacting to the TSU's accusation, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Lien has not kept any of the gifts he received during his term as vice president.
Chang said Lien had submitted all the souvenirs he received to Lee because all the diplomatic missions performed by Lien during his vice presidency were under Lee's directives.
Chang urged the TSU lawmaker "not to carry his political stunt too far."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH APEC SUMMIT ORGANIZING COMMITTEE CHIEF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he would like to attend the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in person but that he has instead named a Nobel laureate to attend on his behalf to spare the host country any unnecessary trouble.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with Milenko E. Skoknic, chief executive of the organizing committee of the APEC Chile 2004 activities scheduled to be held in the Chilean capital of Santiago in November.

After receiving a formal invitation from Chilean President Ricardo Lagos Escobar to attend the Nov. 20-21 APEC summit meeting, Chen told his guest that he has decided to name Lee Yuan-tseh, the head of Taiwan's most prestigious research body, Academia Sinica, to represent him at the upcoming informal leadership gathering.
Lagos asked APEC Secretariat Executive Director Mario Artaza to extend the invitation to Chen in Taipei Sept. 21.
Chen told Skoknic that he feels regret over being barred from attending the annual APEC summit meeting in person simply because of Beijing's opposition.
"I would like to take part in the event in person, but I do not want to cause any trouble for the host country. Therefore, I have named Lee to serve as my proxy at the meeting," Chen said.
He requested that the Chilean organizing committee treat Lee with dignity and extend the same courtesies offered to any national leader.
Chen also asked Skoknic to help arrange for Lee to hold bilateral talks with the top leaders or their representatives of other APEC member states on the sidelines of the summit meeting.
It will be the third time that Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, has represented Chen at the annual APEC summit.

Despite the inability of the president attending, Chen said Taiwan has consistently played an active role in all APEC events. For instance, Taiwan has made positive contributions in the promotion of digitalization, public health and security cooperation -- major tasks outlined in the declaration issued at the end of the 2003 APEC summit.

"We feel honored and take pride in participating in APEC activities, " he said, adding that Taiwan will continue to throw its full support behind APEC's cause of promoting free trade, investment and sustainable development.
Moreover, Chen said, Taiwan will do it utmost to assist the six developing countries in the APEC bloc in technological personnel cultivation to narrow the "digital gap."
Chen also suggested that APEC organize a meeting of health ministers each year to boost cooperation in prevention of communicable diseases.
Meanwhile, Chen promised that Taiwan will take an even more active role in preventing avian flu, dengue fever and AIDS.

APEC groups 21 Asia-Pacific economies -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.
