DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS SAY IMPROVE ECONOMY TO REVERSE FALLING BIRTH RATE TREND

TEXT.P: A group of experts and scholars suggested Friday that Taiwan improve its domestic economy as a fundamental solution to the country's ever-declining birth rate.

At a public hearing sponsored by the Ministry of the Interior, the experts offered stopgap measures as well as fundamental solutions for the problem of Taiwan's declining birth rate, which is now one of the lowest in the world.

The experts suggested that the government offer better subsidies to married couples for births and for child-raising, lower tax rates for adults with children, and provide better nursery facilities to encourage married couples to have more babies. These, they said, are just stopgap measures.

They said measures must be taken to improve the country's economy as a fundamental solution to the problem of Taiwan's declining birth rate. When the economy is revved up, the unemployment rate tackled, and commodity prices stabilized, married couples will feel more secure about having additional children, the experts said.

Chien Tai-lang, vice minister of the interior, said at the hearing that it is an imperative that the government move to reverse the falling birth rate as the declining birth rate is leading to a drop in the ratio of younger citizens to elderly citizens. "A greying society is poised to trigger more social and economic problems for Taiwan," he noted.

According to Interior Ministry tallies, the ratio of married women to childbirths was 1.24 for 2003, representing a significant drop from the figure of 1.8 some 10 years earlier and one of the lowest figures in the world.

Officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , who were also present at the hearing, said that Taiwan's average birth rate will post negative growth by 2022 if the current trend is not effectively reversed.

With the birth rate continuing to fall, Taiwan will see fewer people supporting more elderly people, CEPD officials said. They noted that last year, each elderly retiree was supported financially by eight working-age people in the country. By 2026, there will be only three working-age people to support each retiree, creating a serious social problem, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKER APOLOGIZES FOR 'HUSH MONEY' REMARK ABOUT PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung apologized Friday for accusing President Chen Shui-bian of having paid "hush money" to former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso after the comment received extensive criticism.
A mainland Chinese Web site alleged that President Chen had given Moscoso US$1 million as a birthday gift when he was in Panama recently for the inauguration of the country's new president.

The story was picked up by Taiwan radio talk show host Jaw Shau-kong and then repeated by Liu, who along with his colleague, Tsai Chung-han, speculated that Chen had paid the money to keep her quiet after President Chen made unwelcomed sexual advances toward Moscoso.
President Chen on Thursday filed a civil lawsuit against all three men, asking for the restoration of his reputation.
Liu said he was "only trying to be funny" by using the term "hush money," and that he was sorry for his indiscreet expression.
However, Liu said his apology does not mean that he was wrong for having doubts about the government's foreign aid policy.
Liu said the truth must be discovered regarding the country's "secret funding" to its diplomatic allies.

He declined to comment on reports that Moscoso plans to file a libel suit against the three men over the allegations, saying he will only express an opinion after he understands more of what is going on.
Moscoso has denied she received US$1 million from President Chen.

Also on Friday, a group of female legislative candidates from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party demanded that the PFP remove Liu from its list of nominees for at-large legislative seats because of his chauvinistic language against a female head of state of one of the country's diplomatic allies.
The politicians said Liu's remarks damaged Taiwan's international image, and they also asked Tsai and Jaw to take responsibility for what they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIB DENIES REPORTS ABOUT MAINLAND GETTING NT$8 MILLION BOUNTY

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) denied a media report Friday that mainland Chinese police have received a share of NT$8 million in the NT$20 million bounty promised by the Taiwan government to whoever helped nab two of its most wanted fugitives.

"The report was all wrong, " a CIB official said, adding that no mainland Chinese police have ever applied for the bounty following the Sept. 23 repatriation of Hsueh Chiu and Chen Yi-hua from China to Taiwan in accordance with the Kinmen Agreement signed by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the early 1990s.

According to current regulations, whoever provides leads contributing to the arrest of felons is eligible to receive the bounty as promised by the Taiwan government. Except for Taiwan's law enforcement offices and their staff, the recipients could be local people, foreigners or individual mainland Chinese people or agencies.

Nevertheless, the CIB official said, the regulations stipulate that bounty claimants must tip off Taiwan's law enforcement authorities or their overseas offices and produce a detailed written report of their actions.

"The NT$20 million bounty promised for the arrest of Hsueh and Chen will be distributed in accordance with our existing regulations and procedures, " he said, adding that mainland Chinese police have never filed any application to share the bounty.
According to the official, a Taiwan informant first tipped off the CIB on the two notorious criminals' whereabouts on the mainland.
"After we verified the tipoffs, we requested the informant to report the case to mainland Chinese public security officers who then arrested the two in Xiamen, Fujian province, in July.

Hsueh and Chen, wanted in Taiwan in connection with at least a dozen robberies, kidnappings and extortion plots over the last three years, were handed over to Taiwan police on the outlying island of Matsu by mainland security officers and escorted by police officers to Taipei via air Sept. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW AIR ACCORD EXPANDS CAPACITY ON TAIWAN-JAPAN ROUTES

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan and Japan approved a new air pact Friday authorizing a robust increase in cargo and passenger transport capacities between the two countries.

The pact -- endorsed by the Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR) and the Japan Interchange Association (JIA) -- guarantees that the number of passenger seats offered by airline carriers from the two countries will be increased by some 200,000 a year and the restrictions on bilateral charter flights will be canceled as well, officials from the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said.
CAA officials attributed the increases mainly to the imminent arrival of new A330-300 and A330-200 aircraft to China Airlines' and EVA Airways' fleet plying the Taiwan-Japan route.

Under the new agreement, which took immediate effect, CAL and EVA will have a combined increase of 1,858 passenger seats aboard their flights to and from Japan per week, representing nearly 200,000 seats per year.
Under the new accord, the number of all-cargo flights will be doubled from the current level.

Also under the accord, restrictions on the number of charter flights between the two countries was removed. The number had been fixed at 800 per year before 2002, but the two sides exchanged 1,000 charter flights in 2003.
Sendai, a city in northeastern Japan popular with tourists, and Hiroshima in the Kansai area were added in April to the existing list of Japanese cities operating weekly flights to and from Taiwan.

With the inclusion of Sendai and Hiroshima, the number of Japanese cities operating regular weekly flights to and from Taiwan has increased to seven from the previous five -- Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, Fukuoka and Sapporo.

AEAR and JIA are quasi-official agencies authorized by the Taiwanese and Japanese governments, respectively, to handle exchanges in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.
The renewed air pact is a shot in the arm for Taiwan in its efforts to double the number of foreign tourists arriving in Taiwan by 2008, CAA officials said.
The pact will not only help attract more Japanese tourists to Taiwan, but will also help boost economic and cultural exchanges between the two countries, the officials added.
Japan is Taiwan's largest source of tourists from overseas, with about one-third of the two to three million tourists visiting Taiwan each year being Japanese.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Cabinet reaps 280,000 windfall from second homes.
Cabinet ministers with official government residences have been claiming tens of thousands of pounds from a Commons allowance designed to help MPs to pay for second homes.
Financial Times: Lazard clash puts float plans in disarray.
Bruce Wasserstein and Michel David-Weill once again clashed over plans to take Lazard public, as the New York dealmaker who runs the investment bank rejected the latest conditions set by the scion of the firm's founders. Mr David-Weill, Lazard's chairman, challenged Mr Wasserstein, whom he brought in to run the firm in 2001, to either fulfil his ambition of floating the 156-year-old investment bank in the next eight months or to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG COUNTY TO BE HOME OF ASIA'S FIRST BIKE PATH THROUGH A TUNNEL

TEXT.P: In the latest effort to promote bicycling, the Taichung County government announced Friday that it will build a new route that will be the first in Asia to take advantage of an abandoned train tunnel.

County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng said work for the construction plan will begin in November and is expected to be finished in the early months of next year. He also indicated that the project will give his county its third bike-only trail built along abandoned railroad tracks.

There are currently two bike-only routes along old railways in the county -- the 11-kilometer Tungfeng Green Corridor and the 12-kilometer Tanyalu Green Path. The former route, starting from Fengyuan City and ending at Tungshi Railway Station has become very popular because it passes through scenic parks, historic tourist spots and skirts the Shikang Dam.
The Tanyalu Green Path was built on a military railroad that was used by the Chingchuankang Air Force Base.

The new route will start from the Houli horse stables in Houli township, then enter the 1,269-meter No. 9 tunnel on the old Western Railway Line. Exiting the tunnel, the trail will hook up with the spectacular 382-meter Hualiang Steel Bridge on Tachia River. It will end where the Tungfeng Green Corridor route begins.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC BUSINESS LEADERS TO ATTEND APEC CEO SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Ten business leaders from Taiwan will attend the CEO summit and Business Advisory Council meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum beginning Nov. 16 in Santiago, Chile.

The entrepreneurs, including Teco Group Chairman Theodore M.H. Huang, who is also chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, and Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. Chairman Jeffrey Koo, held a news conference Friday to unveil the issues they will discuss.

As the APEC CEO summit and Business Advisory Council meeting will precede the APEC informal leadership meeting, which will be held Nov. 20-21, Huang said he will take the chance to get acquainted with more foreign political and business leaders, among them, Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Noting that Chinese President Hu Jintao will also be in attendance, Huang said that if he has a chance to speak with Hu, he will ask him to take good care of Taiwan business people with operations in China and will also ask that Taiwan and China take more steps to create opportunities that will benefit each other.

For his part, Koo stressed that the major problem for Taiwan's economic development is the fierce competition from globalization, and this is the issue that participants at APEC meetings should study. (By Elisa Kao)

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH OF TAIWAN'S MANUFACTURING SECTOR TO SLOW NEXT YEAR: TIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's manufacturing sector is expected to post slower growth next year due to a projected economic slowdown in the United States, one of the island's major trading partners, according to a report by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) released Friday.
The report was presented by TIER associate research fellow Chang Chien-yi at a seminar on the status and market trends of technology industries.

Chang predicted Taiwan's industrial production index in 2005 will see moderate growth of between 10 percent to 15 percent, with the economic growth of the U.S. likely to dwindle next year to around 3 percent.

The U.S., as well as mainland China and Europe, are the top three markets for Taiwan's electronics parts and components, chemicals and basic metals, which are the three sectors that account for the largest share of the island's industrial production, according to Chang.
Therefore, the economic showing of these three regions in 2005 is related to the performance of Taiwan's manufacturing sector next year, Chang said.
Despite the projected slowdown in the U.S., the mainland is likely to see an economic growth of at least 8 percent, and Europe at around 2 percent, he said.
Chang noted that export orders received by Taiwan during the first eight months of this year amounted to US$135.8 billion, up 26.21 percent from the same period last year.
Export orders in August alone totalled US$18.06 billion, increasing 25.54 percent year-on-year, Chang said.
Orders for in the electronics sector registered the highest growth rate at 36.45 percent, or US$1.09 billion, as the global semiconductor industry recovered from a recession, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NYMEX TO SIGN MEMORANDUM ON INFORMATION EXCHANGE COOPERATION WITH TFE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Futures Exchange (TFE) is slated to sign a memorandum on information exchange cooperation Oct. 29 with the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) , TFE General Manager Ho Fu-hsiung said Friday.

The main purposes of signing the memorandum are to build mutually beneficial cooperative ties anchored in honesty and good credit principles, and to establish bilateral information exchange procedures. Joint efforts to promote market operation efficiency is another focus.

The NYMEX will be the fifth exchange to have cooperative ties with the TFE. The other four exchanges in cooperation with the TFE are the Korean Futures Exchange (KOFEX), the Tokyo International Financial Futures Exchange (TIFFE), the Tokyo Commodity Exchange (TOCOM) and the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT).

DOC.HEADLINE: TCTU ENDS HUNGER STRIKE AFTER AGREEMENT WITH DPP ON PRIVATIZATION

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) ended a 72-hour hunger strike Friday after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus finally agreed to their demands, which are aimed at slowing the government's privatization efforts.
The appeal had gained the endorsement of the opposition Kuomintang, People First Party and Taiwan Solidarity Union caucuses in the past two days.

Chang Hsu-chung, leader the protest, said the TCTU expects the legislators to pass a resolution in line with the agreement reached between TCTU and the caucuses, before the Legislative Yuan adjourns on Nov. 10 in preparation for the legislative elections.
Chang said the TCTU will start a negative publicity campaign against any party that goes back on its promise.
The agreement states that the government should consult with the TCTU on its privatization policies and postpone the selling of state-run enterprises until a consensus is reached with the workers.
It also says that the state-run enterprises should sign group contracts with trade unions before they are privatized.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PRODUCED LAO TSU TEA WINS AWARD AT PARIS FOOD FAIR
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 21 (CNA) (BY Lo Yuan-shao and sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-produced tea was given an innovative food award at the just-concluded Paris SIAL 2004 international food trade fair for its creative packaging and fortified anti-aging effects.

Lao Tsu Tea Industrial Co. Chairman Yeh Liang-chuan said after receiving the award at the trade show's closing ceremony Thursday that the prize marks the recognition of his company's efforts to inject new life into traditional drinks.

Thanks to the company's long-term marketing efforts, Yeh said, the various kinds of Lao Tsu teas, which come in cans, have made successful inroads into France, Great Britain and the Netherlands. Yeh said the company has traditionally focused on marketing its products at high-end European department stores.

During the SIAL trade fair, Yeh said, several French supermarket chains also expressed interest in selling Lao Tsu teas. Moreover, he added, the teas, including mint- and jasmine-flavored tea and white oolong tea, will soon be available in Belgium and Germany.
Yeh said the company is scheduled to market its 250c.c. "Awakening" series of tea drinks as well as Wuhsing tea bags and green tea capsules in Europe next year.

Lao Tsu Tea Industrial Co. was one of 26 Taiwan food processing companies that took part in this year's SIAL trade fair. They jointly set up a Taiwan pavilion at the show, attracting the attention of many large supermarket operators and food distributors.

Chu Ming-tao, director of the Taiwan Trade Center in Paris, said many trade fair visitors expressed interest in a variety of snack and health foods exhibited by Taiwan manufacturers, some of whom secured orders during the show. Chu said traditional foods and drinks can find a new lease on life with innovative packaging and marketing strategies.
Major Taiwan agricultural products featured at the trade fair included butterfly orchids, sea bream, mangoes, pineapples and other fruits.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DROPS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped in September to a seasonally adjusted 4.35 percent, the lowest record since April of 2001, according to statistics released Friday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Without taking the seasonal factors into consideration, September's unemployment rate stood at 4.5 percent, down by 0.17 percentage points from the previous month's level.
The jobless ratio represents some 461,000 unemployed workers last month across the country.
However, the number of workers hired across the country fell to 978,800 last month, a decrease of 48,000 people from the August level, due to summer jobs ending.
The average unemployment rate for the first nine months of this year was 4.52 percent, down 0.56 percentage points year-on-year.

The unemployed had no work for an average of 27.4 weeks, up 1.2 weeks when compared with the figure of a month ago, which saw new job-seekers being unemployed for an average of 25.2 weeks, while others were jobless for an average of 28 weeks.

Liu Pei-cherng, a DGBAS deputy division chief, ascribed fall in the unemployment rate to the country's economic recovery over the past years. He predicted that the jobless rate will continue to fall for the rest of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO EXACT TIMETABLE FOR LIFTING BAN ON U.S. BEEF: HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: Department of Health officials said Friday that there is no timetable for reintroducing the importation of U.S. beef to Taiwan after America was declared an area affected by mad cow disease late last year.

The health department suspended the import of beef and related products from the United States on Dec. 24, 2003, the same day that the United States announced it had discovered a case of mad cow disease.
In late March, the United States applied to Taiwan's health department to have the ban lifted.

Chen Lu-hung, director of the health department's Bureau of Food Sanitation, noted that although there was only a single case of mad cow disease found in the United States, the actual situation in the United States has to be evaluated.
If everything is fine, U.S. beef can again be imported to Taiwan soon, perhaps sometime between late this year or early next year, Chen added.
However, Chen said, if there is any doubt over the quality of the beef, the ban will not be lifted at that time.

According to statistics released by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, testing for mad cow disease from June 1 to Oct. 17 on 85,812 cows came up negative, indicating that there is very little chance that American cows have mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy.
In addition, the U.S. government has adopted stricter slaughtering techniques to prevent possible infection, Chen added.

Chen also stressed that although a Taiwan "mad cow disease advisory committee" has suggested a conditional re-importation of American beef, Chen said it is necessary that a team be formed to check whether the new butchery measures are fully implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-JAPAN TIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday he hopes cultural exchanges and substantive relations between Taiwan and Japan can be further strengthened.

Ma made the remarks while meeting with Hisaoki Kamei, an influential member of the lower house of the Japanese Diet who is heading a large Japanese delegation from his home prefecture of Shimane on a goodwill visit in Taiwan.
Ma told his guest that municipal senior high schools in Taipei have offered second foreign language courses for its students.

"More than 4,000 senior high school students have chosen Japanese as their second foreign language, while the combined number of students who are studying French, German or Spanish is only about 3,000, " Ma said, adding that the figures indicate that Japanese is the most favored second foreign language for young Taipei students.

Ma said he hopes Taiwan-Japanese cultural exchanges can be further expanded and that senior high school students from both countries can be given more opportunities to learn from each other's cultures, languages, customs and lifestyles.

For his part, Kamei, a senior member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, said he founded a pro-Taiwan association in Shimane Prefecture four years ago to promote commercial and cultural exchanges with Taiwan. Several agriculture schools in Shimane Prefecture, which is located along the Sea of Japan in the Chugoku region on Honshu Island, have forged close ties with Hualien Agriculture School in eastern Taiwan, he added.
Kamei assured Ma that he will continue to promote tourist, cultural, educational and commercial exchanges between Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS TAIWAN'S LEADING ENTERPRISES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised Taiwan's leading enterprises Friday for their contributions to the nation's economic development and for helping lead the nation onto the world stage.

Addressing the 2004 Standard-bearer Enterprises Awards ceremony, Chen said that Taiwan's vanguard enterprises have not only developed world-class stature, but have also established a model for the world in such areas as high-technology and the design and manufacture of bicycles.
The president said that these leading companies continue to create new products on their way to the goal of sustainable development for the nation.
The farsightedness, creativity, innovation and customer-oriented philosophies demonstrated by the award-winning enterprises are examples for the government, Chen said.
The enterprises have played a key role in Taiwan's economic development, which is vital to the country, the president affirmed.

Five of the companies at the ceremony have won the award for 10 consecutive years, namely Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, Uni-President Enterprises, China Steel Corp., Citibank and 7-Eleven.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN EQUESTRIAN CHAMPIONSHIP OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2004 East Asian Equestrian Championship opened in Taipei Friday with athletes from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Thailand, Singapore, Australia and host Taiwan participating.
Addressing the opening ceremony, President Chen Shui-bian bid a warm welcome to the foreign participants and encouraged them to help promote the sport in Taiwan and East Asia as well.
Taiwan's equestrians captured one silver medal and one bronze in the 1998 Hiroshima Asian Games, although the sport was not popular then, Chen noted.
The president also thanked the Chinese Taipei Equestrian Association for its recent help in establishing mounted police for the Taipei County Police, the first of its kind in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADERS EXPRESS CONCERN OVER JAPANESE CASUALTIES IN TYPHOON
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Shieh Chen-nan and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Yu Shyi-kun and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen sent a message to the Japanese government Friday, expressing concern over the casualties caused by Typhoon Tokage.

According to officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, in the message that Taiwan leaders sent to Japanese Primer Minister Junichiro Koizumi and Minister of Foreign Affairs Nobutaka Machimura, they expressed the hope that reconstruction can be completed soon and that life can return to normal soon.
According to foreign wire reports, as of Friday, Typhoon Tokage, the strongest in Japan for more than two decades, has caused 69 deaths and damaged many houses and communities in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO WORK FOR THE CREATION OF WORLD-CLASS UNIVERSITIES

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will earmark NT$10 billion (US$296 million) in 2005 to encourage mergers among universities to create world-class universities, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chang Jing-sen said Friday.

Chang made the announcement after Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday that a plan for the creation of world-class universities began when two major universities in Taiwan -- National Chiao Tung University and National Tsinghua University -- entered into discussions on the matter.

Chang noted that it is expected that the resultant university will be listed as one of the top 200 universities in the world, instead of only being in the top 400, with a future goal to be in the top 100.

National Tsinghua University President Hsu Hsia-sen said he appreciates the Cabinet's plan, adding that he is confident that the new university will be listed in the top 100 universities in the world in 10 years considering the schools' excellent academic achievements in the past with so little funding and resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 23, or the 10th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris headed by Gen. Claude Francois de Malet tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsiang, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup that results in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Beijing government Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The Republic of China government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1948: Changchun, a city in Kirin Province, northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Ukrainian-born microbiologist Selman A. Waksman wins the Nobel Prize for physiology or medicine for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against the Soviet occupation.
1957: ROC Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that the islands of Kinmen and Matsu are "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior proclaims today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Nine Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling its troops out of Vietnam.
1973: The ROC suspends diplomatic relations with Upper Volta following Ouagadougou's recognition of Beijing.
1974: Brig. Gen. Abboud Salem Hassan, commander in chief of the Royal Jordanian air force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: The first Chung Cheng Cup Martial Arts Tournament opens at the Taipei Athletic College with Wang Sun-teh, president of the Taipei Martial Arts Association, presiding.
1980: An economic cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei between La Chambre de Commerce of D'Industrie de Marseilles of France and the Far East Trade Service of the ROC.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Muslim suicide bombers blow up the U.S. and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 U.S. marines and French paratroopers.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil, with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out the 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.
1999: Taiwan finishes second with 15 medals at the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.
2000: The 15th Belgium-Republic of China Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Brussels to discuss ways of bolstering economic cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Paraguayan Vice Foreign Minister Rigoberto Gauto Vielman arrives in Taipei at the start of a five-day visit to the Republic of China.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung agrees to call mainland China "the People's Republic of China (PRC) " rather than "communist China."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

Manila Bulletin: Food program starts November
Government will implement its livelihood and food assistance program next month to help poor families mitigate the effects of the worsening economic crisis, the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) said yesterday.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: CIA leaked military corruption -- Pimentel
THE US Central Intelligence Agency may have had a hand in the disclosure to the Philippine media of the corruption case against Maj. Gen. Carlos Garcia, Senator Aquilino Pimentel, Jr. said quoting an informant.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:Private medical insurance 'just as inadequate'.
You may be covered by CPF-approved private insurance instead of MediShield, but a big hospital bill is just as likely to leave a big hole in your wallet.
For months, the offical word is that the Governmentrun MediShield needs an overhaul. Last night, Health Minister Khaw Boon Wan made it clear that private medical insurance schemes are just as inadequate at helping patients with big hospital bills.
IncomShield, the country's largest private medical insurer, now covers too many bills, he said at an NTUC Income Day celebration at Swissotel The Stamford.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Private medical insurance must be adjust completely.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Nation:Judicial tribunal/NCCC work suspended. The National Counter Corruption Commission has suspended operations, including all ongoing graft probes, as a tribunal prepares for a judical inquiry into its commissioners awarding themselves pay hikes in August. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC AID TO NICARUGUA NOT FROZEN: NICARUGUA MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By M.H.Huang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Nicaruguan Minister of Foreign Affairs Norman Caldera said Friday that the Republic of China has not frozen its economic aid to Nicaragua, noting that a proposal raised by some ROC lawmakers to freeze the aid has already been rejected by their colleagues.

The minister made the remarks while responding to media questions after Nicaruguan President Enrique Bolanos said Thursday that Taiwan had decided to freeze its economic aid to the Central American ally.

Admitting that he had made a report to the president after his ministry received a message from an unofficial channel saying that Taiwan had decided to freeze its cooperation plan with Nicaragua, Caldera, however, said that he later on realized that Taiwan did not make such a decision.
The minister also said that if Taiwan freezes its economic aid to Nicaragua, then his country will not receive a donation of US$5 million and other loans from the island next year.

Meanwhile, ROC Ambassador to Nicaragua, Antonio T.S. Tsai also told local media that freezing the aid to Nicaragua was only a proposal made by the Legislative Yuan's Committee for Foreign Affairs, and that the yuan did not adopted the proposal.
The ambassador said that ROC Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco L.Y. Hwang has also confirmed that the proposal was rejected by the legislature.
Tsai also denied any involvement of the Taiwan government in supporting Bolano's presidential campaign.

The Nicaruguan Ministry of Audit requested Oct. 7 that the Nicaruguan Parliament recall Bolanos since he has refused to explain the source of his expenditures during the campaign. According to the investigation of justice agencies, part of Bolano's outlay for his campaign came from Taiwan's entrepreneurs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 34,000 PEOPLE VIE FOR 476 JOBS AT TWO STATE-RUN COMPANIES

TEXT.P: More than 30,000 Taiwan citizens will compete for the 476 job vacancies offered by two state-run companies Sunday, with the success percentage being only 1.37 percent, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday.
MOEA officials noted that Taiwan Power Co. is expected to recruit 410 new employees after Sunday's exam, and Chinese Petroleum Corp. wishes to recruit 66 people this year.
However, a total of 34,635 people have applied for the jobs and they should face two-stage tests to compete for the tiny piece of cake offered by state-run enterprises.
Sunday's initial test will be held in 14 venues around Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung, and the applicants can visit the Web site: www.taipower.com.tw for more information.
The results of the tests will be released in January, 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAFFIC CONTROLS FOR GOVERNMENT LEADERS TRIGGERS WAR OF WORDS

TEXT.P: Stopping traffic so that leaders of the nation can move around the city unimpeded may seem like a routine privilege accorded statesmen, but Taipei's mayor says that the public is unhappy with the situation and he wants Taiwan's leaders to "go to work on time" instead.

Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that if traffic controls for government leaders troubles the public, the practice ought to be reviewed, but she denied reports that she is often late for appointments.

Lu was responding to remarks by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou the previous day that he hopes "the three top leaders will go to work on time every day" so that special traffic controls will not take too much of local beat-cops' time, adding that the controls create traffic jams.
Although the mayor didn't name the three, he clearly meant President Chen Shui-bian, Lu and Premier Yu Shyi-kun.

President Chen's staff said that the president often stays late at his office. He usually eats lunch in his office and has take-out in the evening; therefore, it is incorrect to say that he spends much time commuting, certainly during rush hours. They added that when the president travels outside Taipei, he does not ride in a motorcade so as not to affect local traffic. The staff said that Mayor Ma was "making a fuss out of nothing."
Lu denied allegations by local beat-cops that she was late eight out of 10 times wherever she went, saying that such claims were an "exaggeration," and were only attempts to smear her name.
She said that she understands the extra effort that the beat-cops have to make on occasion, but protecting the head of state and the vice president is the natural duty of a nation's security forces.
Premier Yu, while campaigning in Miaoli in northern Taiwan. responded Saturday by saying that "Ma could learn from President Chen when Chen was Taipei mayor."

Yu said that poor traffic can be attributed to poor implementation of traffic laws, and Ma shouldn't link the traffic situation with other things, adding that while Chen was Taipei mayor, the traffic was very good, and one premier "who later became the vice president" -- meaning Chairman Lien Chan of the opposition Kuomintang, which is Ma's party -- could go home for lunch and take a nap every afternoon.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Legislative Yuan also said Saturday that Ma was trying to "vilify" the president and vice president and the DPP administration before the year-end legislative elections.

Meanwhile, Mayor Ma said Saturday on the sidelines of a stumping trip for an opposition candidate, that it is a fact that special traffic controls sometimes last longer than expected, and the public has to wait patiently.
The mayor said that he is not assigning blame, but wants to "remind those responsible in a good-natured way."

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO GET PNEUMOCOCCUS SHOTS

TEXT.P: The public is urged to get a flu shot as well as a pneumococcus shot since the number of people dying from pneumonia in Taiwan rises every year, doctors advised Saturday.

Doctors noted that free flu shots began early this month, but in addition to flu, pneumonia is also a common health hazard in the autumn and winter, noting that statistics released by the Department of Health showed that pneumonia is the seventh most common cause of death in Taiwan, with 5,099 people succumbing last year. Pneumonia is the fifth-largest killer of the elder over 65, with 4,380 dying last year.

Doctor Huang Li-ming of National Taiwan University Hospital said Saturday that industrialized countries such as the United States, Canada, Australia and Germany have listed the pneumococcus vaccine, along with flu vaccines, as important for the elderly and patients of chronic diseases to have.
Pneumococcus causes 40,000 deaths and 500,000 cases of pneumonia annually in the United States.
He said that pneumococcus vaccines are not needed each year as one dose is good for five years. One shot in Taiwan costs about NT$1,200 (US$35.70).

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT DECLINES TO SUE TAIWANESE FOR LIBEL
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By M.H.Huang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Former Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso Rodriguez has told the Republic of China's envoy to Panama that she has decided not to sue three Taiwanese for libel.

Two members of the ROC's opposition People First Party (PFP) caucus at the Legislative Yuan alleged Tuesday that Moscoso received US$1 million from President Chen Shui-bian as a birthday gift, allegedly as "hush money" to cover the president's unwanted sexual advances.

The former president was furious after receiving a phone call from former Panamanian Minister of Foreign Affairs Harmodio Arias about the allegations and said at the time that she would sue the lawmakers and a talk radio host for ruining her reputation.

But Moscoso on Friday told ROC Ambassador to Panama, David Hu via Arias that she had decided not to sue and will make a declaration of legal oath as proof for anyone who continues to believe the false claims. The declaration will be sent to the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The ambassador said the same day that Arias also told him that after consulting with her lawyer, the former president found that it would be impossible for her to sue the Taiwanese from Panama.
The ROC Embassy to Panama released a statement Thursday, saying that President Chen will sue two PFP lawmakers and the president of a radio station's board of directors for making the allegations.
Hu also said that on behalf of the president and the Taiwan government, he has asked Arias to convey his regret about the groundless allegations to Moscoso.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION OF SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK TO TOP NT$280 BILLION
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Production at the Southern Taiwan Science Park is expected to reach at least NT$280 billion (US$8.24 billion) this year and stands a chance of reaching NT$300 billion, an official said Friday.

Tai Chein, director-general of the Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration, made the forecast while hosting an investment conference in Dallas, which is known as the "Telecommunications Corridor," in the United States.
Tai noted that the science park has set up a telecommunications technology center in Kaohsiung's Luchu, and urged telecommunications companies in Dallas to invest in the science park.
Tai said the optoelectronics sector, which accounts for 62 percent of manufacturers in the science park, is the main industry of the park, followed by the semiconductor sector at 28.3 percent.
While 95 percent of the land in the Tainan compound of the science park has been leased out, only 50 percent of the land in the Kaohsiung compound has been booked, Tai pointed out.

A total of 150 manufacturers have passed the government's screening for investment in the park, and they include a number of well-known businesses such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., United Microelectronics, Chi Mei Optoelectronics, Corning Incorporated, 3M and NEC, Tai said.
He predicted the total production at the science park will top NT$280 billion this year, creating 35,000 job opportunities.
Unless a violent fluctuation occurs in the global economy, the park is likely to see its production jump to NT$1.9 trillion in 2015 and create 180,000 job opportunities, he added.
The delegation led by Tai visited Silicon Valley in San Francisco and San Diego before arrived in Dallas on Thursday.
Prior to the investment conference, the delegation had called on the headquarters of telecommunications giant Nortel Networks in Richardson, Texas.
The delegation is scheduled to go to St. Louis, Missouri on Saturday. It will also participate in a venture investment conference in Vancouver, Canada before returning to Taiwan on Oct. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON U.S.-TAIWAN-CHINA TIES TO BE HELD IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Williamsburg, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The American Association for Chinese Studies is set to hold a symposium on Saturday in Williamsburg, Virginia on the triangular relations between Taiwan, the United States and mainland China.
The 46th annual meeting will take place at the Williamsburg Hospitality House.

ROC deputy representative to the United States Joanne Chang will deliver a keynote speech at the symposium. Other participants will include former American Institute in Taiwan Chairmen David Dean and Natale Bellocchi.

DOC.HEADLINE: CALIFONIA COMPANIES INTERESTED IN INVESTING IN TAINAN SCIENCE PARK
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chi said Friday that during his past four-day visit to San Diego and Silicon Valley he has obtained letters of intent with three hi-tech companies to invest in southern Taiwan.

Su said the three companies are precision medical equipment company Mei-Wave in San Diego, optical company Peat 3D in Silicon Valley and another hi-tech company. The three have promised to invest in the Southern Taiwan Science Park and an environmental protection science park, Su said.
After arriving in Los Angles Friday, Su went to Newport Beach to inspect the docks used by recreational boats for his reference when he gets back home.
In the evening, Su delivered a speech to Taiwanese expatriates at a forum of the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations in Cerritos in the suburb of Los Angles.
Su is expected to leave for Vancouver, Canada Saturday, while the trade delegation he is leading will continue to Texas to solicit business opportunities. Su is expected to return to Taiwan Oct. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Motorists win a truce in parking war with wardens.
Motorists will be freed from the plague of overzealous parking wardens when cash incentives to issue tickets are abolished in new contracts.
Financial Times: Tax blow on equity release.
Tens of thousands of elderly people who have used one of the two types of equity release scheme to sell part of their homes for retirement cash will face annual income tax bills of thousands of pounds from next April.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALENTED TAIWAN PIANIST INVITED TO PERFORM IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in New York will host a concert at Carnegie Hall Oct. 24 to introduce the young pianist who won first prize at the Taiwan International Piano Competition in 2003.

Chang Chiao-ying, 23, graduated from the British Royal Academy of Music and has won many prizes in music contests such as the AZA Dublin International Competition, the Ettlingen International Competition in Germany and the ARD International Music Competition in Munich, Germany.

The Taiwanese girl took her first piano lesson in England at the age of 16 and has remained in the country ever since. She said Friday that living in the U.K. was useful for her career as there are many opportunities for serious pianists and many people to meet and learn from.

The first Taiwan International Piano Competition was presented by the Council for Cultural Affair in 2003 with the goal of offering a stage for Taiwan musicians to present their talent and artistry and to attract outstanding musicians from around the world.
The council offers US$20,000 first prize money and a number of chances for piano concerts in domestic and foreign countries under its sponsorship.

In addition to Chang, Taiwanese violinists Hsin Ming-feng and Chen Che-hong, as well as Taiwanese cellist Shao Hsin-ling, will also perform at the upcoming "Taiwan Elite" concert to be hosted by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD POSITION ITSELF AS 'ARMED, NEUTRAL COUNTRY': SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan should position itself as an "armed, permanently neutral country" in its new constitution, a respected pro-independence scholar suggested Saturday.

Ketagalan Institute President Lee Hung-hsi, who is versed in constitutional studies, made the recommendation at the inaugural ceremony for an aboriginal affairs research class organized by the Ketagalan Institute, which was founded by President Chen Shui-bian to nurture a new generation of leaders in various professional fields.
Lee said Taiwan should cash in on its economic strength and technological power to build up an elite deterrent force to dissuade mainland China from invading the island.
In addition, Lee said he earnestly hopes that Taiwan can soon formulate a new constitution which he said should define Taiwan as a permanently neutral country with an adequate defense capability.
"The best way to spare Taiwan from war is to develop the island in this way," Lee stressed.
Meanwhile, Lee said Taiwan will have to tackle three tough challenges -- incessant natural disasters, industrial upgrading and social schisms -- in the future.

Taiwan must craft a disaster prevention and post-disaster rehabilitation mechanism as the island could face increased natural disasters, such as typhoons and earthquakes, in the years ahead, Lee said.

Moreover, Lee said Taiwan must upgrade its industries from export processing to production of high-end products while simultaneously giving emphasis to environmental protection to ensure sustainable national development. Among others, Lee said, Taiwan should give priority to developing the biotechnology and medical industries.
The third challenge is to promote internal harmony, Lee said, adding that ethnic rifts should be addressed with mutual respect, understanding, patience, love, tolerance and forgiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUES' SHOULD EXCLUDE OPTION OF TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE: SOONG

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PDP) Chairman James Soong on Saturday urged the "pan-blue alliance" to insist that Taiwan independence not be a political option, and not to mix their ideals with those of former President Lee Teng-hui.

Soong made the remarks in response to reports that Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said Friday that if there is time, he would not exclude the possibility of stumping for legislative candidates from the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , which, jointly with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), belongs to the "pan-green camp."
The "pan-blue alliance" is made up of the KMT and PFP.
The TSU considers Lee their spiritual leader because of his advocacy of Taiwanization and Taiwan independence.
Soong stressed that the year-end legislative elections will be a war to defend the Republic of China, reaffirming that he will not support candidates who list Taiwan independence as an option.

Soong also urged "pan-blue alliance" candidates to issue a joint statement to distinguish their ideals from those of Lee, and criticized Lee and the DPP as the ones that caused the ethnic rift on the island.

While expressing regret for the allegations made by PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung against President Chen Shui-bian that Chen had presented a US$1 million check to former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso as a "birthday gift, " Soong noted that the DPP's decision to sue several PFP lawmakers over the issue is only to shift public attention from allegations related to the Presidential Office, in which a former assistant of first lady Wu Shu-jen was said by opposition lawmakers to have abused some privileges.
Soong urged the public to vote for the "pan-blue alliance" to strictly supervise the ruling party.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said he can understand that Wang, being the president of the Legislative Yuan, sometimes is obligated to stump for candidates of other parties, but he believes that Wang has the wisdom to handle the issue well.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO RETRIEVE KMT'S ILL-GOTTEN ASSETS FOR THE NATION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday most of the huge assets possessed by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) today were "robbed" from the people and that the government certainly must have them back.
Yu made the remark while addressing the opening of the campaign headquarters of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative candidates Tu Wen-ching and Chen Chao-ming in Miaoli County.
Yu said the KMT was penniless when it fled to Taiwan from mainland China, but it has gathered assets worth more than NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion) over 50 years by "robbing the people."
The government cannot tolerate this kind of exploitation and will make every effort to retrieve the "booty," Yu said.

The premier urged voters to help the DPP win over half of the seats at the Legislative Yuan to facilitate the implementation of President Chen Shui-bian's policies, pointing out that a lot of the bills raised by the DPP government were blocked by the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party (PFP).

The alliance, meanwhile, was able to push through bills they favor such as the "unconstitutional" special statute on the establishment of a "truth investigation commission" to probe the March 19 shooting of President Chen, Yu said.
He said only by letting the DPP gain control in the legislature will such chaotic situations be brought to an end and foster progress and reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIB INSTALLS TELECONFERENCING SYSTEM TO FIGHT CRIME

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) recently completed the installation of a teleconferencing system, which it says will serve as a mobile command center in the fight against crime.

The system establishes a real-time connection among the 36 police units around the island, and also links with more then 300 government agencies, providing them with key information on events as they unfold.
Thanks to the system, the CIB will be able to better understand security situations and the latest developments in various places, giving them the ability to make adjustments and timely decisions.
CIB agents noted that the system connects police bureaus in various cities and counties, aviation police, harbor police, traffic police and CIB crime centers in central and southern Taiwan.

In addition to upgrading the efficiency of investigations and reducing the time and cost needed for police to travel, it will increase the chances that a crime will be solved. It will also be useful in transferring criminals and in joint efforts to fight cross-border crime, the agents said.

CIB Commissioner Hou You-yi said that the teleconference system would be a powerful tool in fighting against crime, adding that the installation of the system also work in tune with the government's plan to achieve the goal of a digital Taiwan by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRD WGU INTERNATIONAL GATEBALL TOURNAMENT OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The third WGU International Gateball Tournament opened in Kaohsiung Saturday, with 128 teams from 12 countries and regions competing, Kaohsiung City officials said Saturday.
Participating countries include the United States, Brazil, South Korea, Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore, India, Nepal, Pakistan, Taiwan and the Philippines.

Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, World Gateball Union (WGU) director Taka Kono and Huang Chih-huang, vice chairman of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports were on hand to cheer for the players. The mayor said the city government intends to earmark budgets for promoting gateball activities in preparation for the 2009 World Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JOBLESS RATE TO DROP BELOW 4% IN 2005: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government's "Challenge 2008" six-year development plan has started to make headway as Taiwan's unemployment rate is expected to dip below 4 percent next year ahead of schedule, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said Saturday.
Hu was addressing the opening of an exhibition on the "Challenge 2008" program at the National Taiwan University stadium in Taipei.
Hu said Taiwan is facing an unprecedented challenge in the 21st century with the combined impact of globalization, technological innovation and green reforms.

The program was drafted by the government against this backdrop two years ago to realize its visions of building Taiwan into a "green silicon island" to enhance the country's competitiveness, Hu said.
The program has produced some preliminary results after the efforts over the past two years, Hu said.

For example, he said, the country's economic growth will reach 5 percent this year; the unemployment rate will drop to below 4 percent next year; and investment in research and development is expected to account for 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2006.
These goals are being achieved ahead of schedule, according to Hu.
On the plan to assist the development of high-value industries, the production of the semiconductor sector will top NT$1 trillion this year, he said.

More than 3.51 million households have access to broadband networking in Taiwan today, and the island successfully completed the construction of the Hsuehshan Tunnel -- the world's fifth-longest and the longest in Southeast Asia -- on Sept. 16, Hu said.
The free trade zone at Kaohsiung Port will start operations in January next year, after the openings of a similar one at Keelung Port on Sept. 30, Hu said.

In addition, Hu continued, 95 research and development centers have been set up by domestic and foreign corporations in Taiwan, and 200 corporations have set up their operations headquarters on the island.
The exhibition, which showcases Taiwan's technology and lifestyle of the future, is being held in the northern, central and southern parts of the island.

The show in Taipei will run through Nov. 1. It will move to the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung from Nov. 6-15 and then to the National Science and Technology Museum in Kaohsiung from Nov. 20-29.

Items displayed in the exhibition include anti-bacterial cups, baseballs and leather couches developed with nanotechnology, interactive digital TV shows, solar powered generation facilities and a model of a newly developed anti-mudflow dam.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA WILLING TO REVIEW BARTHEL INDEX FOR HIRING FOREIGN CAREGIVERS

TEXT.P: The Barthel index used by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to determine whether a local family can hire a foreign caregiver can be subject to review whenever necessary, a labor affairs official said Saturday.

Tsai Meng-liang, a CLA official in charge of foreign laborers' vocational training, made the remarks at a public hearing on caregiver issues sponsored by Legislator Hsu Yuan-kuo of the opposition People First Party.
The Barthel index assesses the degree of disability in a particular individual.
During the hearing, Chuang An-chi, a representative of employers of foreign caregivers, complained that the existing Barthel index adapted by the CLA is too stringent.

"According to the CLA standards, only those who have an almost completely disabled family member can hire a foreign caregiver. It's a nightmare for prospective employers. For instance, only a terminally-ill cancer patient can apply to hire a foreign caregiver. In many cases, when the applicant finally receives a CLA permit, the patient has already died," Chuang said.

In response, Tsai said, the CLA is willing to review its measurement system whenever necessary. Nevertheless, he added, the ceiling on the total number of foreign laborers to be imported must be maintained. Tsai said the CLA will discuss technical details regarding amendments to foreign caregiver employment regulations.

During the hearing, Legislator Hsu pointed out that the current NT$18,400 minimum wage protection for foreign caregivers tends to encourage them to abscond from their original workplace shortly before their work contracts expire so that they can find another job illegally in Taiwan.

"The minimum wage is usually 10 times the amount a foreign laborer can earn in his or her home country. Against this backdrop, foreign laborers like to run away before their original work contract expire so that they can continue staying in Taiwan to work. I think we should cancel minimum wage protection for foreign laborers, " Hsu said, adding he believes that the stringent regulations for hiring foreign workers are one of reasons for local employers to be willing to employ runaway foreign laborers.

Commenting on Hsu's proposals, Tsai said lowering the minimum wage for foreign workers would affect local people's job opportunities. Under current regulations, he added, a local employer who hires an absconded foreign worker could face a fine ranging between NT$150,000 and NT$700,000.
Taiwan now has more than 300,000 legal foreign workers, most of whom are from Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam, Indonesia and Mongolia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH AND KERRY HAVE SIMILAR CHINA POLICIES BUT DIFFER OVER TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A U.S. administration with John Kerry as president would likely maintain much of the current U.S.-Taiwan policies with a few critical differences, according to a report released Saturday by George Washington University's Elliott School of International Affairs.

The report on the foreign policies of the two U.S. presidential hopefuls said that if President George W. Bush is re-elected, his administration will continue as before, meaning adhering to the "three communiques" with mainland China and the Taiwan Relations Act. The United States would also maintain that force by Beijing is no solution to cross-strait issues and that Taiwan must not do anything unilaterally to change the status quo.

If Kerry is elected, his administration is not expected to change U.S. China policy dramatically, but where Taiwan is concerned, there could be less overt backing of President Chen Shui-bian's government and restrictions could be imposed on the amount and kinds of military hardware and software, as well as assistance that the United States would be willing to offer.
In addition, a Kerry administration is expected to "draw a line in the sand" for Taipei to observe and would more actively promote cross-strait dialogues.
But the report also said that whoever moves into the White House, the United States will not forsake Taiwan.

The report also said that even though the stalemate across the Taiwan Strait has been in effect for many years, a flash point is drawing near and could even erupt during the next president's term. If the United States doesn't want to get involved in a terrible war, even a nuclear one, then its government must have sufficient contingency plans, it concluded.
On trade policy, both candidates attach great importance to the mainland Chinese market, and will likely pressure mainland China to fully open its economy to market forces.

In dealing with trade disputes with China, the Bush administration will adopt a more moderate approach, while Kerry will be more likely to take a harsher stance. Basically, a Bush administration sees opportunities in an expanding Chinese economy, while a Kerry administration would see it as a potential threat. (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu) enitem/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: ITALIAN CYCLIST WINS 2004 NUTRILITE CUP

TEXT.P: Italian cyclist Daniele Nardello won the 2004 Nutrilite Cup Taiwan cycling competition held in the Alishan mountainous area Saturday.

The event began at 7 a.m., with cyclists riding from Chiayi City at an elevation of 50 meters to the top of Ali Mountain at an elevation of 2,174 meters. The total distance traveled was 75 kilometers.
Nardello completed the course in two hours, 24 minutes and 19.24 seconds.

DOC.HEADLINE: REQUIEM MASS FOR MADAME CHIANG'S DEATH ANNIVERSARY HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A requiem mass was held in Taipei Saturday in memory of the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek who passed away at her New York home Oct. 23 a year ago at the age of 106.

Former Premiers Sun Yung-hsuan and Lee Huan and Elizabeth Chiang, granddaughter-in-law of Madame Chiang, attended the requiem organized by the National Women's League of the Republic of China to mark Madame Chiang's death anniversary.

The solemn ceremony, presided over by women's league Chairwoman Cecilia Y. Koo, was proceeded with religious activities including reading the Bible, praying and singing hymns in honor of Madame Chiang, the most famous ROC first lady.

Madame Chiang, whose life traversed three centuries, helped her husband, the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek, rule mainland China and later Taiwan during years of war, upheaval and Cold War tensions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY POPULATION NEARS 300,000 IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: There were 284,000 people 65 or older in Taipei City as of the end of September, with the aging index registering a record high of 60.73 percent, according to statistics from the Taipei City Government released Saturday.
The level is much higher than the average aging index for the entire Taiwan region, which stands at 48.3 percent, the statistics show.
Of these seniors, approximately 6,000 are living alone, and 20,000 are estimated to have some degree of Alzheimer's disease.
To provide better care for these senior citizens, the city government has offered family caregiving services and granted special allowances for old people from low-income families, officials said.

The city government has also set up an emergency help network for old people living alone, and about 2,200 old people in the city have been connected to the system as of the end of September, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR REAFFIRMS GUGGENHEIM BRANCH WILL BE ASSET

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu reaffirmed Saturday that a Guggenheim branch in the central Taiwan city will not be a liability, adding that he won't do anything that will leave large debts for future generations.

Hu was responding to a challenge by Taichung City Councilwoman Lin Pei-le who asked the mayor to vow on the fortune of himself and his family, that a Taichung branch of the Guggenheim Museum won't leave huge debts in the future.

The Taichung City Council is currently reviewing the initial agreement on building the branch signed between the Taichung government and the prestigious museum earlier this month. Most of the members of the reviewing group of the city council and several lawyers taking part in the review said that this is an "unequal" contract for Taichung City.

Lin noted that the Taichung City Government has to pay expenses of up to NT$15.8 billion (US$468.84 million), including construction costs, management bills, funding for collecting artistic works, development costs, subsidies and other miscellaneous fees to establish the branch.

The mayor said categorically that he will never leave behind huge debts for the nation's children, adding that anyone who had read the feasibility study of the Guggenheim branch project will understand that its financial assessment is stated quite clearly, and that it will "bring prosperity to Taichung's service sector."

"If we leave huge debts to our children, do you think the Central Government will support us and subsidize the budgets? " Hu asked, referring to earlier promises in August by President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Yu Shyi-kun to support the project.

Hu said that even before the Guggenheim branch comes to Taichung, it has already brought benefits to the city, meaning that land values have increased sharply, especially the land surrounding the scheduled construction site of the branch.

On question that the agreement is unfair, Hu said that the agreement only stipulates the payment Taichung City has to make, and does not cover the benefits brought with the establishment of the branch.

He urged a "different and a broader perspective" to look at the matter, saying that the fund for artistic collection belongs to the branch and the city, which can hardly be called a debt to the central Taiwan city.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANY KMT MEMBER CAN NOW APPLY TO STUMP FOR PFP CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: An official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday that as long as KMT members apply, they will be allowed to stump for candidates of the People First Party (PFP) , an ally of the KMT, in the year-end elections.

Lin Fong-cheng, KMT secretary-general, made the remarks as he accompanied KMT Chairman Lien Chan on the campaign trail in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan in support of candidates from both the KMT and the PFP.

Lin's remarks were an aboutface from the KMT's earlier stance that only approved of those KMT officials above the level of vice chairmen to stump for PFP candidates, triggering discontent from such KMT stars as Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARENTS URGED TO RESPECT CHILDREN'S RIGHT TO PLAY

TEXT.P: Local parents should respect children's rights to express their opinions and to learn new things through play, a senior official said Saturday.
Huang Pi-hsia, director of the Children's Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior, made the call at the opening of the 2004 International Children's Summit in Taipei.

Huang said local children now enjoy full rights to education, but she said there is still room for improvement in the protection of children's rights to express their opinions and their rights to learn through play.
"I hope parents can give their children more time and space to play and respect their opinions," Huang said.
Eighty child ambassadors from 17 countries are attending the two-day summit with a theme of environmental protection and children's rights.
In addition to discussing environmental potection issues, the child ambassadors will visit the Central Weather Bureau, the Kuantu Nature Park and other tourist attractions during their stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN OPTIMISTIC ABOUT RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday he is optimistic about the resumption of long-stalled dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"I'm convinced that there should be a good chance for resuming cross-strait dialogue next spring. We may be able to turn a new page in the cross-strait history and even to create history, " Chen said while giving a lecture at the Ketagalan Institute.
Noting that kicking-start the deadlocked cross-strait dialogue is an important part to determine his historical status, Chen said he will make every possible effort to realize this goal.

Chen said he believes that the "pan-green" camp of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- will be able to win a majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

"The U.S. presidential election will conclude in November and our legislative elections will be held in December. So long as the 'pan-green' camp manages to win a majority in the upcoming elections, we'll stand a better chance to have Beijing resume cross-strait dialogue. I think 2005 and 2006 are good time for cross-strait engagements. Next spring, in particular, should be an auspicious time for talks. After 2007, Taiwan will enter a presidential election season again when the thorny cross-strait issues may not be high on the agenda of both the ruling and opposition camps," Chen said.

Over the past four years, Chen said, he has extended olive branches to Beijing on more than 30 occasions. "I think nothing is impossible in the development of cross-strait ties in the next three years," he added.

It marked the first time that Chen has taught at a class at the Ketagalan Institute since its inauguration more than a year ago. The institute was founded by Chen to nurture a new generation of leaders in various professional fields.
Students of the institute's "national leadership and development strategy" class came from various social quarters, including lawmakers, media executives, bankers and other professionals.

Students raised 10 questions related to cross-strait relations, constitutional re-engineering, arms procurement, economic and financial reforms, historical status, political reforms and national competitiveness during the closed-door two-hour class. Chen responded to all the questions in detail.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO FORM SPECIAL TASK FORCE TO COPE WITH KYOTO PROTOCOL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will form a supraministerial task force to work out strategies for coping with the possible impact of the Kyoto Protocol which will take effect in three months, a senior official said Saturday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that with Russia's parliament ratifying the Kyoto Protocol Friday, the 126-nation U.N. pact, aimed at battling global warming through curbing greenhouse gas emissions, will come into force 90 days later.

The implementation of the treaty is expected to affect greenhouse gas emission standards in many industries, including semiconductors, flat-panels, household electric appliances, automobiles, petrochemicals, steel mills and cement, Hu said.

Although Taiwan is not a Kyoto Protocol signatory, Hu said, Taiwan will certainly face pressure from the treaty's signatories because the country ranks 22nd in the global greenhouse gas emission rating.

The CEPD already held a meeting Friday to discuss relevant issues, Hu said, adding that he has urged the Cabinet to form a supraministerial task force to draw up a comprehensive package of measures to cope with all possible impacts.
Nevertheless, Hu said optimistically that the impact to Taiwan should be not as great as in the past now that Taiwan has shifted its focus on the service industry development.

"The service sector now accounts for 67.8 percent of our gross domestic product (GDP). When the ratio reaches 71 percent in the next few years, our greenhouse gas emissions will further drop, " Hu said, adding that the government has been endeavoring to develop eco-friendly and energy-saving high-technologies and turn Taiwan into a "green silicon island."

DOC.HEADLINE: APPLY FOR 'NATURAL PERSON CERTIFICATE' SOON, MOF URGES

TEXT.P: Local citizens are welcome to apply for "Natural Person Certificate" (NPC) soon, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Saturday.
NPC applications before the end of this year are free of charge, the official said, adding that starting next year, applicants will have to pay NT$275 each.
The official said the ministry will award the 500,000th NPC applicant with a full set of personal computer, including terminal, monitor, laser printer and NPC card reading machine.

The Natural Personal Certificate is an electronic identity IC card on the Internet. The certificate is a protocol of the electronic signature and electronic code between the smart card holder and the government.

Noting that the certificate is an infrastructure service for the promotion of e-government to upgrade administrative efficiency and strengthen services for ordinary citizens, the official said more than 280 public services can now be provided through the Internet with the NPC card. The number of such services will break the 1,000 mark in three years, he said.
The MOI began to accept NPC card applications April 30, 2003, and more than 490,000 cards have been issued so far. The number is growing by 1,000 pieces a day, the official said.
With a view to encouraging local people to apply for the NPC cards, the official said, the ministry will award a personal computer plus all necessary accessories to the 500,000th applicant.
"The application procedures have been simplified. Prospective applicants can apply with the household registration offices near their homes," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGNITUDE-4.1 EARTHQUAKE JOLTS NORTHEASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A magnitude-4.1 earthquake jolted northern Taiwan at 10:04 p.m. Saturday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said. No damage or injuries were immediately reported.
The moderate earthquake was centered 6.6 kilometers southeast of Taipei at a depth of 8.8 kilometers, CWB seismologists said.
The quake was felt in the greater Taipei area and the northeastern county of Ilan.

The earthquake came a few hours after several powerful quakes rattled northwestern Japan over a span of two hours starting 5: 56 p.m. But CWB seismologists said they didn't think that the Taipei tremor had anything to do with the temblors in Japan.
Earthquakes frequently hit Taiwan, but most were minor and cause little or no damage. However, a magnitude-7.6 earthquake in central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999 killed more than 2,300 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB ISSUES SEA WARNING ON TYPHOON NOCK-TEN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning against medium-size Typhoon Nock-Ten Saturday evening.
The bureau cautioned people on the island for possible heavy rains in the next few days.
The bureau urged ships operating in the Bashi Channel and waters southeast of Taiwan to beware of strong winds brought by the medium-size storm.

The typhoon was centered some 960 kilometers east-southeast of Taitung in southeastern Taiwan at 8: 30 p.m., moving west-northwesterly toward the island at a speed of 28 kilometers per hour, meteorologists said.
With a radius of 250 kilometers, Nock-Ten was packing center winds of up to 155 kilometers per hour, they said.
The CWB said it will continue to closely monitor the movement of the typhoon to decide whether to issue a land warning on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: No Evidence Found of Pre-Election Plot
Officials say they have been unable to detect signs of an ongoing plot to attack the U.S. before the Nov. 2 elections.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Oct. 24:

11: 10, Vice President Annette Lu will receive participants to an international seminar on international negotiations and conflict resolutions at the Presidential Office.
