DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 24, or the 11th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first U.S. transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1901: Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to raise money to help pay her mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an US$80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: New Zealand aviator Jean Batten breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by U.S. planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the puppet government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: French fashion designer Christian Dior dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia, with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: Mainland China's Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bed by armed guards Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea after flying it from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: American television preacher Jim Bakker is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.
1990: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes a partial revision of the Corporate Law.
1999: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The Asian Wheelchair Sports Federation is formally established, with Lai Fu-huan, deputy chairman of the ROC's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, elected as its chairman.
2000: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun issues a statement expressing regret that three of his former colleagues in the ROC Navy have been impeached by the Control Yuan for their connection with an arms purchase scandal 10 years ago.
2001: The Kaohsiung city government holds a ground-breaking ceremony attended by President Chen Shui-bian for the southern Taiwan city's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system.
2001: The 2001 Taipei Nuclear Insurance Pools Forum opens for a three-day discussion with 31 representatives from 21 national nuclear insurance pools around the world participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character. He would prefer to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB ISSUES LAND WARNING AGAINST TYPHOON NOCK-TEN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning Sunday morning for Typhoon Nock-Ten, several hours after the bureau issued a sea warning.
Nock-Ten is the 24th typhoon reported in the Pacific Ocean this year.

As Typhoon Nock-Ten had slowed its pace to 19 kilometers per hour as of 11 a.m. Sunday as it moved directly toward Taiwan, the weather bureau warned that the sphere of Nock-Ten's influence on the island has increased.

CWB forecasters expanded their warning against Nock-Ten from Taitung and Hualien in eastern Taiwan, and Orchid Island, Green Island, and the Pingtung Peninsula in southeastern Taiwan, to Ilan and Keelung in the northeast, Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu in the north, and Nantou in central Taiwan.

The CWB meteorologists also warned that ships operating in the Bashi Channel and waters southeast, northeast and north of Taiwan, as well as in the Taiwan Strait should be on alert against strong winds and high waves triggered by Typhoon Nock-Ten.

Expecting Nock-Ten to dump tremendous amounts of rainfall on Taiwan over the following couple of days regardless of whether or not it hits the island directly, the weather bureau also expanded its warning against flash floods, landslides and storm surges from eastern and southeastern Taiwan to the north, northeast, northwest and central parts of the island.
Precipitation in mountainous areas in north and northeastern Taiwan is expected to exceed 1,000 millimeters a day over the following several days, the forecasters warned.
Typhoon Nock-Ten was centered some 520 kilometers east-southeast of Taiwan at 11 a.m. Sunday, moving west-northwesterly toward the island at a speed of 19 kilometers per hour, the forecasters said.
With a radius of 250 kilometers, Nock-Ten was packing center winds of up to 155 kilometers per hour, they said.

The weather bureau warned people in Taiwan not to take any autumn typhoon lightly because the arrival of such typhoons coincides with the northeast monsoon season, a combination which can cause torrential rains, that in turn can trigger torrents and landslides.

Typhoon Nok-Ten comes on the heels of Typhoon Tokage, another "autumn typhoon, " which pounded Japan Wednesday and caused heavy damage and the highest death toll of any typhoon to hit the country in the last two decades.
Meanwhile, the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center activated its operations against Tyhpoon Nock-Ten at 10 a.m. Sunday, with Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan presiding.
Some 2,000 tourists on Orchid Island and Green Island were forced to cut short their leisure trips in the areas and returned to Taiwan proper Sunday morning and afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCES OF TAIPEI BEING STRUCK BY MAJOR QUAKE SLIM: SEISMOLOGIST

TEXT.P: The chances of Taipei being hit by a major earthquake with a magnitude of 5.5 or greater are slim, given that fracture zones under the Taipei basin are relatively much smaller and shorter than most faults found elsewhere in Taiwan, a leading seismologist with the Central Weather Bureau said Sunday.

Hsin Tsai-chin, a deputy director of the CWB, said that although there are many faults in the greater Taipei area, they are small and short, with lengths ranging from three kilometers to five kilometers, and are unable to accumulate too much tectonic momentum for major earthquakes to occur.

Quoting CWB tallies on earthquake history in the Taiwan area, Hsin said that the Taipei basin experiences an average of 12 earthquakes per month, although most of these are imperceptible except to seismological monitoring instruments.

This figure is relatively much smaller than those recorded in other areas around Taiwan. For example, Hsin said, Hualien in eastern Taiwan experiences about 400 earthquakes per month, although most of them are also imperceptible.

Only two earthquakes larger than magnitude 3.0 with their epicenter located in the Taipei basin were recorded over the past 10 years -- one with a magnitude of 3.76, which occurred in 1992, and another of magnitude 3.7 in 1997, Hsin added.

Nevertheless, he pointed out, the Taipei area could be hit by major earthquakes that are centered in other areas in Taiwan, much like the magnitude 7.3 earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, which was the deadliest in five decades in Taiwan, killing 2,415 people and injuring more than 10,000 others.
The 921 earthquake sent a tectonic shock north to Taipei, where the intensity was registered as 4.0, one of the strongest in hundreds of years.
The epicenter of the 921 earthquake was in the Chelungpu Fault, which has a length of over 80 kilometers, Hsin said.

According to CWB archives on seismological activity, the Taipei basin gradually settled after a magnitude 5.5 temblor occurred in April 1694 during the Kanghsi period of the Ching dynasty. Immediately after that quake, a lake was created in the heart of Taipei, with sea water pouring into the area from an opening in today's Tamshui River.
Hsin made the remarks in response to concerns expressed by Taipei residents after a magnitude 4.1 earthquake jolted northern Taiwan at 10:04 p.m. Saturday.
That quake, centered 6.6 kilometers southeast of Taipei at a depth of 8.8 kilometers, had an intensity of 3.0 in Taipei City, but caused no damage or injuries anywhere, CWB seismologists reported.

The jolt came a few hours after several powerful quakes rattled northwestern Japan over a span of two hours starting at 5: 56 p.m. Saturday. CWB seismologists said that the Taipei temblor had nothing to do with the earthquakes in Japan.
A magnitude 7.0 earthquake occurred off Taiwan's eastern coast Oct. 15, marking the strongest temblor to shake Taiwan since Sept. 21, 1999, the CWB seismologists said.

The quake, centered about 110 kilometers off the coast from Ilan City at a depth of 59 kilometers beneath the surface of the sea, was also the third strongest "undersea" earthquake since Taiwan began to keeping firefighting records in the early 20th century. No major damage was reported, and only two people were slightly injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEEFING UP DEFENSES SHOULD COME BEFORE CONSTITUTIONAL CHANGES: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should build up its self-defense capability before amending its Constitution, John J. Tkacik, an Chinese affairs expert at the Heritage Foundation said here Saturday.

Delivering a speech to the Friends of Taiwan in Monterey Park, a suburban residential city of Los Angeles County, Tkacik said the Republic of China Constitution was formulated in 1947 on the Chinese mainland and doesn't fit today's Taiwan.

However, any amendment to the Constitution would inevitably invoke Beijing's anger, even though President Chen Shui-bian has pledged that the country's official name, definition of its territory, and national flag would be left intact.

In order to stand up against Beijing's bullying, Tkacik pointed out, Taiwan should beef up its defense capability, which he said means that Taipei should not miss the opportunity to purchase the US$18.23 billion worth of arms being offered by Washington.

Tkacik said Washington will contact the European Union in November to try to dissuade it from lifting its ban on arms sales to mainland China which would give Beijing more access to advanced military technology.

Noting that he believes that only the people of Taiwan have the right to determine the future of Taiwan, Tkacik pointed out that he is concerned about Taiwan's self-defense capability, which he said is important in terms of deterring Beijing from launching an attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU PROMISES TO USE KMT'S 'ILL-GOTTEN' ASSETS TO PROVIDE FREE TEXTBOOKS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Sunday that the assets "illegally" accumulated by the Kuomintang (KMT) during its five decades in power will be used to provide free textbooks for elementary and junior high school students once the assets are recovered by the current government.

Stumping for Democratic Progressive Party legislative candidates in Panchiao, Taipei County, the premier said that the government is working to recover the assets and that the assets will be used toward helping the cash-strapped central and local governments.

The premier promised that elementary and junior high school students will get free textbooks for one year, providing his government can recover NT$3 billion (US$88.8 million) worth of KMT's "ill-gotten" assets, and free text books for one hundred years, if it can recover NT$300 billion (US$8.88 billion) worth of assets.
With the approach of the December legislative elections, the DPP has been focusing in its campaign on the issue of the KMT's "ill-gotten" assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL DO ITS UTMOST TO RESUME CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will do its utmost to resume talks with Beijing in the next year, a lawmaker from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Sunday.

Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, the whip of DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, said next year would be a favorable time for a resumption in talks between Taipei and Beijing as there are no national elections scheduled in Taiwan and as this December's legislative elections will usher in a new era in Taiwan, adding that President Chen Shui-bian has continuously reached out to Beijing.

He noted that Taiwan has already done its part to try to restart cross-strait dialogue, which he said would benefit the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait, adding that the ball is now in Beijing's court.

Tsai made the remarks in line with a statement by President Chen Shui-bian the previous day that he has a free hand in terms of negotiating with Beijing as he does not face any pressure to be re-elected for a third term.

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. SOLICITS WORLD SUPPORT TO FACILITATE CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Sunday solicited the support of nations around the world in Taiwan's efforts to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.

Noting that Beijing has been working toward becoming a hegemonic power in the region, Lu appealed to governments across the globe to recognize and appreciate Taiwan's determination in maintaining and upholding peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Lu said that in light of Beijing's ambitions, the so-called Taiwan issue is not an issue between two nations, but instead a regional issue that requires regional efforts to tackle successfully.

The vice president made the remarks during an audience at the Presidential Office with a group of foreign academics and opinion leaders who are in Taipei to take part in the Workshop on International Negotiations and Conflict Resolution sponsored by National Chengchi University.

Lu's guests included Jacob Bercovitch, dean of the Institute of Mass Communications Studies of the University of Canterbury, New Zealand; Norbert Ropers, director of Sri Lanka Department of the Berghof Foundation for Conflict Studies; and Quansheng Zhao, a director with the Institute of International Affairs, American University of the United States.
The vice president said that the people of Taiwan have for a long time been ingenious in preventing an outbreak of war in the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan is one of the very few countries in the world that has continued to survive under persistent and long-term political and military threats from a neighboring country plus diplomatic isolation in the international community, Lu said.
The world may have recognized Taiwan's economic miracle and its political democratization, but the "miracle of peace" that Taiwan has achieved needs greater recognition, Lu added.

She said that the last thing that the Beijing leadership wanted to see was the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and herself, despite the fact that she and President Chen extended olive branches to Beijing on at least 30 occasions between 2000 and 2004.

Lu noted that in his Oct. 10 National Day speech, President Chen suggested that the two sides of the strait build a mutual trust military mechanism, enter an era of cross-strait peace negotiations, and conduct arms control talks. His words were aimed at facilitating a resumption in the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue, Lu noted.

She stressed that in the era of globalization, the concepts of cross-strait reunification and Taiwan independence are both "outdated, " saying that Taiwan does not belong to China. "Taiwan belongs to the world," she asserted.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Sunday that next year is the best time for Taiwan and mainland China to resume cross-strait talks as there are no national elections scheduled in Taiwan and as this December's legislative elections on the island will create a new situation across the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan will do its utmost in this regard, and if Beijing continues to refuse to return to the negotiating table, it will have to bear full responsibility for the results, said Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, a DPP party whip.
President Chen said Saturday while giving a lecture at the Ketagalan Institute that he is optimistic about a resumption in the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.
"I'm convinced that there is a good opportunity for resuming cross-strait dialogue next spring," Chen said, adding that "we might be able to turn a new page in cross-strait history."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PROGRESS IN TAIWAN-U.S. FTA TALKS LIKELY IN SHORT TERM: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Regardless of who wins the upcoming U.S. presidential election, bilateral Taiwan-U. S. talks on signing a free trade agreement (FTA) won't see much progress in the short term, according to a Taiwan analyst.

Wang Chun-jieh, a researcher at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, made the comments in the latest issue of a weekly magazine on the international situation run by the Cabinet -level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

According to Wang, regardless of whether President George W. Bush is re-elected or Democratic presidential nominee Sen. John Kerry wins the presidential poll, there won't be any new breakthroughs in the Taiwan-U.S. FTA talks in the near term.
However, Wang added that if Bush wins, the two countries will be more likely to re-open the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) talks based on the existing model.

The Taiwan-U.S. TIFA talks have been suspended for more than a year due to what the United States has called a lackluster performance on Taiwan's part in resolving key matters related to foreign rice market access, telecommunications services, pharmaceutical pricing, and intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.
Wang also contended that economic exchanges between the two countries are expected to become closer and more frequent if Bush wins a second term.

According to the CEPD, the American Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan has suggested to the U.S. administration that it resume the TIFA talks with Taiwan in late November and remove Taiwan from its "301 priority watch list" on the grounds that Taiwan has made noticeable progress in IPR protection.

However, Wang pointed out that the hope of Taiwan and the United States concluding FTA negotiations in the short term is slim due to the sharp differences that exist between the two sides regarding Taiwan's market access for foreign rice.

If Kerry is elected, he is very likely to resort to the "super 301" in dealing with Taiwan to settle bilateral trade disputes, leaving no room for fresh progress in bilateral FTA and TIFA talks, Wang claimed, adding that Taiwan-U.S. trade ties will become more tense with Kerry in the White House.

Despite the fact that Bush and Kerry remain widely divided on the diplomatic, economic and environmental protection fronts, it is worth noting that both men have said they will stick to the "one China" policy, Wang noted.
Although some prominent figures in Taiwan have pushed for the United States to review its "one China" policy, the efforts will undoubtedly be in vain, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-FRANCE NANOTECHNOLOGY SEMINAR TO OPEN MONDAY IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-France symposium on nanotechnology devices will open Monday at National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan, organizers said Sunday.

The symposium is being jointly sponsored by the National Nano Device Laboratories, the National Applied Research Laboratories, the National Science Council, the Atomic Energy Commission of France, and the French Institute in Taipei.

The purpose of the symposium is to provide an open forum for discussion on recent developments regarding nanotechnology devices, materials and processes, and to encourage more close cooperation between Taiwan and foreign countries, especially in the areas of advanced nanotechnologies and related applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HOLD SEMINARS ON DOHA ROUND TO HELP TAIWAN BUSINESSES

TEXT.P: Starting from this week, the government will hold a series of seminars to help local businesses to gain a detailed understanding of the latest developments in the World Trade Organization (WTO) Doha Round Talks, according to a government official.

The official from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the MOEA will jointly host the seminars across the country, beginning in Taipei Tuesday, followed by seminars in central Taichung and southern Kaohsiung through the middle of November.

The aim of the seminars is to provide Taiwan-based companies with the world's latest trade information and to help them grab business and investment opportunities after all the WTO member states reached agreement upon the so-called "July Package" -- a key segment of the Doha Round Talks -- Aug. 1 in Geneva, the official said.

The July Package sets a set of rules on a wide range of issues related to further liberalization of the agriculture, industrial and service sectors and promotes trade facilitation, which he said will have a profound impact on the future development of Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-AIT CHIEF SUGGESTS FIVE-YEAR TAIPEI-BEIJING PEACE AGREEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Williamsburg, Virginia, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: David Dean, a former chief of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) suggested Sunday that Taiwan enter into a five-year agreement with mainland China wherein Taiwan promises to forsake the idea of independence while China promises not to attack Taiwan.

Dean, who served as the Washington-based AIT chairman between 1979 and 1986, told the 46th annual conference of the American Association for Chinese Studies in Williamsburg, Virginia, that Taiwan could ask the United States to broker such an agreement.
Dean suggested five years as this is a relatively short period of time and therefore more likely to be accepted by Taiwan and China.

Such an agreement would benefit all the parties involved, Dean noted, saying it would allow China to concentrate on hosting the 2008 Olympic Games, allow Taiwan the time to mend fences with the United States, and allow the United States to focus its attention on Iraq.

Pointing to a line from Washington that its ties with mainland China are better now than at anytime in the last thirty years, Dean said that U.S.-Taiwan ties are in a bit of an "unhealthy" state at present because the U.S. administration feels that Taiwan hasn't given enough thought to Washington's need to concentrate its efforts in wrestling with the issue of Iraq.

Such an accord might only represent a small step toward settling the dispute between China and Taiwan, but it's better than no step at all, Dean said, adding that much would still remain to be done even if the agreement were concluded.
Admitting that his idea is at the preliminary stage, Dean said the question of what Taiwan forsaking its independence would mean still needs to be worked out.
He added that brokering such an agreement wouldn't contradict Washington's longstanding policy of facilitating but not mediating any talks between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ORGANIZE TRADE MISSION TO VISIT LATIN AMERICA: VP LU

TEXT.P: The government is planning to organize a large-scale trade mission to visit Latin America early next year, Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the Latin Plaza-Expo 2004, an exhibition of handicrafts and products from Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Latin America, Lu said that the executive branch is making preparations for the mission.
During the ceremony, Lu played the marimba together with Costa Rican Ambassador in Taipei Oscar Alvarez, symbolizing the close cooperation and friendship between Taiwan and Latin American nations.
Lu is scheduled to visit Central America again next spring and to attend the Democratic Pacific Union's East Pacific regional forum to be held in Costa Rica.
The exhibition, being held at the Taipei World Trade Center, will run through Oct. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT SET TO ARRIVE MONDAY

TEXT.P: Former South Korea President Kim Young Sam is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Monday for an eight-day visit, an official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Sunday.

Kim and his wife were invited by President Chen Shui-bian to visit Taiwan. Kim is expected to exchange views on issues of mutual concern with Chen, as well as with Foreign Affairs Minister Tang Sun Chen and other government and business leaders, the official said.
Kim, who served as president between 1992 and 1997, visited Taipei in July, 2001 to lay the groundwork for a resumption of direct flight services between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED NOT TO MAKE CONCESSIONS TO CHINA ON TAIWAN ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Williamsburg, Virginia, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Oliver LIn & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The United States should not make concessions to China on the Taiwan issue and should instead take concrete actions to encourage the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume dialogue, a Taiwan official stationed in Washington, D.C., suggested Sunday.

Joanne J.L. Chang, deputy representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the U.S. capital, said at the annual conference of the American Association for Chinese Studies that Beijing will be more reluctant to hold talks with Taiwan when the international community is more concessive toward Beijing.
Washington should be willing to play the role of promoter of cross-strait talks even though it is not willing to be a mediator, Chang said.
Taiwan appreciates the efforts made by the United States in promoting a resumption of the cross-strait talks, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD CRAFT COMPREHENSIVE ARGUMENT ON U.N. BID:VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The government should craft a comprehensive argument to explain Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, and the public should back the government's U.N. bid to allow the international community to hear Taiwan's voice, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao said Sunday.
Kau made the remarks while giving a speech at a seminar held by the Taiwan United Nations Alliance, a civic group advocating U.N. membership for Taiwan.

According to Kau, Taiwan, as an independent and sovereign country with its own government, people and troops, has the right and obligation to enter the United Nations at a time when the world has become a global village.

He urged all the people of Taiwan to support the government's efforts to join the United Nations in order to allow the world to hear Taiwan's voice. "Otherwise, Taiwan will not be able to reach out, and the people of Taiwan will not have their voice heard internationally," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MAJOR CARRIERS FARING WELL DESPITE SOARING OIL PRICES

TEXT.P: Despite soaring world oil prices, Taiwan's two leading airlines have been faring well, with China Airlines (CAL) recently raising its profit forecasts for 2004 and EVA Airways expected to follow suit shortly.

According to a spokesman for CAL, Taiwan' s largest carrier, the airline has raised its gross revenue forecast for 2004 to NT$93.549 billion (US$2.76 billion), with estimated pre-tax profits of NT$4.051 billion and after-tax profits per share of NT$1.35.

The CAL spokesman attributed the carrier's good performance to its upgraded transport capacity thanks to its new fleet and effective damage control by having hedged 80 percent of its fuel oil. In addition, he said that the carrier's improved flight safety record has also helped it save a considerable amount on insurance premiums.

CAL registered total business revenue of NT$70.05 billion for the first three quarters of this year, up by 30.8 percent over the previous year's level. Pre-tax earnings for the January-September period hit NT$3.5 billion, or 11.1 percent higher than the original forecast.

As the fourth quarter is traditionally the peak season for cargo transport, CAL's profits are expected to continue to grow through the end of the year due to a hike in transport fees, the spokesman said.
With a quickened delivery of new all-cargo planes set for January next year, CAL expects its cargo business revenue and profits to increase by 14 percent and 15 percent, respectively, in 2005.

EVA Airways Corp. has forecast gross revenue of NT$76.778 billion for 2004, with pre-tax earnings of NT$3.121 billion, and after-tax profits of NT$2.784 billion, or NT$0.93 per share. EVA Airways has hedged 60 percent of its fuel oil at US$35 per barrel.
Analysts said that Taiwan's second-largest carrier may raise its 2004 business revenue forecast soon.

Meanwhile, the price of oil shot up to an all time high of more than US$55 per barrel Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after mainland China announced that its Q3 economic growth had surpassed its original forecast.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush and Kerry focus campaigns on 11 key states.
U.S. President George Bush and Senator John Kerry move into the last days of the presidential contest in agreement that the race has come down to just 11 states, and have laid out plans for a barrage of visits and television advertisements across this final battleground between now and Nov. 2. Aides said Bush and Mr. Kerry will spend virtually all their time - and most of their remaining advertising budgets - in those states.
Wall Street Journal: Official report about 50 bodies from Iraqi troops are found.
The bodies of about 50 Iraqi soldiers were found on a remote road in eastern Iraq, apparently the victims of an ambush as they were heading home on leave, Iraqi authorities said Sunday. Interior Ministry spokesman Adnan Abdul-Rahman said the victims were believed to have been killed about sundown Saturday on a road about 95 miles east of Baghdad near the Iranian border.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S STOCK MARKET VALUE DROPS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market value dropped to NT$12.99 trillion (US$383.19 billion) at the end of last week, down NT$103.03 billion or 0.79 percent over the week-earlier level, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).
The weighted index -- the benchmark indicator of the domestic bourse -- fell by 46.15 points, or 0.79 percent for the whole week to finish at 5,774.67 on Oct. 22.

Share prices of 18 of the 20 major categories lost grounds with the steel and iron industry, transportation, glass and ceramics, and plastics being the largest losers by giving up more than three percent.
Weathering through a negative market trend, share prices of the financial and insurance industry moved up by 0.72 percent, while the construction surged by 0.26 percent.
The total trading value of listed stocks amounted to NT$305.72 billion during the period between Oct. 18 and Oct. 22.
In the 201 trading days since the beginning of this year, the average daily stock trading value stood at NT$103.039 billion, accumulating to a total of NT$20.966 trillion, the tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 25, or the 12th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: The Erie Canal, which connects the Great Lakes with New York City via the Hudson River, is opened, assuring the future prosperity of the upper Midwest region of the United States.
1825: Austrian composer Johann Strauss the Younger is born. He is best known for his waltzes, such as the ever-popular "The Blue Danube," and for operettas such as "Die Fledermaus."
1881: Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter, sculptor, graphic artist, ceramist, and designer, is born. He became one of the greatest and most versatile 20th-century artists.
1909: Prince Ito Hirobumi, former Japanese premier and resident-general in Korea, is assassinated by a Korean nationalist.
1914: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, marries Soong Ching-ling in Tokyo, Japan.
1928: The Republic of China Nationalist government begins to implement the five-yuan system -- Executive Yuan (the Cabinet), Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan, and Control Yuan.
1936: Leaders from Germany and Italy meet to form the Berlin-Rome Axis, providing mutual assistance and opposition to communism.
1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The Nationalist government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy the city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: ROC government troops win a victory at Kinmen against a communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1976: An eight-member ROC delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians on Kinmen celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated in Taiwan.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
2000: National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i says that the ROC will gradually open its doors wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals.
2001: Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue affirms Pope John Paul II's statement regarding past Catholic "errors" in China.
2001: Government agencies mobilizes over 1,000 military, medical, police and environmental protection personnel in their second joint exercise staged at a Taipei subway station to simulate possible responses against a chemical attack.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "A great man is one who has not lost the child's heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON AFFECTS EX-SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT'S TAIWAN VISIT SCHEDULE

TEXT.P: The schedule of former South Korean President Kim Young Sam's Taiwan visit has been affected by Typhoon Nock-Ten, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.
Kim was originally scheduled to arraive at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, at 11: 30 a.m. on a China Airlines flight.

As Typhoon Nock-Ten battered Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains early Monday, Kim's arrival has been delayed to around 6 p.m., MOFA officials said, adding that the exact arrival time will depend on the weather condition.
Kim's originally scheduled news conference at the Grand Hotel in Taipei at 6:30 p.m. will also be postponed and rescheduled later, the officials said.
As to the dinner to be hosted by Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen in Kim's honor, the officials said it will be scheduled based on Kim's actual arrival time.

Kim and his wife were invited by President Chen Shui-bian to visit Taiwan. Kim is expected to exchange views on issues of mutual concern with President Chen as well as with other government officials and business leaders during his eight-day visit.

Kim, who served as president between 1992 and 1997, visited Taipei in July 2001 to lay the groundwork for a resumption of direct flight services between the two countries. After a 12-year hiatus, the two countries finally agreed to resume direct airlinks last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER ASKS FOR RIGOROUS DISASTER PREVENTION AND RELIEF

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan on Monday inspected the central disaster prevention and relief center in Taipei, asking all local relief centers to carry out disaster prevention works rigorously.

Yeh made the remarks as northern, eastern and northeastern Taiwan were in the grip of Typhoon Nock-Ten, which made landfall between Toucheng and Santiaochiao in Ilan County, northeastern Taiwan, at 10:30 a.m, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The CWB has issued the highest-level torrential rain warning in the four-level rainfall warning system, indicating expected hourly rainfall of 15 millimeters, or over 350 mm in a 24-hour period.

CWB meteorologists urged the public not to take Nock-Ten lightly because the arrival of the autumn typhoon coincides with the rising tides and the northeast monsoon season, a combination which can cause torrential rains and in turn trigger torrents and landslides.
Yeh instructed the center to monitor low-lying areas and areas prone to mudslides. She also urged the public not to take any unnecessary risks while Taiwan is under the typhoon's influence.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou instructed that residents in hazardous areas be evacuated quickly for safety reasons. While inspecting the city's disaster prevention and relief center, Ma warned that the earthquake that jolted some parts of the city over the weekend may have made them more prone to landslides with the onslaught of torrential rains brought by Typhoon Nok-ten.

The Taiwan stock and foreign exchange markets were closed Monday, as were schools and offices in Taipei City and Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County, Keelung, Ilan, Hualien, and Taitung due to the typhoon, the 24th reported in Pacific Ocean this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOPES TO DISCUSS BEEF MARKET REOPENING WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By J.L. Chi and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior official of the U.S. Department of Agriculture said discussions will take place on the resumption of beef exports to Taiwan after Japan recently agreed to resume part of its beef imports from the United States.

According to J.B. Penn, Under Secretary, Farm and Foreign Agricultural Services of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the United States and Japan concluded an agreement Oct. 23 in Tokyo that paves the way for a partial resumption of beef trade between the two countries.
The official also said that the United States will hold bilateral consultations with the Taiwan and South Korean governments on reintroducing U.S. beef imports.

Taiwan, Japan and South Korea decided to ban beef imports and related products from the United States immediately after Washington announced Dec. 24, 2003 that it had discovered a case of mad cow disease.

Japan is the largest importer of U.S. beef, and before it imposed the ban last year, its annual beef imports from the United States amounted to more than US$1.4 billion, or more than 30 percent of total U.S. beef exports.

Asked whether Taiwan will follow Japan to reopen part of its market for U.S beef, a high-ranking official of the Republic of China's Council of Agriculture (COA) said that Taiwan's Department of Health officials are currently holding bilateral consultations with their U.S. counterparts on the matter.

Yeh Ying, deputy director-general of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, who recently visited Washington, D.C., also said that the U.S.-Japan agreement on the resumption of beef trade can be used by Taiwan as a reference, and that the bureau will serve as a watchdog once the island agrees to reintroduce the importation of U.S. beef into its market.

Whether Taiwan will resume its beef imports has become a matter of serious concern for the United States. The U.S. beef market in Taiwan has been replaced by Australian beef since the discovery of mad cow disease in the U.S. last year, and Washington requested in March of this year that Taiwan reopen its market for U.S. beef.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the U.S. Meat Export Federation is optimistic about the resumption of U.S.-Taiwan beef trade, saying that the island will soon reintroduce its importation of beef from the United States.
Spokesman Lynn Heinze recently said that Taiwan will send a group of experts to the United Sates to better understand its new butchery measures and its surveillance system for beef exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN EXTENDS SYMPATHY TO JAPAN OVER TYPHOON, EARTHQUAKES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed concern and sympathy for the people of Japan Monday after the country was hit by a strong typhoon and a series of earthquakes in the past week.
Chen extended his regards on behalf of the Republic of China government and people while meeting with Hisaoki Kamei, an influential member of the lower house of the Japanese Diet.

Typhoon Tokage pounded much of Japan Oct. 20, leaving at least 66 dead and 22 missing; and a magnitude 6.8 earthquake and a series of aftershocks shook the northeastern Japanese prefecture of Niigata over the weekend, resulting in 25 deaths and over 2,200 injuries.
Chen took advantage of his meeting with Kamei to express his condolences to the families who have lost members to the disasters or have had to seek shelter.

Both Taiwan and Japan are located in earthquake-prone areas and face the threat of typhoons, Chen said, adding that he hopes the two countries can cooperate in research on natural disaster prevention and post-disaster reconstruction technologies.
Touching on bilateral relations, Chen said he looks forward to seeing Taiwan tourists enjoy visa-free treatment by Japan starting from next year.
In the face of mainland China's strong attraction of foreign investment, Chen said Taiwan and Japan should sign a free trade agreement as early as possible to prevent a regional trade imbalance.
Chen said he is convinced a Taiwan-Japan free trade agreement would benefit both sides and contribute to free flow of capital, goods and information as well as help regional economic prosperity.
Chen also expressed his gratitude for Kamei's long-term efforts in promoting friendship and substantive relations between Taiwan and Japan.

Kamei, a senior member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, founded a pro-Taiwan association in his home prefecture of Shimane four years ago to promote commercial and cultural exchanges with Taiwan. He is currently heading a large delegation of association members on a goodwill visit to Taiwan.

The Moscow Times: 50,000 Rally for Yushchenko in Kiev.
Tens of thousands of supporters of opposition presidential candidate Viktor Yushchenko rallied in the Ukrainian capital Saturday to demand that the country hold a free and fair presidential election next Sunday.

THE Treasury reacted with fury last night after details of a secret offer by government officials to slash tax on gaming were uncovered by The Times. The GOP holds a 227 to 205 advantage in the House, and the combination of Republican firepower, Democratic miscues and a controversial Republican redistricting plan in Texas virtually assures the continuation of GOP rule, according to independent political analysts, the paper said.

The Nation: Constitution Court pay rise; 'Give money back now.'
Time is running out for Constitution Court judges to try and undo the damage inflicted by their self-awarded pay rise before they face the brunt of the public's scorn, an outspoken senator warned yesterday. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP URGES LAWMAKERS TO FOCUS ON DUTY, NOT ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers must not forsake their obligations in the Legislative Yuan because of the Dec. 11 legislative elections, an anti-nuclear power association said Monday.

Chang Kuo-lung, convener of the Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association (Nuke-4 RIA), and Yeh Po-wen, executive director of the group, made the appeal as they paid a visit to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party headquarters.
The two said that they would visit the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party Tuesday to make sure their legislators don't get sidetracked from reviewing bills because of campaign activities.
They said that according to the regulations on the election and recall of the public functionaries, the official campaign period begins 10 days before the legislative elections on Dec. 11.
However, they lamented that legislators had agreed to recess for a month starting Nov. 10. Recently, most legislators have returned to their constituencies to concentrate on campaigning.
They noted that several committees in the legislature have only one or two legislators left to review the budgets, and that several budgets recently passed the committees without any cuts.

They also said that some articles in the referendum law that was rammed through the legislature late last year were unreasonable, and that both the ruling and the opposition parties agreed that an amendment is needed, but when they sought the signatures of the legislators for the amendment, they found that most of the legislators were not even in the legislature, but had returned to their constituencies.

They said that lawmakers shouldn't violate the law by jumping the gun and campaigning early. Besides, they are duty-bound to sit in the legislature and review bills, instead of just caring about the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV REPORTER DROWNS ON ASSIGNMENT

TEXT.P: A local TV reporter was swept away by floodwaters and drowned while covering Typhoon Nock-Ten in Taipei County Monday morning.
Three others in Taipei County were killed and two are missing. There have been three reported injuries in Taipei City so far.

Ping Chung-cheng of Taiwan Television Enterprise stationed out of Keelung and three other reporters from different news organizations went to the sluice at Yuanshantse that diverts water from the Keelung River to the ocean.

Firefighters said that the reporters' vehicles became stuck in a low-lying area about 200 meters from the Yuanshantse sluice on their return trips and were penned in by rising waters rushing down the mountainside. The water in the area was about a meter deep.

The vehicles and reporters were swept away just before 11: 30 in the morning; however, firefighters managed to save Huang Chun-ming from the China Times, Yang Huei-chi from the United Daily News and Yang Shu-ling, a local cable television station reporter.
Ping, 30, was recovered almost an hour later barely alive. He was rushed to Rueifang Hospital and pronounced dead later despite efforts to revive him.

According to Huang, the reporters had come to the area to cover the story and were preparing to leave when they were told that Premier Shyi-kun would come later and inspect the sluice. Not wishing to miss the story, most reporters stayed on to wait for the premier.
Unbeknownst to them, however, Premier Yu's inspection tour was called off because the severe weather had not abated.
Another reporter, Lee Wen-yao from the Chinese Television System, said that they were the ones that remained because other reporters had to hurry back to their offices to file their stories.

Premier Yu had intended to inspect the diversion of water at Yuanshantse, and he and his entourage even started out for the area by cars, but were forced to turn back because of the vicious winds and rain.

The sluice is still under construction and was first opened to divert Keelung River water to the ocean last mouth after an all-night downpour caused serious flooding in low-lying areas in northern Taiwan.
Premier Yu said he was saddened by the news of the tragic death of the reporter and instructed the Government Information Office to provide all necessary assistance to the man's family.
The Central Weather Bureau said that although the lashing rain and winds had begun to slacken at noon, the public should be alert for any sudden changes in the situation.

Methodologists said that Typhoon Nock-Ten made landfall between Toucheng and Santiaochiao at Ilan at around 10: 30 a.m. and that the eye of the typhoon will slowly pass the greater Taipei area. The rain and winds are expected to intensify and will only ease in the evening.

Land warnings have been lifted for the Henchun Peninsula, Taitung, Kaohsiung and Pintung, they said, adding that the typhoon will leave Taiwan Tuesday morning and that sea warnings will likely be lifted then at noon.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TYPHOON DAMAGE AT HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK

TEXT.P: Taiwan 's key science-based industrial park in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, escaped damage from Typhoon Nock-Ten, officials of the typhoon prevention center of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration said Monday.
They noted that except for leaves and branches, there were no signs of flooding in the park, and the supply of electricity and water remained normal.
However, the officials said they are on alert for the next 24 hours in conjunction with local fire departments and police authorities to deal with possible incidents caused by the typhoon.

The storm has killed four people including a TV reporter, and resulted in the blackout of more than 100,000 households on the island. Air, marine and ground traffic were also affected, with financial markets, schools and governmental offices in mayor cities in northern and northeastern Taiwan being closed.
Nock-Ten was about 90 kilometers north of Taipei Monday afternoon and was moving northeasterly at 23 kilometers per hour, packing sustained winds of 120 kph, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES DISASTER PREVENTION EFFORTS TO ENSURE SAFETY

TEXT.P: Being prepared is key when it comes to natural disasters, President Chen Shui-bian said Monday after inspecting the central disaster prevention and relief center in Taipei.
The president spoke after Typhoon Nock-Ten killed four and left two missing in Taipei County.
Chen said that he has kept in touch with Premier Yu Shyi-kun since the typhoon began to affect Taiwan Sunday night.
He also said he was saddened to learn that a TV reporter died on assignment and another man who was doing alternative military service was swept away on a rescue mission by flood waters.

Nock-Ten, a typical autumn typhoon, brought torrential rains to northern Taiwan, the president said, adding that the public still has to be on guard as the Central Weather Bureau predicted that there is still a chance of torrential rains even if the sphere of influence of the typhoon gradually passes Taiwan.

He pointed to the recent earthquakes and typhoon in Japan that brought heavy casualties as an example of the destructive power of nature, saying that the public must prepare for the worst to ensure a less disaster-prone environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATIONAL MISSIONS ABROAD TO ATTRACT EUROPEAN STUDENTS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two missions commissioned by the Ministry of Education left for Europe late Sunday to recruit European students to study under scholarships in Taiwan.

The two delegations, led by National Chiao Tung University President Chang Chun-yen and National Taiwan University (NTU) Vice President Wu Ching-hsiung, will visit more than 10 prominent universities in Europe.

Chang's group, composed of representatives from nine Taiwan-based universities, including NTU, National Taiwan Normal University, National Central University, National Sun Yat-sen University, Fun Jen Catholic University and Ming Chuan University, will focus on luring technology students by visiting universities in Eastern Europe, such as Kiev, Prague and Warsaw.
Chang said that they hope to court qualified high school graduates from these places to study in Taiwan on scholarships offered by the Taiwan government or the universities.

Wu's group, comprising representatives from the same universities, with focuses on the arts, law and literature, will travel to higher learning institutes in France, Belgium and Holland and visit the Directorate-General for Education and Culture of the European Union based in Brussels to exchange opinions and viewpoints on advanced studies.
The two delegations are slated to return to Taiwan in early November.

In an effort to explore Taiwan's presence in the international community and boost the world's understanding of the country, the government, in conjunction with local universities, are providing better scholarships to lure foreign students to study in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER DENIES REPORT OF MISSING NUCLEAR FUEL RODS

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) denied Monday a media report of missing nuclear fuel rods at its nuclear power plants, calling the story a far cry from the truth.

According to a Taipower spokesman, no fuel rods at its three nuclear power plants are missing as reported by a local daily newspaper, which cited a source as saying that "the U. S. Department of Energy had found that various nuclear fuel rods installed in the reactors at Taiwan's nuclear power plants had gone missing."

The spokesman categorically denied the report and stressed that the three nuclear power plants are constantly under strict scrutiny by the Taiwan and U. S. authorities and the International Atomic Energy Agency, although Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations.
Pointing out that all facilities at the three nuclear power plants are closely inspected by monitors and that key parts are sealed, he said that what the report said is totally impossible.

Uranium and plutonium are the main substances contained in a nuclear fuel rod, which is the source of nuclear energy in a reactor. The two sensitive materials can be extracted from the highly radioactive spent rods for applications in other fields, including making nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVINCIAL GOVERNOR URGES UNITY ON RETROCESSION DAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lin Kuang-hua on Monday urged the ruling and the opposition parties to unite for a better future for the nation, saying that the country cannot afford to have its people divided.
Lin made the remarks as the Taiwan Provincial Government marked the 59th Taiwan Retrocession Day Monday with a party.
Lin invited all living Taiwan governors to attend the party, but only former governor Chang Po-ya was on hand. She and Lin toasted to the prosperity of Taiwan.

The progress of Taiwan can be attributed to the efforts of governors passed and the people, he said, adding that the process might have been flawed, but Taiwan's achievements have won recognition from around the world, and that the sweat of the people was not in vain.

He also went out of his way to plead for the unity of the people, saying that Taiwan cannot afford to be divided, but added elections seem to bring the worst out in candidates and society is pitched into chaos.

Both former Governor Chang and Taiwan Provincial Consultation Council Speaker Yu Ling-ya lamented that the people in Taiwan no longer care about or observe Retrocession Day, saying that it is a day worth remembering.

Taiwan was under the colonial rule of Japan for half a century before it finally returned to the fold of its motherland on Oct. 25, 1945. It used to be a national holiday, but it gradually lost its luster after the streamlining operations of the provincial government began in late 1998.
President Chen Shui-bian, in a congratulatory message to the party, was positive about the contributions Taiwan province has made in the democratic and economic development in Taiwan.
A fireworks display was arranged at the arena in front of the provincial government hall at night to bring the celebrations to a climax.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN OFFICIAL WELCOMES TAIWAN INVESTORS
DOC.DATELINE: India, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Huang Chao-ping and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and India should expand trade and economic cooperation in a variety of fields, including the telecommunications and information technology (IT) industries, an Indian official said Monday.

Umesh Kumar, director of the commerce department of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry of India, further said Taiwan businessmen investing overseas, known in Taiwan as "Taishang, " are welcome to invest in India.

With a population of more than 1 billion, Kumar said, India is the world's second-largest market after mainland China. Moreover, India can serve as a springboard or a midpoint for taishang to tap into the European or Middle Eastern markets.
Given these benefits, Kumar said, taishang should take immediate steps into India. "Otherwise, you'll miss the opportunity," he added.
Kumar, who made the remarks during an interview with a team of reporters from the Central News Agency, visited Taiwan last month and is familiar with Taiwan's economic and technological developments.
He said there is great potential for Taiwan's IT hardware makers to cooperate with India's world-renowned IT software manufacturers.
Beyond the IT industry, Kumar said, India can offer enormous business opportunities in many other fields.

With abundant cheap labor, Kumar went on, India is very competitive in the manufacturing sector and has been selected by major automakers as their automotive and spare parts production bases. Among others, he said, South Korea's Hyundai Motors has selected its Chennai plant in India as the production center for the company's Santro cars, which are to be marketed around the world. Japan's Suzuki Motors has also recently set up a second production facility in India.

Kumar claimed that foreign investors in India, regardless of the lines of business they enter, can begin to turn profits or even earn back all of their paid-in capital, in five or six years. South Korea's Samsung and LG business groups, for instance, began to turn profits six or seven years after they each invested US$1 billion in consumer electronics production in India, he said.

"The Indian market is immense. You can succeed easily so long as you have good products and good services. The market is out there. Whoever is interested is welcome to explore," Kumar said, adding that taishang should not drag their feet debating whether to invest in mainland China or in India.
"Time waits for no man. If you come late, you may lose opportunities. If you don't come, others will come," Kumar said.

For taishang, Kumar said, the mainland may have a competitive edge due to its geographic proximity to Taiwan and the shared language and cultural backgrounds. However, he went on, India is a democratic country with more comprehensive legal and accounting systems than those of the mainland.
With its huge population, Kumar said, India has a massive domestic market and can additionally serve as a conduit for taishang wishing to explore the European and Middle Eastern markets.
Kumar said India is now the world's six-largest mobile phone market and that its telecommunications market will continue to grow even faster in the years ahead.
Other promising fields for taishang investment include infrastructure construction, auto parts, food processing, chemical and petrochemical production, Kumar said.
Nevertheless, he expressed reservations regarding the signing of a bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) with Taiwan in the near future.

"The time is not yet ripe for talks about FTA issues, " Kumar said, adding that the time for such talks will be when bilateral trade and investment further increase. Two-way trade between Taiwan and India amounted to US$1.2 billion last year.

As to the signing of a double taxation avoidance agreement, Kumar said the two countries need not sign such an accord because Taiwan investors will automatically be exempt from Indian taxes under current Indian laws and regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER EXTENDS SYMPATHY OVER DROWNING OF TV REPORTER, DRAFTEE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun extended sympathy to the families of a TV reporter and a draftee on alternative military service who drowned due to flooding triggered by typhoon Nock-Ten, Executive Yuan officials said Monday.

Ping Chung-cheng of Taiwan Television Enterprise was swept away on his way to report on a water diversion at the Yuanshantse sluice, used to channel water from the Keelung river to the sea. Ping was rescued and rushed to hospital, but efforts to resuscitate him proved fruitless.
Chen Chih-hsiang, a draftee on alternative military service at a fire department in Taipei County, was also killed by floodwaters while taking part in a relief mission.
Yu said he will ensure that assistance is provided for the families of the victims and he called on reporters and draftees to beware of danger while on reporting assignments or relief operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Huge cache of explosives vanished from site in Iraq.
The Iraqi interim government has warned the United States and international nuclear inspectors that nearly 380 tons of powerful conventional explosives - used to demolish buildings, make missile warheads and detonate nuclear weapons - are missing from one of Iraq's most sensitive former military installation. The huge facility, called Al Qaqaa, was supposed to be under American military control but is now a no man's land, still picked over by looters as recently as Sunday. United Nations weapons inspectors had monitored the explosives for many years, but White House and Pentagon officials acknowledge that the explosives vanished sometime after the American-led invasion last year.
Wall Street Journal: Conflicting data mixed job picture offers ammunition for both candidates.
The two presidential candidates are applying various data of the state of the economy in their campaign. After consideration hesitation hesitation, the economy began to produ ce more jobs about a year ago, as President Bush points out at every opportunity. But many of those jobs don't pay as much or offer as much security, a point Democratic challenger John Kerry makes just as often.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN MANILA INAUGURATES WEB SITE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in the Philippines inaugurated a Web site Monday to offer Chinese and English information services for the overseas Chinese community, Taiwanese expatriates and Philippine citizens intending to visit Taiwan.

Wu Hsin-hsing, the ROC representative to the Philippines, said the inauguration of the Web site signifies the representative office's determination to use modern technology to provide better services for Taiwan expatriates and forge closer friendship with Philippine people.

The Web site at www.taiwanoffice.org.ph will introduce Taiwan's latest national developments, social customs, consular affairs, work visa regulations and economic and cultural cooperation agreements with the Philippines, as well as Taiwan's tourist attractions.

"We hope the Web site will help keep Taiwan expatriates abreast with the domestic situation and help the Philippine people better understand Taiwan's present situation, legal system and consular regulations," Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HOLDS SEMINAR IN U.S. ON PROJECT TO SEND STUDENTS OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) convened a two-day seminar on the nurturing of "world-class elites" in San Francisco Monday to pave way for a project to send more than 2,000 students overseas to study over the next three years.

CEPD Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said that more than 130 Chinese American scholars were invited to attend the seminar in the hope that with them as intermediaries, Taiwan can establish cooperation relations with prestigious schools in the United States and that if the U.S. experience proves successful, the model can be expanded to Britain and Germany.

Hu noted that the government attaches great importance to the short-, middle- and long-term needs for talent in the nation and said that the "elite going overseas" project mapped out by the CEPD is now finalized.

He said that from 2005, the council will choose at least 370 students who will be offered the opportunity to study overseas, including 120 students with masters or doctoral degrees, and 250 students who will be provided with low-interest student loans.

In addition, the Ministry of Education and the National Science Council will also select students, Hu said. In 2005, it is expected that 974 students will be sent overseas, with more than 2,000 over a three-year period, he added.
He said the details of the project will be unveiled in late October and that the study will cover such areas as the high-tech industry, finance and cultural creativity.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L SEMINAR ON LEGITIMACY OF NEW CONSTITUTION TO BE HELD

TEXT.P: An international seminar on the legitimacy of writing a new constitution for Taiwan will be held in Taipei next month, organizers said Monday.
The seminar, scheduled for Nov. 27-28, will be organized by Taiwan Advocates, a pro-independence think tank headed by former President Lee Teng-hui.

According to a spokesman for the think tank, scores of noted academics from the United States, Japan, Germany and France will attend the seminar to speak on experiences in constitutional amendments and constitutional formulation in their own countries.

Lee will take part in the seminar and will exchange views with the foreign scholars on Taiwan's plan to write a new constitution that fits the nation's status quo and the prevailing thinking in the 21st Century, the spokesman said.
Noting that the existing Constitution was written in mainland China in the late 1940s, the spokesman said it is outdated and fails to address Taiwan's current needs and challenges.

"The Taiwan Advocates wants to play a locomotive role in formulating a new constitution, `rectifying' Taiwan's national title and developing Taiwan into a normal and complete new country, " the spokesman said, adding that the seminar will be critical in the think tank's attempts to realize these goals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TELCORDIA TO SET UP RESEARCH CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Telcordia Technologies Inc., a New Jersey-based hi-tech firm, signed a cooperation accord Monday with the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) to set up a research and development center in Taiwan.
ITRI officials said that the Telcordia Applied Research Center in Taiwan (TARC-TW) will focus on the research and development of open network service platform (ONSP).

Telcordia has developed a rich history as an agent of change in the telecommunications industry, the officials said, adding that its research has led to ADSL, ATM, Frame Relay, SONET, AIN, ISDN and many other industry breakthroughs.
The TARC-TW will help improve the research ability of Taiwan's telecommunications industry, they claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT VISITS TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former South Korean President Kim Young Sam left Seoul Monday for an eight-day visit to Taipei.

Kim and his wife originally planned to board a China Airlines flight for Taipei that morning but were forced to delay the trip until the afternoon because of typhoon Nock-Ten, which brought gusty winds and torrential rain to Taiwan.

Kim said before his departure that his trip is designed to show support for the resumption of Taipei-Seoul air links in September after a hiatus of 12 years since the two nations severed diplomatic relations.
Kim said that when he visited Taiwan three years ago, he promised President Chen Shui-bian that he would come back to convey his congratulations if the air links were resumed.
Kim, who served as president between 1992 and 1997, visited Taipei in July 2001 to lay the groundwork for a resumption of direct flight services between the two countries.
Touching on cross-Taiwan Strait issues, Kim said the two sides should resolve their differences in a peaceful way through dialogue.

On the prospects for Taiwan-South Korea relations, Kim noted the close and ever-expanding trade cooperation between the two sides and said he plans to exchange views with President Chen on the continuation of bilateral friendly ties.

During his stay, Kim will also meet with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, the heads of various political parties and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.
He will also exchange views with business leaders on strengthening bilateral trade and cooperation and will give a speech at National Chengchi University before returning to Seoul Nov. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: 94 PERCENT OF CENTRAL TAIWAN PEOPLE SATISFIED WITH EPA EFFORTS

TEXT.P: A vast majority of the people in central Taiwan are satisfied with the efforts made by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) in handling pollution cases in their nearby environments, a spokesman for the administration said Monday.

According to the spokesman, as much as 94 percent of the poll respondents were satisfied with the results of the cases dealt with by the EPA through a computerized round-the-clock telephone line service covering nine cities and counties, from Miaoli County in northern Taiwan to Chiayi County in the south, as well as offshore Kinmen County.

During the first nine months of this year, the public service center received a total of 1,562 complaints, including 612 regarding air pollution and 344 noise pollution complaints -- the top two categories -- said an EPA inspection chief in charge of operations in central Taiwan.

Residents in Taichung County filed 416 complaints, followed by Taichung City residents with 406. Neighboring Changhua and Miaoli counties had 334 and 141 cases, respectively, ahead of Nantou County with 99 cases, Yunlin County with 89 cases, Chiayi County with 69 cases and Chiayi City with 35 cases. Kinmen County reported 11 cases, he said.

Of the more than 1,500 complaints, 293 were regarded as serious cases, 236 of which had been investigated, with the respondents expressing satisfaction about 223, marking a 94 percent approval rate, he noted, adding that the figures indicate that air quality and life environments are the top concerns for people living in urban areas nowadays.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN GIVES DIRECTIVES ON APEC CONFERENCES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday Taiwan should present innovative initiatives at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's annual conferences to win international support and respect.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with members of the Taiwan delegation to attend the 2004 ministerial conferences and informal leadership meeting scheduled to take place in the Chilean capital of of Santiago in November.

Noting that Taiwan faces a difficult international situation due to Beijing's ubiquitous diplomatic suppression and the world society's reluctance to offend Beijing, Chen said Taiwan should actively take part in APEC activities with dignity and parity.

"We should also come up with forward-looking initiatives to boost regional development and signify the value of Taiwan's separate existence, " Chen said, adding that Taiwan must win international friendship and respect with vision and insightful overtures.
APEC is one of the few international cooperation forum that simultaneously admits Taiwan and mainland China.
Chen said the upcoming APEC conferences will discuss for the first time the feasibility of forming an Asia-Pacific free trade agreement (FTAAP).
"We should express our support for the formation of an Asia-Pacific free trade bloc and compe up with concrete proposals for its materialization," Chen said.

Moreover, Chen said, the delegation should continue to solicit other member economies' support for Taiwan's proposals to boost regional cooperation in health care, vian flu prevention and avian flu vaccines production.

As human security will be one of the main themes to be discussed at this year's APEC conferences, Chen said, the Taiwan delegation should express Taiwan's desire to play an active role in cultivating safe living environment and its past contributions in this regard.

Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Finance Minister Lin Chuan and many other officials were also present at the meeting.

After receiving a formal invitation from Chilean President Ricardo Lagos Escobar to attend the Nov. 20-21 APEC informal leadership meeting, President Chen has decided to name Lee Yuan-tseh, the head of Taiwan's most prestigious research body, Academia Sinica, to represent him at the gathering. Lagos asked APEC Secretariat Executive Director Mario Artaza to extend the invitation to Chen in Taipei Sept. 21. Beacuse of Beijing's opposition, Taiwan's president has been unable to attend the annual APEC summit in person and has to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

During a meeting in Taipei last Friday with Milenko E. Skoknic, chief executive of the organizing committee of the APEC Chile 2004 activities, Chen said he would like to attend the annual APEC summit in person but that he has instead named a Nobel laureate to attend on his behalf to spare the host country any unnecessary trouble.

APEC groups 21 Asia-Pacific economies -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.
