DOC.HEADLINE: MAWEI PORT AGREES TO LANDING VISA TREATMENT IN LINKS WITH MATSU

TEXT.P: After years of lengthy negotiations, the Mawei Port Zone authorities in mainland China's Fujian Province have finally agreed to grant landing visa treatment for visitors from Taiwan's Matsu Island in bilateral direct transport links, Lienchiang County Magistrate Chen Hsueh-sheng said Monday.

The practice, scheduled to be put in place from Jan. 1, 2005 by both sides, will boost the existing direct trade and transport links maintained between Matsu and Mawei and between Taiwan's Kinmen Island and Fujian's Xiamen Port since Jan. 1, 2001 -- popularly known as the "mini three links" -- Chen said.

Kinmen and Xiamen have granted landing visa treatment for visitors from either side since the inception of the mini links, but such a measure has been absent in bilateral links between Matsu and Mawei due to financial difficulties and lax facilities on the part of Mawei, despite repeated appeals from Matsu.

According to Chen, the much larger number of passengers traveling between Kinmen and Xiamen heightens the urgent need for Matsu and Mawei to implement the same visa practice, and the Mawei Port Zone authorities eventually agreed to do so after a recent visit he made to discuss the issue with Mawei officials.
Chen also suggested that the Mawei Port Zone authorities pay attention to the service attitude of customs agents and called for an improvement in baggage check facilities.

For the time being, the Fuzhou city government and the Mawei Port Zone authorities have decided to split spending on building and expanding the facilities needed to allow the landing visa procedure to operate smoothly by the beginning of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Former South Korean President Kim Young Sam arrived in Taipei Monday at the head of a 23-member delegation for an eight-day visit.
Shortly after their arrival, Kim and his delegation attended a dinner party hosted by Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen in their honor.

Kim and his delegation, who were originally scheduled to arrive in Taiwan earlier in the day, were forced to delay their trip due to typhoon Nock-Ten, which brought gusty winds and torrential rain to the country.
President Chen Shui-bian will receive Kim and his delegation and host a dinner party for them at the Presidential Office Tuesday, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

During their stay, Kim and his delegation will also meet with Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, business leaders and scholars, ministry officials said.
They will also tour various economic and cultural establishments before departing Nov. 1, the officials added.

Prior to his departure from Seoul, Kim said that his trip is designed to show support for the resumption of Taipei-Seoul air links in September after a hiatus of 12 years since the two nations severed diplomatic relations.
Kim said that when he visited Taiwan three years ago, he promised President Chen that he would come back to convey his congratulations if the air links were resumed.
Kim, who served as president between 1992 and 1997, visited Taipei in July 2001 to lay the groundwork for a resumption of direct flight services between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORLD'S 15TH-LARGEST EXPORTER: WTO
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the world's 15th-largest exporter, with exports that amounted to US$150.3 billion in 2003, according to the latest statistics compiled by the World Trade Organization.
The tallies show that Taiwan's exports enjoyed an 11 percent growth last year and accounted for 2 percent of the world's total outbound shipments.
Meanwhile, imports totaled US$127.4 billion, up 14 percent year-on-year and ranking the country as the world's 16th-largest importer.
The world's commodity trade amounted to US$7.3 trillion in 2003, a real annual growth of 4.5 percent, the statistics show.

Germany is the world's largest exporter, with outbound shipments worth US$748.3 billion registered in 2003, while the United States is the world's top importer, with inbound shipments worth US$1.303 trillion.
The WTO predicted that world trade will post an annual growth of 8.5 percent this year, despite recent sharp oil price hikes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 26, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1879: Leon Trotsky, Russian communist leader who, along with Lenin, organized the October Revolution, is born. He was forced into exile by Stalin, sentenced to death in a Soviet court, and murdered in Mexico, where he had found asylum.
1919: Francois Mitterand, French president from 1981, and founder of the French Socialist Party, is born.
1931: Japan turns down a proposal of the Council of the League of Nations which adopted a resolution on Oct. 24 urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Chinese troops begin a withdrawal from Shanghai to the northern Soochow River after Japanese troops capture Tachang. Shanghai would be captured by the Japanese Nov. 11.
1942: The aircraft carrier USS Hornet is sunk after being attacked by Japanese aircraft in the Solomon Islands Battle.
1944: After three days, the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines ends with victory for the United States. Over 30 ships are sunk in the great sea battle, most of them Japanese, including the Japanese navy's last four aircraft carriers.
1954: Britain and the United States end their occupation of Trieste and return control of the area to Italy.
1951: Winston Churchill is appointed British prime minister for a second time.
1955: The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed under Ngo Dinh Diem.
1961: Outer Mongolia is admitted into the United Nations.
1964: The Republic of China opens a consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
1964: The Republic of China and Panama sign a trade agreement in Panama City.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Belgium as the latter establishes ties with mainland China.
1971: The Republic of China withdraws from the United Nations.
1973: President Richard Nixon prepares for the possible launching of World War III after hearing that the Russians are sending arms to the Middle East as war rages there.
1973: David M. Kennedy, the U.S. ambassador-at-large, arrives in Taipei for a three-day private visit.
1975: The First Taiwan Area Games opens in Kaohsiung with 4,980 athletes participating.
1979: Park Chung Hee, president of South Korea, is slain by Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean intelligence agency.
1989: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes near Taiwan's Siulin Village in Hualien County on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing 54 people on board.
1993: The ROC and Mexico sign a pact to promote bilateral investment and technology transfers.
1994: Israel and Jordan sign a peace treaty in a ceremony at their mutual border attended by U.S. President Bill Clinton, ending 46 years of hostilities.
1995: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized in Moscow after an apparent heart attack, his second in four months.
1999: Nankang Software Park, the largest software manufacturing park in Asia, is opened by President Lee Teng-hui in suburban Taipei.
2000: Former Commander in Chief of the ROC Navy Adm. Yeh Chang-tung claims that he has been falsely accused in an impeachment brought against him by the Control Yuan.
2000: Morris Chang, chairman and chief executive officer of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., urges the government to open up to the mainland Chinese market or face the stifling of Taiwan's industry.
2001: A passenger ship sails from a harbor other than Liaolo directly to mainland China, marking a breakthrough in the "mini three links" implemented by the Republic of China government at the start of 2001 on a trial basis.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sages are of the same species as ourselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. GUARANTEES CROSS-STRAIT POLICY REMAINS UNCHANGED: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top envoy to the United States said Monday that a high-ranking U.S. State Department official gave him a guarantee the same day that Washington's cross-Taiwan Strait policy remains unchanged.

David Lee, Taiwan's representative to the United States, said while responding to questions raised by the Central News Agency that the U.S. official also reiterated that the United States' longstanding position is to support a peaceful resolution to cross-strait differences through dialogue between Taipei and Beijing.

Lee said that he immediately contacted the State Department for clarification after Secretary of State Colin Powell made some remarks regarding Taiwan and its relations with mainland China in an interview with the Hong Kong-based Phoenix TV Group during his Oct. 25 visit to Beijing.
In the interview, Powell said that "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation, " and that "the two sides should move forward to a peaceful unification through dialogue."

Noting that a high-ranking State Department official guaranteed that the United States' cross-strait policy remains unchanged, the envoy said that the official also told him that the United States has consistently supported a peaceful resolution to cross-strait differences through dialogue.
Meanwhile, State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli also made it clear at a daily briefing the same day that the United States has not changed its cross-strait policy.
"One element of our policy has been to favor a peaceful resolution of the cross-strait issue through dialogue and through a resolution that is acceptable to both sides," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:Violent rioting in S. Thailand.
Dozens of people have been injured in clashes between Thai security forces and hundreds of protesters who tried to storm a police station in Muslim southern Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWELL'S REMARKS 'HARSHEST TO DATE' SAYS ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday that U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks on Taiwan the previous day "are the harshest by the United States to date."

Chen made the comments while fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan about Powell's remarks during an interview with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV in which he reaffirmed the U.S. "one China" policy and said that "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation."
Chen said that Taiwan is a sovereign and independent state -- before and after it was forced to quit the United Nations in 1971 -- which "is a fact that cannot be denied."

The foreign minister said that Powell had briefed the Taiwan mission in Washington, D.C., prior to his departure on the three-nation tour in Asia last weekend, but that he had not gone into details about what he would say while in mainland China.
Republic of China Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee will seek a clarification of the matter and then make a report to the Foreign Affairs Ministry as soon as possible, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY PROTESTS AGAINST POWELL'S REMARKS ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Tuesday protested strongly against U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks on Taiwan the previous day.

Powell, currently on a three-nation tour in Asia, reaffirmed the U.S. "one China" policy, saying that "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation, and that remains our policy, our firm policy " during an interview with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV Monday prior to his departure from Beijing for Seoul.
Stressing that Taiwan is in fact an independent and sovereign state, the DPP legislative caucus protested strongly against Powell's "ignorance of the facts."

Lee Chun-yi, DPP whip in the Legislative Yuan, said he regrets and condemns Powell's remarks, noting that President Chen Shui-bian stated clearly in his Double Ten National Day speech that "the sovereignty of the Republic of China is vested with the 23 million people on Taiwan. The Republic of China is Taiwan, and Taiwan is the Republic of China."

But he also said that there is no sign of change in U.S. policy toward the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, which is not to encourage the People's Republic of China to solve the Taiwan issue by force, and not to encourage Taiwan to unilaterally change the status quo.
DPP Legislator Tsai Huang-liang echoed Lee's words, and asked: "If Taiwan isn't a sovereign state, then what is it?"
Tsai said that the DPP legislative caucus could not accept Powell's remarks which he described as "ignorant of the facts."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REAFFIRMS NO CHANGE IN NATIONAL POLICY

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office reaffirmed Tuesday that there has been no change in national policy after U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell said in Beijing a day earlier that "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation."

James Huang, deputy secretary-general to the president, said the government's policy toward relations across the Taiwan Strait and the nation's future development will continue to follow the principles outlined in President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration speech and Oct. 10 National Day address.
"Our stance remains unchanged, " Huang said. He declined to go into further details.

Meanwhile, Huang said U.S. State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli has made clarifications of Powell's remarks in an interview with the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV during his Oct. 25 visit to Beijing.
Ereli made it clear at a daily briefing the same day that the United States has not changed its cross-strait policy.

"One element of our policy has been to favor a peaceful resolution of the cross-strait issue through dialogue and through a resolution that is acceptable to both sides," Ereli said, adding that Powell's remarks should be interpreted in terms of the context of the interview.
Huang said that since Ereli has made a clarification, it is not necessary to engage in too much speculation.

President Chen proposed in his National Day address that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait use the basis of the 1992 meeting in Hong Kong to seek possible ways that are "not necessarily perfect, but acceptable" in preparation for a step forward in the resumption of the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue and consultations.

Referring to himself by his nickname 'A-bian, ' Chen further said that as any conflict would cause irreparable damage to both sides, Taiwan and mainland China should seriously consider practical steps toward "arms control."
"Therefore A-bian proposes that both sides should seriously consider the issue of arms control and take concrete actions to reduce tension and military threats across the Taiwan Strait."
Quoting Chen's National Day speech, Huang said Taiwan has consistently pursue cross-strait peace and stability. "We hope the two sides can shelve disputes and sit down to talks."

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON NOCK-TEN CAUSES NT$169 MILLION IN AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: Typhoon Nock-Ten, which pounded northern and northeastern Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains Monday, has caused NT$169 million in agricultural losses, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said Tuesday.

According to COA tallies, 1,802 hectares of farmland was affected by Nock-Ten, the 24th typhoon reported in the Pacific Ocean so far this year. The hardest-hit crops included rice, leafy vegetables, papayas, citruses, guavas and other in-season fruits.
COA officials said most of the agricultural losses were in the farming sector, while losses in the fishery, poultry and forestry sectors were comparatively minimal.
With the lifting of the typhoon warning, the COA officials said, vegetable supplies in the greater Taipei area have returned to normal.
As the main vegetable production areas in central and southern Taiwan were not hit by the typhoon, the officials said, urban consumers do not need to make panic purchases.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York times: U.S. action bars right of some captired in Iraq
A new legal opinion by the Bush administration has concluded for the first time that some non-Iraqi prisoners captured by American forces in Iraq are not entitled to the protections of the Geneva Conventions, administration officials said Monday. The opinion reached in recent months, establishes an important exception to public assertions by the Bush administration since March 2003 that the Geneva Conventions applied comprehensively to prisoners taken in the conflict in Iraq, the officials said.
Wall Street Journal: Bush focuses on weathering wave of bad news
U.S. President Bush is getting hit by a wave of bad news -- including further setbacks in Iraq and slumping financial markets -- just a week before a dead-heat election. Bush's ability to ride out the gloomy headlines hinges on a strategy that has served him for months --keeping the campaign on terrorism while trying to under mine public confidence in Democratic challenger John Kerry's ability to protect the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT POLICY REMAINS UNCHANGED: STATE DEPARTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. State Department press officer reiterated Monday that the U.S. cross-Taiwan Strait policy remains unchanged and that cross-strait differences must be resolved peacefully and in a way that is acceptable to both sides.

Adam Ereli, deputy spokesman of the State Department, made the comments at a daily press briefing in response to reporters' questions related to Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks on cross-strait issues during visit to Beijing a day earlier.

In an interview conducted with the Hong Kong-based Phoenix TV , Powell said: "There is only one China. Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation, and that remains our policy, our firm policy."

"Both sides should show restraint, not take any unilateral actions, look for ways of improving dialogue across the strait and move forward toward that day when we will see a peaceful unification, " Powell also said, adding that " we want to see both sides not take unilateral action that would prejudice an eventual outcome, a reunification that all parties are seeking."

Asked whether Powell's remarks represent a change in U.S. cross-strait policy, Ereli said that the secretary was very clear that the United States remains firmly committed to its "one-China" policy based on the three communiques and to its responsibilities under the Taiwan Relations Act.

The secretary also made it clear that Washington opposes any unilateral actions by either side, that the United States does not support Taiwan independence, and that the way to resolve the issue is through peaceful dialogue, Ereli added.

In response to questions regarding whether Powell's remarks regarding "looking for ways of improving cross-strait dialogue and moving forward toward that day when we will see a peaceful unification" are in contradiction to the longstanding U.S. cross-strait policy, the deputy spokesman said that one should not read into the remarks a hinting or departure from Washington's longstanding position.

Reiterating that the U.S. cross-strait policy has not changed, Ereli said that "one element of our policy has been to favor a peaceful resolution of the cross-strait issue through dialogue and through a resolution that is acceptable to both sides."

"There are a whole wealth of possibilities there. We are not prejudging those possibilities: we are simply emphasizing that it has to be done through dialogue," Ereli said, adding that he thinks that the secretary is very outspoken and very emphatic about encouraging an intensification of that dialogue, and that's where the United States thinks the focus ought to be.

Touching on the question of Taiwan's sovereignty, Ereli said that he does not think that there was any new ground broken on that issue, noting that the words the secretary used accurately reflect Washington's longstanding policy on Taiwan's status. "Frankly, I think we are today where we were yesterday," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMOTING MULTILATERAL TRADE A PRIORITY: ROC'S WTO TRADE OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top trade official in Geneva on Monday strongly supported the European Union's focus on a multilateral trade mechanism and urged all members of the World Trade Organization (WTO) follow suit.

Yen Ching-chang, Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO, also lauded the EU's great attachment to multilateral trade negotiations and the "go slow" approach to the formation of bilateral free trade agreements (FTA).
Yen was speaking at a meeting to review the EU's trade policies.

Taiwan fears being marginalized because of the number of WTO member economies that are seeking to establish FTAs, even though trade experts and WTO officials have said that a collection of FTAs cannot replace a multilateral trade system.
Yen said Taiwan's stance is that WTO members should treat the promotion of multilateral trade talks as a priority.

Since FTAs or Regional Trade Agreements might have an impact on the participation of many WTO members in WTO trade talks, Yen said that the "go slow" approach used by the EU in dealing with its FTA negotiations with other economies and its attachment to multilateral trade talks ought to be emulated.

Pointing out that Taiwan and the EU have the same idea, the representative said that Taiwan believes that multilateral trade liberalization will bring more economic benefits than from regional or bilateral trade liberalization.
Meanwhile, Yen also said that the EU's experience of enlargement might provide other WTO members an opportunity to review whether closer economic integration is the best choice.

While affirming the EU's contributions to the new Doha Round of trade negotiations and to the improvement of a multilateral trade mechanism, the representative also expressed his concern about trade compensation problems that emerged after the EU's May 1 expansion.

Noting that several European countries have raised part of their import tariffs after joining the EU, and that more than 20 countries, including Taiwan, have formally requested that the EU offer compensation through negotiations, Yen said that Taiwan will cooperate with the EU to seek a reasonable settlement of the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICANS OF TAIWANESE, INDIAN ORIGINS PLAN TO FORGE PARTNERSHIP

TEXT.P: Two senior executives of the U.S.-India Institute for Strategic Policy are currently in Taipei to promote cooperation between Taiwanese-Americans and Indian-Americans in an effort to help boost substantive Taiwan-India relations.

Armeane Choksi, chairman of the Washington-based U.S.-India Institute for Strategic Policy, and Manish Thakur, executive director of the institute, arrived in Taipei Monday for a five-day visit at the invitation of the Taiwan Democracy Foundation.

Choksi told the Central News Agency that his institute looks forward to forging cooperative ties with Taiwanese-American groups in the United States with a common goal of helping reinforce Taiwan's defense capability and promoting India's economic development.

Noting that both Taiwan and India are Asian democracies with advanced high-tech industries and have shared values in promoting democracy, freedom, security and prosperity, Choksi said he feels that Taiwanese-Americans and Indian-Americans also have a lot in common in U.S. society.
Choksi said he believes that there should be ample room for the two ethnic groups to cooperate in helping promote Taiwan-India relations as well as boost Taiwan's and India's national interests.
Initially, Choksi said, the institute will follow the formula used in promoting its cooperation with Jewish-American groups in the past.

"The U.S.-India Institute is willing to play an intermediary role in organizing seminars or conferences in various U.S. cities and communities to facilitate opinion exchanges and integration, " Choksi explained.

During the interview, Thakur said that Indian-Israeli relations were not close in the past. But the situation has changed since 1997-98 when Indian-Americans formed cooperative ties with Jewish-Americans who have traditionally held great influence in U.S. society, Thakur said, adding that such a development has been widely viewed as contributing much to the significant progress in India-Israel and India-U.S. relations in recent years.

To the best of his understanding, Thakur said, Taiwanese-Americans have maintained good relations with Jewish-Americans. He acknowledged that engagements between Taiwanese-Americans and Indian-Americans have remained sparse. If the three ethnic groups cooperate closely, Thakur said, they could form a powerful lobbying force in U.S. society.
Academic sources said noted Indian geopolitical scholar Monu Nalapat has helped arrange for the two U.S.-India Institute executives' current Taiwan visit.

During their stay, Choksi and Thakur will meet with Vice President Annette Lu, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau as well as academics from Taiwan Thinktank and the Taiwan Democracy Foundation.

According to unofficial tallies, Americans of Taiwanese, Indian and Israeli origins total more than 10 million, with Israeli descendants accounting for 600 million, Taiwanese descendants about 2.5 million and Indians about two million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market generally moved down Tuesday after the market was moved by a losing trend in international markets, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November plunging 136 points to close at 5,660, with 26,563 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December lost 142 points to finish at 5,656, with 194 contracts traded, as March futures dropped 162 points to close at 5,612, with eight contracts traded, and June futures lost 120 points to close at 5,625 with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,796 for November, 5,798 for December, 5,774 for March, 5,745 for June and 5,883 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

November TE futures moved down 7.45 points to close at 206.4, with 5,854 contracts traded, while December TE futures fell 7.6 points to finish at 206, with 36 contract transactions, and June TE futures plunged 11.6 points to close at 200.15, with two contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures dropped 14 points to end at 1,003.2, with 7,122 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures fell 14.6 points to close at 1,000, with 125 contracts traded.

March TF futures moved down 21 points to close at 986.2, with two contract transactions, while June TF futures lost 20.2 points to end at 980.4 points, with one contract traded, and September TF futures plunged 35.8 points to end at 990 points, with two transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 111.79 points to close at 5,662.88.

The bourse opened at the day's high of 5,715.49 and hit a low of 5,655.98 during the day's trading. A total of 2.67 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$56.17 billion (US$1.66 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 3 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 2.7 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.5 percent, construction issues at 1.4 percent, textile stocks at 0.7 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 634 to 83, with 70 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.103 to close at NT$33.693.
A total of US$673.5 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.705 and fluctuated between NT$33.600 and NT$33.729.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH SIDES OF TAIWAN STRAIT SHOULD SIT DOWN AND TALK: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that Taiwan has always pursued peace across the Taiwan Strait and dialogue is the best way to achieve this.

The premier was responding to U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks the previous day when he reaffirmed the "one China" policy of the United States, saying, "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation, " during an interview with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV prior to his departure from Beijing to Seoul.
Powell also said that President Chen Shui-bian's Double Ten National Day address provides an opportunity for the resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

The premier said that it is a fact that Taiwan is a sovereign state and that it has always sought to pursue cross-strait peace and stability, which was evident in the peace overtures offered by President Chen in his inauguration speeches in 2000 and early this year.

Regarding Powell's remarks that "we want to see both sides [of the Taiwan Strait] not to take unilateral action that would prejudice an eventual outcome, a reunification that all parties are seeking, " the premier said that President Chen has stated clearly in his May 20 inauguration speech early this year that both sides should shelf disputes and sit down to talk.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS SAY POWELL CANNOT DICTATE SOVEREIGNTY ISSUE FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Legislators from across the political spectrum on Tuesday disputed U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks about Taiwan the previous day, stressing that Taiwan is in fact a sovereign state.

They made the remarks after Powell reaffirmed the "one China" policy of the United States, saying, "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation." Powell was speaking during an interview with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV prior to his departure from Beijing to Seoul.

Legislator Chen Chin-jun of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that Taiwan is a sovereign state and its name is the Republic of China, which is an "indisputable fact, " and that Powell has no reason to interfere with the internal affairs of Taiwan.

Chen asked, "If Taiwan is not a sovereign state, why would there even be a Taiwan Relations Act, and why would it contain the provision that the United States will provide Taiwan with defensive weapons?"

Chen criticized the United States for ingratiating mainland China, saying that it is regrettable that a superpower like the United States has turned a deaf ear to the voices of the 23 million people on Taiwan and trampled the dignity of an ally country.
Another DPP legislator, Lin Cho-shui, said that Powell's remarks were the "most negative from a U.S. administrations on Taiwan's sovereignty issue over the past three decades."

Granted, Lin added, that there are American interests involved what Powell had to say, Taiwan must also shoulder some of the responsibility for the Secretary of State's view. "It is obvious that Taiwan's foreign policy has not earned the trust of the United States," he said.

Lin said both the ruling and opposition camps need to be introspective and forge a consensus on diplomatic issues. The administration should also review its overall foreign policies and form a steadfast and consistent path.

Meanwhile, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that it insists on the " sovereignty" of the Republic of China, adding that it does not condone other countries, regardless of how powerful they might be, that try to dictate the future of Taiwan, since that is a matter that can only be left up to the 23 million people on the island.

The People First Party, an ally of the KMT, said both sides should maintain the status quo and return to a 1992 cross-strait consensus, being that both sides agree on their own version of "one China," for further talks to reach a consensus on peace.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP, said that whether Taiwan is a sovereign state will not be dictated to Taiwan by Powell, but by its 23 million people.
Huang Chung-yuan, TSU whip in the legislature, said that Taiwan has its own people, land and government and that this denotes a sovereign state according to international law.

Pro-independence groups such as the Taiwan Independence Alliance and the Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan said Tuesday that Powell made the remarks because Taiwan's present name is the Republic of China, which they said is not recognized internationally.
They said that the name of the country must be changed to Taiwan so that the words "Republic of China" or the "ROC" can be avoided.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S CITIES WILL STILL BE USED IN NAMING WARSHIPS: DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The practice of using the names of cities in China for the names of Taiwan's warships will remain unchanged, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense said Tuesday.

Huang Suey-sheng made the remark amid criticism by some legislators that warships are traditionally named after places in mainland China, believing that Taiwanization should take precedence over sinicization.

Huang said that under the framework of the Republic of China Constitution, the names of warships are to be taken from the geographical names defined by the Constitution as national land and from national heroes.
The ROC Constitution was promulgated in 1947 when the Republic of China still ruled the mainland.
He said the principle of naming warships will not change and there is no political consideration involved since the defense ministry acts in accordance with the Constitution.
He also noted that the defense ministry has used places in Taiwan for the names of some vessels.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Increase In War Funding Sought; Bush to Request $70 Billion More.
The Bush administration intends to seek about $70 billion in emergency funding for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan early next year, pushing total war costs close to $225 billion since the invasion of Iraq early last year, the paper quoted Pentagon and congressional officials as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Chaos over casinos.
Growing disarray over the reform of gambling laws last night forced ministers to consider a statutory limit on the number of new super-casinos. There was a wave of recriminations across Whitehall at reports that Gordon Brown and John Prescott were leading a Cabinet revolt against the proposals to expand Britain's casino industry.
Financial Times: Clinton back on the Road to bolster Kerry.
Former US president Bill Clinton on Monday emerged from convalescence in an effort to boost Democratic spirits and lift voter turnout in the final week of the election campaign, as John Kerry and President George W. Bush called in political favours to get an edge in a tied race.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RULES OUT HIKES IN TAXES, POWER AND WATER RATES BEFORE FEB. 1

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reiterated Tuesday that there will be no increases in taxes or electricity and water rates before his tenure ends next February.
Yu made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session.

During the session, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chiang Chi-wen said domestic consumer prices have been on an upward swing. Worse still, Chiang said, the Ministry of Finance has on many occasions released information about possible tax hikes and there have also been frequent reports about adjustments of utility rates.
Chiang asked Yu whether he can promise that there will be no increases in taxes or electricity and water rates in the first half of next year.

In response, Yu said, the Cabinet has no plans to adjust any tax rates or electricity and water rates at the moment. He further said that definitely before his term ends Feb. 1, 2005, tax rates and all public utilities rates will remain unchanged.
According to current regulations, the Cabinet has to resign en masse on the inauguration of a new Legislative Yuan. The next legislature will be elected Dec. 11 and inaugurated Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: TELECOMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRY HOPEFUL OF MAKING ITS OWN MARK: MOEA

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's telecommunications industry is expected to hit about NT$432.3 billion (US$12.8 billion) this year, marking an annual growth rate of 21.4 percent, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

In view of the domestic industry's strong performance on the global market, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh has recently said that it possesses the potential to become the third-most profitable technology capable of creating an output value of over NT$1 trillion, in addition to biotechnology and the digital content industry keenly promoted by the government in its flagship "two-trillion, two-star" program.
Of the more than NT$400 billion in production output, the broadband industry and the telecommunications facilities sector will generate some 40.8 percent and 59.2 percent, respectively.

A senior manager at the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) forecast that the telecommunications facilities sector will be able to yield NT$480.9 billion in production this year, up by 11.2 percent over the previous year's level.

It is worth noting that the telecommunications equipment sector is gradually gaining an upper hand over the broadband sector thanks to the widespread penetration of cell phones, which the ITRI manager said will lead to rapid development in the wireless local area network.

The telecommunications service sector is another key focus in the global market, he said, citing information provided by the Garnter Group as predicting that it will account for 80.4 percent of the world's overall telecommunications industry market valued at US$1.414 trillion this year. The ratio is expected to increase to 82.7 percent of the world market scale of US$1.675 trillion in 2008, he added.

He is highly optimistic about Taiwan's chances of becoming a front-runner in the global wireless telecommunication industry, citing Taiwan companies' high self-content percent in making key parts, a comprehensive supply chain and their long-term cooperative ties with the world's top multinationals.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA'S CHIEF ECONOMIC ADVISERS HOPE FURTHER COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New Dehli, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Huang Chao-ping and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Chief economic advisers from two of the largest political parties in India have expressed the hope that Taiwan can pay more attention to the subcontinent and that there will be further exchanges and cooperation between the two countries.

Jairam Ramesh, a parliamentarian and chief economic adviser for the ruling Indian National Congress's (INC) Economic Committee, said that the economic reforms that started in India in the 1990s will remain unchanged despite the power transfer of political parties.

Ramesh was referring to the INC's success in elections earlier this year, in which the INC upset the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) , which had called for an early election because it was confident of its own economic performance.

Jagdish Shettigar, chief economic adviser for the BJP, concurred, saying that it would be impossible for the INC to backtrack after it took the helm of the nation, saying, "India's basic policy, especially its economic policy, will only be adjusted in a minor way; there will be no dramatic changes."
The course of liberalization, reform and opening to foreign investment will continue, Shettigar said.

Ramesh added that privatization of state-owned enterprises will continue, although this will not all be open to foreign investment. Currently, foreigners are not allow to invest in such sectors as the petroleum, natural gas, railway, national defense, space and public health sectors.

On relations between Taiwan and India, Ramesh said they are in good shape although there is still room for further development. Two-way trade between Taiwan and India amounted to US$1.2 billion last year.

He said that India can provide Taiwan more resources, adding that both sides can consider cooperation in the areas of software, information technology, biotechnology, pharmaceuticals and semiconductors. In tourism, there is also room for further growth.
He pointed out that Taiwan has focused too much in mainland China. It is too risky, he said, suggesting that Taiwan ought to diversify its investment.

He stressed that India is populous, and its population is expected to surpass that of mainland China by 2030 or 2035. It also has a great history, and is a democratic country as well as a pluralistic society with 18 languages. It has maintained economic growth of 6 percent over the past 20 years, and that growth is expected to be between 6.5 percent and 7.5 percent in the next few yeas.

He also said that India has 300 universities and 2 million graduates every year, adding that individuals talented in high-technology are India's advantage, although the number of such people needs to rise.
Believing that India has more potential than mainland China in terms of investment, Ramesh said that both countries should further cooperate and engage in exchanges.

Taiwan should take a closer look at the Indian market, Ramesh said, adding that investment is never like instant coffee, and that the key is to have determination and perseverance, adding that South Korean enterprises such as Samsung group and Hyundai Motors have long-term plans and determination in their investments in India.
Ramesh expressed the hope that he would be able to visit Taiwan within six month to enhance bilateral understanding.

Shettigar also welcomed Taiwan businessmen to invest in his country, suggesting that they can buy local companies or bid for major construction projects. The food processing and technical sectors are also worth investing in, he added.
He also encouraged Taiwan businessmen to set up plants in Indian special economic zones, using them as springboards to make inroads into the Middle East, the European Union and Africa.
Shettigar said he is scheduled to travel to Taiwan to attend an international seminar next month to express his views on matters of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE UPGRADING PREREQUISITE TO MAINTAINING STATUS QUO: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Tuesday his claim that upgrading Taiwan's defense capabilities is a prerequisite to maintaining the status quo and a buttress to engaging in dialogue with mainland China on an equal footing.
Chen also stressed that he will continue to promote dialogue across the Taiwan Strait under the principle of safeguarding national sovereignty, dignity and security.

Chen's reaffirmations, which were made during a meeting with senior executives of major Taiwanese associations in the United States and Canada, came after U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell said in Beijing a day earlier that U.S. arms sales to Taiwan are based on the Taiwan Relations Act and that the U.S. government encourages both sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume dialogue.
Chen said national security should never be compromised by partisan political wrangling and that investment in national defense is ultimately aimed at safeguarding permanent peace for posterity.

"We should never let mercurial political partisan strife undermine our defense capabilities and national security, " Chen said, referring to the opposition-controlled legislature's stonewalling of a NT$610.8 billion arms procurement budget bill.

In the face of mainland China's continued military buildup and missile threat, Chen said, Taiwan must beef up its defense arsenal in order to keep its status quo from being changed and to enable it to engage in cross-strait dialogue with dignity and parity.
While endeavoring to upgrade Taiwan's defense capabilities, Chen said, his administration will also spare no efforts to forge rapprochement and mutual trust with the mainland.

"We'll continue to promote cross-strait engagements under the principle of ensuring national sovereignty, dignity and security, " Chen said, adding that his administration looks forward to working with Beijing in crafting a viable mechanism for peaceful and stable cross-strait interaction and guiding cross-strait relations to develop in a "normal, win-win" direction.

Earlier in the day, Chen took advantage of a meeting with visiting Marshall Islands Minister of Foreign Affairs Gerald Zackios to express his gratitude for the Pacific island nation's support for the Republic of China's independent sovereign status.

Marshall Islands President Kessai Note and the nation's ambassador to the United Nations have on many public occasions spoken out for Taiwan's quest for U.N. representation on the grounds that the ROC should enjoy the same rights and status as all other countries around the world, Chen said.
"We are grateful for your country's firm support for our national causes, including joining the United Nations and the World Health Organization," Chen told his guest.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SETS DPP TARGET OF 100 SEATS IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian set a target Tuesday for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to win 100 seats in the year-end legislative elections.

Speaking at the weekly DPP Central Standing Committee meeting in his capacity as party chairman, Chen said that the "pan-green camp" -- formed by the DPP and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- will be able to control a majority of seats in the 225-member legislature if the DPP captures 100 of them in the Dec. 11 elections.

Chen encouraged party members to do their utmost and to set aside personal interests to achieve the party's goal. "Only when the DPP dominates the legislature will the administration be allowed to do its job and push forward Taiwan's reform programs," Chen claimed.
DPP officials said that they are confident of achieving the goal and predicted that the TSU will win at least 20 seats in the elections.

Citing the results of various recent surveys, Chung Jia-ping, a DPP deputy secretary-general, said that 73 of the DPP candidates for the constituent seats, 18 for the legislators-at-large and three for the overseas Chinese seats have been listed as "sure" to win in the elections.
In order to achieving Chen's target, Chung said the DPP must pursue five additional constituent seats and one more overseas Chinese seat.
A total of 387 candidates have registered to vie for 168 constituent and eight aboriginal seats, of which 92 have been recommended by the DPP.

The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has nominated 74 candidates, followed by the People First Party (PFP) with 41, the pro-independence TSU with 30 and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) with 26.
The parties will add additional seats for 41 legislators-at-large and eight overseas Chinese legislators based on proportional representation of the ballots that each party secures in the election.

According to a survey conducted earlier this month by the Chuan Kuo Credibility Polling Company, the DPP is the most popular in the year-end legislative elections with a 24 percent approval rating, followed by the KMT with 14 percent, the PFP with 5.12 percent, the TSU with 2.74 percent and the NPSU with 2.33 percent, while 44.03 percent of the respondents said they were undecided.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OUTLINES NEW PRINCIPLE FOR DETENTION OF MAINLAND ILLEGALS

TEXT.P: Illegal mainland Chinese immigrants will be sent to Taiwan-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu for temporary detention in the future to facilitate repatriation, a senior mainland affairs official said Tuesday. Both Kinmen and Matsu lie closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun made the remarks while delivering a speech at the Tainan City Government in southern Taiwan.

Liu said mainland China has often delayed in taking back illegal mainland immigrants for political reasons. As a result, it usually takes more than 100 days for mainland authorities to send ships to take back seized mainland immigrants, adding up to Taiwan's financial burden and staff workload. In some cases, he said, illegal mainland immigrants have to stay far longer in Taiwan's detention centers. For instance, a group of illegal mainland immigrants seized on March 18 were not repatriated until in late August due to Beijing's reluctance to cooperate.
Liu said the government is constructing a new detention center in Kinmen which will be inaugurated by the end of the year.
There are currently two special detention centers for mainland illegal on the Taiwan proper -- one in Hsichu and the other in Ilan. There is also a similar detention in Matsu.
"Once the Kinmen detention center is completed, it will accommodate all illegal mainland immigrants seized in the Taiwan proper," Liu said.

In his speech, Liu also said the government has no timetable to lift the ban on local civil servants from making sightseeing trips to mainland China. According to Liu, the ban is not expected to be lifted anytime soon.
At the moment, civil servants can travel to the mainland for family reunions, visiting ailing relatives or attending meetings with prior government approval.
Liu also said that presently, an average of 1,000 to 2,000 mainland Chinese citizens make pleasure trips to Taiwan via a third area per month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN TO FORGE COOPERATION LINKS BETWEEN SCIENCE PARKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Science-based Industrial Park Administration under the National Science Council recently reached consensus with Kitakyushu City officials on proposed sisterhood links between the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and the Japanese city's Science and Research Park, NSC officials said Tuesday.

NSC Chairman Chi Kuo-chung visited the Kitakyushu Science and Research Park a few days ago, where, in addition to touring the advanced park's various facilities for scientific and industrial research, he also called on park administrators, as well as representatives of a number of local universities that are in collaboration with the park, the officials said.

Chi's visit also focused on the promotion of cooperation and exchanges between the two science-based parks, they noted, indicating that an official agreement for the proposed relations will be sealed in the near future.

Taiwan is seeking to learn more about high-tech manufacturing and has therefore been making efforts to borrow knowledge and experience from other countries, one of which efforts involves seeking exchanges and cooperation with foreign science and research facilities, they noted.
The Hsinchu park has so far signed sisterhood accords and protocols of cooperation with 15 science parks or institutions in eight countries, according to the NSC.

Japan is one of the major trade partners of the Hsinchu facility, with its exports of high-tech equipment and raw materials to the park from January to September this year reaching NT$99 billion (US$2.97 billion) in value, according to park administration statistics.

The amount accounted for 36 percent of the park's total imports, making Japan the largest exporter to the park. During the same period, the park exported NT$45.3 billion-worth of products to Japan, a figure that accounts for 12 percent of its total exports and makes Japan the third-largest customer of the park, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT ENGAGED IN DOLLAR DIPLOMACY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan will never engage in dollar diplomacy against mainland China, and the financial aid provided to other countries is for humanitarian purposes rather than being bargaining chips to win diplomatic recognition, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday.

Chen, who also serves as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , made the remarks after hearing a report by Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao in a weekly meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee.

Claiming that Taiwan's economic assistance to friendly countries is by no means a cash-backed offensive to seek diplomatic ties in the face of Beijing's diplomatic blockage of Taiwan, Chen said it is the country's right and obligation to give back to the international community for the help that it received from the United States and other countries in the past.

In the future, Taiwan will stick to this ideal and will do its utmost to play a constructive role in international society by helping friendly countries in need through proper and adequate channels, he said.

To avoid speculation, misunderstanding or corruption, the government will further increase its transparency and strengthen and consolidate related mechanisms and sources of such outbound humanitarian operations, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWELL'S REMARKS ABOUT TAIWAN `CONTRADICTORY': OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's recent remarks on Taiwan were "contradictory" and made Taiwan "feel very uncomfortable, " a senior government official familiar with U.S. affairs said Tuesday.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, was commenting on Powell's statements during an interview Monday in Beijing with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV that the United States will continue to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan in line with the Taiwan Relations Act while claiming that "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation."

"If Taiwan is not an independent sovereign state, as Powell claims, how can the United States sell weapons to Taiwan? Isn't the United States encroaching upon China's sovereignty by selling defensive arms to Taiwan?" the official asked.

While Taiwan can understand the nature of "big power diplomacy, " the official said, Powell's comments were "too straightforward and too harsh. His comments made us very uncomfortable, particularly as he made the comments in Beijing."

Even though the United States diplomatically recognizes China and terminated diplomatic ties with Taiwan in 1979, the official said such facts cannot justify Powell's claim that Taiwan is not an independent sovereign state.

For instance, he said, the United States cut diplomatic ties with Cuba after Fidel Castro took power in 1959. The absence of formal ties with the United States does not invalidate Cuba's independent sovereignty, he pointed out.

Noting that Powell's defining Taiwan's status quo as "not independent, not enjoying the sovereignty as a nation" is extremely dissatisfying, the official said Taiwan must carefully review whether its relations with the United States has undergone grave changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES FROM TYPHOON SURGES TO NEARLY NT$300 MILLION

TEXT.P: The agricultural losses resulting from Typhoon Nock-Ten, which pounded northern and northeastern Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains Monday, have surged to NT$300 million, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said Tuesday.

According to COA tallies, 2,895 hectares of farmland was affected by Nock-Ten, the 24th typhoon reported in the Pacific Ocean so far this year. The hardest-hit crops included rice, leafy vegetables, papayas, citruses, guavas and other in-season fruits.
COA officials said most of the agricultural losses were in the farming sector, while losses in the fishery, poultry and forestry sectors were comparatively minimal.
With the lifting of the typhoon warning, the COA officials said, vegetable supplies in the greater Taipei area have returned to normal.
As the main vegetable production areas in central and southern Taiwan were not hit by the typhoon, the officials said, urban consumers do not need to make panic purchases.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC IS AN INDEPENDENT SOVEREIGNTY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is an independent sovereignty and its de-facto existence is a reality that cannot be denied or changed, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting with former South Korean President Kim Young Sam at the Presidential Office. Kim arrived in Taiwan a day earlier for an eight-day visit.
Stressing that the ROC is a great nation that is not a part of the People's Republic of China, Chen said that the existence of this country and its status are nothing but the truth.

"Taiwan's status as an independent and sovereign nation cannot be denied or changed, a fact that has nothing to do whether a foreign country sets up diplomatic ties with it or not, " Chen noted, pointing to his March 20 re-election.

Chen said he will safeguard Taiwan's sovereignty, dignity and security as the country's paramount leader and he called for a normalization of cross-Taiwan Strait ties through an early reopening of negotiations with mainland China. This has always been his basic stance and was outlined in his Oct. 10 National Day address and his May 20 inaugural speech, he pointed out.
He also thanked Kim for visiting Taiwan and made it clear that maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait and the Asia-Pacific region is one of his top concerns.

Peace in Northeast Asia is in the best interests of both Taiwan and South Korea, and the establishment of a trilateral security dialogue forum among Taiwan, Japan and South Korea is vital to that end, he said.

The president's comments came a day after U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell reaffirmed in an interview with the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV that the United States will maintain its "one China" policy and said that "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES RELIEF FUND FOR JAPANESE EARTHQUAKE VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Amy Huang & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Deputy Representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan Chen Hung-chi donated 2 million yen (US$185,000) on behalf of the Republic of China government Tuesday to the government of Nigata Prefecture as a relief fund for Nigata earthquake victims.
Chen delivered the donation to Yusuke Sekine, accounting department chief of the Nigata Prefecture government, at a ceremony held at the prefecture government offices.
Speaking on the occasion, Chen conveyed President Chen Shui-bian's sympathy for the earthquake victims.

In response, Sekine thanked Chen for the donation and asked him to also convey the Nigata prefecture government's appreciation for a donation of 5 million yen made by Taiwan through the Interchange Association of Japan in July for flood victims in northern Japan.
Also present at the ceremony were local government officials, lawmakers, representatives of pro-Taiwan civic groups and overseas Chinese community leaders.
After the ceremony, Chen visited various overseas Chinese communities in Nigata.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO INCREASE ASSISTANCE TO FOREIGN SPOUSES

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will integrate government resources to increase assistance to foreign spouses of Taiwan residents, government officials said Tuesday.
The officials said that the Executive Yuan plans to earmark NT$3 billion (US$86.2 million) within 10 years to finance foreign spouses' education, assistance and care-giving programs.
An assistance program for foreign spouses will be presented by the Ministry of the Interior Wednesday at a Cabinet meeting, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIUM 'FORMOSA STAR' TRAIN MAKES MAIDEN JOURNEY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) launched its premium "Formosa Star" tourist train Tuesday as part of its efforts to help boost the country's tourism industry.

Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara and Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san jointly presided over a ceremony to inaugurate the top-end tourist train at the Taipei Railway Station. Both men boarded the train along with reporters and tourists for its maiden journey to Ilan, Hualien and Taitung in eastern Taiwan.
Lin said Ishihara was invited to take the ride to help introduce Taiwan's beautiful scenery and delicious cuisine to the Japanese people.
During a visit by Ishihara in May to attend President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration, Lin said he asked the Tokyo governor how to attract Japanese tourists to Taiwan.

"Ishihara reminded me that we can better use Taiwan's hot springs and train services to attract both senior and young Japanese holidaymakers, " Lin recalled, adding that he then directed the TRA and the Tourism Bureau to jointly design the premium "Formosa Star" tourist train and its round-the-island journey.

The tourist train has all sorts of modern amenities and entertainment equipment as well as catering services. Food and beverages are included in the ticket price. Moreover, the TRA has joined forces with five-star tourist hotels and major recreation centers to offer three-day, two-night or four-day, three-night tour packages.

Ishihara said this is his fifth visit to Taiwan. He noted that Taiwan has beautiful scenery, a diverse cultural heritage and delicious cuisine. "These are precious tourism resources. With well-designed marketing strategies, Taiwan will be able to attract many foreign tourists, including Japanese citizens," he said.

Six major Japanese news media organizations sent journalists to cover Ishihara's trip. They will produce special programs introducing Taiwan's tourist attractions, Lin said, adding that the programs will be a boon to Taiwan's tourism promotion drive.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 27, or the 14th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1728: Captain James Cook, English navigator, is born. His voyages on the ship Endeavour led to the European discovery of Australia, New Zealand and the Hawaiian Islands.
1858: Theodore Roosevelt, U.S. statesman and president, is born. He won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in ending the Russo-Japanese War in 1905.
1921: Yen Fu, a noted Chinese translator who introduced Western culture to China, dies in his hometown of Minhou in Fukien Province at the age of 67.
1922: The Italian government resigns under increasing pressure from the fascist movement under Benito Mussolini.
1927: Mao Zedong leads his followers and reaches Chingkang Mountain in Kianghsi Province to establish a stronghold for the Chinese Communist Party.
1930: The Wuhsheh Incident occurs when Taiwan's aboriginal inhabitants in the Wuhsheh area of Taichung County launch their resistance campaign against Japanese rule and kill 134 Japanese.
1931: Representatives from Nanking and Canton meet in Shanghai for peace negotiations.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States to address a joint session of the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives.
1947: The Ministry of the Interior announces that the "Democracy Alliance" is an illegal organization subject to being cracked down on in accordance with current laws.
1947: The Sino-American Relief Treaty is signed in Nanking under which US$30 million worth of relief goods are to be shipped to Taiwan.
1955: Taiwan's first sex-change operation is successfully carried out at the Army First Hospital.
1961: The 16th United Nations General Assembly votes in favor of the admission of Outer Mongolia. The Republic of China abstains from the vote.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a treaty of amity in Seoul.
1974: Teizo Horikoshi, president of the Interchange Association of Japan, and Sadan Iguchi, the association's director, arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1978: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt shares the Nobel Peace Prize with Premier Menachem Begin of Israel.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on Korean Ambassador Ock Man Ho to express his condolences over the death of President Park Chung Hee.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan defends his decision to send a 2,000-strong force of Marines and Army Rangers to the Caribbean island of Grenada.
1986: An international conference on "Chiang Kai-shek and Modern China" opens in Taipei, with more than two hundred Chinese and foreign scholars attending the four-day meeting.
1987: A referendum in the Republic of Korea approves constitutional reforms, including the establishment of direct presidential elections.
1990: Moscow City Mayor Gavriil H. Popov arrives for a formal visit to the ROC to discuss the strengthening of ROC-Soviet trade relations.
1994: The Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the "Wildlife Conservation Law," greatly toughening penalties against violators and stipulating that the breeding of endangered animals in captivity must cease within three years.
1997: The Dow Jones index drops 554.26 points, its largest one-day decline in terms of points.
1999: The International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives amends and passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, aiming at extending U.S.-Taiwan security ties.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan hold their first meeting since Chen's election in March, in which Lien urges Chen to convene a National Unification Council meeting.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announces a decision to halt construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant, saying the move is the only choice for building a nuclear-free homeland.
2001: The 47th congress of the Asia Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) opens at a Auckland, New Zealand hotel with the participation of some 60 delegates from 15 countries.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sense of mercy is in all men; the sense of shame is in all men; the sense of courtesy and respect is in all men; the sense of right and wrong is in all men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AGREES IN PRINCIPLE TO RESUME IMPORTS OF U.S. BEEF: USDA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By J.L. Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has agreed in principle to resume imports of U.S. beef and beef products, which were suspended in December 2003 due to safety concerns, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) said Tuesday.

Dr. J. B. Penn, undersecretary for Farm and Foreign Agricultural Services, at the head of a U.S. delegation, met with Taiwan health and agriculture officials early this week for talks on the matter, USDA officials said.

Taiwan officials will travel to the United States Nov. 10 to begin on-site inspection of the major features and implementation of the U.S. safeguards against bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , also known as mad-cow disease, according to a USDA news release.

The Taiwan officials have indicated that they are close to completing the reviews necessary for resuming the beef trade, with on-site inspections as the final step in the process, the USDA news release indicated.
If everything goes smoothly, it is expected that Taiwan will reopen its doors to U.S. beef and beef products before the end of 2004, the USDA officials said.

"We are very pleased with this progress in yet another important beef market, " Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman said. "We are continuing our market opening efforts in the remaining key countries. Our goal is a return to a normal beef trade as quickly as possible."

Taiwan suspended U.S. beef imports in December 2003 following the discovery in the U.S. state of Washington of a single BSE-infected cow. Taiwan purchased $325 million worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003, according to USDA officials.
According to Penn, the United States and Japan concluded an agreement in Tokyo Oct. 23 that paves the way for a partial resumption of the beef trade between the two countries.

Japan was the largest importer of U.S. beef before it imposed a ban last year, with annual beef imports from the United States amounting to more than US$1.4 billion, or more than 30 percent of total U.S. beef exports.

Taiwan was the sixth largest importer of U.S. beef before it imposed the ban. Only Mexico continued to import U.S. beef and beef products after the discovery of the case of mad cow in Washington State, according to USDA.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWELL'S 'PEACEFUL UNIFICATION' REMARK ONLY AN 'ORAL MISTAKE': EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. China policy expert said Tuesday that some State Department officials told him a day earlier that Secretary of State Colin Powell's recent comment that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should move forward to a peaceful unification through dialogue was only an oral mistake.
John J. Tkacik, senior research fellow at the Asia Studies Center of the Heritage Foundation, also said that the secretary had no intention of prejudicing the eventual outcome of the dialogue.

In an interview conducted with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV during his visit to Beijing Oct. 25, Powell said that "both sides should show restraint, not take any unilateral actions, look for ways of improving dialogue across the strait and move forward toward that day when we will see a peaceful unification."
The secretary also said that "we want to see both sides not take unilateral action that would prejudice an eventual outcome, a reunification that all parties are seeking."

Nevertheless, Tkacik said that some of his friends working at the State Department told him that the department's spokesmen are ready to clarify some of the secretary's remarks and to reiterate that the U.S. cross-strait policy remains unchanged.
Tkacik also noted that the State Department officials told him that unification is only one of the possible outcomes of cross-strait dialogue.
Meanwhile, State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli made it clear at a daily press briefing Monday that the United States has not changed its cross-strait policy.
"One element of our policy has been to favor a peaceful resolution of the cross-strait issue through dialogue and through a resolution that is acceptable to both sides," he said.

Ereli also said Tuesday that "our concern is that neither side should act unilaterally to change the status quo and that differences between the People's Republic of China and Taiwan are matters to be resolved peacefully, absent the threat or use of force, and should be acceptable to people on both sides of the strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 60TH IN PRESS FREEDOM
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked 60th among 167 countries and areas surveyed in the world in terms of respect for press freedom, up one notch from its 2003 ranking, in the latest report released by the Reporters without Borders (RWB) organization Tuesday.

In its 2004 press freedom report, the RWB said that Scandinavian countries continue to rank at the top of list, while East Asian and Middle Eastern countries continue to take up most of the spots at the bottom of the list.

The RWB reported that in the year between September 2003 and September 2004, East Asia remained the area with the least amount of press freedom, with North Korea finishing at the bottom of the list for the third consecutive year, Myanmar ranking 165th and mainland China placing 162th. The other two countries on the "five worst offenders" list are Turkmenistan and Bhutan. Vietnam placed 161th, while Laos ranked 153rd.
New Zealand, placing ninth, was the highest ranked country among all non-European states.

Mainland China continued as the "largest jail in the world" for reporters and journalists, with 27 currently locked up, according to the report. The RWB said that although Beijing had promised when bidding for the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games to improve treatment of members of the media, foreign media organizations continue to be regularly monitored and censored by mainland authorities.
The RWB report also mentioned that government authorities in South Korea, which ranked 48th, and in Taiwan have "not always" been tolerant of opposition in the media.

The Paris-based NGO group drew up the press freedom ranking report by asking journalists, researchers and legal experts to answer 52 questions about the whole range of press freedom violations, such as murders or arrests of journalists, censorship, pressure, state monopolies in various fields, punishment for press law offenses, and regulation of the media.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING BLOCKS TAIWAN'S PROPOSAL AT WTO'S SPS COMMITTEE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Mainland China blocked a proposal Tuesday put forward by Taiwan to establish working relationships with other international organizations via the framework of the World Trade Organization's Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures (SPS) Committee, a trade source in Geneva said the same day.

The organizations include the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), the CODEX Alimentarius Commission and the IPPC, which is based on an international treaty to secure action to prevent the spread and introduction of pests in plants and plant products, and to promote appropriate measures for their control.

The SPS concerns the application of food safety and animal and plant health regulations. According to the WTO Web site: "It allows countries to set their own standards. But it also says regulations must be based on science. They should be applied only to the extent necessary to protect human, animal or plant life or health. And they should not arbitrarily or unjustifiably discriminate between countries where identical or similar conditions prevail."

"Member countries are encouraged to use international standards, guidelines and recommendations where they exist. However, members may use measures which result in higher standards if there is scientific justification. They can also set higher standards based on appropriate assessment of risks so long as the approach is consistent, not arbitrary."

As the SPS committee's mandate is closely related to the missions of the three international organizations, Taiwan fears the lack of memberships in such organizations might affect its right and interests; therefore, Taiwan's representative made a proposal recently at the SPC Committee, requesting that it establish a mechanism to help Taiwan and other WTO members that encounter the same problems participate in the work of the organizations.

In the proposal, Taiwan also suggested that the SPS request that the organizations invite those WTO members who are interested in their operations to attend their technical meetings as guests or observers.

However, the source said at an informal SPS Committee meeting held Tuesday at the WTO headquarters that mainland China's delegates opposed the idea, saying that Taiwan is not a developing country as it mentioned in the proposal, and that the WTO should not be involved in other international organizations' affairs.

A Canadian delegate to the WTO also said at the meeting that the committee has reinforced its contacts with other applicable international organizations, and that the WTO has no right to intrude in other international organizations' operations.
