DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGERS ON FLIGHT WITH SMUGGLED BIRDS UNLIKELY TO BE INFECTED
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: European Union authorities have been searching all passengers who traveled on flights with a Thai man who tried to smuggle two Asian eagles into Belgium on Oct. 17-18 due to health concerns. Most of the passengers were from Taiwan.

A total of 135 passengers were reportedly aboard a Taiwan-based EVA Airways flight from Bangkok to Vienna the night of Oct. 17 with the Thai man who carried in his hand luggage two mountain hawk eagles which were confirmed Oct. 23 of having been infected with the bird flu virus.
Of the passengers, 122 were Taiwan citizens.
The birds of prey were then smuggled into the passenger cabin on an Austrian Airlines flight from Vienna to Brussels in the morning of Oct. 18, according to European Union officials.
Belgium asked the European Commission for help to find the passengers of different nationalities who might have been exposed to the avian flu virus.

"Although the risk of transmission from animals to humans is limited, it cannot be excluded since the birds traveled in the passenger cabin in hand luggage, " the European Commission said in a statement a couple of days ago.
The Thai man was apprehended by customs officers at Brussels airport when the eagles were discovered in his bags, alive and in plastic tubing Oct. 18. But he was apparently then released.
The eagles have been destroyed, as have some 200 parrots that were being kept at the same quarantine center.

Officials from Taiwan's Department of Health said Tuesday that it was highly unlikely that the Taiwan passengers were inflicted with bird flu by the two eagles because the birds were contained in closed luggage and the Thai man was examined in Brussels and found not to have any infection.

Meanwhile, the officials said that since the bird flu virus incubation period is about one week, passengers who do not display any symptoms after seven days from Oct. 18 should not have been infected.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.078 to close at NT$33.615.
A total of US$708 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.660 and fluctuated between NT$33.610 and NT$33.719.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT MEETS TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Visiting former South Korean President Kim Young Sam said Wednesday that since direct air links between Taiwan and South Korea have been resumed, political, cultural and economic ties between the two countries should be further developed.
Kim said he hopes his current visit will contribute to Taiwan's efforts to further integrate into the international community.
Kim made the remarks during a courtesy call on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou at Taipei City Hall.
The former South Korean head of state and Ma exchanged views on mostly casual and everyday topics in a very relaxed atmosphere.
Kim said that he shares with Ma a common love for jogging, adding that he has been running every day for the past 33 years.
For his part, Ma introduced Taipei 101, the tallest building in the world, to Kim and offered him a series of books about the city of Taipei.
Kim arrived in Taiwan Monday for an eight-day visit at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian. It is his fourth visit to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION MINISTER AFFIRMS SAFETY OF "FORMOSA STAR"

TEXT.P: The maiden journey of the premium-class "Formosa Star" tourist train was launched after railway traffic conditions had been determined safe, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Wednesday.

Lin made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in response to questions by some lawmakers who doubted the safety of the journey, which was inaugurated on the east coast of Taiwan with the participation of Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara Tuesday morning, when normal passenger train services for the route were still stopped because of damage caused by Typhoon Nock-Ten a day before.
The lawmakers wondered if the Ministry of Transportation and Communications was granting "special privileges" to Ishihara by allowing him to go ahead with the journey.
Lin said workers had conducted a safety inspection on railway traffic conditions before the journey.
Lin said the ministry decided to go ahead with the trip mainly to accommodate Ishihara's tight itinerary. He was invited to Taiwan as a special guest to help promote Taiwan's tourism.

The minister said Ishihara was aware of the condition of railway before boarding the train, and the governor observed that the damage caused by typhoons in Japan was 10 times more severe than that done to Taiwan.
Also, Lin said the train would not have been ready for its official operation on Oct. 30 -- the tickets for which are fully booked -- had the inauguration ceremony been delayed.

According to Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) Director-General Hsu Ta-wen, Ishihara is joining a three-day, two-night tour and it would leave insufficient time for the train to undergo maintenance before it starts official service unless the inaugural journey was made as scheduled.
Meanwhile, Lin said regular passenger services along the east coast were not resumed until Tuesday evening because the signals and electricity were down.
While regular train services are not allowed to run under this circumstance, a special train is not subject to this restriction, Lin said.
The top-end tourist train has all sorts of modern amenities and entertainment equipment as well as catering services. Food and beverages are included in the ticket price.
The TRA has also joined forces with five-star hotels and major recreation centers to offer tour packages.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Banks make millions from unfair credit card charges.
The big banks have been accused of using bogus accounting practices to cheat millions of credit card customers with late payment and other penalty charges. The Office of Fair Trading has written to all the main credit-card issuers asking them to explain how they calculate fees for customers who exceed their credit limit or pay late.
Financial Times: Barroso's EU team braced for rejection.
Jose Manuel Barroso's new European Commission on Tuesday night faced rejection by the European parliament, after a day of concessions, arm-twisting and pleading still left him facing defeat. A defeat would create a power vacuum at the heart of the European Union, with Mr Barroso's 24-member team unable to take office as planned on November 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: 57 KMT/NEW PARTY CANDIDATES IN SECURE POSITION: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng estimated that about 57 legislative candidates nominated by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the New Party are in secure positions ahead of the Dec. 11 elections, KMT sources said Wednesday.
Wang made the remarks when he attended a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting during which the participants heard assessments on the year-end legislative elections.
The New Party, a splinter party of the KMT, is now running under the banner of the KMT.

Wang, who serves concurrently as a KMT Vice Chairman, told the participants that as the elections drew near, the party should pay close attention to the changes in the overall situation, issues concerning current affairs and personal factors.

Wang's remarks came on the heels of President Chen Shui-bian's call Tuesday for 100 seats to be won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the 225-seat legislature so that the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , will command a comfortable majority. The president concurrently serves as the DPP chairman.
Wang also estimated that some constituencies are precarious for the KMT and the New Party -- Taoyuan, Yunlin and Changhua -- and urged the candidates in those areas to go all out to win votes.
The participants also heard the strategy of "redressing the weaknesses of the KMT and attacking the weaknesses of our rivals."

A record 387 candidates have registered to vie for 168 regional and eight aboriginal seats, of which 92 have been recommended by the ruling DPP. The at-large seats will be awarded in proportion to the votes each party garners.
The KMT has nominated 74 candidates, followed by its ally, the People First Party (DPP) with 41, the pro-independence TSU with 30 and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union with 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSITION ON LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS UNCHANGED: CABINET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's position regarding special charter flight services to carry mainland-based Taiwan businessmen to spend lunar new year at home has not changed, and the government and the private sector have joined forces to study the issue, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun has instructed the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to begin assessing the feasibilities based on the framework laid down by President Chen Shui-bian in his Oct. 10 National Day address and May 20 second inaugural address, Chen Chi-mai said.

Chen Chi-mai said that the president has raised many constructive proposals in terms of cross-Taiwan Strait relations in the two speeches and he urged Beijing leaders to be wise enough to accept Taiwan's goodwill overtures and reopen bilateral negotiations based on parity and dignity.

Next spring should be the right time for the two sides to rekindle negotiations, he said, adding that both can start first with technical issues, referring to Taiwan's proposed charter flight services.
The Executive Yuan has instructed the MAC, the CEPD and the MOTC to accelerate the pace in studying the issue with the six leading trade groups and various shipping companies, he noted.

In line with the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, relevant government authorities, such as the MAC or the semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation, are entitled to commission the private sector to handle the issue with the mainland side.

Chen Chi-mai's remarks came shortly after Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office, earlier the same day told a news conference that lunar new year charter flight services for Taiwan businessmen could be "workable, " as long as it is dealt with as an internal issue of a country.
Under this prerequisite, private groups or corporations from the two sides would be allowed to negotiate the issue or even the opening of direct trade, transport and postal links, Zhang said.
The three direct links have been absent across the Taiwan Strait since 1949, when Taiwan and mainland China split at the end of a civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: 220KG GOLD BRICK COULD BREAK GUINNESS RECORD

TEXT.P: Taipei County's Gold Ecological Park will display a gold brick weighing 220 kilograms Oct. 28, officials said Wednesday.
The brick could break the current Guinness record for the heaviest single gold brick. The Taipei County Government intends to apply to Guinness for inclusion.
An official from Guinness stationed in Taiwan will be on hand to witness the unveiling of the gold brick.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESULTS OF PROBE INTO TRANSASIA PLANE MISHAP TO BE RELEASED NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: A damage report on a Transasia Airways Corp. A320 airplane that skidded off the runway after landing Oct. 19 at Taipei's Sungshan Airport is expected to be completed by next week when Airbus engineers will decide whether or not the plane can be repaired.

TransAsia flight GE536 from Tainan, southern Taiwan, suffered damage to the front wheel of the aircraft and the cowling covering a generator. One hundred passengers and six crew members were on board at the time.
Aviation safety experts have been analyzing data on the incident to determine if the cause was pilot error, weather or mechanical failure.
TransAsia Airways officials said Wednesday that experts from the aircraft's manufacturer, Airbus Industrie, are currently in Taiwan assessing the damage.

A similar incident happened in Tainan Airport in March last year, when an airplane owned by the same airlines hit a construction vehicle while taxiing on the runway. The military was faulted for leaving the vehicle in the wrong place at the dual-use airport and the airlines subsequently petitioned the government for NT$400 million (US$11.9 million) in compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEARING HELD ON CONSTITUTIONALITY OF 'TRUTH COMMISSION'

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices held a hearing Wednesday on the constitutionality of a special statute authorizing the formation of an investigation commission to probe the March 19 election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

Representatives from the two sides -- the "pan-green camp" of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on the one hand and the Legislative Yuan on the other -- made opening statements followed by a question time and ending with final statements. The process lasted for about eight hours.

The hearing -- the second such hearing -- was arranged by the Council of Grand Justices after the "pan-green camp" asked for an interpretation of the constitutionality of the "3-19 Truth Investigation Commission" that passed the Legislative Yuan in August. The first hearing was held Oct. 14 to hear the petition from the "pan-green camp" for an injunction of the operations of investigation commission, which started formal operations Oct. 4.

The "pan-green camp" criticized the bill for seriously violating the division of power and the checks and balances principles stipulated under the Constitution, encroaching on the judicial and prosecutorial powers and representing a serious violation of human rights.

DPP Legislator Yu Ching wanted the grand justices to proclaim the bill void from the beginning. The "pan-green camp" failed to overturn the bill in its reconsideration bid in September due to the slight edge enjoyed by the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in the legislature.
TSU Legislator Wu Tung-sheng said that though one should respect the authority of the legislature, "evil law is no law" and that the grand justices should pronounce its annulment.

Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, who represented the ministry, claimed that the 3-19 bill is the "most gross violation" example of the constitutional system since the Constitution was first promulgated in 1947.

He criticized the commission for being granted with unlimited power to target a specific and individual shooting and pointed out that the commission is not under any jurisdiction whatsoever under the current five-branch government structure system, but can still exercise all the powers of a government agency.

On the other hand, Legislator Kao Yu-jen of the Kuomintang, spoke in favor of the bill, saying that the controversy over the election-eve shooting has created a deep cleft between the ruling and the opposition parties and claiming that a so-called "independent" investigation is the opposition's "responsibility to history."
PFP Legislator Chen Chin-hsin claimed that the bill was passed in response to public calls for an independent investigation of the shooting.

He rebutted accusations that the bill encroaches on judicial and prosecutorial powers, or criminal immunity for the president, claiming that it is for the upholding of social justice and is constitutional.

Chen denied that the commission has unlimited power, claiming that only when individuals, groups, or government agencies resist the investigation of the truth commission will related laws be overruled by the commission.

He expressed the hope that the grand justices will give a ruling on the constitutionality bill so that the commission, which has been getting nowhere since its inauguration because of a boycott by the administration, can begin to operate efficiently.
Lawyers and professors from both sides were also on hand to provide their views to the Council of Grand Justices, which will hold its last hearing Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REGRETS "REUNIFICATION" REMARKS BY U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen expressed regret and grave concern Wednesday over recent remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell in which he used the term "reunification" to refer to the future development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and denied Taiwan has "sovereignty as a nation."
Chen reaffirmed that "the Republic of China (Taiwan) " is a sovereign state, a fact which he said no country can deny.

"It is unacceptable to Taiwan and regrettable that Secretary Powell has denied the sovereignty enjoyed by Taiwan and predetermined a position on future cross-strait development, " Chen said in a statement.

Chen said Powell's remarks have harmed Taiwan's democracy and prestige because they were made in ignorance of the fact that Taiwan has for a long time participated in international affairs and exercised its sovereignty as an independent nation.

"The U.S. government should respect the will of the 23 million people of Taiwan, which should be a crucial basis for its policies toward Taiwan and for its efforts to promote peaceful dialogue across the strait," Chen said.
Powell spoke of Washington's stand on the status of Taiwan during interviews with CNN and Hong Kong-based Phoenix TV in Beijing Monday.
Powell said: "We want to see both sides not take unilateral action that would prejudice an eventual outcome, a reunification that all parties are seeking."
Powell also reiterated that the United States does not support independence for Taiwan, saying the island "does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation, and that remains our policy, our firm policy."

The remarks were obviously different from the usual U.S. practice of urging both sides to seek a "peaceful resolution" without specifying its stance on future relations between Taiwan and mainland China.

Earlier in the day, Chen invited American Institute in Taiwan Director Douglas Paal -- Washington's de facto ambassador to Taipei -- to his office to find out if there has been a shift in U.S. policy toward Taiwan.

According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , Paal emphasized during the meeting that the U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged, pointing out that the U.S. Department of State has reaffirmed Washington's policy favoring a "peaceful resolution" of the cross-strait dispute.
Paal also said Powell spoke in favor of Taiwan during his recent meeting with Beijing leaders, according to MOFA.

Powell defended Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization, the island's full participation in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, and Washington's arms sales to Taiwan, Paal said.
Powell also urged Beijing to take seriously President Chen Shui-bian's peace overtures -- made in his Oct. 10 National Day address -- and to resume dialogue with Taiwan soon, Paal said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWELL'S REMARKS ARE SERIOUS WARNING TO TAIWAN: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Recent remarks by U. S. Secretary of State Colin Powell on cross-Taiwan Strait ties are a "very severe warning" to Taiwan and the government must assume responsibility for the situation, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday.

Lien's comments came after Powell said Monday in an interview with the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV in Beijing that the United States will maintain its "one China" policy and that "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation."
Powell also said that "the United States wants to see both sides not take unilateral action that would prejudice an eventual outcome, a unification that all parties are seeking."

Lien described Powell's remarks as a "very serious warning" to Taiwan and said that the government led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must be held accountable for the lion's share of responsibility for the development.

Lien blamed what he described as the government's flip-flops and doublespeak in its dealings with the United States for Powell's remarks and said that the KMT has always remained firm on its stance that the Republic of China is a wholly independent sovereignty.

"There must not be the slightest bit of doubt about this fact, because Taiwan, of the sovereignty of the ROC, is our home where we were born and set our roots, " the KMT chairman said, arguing that the government and President Chen Shui-bian owe a clear explanation to the Taiwan people in the wake of the U.S. rhetoric suggesting a peaceful unification across the strait.

Earlier the same day, the legislative caucuses of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) , annoyed by Powell's words, called a news conference at the Legislative Yuan to defend Taiwan's sovereignty.

Pointing their fingers at the United States, they said that the U. S. government has no right to "arrange, meddle in or interfere with" any issue that is of maximum concern to Taiwan's 23 million people.

KMT whip Tseng Yung-chuan claimed that Powell's words are a reflection that Chen's performance over the past four and a half years has not won approval from the United States and he urged the government to carefully handle Taiwan's delicate relations with the United States, especially now, at a time when the Bush administration is skeptical of Taiwan's cross-strait policy.
PFP whip Liu Wen-hsiung ascribed the situation to what he said is the problem of Chen's integrity, which he described as the country's "largest crisis."

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 SKAL INTERNATIONAL ANNUAL MEETING TO BE HELD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The 2008 Skal International Annual Meeting is slated to take place in Taiwan, Skal International Taipei Chairman Edward Lo said Wednesday.

Lo attended the 2004 Skal International annual meeting in South Africa Oct. 25 at the head of a 12-member delegation, during which he described Taiwan's tourism environment to 52 participating tourism operators from around the world.
Taiwan's gaining of the hosting right adds momentum to the country's efforts to double the number of foreign tourist arrivals by 2008, Lo added.
The Taiwan delegation is scheduled to return home Oct. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Lawmakers back Sharon on plan for leaving Gaza.
Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, won what he called the most important vote of his political life on Tuesday night, as the Israeli Parliament approved his plan to remove all Israeli settlements from Gaza. The vote was 67 to 45, with 7 abstentions and one legislator absent because of illness.
Wall Street Journal: Block the vote as a final gambit, parties are trying to damp turnout.
With President Bush more dependent than ever on his political base, Democrats hoped that by amplifying the conflict between the White House and a religious right leader might produce a salutary result: diminished zeal among conservative Christians to turn out on Nov. 2. A top Democratic operative in California said that the Democrats are trying to discourage the opponent's base with bad news.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET FULLY BEHIND GUGGENHEIM TAICHUNG BRANCH PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan fully supports the plan for a Guggenheim branch in the central Taiwan city of Taichung, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.
Chen Chi-mai made the remarks amid reports that Taichung city councilors had lashed out at the plan during a review of the initial agreement reached between Taichung and the prestigious museum.

Chen expressed confidence that Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, who made a Taichung Guggenheim branch his campaign platform when he ran for mayor, can use his tact and influence to resolve the differences over its construction.

Chen also said that if there is a need for the government to explain the situation to the Guggenheim Foundation, then President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Yu Shyi-kun will be willing to meet with the heads of the foundation to lend support to Taichung City.

The Taichung city council began a two-day review of the initial agreement Wednesday, with most of the councilors questioning the agreement as an "unequal treaty" and expressing worry that the project would become a financial "black hole."

Councilor Yu Ming-tze said that the agreement would strip the city of its dignity, pointing out that under the plan, the city would have to appropriate a 10-year budget for the branch and then turn it over to the Guggenheim Foundation after 10 years.
Councilor Lin Pei-le asked Hu to pledge the fortune of him and his family that the branch will not leave huge debts for future generations.

However, the mayor defended the project as an "asset, " noting that when the idea of a central Taiwan science park was broached years ago, a lot of people were pessimistic, but the park has now reaped economic benefits for the city.

He said that the Guggenheim branch plan has been subjected to a feasibility study that came to the conclusion that it would bring benefits in the long term. Taiwan has enjoyed no such international cooperation projects before, he said, urging the naysayers to adopt a newer and broader perspective on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT UPBEAT ABOUT PROSPECTS FOR TAIWAN-INDIA TRADE TIES

TEXT.P: The prospects for future trade relations between Taiwan and India are promising, with significant growth already seen this year, Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-general Huang Chih-peng said Wednesday.
Huang pointed out that Taiwan's exports to India at present account for only 0.6 percent of its out-bound shipments.
However, these exports amounted to US$767.7 million from January to September this year, equivalent to the amount for the whole of 2003, Huang said.
Imports from India during the same period stood at US$630 million, Huang added.

While fewer than 100 Taiwanese businesses have invested in India in the past -- mainly because of language differences and the geographic distance between the countries -- India has in recent years become a major target of Taiwanese investors and traders in light of its fast economic growth, vast domestic market and excellent IT software design capacity, according to Huang.

Huang said the BOFT has been promoting trade activities with India by maintaining close contact with India's investment and trade authorities and organizing fact-finding tours to India to look at trade and investment opportunities there.

In addition to the IT industry, other industries with cooperation potential between the two sides include textiles, bicycles, medical equipment, sports equipment, stationery and gifts, and mechanical instruments, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIALS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT RELATIONS WITH INDIA

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and India are becoming closer and the prospects for bilateral trade and economic cooperation are rosy, government officials said Wednesday.

Both Lin Sung-huan, director-general of the Asia-Pacific Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and Kao Cheng-chiung, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center in New Delhi, said that the two countries are complementary in the economic and technology fields and that there is an ample room for the promotion of cooperation between them.

Taiwan-India relations were revitalized in 1995 when the two sides decided to establish representative offices in each other's countries, Lin noted, adding that the bilateral ties have become even closer since 2002, when the two countries signed an investment guarantee accord.

Taiwan greatly appreciates its relations with India, Lin noted, adding that he believes the complementary effects between the two countries in the economics and technology industries will contribute to the promotion of bilateral ties.
The government will continue to do its best to promote relations with India and make it another destination for Taiwan's overseas investment under the government's "southward" policy, Lin went on.
India has large-scale market potential given that it is very populous and an emerging market, Lin said. He encouraged Taiwan enterprises to explore business opportunities in the subcontinent.

In comparison with mainland China, Lin said, it is a safer destination for investment because India has a market-oriented economy, while the mainland is less open in the political and economic fields and lacks the rule of law.
For his part, Kao said that Taiwan-India ties have steadily improved since 1995 and exchange visits by government officials have been increasing.
In addition to the existing investment guarantee accord, the two countries are seeking to sign a double taxation prevention accord and to hold regular meetings of senior government officials.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Center in New Delhi is also seeking to set up a technological group that will be in charge of further promoting technological exchanges between the two countries, Kao revealed.

The Taiwan-India Forum, which was established two years ago, has been serving as a second track of official communications between the two countries, with the Institute for Defense Studies and Analyses (IDSA) in India and the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University in Taiwan as their communication channels, Kao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY FLASHES YELLOW-RED LIGHT FOR SEPTEMBER: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy in September posted a yellow-red light in the government's five-color rating system, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

The composite index fell from August's 33 points to 32 points for September, which is close to a green light, as the domestic economy flashed a fourth consecutive yellow-red light, said Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department.

The possibility of a green light indicates that the booming domestic economy is likely to abate in the coming months, despite the fact that sales volumes and export order numbers last month were slightly up compared to August levels, Hu said, adding that a larger percent of the Taiwan companies surveyed are pessimistic about their business conditions in the short term compared to August.

According to the five-color rating system designated by the CEPD, a red light indicates an overheated economy, yellow-red indicates a heating up economy, green means steady growth, yellow-blue signals sluggishness and blue points to recession.
The leading index for September stood at the August level of 107.8 points, while the month's current index fell by 0.7 percent to 110 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING UNLIKELY TO PROVOKE WAR AGAINST TAIWAN: FORMER KOREAN LEADER

TEXT.P: The Beijing leadership is unlikely to rashly launch an attack against Taiwan, because such a move would come at a huge price for mainland China, former South Korean President Kim Young Sam said Wednesday.
Kim made the remarks while giving a speech at National Chengchi University.
Pointing to the mainland's invasion of Vietnam as example, Kim said it is impossible that Beijing will stir up a war rashly against Taiwan at a very possible terrible cost to itself.

South Korea, like Taiwan, is also a democratic country and the South Korean people, like the Taiwan people, will never give way to military intimidation from North Korea's unification scheme, Kim said.
Stressing that democracy is the highest value for all mankind to live in freedom and with human rights, Kim said the people in both Taiwan and his own country should cherish their democratic systems.

Commenting on the recent remarks made in Beijing by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell that Taiwan is not independent and does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation, Kim declined to speculate as to why Powell said what he did.
But he said, citing his many American friends, that he strongly believes Washington will not give up on Taiwan because it is an important partner of the United States.
The former South Korean president arrived in Taiwan Monday for an eight-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY SHOULD BE DICTATED BY HISTORY: TOKYO GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's sovereignty should be dictated by history, not by the United Nations or by any other country, Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara said Wednesday.

Ishihara, who was visiting Taiwan, made the remarks while commenting on U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's recent remarks that Taiwan is not independent and does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation.
Ishihara said that he opposes Powell's remarks and that Powell made a mistake by saying what he did.
He also reminded the United States to remember what happened in Tibet and the cruelty demonstrated by the Chinese military during China's invasion decades ago.
China may split into various parts in years to come given that it is facing serious economic problems with a great gap between the rich and the poor, Ishihara warned.

At the invitation of the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) , Ishihara was in Taiwan to attend the launch of the TRA's new tourist train, the "Formosa Star," which made its maiden journey Tuesday down the east coast of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 28, or the 15th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Christopher Columbus discovers Cuba on his first voyage to the New World and claims it in the name of Spain.
1636: Harvard College is founded at Cambridge by the General Court of Massachusetts on the comparatively modest sum of US$740, part of US$1,440 bequeathed to the university by Mr. John Harvard, assistant pastor of the First Church of Charleston.
1746: An earthquake completely destroys Lima and Callao in Peru, killing more than 18,000 people.
1794: Robert Liston, the Scottish doctor who performed the first operation in Britain on an anesthetized patient, is born.
1886: A statue called Liberty Enlightening the World, the largest present ever sent to the American people from the French, is inaugurated on Liberty Island in the Upper Bay of New York Harbor by President Grover Cleveland.
1891: A strong earthquake rocks the Niphon Islands in Japan, killing 10,000 people and leaving more than 300,000 others homeless.
1901: Taiwan's first Shinto shrine is inaugurated on Yuanshan in Taipei during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
1912: Sir Richard Doll, the British cancer researcher who proved the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, is born.
1914: Jonas Salk, the American microbiologist who developed a polio vaccine, is born.
1950: Finland establishes diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1953: A launch ceremony for the first batch of U.S.-provided fishing boats to Taiwan is held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
1962: Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev informs U.S. President John F. Kennedy that work on missile sites under construction in Cuba will be halted and that missiles already delivered will be shipped back to the USSR.
1966: Wu Chen-nan, former leader of the "Taiwan Independence Revolutionary Council" in Japan, returns to Taiwan.
1972: Two pandas, a gift from Communist China to Japan, arrive at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo.
1973: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and two other Japanese leaders arrives in Taipei to extend birthday congratulations to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1977: Taiwan's first experimental geothermal power plant goes into operation in Ilan.
1979: Movie star James Mason arrives in Taipei to attend the Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony at the invitation of the Movie and Drama Association of the ROC.
1980: Asaad Abdul Aziz Al-Zuhair, the first resident Saudi Arabian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Felipe Gonzales, 40, becomes Spain's first Socialist prime minister in a landslide victory.
1992: Australian Tourism and Resources Minister Alan Griffiths visits Taipei to promote closer bilateral trade relations. He is the first Australian minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1993: An explosion occurs at Taiwan Power Company's Hsintienlun power plant in central Taiwan, killing six people and injuring 26 others.
1993: Communist China resumes trade relations with South Africa, cut off since July 1960.
1999: Renowned Japanese writer Ayako Sono arrives in Taipei, bringing with her a cash donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) and immeasurable compassion for Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: Former Finance Minister Paul Chiu is ordered to post NT$600,000 bail after he was formally questioned by a Taipei district prosecutor about his alleged wrongdoings during his tenure as finance minister.
2001: Amid increased exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Philippine Airlines begins operating flights on the Taipei-Manila-Shanghai route.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "He who attends to his smaller self becomes a small man, and he who attends to his greater self becomes a great man."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL REAFFIRMS NO CHANGE IN 'SIX ASSURANCES' TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top representative to the United States confirmed Wednesday that U.S. officials have reassured him that Washington will stick to the "Six Assurances" it pledged to Taiwan in 1982 as the guidelines in its policy toward Taiwan.

During a meeting with Chinese-language media in Washington, D.C., David Ta-wei Lee confirmed that Randall G. Shriver, U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian Affairs, told him Tuesday that the United States' stance on Taiwan's sovereignty has not changed and that the "Six Assurances" remain unchanged.
The Reagan administration offered the "Six Assurances" to Taiwan after it signed a joint communique on Aug. 17, 1982 with mainland China over arms sales to Taiwan.

Lee said that he immediately contacted the State Department to express Taiwan's "grave concern" and ask for clarification after Secretary of State Colin Powell made some remarks regarding Taiwan and its relations with mainland China in an interview with the Hong Kong-based Phoenix TV Group during his Oct. 25 visit to Beijing.
In the interview, Powell said that "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation, " and that "the two sides should move forward to a peaceful unification through dialogue."

According to Lee, Shriver reiterated in a "face to face" talk with him Tuesday that the "Six Assurances, " particularly the fifth point -- namely, the United States would not alter its position about Taiwan's sovereignty, which was that the question was one to be decided peacefully by the Chinese themselves -- remain unchanged.

Meanwhile, Lee said that Powell clarified during an interview with Ron Insana of CNBC Wednesday that the words "peaceful reunification" of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that he mentioned during his 24-hour visit in Beijing should be "a peaceful resolution" of the problem.
"The term of art really is to have a 'peaceful resolution' of the problem. And that's the term of art, and that is our policy and remains our policy," Powell was quoted as saying to CNBC.

Lee said that he believes that Washington will formally reiterate its "Six Assurances" toward Taiwan again shortly, adding that he will be briefed by U.S. officials Wednesday or Thursday about Powell's recent Beijing visit.

The "Six Assurances" stipulate that the United States has not agreed to set a date for ending arms sales to the Republic of China; has not agreed to hold prior consultations with Beijing on arms sales to the Republic of China; will not play any mediation role between Taiwan and Beijing; has not agreed to revise the Taiwan Relations Act; has not altered its position regarding sovereignty over Taiwan; and will not exert pressure on the Republic of China to enter into negotiations with Beijing.

Meanwhile, Lee said that actually, Powell has on many occasions during his talks with the mainland Chinese leadership spoken favorably for Taiwan, including that the United States remains firm in its stance on arms sales to Taiwan despite Beijing's strong opposition and that the United States has continued to encourage Beijing to face squarely the goodwill that President Chen Shui-bian demonstrated toward mainland China in his Oct. 10 National Day address.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG HOPES ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL CAN BE PUT TO REVIEW BEFORE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that he still hopes a bill authorizing a major arms procurement package from the United States will be put to review by a legislative committee before the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Wang's words came amid grave concerns in Taiwan over U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's recent remarks about Taiwan in which he denied Taiwan has "sovereignty as a nation" and used the term "unification" to refer to the future development of cross-strait relations.

Asked about the possible impact of Powell's remarks on the bill authorizing a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) proposed by the Executive Yuan for arms procurement, Wang said there are positive and negative views on Powell's remarks, and some may think arms procurement is more necessary while others may think it less necessary.
Wang said he "personally hopes the Procedure Committee in the Legislature can arrange for it to be put on the agenda for review Tuesday."

An attempt by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to put the bill on the agenda for review failed last week. The DPP has said it hopes the bill can be reviewed quickly and complete its third reading in the Legislative Yuan before the legislative elections. The party also said that an arms procurement bill can be passed before talking about the budget for the arms procurement after lawmakers reconvene after the elections.
But the opposition Kuomintang said the Legislative Yuan is scheduled to go into a one-month recess Nov. 10 in preparation for the elections, and that there is not enough time to review the bill.

Minister of National Defense Lee Jye has said that if the arms deal, mainly for six batteries of anti-missile PAC-III missiles, eight diesel-electric submarines, and a squadron of anti-submarine aircraft, failed to pass the legislature before next January, he would resign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PHILIPPINE FISHERY WORKERS ARRESTED ON HOMICIDE CHARGES

TEXT.P: Two Philippine citizens working aboard a fishing vessel based in the eastern Taiwan county of Taitung were arrested Thursday on charges of colluding to murder a colleague, police said.

Liqe Alvin Barpolapa, 33, and Arellana Joeyilagan, 32, are accused of having stabbed Egot Danny Zalvado, 36, to death with fruit knives in the vessel's cabin early Thursday. The victim was also a Philippine citizen.

The two men are reported to have first subdued Zalvado and intimidated the other crew members aboard the "Yutsaiwang" fishing boat not to try to stop them. Two fishery workers fled in fright and reported the case to police.
When police officers arrived, the victim had already lost consciousness due to excessive bleeding. He was later pronounced dead upon arrival at a nearby hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-EL SALVADOR RELATIONS UNCHANGED: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Thursday reaffirmed that relations with El Salvador are unchanged and high-level exchanges are continuing as usual.

Foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu was responding to an AFP report that El Salvadoran Foreign Minister Francisco Lainez said that the government will study the possibility of establishing diplomatic relations with mainland China.

After checking with the ROC Embassy in El Salvador, the foreign ministry found that the El Salvadoran Chamber of Commerce had suggested that establishing formal diplomatic relations with mainland China could be good for expanding El Salvador's exports of coffee and pharmaceuticals to the mainland, Lu said.

The spokesman stressed that President Antonio Saca led a delegation to attend a Democratic Pacific Assembly in Taipei in August, showing the high level of exchanges that take place between the two countries, adding that there is no need to worry about any change of relations with the Latin American country.
Meanwhile, Thomas Hou, ROC Ambassador to El Salvador, said in San Salvador that he had a pleasant meeting with Lainez Wednesday afternoon.

Hou said that some El Salvadoran enterprises have designs on the vast market in mainland China, believing that they have the opportunity to increase exports of coffee and other agricultural products to the mainland.
He will try to talk with the business leaders on the subject when he attends a seminar sponsored by the El Salvador Chamber of Commerce this Saturday, Hou said.

He pointed out that Central American countries export a large number of textile products to the United States, and El Salvador textile manufacturers worry about the impact after the United States lifts its quota on mainland Chinese textile products in 2005.

He noted that the Common Market of the South (Mercosur) -- an economic integration agreement between Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay -- recently said it desired to enter into a free trade agreement with mainland China, and Central American countries are simply trying to jump on the bandwagon and this is the reason the chamber of commerce is calling for increased trade with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST KIDD-CLASS DESTROYER TO BE DELIVERED AHEAD OF SCHEDULE: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The first of the four Kidd-class destroyers that the United States agreed to sell to the Republic of China Navy in 2001 is expected to be delivered ahead of schedule and commissioned into service in 2005, the ROC's top envoy to Washington said Wednesday.

David Ta-wei Lee said that he visited a shipyard in Deytens, South Carolina several days ago and was briefed there that the process of de-mothballing and renovating the four Kidd-class destroyers has been going smoothly, with the work expected to be finished ahead of the original schedule.

Lee did not give an exact date on when the first destroyer will be delivered to Taiwan out of security considerations. However, it has been learned that the destroyer will be formally commissioned prior to the Oct. 10 National Day in 2005.

According to the ROC Navy officials who are currently in Deytens to oversee the destroyers' warfare software renovation work, the first Kidd-class destroyer was originally scheduled to be delivered to Taiwan at the end of 2005, followed by the second, third and fourth destroyers between 2006 and 2007.

Lee said that he was impressed by the performance and work ethic demonstrated by the some 300-plus ROC Navy officers who are taking part in the de-mothballing and renovation projects in a shipyard in Charleston, S.C., and another in Deytens.

The navy officers are also working there in preparation for taking delivery of the four 9,600-ton destroyers that the United States originally built for the Shah of Iran in 1979 but were later mothballed when Iran canceled the deal.

According to an assessment by the ROC Navy, the Kidd-class destroyers -- to be equipped with a new missile package -- have superb naval and air defense capabilities and will provide Taiwan with an effective deterrent against a mainland Chinese naval attack up to around the year 2010 ahead of China further beefing up its navy with advanced weapon systems.

The Kidd-class destroyers are also expected to serve as a training platform for ROC naval officers in preparing them to operate Aegis battle management system-equipped Arleigh Burke-class guided missile destroyers in the future, according to the ROC Navy. Taiwan has expressed interest in purchasing the highly advanced Aegis-equipped destroyers, but the United States has not yet agreed to negotiate such a deal.
To be included in the missile package that will be mounted aboard the Kidd-class destroyers will be 248 SM-2 Block IIIA Standard missiles and 32 RGM-84L Block II Harpoon missiles.

Also included in the destroyer sale, which has a price tag of more than NT$28.4 billion (US$818 million) , are shippyard and port support services as well as post-transfer activities, including personnel training and spare parts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS A SOVEREIGN COUNTRY: FORMER S. KOREAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan is an independent country with sovereignty, visiting former South Korean President Kim Young Sam said in Taipei Thursday.

Answering reporters' questions at his first news conference since arriving in Taiwan Monday, Kim said that Taiwan is a sovereign state with a population of 23 million with its president, legislators and local government officials and representatives being popularly elected.
Kim said that Seoul has no alternative but to engage Beijing given the existing world situation, but Taiwan's existence as a sovereign state is an undeniable fact that should not be ignored.
Consequently, Kim said, he has stressed that Taiwan and South Korea should further enhance bilateral ties in political, economic and many other sectors.
Kim disclosed that Beijing had tried to lobby him prior to his Taiwan trip for closer ties with mainland China rather than with Taiwan.

Stressing that he was not moved by the Beijing invitation to visit China again and "meet whoever I want to meet," Kim said that he has no strong urge to visit China and as far as future development is concerned, he would like to let nature take its course.

Kim said that he met with former Chinese President Jiang Zemin on many occasions during the five years he was in office as South Korea's president and became aware that Jiang had great concerns about the Taiwan issue. One of Jiang's concerns was the eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to Kim.
Kim added that he sees no difference in Beijing's policy toward Taiwan in the reign of current Chinese President Hu Jintao from that when Jiang was in office.

Against this backdrop, Kim suggested that Taiwan and mainland China solve their differences via dialogue. "Taiwan should make it very clear that it is ready to return to the negotiating table and an attitude of resistance against this effort by any side would be unacceptable," he said.
Kim pointed out that the United States should also play a key role in efforts to safeguard Taiwan's security given the island's strategically important position in the northeastern Asian region.
The former South Korean head of state arrived in Taiwan Monday for an eight-day visit at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian. It is his fourth visit to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GEARS UP TO ATTRACT EUROPEAN TOURISTS
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has stepped up efforts to attract European tourists to realize its goal of doubling tourist arrivals by 2008, a tourist official said Wednesday.
Huang Lan-hsuan, a Taiwan Tourism Bureau official stationed in Frankfurt, Germany, made the remarks at a promotional presentation held in Rome Wednesday evening.

Republic of China Ambassador to the Vatican Tu Chu-sheng and ROC Representative to Italy Lin Chi-cheng also attended the presentation, which was jointly organized by the Taipei Tourism Office in Frankfurt and the Italian office of China Airlines (CAL) -- Taiwan's largest air carrier.

More than 70 travel agencies in Rome and its nearby areas sent staff members to the presentation in which Huang introduced Taiwan's tourist resources with a slide show. The participants were also entertained with a variety of delicious Taiwanese dishes and snacks. A similar presentation will be held in Milan Thursday.

Huang said the Tourism Bureau has set the goals of attracting 37,000 Germans, 35,000 Britons, 23,000 French, 5,000 Italians, 4,000 Spaniards and 5,000 Scandinavians to make pleasure trips to Taiwan this year.

"All of our promotional programs have so far proceeded smoothly and we have confidence in presenting a satisfactory score card by the end of the year, " Huang said, adding: "If all promotional projects are carried out in line with our goals, the number of total European tourists to Taiwan will reach 160,000 by 2008."

Huang said the Tourism Bureau has adopted many measures to introduce Taiwan's tourist attractions to European tour operators and prospective individual holidaymakers, including taking part in travel fairs, organizing evening presentations and cooperating with airlines in offering tour packages. She said the Taipei Tourism Office in Frankfurt has established promotional networks in France and Britain by cooperating with public relations firms.
Chen Fai-fan, general manager of CAL's Italian office, said CAL hopes to attract more than 12,000 Italian passengers to travel to Asia via its flights annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-SOUTH KOREAN PRES URGES TAIWAN NOT TO OVERREACT TO POWELL'S WORDS

TEXT.P: Visiting former South Korean President Kim Young Sam Thursday urged Taiwan not to overreact to the recent remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell on Taiwan's status, saying "slips of the tongue" do happen to politicians.

Kim was referring to the comment made by Powell early this week in Beijing that Taiwan "does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation." Powell also used the term "reunification" to refer to the eventual development of cross-strait relations.
During a visit to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) headquarters, Kim said the existence of Taiwan is a reality and that "realities are not to be denied by politics."
Kim said Taiwan does enjoy sovereignty and has never been ruled by China.
Taiwan has met all the requirements of a democracy for having a population of 23 million, a directly elected president, independent legislature and a complete judicial system, Kim pointed out.
Kim said the defense capabilities of Taiwan and the firm commitment of the United States to defend Taiwan will deter China from attacking the island.
He called on Taiwan and China to resume dialogue to seek to resolve their disputes through peaceful means.
DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, meanwhile, said Taiwan regrets the fact that Powell felt it necessary to say something inconsistent with reality.
Chang said Kim's visit is very valuable to Taiwan because it represents an enduring friendship that has remained undeterred despite Beijing's protests.
After ending his visit to the DPP headquarters, Kim met Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng over lunch.

According to Wang, Kim believes Taiwan and China should be able to maintain peace and stability as long as they stick to "a certain principle, " noting that Washington's policy toward Taiwan has remained the same since President Bill Clinton.
On the relations between Taiwan and South Korea, Wang said the recent agreement on the resumption of air links between the two sides shows that bilateral ties are improving.
Kim arrived in Taiwan Monday for an eight-day visit at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian. It is his fourth visit to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: More owners lose homes as interest rates bite.
Court actions to repossess homes have leapt to the highest for four years as over-stretched property owners struggle to cope with increased mortgage rates. The latest figures for such actions to seize homes come as a significant slump in demand for new mortgages last month signals growing stress within the already faltering property market.
