The European Union faced institutional paralysis yesterday as a power struggle between its executive and parliament came to a head. Jose Manuel Barroso, the incoming European Commission president, was forced to withdraw his proposed team for the EU's executive rather than face a humiliating rejection by members of the European parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REGRETS 'FRIVOLOUS" LAWSUIT BY RADIO HOST

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office said Thursday it was regrettable that a popular radio talk show host had filed a "frivolous" lawsuit against President Chen Shui-bian and Secretary-General to the President Su Tseng-chang in Taipei District Court earlier that day.
James Huang, deputy secretary-general to the president, was responding to a civil suit by Jaw Shau-kong, the chairman of UFO Radio, that seeks to "restore his reputation."

Jaw's countersuit came on the heels of a suit by President Chen against him and two legislators who cited Jaw's remarks in his program and said that Chen offered US$1 million to former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso as a birthday present, ostensibly to cover up unwanted sexual advances.
Jaw said in his lawsuit that he obtained the information from a Web site he had found using Google.

However, Su described him as a "media disgrace" and an "unscrupulous media man." During a recent visit to a Chinese calligraphy show, President Chen used a play on words to insinuate that Jaw was a "mean people" when asked about his feelings in filing the suit.

Jaw said that freedom of speech, from which a free press is derived, is the basic right of the people, and the nation should give it maximum protection. As a member of the media, he was only quoting news that have been talked about at home and overseas for a long time and there was nothing "improper" or "illegal" in so doing.
Huang said the Presidential Office will be taking Jaw's lawsuit seriously.
Huang pointed out that Jaw has been in the media long enough to understand the standards of journalism, yet he did not follow the basic tenet of verifying a report before transmitting it as "news."
Jaw was citing a mainland Chinese Web site that is well known to have a high degree of animus toward Taiwan, a fact he was most likely aware of, Huang said.

He added that Jaw's rumor about the US$1 million "birthday gift" to the former Panamanian president in his program "created a social disturbance" and was "a serious defamation to the personality and reputation of our national leader as well as damaging to the nation's friendship with its allies."

Huang said that President Chen, to redeem the dignity of a national leader, was forced to file suit last week, and that Moscoso would support the president by providing a written statement under oath to refute the allegations.
Huang said that the matter is now entering the judicial process and the Presidential Office will respect the ruling of the court and will refrain from further comment.

He also noted that Su said he "was chilled to bone" to hear that ill-intended political and senior media figures had spread unfounded "news" without proper verification, adding that such a reaction is understandable to the public.
Huang said that Jaw, however, instead of reflecting on the incident, turned around and filed lawsuit, which was done only to "try to shift the focus from himself."

The president demanded that the three defendants publish the court verdict and an apology to him on the front pages of five major local newspapers for three consecutive days. Jaw asked the president and his top aide to do the same.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENJOYS LEADERSHIP ROLE IN GOVERNMENT IT INFRASTRUCTURE: IDC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government is a world leader in information technology (IT) infrastructure because of its programs and funding of the sector, according to a recent report published by the International Data Corporation (IDC).

Different from most other countries with advanced IT infrastructure, Taiwan's e-solutions have deeply penetrated into the government's daily operations, the IDC said in its Asia/Pacific Policy and Strategies Influencing Government IT Spending, 2004.

Although many Asia-Pacific governments are hoping to get more value and effectiveness from their IT investments, the IDC said that most of them still rely on "brick operations" and pointed out that the key issue now is how to create maximum value-added services through their IT infrastructure to serve the people.

According to an IDC senior researcher in Taiwan, the government of Taiwan has an across-the-board e-program, which has helped its agencies build a massive Internet service basis. The country's continued investment in improving its government sector's e-solutions has achieved initial successes in many fields, he said.

For instance, Taiwan government agencies have performed well in providing quick digital content information on a wide range of fronts to the public, successfully linking the government and a society keen for knowledge, he explained.

"One of the foremost policy challenges for Asian governments is tackling how to successfully develop cross-agency services, further increasing the effectiveness of their IT infrastructure, " an IDC Asia/Pacific research manager said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY PIRACY POLICE UNIT TO BEGIN NOV. 1

TEXT.P: A new, 220-man police unit specializing in preventing intellectual property rights infringements will begin operations Nov. 1, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said Thursday.
The decision was made in an inter-ministerial meeting hosted by Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh.
Since Jan. 1 last year, police officers have been assigned to perform the mission in the form of an ad hoc task force.

According to Lu Wen-hsiung, deputy director-general of the ministry's Intellectual Property Office, the task force has produced good results over the past 20 months and he hopes Taiwan will perform even better in terms of its anti-piracy efforts after the new unit begins its work.

Lu said the United States is expected to announce in December the results of its review on whether to downgrade Taiwan's status or remove the island completely from the "Special 301" priority watchlist.

Lu, who visited Washington, D.C. earlier this month to present Taiwan's anti-piracy efforts to authorities and groups there, said the U.S. side has expressed its satisfaction with what Taiwan has done, especially the amendments to the Copyright Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANGMINGSHAN MOST POPULAR NATIONAL PARK IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Hikers and tourists made a total of 4.06 million person-visits to Yangmingshan National Park in Taipei's north suburb in the first nine months of this year, making it the most popular national park in Taiwan, the Ministry of the Interior reported Thursday.

Yangmingshan, named after the great ancient Chinese philosopher Wang Yangming, is popular mainly because the park can be reached by a 20-minute drive from downtown Taipei, in addition to its volcanic scenery, thick forests and mountain trails, interior ministry officials said.

In its latest survey, the interior ministry found that Taiwan's six national parks posted a total of 12.06 million person-visits during the Jan.-Sept. period, with Yangmingshan attracting about 33 percent of these people.

Trailing Yangmingshan was Kenting National Park located at the southernmost tip of Taiwan, which attracted 3.17 million person-visits, and Taroko Gorge located in the eastern section of the island, which attracted 2.54 million person-visits. Taroko Gorge used to be Taiwan's top tourist attraction. It is known for its stunning natural beauty.

Of the six national parks, Kinmen National Park, located in the ROC-held outlying island of Kinmen, posted a whopping growth of 19 percent in the number of tourists and visitors during the nine-month period, representing the greatest growth in this regard among all six national parks.

By comparison, Jade Mountain National Park in the Central Mountain Range and Sheipa National Park, another high-mountain natural attraction, witnessed a decline of 15 percent and 10 percent, respectively, in numbers of visiting tourists due to damage to their trails caused by typhoons and torrents, according to the survey.
Meanwhile, the survey also found that a total of 870 cases of national park law violations were reported in the six national parks during the nine-month period.

Charges involved trespassing into off-limit wildlife conservation areas, illegal entry by vehicles, installing stands to sell food or items illegally and construction private buildings, in that order, interior ministry officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD GROUP TO VISIT U.S. TO LEARN ABOUT CONTAINER SECURITY PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will organize a delegation to visit the United States next month to learn about cargo and container security management that has been in place since Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks on the U.S.

CEPD Vice Chairman Yeh Ming-feng said Thursday that he is scheduled to go with Yu Shao-wu, head of the Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance, Lin Chi-ming, director of the Department of Navigation and Aviation under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, as well as other officials to leave for the United States Nov. 14 for an 11-day visit.

The delegation is expected to call on the Department of Homeland Security, the Customs Bureau and the Trade Representative Office, the Department of Commerce as well as San Francisco and other harbors.

The delegation will observe the homeland security strategies, cargo clearance and security, as well as control and management of transportation in the hopes of gaining a better understanding of software and hardware facilities concerning the U.S. "Container Security Initiative" as well as the "Customs-Trade Partnership against Terrorism" before returning to Taiwan Nov. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES TO OPEN CARGO LINE TO PRAGUE

TEXT.P: Taipei-based China Airlines will open a cargo route to Prague, the capital of the Czech Republic, by the middle of November, the sixth cargo-only line to Europe.

China Airlines currently has cargo flights to Luxembourg, Amsterdam, Frankfort, Manchester and Milan. With the new line, its cargo shipment network will extend from southern and western Europe to the continent's center, according to a China Airlines statement.
It said there will be two flights per week to Prague.

The Czech Republic has offered many privileges for investors since joining the European Union earlier this year. It also removed a great deal of tariff barriers to attract foreign investors, a move that did attract many Taiwanese investments, including those from Hualon Textile, ASUSTek Computer and Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. Ltd., according to China Airlines.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN REAFFIRMS SINCERITY TO PROMOTE NORMALIZATION OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his sincerity Thursday to promote normalization of relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen also reiterated that his administration's constitutional re-engineering plan is primarily aimed at enhancing government efficiency and upgrading Taiwan's competitiveness.

"Although Taiwan is a sovereign state, it has not been that normal or complete. We need constitutional re-engineering to ensure good governance, " Chen said, adding that it's extremely unfair to Taiwan to distort the constitutional reform program as a tactic to promote de jure independence in a gradual manner.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with Douglas Bereuter, chairman of the U.S. Asia Foundation, and other senior executives of the foundation, who arrived in Taipei Wednesday to attend a meeting marking the foundation's 50th anniversary.
In his May 20, 2000 inauguration address, Chen said he has made it clear that he will not declare Taiwan independence during his tenure.

Even though facing divided opinions in domestic society, Chen said he is still willing to extend an olive branch to mainland China with maximum sincerity to promote normalization of cross-strait relations.
However, Chen said, mainland China has stubbornly insisted on its "one China" principle aimed at forcing Taiwan to accept its "one country, two systems" unification scheme.
"The majority of Taiwan people cannot accept such unification terms, and this is the biggest obstacle to the opening of cross-strait dialogue and negotiations," Chen said.
During the meeting, Chen expressed his gratitude for the U.S. Asia Foundation's contributions to Taiwan's democratic development over the past five decades.
Between 1954 and 1996, Chen said, the foundation has contributed much to having such universal values as democracy, freedom, rule of law and human rights take root in Taiwan.

The foundation has also assisted Taiwan's Legislative Yuan in establishing a library and an assistant system. Moreover, it has helped elite members in various Taiwan quarters to do advanced studies in the United States. Thanks to the foundation's assistance, more than 700 aspiring Taiwan youths, including Vice President Annette Lu, have managed to pursue tertiary academic degrees at U.S. universities over the past years.
For his part, Bereuter said, the U.S. Asia Foundation will cooperate with the Taiwan Asia Foundation in promoting grassroots democratic participation and cross-strait exchanges and dialogue.

In response, Chen said he believes that Taiwan's democratization can spawn a "lighthouse effect" to inspire mainland China to evolve into a liberal democracy in the future. Such a development would be conducive to the easing of cross-strait tensions, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS FRIENDSHIP WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Lee Pei-jen and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte reaffirmed cordial ties between his country and the Republic of China Wednesday, describing the relations as stable, firm and transparent.
Duarte made the remarks at a ceremony to mark the completion of 81 housing units for low income families, which were donated by the ROC government.

In addition to expressing his gratitude to the ROC government for the donation, Duarte also tried to assure Republic of China Ambassador to Paraguay Yen Ping-fan about the security of Paraguayan-Taiwan relations, which Beijing has been trying hard to sabotage.
The public housing units, located in Lambare City, were part of the 1,000 houses that the ROC government donated to poor families in Paraguay.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DO ITS BEST TO CONFORM TO KYOTO PROTOCOL MANDATES: MOEA

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, the country will do its utmost to abide by its new rules aimed at easing emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2), a spokesman for the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

As a constructive member of the global village, Taiwan is poised to comply with the pact's new measures, whatever they may call for, the spokesman said, adding that the ministry and relevant agencies are already carefully assessing the possible impact on Taiwan industries.

The spokesman's remarks fully echoed recent statements by Vice Minister Chen Ruey-lung, who said Tuesday that the MOEA is very concerned about the energy issues underlined by the Kyoto Protocol and that it has actively been promoting public awareness of energy efficiency, energy diversity and pollution prevention.
According to Chen, the MOEA has also worked out a program to help Taiwan's top 100 energy consumers save energy.

Claiming that Taiwan will undoubtedly conform to the Kyoto Protocol's stricter regulations, Chen said that Taiwan will consider resorting to the World Trade Organization mechanisms to seek resolutions to disputes should Kyoto Protocol member states impose trade barriers against Taiwan.

The Kyoto Protocol, which is slated to become effective at the beginning of next year, is expected to have a serious impact on Taiwan's semiconductor, flat panel, automobile and home appliances industries that are high energy consumers.

A total of 36 industrialized countries ratified the Kyoto Protocol Oct. 24, pledging to slash their output of greenhouse gases by the deadline during the 2008-2012 period. The United States and Australia, however, failed to sign the high-profile environmental protection accord.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CANADA INK MEMORANDUM ON COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Vancouver, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Lin Ying-kuo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Tainan county government and the Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration signed a memorandum of cooperation Wednesday with Canada's Innovation and Science Council of British Columbia (ISCBC).
According to the terms of the memorandum, Tainan County and British Columbia will share information on science-based industries, investment and technological transfers.
The authorities will also assist knowledge-based corporations from both countries in seeking cooperation or partnership opportunities, according to the memorandum.
The memorandum will be reviewed every two years to ensure the cooperation is carried out smoothly.
The signatories of the memorandum included Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih, Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration Director-General Tai Chein and ISCBC Chairman Don Rix.

Also Wednesday, a delegation led by Su and Tai to Canada met representatives from a number of Canadian corporations to introduce the excellent investment environment of the science park to potential investors.
The delegation arrived in Vancouver Sunday after concluding a visit to the United States. They departed for Taiwan late Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN OFFICIAL URGES EXPANSION OF TRADE EXCHANGES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan and India should focus on bilateral trade and economic exchanges at the present stage and should then expand the exchanges to other areas, the head of the India-Taipei Association said in Taipei Thursday.

Vijay Gokhale, who was referring to the areas of hi-tech, academia, culture and tourism during an interview with CNA, added that his association is hoping to act as a bridge for promoting such exchanges and cooperation.
He also said that when bilateral trade reaches "a certain degree, " it will be natural for the two countries to sign an agreement to avoid double taxation.

According to statistics released by the Taiwan External Trade Development Center, bilateral trade in recent years has continued to increase and is expected to reach US$2 billion this year. Two-way trade between mainland China and India was between US$6 billion and US$7 billion last year.
But he said it is too early to talk about signing a free trade agreement between the two countries, saying that India has in fact only signed such agreements with Sri Lanka and Thailand so far.
On bilateral cooperation, he made particular mention of the information technology (IT) and software industries.

He said that Taiwan's electronics, communications, IT, manufacturing and food processing industries are competitive, while India is good in the field of software research and development, making the two countries complementary in these areas.

Taiwan's Acer Corp. is now the third-largest PC manufacturer in India, while BenQ is the third-largest cellular phone manufacturer and D-Link Corp., Taiwan's leading supplier of telecommunication devices, has enjoyed good development after venturing into India in 1993, he noted, adding that India has a vast market for communications equipment.

Vehicle parts and components represent another advantage for Taiwan manufacturers, he went on, noting that they are specialized in producing high-priced parts, while Indian manufacturers concentrate mostly on mid- or low-level products.
He noted that although the overall investment environment in India is far from ideal, especially its infrastructure, it has great potential with its vast population and market.
"It is time to invest in India. Come later and the opportunities will be missed forever," he said.

He noted that others have often compared the investment environment between India and mainland China and recalled that when he was sent to the mainland in 1990, the investment environment there was also not good because of insufficient infrastructure, but Taiwan businessmen came in droves nonetheless. Taiwan businessmen also flocked to Vietnam, he noted.
He stressed the three strengths of his country -- vast market, rich resources and well-trained manpower -- which make it a superb option for Taiwan businessmen.

He noted that the middle-class is increasing among the 1.1 billion population, accounting for at least 200-300 million, while those who have the ability to purchase consumer goods probably number 500 million. He urged Taiwan businessmen not to look at the dark side of his country, such as the poor infrastructure, high illiteracy and poverty.

He noted that India's judicial system is patterned after that of Britain, which provides domestic and foreign manufacturers with the same protection under the law. It also offers good conditions for foreign investment, such as the establishment of special economic zones and custom tariff incentives, and allows the products to be sold both domestically and overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO CORPORATIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reaffirmed Thursday the government's commitment to helping domestic corporations enhance their strength, upgrade their quality and improve their investment environment.

Yu said the excellence of Taiwan's innovation technology and the stability of Taiwan's overall economic environment have contributed a great deal to the country's competitiveness, which ranks fourth in the world according to the latest report by the World Economic Forum.

This achievement represents international recognition for the government's efforts to upgrade industrial technology, improve the domestic investment environment and build up the country's economic potential, Yu said.
He made the remarks at the award presentation ceremony of the 15th National Quality Awards.
The winners for the Corporate Award were Gigabyte Technology and Shin Kong Life Insurance Co., while the winner of the Small- and Medium-Sized Business Award was GSK Steering Wheel Co.

The Organization Award went to the Tri-Service General Hospital and the Individual Award went to former National Taiwan University Hospital President Lee Teh-yuan and Provincial Fengyuan Hospital President Chen Chin-tang.
The winner of the Distinguished Contribution Award was Tainan City's Revenue Service Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Red Sox erase 86 years of futility in 4-game sweep of Cardinals.
The Red Sox won the World Series on Wednesday for the first time since 1918, overcoming, at last, the sale of Ruth to the Yankees. The Red Sox, the franchise that perfected heartbreak, won the title with one of the most dominating performances in World Series history, silencing the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-0, in Game 4 to sweep a series in which they never trailed. They won their last eight games of the season.
Wall Street Journal: If election isn't resolved Nov. 2, battles loom in seven key states.
U.S. Presidential Election day is less than a week away, but Americans may not know the winner for days, if not weeks, after the polls close. Never before have states faced so many ballots that won't be counted until after Election Day. This year will see the first nationwide use of provisional ballots, for voters whose eligibility is questioned at the polls. How those ballots are counted has already been a matter of dispute. And with participation expected to be high, states are bracing for an unprecedented number of absentee, early-voting, military and overseas ballots that in some states could total more than one-third of votes. Both campaigns' legal teams are focusing on real and potential problems plaguing a number of states including Ohio, Florida, and five other crucial states. Republicans are poised to challenge voters' legal status, suspecting Democratic fraud. Republicans generally have an interest in damping participation: Larger turnouts typically suggest greater participation from infrequent and downscale voters who tend to vote Democratic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ZOO TO HOST JOINT ANNUAL MEETING OF CBSG, WAZA

TEXT.P: The Taipei Zoo will host the 2004 joint annual conference of the Conservation Breeding Specialist Group (CBSG) and the World Association of Zoos and Aquariums (WAZA) , running from Oct. 29 through Nov. 4, a spokesman for the zoo said Friday.

More than 200 zoo presidents and animal conservationists from over 40 countries will take part in the opening Friday, a prominent event that will coincide with an ongoing art festival being held through January next year, including exhibitions of wild animal posters and worldwide zoo presentations, in Taipei Mass Rapid Transit system galleries, the spokesman said.
According to the zoo official, the CBSG, composed of global conservationists and experts dedicated to biodiversity, is affiliated to the World Conservation Union ICUN's Species Survival Commission.

The WAZA, a non-government group comprising zoos and aquariums around the world, is committed to global conservation through extensive member research, the formulation of achievable strategies and the support of education and direct action campaigns.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT THANKS TOKYO GOVERNOR FOR PROMOTING TAIWAN TOURISM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his heartfelt gratitude to Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara Thursday, saying that Ishihara's assistance in promoting Taiwan's new tourist train is "priceless."

During a meeting with Ishihara at the Presidential Office, Chen also apologized for what he described as "wrongful accusations" against the Tokyo governor by some opposition politicians and pro-unification radicals.

Ishihara was a guest of honor on the maiden journey of the Taiwan Railway Administration's (TRA's) premium-class "Formosa Star" tourist train from Taipei to the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung Tuesday, at a time when normal passenger train services on the route were still suspended because of damage caused by Typhoon Nock-Ten a day earlier. Opposition lawmakers blamed the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) for granting "special privileges" to Ishihara.

"I feel regret that you have been wronged, " Chen told his guest, adding: "There have been some abnormal phenomena in Taiwan society these days. Foreign friends who truly support Taiwan are often stigmatized and for this I feel sadness and regret."
Chen said some countries have spent large sums of money inviting popular fashion models to spearhead their tourism promotion programs.

"What a precious gift Ishihara has given us. He traveled to Taiwan to help promote our country as a new tourist paradise. Without spending a dime, we got such a heavyweight spokesman for our new tourist train," Chen said.

Noting that Japan has been battered by a typhoon and a series of earthquakes in recent days, Chen said that Ishihara honored his promise to visit Taiwan as scheduled. "We appreciate your true friendship and we take pride in having a friend like you, " Chen told Ishihara.

In Taiwan, Chen said, diehard pro-unification and pro-China supporters in Taiwan like to wrong foreigners who support Taiwan's independent sovereign status. Similarly, the international community does not recognize Taiwan's sovereignty and has not treated the 23 million Taiwan people fairly, he added.
For his part, Ishihara said he did not care about the wrongful accusations against him, brushing them aside lightheartedly as "probably just a ploy to get a bit of media hype."

MOTC Minister Lin Ling-san said earlier this week that Ishihara gave the idea of cashing in on Taiwan's hot springs and train services to attract Japanese tourists during his visit to Taipei in May to attend President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration.

"During that trip, I asked Ishihara how to entice Japanese citizens to visit Taiwan. Ishihara reminded me that we can better use Taiwan's hot springs and train services to attract both senior and young Japanese holidaymakers, " Lin recalled, adding that he then directed the TRA and the Tourism Bureau to jointly design the premium "Formosa Star" tourist train and its round-the-island journey.

The tourist train has all sorts of modern amenities and entertainment equipment as well as catering services. Food and beverages are included in the ticket price. Moreover, the TRA has joined forces with five-star tourist hotels and major recreation centers to offer three-day, two-night or four-day, three-night tour packages.
The top-end train will begin formal operations on Oct. 30 and the the tickets for its first three journeys have been fully booked.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLANS TO INVEST IN SOUTH KOREA AT PRESENT: FPG LEADER

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Chairman Y.C. Wang offered high praise Thursday for South Korea's car and shipbuilding industries, but said FPG has no plans to invest in that country at present.
Wang made the remarks during an hour-long meeting with former South Korean President Kim Young Sam at FPG headquarters in Taipei.

During his visit to FPG, Taiwan's petrochemical giant, Kim exchanged views and opinions with Wang on the interaction between South Korea and North Korea and a similar situation that used to exist between West Germany and East Germany prior to unification.
Kim also asked Wang about his group's investment strategies in mainland China.
According to an FPG manager, Kim's call on Wang was purely cordial without any specific purpose.
The former South Korean president arrived Monday for an eight-day visit at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN ENVOY REAFFIRMS TAIWAN-EL SALVADOR DIPLOMATIC TIES

TEXT.P: Salvadoran Ambassador to Taiwan Francisco Ricardo Santana reaffirmed Taiwan-El Salvador diplomatic ties Thursday, saying that the relations are not subject to change.
Santana made the remarks while commenting on wire reports that the El Salvador government will study the possibility of establishing diplomatic and trade relations with mainland China.
It is not the Salvadoran government's stance but merely a suggestion by a local business group, he noted.
Relations between Taiwan and El Salvador have been cordial and solid for a long time and will definitely remain intact, Santana claimed.

Meanwhile, Michel Lu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said the reports came from a local chamber of commerce that said establishing normal ties with the mainland could be good for expanding El Salvador's exports of coffee and pharmaceuticals.
Salvadoran President Antonio Saca visited Taiwan in August, Lu went on, adding that it is evident relations between the two countries are solid and stable.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACEFUL CROSS-STRAIT TIES IN U.S. INTERESTS: U.S. SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A mutually beneficial relationship between Taiwan and mainland China is in the interests of the United States, and Washington should urge the two sides to move in this direction, a respected American scholar said Thursday in Taipei.
Dr. Harry Harding, dean of the Elliot School of International Affairs at George Washington University, made the remarks in an exclusive interview with CNA.

Noting that there is growing concern in the United States about the current tense situation across the Taiwan Strait, including a military buildup on both sides, Harding said Washington is taking a more active role to prevent an outbreak of conflict between Taiwan and the mainland by discouraging either side from taking unilateral action to disrupt the status quo.
Harding made the remarks in reference to comments made recently by U.S. Secretary of States Colin Powell regarding the future course of cross-strait ties.

"From my understanding, he simply made a mis-statement, he mis-stated American policy on that issue, of unification versus independence, " he said, adding that "the really important point is that his statements contain a very clear repudiation from the American perspective of the idea that Taiwan is an independent sovereign country."

Powell said Monday in an interview with the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV in Beijing that the United States will maintain its "one China" policy and that "Taiwan is not independent. It does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation."
Powell also said that the "the United States wants to see both sides not take unilateral action that would prejudice an eventual outcome, a unification that all parties are seeking."
Harding is in Taipei to take part in the 50th anniversary of the Asia Foundation in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATE OF TAICHUNG'S GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM PROJECT STILL IN LIMBO

TEXT.P: The Taichung city council decided Thursday to shelve a draft bill on cooperation with the New York-based Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation to build a branch museum in the central Taiwan city, leaving the fate of the long-talked about project up in the air.

According to a consensus reached during a visit by Taichung Mayor Jason Hu to the Guggenheim Foundation Sept. 21, the two parties should have signed an initial agreement before Oct. 12 and the Taichung city government would have had to pay a total of US$8 million in initial royalties, project management and architectural design fees before Oct. 29 as a guarantee that it would carry out the cooperative project. Failure to do so would cause the foundation to scrap the project.
As the city council did not open its new session until Oct. 18, Hu obtained the consent of the Guggenheim Foundation to postpone the signing of the initial agreement by fax until Oct. 29.

The city council began screening the cooperative project Wednesday and was expected to come to definite decision the following day, but as many councilors felt that some provisions of the proposed agreement are unfair to Taiwan, City Council Speaker Chang Hung-nien ruled at the end of the morning session that the proposal be shelved temporarily.
Chang said the city council will ask Hu to continue negotiating with the Guggenheim Foundation based on recommendations by the city council's legal advisers.

"The negotiation results should be sent to the city council for further discussion before the end of its current session on Dec. 3, " Chang said, adding that the council will also put the draft agreement on its Web site to help Taichung citizens better understand the content.

Observers originally expected that the city council would decide the project's fate by a showdown vote, so the decision to shelve the bill came as a surprise. Some observers said the decision has in effect killed the project as the Guggenheim Foundation is not expected to agree to revise the cooperation terms, nor will it agree to any further delay in striking the deal.

Mayor Hu said he will do his utmost to negotiate with the Guggenheim foundation in hopes of reaching a mutually acceptable formal agreement before Dec. 3. If all goes well, he said, the project will remain alive. But if the foundation would not tolerate any delay, Hu said, the city government will have to forget the project.

Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday the central government fully supports the project adding that both President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Yu Shyi-kun would be willing to meet with Guggenheim foundation executives to lend support behind the Taichung City Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTS GROW 34.3 PERCENT IN FIRST NINE MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's imports in the first nine months reached US$121.92 billion, representing growth of 34.3 percent over the same period of last year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Thursday.
According to DGBAS officials, exports in the same period totaled US$128.29 billion, an increase of 24.2 percent over the same period of last year.

Meanwhile, domestic ports handled 9.76 million twenty-foot-equivalent unit (TEU) containers in the period from January to September, an anual growth of 9.1 percent, with Kaohsiung Port accounting for the bulk of the cargo at 7.28 million TEUs.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPRESENTATIVES OF TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES VISIT EUROPE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: An education delegation from Taiwan arrived in Belgium Thursday to visit various educational organizations and universities in Europe to cement cooperative ties.

In Belgium, the 22-member delegation, led by Vice Minister of Education Lu Mu-lin and composed of representatives from 11 Taiwan universities, will visit the Brussels-based Directorate-General for Education and Culture of the European Union to exchange information about advanced education in Taiwan and Europe, as well as to explore the possibilities for cooperation between the two sides in several educational programs.
The visit takes place amid the government's efforts to promote the globalization of domestic universities.
On Oct. 29, the delegation will visit the Catholic University of Leuven, Belgium, to seek possibilities for educational cooperation, such as the exchanges of students and teachers.
After concluding the visit to Belgium, the delegation will proceed to the Netherlands Oct. 31 to visit Utrecht and Leiden universities.
Meanwhile, Leiden University President A.W. Kist will visit Taiwan from Oct. 30 to Nov. 6 at the invitation of the Ministry of Education.

According to Cho Ming-feng, a session chief responsible for cultural affairs at the Taipei Representative Office in Belgium, Leiden University has maintained academic cooperation with Taiwan for many years and Kist's visit to Taiwan is aimed at increasing cooperation programs between both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCT. 29 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, Oct. 29:
09: 00, A seminar on national security and military strategy organized by the Ministry of National Defense will be held at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei.
09: 00, The Constitutional Court will open hearings on the constitutionality of the statute authorizing the formation of the 3-19 Truth Investigation Commission.
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
09: 00, The inauguration of the WiMAX Industry Alliance will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center.
10:00, New Ambassador of St. Tome and Principe Ladislau Quaresma Frederico d'Almeida will present credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
10:00, The Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan will hold a news conference in front of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office.
10: 30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a routine news conference at the council's headquarters.
10: 30, Former South Korean President Kim Young Sam will call on Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh at Kaohsiung City Hall.
16: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive the Benevolence Awards winners at the Presidential Office.
16:00, The Bureau of Foreign Trade will hold a news conference at the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
16: 20, The Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
17: 30, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will receive the Best Veteran Award winners at the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS SOVEREIGN COUNTRY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan is an independent sovereign country, a fact that nobody can deny, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.

In a meeting with visiting former South Korean President Kim Young Sam, Yu said that Taiwan is a democratic country with its own territory, people, Constitution and elected president. He described Taiwan and mainland China as "one country on each side" of the Taiwan Strait, neither of which belongs to the other.
Yu made the remarks after U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell said during a recent visit to Beijing that Taiwan does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation.

The premier expressed gratitude to Kim, whose Taipei visit has faced strong opposition from Beijing, for his long-term support for Taiwan and his moral encouragement to the island after Powell's remarks.
Noting that Taiwan is a democratic country, Yu added that the island also performs well economically and has become the 15th-largest trading country in the world.

In addition to expressing admiration to Kim for his long-term contribution to South Korea's democratic movement, Yu also expressed hope that Kim can promote a dialogue mechanism or a forum among Taiwan, Japan and South Korea in a bid to help strengthen security and stability in Northeast Asia and that he will push for ministerial-level visits between Taiwan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRAISES ASIA FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised the Asia Foundation Thursday for its contributions to Taiwan's democratization and economic development.

Addressing a dinner party in celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Asia Foundation, Chen said the organization has made a great many contributions to democratic, economic and social developments in nations of the region.
Taiwan could not have made the achievements in the economic and political fields it enjoys now without the foundation, according to Chen.
Taiwan is willing to share with other nations its experiences in the rule of law, economic, educational and social developments over the past five decades, he went on.

He also expressed hope that the Asia Foundation in Taiwan and its counterpart in the United States will keep close contact and will cooperate to further promote civil exchanges between Taiwan and other nations in Asia.

Speaking on the same occasion, Vice President Annette Lu recognized the achievements made by the foundation in the promotion of democratic development and the protection of human rights and women's interests in Asia.
Lu said that she herself has benefited from the assistance granted by the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 29, or the 16th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1618: Sir Walter Raleigh, English courtier, navigator, colonizer and writer, is beheaded in the Tower of London for treason against King James I at the age of 54. His literary works include poetry, memoirs, and a world history.
1863: Henri Dunant, Swiss philanthropist, founds the International Red Cross. He was a joint recipient of the 1901 Nobel Peace Prize.
1881: The first national political party is founded in Japan.
1911: Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American journalist and newspaper publisher, dies at the age of 64. He owned papers in St. Louis and New York City as well as established the Pulitzer Prize.
1923: The Republic of Turkey is proclaimed, with nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk as its first president.
1927: Russian archaeologist Peter Kozlov discovers the tomb of Genghis Khan in the Gobi Desert.
1929: "Black Tuesday" follows "Black Thursday" on Wall Street as the crisis of confidence hits the New York stock market, leading to the Great Depression of the 1930s.
1932: The Normandie, one of the three most luxurious ships ever built, is launched in France. The 300 meter-long vessel crossed the Atlantic Ocean in just over four days. A fire destroyed the ship while it was berthed in New York Harbor in 1942.
1942: Nazis massacre 16,000 Jews in Pinsk, Russia.
1944: In his capacity as supreme commander of the China Theater of War, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appoints U.S. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China Theater of War. Meanwhile, U.S. Gen. Daniel L. Sultan is appointed commander in chief of the U.S. Expeditionary Forces in India.
1945: Anna Rosenberg is given the first U.S. Medal of Freedom ever awarded to a woman.
1953: The North American F-100 Super Sabre jet fighter sets a record by reaching a speed of 1,215 kilometers per hour, becoming the first jet capable of being operated at supersonic speeds.
1962: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a statement refusing to recognize India's position of using the "McMahon Line" as the border line between India and China.
1964: Tanganyika unites with Zanzibar, forming Tanzania.
1974: A five-member Korean parliamentary mission headed by the chairman of the Korean Democratic Republican Party, Rhee Hyo Sang, and 130 members of the Japanese Diet, arrive in Taipei to take part in celebrations marking President Chiang Kai-shek's 87th birthday.
1977: Taiwan's first IC (integrated circuit) plant, under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, is inaugurated in Chutung in Hsinchu County.
1980: A declaration by Deng Xiaoping, vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, that Mao Zedong made serious political mistakes during his rule, is made public.
1981: The Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Chamber of Industry of Guatemala sign a cooperation agreement to promote economic, trade and cultural relations.
1984: The Chinese team from Taiwan wins second place in the World Amateur Baseball Championship in Cuba.
1985: The first prototype of "Ching Kuo," the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, bursts its nose-wheel during a test flight at Chingchuenkang Air Force Base in Taichung.
1986: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that ROC-U.S. trade talks on wine and tobacco imports are in a stalemate. Washington charged that Taipei failed to keep promises of providing greater market access for U.S. beer, wine and tobacco, and said the United States would draft retaliatory measures against the ROC under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974.
1998: John Glenn, U.S. astronaut, blasts off aboard the space shuttle Discovery at the age of 77, 36 years after his first space mission.
1999: Carleton S. Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's No. 2 computer maker, arrives in Taipei for a two-day whirlwind visit.
2000: Taiwan's China Airlines inaugurates a new flight route between Taipei, Penang in Malaysia, and Medan in Indonesia.
2000: A poll unveiled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party shows that only 33.2 percent of the Taiwan public supports the Cabinet's decision to halt construction on the island's fourth nuclear power plant, while 47.5 percent oppose the decision.
2001: The Republic of China Ministry of Finance approves an application from Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp. -- the second-largest banking group in Japan and the world -- to upgrade its local representative office to a branch office.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When a ruler regards his ministers as his hands and feet, they regard him as their belly and heart; when he regards them as dogs and horses, they regard him as a common citizen; when he regards them as dirt and grass, they regard him as a robber and enemy."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO AUTHORIZE PROPER PERSON TO NEGOTIATE CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged mainland China Friday to authorize a appropriate person or persons to negotiate with Taiwan for the opening of direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san made the call during a regular news conference.

Chiu said the Republic of China government has demonstrated goodwill and flexibility toward the proposal for carriers from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to operate direct non-stop charter flights during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday which will begin Feb. 6, 2005 and runs through Feb. 13.

"We are hopeful that neither side would set any political prerequisite for negotiations about such holiday charter flight services for the convenience of Taiwan businesspeople operating in mainland China intending to return home for family reunions, "Chiu said, adding that the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, would name a proper person or persons to discuss relevant technical details with Taiwan as early as possible.

With Beijing's consent, Taiwan carriers operated special charter flights between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau during the 2003 Chinese New Year period. Such services were not offered during the 2004 Chinese New Year holiday because Beijing insisted that mainland carriers be allowed to join such flight services while declining to negotiate technical details with Taiwan. The ROC government said that as the opening of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flight services involve exercise of public authority, prior negotiations are necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL M'LAND CHINESE MURDER SUSPECT CLAIMS HE SHOT PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: An illegal mainland Chinese immigrant who has been locked up since Oct. 21 on suspicions of murdering a local elected official in Kaohsiung, claimed recently that he was the shooter in the assassination attempt against President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of the March 20 presidential election.

Wang Erjiang -- who had been using a forged Taiwan ID card with the name Chen Chih-wei -- claimed to prosecutors in the southern county of Kaohsiung several days ago that he shot at the president because he was angry at being awakened by the noise of firecrackers while he was napping in a park near the street in Tainan, southern Taiwan where the president's campaign motorcade was passing.
Wang said that he does not remember how many times he shot at the president and claimed that he threw the gun into the Tainan Canal after the shooting.

Most prosecutors might consider Wang's claims as frivolous because of the many holes in his story, but some investigators on the 319 special investigative task force found that Wang looks "about 50 percent" like a suspect that the task force has been trying to track down.

Kuo Chen-ni, a spokeswoman for the task force, said at a press conference in Tainan City Friday that her team does not exclude the possibility of dredging up the gun that Wang has claimed he dumped in the Tainan Canal.
Kuo said that only solid evidence counts. She added that the 319 task force will subpoena Wang shortly for further questioning about his shooting story.

Wang was arrested in Kaohsiung Oct. 21 on suspicions of shooting Kuo Ching-hua, chief of the rural township of Yungan, Kaohsiung County, in May this year. Kuo died of gun wounds in hospital about one month later.
During a recent questioning, Wang claimed that he shot the president but could not pinpoint where exactly in the Tainan Canal he dumped the weapon used in the assassination attempt.

According to the investigators, Wang first arrived in Taiwan in early 2002 under an arrangement by a cross-strait "snake head" human smuggling ring. Within half a year, he was given an ROC passport with the name of Chen Chih-wei. He then used the passport to exit and enter Taiwan several times via Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. The last time he entered Taiwan was in November 2003. Law enforcement authorities said they believe that Wang was supported by an organized crime ring in southern Taiwan.

Meanwhile, the 319 task force spokeswoman said Friday that two more men, Wu Cheng-tao and Tsai Ming-che, were recently indicted for possessing bullets that match the characteristics of the one found at the scene of the March 19 shooting. So far, five people have been indicted and 10 more are currently in police custody on similar charges, Kuo noted.

On August 30, officials from the State Public Prosecutor-General's Office reported that 12 bullets had been found that were identical in structure with the one found lodged in President Chen's jacket after he was shot.

Kuo also said that after the election-eve shooting, investigators followed up on more than 3,100 cases regarding violation of regulations on guns and ammunition. Of these cases, 22 involved ammunition that match the characteristics of the bullet found in Chen's jacket, according to Kuo.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LEGISLATOR STABBED

TEXT.P: Legislator Shen Chi-huei of the opposition People First Party (PFP) required several stitches after being stabbed in the back of her head and neck Friday, doctors at Taichung Veterans General Hospital said.
Shen, whose injuries are not life-threatening, also suffered a mild concussion, the doctors said, adding that they will keep her in hospital for further observation.

Shen, who is seeking another term in the year-end legislative elections, was attending a veterans activity when she was stabbed from behind with a pair of scissors wielded by Hsu You-san, a 80-year-old veteran.

Taichung City Councilwoman Shen Yu-lien, sister of Shen Chi-huei, said that the veteran had lost his life savings in an investment scam by a fraud ring and had solicited her sister's assistance without success.
Legislator Shen said in hospital that she bears no ill-will toward Hsu and forgives him out of consideration of the fact that he was the victim of a fraud ring.

Hsu told Taichung City police during questioning that he had petitioned Legislator Shen several times for her assistance to get his money back. He also said that he began to suspect that the legislator had colluded with the investment company.

Meanwhile, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Shu will face justice for the stabbing incident, and vowed to step up protection for legislative candidates, although he added that this doesn't necessarily mean more police officers will be assigned to such duty.
The premier said that he regrets the stabbing incident and that he has instructed Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan to find out how the incident took place.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, after visiting Shen at the hospital, said that he has instructed the police department to ask legislative candidates whether they need any police officers to escort them for protection.
Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP whip in the Legislative Yuan, immediately condemned violence against legislative candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT BEDROCK OF U.S.-TAIWAN RELATIONS: VP LU

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Relations Act is the bedrock of relations between Taiwan and the United States, and the U.S. law stipulates clearly that differences across the Taiwan Strait must be resolved peacefully, Vice President Annette Lu said Friday.

Lu invited all parties concerned to return to the Taiwan Relations Act at a time when widespread anxiety has been aroused in the country by the recent remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell in Beijing that she said have added confusion to the question of Taiwan's sovereignty and U.S.-Taiwan relations.
Lu called for the people of Taiwan not to panic over Powell's remarks, which she said do not reflect a change in the U.S. stance and policy toward Taiwan.
The vice president called for her fellow compatriots to realize that in the Taiwan Relations Act, the U.S. government does not say that Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China.
Lu made the remarks while stumping for Legislator Chao Yung-ching of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

She said that following the controversies stirred up by Powell's remarks, Washington has reiterated that its policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged, that it will not pressure Taiwan to reunify with mainland China, and that the so-called Taiwan issue should be resolved in a peaceful manner.

Lu added that although Powell's remarks have hurt the feelings of the people of Taiwan, they should respond by engaging in some soul searching about their own ideas and positions on Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 10.37 points to close at 5,705.93.
The bourse opened at 5,693.11 and fluctuated between 5,717.7 and 5,673.07 during trading. A total of 2.94 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.59 billion (US$1.93 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 2.2 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2 percent, textile stocks at 2.1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.8 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 469 to 185, with 130 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP SOLICITS SUPPORT FOR PROPOSED DRAFT BILL ON CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) called on the legislative caucuses of the various political parties Friday to solicit support for its proposed draft bill on cross-Taiwan Strait peace, but was rejected outright by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP legislative whip, said the progress of cross-strait exchanges should have the support of all political parties and that the proposed bill represents an earnest hope of a contribution to break the cross-strait impasse.
PFP Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang said that cross-strait talks should not just be "empty talk" and that a cross-strait peace promotion bill would serve as a platform for cross-strait exchanges.

However, Tsai Huang-liang, the DPP whip in the legislature, said that the PFP's proposal is "impractical" and "an encroachment on the right of the executive branch that may also be unconstitutional or illegal."

Instead, he urged the PFP to support a bill authorizing the Executive Yuan to take on a major arms procurement package from the United States, saying that only a stable national defense, boosted by the arms procurement, will lay the solid groundwork for cross-strait talks.

DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi said that cross-strait peace and exchanges should be based on the principle of equal footing and that the PFP-proposed bill would constrain Taiwan rather than the other side of the strait.
Lee said that cross-strait talks must be based on strength and not illusion and that the country's self-defense capability should not be forfeited.
"The PFP has to support the arms procurement bill, otherwise peace is only empty talk," he said.
PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei said that if the DPP has differences over the proposed bill, it can propose its "own version of bill."

The PFP caucus incurred the ire of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP, after it failed to call on the TSU caucus. Chen Chien-ming, TSU legislative whip, rushed to the DPP caucus to question if the cross-strait peace promotion bill is based on the stance of "unification, independence or one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait."
The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which is an ally of the PFP, lent its support to the proposed bill.

Huang Teh-fu, KMT legislative whip, said that cross-strait peace is the common aspiration of all sides and that an insistence on peace is not capitulation, but allows both sides to have the opportunity for development.
The KMT and the PFP advocate peace and are opposed to war, Huang said, adding that the passing of the law would be a step in the right direction.

The DPP has so far failed in its attempt to put the arms procurement bill on the agenda for legislative review before the Dec. 11 legislative elections because the opposition parties feel there is not enough time to review the bill before the elections, as the legislature is scheduled to go into a one-month recess starting Nov. 10 in preparation for the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUALITY OF TAIWAN'S SERVICE SECTOR BARELY PASSES INSPECTION

TEXT.P: The average quality of Taiwan's front-line service sector has been rated below par at 60.14 marks on a 100-point scale, with half of the service industries surveyed failing the evaluation, according to the survey results released Friday.
The Landis Taipei Hotel won the highest rating at 83 marks among the 52 corporations surveyed.
The survey was conducted by the Global View Monthly in cooperation with SGS Taiwan, which provides inspection, verification, testing and certification services.

Secret inspectors were assigned to carry out the survey from Sept. 1-20 by checking on 52 hotels, chain restaurants, department stores, convenience stores, hypermarkets and electrical appliance hyper-stores.

The average rating for hotels was 66.5 marks. The top five highest-rated hotels were the Landis Taipei Hotel (83 marks) , the Westin Taipei (75 marks), Kaohsiung's Grand Hi-Lai Hotel (75 marks), the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel (73 marks) and the Evergreen Laurel Hotel (69.5 marks).

Chain restaurants scored an average of 61.38 marks, with the top five being Wang Steak (74 marks), Tasty (70.5 marks), T.G.I. Friday's (70.5 marks) , Taoban Restaurant (68 marks) and Ten Ren Cha For Tea (67.5 marks).
The average rating for department stores was 60.38 marks. The top three were Dayeh Takashimaya (72 marks), Hanshin (68 marks) and Shin Kong Mitsukoshi (65.4 marks).
Convenience stores scored an average of 59.79 marks, with the top three being FamilyMart (62.9 marks) , 7-11 (59.6 marks) and Nikomart (59.5 marks).
The average rating for hypermarkets was 56.78 marks. The top three were RT-Mart (62.3 marks) , Costco (61.5 marks) and Carrefour (55.2 marks).
Electrical appliance hyper-stores scored an average of 55.6 marks, with the top three being Linkuswell Technologies (63 marks) , E-Life Mall (59 marks) and Tsann Kuen (58 marks).

DOC.HEADLINE: 8TH ACG ANNUAL MEETING TO BE HELD IN NOVEMBER IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 8th annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Central Securities Depository Group (ACG) is slated to take place Nov. 1-2 in Taipei, organizers said Friday.

More than 50 senior executives from 20 securities central depository firms in Asia-Pacific countries, including Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore and Thailand, are expected to take part in the event, according to the Taiwan Securities Central Depository Co. (TSCD).
Jill M. Considine, chairwoman and CEO of the U.S.-based Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation (DTCC) , will also attend the meeting as a keynote speaker, TSCD officials said.

During the meeting, the TSCD will sign a memorandum on cooperation and exchanges with the Japan Securities Depository Center (JASDEC) and Japan Securities Settlement and Custody Inc. (JSSC), the officials added.
The ACG, which was founded in 1997 in Hong Kong, consists of 21 members from the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TROUPE PERFORMS BUDDHIST CHANTS IN OTTAWA
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Wu Hsien-kuang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Members of a musical troupe from Taiwan's Buddhist Fukuangshan Temple visited Taiwan Representative to Canada Thomas Chen at his office in Ottawa Thursday, and were treated with a luncheon by Chen's wife Chang Mei-he at Chen's residence.

The group had entertained the couple, staff of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada, Taiwan expatriates in Canada and a Canadian audience the previous evening with peaceful Buddhist chants.
Following the performance, the audience also heard an address from the Fukuangshan Temple founder, Master Hsing Yu, and received his blessing.

The troupe set off for Toronto after the visit and is scheduled to fly to Saint Louis in the United States, where it will give its last concert of the North American tour Sunday before returning to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELITE-NURTURING PROJECT EXPECTED TO KICK OFF BY YEAREND: CEPD

TEXT.P: A project aimed at nurturing high-caliber intellectuals and technocrats for the country in research institutes abroad is expected to kick off by the end of this year, a Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) official said Friday.

Operations of the new elite-building project -- to be jointly sponsored by the CEPD, the Ministry of Education and the National Science Council (NSC) -- is expected to begin in December at the latest to begin accepting applications by Taiwan students hoping to pursue advanced studies with state funding in research institutes abroad, mainly the United States, according to CEPD Vice Chairman Hsieh Fa-ta.

Under the program, potential government scholarship winners can choose their subjects for advanced studies in institutes abroad under three major research areas -- fundamental sciences, humanistic and social studies, and national development -- that a guiding committee of the project has mapped out.

Under the three major areas, there will be 12 research fields for the applicants to choose from. These fields include biotechnology, image display, digital content, telecom technology, semiconductors, energy technology, environments and natural disasters, nanotechnology and cutting-edge materials, international law and politics, as well as arts and history, Hsieh added.

He noted that a group of officials and academics, including Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng and NSC Chairman Wu Mao-kun, and presidents of several leading universities around Taiwan, traveled to San Francisco last week to meet members of Academia Sinica and U.S.-based Taiwanese academics for discussions on the elite studying abroad program.
Quite a few valuable solutions were concluded during the meetings that will serve as guidelines when the project is implemented, Hsieh said.

The program was initiated earlier this year after the government became aware that there is an ever-growing gap between Taiwan's educational sector and the industrial sector in terms of quality and quantity of supplies of high-caliber manpower.
The government decided to allow more Taiwan students to seek advanced studies abroad with government funding in an effort to reverse the trend.

In a recent speech, Premier Yu Shyi-kun quoted a research report by the Council for Cultural Affairs as indicating that Taiwan's hi-tech industrial sector as a whole has 6,100 openings for various jobs this year that are still unfilled and that the manpower shortage is expected to top 10,000 individuals in 2005.

Yu said that Taiwan's hi-tech industrial sector -- a driving force pushing Taiwan to become one of the world's economic powerhouses -- was established and is nurtured by high-caliber scientists and specialists who returned to Taiwan after obtaining advanced degrees abroad.

In recent years, however, the number of Taiwan students going abroad for higher education, particularly to the United States, has continued to drop, Yu said. This is a situation about which the government is most concerned, he added.

According to government tallies, a total of 13,767 Taiwan students went to the United States for advanced studies in 2002, compared with 10,324 students in 2003, marking a whopping decline of 25 percent.

Hsieh said that there are a variety of factors behind the decline, including the fact that more and more Taiwan college graduates continued their studies at Taiwan graduate schools, while the considerable increase in the numbers of students from mainland China and South Korea seeking advanced studies in the United States is another factor adversely affecting the enrollment of students from Taiwan.
