DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND INTEREST RATE HIKE HAS LITTLE IMPACT ON TAIWAN COMPANIES

TEXT.P: Mainland China's surprise key interest rate hikes will not have a large impact on Taiwan businesses operating there, a market analyst predicted Friday.

K. C. Chung, a vice manager at the JIH SUN Securities Investment Consulting Co. Ltd., said the mainland's decision to increase the interest rates will only have a slight impact on Taiwan companies, as a 0.27 percentage point hike is on par with a 0.25 percentage point raise made by Taiwan's central bank in late September, Chung said.

The People's Bank of China announced a day earlier that it will adjust its one-year loan and deposit interest rate from 5.31 percent to 5.58 percent and from 1.98 percent to 2.25 percent, respectively,

According to Chung, the mainland's interest rate raises are aimed at supporting its efforts to curb its overheating economy and a complementary measure to ease strong pressure on the renminbi to appreciate.

A Taiwan company manager said that Taiwan businesses with operations in mainland China will have to pay more interest on their loans, but he pointed out that the additional costs will be less significant than an appreciated renminbi, as many of them are involved in export-oriented businesses.

Academia Sinica researcher Wu Chung-shu and National Chengchi University Professor Chu Hau-min both said that the mainland move has no immediate leverage on Taiwan's central bank, which is not expected to raise interest rates in the short term due to its higher-than-expected interest rate hike in September.

Wu said that an interest rate increase is necessary if the mainland wants to stem its economic growth rate. The mainland economy in the third quarter expanded by 9 percent, well exceeding a government target of 7 percent.

Chu contended that a deposit interest rate hike will help lure foreign capital into the mainland, but will put increasing pressure on its currency to appreciate. He predicted that the mainland will raise its interest rates again in the near future to gauge an acceptable range for the renminbi to gain in value.

DOC.HEADLINE: EL SALVADOR REAFFIRMS TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca assured Taipei Thursday that his government will not switch recognition to Beijing during his term, following reports that El Salvador is to study the possibility of forming diplomatic relations with mainland China.

Saca emphasized that the friendship between El Salvador and Taiwan has remained unchanged and that if necessary, he will telephone President Chen Shui-bian up to clarify the misunderstanding, according to ROC Ambassador to El Salvador Hou Ping-fu.

It was reported Wednesday that the government of the Central American nation would "analyze the possibility" of establishing diplomatic and trade relations with the mainland in response to a call from a group of Salvadoran business leaders who believe normalizing ties with Beijing will help Salvadoran goods gain access to the Chinese market.
Saca and Salvadoran Foreign Minister Francisco Lainez phoned Hou in person to clarify the reports Thursday morning.
Hou said he had just returned to his residence from the El Salvador Ministry of Foreign Affairs when the report was published Wednesday.

Hou said he felt at the time that the report was mistaken because he and Lainez had just been discussing strengthening bilateral cooperation in terms of agriculture, environmental protection and career guidance for young people.

Although El Salvador is under intense pressure from the private sector, which is pushing the government to exchange trade offices with the mainland, diplomatic relations between Taiwan and El Salvador have remained steady, Hou said.

In addition to an exchange of visits by the heads of state of both countries earlier this year, a series of visits to Taiwan by Salvadoran government officials will take place over the next five months, Hou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT VISITS KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Former South Korean President Kim Young Sam said Friday he looks forward to seeing enhanced cultural and commercial exchanges between Taiwan and South Korea.

Kim, who is currently on an eight-day visit to Taiwan at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian, made the remarks while meeting with Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh at the municipal hall of the southern Taiwan port city.

Despite a cooling-off in Taiwan-South Korea relations following Seoul's switching of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, which prompted Taipei to cut ties with Seoul Aug. 23, 1992, Kim said friendship between the two countries has gradually regained steam.
"I hope our two countries can continue to expand engagements and cooperation in various fields for mutual benefit," Kim said.

For his part, Hsieh said that throughout history, Taiwan and Korea have experienced being bullied but they have never bullied other countries. This similar background has contributed to the development of friendship between the two countries, Hsieh said, adding that Kaohsiung has formed sisterhood ties with South Korea's second-largest city of Busan and maintains close exchanges with several other South Korean cities.

In the past, Hsieh said, average Taiwan people were not familiar with South Korea but thanks to the popularity here of South Korean soap operas, Hsieh said, many Taiwan people have become fascinated with the country.
Hsieh lauded Kim for his contributions to South Korea's democratic development, calling him South Korea's "Mr. Democracy."

Kim said South Korea has come a long way liberating its people from authoritarian rule and building up a liberal democracy. "In the pursuit of democracy, I consistently fought against armed forces with courage, self-confidence and perseverance," he added.
Noting that Taiwan's democratization process has been similar to that of South Korea, Hsieh said he has much to learn from Kim.

Later in the day, Kim toured Kaohsiung Harbor in the company of Deputy Mayor Yao Kao-chiao. Kim said he was impressed by the port facilities and by the harbor's outstanding geographic location and natural conditions that have helped made Kaohsiung into a fine deep-water port.

Kim arrived in Taipei Monday for his fourth visit to Taiwan. In the past few days, he has met with President Chen and other local political heavyweights, as well as delivering a speech at National Chengchi University.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN REMAINS UNCHANGED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged despite recent remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell on Taiwan.

During interviews with Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite TV and CNN Monday in Beijing, Powell denied that Taiwan "has sovereignty as a nation" and referred to the possible development of cross-strait relations as "peaceful reunification," which is wanted by all parties.

Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said Powell's remarks were the "most harsh" remarks from the United States over the past three decades and called in Douglas Paal, director of the American Institute in Taiwan in Taipei, for consultations.

The premier reiterated that the consultations show that U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged and continues to be based on the Taiwan Relations Act under which the United States promises to provide Taiwan with sufficient defensive weapons, and the "six assurances."

The latter means that the United States will not set a date for ending arms sales to Taiwan, will not hold prior consultations with mainland China on arms sales to Taiwan, will not play any mediation role between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, has not agreed to revise the Taiwan Relations Act, has not altered its position regarding sovereignty over Taiwan, and will not exert pressure on Taiwan to enter into negotiations with the mainland.
Powell has also clarified that he should have said cross-strait "peaceful resolution, " instead of "peaceful reunification, " the premier said.
But the premier also noted that Powell's remarks went out of the bounds laid out in a briefing U.S. officials gave to Taiwan prior to his departure for a three-nation visit in Asia last weekend.
The premier said that senior U.S. officials had briefed a Taiwan mission before Powell's visit and that he himself read the report but saw nothing resembling Powell's remarks.
Yu said that Powell's remarks during the interviews took him "by surprise" and show that Taiwan should further work on its relations with the United States.
When asked why the national security system was not made aware of Powell's possible remarks beforehand, the premier said "the entire government, including myself, should review this question."

Meanwhile, the premier said that he had not read a report by world-renowned U.S. forensic expert Henry Lee on the March 19 election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, either in English or in Chinese.

Lee submitted his report based partly on forensic studies he made during a trip to Tainan where the shooting took place in April and partly on information provided by the Criminal Investigation Bureau, in late August.
The premier said that out of respect for judicial independence, the Executive Yuan will not interfere with it.

He was fielding a question in the Legislative Yuan from Legislator Huang Chao-shun of the opposition Kuomintang on whether he had read Lee's report and whether the spirit of the original English copy was retained in the Chinese translation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT FROM GUGGENHEIM ON TAICHUNG CITY COUNCIL'S DECISION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An official from the New York-based Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation refused to comment Thursday on a decision by the Taichung city council to shelve a long-discussed project to build a Guggenheim branch in the central Taiwan city.

The city council began a two-day screening session Wednesday and was expected to come to a definite decision the following day, but as many councilors felt that some provisions of the proposed agreement were unfair to Taiwan, Council Speaker Chang Hung-nien ruled Thursday that the proposal should be shelved temporarily.
Chang also said the city council will ask Taichung Mayor Jason Hu to attempt to continue negotiating with the Guggenheim Foundation, based on recommendations by the city council's legal advisers.
A staff member of the office of Thomas Krens, executive director of the Guggenheim Foundation, said the foundation would not comment on the matter.
On whether Hu had contacted Krens to discuss the latest demand by the councilors that the draft agreement be amended, the staffer said that even if there was such contact, it would be secret.

The promotion of a Taichung branch has been in the works for some time -- Hu made it one of his major campaign platforms when he ran for the mayorship in 2002 -- and the mayor went to New York last month to discuss how to push for the long-delayed international cooperation project, which has been plagued by problems on how to finance it, after the government promised Aug. 31 to earmark NT$2 billion (US$58.99 million) in its 2005 budget to help finance the project.
The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation is founded in 1937. Its primary accomplishment has been the construction of a number of international museums in New York, Venice, Bilbao, Berlin and Las Vegas.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION OF PETROCHEMICAL SECTOR TO TOP NT$1.8 TRILLION IN 2004

TEXT.P: The total production of Taiwan's petrochemical sector is expected to amount to NT$1.8 trillion (US$53.73 billion) in 2004, which will represent a growth of 27.3 percent over last year, according to a report by the Industry Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) Friday.
The demand for basic industrial chemicals including ethylene, polylene and butadiene is estimated at 591.9 metric tons, and that for aromatics is estimated at 536 metric tons, the report said.

It said the combined production of petrochemical intermediates, synthetic fibers, polymers and petroleum products in the first three quarters of this year amounted to NT$1.36 trillion, up 31.7 percent compared with the levels of the same period last year.

Of these products, petrochemical intermediates posted the highest growth rate at 48.2 percent mainly because the prices of petrochemical raw materials were rising in tandem with soaring oil prices, according to the report.
On the market outlook for next year, the report predicted that the margin of profit for CPL, VCM, EG and PTA will expand owing to strong global demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PUBLIC BUS TRANSFORMED TO PROMOTE TOURISM

TEXT.P: Taipei city buses on three routes in Mucha, Peitou and Yangmingshan were dressed up in bright colors Friday to attract passengers for a "tourist ride."

The buses include the "Brown 15" that serves the Maokung tea-production area in Mucha, the "Small 25" serving Peitou, which is famous for hot springs, and the "No. 260" that passes through the scenic mountainous region of Yangmingshan, officials of the Taipei City Department of Transportation said Friday at a news conference to announce the start of the tourism drive.

They said that the vehicles are adorned with paintings that feature three different tourist topics -- drinking tea in autumn, enjoying hot springs in winter, and touring flower gardens in spring -- in order to draw the public to visit Taipei tourist spots.

To mark the start of the sight-seeing buses, the city government has also issued sets of commemorative tickets for the bus and MRT systems with various coupons for food, hot spring activities and free bus rides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO CHARTER FLIGHTS PLANNED FROM CENTRAL TAIWAN AIRPORT TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines, in cooperation with Chingchuankang (CCK) International Airport in central Taichung County, will provide two charter flights to Shikoku, Japan in late November, a government official said Friday.

According to the spokesman for the central coordination service center under the Executive Yuan, the planned charter flights bound for Japan are a follow up to the enthusiastic public response to a similar service launched by CCK Airport to Seoul since Oct. 10.
The two charter flights for Shikoku are slated for Nov. 13 and Nov. 20.

The Seoul-bound charter flights, also operated by Mandarin Airlines on a regular basis, marked the start of international air travel service for CCK International Airport, which opened in early March this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE DIETMEN TO PROMOTE EXCHANGES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of pro-Taiwan Japanese dietmen from the Democratic Party (DP) said Friday that they will promote bilateral exchanges with Taiwan.

The DP Dietmen's Alliance for Japan-Taiwan Friendship said in a resolution that it will be dedicated to promoting friendship with Taiwan, and will organize a group to visit Taiwan soon and strengthen exchanges.

The group, which is comprised of 50 lawmakers from the lower house and 17 from the upper house, passed the resolution at its annual conference during which the participants also voted for Motohisa Ikeda, a lawmaker from the lower house, to serve as the new president.

Ko Se-kai, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, and deputy representative Chen Hung-chi also addressed the meeting saying that they conveyed the concerns of President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Yu Shyi-kun on the earthquakes recently in Niigata Prefecture.
Deputy representative Chen donated two million yen (US$185.000) on behalf of the Republic of China government Tuesday to the Niigata government for victims' relief.

Ko also expressed appreciation for the support and friendship of DP dietmen toward Taiwan, hoping that they can help promote visa-free treatment for Taiwan tourists to further strengthen bilateral exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS SEEKING ADVANCED DEGREES IN U.S. FALLS SHARPLY IN 2003

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan students applying in 2003 to pursue advanced studies in the United States was the lowest in eight years, Hsieh Fa-dah, Vice Chairman of Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said Friday.
The number of students applying for admittance to universities in the United States in 2003 was 10,324, down 25 percent from 2002, Hsieh said.

The enticements of the national defense training and reservation program and the increasing number of enrollment in graduate schools at Taiwan's universities dissuaded many students from studying in the United States.

Draftees performing military service under the national defense training and reservation program may pursue advanced studies during their services, which makes university graduates drop their willingness to pursue advanced studies abroad, Hsieh said.

If the trend continues, Taiwan's knowledge pool might be drained, thus resulting in the decline of Taiwan's competitiveness in the world, Hsieh said. Because of this, CEPD officials will promote an "elite study abroad program" by earmarking a budget of NT$200 million (US$5.97 million) every year for those willing to study abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,200 JAPANESE TOURISTS TO JOIN CHARTER TOURS TO TAIWAN IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: About 1,200 Japanese tourists will visit Taiwa in November by charter flight services subsidized by the Tourism Bureau, officials said Friday.

The visitors are workers of Japan's Asahi Group and their families, who will take 10 flights from Hiroshima to Kaohsiung on a four-day, three-night package tour around southern Taiwan, the officials said.
The Asahi Group originally had planned to arrange a tour for its workers to Guilin on mainland China, but it later decided to change the plan and fly to Taiwan, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRUCTURED AIR FORCE UNITS COMMISSIONED TO UPGRADE AIR DEFENSE

TEXT.P: Restructured air force combat units were commissioned into service at Hsinchu, Chiayi, Hualien and Chingchuankang (CCK) air bases around the island Friday as part of the military's efforts to upgrade its air defense capabilities. ROC Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Liu Kuei-li presided over a joint commissioning ceremony for the newly formed "independent combat squadrons" belonging to the 499 Tactical Jet Fighter Wing at Hsinchu air base, the 455 Wing at Chiayi air base, the 401 Wing at Hualien air base, and the 427 Wing at CCK air base.
A spokesman for the ROC Air Force General Headquarters said that except for the "independent combat squadrons," other units of those wings were not restructured and will remain intact.
According to the spokesman, the restructuring was aimed at upgrading command and control efficiency, extending the warplane pilot service period and thus enhancing their airborne combat prowess.

Air force authorities would not divulge details of the restructured combat units, saying the "independent combat squadrons'" structures are "military secrets." Military analysts said the jet fighter pilots' flight service period will be extended by three to five years.

Under the previous system, jet fighter pilots who had just matured in flight skills were often transferred to handle ground staff due to rank promotions work. The phenomenon had exacerbated the air force's pilot shortage problems. Military sources said the number of air force pilots has not grown in proportion to the expansion of the nation's second-generation jet fighters in the past decade.

Against this backdrop, Chief of the General Staff Lee Tien-yu proposed a restructuring of air force combat units during his tenure as air force commander-in-chief to upgrading airborne combat capabilities.

The 443 Wing at the Tainan air base began to undergo restructuring in December 2002 on a trial basis. After the experiment proved the feasibility of Lee's restructuring proposal, the air force began an across-the-board restructuring of its combat wings and the restructured "independent combat squadrons" were formally commissioned into service Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 30,000 SENIOR CITIZENS LOOKED AFTER IN NURSING HOMES

TEXT.P: Nearly 30,000 elderly citizens were being taken care of in nursing homes as of late June across Taiwan, an official at the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.

According to the DGBAS official, as of the end of June, some 30,000 senior citizens, mainly those who were homeless or those who suffer from various diseases, were living in different kinds of nursing homes across the country for everyday care or long-term medical treatment and assistance.

Statistics compiled by the DGBAS show that there were 2.13 million citizens aged over 65 years as of the end of June, accounting for 9.4 percent of the country's total population, slightly up from the previous year's 9.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT, PRIVATE GROUPS OFFER AID FOR JAPANESE QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government and private groups have offered aid to help Japanese people affected by the recent earthquakes in the northeastern Japanese prefecture of Niigata, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Friday.

Chen Chi-mai said Premier Yu Shyi-kun expressed his concern and sympathy to Japanese Prime Minister Ichiro Koizumi through the ROC representative office in Japan right after the Niigata prefecture was shaken by a magnitude 6.8 earthquake and a series of aftershocks last Saturday.

In addition, Chen Hung-chi, Taiwan's deputy representative to Japan paid a visit to the Niigata Prefecture Government Tuesday in the company of Kazuo Okazawa, president of a pro-Taiwan Japanese parliamentarians association, to convey President Chen Shui-bian's and Premier Yu's concern for earthquake victims.

"Chen Hung-chi also presented 2 million Japanese yen in relief funds to the Niigata Prefecture Government on behalf of the ROC government, " Chen Chi-mai said, adding that ROC Representative to Japan Ko Se-kai will travel to Niigata Oct. 31 to express his concern for Japanese victims as well as Taiwan expatriates living in the quake-affected regions.

According to the ROC representative office in Japan, there are about 146 Taiwan expatriates and students in the Niigata area. Only the home of a Taiwanese physician in the region was partially damaged, while all other expatriates and students didn't incurred any losses in the disaster.

Noting that Japan had offered various kinds of assistance to Taiwan when the island's central mountainous region was rattled by magnitude 7.6 earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999, Chen Chi-mai said the government has invited major private groups, including the Chinese National Association of Commerce and Industry, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Christian churches and other charitable organizations, to donate relief goods to be sent to the Niigata disaster zone.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY RELEASES TV SPOT PROMOTING ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: TV commercials sponsored by the Ministry of National Defense began airing Friday to solicit support for the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement package which is aimed at deterring any attack from mainland China.
The commercial, jointly produced by the defense ministry and the Government Information Office (GIO) , will be broadcast on all local terrestrial television stations from Friday.
A military spokesman said the 30-second spot was designed to remind the public that arms procurement is not a political issue but rather a professional topic to be addressed by the military.

Speaking at a news conference, GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung said national security is like air. "When it exists, nobody notices its existence. But when we lose it, we suffocate. We hope the TV commercial will help our people understand the urgency and importance of the arms procurement project," he said.

The NT$610.8 billion budget bill, which is pending legislative approval, will cover the cost of purchasing eight diesel-powered submarines, a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft and six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN MARINE Q3 WAS 449 PERCENT BETTER THAN LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Evergreen Marine Corp. (Taiwan) Ltd., Taiwan's largest container liner, announced Friday a combined pre-tax net profit for the first three quarters of NT$10.17 billion (US$303.5 million) , marking an astounding 449 percent growth rate over the year-earlier level.
After-tax net profit amounted to NT$8.951 billion for the nine-month period ending in September, with earnings per share standing at NT$3.93, an Evergreen spokesman said.
For the third quarter alone, quarterly pre-tax earnings swelled to NT$5.13 billion, up by 79 percent from the Q2 level. After-tax net profit grew by 63 percent quarterly to NT$4.338 billion.

Based on the solid performance over the past three quarters, Evergreen lifted it full-year business turnover forecast from NT$34.511 billion to NT$39.664 billion for 2004, an expansion of 15 percent year-on-year, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S Q3 BALANCE OF PAYMENTS POSTS US$1.855 BILLION SURPLUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's balance of payments for the third quarter of this year was about US$1.855 billion, down from both the Q1 and Q2 levels, a spokesman for the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Friday.

Citing the newest statistics compiled by the CBC, the spokesman said that the figure represents a fall from the Q1 level of US$21.1 billion, a historical quarterly high. It is also smaller than the Q2 level of US$3.05 billion, he pointed out.

The CBC official attributed the lackluster performance for the July-September period to a smaller net influx of foreign capital due *o a sluggish stock market and mediocre growth in the foreign trade surplus registered by the country as a whole.
Capital outflows in the third quarter were quite obvious compared to the Q2 capital movement, he noted.

Meanwhile, tallies published that same day by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that the number of Taiwan's foreign trade companies grew by 123 percent over the past decade, with their business volumes expanding by an average 136 percent.

According to the BOFT statistics, there were 88,978 foreign trade companies in 1993 in Taiwan, with the number rising to 109,446 in 2003. Each company did business worth more than US$1.82 million on average in 1993, with the average value increasing to over US$2.47 million.
Over the past decade, mainland China emerged as one of Taiwan's leading export markets.

In the first eight months of this year, Taiwan's trade with the mainland totaled US$39.646 billion, accounting for 17.9 percent of the country's total foreign trade and up by 1.1 percent over the year earlier level, BOFT tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Sharp increase in early voting alters campaign
State election officials around the country said on Thursday that there had been a surge in early voting this year, with people lining up in numbers so large that some analysts predict that one-fifth of presidential ballots will be cast before Nov. 2. The early voting trend is sharply altering the home stretch calculus of campaign strategists, affecting where candidates are sent and money is spent in the final days. And it has turned the get-out-the-vote drives that are usually reserved for the final hours of the campaign into a half-month marathon.
Wall Street Journal: Big dealers pressure car makers to cut production
Some of the biggest auto-retailing groups in the United States, citing higher interest cost and thinner margins in their new-car businesses, say they no longer will crowd their lots with slow- selling cars and trucks to help Detroit's auto makers avoid production cuts. General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. are already making plans to cut overtime or lay off temporarily thousands of workers to avoid a repeat of this summer's inventory glut. Industry executives expect even more cuts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORAL PROCEEDING CLOSED IN DISPUTE OVER TRUTH COMMISSION

TEXT.P: The oral proceeding in the dispute over the constitutionality of the Truth Investigation Commission closed Friday, and the Council of the Grand Justices said they will hand down a decision at a yet unspecified date.

The oral proceeding was the last step in the hearing of the dispute in which the lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) asked the Council of the Grand Justices to annul a statute proving for the formation of the Truth Investigation Commission on the ground of unconstitutionality.
The council is obliged to hand down a decision in the form of an interpretation of the Constitution within two months.

During Friday's proceeding, which was the second day of arguments that began on Wednesday and recessed on Thursday, both the applicant, DPP Legislator You Ching, and the representatives of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, which passed the controversial statute, including Koumintang Legislator Kau Yu-jen and several others who gave opinions as friends of the court.

You Ching argued that by creating the Truth Investigation Commission, the legislature has expanded its role by usurping the power of crime investigation which was shared by the Ministry of Justice under the Executive Yuan and the Control Yuan.
His argument was echoed by friend of the court Tsai Tsung-chen, who said the legislature has infringed on the power of the Executive Yuan and is therefore inappropriate under constitutional theory.

However, another court participant, Chen Ai-er, said the Control Yuan, whose members are appointed by the president with the approval of the Legislative Yuan, is no longer a representative office of public opinion.
Meanwhile, the Legislative Yuan has no power to investigate irregularities in the government even if it reflects public opinion, and this is a defect in the current Constitution, Chen added.

Kau Yu-jen said the statute enacted by the Legislative Yuan had some of its articles approved unanimously by the lawmakers, including those from the DPP, and it would be ridiculous to called the whole statute unconstitutional and invalid.

Another representative of the Legislative Yuan, KMT lawmaker Chen Ching-hsing defended the legality of the statute claiming that every article in it had been thoroughly debated at the Legislative Yuan before enactment.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCT. 29 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Oct. 30:
09:00, President Chen will attend a presentation on the results of a survey of the conventional territories of the Taiwan aborigines in Pingtung, southern Taiwan.
09:30, The Democratic Progressive Party will open its legislative election headquarters in Kinmen County.
09:50, Vice President Annette Lu will preside over the opening of the campaign headquarters of a Democratic Progressive Party candidate for legislator in Tali, Taichung County.
10: 20, President Chen Shui-bian will preside over a ceremony celebrating the 40th anniversary of Tainan's Women's Technology Institute in Yungkang, Tainan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 30, or the 17th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories to the Declaration of Independence, and he negotiated the end to the War of American Independence.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary forces of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions in Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference, which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive in Taipei to join in birthday celebrations for President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: The first F-5E Freedom jetfighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, the ROC minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa at the head of an envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to go into effect Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history, held in Yongin, South Korea, where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan, killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: The ROC's opposition parties declare Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "persona non grata" for his announcement of a major policy turnabout that they say was not only "illegal," but also "sacrificed the public interest."
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen signs a memorandum on military cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart Ljuben Paunoski in Taipei.
2001: Microsoft Taiwan formally launches the new Microsoft Windows XP operating system at the Taipei International Convention Center, with thousands registered to try out the system.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "There never was a man trained to benevolence who neglected his parents. There never was a man trained to righteousness who made his ruler an after-consideration."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUTURES EXCHANGE SIGNS COOPERATION PACT WITH NYME
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Futures Exchange (TFE) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on cooperation with the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYME) Friday as part of its globalization drive.

The MOU was inked by TFE President Ho Fu-hsiung and NYME President James E. Newsome in a ceremony witnessed by Kung Chao-sheng, chairman of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).
The MOU follows similar TFE cooperative accords with futures exchanges in Seoul, Tokyo and Chicago, Ho told a news conference held after the signing ceremony.
Under the terms of the MOU, Ho said, the TFE and the NYME will strengthen dialogue, experience exchanges and mercantile cooperation.

"The MOU marks just the start of the TFE-NYME cooperation. In the future, we hope to forge an even closer strategic partnership with the 130-year-old NYME to facilitate the diversification of Taiwan's futures trading," Ho said.
Ho was a member of a Taiwan delegation headed by Kung that attended a just-concluded international seminar on the financial services' supervisory mechanism, accounting, auditing and trading systems.

Kung said the two-day seminar provided a platform for senior executives of securities and futures exchanges in major countries around the world to exchange views and experiences in stock listing, trading, auditing, accounting and supervisory work.
The six-member delegation will leave for home Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN URGES SUPPORT FOR KMT LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: Lien Chan of the opposition Kuomintang urged voters Saturday to cast their ballots for the right people in the year-end legislative elections so that the country can have a brighter future.

Lien made the remarks when he attended the inauguration of the campaign office of KMT legislative candidate Chu Chun-hsiao in Taipei County to lend support to the former National Assembly member in the Dec. 11 elections.

Currently, the nation faces five problems, according to Lien. First and foremost is its national identity, he said, adding that the name of the Republic of China needs no change and neither does the Constitution, as has been advocated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
He also noted that both sides of the Taiwan Strait need peaceful relations and he advocated the signing of a 50-year peace agreement with the other side of the strait.

The democratic development in Taiwan needs further strengthening, Lien said, adding that the executive branch needs to maintain neutrality, while the judicial system has to have independent status and there should be freedom of speech.
The various ethnic groups should be able to live in harmony and equality and there should be no incitement of ethnic rivalry in the election campaigns.

Last and not least, Lien stressed that Taiwan has been seriously marginalized in the international community and that it has been shut out of major international and economic organizations, which he said is a grave warning signal for the country.

DOC.TEXT:
