The Lianhe Zaobao:Singapore government asks the chemical merchant to join the anti-terrorism team.
The anti-terrorism was been expanded, Singapore Ministry of Home Affairs asked chemical products manufacturers,sales store owners,and importers must report the buyer looks like terrorist.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bin Laden Warns U.S. Voters; 'Your Security Is in Your Own Hands,' He Says on Videotape.
Osama bin Laden injected himself into the final days of the U.S. presidential campaign, warning that American voters will be held accountable for electing any president who seeks to destroy al Qaeda and persecutes Muslims, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Nation:Violence in the South/ Muslim leaders blame PM. Muslim leaders yesterday blamed Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra's hard-line stance for growing violence in the deep South. It was the first time that Muslim leaders had publicly blamed Thaksin for violence in the southern border region. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT TAKES POWELL'S WORDS AS ENCOURAGEMENT

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese people should take U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's recent remark on the status of Taiwan as an encouragement for them to continue to strive for the country, former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday.
Lee was referring to Powell's comment in Beijing earlier in the week that Taiwan "does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation."

Lee, who advocates drafting a new constitution for the country, said Powell's remark should not be taken as a threat but as motivation spurring the people of Taiwan to fight for and take care of their country.
He dismissed as "a lie" the interpretation from some quarters that Powell's remark indicates that the United States is abandoning Taiwan to engage mainland China.

Lee spoke on the issue while addressing the opening of the campaign headquarters of Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Hsu Teng-kung in Sanchung, Taipei County. Hsu is running for re-election in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
Lee said the people of Taiwan must develop a "Taiwan consciousness" in order to build up the country.

He expressed his support for a controversial proposal on the elimination of questions related to the mainland from the section on "domestic history and geography" for civil service examinations, saying that it is very improper for Taiwan civil servants to know nothing about the history of their own country.
Lee repeated his claim that the "Republic of China" does not exist and urged the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party to stop "deceiving themselves."
He said the Legislative Yuan, which is controlled by the "pan-blue alliance, " has become the main origin of chaos in the country and the biggest obstacle hampering Taiwan's democratic development.
He called on the voters to support candidates with "Taiwan consciousness" and allow them to take control of the legislature so as to bring stability to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Ailing Arafat Heads to Paris. With his wife and doctors by his side, ailing Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat was flown out of the West Bank early today for medical treat- ment abroad, heralding the likely end of his longtime grip on power.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WANTS PASSAGE OF 'POLITICAL PARTIES ACT' TO CHANGE KMT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun promised Saturday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will push through a Political Parties Act to transform the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) into a "democratic party" if the DPP seizes over half of the seats in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.
The party will also pass a special statute to retrieve the ill-gotten assets of the KMT for the nation and introduce a National Pensions Act to provide better care for the elderly, Yu said.
He was speaking to supporters during the opening of the legislative election campaign headquarters of DPP Legislator Ker Chien-ming in Hsinchu.
Yu said the DPP will have a free hand to do a lot of things for the country if it can take control of the Legislative Yuan.

He attacked the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition KMT and People First Party for blocking many bills that should have been passed and constantly making up unfounded accusations against the DPP government.
This problem will be solved by ending the "pan-blue" dominance of the Legislative Yuan, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT STUDYING BALLOT ALLOCATION STRATEGY

TEXT.P: With the crucial year-end legislative elections approaching, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday it is studying its strategy for ballot allocation, while its ally, the People First Party (PFP) called for an overall consideration of ballot allocation among candidates from the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP.
Lin Fong-cheng, KMT secretary-general, said the KMT will first study the guidelines for ballot allocation and then take into consideration the factors of each candidate and constituency.

Noting that the KMT has not employed this strategy before -- a method at which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) excels and has used to repeated success, Lin said related operations should be ready in about two weeks.

Lin said the party will consider the situation of each constituency when coordinating with the candidates on ballot allocation. In places where such a strategy is not feasible, the party will pool its strength to help prop up struggling candidates.
The two methods will be used simultaneously, Lin said, with the main purpose being to ensure that as many KMT candidates as possible win a legislative seat.
"Ballot allocation will give priority consideration to KMT candidates and will not consider candidates from other parties or the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) for the time being," Lin added.

The KMT does not want to place too much emphasis on "political superstars" that have more votes than needed to win, but will try to salvage those who are struggling on the election threshold through the ballot allocation strategy, he added.
But his remarks immediately raised the ire of PFP Chairman James Soong.

Soong said that both the KMT and the PFP need to perform well so that the "pan-blue alliance" can command a majority in the Legislative Yuan. The scale of the ballot allocation should include all alliance members, he stressed.

Even if all the KMT nominees are elected, this will amount to a little more than 70 seats, and only if more than 40 PFP candidates are also elected will the "pan-blue alliance" have the needed majority in the 225-seat legislature.

He also said that the PFP has been restrained in its nomination for overall consideration, although it will inevitably affect the PFP at-large seats, which are awarded in proportion to the number of ballots garnered by each political party.
Lin later responded to Soong's remarks by saying that "we of course have the 'pan-blue alliance' in mind, " adding that the KMT will also help PFP candidates who are struggling.

Lin said that the KMT can stump for PFP candidates in Nantou in central Taiwan, but "in fact, the PFP can also take the initiative to allot ballots, " citing the example of PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei of Taipei County, who is far ahead of his closest rival in Taipei County according to several polls.
"The urgent task now is to communicate with the 'pan-blue' candidates around the island," Lin said.

A record number of 387 candidates have registered for the Dec. 11 elections, among which, 92 were nominated by the DPP, followed by the KMT with 74, the PFP with 41, the Taiwan Solidarity Union with 30 and the NPSU with 26.
President Chen Shui-bian, in his capacity as DPP chairman, has vowed to take 100 seats in the legislature to ensure a comfortable majority of the "pan-green camp" which includes DPP ally the TSU.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Abu warns gov't destabilizers
Lt. Gen. Efren L. Abu, the newly installed Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP), yesterday warned groups plotting to overthrow the Arroyo government that they will be dealt with severely, stressing that he will not allow any destabilization move to gain momentum.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Abaya bows out with fury
GEN. Narciso Abaya yesterday assailed the media for supposedly engaging in "sensationalism," "rumor-reporting" and trial by publicity during times of crisis. In his farewell speech as Armed Forces chief, Abaya also blasted away at "politicians" dangling "congressional confirmations" at the military.
The Philippine Star: GMA to Abu: Stamp out graft
The new military chief got his marching orders yesterday from his commander-in-chief: Stamp out corruption that is destroying the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP).
The Manila Times: Abaya takes final swipe at Santiago
Gen. Narciso Abaya reserved his last day as a soldier Friday by taking a swipe at Sen. Miriam Defensor Santiago, who had spoken against the military and threatened to block the confirmation of at least one general.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CALLS FOR SOLIDARITY AMID MAINLAND CHINESE THREAT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called Saturday for solidarity among the Taiwan people amid the increasing threat from mainland China.
Lu made the appeal during a visit to Taichung County to stump for two ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidates for the year-end legislative elections.

She stressed that Taiwan has faced many challenges during recent years, such as Beijing's deployment of more than 600 missiles aimed at Taiwan and its increasing military buildup. All these reflect the Beijing's ambition to include Taiwan as part of its territory, she added.

In addition, the mainland might become the new superpower after its organization of the 2008 Olympic Games and the 2010 World Expo in Shanghai, which could enable it to directly challenge the power of the United States and take Taiwan, according to Lu.
The anxiety of the Taiwan people has increased further after U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell said recently that "Taiwan does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation," Lu said.
She rebutted Powell's remarks, saying that Taiwan is an independent sovereign country and that the "Taiwan problem" should be resolved peacefully through the will of its people.
Noting that these coming few years will be a crucial time for Taiwan's future, Lu urged the public to show solidarity and support the government.
On constitutional reforms, Lu urged the lawmakers that will be elected in the Dec. 11 legislative elections to engineer a new constitution that fits the island's development.

On the topic of environmental protection, Lu said that in addition to the devastating earthquake of 1999, Taiwan has faced frequent typhoons and consequent mudslides, which she claimed are "due to global warming." She called for new and comprehensive planning for land preservation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60% OF YOUNG PEOPLE WANT TO START THEIR OWN BUSINESSES: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Six out of 10 young people currently working want to start their own businesses, while 66 percent also said they could be successful within one year, according to the results of a survey unveiled Saturday.

The survey, conducted by www.9999.com.tw -- an online human resources company -- between Oct. 11-26 among respondents aged under 28 via e-mail, sent out 20,000 questionnaires and collected 8,363 effective samples with a margin of error of 1.07 percent.

Thanks to the economic recovery, 18.7 percent said they are ready to start their own businesses, while 41.4 percent said they are mulling the idea, showing that 60 percent of the respondents want to be their own boss, up six percentage points from the previous year.

The reasons most cited for wanting their own business is "to make a fortune" (55.6 percent) , followed by "do things one is interested in" (44.1 percent), and "have the technical skills or specialties to start own business" (38.1 percent).

In order to "do things one is interested in," 19.1 percent of the polled said that they would accept a net profit of less than NT$100,000 (US$2,990) a month, while 3.7 percent said they would be happy "as long as they are earning money."

The survey also found that the respondents are most afraid of four things when starting their own businesses: patrons do not like their service; earning are not coming in a stable way; insufficient business information; and poor location.

Asked how long they expect to be successful, the answer of between six months and one year accounted for the most at 36.5 percent, followed by three months to six months (24.2 percent). 5.6 percent predicted with confidence that they could reach their goal in three months, according to the survey results.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CYCLING TOURNAMENT BEGINS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The seven-day international cycling tournament, "Tour de Taiwan 2004, " kicked off Saturday in the southern county of Kaohsiung, with 15 teams from around the world competing.

Saturday's competition began from Liukuei village, with Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, officials from the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports and the Chinese Taipei Cycling Association presiding over the starting ceremony.
Milatz Moritz, representing the European team, won Saturday's 100 km leg of the tournament with a time of 2 hours, 31 minutes and 25.54 seconds, only 0.15 seconds ahead of his Japanese rival.
Sunday's leg will include 30 laps around Kaohsiung's Love River, while other legs will include cycling around Sun Moon Lake, over Hohuanshan and around the east coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER ANGRY THAT LINGUISTICS INSTITUTE IGNORES HOKLO RESEARCH

TEXT.P: A legislator from the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) expressed displeasure Saturday with the Institute of Linguistics of Academia Sinica for listing its budget for Taiwanese language or Hoklo research for next year as "nil."

Legislator Chien Lin Huei-chun threatened that if the institute does not redress the issue, the legislature will cut all its research funds except those for the research of the Hakka and aboriginal languages during a review of the institute's budget.

She said she is opposed to the institute' appropriation of up to NT$100 million (US$2.99 million) per year to study obscure languages such as Hsi Hsia language which was spoken in today's Inner Mongolia and Gansu areas in mainland China during the Sung Dynasty, and a little-known tongue spoken in Mongolia.
"These languages have nothing to do with the great majority of Taiwan people, " she said, and the institute should be taken to task for making use of taxpayers' money in that way.

As the nation's highest research institute is financed by the taxpayer, she said, it should study the major languages in Taiwan, especially those languages that have been listed for study in schools -- namely Hoklo, Hakka and aboriginal languages -- and it should also focus on basic research into the mother tongues of the various ethnic groups in Taiwan, as well as the connection between local languages and those in East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SUPPRESSION AT NUREMBERG SHOW COUNTERPRODUCTIVE: MOFA

TEXT.P: Mainland China's suppression of the Taiwan delegation at the ongoing Nuremberg International Invention Exhibition (NIIE) in Germany is counterproductive to relations across the Taiwan Strait, a diplomatic official said Saturday.

Michel Lu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), was commenting on the mainland delegation's repeated demand at the Oct. 27 opening ceremony that the Republic of China flag be removed from the NIIE venue. A clash between delegates from the two sides almost broke out at the exhibition site over the issue.

Lu said the ROC's representative office in Munich had helped the Taiwan delegation to negotiate with the NIIE authorities and that the organizing committee finally reached a decision that none of the participating countries would be allowed to hoist their national flags at the venue.

Noting that the NIIE is a non-governmental international event, Lu said mainland China's suppression of Taiwan's equal participation in international activities, regardless of governmental or non-governmental in nature, has gravely hurt Taiwan people's feelings and is counterproductive to the improvement of cross-strait ties.

Lu said MOFA staff in Munich have been assisting the Taiwan delegation in fighting against the mainland's repressive act and that he himself has kept close contact with Chou Hsiu-chen, chairwoman of the Child Welfare League Foundation, who is a staff member of the Taiwan delegation to the annual invention exhibition.

"The NIIE decision to remove the flags of all participating countries was the result of the MOFA staff's hard work, " Lu said. "Mainland China's suppressive act was not unexpected. We were well prepared and our top priority is to protect our right to participate."

As to a report that the mainland delegation had pressured the NIIE organizers to ban Taiwan journalists from covering the event, Lu said such a demand would be immoral and that if the report is true, the MOFA has worked out response strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO INCLUDE ABORIGINAL CHAPTER IN NEW CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Saturday his campaign promise to include a special chapter on the rights of indigenous people in the new constitution that he plans to introduce in 2008.

Chen pointed out that he signed a document on "the new partnership between the aborigines and the Taiwanese government" with tribal representatives on Orchid Island during the run-up to the 2000 presidential election and promised to set up a special chapter on the issue in the new constitution.
Chen said the aborigines are the earliest settlers of Taiwan and that they must enjoy dignity and hope in order to make Taiwan dignified and hopeful.

Over the past few years, the government has proposed various projects and legislation to realize the concept of a "quasi nation-to-nation" partnership between the aborigines and government, Chen said.

These include a project aimed at restoring the traditional territories of aboriginal tribes, which will involve land surveying and mapping of the traditional distribution of indigenous people, he added.
The president said representatives of various aboriginal tribes have participated in drawing the map, which he said symbolizes the exercise of self-determination of the indigenous people.
He said the government will continue to work to complete the rights of the indigenous people by realizing their natural autonomy, right to land and self-government.
Chen made the remarks while participating in a briefing held in Pingtung on the aboriginal tribal territories survey project.

Also Saturday, while attending the 40th anniversary celebration of the Tainan Woman's College of Arts and Technology, Chen spoke of his wish to see a woman becoming the head of one of the five government branches, and even president, in the future.

According to Chen, the performance of Taiwanese women is the 20th-best among more than 190 countries around the world and that promoting equality of the sexes has been one of the main policies of his government.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLAR CAR EXHIBITION OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A three-month exhibition of solar-powered cars opened Saturday at the National Taiwan Science Education Center in Taipei, according to Cheng Jung-ho, a professor at National Taiwan University (NTU).
The event is being co-organized by the National Taiwan Science Education Center and the NTU's Mechanical Engineering Department.
All of the cars on display were developed and built by NTU students with the help of their teachers.

The theme of the exhibition will revolve around the development of solar cars from Formosun I to Formosun II. Another focus is how inventors of Formosun surmounted difficulties to compete in a grueling 3,100-km race in Australia earlier this year.

Other purposes of the exhibition are to acquaint visitors with the power of solar energy through a series of hands-on activities that will allow them to experience power generation by solar energy, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC WORKERS ENCOURAGED TO UPHOLD CORE PRINCIPLES

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Ltd. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip maker, encouraged his staff Saturday to adhere to the company's three core principles in the face of a cyclical slowdown and keen competition in the world market.

Morris Chang said at the TSMC sports fair for workers that only by maintaining the company's technology, manufacturing process and customer service in the best possible shape can the company keep its leading position in the world.
Chang was kicking off the annual workers' games at the TSMC headquarters in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, which drew over 10,000 TSMC workers their families.

In his address at the opening ceremony, Chang noted that TSMC's revenue for the third quarter of this year reached NT$69.74 billion (US$2.09 billion) , with a net income for the three-month period hitting NT$27.93 billion, both figures representing the highest on record since the semiconductor foundry's establishment in 1987.

Moreover, the CEO said, the company is expected to see an annual revenue of more than NT$250 billion for the year, and over NT$90 billion in net income after tax in the first three quarters of the year.

At the workers fair, a group of workers and employees from TSMC's Songjiang factory in Shanghai, mainland China, drew a great deal of attention. The factory is the first investment project of its kind by a Taiwan company in mainland China to be permitted by the Taiwan government. It did not enter mass production until the third quarter of this year, according to the TSMC.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL GROUP TO RAISE FUNDS FOR JAPANESE QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan (FMPAT) launched a fund-raising campaign Saturday as part of its efforts to help Japanese people affected by recent earthquakes in Niigata Prefecture in northeastern Japan.

FMPAT Chairman Wu Shu-min, who is also a national policy adviser to the president, said the fund-raising campaign is aimed at expressing the Taiwan people's concern for the earthquake victims and gratitude for Japan's pass assistance to Taiwan.
"We look forward to raising at least NT$5 million in the next week or two to help with Japan's post-disaster relief work," Wu said.

Acknowledging that Japan is richer and more advanced than Taiwan, Wu said the planned donation is primarily moral support to express Taiwan's goodwill toward the Japanese people. Taipei's Jen Chi Hospital, where Wu works, has decided to donate NT$1 million, he said.

Quoting recent statements by Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Wu said Taiwan's annual foreign aid accounts for a marginal 0.07 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) , far below the U.N.-proposed 0.7 percent of the GDP standard.
In his view, Wu went on, Taiwan should be more active in fulfilling its international obligations as a member of the global village now that the nation has become the world's 18th-largest economy.
Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said a day earlier that the ROC government has extended condolences and sympathy to Japan over the recent earthquake disaster.

"Premier Yu Shyi-kun expressed his concern and sympathy to Japanese Prime Minister Ichiro Koizumi through the ROC representative office in Japan right after Niigata Prefecture was shaken by a magnitude 6.8 earthquake and a series of aftershocks last Saturday, " Chen Chi-mai said.

In addition, Chen Hung-chi, Taiwan's deputy representative to Japan, paid a visit to the Niigata Prefecture authorities Tuesday in the company of Kazuo Okazawa, president of a pro-Taiwan Japanese parliamentarians association, to convey President Chen Shui-bian's and Premier Yu's concern for the earthquake victims.

"Chen Hung-chi also presented 2 million yen in relief funds to the Niigata prefecture government on behalf of the ROC government, " Chen Chi-mai said, adding that ROC Representative to Japan Ko Se-kai will travel to Niigata Oct. 31 to express his concern for the quake victims, including Taiwan expatriates living in the quake-affected regions.

According to the ROC representative office in Japan, there are about 146 Taiwan expatriates and students in the Niigata area. However, only the home of one Taiwanese physician in the region was partially damaged, while none of the other expatriates or students incurred any losses.

Noting that Japan offered various kinds of assistance to Taiwan when the island's central mountainous region was devastated by a magnitude 7.6 earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999, Chen Chi-mai said the government has invited major private groups, including the Chinese National Association of Commerce and Industry, the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Christian churches and other charitable organizations, to donate relief goods to be sent to the Niigata disaster zone in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO COMPLETE REVIEW OF PROTECTION OF COASTAL AREAS

TEXT.P: The Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior said Saturday it is reviewing a project on natural environment protection of the coastal areas of Taiwan.

Agency officials noted that Taiwan is surrounded by sea with diverse biological and landscape resources along its coastal areas, and said that management and protection of these resources will ensure their sustainable development.
They noted that the Ministry of the Interior set up 12 coastal protection areas, including the mouth of the Tamshui River, the coast around Kenting, and the Northeast Coast, between 1984 and 1987.

In addition, the agency started to review Taiwan's coastal areas in 2001 in three stages and it is expected that the third stage will be completed by the middle of next year, making it possible for planning, management and conservation of the country's coast.

The officials expect that the completion of the environment and biology survey will help establish a comprehensive information databank and allow mapping of major wetland and coral shelf areas so tangible measures can be worked out to protect and manage the valuable coastal resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY DOCTOR PROJECT HELPS KEEP HEALTH INSURANCE SYSTEM VIABLE: DOH

TEXT.P: The nation's top health official said Saturday that the rigorous implementation of a family doctor patient referral project will contribute to the sustainable development of the national health insurance system.

Department of Health Minister Chen Chien-jen made the remarks when he attended an activity to promote awareness of the project to integrate family doctors into the medical care system sponsored by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI).

The BNHI has in recent years promoted the project, hoping that with family doctors referring patients to the appropriate hospitals, it will end the habit Taiwan people have of visiting one hospital after another when they have the slightest discomfort because of the cheap and convenient service under the current health insurance program or of visiting large medical centers for minor health problems, which has been the major reason for the depletion of the valuable medical resources.
"A good family doctor can keep a record of all the health problems of his patients," Chen pointed out.

There were 223 community medical groups in operation as of September, provide the best possible medial care for all the families in their communities, he said, adding that he hopes that everyone will develop the habit of going first to their family doctor when they feel unwell.
The project refers to between five and 10 grassroots clinics in the same community forming a community medical care network by working with regional hospitals in their areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAM RADIO OPERATORS JOIN 2004 CQ WORLDWIDE SSB CONTEST

TEXT.P: A group of ham radio fanatics in Taiwan joined other amateur radio operators around the world on air Saturday in the 2004 CQ World Wide SSB Contest.
The Taiwanese participants consisted of 16 members of the Chinese Taipei Amateur Radio League (CTARL) , led by secretary-general Yu Tai-ping.
They are required to contact via single sideband (SSB) radio with amateurs in as many zones and countries as possible in 48 hours from 0000 GMT Oct. 30 to 2400 GMT Oct. 31.
The CTARL members, who operate a station codenamed "BO0K" on the frontline island of Kinmen, said they aim to reach 10,000 radio operators worldwide during that period.
According to Yu, there are approximately 20 million licensed amateur operators around the globe, but less than 200 Taiwanese amateurs active internationally.
In addition to Kinmen, CTARL has also operated from other outlying islands including Matsu, Orchid Island, Green Island and Pengjia Islet in past contests, Yu said.
He said the CTARL plans to set up a station in the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST GOLD ECOLOGICAL PARK INAUGURATED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taipei County Acting Magistrate Lin Hsi-yao on Saturday presided over the inauguration of the country's first Gold Ecological Park in Chinkuashih, on Taiwan's northeast coast.
Chinkuashih, a former gold-mining town, is also famous for its diverse ecological scenery and plants and was once considered as a potential world heritage site.

Lin noted that the Gold Ecological Park is a complex that will include the Gold Museum, in which the history of gold exploitation will be exhibited along with a 220 kg gold ingot, as well as an ecological park.
While visiting the abandoned mines, the public will also get a glimpse of the hardships experienced by the mine workers in the past, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EDUCATIONAL EXHIBITION KICKS OFF IN THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taiwan Educational Exhibition began Saturday in Bangkok in a bid to attract Thai and overseas Taiwanese students to study in Taiwan.

Cheng Boh-chu, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Thailand, and Virasak Wondgsawang, a session chief responsible for vocational education from Thailand's Ministry of Education, as well as Taiwanese business leaders in Thailand, presided over the ceremony.

Cheng stressed that Taiwan's economic miracle and rapid democratization lie in its successful education and that the country's universities are willing to offer scholarships to Thai people as a means of contributing to the world community.
Virasak hailed Taiwan's educational level and its high-tech development, saying that it is worthwhile for Thai students to study in Taiwan.
The exhibition forms part of the Republic of China government's efforts to attract foreigners to study in Taiwan in order to promote the globalization of domestic universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ TO SET UP AD HOC GROUP AGAINST VOTE-BUYING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) and the State Public Prosecutor-General's Office will set up an ad hoc group 10 days before the Dec. 11 legislative elections to crack down on vote-buying and election-related violence.

MOJ officials noted that the ministry adopted similar measures in the legislative elections three years ago and in this year's March 20 presidential election, obtaining good results as the measures served as a strong deterrent to some candidates who might have intended to buy votes.
Meanwhile, President Chen Shui-bian has given instruction to Wu Ing-chao, the state public prosecutor-general, to list the crackdown on vote-buying as his priority task.

Wu, who assumed his post in September, is well-known for his efforts to crack down on corruption in his former posts at the Taipei District Public Prosecutors' Office and the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER PUSHES FOR NEW NAVAL, MARINE ENSIGNS

TEXT.P: Legislator Lee Chen-nan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the military Saturday to phase out the ensigns currently flown by the nation's naval ships and marine forces, which he said do not reflect their nationality.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Lee claimed that the ensign flown at the stern of Taiwan's warships closely resembles the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) party flag and that the marine ensign looks very like mainland China's "red star" national flag.

"As these ensigns were adopted during KMT rule, they reflect the party-state and Chinese ideological thinking prevalent at the time. Now that Taiwan has evolved into a liberal democracy, those outdated ensigns, which do not feature any trace of Taiwan, should be phased out," Lee said.

He suggested that the Ministry of National Defense hold a public contest to solicit new designs for the naval and marine ensigns. In his view, Lee said, the new flags should be designed in line with the principles of professionalism and should highlight Taiwan's unique national identity as opposed to that of China, in order to boost military service members' morale and patriotism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESEARCHERS DEVELOP NEW METHOD FOR KILLING FIRE ANTS

TEXT.P: Members of an Academia Sinica research team said Saturday they have developed a new method that uses low-temperature liquid nitrogen to eradicate red fire ants.
According to team leader Chen Yang-yuan, the ants are frozen or suffocated to death in a few minutes after liquid nitrogen at -160 degrees Celsius is sprayed into their nest.
The temperature in the nest will remain low for several hours, lengthening the eradication effect of the method, Chen said.
Chen said the method has been tried on the Sanhsia campus of National Taipei University, which has suffered an invasion of the red fire ants, an imported pest not native to Taiwan.
The team is applying for patent registration for the method, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROSY PROSPECTS FOR IT COOPERATION BETWEEN TAIWAN, INDIA

TEXT.P: The prospects for information technology (IT) exchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and India are rosy, an Indian official said Saturday, noting that the former is a world-renowned computer manufacturing country, while the latter is rich in quality software talent.
J. Parthasarathy, deputy director of a software park run by the Indian Ministry of Information and Technology, made the remarks in an interview with CNA.

He cited figures released by India's National Association of Software and Service Companies and the consultancy company McKinsey to show that by 2008, India's software service exports will have grown to between US$28 billion and US$30 billion.

He noted that Bangalore, in southwestern India, is a software stronghold because it has several advantages, including low-cost, high-quality manpower, the second-largest population that can speak English, clement weather and the full support of the government.
ROC Economic Affairs Vice Minister Yiin Chii-ming, who was highly positive of India's software sector, also said there is ample room for bilateral cooperation.
Yiin will lead a delegation of Taiwan businessmen on a visit to India next month, hoping to find suitable investment partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURBERRY CHECK SUBJECT TO TRADEMARK LAW PROTECTION: MOEA

TEXT.P: The famous Burberry Check of the noted British fashion brand Burberry is subject to Taiwan's trademark law protection, the Intellectual Property Office (IPO) of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Saturday.
The office was commenting on reports circulating on Web sites that the black-red-beige Burberry Check is not subject to any trademark law protection and can be copied in fashion goods.
"The reports are wrong," an IPO official said, adding that Taiwan approved the British firm's Burberry Check trademark registration in 2000.

According to the official, the company has used the Burberry Check on a variety of fashion goods, including costumes, handbags, shoes and scarves, for more than 140 years and completed trademark registration in France, the United States, Italy, Australia, Canada, Spain, Denmark and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND PLANS NEW WARPLANES DEPLOYMENT BETWEEN 2020-2035

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has come up with a plan to deploy a new generation of warplanes between 2020 and 2035, military sources said Saturday.
According to the sources, the acquisition and deployment of new-generation jet fighters will be carried out after the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement project is completed over the next 15 years.

The NT$610.8 billion arms procurement budget bill, which is pending legislative approval, will cover the cost of purchasing eight diesel-powered submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six PAC II Patriot anti-missile batteries from the United States.

According to a three-to-one combat power ratio, the sources said, the offensive side would certainly win in case the assault force is three times that of the defensive side; the defensive side would certainly win in case the combat power ratio falls below 1.5-to-one; and the result is uncertain when the ratio is two-to-one.

MND officials said if the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement package fails to clear the legislature, the mainland China-Taiwan combat power ratio would be 1.46 to 1 between 2006 and 2012, and the ratio could widen to 2.18 to 1 between 2013 and 2019; and the ratio would become 2.8 to 1 between 2020 and 2035. In terms of the three-to-one ratio, mainland China's determination to invade Taiwan could become firmer during the 2020-2035 period.

But if the critical arms procurement project can proceed smoothly, the officials said, the combat power ratio could maintain at 1.46 to 1 between 2006 and 2012 as Taiwan will take delivery of the Kidd-class destroyers during this period. And the ratio would decline to 1.24 to 1 between 2013 and 2019 with the deployment of weapons acquired from the new arms procurement package. After that, the officials said, Taiwan must begin purchasing and deploying a new generation of jet fighters to maintain its defense capabilities.

"If we can complete deployment of new warplanes between 2020 and 2035, the combat power ratio would be about 1.67 to 1. And this scenario could help deter mainland China from mounting an attack on Taiwan," said an MND official.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMOUS SONGWRITER DIES OF PANCREATIC CANCER

TEXT.P: Famous songwriter Liang Hung-chih died of pancreatic cancer at Tri-Service General Hospital Saturday at the age of 44.
Liang was already in the terminal stage of pancreatic cancer when his disease was discovered by Tri-Service General Hospital doctors early this year.

Doctors said pancreatic cancer is one of the most virulent forms of cancer because it shows no special symptoms in the early stage. Doctors said Liang had undergone chemotherapy and radiotherapy, but the treatment was not effective.

Liang had composed many popular lyric songs during his music career that spanned nearly three decades. A number of Mandarin pop singers, including Tsai Chin, Su Jui, Wang Chi-lei, Cheng Yi, Yu Tai-yen, Chiang Yu-heng and Tseng Ching-yu came to fame after singing his songs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: In video message, Bin Laden issues warning to U.S.
In a new videotape televised Friday, Osama bin Laden made a direct, formal address to the American people, saying that the best way for Americans to avoid a repeat of the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, was to stop threatening Muslims' security. The videotape was first broadcast on Al Ja zeera, the Arabic-language satellite network. Though Bin Laden's statement referred to President Bush and Senator John Kerry by name, he said the prospect of a future terrorist attack would depend not on the outcome of the election but on concrete actions taken by the United States.
Wall Street Journal: New Bin Laden tape is aired on Al Jazeera
Osama bin Laden, reading a statement to the to the American people in a new videotape aired Friday, directly admitted for the first time that he ordered the Sept. 11 attacks and said "the best way to avoid another Manhattan" was to stop threatening Muslims' security. President Bush said late Friday that "Americans will not be intimidated'' by Bin Laden. Bush's election rival John Kerry pledged to "hunt down and destroy'' Bin Laden. A White House spokesman said the administration didn't plan to raise the nation 's threat level for now, four days before the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCT. 31 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Oct. 31:
09:30, A seminar on Taiwan's constitutional reform, organized by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission will open at National Taiwan University Law College.
10:00, Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan will attend a ceremony honoring outstanding baby sitters to be held at a stadium in Pingtung.
12:00, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan will attend a Yeh clan gathering in Miaoli.
14:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a ceremony marking the 50th anniversary of the establishment of the Veterans Affairs Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 31, or the 18th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Martin Luther nails his 95 theses against papal corruption in Rome to the church door in Wittenberg.
1887: Chiang Kai-shek, the late president of the Republic of China, is born at Hsikou in Fenghua County, Chekiang Province.
1916: Gen. Huang Hsin, leader of the revolution that overthrew the Ching dynasty, dies in Shanghai at the age of 43.
1947: The United Nations sets aside Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."
1952: The China Youth Corps is organized with Chiang Ching-kuo serving as director.
1957: Tsung Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang share the Nobel Prize for physics for work disproving the law of conservation of parity.
1958: Nobel Prize winning author Boris Pasternak is expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union and faces possible exile for his "Dr. Zhivago."
1966: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Lesotho.
1971: China Television Service, the third commercial TV network in the Republic of China, begins regular programming.
1972: The Southern Cross-Island Highway, which took four-and-a-half years to build at a cost of nearly NT$500 million, is opened to traffic.
1974: People throughout the Republic of China celebrate the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses leaders gathered to pay tribute to President Chiang Kai-shek on the late leader's 90th birthday, then breaks ground for the Chung Cheng Memorial Hall to honor President Chiang.
1976: Taichung port in west central Taiwan is formally opened.
1978: The Taiwan Area Freeway, with a total length of 377 km, is fully opened to traffic on the 92nd anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1978: The Sino-Saudi Arabian Bridge over the Choshui River in central Taiwan, which was built with low-interest loans from Saudi Arabia, opens to traffic as a part of the newly completed North-South Freeway.
1979: Representatives of retired servicemen meet at the Taipei City Auditorium to mark the first Veterans Day, also marking the 25th anniversary of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen.
1981: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives J.A. Guevara Moran, the minister of agriculture and pasture of the Republic of El Salvador.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old MiG-19 pilot in the Communist Chinese air force who flew to a U.S. military base outside Seoul on Oct. 16, arrives in Taipei.
1983: Taipei's Kuantu Bridge, the first multi-arch steel bridge in East Asia, opens to traffic. The construction of the bridge, 809 meters long, took three years and cost NT$700 million to complete.
1984: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian prime minister, is shot dead while walking in the garden of her home in New Delhi. She was 67.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek presides over and addresses a mass rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang.
1996: Former Polish President Lech Walesa visits the Republic of China.
1999: A delegation from the Taiwan Roots Medical Organization leaves for a visit to four African countries to evaluate the possibility of providing medical care to one of them.
2000: Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the opposition Kuomintang says that he is continuing to solicit more support for his proposal to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
2000: A Los Angeles-bound Singapore Airlines Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet crashes while taking off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 81 of the 179 aboard, leaving 44 injured and 54 others unhurt.
2001: Participants in a civil nuclear cooperation meeting between the Republic of China and the United States agree to increase exchanges on nuclear power plant safety and to establish formal communication channels regarding the matter.
2001: Former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen, accompanied by a two-member entourage for a three-day visit in the Republic of China, calls on Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and other high ranking officials.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you will practice a benevolent government, then the people will love all above them and will die for their officers."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times: Osama bin Laden's threat disrupts U.S. presidential election.
The United Daily News: Elderly couples jointly jump to death at home for old-aged people.
The Liberty Times: Osama bin Laden's broadcast influences U.S. presidential election.

The Central Daily News: Lien Chan: Chen's diplomacy is self-ruined.
The China Post: Bin Laden says U.S. safe from 2nd 9-11 if Muslims left alone.
The Taiwan News: Bin Laden video gives warning to U.S.
The Taipei Times: Marines to boost Taipei security.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush, Kerry in Reach of Electoral Win; But Neither Has Clear Advantage In Tossup States.
President Bush and his Democratic challenger, Sen. John F. Kerry, go into the final 48 hours of the 2004 presidential campaign within easy reach of an electoral majority, but neither has a clear advantage in the remaining handful of tossup states, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TERRY FOX RUN FOR CANCER RESEARCH RAISES NEARLY NT$3 MILLION

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taipei Terry Fox Run was held Sunday, successfully raising nearly NT$3 million (US$89,820) for cancer research in Taiwan.

It was the 10th year that the Terry Fox Run was held in Taipei to commemorate the late Canadian Terry Fox, who raised cancer awareness in his country by attempting to run across Canada. The run raises funds for cancer research and prevention.
More than 4,000 people, including some 1,000 foreign nationals, took part in the run, which featured a three-kilometer and a six-kilometer run.
Participants donating NT$300 or more received a Terry Fox Run T-shirt.

Presiding over the start of the run, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who has been director of the organizing committee of the Terry Fox Charity Run Competition in Taipei for 10 years, exhorted the people of Taiwan to remember Terry Fox -- a young Canadian athlete who lost his right leg to bone cancer but tried to run across North America -- and try to emulate his courage and perseverance.

Fox, who had his leg amputated in 1976 at the age of 17, began his cross-Canada run in 1980 with a prosthetic leg, asking every Canadian to donate one Canadian dollar for cancer research. He accomplished his goal before dying of cancer in 1981.
Ma, who visited the headquarters of the Terry Fox Foundation in Toronto in August 2003, said that whenever he is distressed, he thinks about Terry Fox and regains his inner strength.

Ma said he feels very proud that the number of Taipei residents participating in the Terry Fox Run is the fifth-highest in the world, and the amount of money raised through the runs has been the seventh-highest in recent years.
Proceeds from the annual run, which started at the Taipei City Hall plaza, will be donated to the Cancer Research Foundation of Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.
The Terry Fox Run, originated in Canada in 1980, has become a worldwide event with over 1.3 million people from more than 50 countries participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Bangkok Post: Army frees most detainees, lifts curfew.
Pressure continues to mount on the government over the deaths of 79 Muslim protesters following the Oct.25 riot in NArathiwat's Tak Bai district, even as most detainees rounded up in the crackdown were released and a vurfew lifted yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Bin Laden, on Tape, Reveals Sept. 11 Motive.
Four days before the U.S.presidential election , Osama Bin Laden appeared on a videotape broadcast worldwide, describing his motives for plotting the Sept. 11 attacks and telling Americans that they can save themselves from future violence by not supporting a crackdown on his Al Qaeda network.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIVISION OF SUPPORT IN TSU AND DPP CAMPAIGNS GOOD STRATEGY: DPP WHIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui should coordinate their campaign appearances for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) for the Dec. 11 legislative elections to better cover the most constituencies, Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, DPP caucus whip at the Legislative Yuan said Sunday.

The TSU, which is made up of political followers of Lee, firmly supports the DPP in the Legislative Yuan. Therefore, said Tsai, President Chen, who duals as DPP chairman, can stump for TSU candidates if the situation and timing is suitable.
Moreover, if TSU candidates want Premier Yu Shyi-kun to campaign for them, Tsai said he was sure that Yu would be more than willing to do so.
Tsai added that the best strategy would be for former President Lee to campaign for those DPP candidates whose followers are most closely enamored with Lee.

Some TSU candidates have called for efforts to be made to more evenly distribute the share of possible votes for both the TSU and the DPP to optimize the potential number of seats for each in the legislature, to which Tsai said that this was possible, but a strategy best deployed in areas where the two parties' supporters are already spread thin.

Since the DPP is vying for a simple majority at the Legislative Yuan, the number of seats the DPP wins is much more important than the number of ballots any individual DPP candidate can garner, Tsai said.

A total of 378 candidates will compete for 176 seats in the Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 elections, with 49 other seats to be appointed by political parties in proportion with their share of votes they win in the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: EGG-THROWING WOMAN MISSES MAYOR MA

TEXT.P: The yolk was nearly on Taipei's mayor Sunday during campaigning in Panchao, Taipei County, but the woman trying to vote by pelting Ma Ying-jeou with an egg missed her mark.
Ma was in an open-air market stumping for Kuomintang (KMT) legislative candidate Lin Hung-chih when an unidentified woman tossed an egg at the mayor from behind.
Bodyguards and supporters immediately surrounded Ma and the woman was prevent by the mayor's security detail from throwing any other eggs.
Ma took the incident in stride, saying it must be a negative campaign side-effect of the competition between the KMT and the Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: 319 SHOOTING REPORT WILL BE MADE PUBLIC IN DUE TIME: HENRY LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's law enforcers will make public the entire contents of the report regarding the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and the vice president when they feel the time is right, U.S.-based forensic scientist Henry Lee said Saturday.
Lee, who was asked by the Taiwan authorities to help examine the attempted assassination site and the two bullets found there, delivered his report to the Taiwan authorities on Aug. 28.
Lee said he guesses that Taiwan investigators have yet to make the report public because they themselves have not obtained enough evidence.
"If the report is publicized, it may scare away suspects or lead to further destruction of evidence," Lee said.

Lee led a team to Taiwan in April to examine the wounds of President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu, inspect the scene of the shooting and tour the hospital where the president and the vice president were taken for medical treatment in southern Taiwan.
Lee made the remarks after delivering a speech on his life in America in Rosemead, a city near Los Angeles, Saturday.

He was asked by reporters his opinion on why the Taiwan authorities have not released the full results of his report more than two months after it was presented to Taiwan's State Public Prosecutor-General Ru Jen-fa prior to Ru's retirement in September.
Lee also said that he suggested to the Taiwan authorities that an independent investigation committee be established in Taiwan to investigate into all matters surrounding the election-eve shooting.

He added that members of the independent investigation committee should come from parties across the political spectrum in Taiwan and all the material in the report should be reviewed by completely neutral individuals before further investigations begin.

Lee reiterated that the way to crack the March 19 shooting case is to find the gun, believed to be a remodeled handgun, or the underground gunsmith where the weapon was made, or find the gunman who fired the two shots.
He said that he arrived at the scene in Tainan, southern Taiwan, April 9, almost 20 days after the shooting and, therefore, had difficulty reconstructing the scene.
As a forensic expert, Lee said his job is to reconstruct the scene and find as many clues as possible, not to crack the case.

In his report, Lee shed no new light on the case, in which little headway has been made with no major leads and no arrests after seven months. He said in the report that the president's injury to the abdomen was caused by a bullet and that the bullets retrieved were not used in regular handguns.

The most significant finding in his draft report was the special "tool marks" on a shell casing found at the scene. Lee suggested in the report that Taiwan law enforcement officers continue to aggressively search for and seize all illegal firearms in the country and "examine and compare all the guns."

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party has insinuated that the shooting was staged to win President Chen sympathy votes in the bitterly contested election. Chen beat his rival, Lien Chan of the KMT, by a slim margin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST ABORIGINAL SCHOOL TO CELEBRATE 100TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first elementary school for aboriginal people, established during the Japanese colonial period, will turn 100 in a few days.

A ceremony is scheduled to be held at Tah Pang Elementary School near Mt. Ali in Chiayi County Nov. 4 to celebrate the 100th birthday of the school established by the Japanese in 1905 to provide education to children of the Taiwanese timber workers who felled high-valued Taiwan teak to be shipped to Japan.
Most of the school was destroyed by an earthquake in 1989 and new buildings were added until 1991, according to Pu Chung-yung, the principal of the school.

Currently, the school runs six classes in six elementary school levels for 108 students. More than 90 percent of the school's students have been children of the Tsou tribe, one of the smallest groups among Taiwan's nine mountain-dwelling aboriginal tribes.
The school has strived to conserve the language of the Tsou people and their culture, which, like most of the other aboriginal tribes in Taiwan, are gradually dying out, Pu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MAINLAND TRADE CONTINUES GROWING

TEXT.P: Bilateral Taiwan-mainland trade in the first eight months of this year totaled US$39.646 billion, up by 38.5 percent over the previous year's level, according to the latest government statistics.

Statistics compiled by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) show that the figure accounts for 17.9 percent of the country's overall foreign trade for the January-August period.

During the eight-month period, Taiwan exports to mainland China hit US$29.311 billion, or 25.9 percent of the country's total outbound shipments -- a 1.7 percentage point growth over the year-earlier level. Mainland exports to Taiwan stood at US$10.335 billion, making up 9.6 percent of the country's total inbound shipments -- a 1.3 percent increase year-on-year.
Taiwan enjoyed a surplus of US$18.976 billion in trade with the mainland, up by 23.9 percent compared to the year-earlier mark.

Major items among Taiwan exports to mainland China (including Hong Kong) are electrical engineering equipment and parts, opto-electronics, machinery, steel, chemicals and man-made fibers, while prime inbound shipments from the mainland are cement, aluminum, chemicals, electrical engineering facilities and parts and machinery equipment.

Citing statistics made public by mainland customs authorities, Japan, Taiwan and South Korea were the mainland's top three trading partners in the January-August period. The United States came in fourth, followed by Germany, Malaysia, Singapore, Russia, Hong Kong and Thailand.
Except for imports from Hong Kong, which grew by 2.2. percent, those from other countries and areas all had double-digit expansion.

With an economic growth rate running at more than 9 percent per year now, mainland China is the main engine of the world economy and also a strong underpinner of international oil and commodity prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS ARGUE OVER MERITS, DRAWBACKS OF U.S. ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: The military balance of power across the Taiwan Strait will tip in China's favor next year and Taiwan will have to acquire advanced defensive weapon systems to counter this situation, Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party claimed Sunday.

Quoting a recent U.S. Pentagon report indicating that "the threat to Taiwan will become critical in the 2005 to 2010 timeframe, " Lee said this is a major reason the U.S. administration has been pressuring Taiwan to invest in missile defenses and anti-submarine weaponry, adding that the implementation of the special arms procurement program is imperative.

Under the NT$610.8 billion (US$18.28 billion) program, the Ministry of National Defense plans to buy eight diesel-powered submarines, 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six new Patriot anti-missile batteries and associated PAC-3 interceptor missiles.
Lee said that no legislator, including himself, is qualified to judge whether the cost for the defensive weapons is too high or not, since legislators are not professional arms dealers.

Speaking on the same television talk show where Lee made his remarks, Legislator Lin Yu-fang from the opposition People First Party said that he personally does not oppose the special arms procurement package, but NT$610.8 billion is an astronomically high amount.

Noting that Taiwan already has a debt of NT$11 trillion, Lin said that going further into the red because of the arms purchases and given the proposed NT$500 billion budget for the five-year national development project, citizens will have to shoulder a national debt that amounts to about NT$500,000 per person.

Leaving such massive debts as a legacy to our children and grandchildren is immoral and irresponsible, Lin said, adding that the price to be paid the United States for the arms procurements needs to be reconsidered.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL OF AGRICULTURE READY TO TURN UP THE HEAT ON RED FIRE ANT

TEXT.P: A national center for the prevention and eradication of red fire ants will be formally inaugurated Monday to coordinate efforts to wipe out the insect, according an official from the Council of Agriculture Sunday.

The center, to be headed by Yang Ping-Shih, a professor at National Taiwan University, is to be set up by the council with the help of National Taiwan University, National Chung Hsing University, National Chiayi University and National Pingtung University of Science and Technology.

Agriculture council Vice Chairman Hu Fu-hsiung said the center will monitor the spread of the ants, teach farmers how to effectively get rid of the ants and keep the government informed of the situation.

A light rating, similar to a traffic light, will be set up to show the seriousness of the ant problem in a particular location, with red indicating the discovery of the ants but no action having been taken; yellow indicating that ants are currently being exterminated; and green indicating that the ants have been eliminated, Hu said.
Yang said the center will organize presentations around the island to raise public awareness of the insect.
He predicted that the ants, which entered Taiwan on cargo ships from the United States and have been found in 20 cities and rural townships around the island, will be controlled within three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM UNIT TO BE FORMED AFTER DEC. ELECTION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A constitutional reform committee is expected to be formed after the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Secretary-General to the President Su Tseng-chang said Sunday.

Speaking at a seminar about constitutional reform, the president's chief of staff said the Presidential Office has already begun the process of consulting public opinion leaders about the ways to amend the Constitution and has collected some valuable ideas.

Yeh Jiunn-rong, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan said at the seminar that constitutional reform should address several problems such as whether the Control Yuan and Examination Yuan should be abolished, whether the government should be in the charge of the president or the premier, and whether the people's right of referendum should be listed in the Constitution.
He said constitutional reform should be done with the support of the whole country.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL ACTION URGED TO BLOCK GOVERNMENT ARMS PROCUREMENT: ACTIVISTS

TEXT.P: Scholars and social activists spoke out Sunday advocating the formation of an alliance to protest what they described as an incorrect government policy regarding military procurements.

Prominent figures from the private sector, such as poet Chan Che and Professor Chu Yun-peng, issued the call at a news conference. They urged the public to join forces with them to block the government's plan to purchase weapons from the United States with a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion).

Claiming that the government's poor policy is much more devastating than corruption and that such a situation is increasingly taking shape in Taiwan, they called on people from all walks of life to back the alliance to try to counter the government's wrongheaded policy.

They cited some countries in the Caribbean and Latin America as examples and warned that buying large amounts of weapons from foreign countries at the cost of the people's benefit will only lead to economic collapse.

The government's flip-flop on the issue of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant cost the nation's coffers NT$74 billion, they said, adding that its funding of the private Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. to build the country's first "bullet" train and its role in the privatization of Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd. also set the country back NT$27 billion and NT$65.4 billion, respectively.

Annoyed by what they called inadequate monitoring by the various opposition parties, they said that forming a vanguard social force to combat wrongheaded government policies is very necessary, especially at a time when the government is becoming the country's largest "capitalist" by embezzling official properties and funds.

They urged the Taiwan people to challenge the inept government, whose inadequate policies have made poor people poorer, but rich people richer, and called on the public to actively endorse their campaign.

Earlier the same day, an anti-war group from the academic sector protested against the government's military procurement plan in front of the Legislative Yuan by displaying a large, child's painting calling for peace.

A group leader said that they will send the painting to the United Nations in mid-November to express the Taiwan people's desire for peace and to urge the world body to play a key role in arranging a 50-year peace accord between Taiwan and mainland China.

The group leader argued that the government should not just rashly rely on the United States to determine Taiwan's future, as the recent remarks made by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell show. Taiwan must walk its own path, he said.

As the legislative steering committee is slated to screen the NT$610.8 billion special budget allocations, the fourth such meeting, group members aired their strong dissatisfaction about the development and vowed to launch an attack against legislators should they allow the budgets to clear the floor.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic prospects remain rosy despite some indications showing that the booming domestic economy is likely to abate in the coming months, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Sunday.

Taiwan's economy enjoyed a growth of 6.67 percent in the first quarter of this year and 7.68 percent in the second quarter, Ho noted, adding that the third quarter's growth rate is estimated to post more than 5 percent.

In another development, the minister said that export orders received by Taiwan in the first nine months of this year accumulated to US$155.29 billion, up 26.26 percent from the previous year's level.
In September alone, she went on, Taiwan received export orders worth US$19.5 billion, an increase of 26.61 percent year-on-year and marking a new monthly record.

The figures indicate that Taiwan's economy has been growing steadily and will continue to keep rising, Ho explained, claiming that she is confident that the annual growth rate will meet the target of 5.87 percent set by the government for this year.

A report issued by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) last week showed that Taiwan's economy in September posted a yellow-red light in the government's five-color rating system, with the composite index falling from August's 33 points to 32 points, which is close to a green light.

According to the five-color rating system designated by the CEPD, a red light indicates an overheated economy, yellow-red indicates a heating up economy, green means steady growth, yellow-blue signals sluggishness and blue points to recession.

The domestic economy flashed a fourth consecutive yellow-red light in September, which was the ninth month with a heating-up economy over the past 10 months, Ho noted. A red light rating was registered for May, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LITERATURE AND PROGRESS GO HAND-IN-HAND FOR TAIWAN: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised literature Sunday as a key force in advancing Taiwan and he urged veteran writers to help cultivate new talent to further promote the country.
Chen made the remarks at a ceremony held by Unitas Literary magazine in celebration of its 20th anniversary and its 18th annual awards for young novelists.

Calling Unitas Literary the cradle of the Taiwan people's spiritual comfort over the past 20 years, Chen said the magazine provides an important channel for local writers to express their love and concerns for the land and the environment, even in the days under the rule of a dictatorship.

The people in Taiwan have learned respect and leniency from their past experiences, Chen said, encouraging the magazine to keep on standing tall as a guidepost of "independence, freedom and openness" for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: 73 PERCENT OF TAIWAN FAMILIES HAVE A COMPUTER: CEPD

TEXT.P: About 73 percent of Taiwan people have at least one computer at home and 53 percent of them are Internet surfers, according to the results of a recent government survey.

Some 43 percent of the respondents said that they are aware of an e-government plan being promoted by the administration, while 57 percent said that they had searched for information on Web sites run by government agencies, with 53 percent of them saying that they did so to purchase train tickets, the poll results show.

Around 45 percent and 42 percent of the people surveyed said that they visited different Web sites to make an appointment at a hospital and to pay taxes, respectively, while 35 percent and 29 percent said that they did so for consultations and to look for a job.

The survey was carried out Oct. 26 by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, covering 1,094 valid questionnaires from people aged over 20. It had a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Focus narrowing as close contest nears finish line.
As the U.S. presidential campaign nearing its finish line, both candidates are focusing on the three pivotal states that they depend most: Florida, Pennsylvania and Ohio. Both President Bush and Senator John Kerry have invested tens of millions of dollars on advertising there, deployed armies of field workers and spent hundreds of hours on the stump, including visits in the race's final weekend. With the furor over a new Osama bin Laden tape filtering through the campaigns, both men crossed through Midwestern swing states on Saturday and are to appear in Florida on Sunday. In the end, the outcome is likely to be decided by what political pros call "the ground war": the effort by both parties to get every supporter to the polls on Tuesday. Although there are almost limitless ways either candidate could reach the magic number of 270 electoral votes needed to win, whoever wins two of the big three states would have an advantage that would be difficult to overcome.
Wall Street Journal: Bush, Kerry focus on terrorism.
President Bush and Sen. John Kerry charged into a sharp final round of argument Saturday over which one can best fight global terrorism, the import of their debate underscored by Osama bin Laden's sudden reappearance on tape at "a time of great consequence," in the words of the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF BEEFING UP DEFENSE CAPABILITIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan must beef up its defense capabilities to deter any military adventures from mainland China, President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday.
Addressing a rally marking the 50th anniversary of the Veterans Affairs Commission under the Executive Yuan, Chen said that the mainland has never abandoned the option of using force against Taiwan.
Beijing dared not to initiate an attack on Taiwan over the past five decades because Taiwan had sufficient defense capabilities, Chen noted.

In the face of China's growing military buildup nowadays, he added, Taiwan must beef up its defense capabilities to avert war and ensure peace across the Taiwan Strait as well as the country's and regional security.
He lashed out at the opposition camp's boycott on a special arms procurement budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) introduced by the executive branch in the Legislative Yuan.
Although legislators of various political parties can have different opinions on the matter, they should seek a consesus through rational discussions and communications, the president stressed.
It is irresponsible to ground the budget proposal by using technically the steering procedures in the legislature, he criticized.
Chen called on lawmakers across the political spectrum to put the national security and interests on the priority instead of personal and party's interests in dealing with the budget proposal.

Chen's administration has approved the special budget for the purchase of eight diesel-powered submarines, six baterries of Patriot PAC-III missiles and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States over a 15-year period starting in 2005.
The budget proposal is pending screening by the legislature.

14: 00, The Rotary International will hold a news conference at Mandarina Crown Hotel in Taipei on its assistance extended to the Orbis International.
